title: Corporate Support Rises For Minorities' Education
description: This spring Isaac Halls, 24 years old, will join thousands in taking that historic walk across the graduation platform to receive a college diploma.

title: Indonesia to Raise Oil Price to $11.70
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia (Reuters) March 31  The Indonesian Government announced that it would increase its oil price from $10.80 to $11.70 barrel, beginning tomorrow.

title: LAST PAYMENT DUE ON NIXON PROPERTY
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)President Nixon has a final mortgage payment of nearly $250,000 coming due this summer for his San Clemente, Calif., estate, and he may be facing other major personal expenses as a result of possible income tax and impeachment proceedings.

title: Demel Takes Ski Race
description: BOZEMAN, Mont., March 31 (AP)  Walter Demel, a West German, and Bjorg Lund, a Norwegian, won the final events of the North American crosscountry ski championships today. Demel took a special 22kilometer race in 1 hour 12 minutes 50 seconds. Miss Lund won a 20kilometer racein 1:12.32.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Spring Stirring Thimble Islands
description: STONY CREEK, Conn., March 26The first boatload of Thimble Islanders set out from this fishing village just east of New Haven last weeka sign of spring along the shores of Long Island Sound as sure as the first robin or the first fighting striped bass.

title: Trevino Wins by 8 Shots
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 31 For all practical purposes the Greater New Orleans open golf tournament ended today when Lee Trevino shot four birdies in the first six holes.

title: U.S. Appeals Court Begins a Program To Expedite Cases
description: An innovation to speed appeals for civil cases will take effect today in the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: Laver Wins W.C.T. Final On Coast
description: PALM DESERT, calif. March 31Rod Laver, who confesses it's harder to get properly motivated at the age of 35 with a million dollam in tennis earnings already behind him, took a long step today toward reinstating himself among the current professional leaders by winning the Kemper Desert Classic, a Green Group tournament on the World Chainpionship Tennis tour.

title: Con Ed's Growth Plan Facing Big Obstacles
description: Consolidated  Edison's hope for the future, its vast program of streamlining and modernizing its plants and equipment that the utility has long counted on to turn the company around in the nineteenseventies and nineteeneighties, is in serious trouble.

title: U.S. Economists Divided On How to Curb Inflation
description: Milton L. Friedman, the celebrated conservative economist at the University of Chicago, predicts that three or four years from now inflation in the United States will be soaring at a steady 10 to 12 per cent.

title: Books of The Times
description: Although the plot is intriguingly ramified and identification of the killer sufficiently deferred, the real suspense of Appleby's Other Story lies in its language. What will the characters say next, as their conversation ranges from the sublime to the ridiculous, all up and down the social scale from precious to demotic? Michael Innes is a mischievous English don who writes mysteries as a sort of commonplace book for his satirical fancies, and as an excuse for indulging his nostalgia for idiosyncrasy in speech, society, architecture and behavior. In his novels, it is often not only a character's life, but a way of life as well that has been ended. With diction as his principal weapon and classical analogies as his chief clues, retired Police Commissioner Appleby does what he can to delay the remorseless erosion of British mores.

title: Bridge: Wei and Kokish Teams Reach Vanderbilt Knockout Finals
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbla, March 31The Precision team led by Katherine Wet of New York clashed to day with a young quartet headed by Eric Kokish of Montreal in the final of the Vanderbilt knockout team final of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals. Both teams survived tough battles in the semifinals last night.

title: COMMUNISTS SAID TO SHELL BASE AGAIN
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 31 (UPI)  Communist longrange artillery shelled a Government base near the Cambodian border for the second day, and a relief force was held up a few miles away, military sources reported today.

title: Security Chiefs in Ulster Confer After Terrorists Step Up Raids
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 31Military and police chiefs held toplevel security talks today after a weekend of terrorist violence in Northern Ireland that claimed five lives and caused damage estimated at $20million.

title: Jazz Concert Draws a Varied Audience
description: MONTCLAIR, March 31A musical program called The Evolution of Jazz, which has been evolving for five years, primarily in schools in Bergen county, drew an audience of various ages last night to Memorial Auditorium at Montclair State College.

title: Trout Season Opens Today
description: ROSCOE, N. Y., March 31Diehard pursuers of the trout gathered today in this Sullivan County hamlet, eager to cast their first lines of the year when the New York State season opens tomorrow. The weekend's snowstorm, which left 7 inches of snow on the banks of the legendary Beaverkill and Willowemoc rivers, where flyfishing was born in the United States, is not expected to slow opening day fishing. Skies are expected to be clear with temperatures in the 40's.

title: A 2D MURDER LAID TO FREED SUSPECT
description: A man accused of murder in Scranton, Pa., who was set free when he posted $100,000 bail there, is in Essex County Jail in Newark charged with another murder.

title: Malone Paces Victory
description: PITTSBURGH, March 31The United States allstar high school basketball team scored in the last eight seconds today to defeat the Pennsylvania allstars, 7776. Moses Malone, the 6foot11inch, 210pounder front Petersburg, Va., scored with time running out before 13,000 fans at Civic Arena in the Dapper Dan Classic. Malone scored 31 points.

title: Color Your Hair Simply, or Turn It Blue  Salons Can Do It All
description: It may be called frosting, Creaking, highlighting, naturalizing, tinting or coloring. The words are euphemisms for hair dyeing, a term avoided by hairdressers. (We never like to speak of dying, misspells one hairdresser's brochure.)

title: U.S. Districting Inquiry May open Political Rift
description: ALBANY, March 31The current Federal inquiry into charges that the legislative district lines in New York City are racially unfair seems likely to produce changes in Brooklyn and the Bronx, in the opinion of some legislative specialists working on the case.

title: Spring Training: Place in Sun OldTimers and Big Business es
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 31To the 1,000 or so baseball players with invitations, it means six weeks in the sun and, maybes a job for the summer. To the local businessmen, it means that the flood of visitors is on 26 million a year in Florida alone. To the tourists themselves it's a chance Willie to watch Willie Mays and Mickey Mouse, on the same trip a.

title: GURNEY IS ACCUSED OF APARTMENT DEAL
description: MIAMI, March 31 (AP)  A former fundraiser for Senator Edward J. Gurney, Republican of Florida, has sworn under oath that Mr. Gurney once approved the exchange of Federal Housing Authority influence for a free oceanfront apartment, a newspaper quoted unidentified sources as saying last night.

title: Graduates Help Inmates in Women's Prison Program
description: BEDFORD HILLS, N. Y., March 30Mrs. Abbie Rivers, a 34yearold inmate of the state prison for women here, looked over the tables of people talking happily of life on the outside and of their plans for the future.

title: Concert
description: When two stars are in conjunction, as every astrologycolumn reader knows, auspicious things can happen. In music, the meeting of two stars does not automatically insure heavenly results, particularly when the subject is chamber music. Still, there are perfect courbinations, even in that cozy medium.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 29

title: 2 BLACK MILITANTS FLEE SAN QUENTIN
description: SAN QUENTIN, Calif., March 31 (AP)Two brothers who were serving life sentences for conspiracies to murder two Los Angeles Black Panther party leaders escaped from San Quentin Prison last night, a spokesman said.

title: Csonka, Warfiedd and Kiick to Go to W. F. L.
description: For a total of approximately $3million, three stars, of the Super Bowl champion Miami DolphinsLarry Csonka, Paul Warfield and Jim Kiickprovided the new World Football League with instant credibility yesterday by signing, threeyear contracts with the Toronto Northmen, beginning in 1975.

title: A Golan Kibbutz Fearful Of Both War and Peace
description: MEROM GOLAN, IsraeliOccupied Syria, March 27For nearly three weeks gunfire has again been the backdrop for the daily life of this border kibbutz, and its 100 or so children play above ground only during the few hours in which the danger of shelling is minimal.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Hayes Scores in Japan
description: OSAKA, Japan, March 31 (UPI)Bob Hayes of the Dallas Cowboys caught a 35yard touchdown pass today to help a team of American armed forces players rout a Japanese allstar eleven, 348.

title: Robbie Hints Legal Action
description: MIAMI, March 31 (UPI) The Miami Dolphins' princlpal owner, Joe Robbie, said tonight he refused to put $3million in cash in a bank to keep Larry Csonka, Paul Warfield and Jim Mick on the team and said he might take legal action to stop their defection to the World Football League.

title: G.O.P. IN NASSAU STILL UNDAUNTED
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., March 31 Desplte Watergate and a series of indictments right here in Nassau County, the poiverful machine of Joseph M. Margiotta shows no sign of losing its grip on the Republican party faith ful.

title: An Energy Budget
description: Looking both forward and backward, the initial report on an energy study sponsored by the Ford Foundation effectively articulates the wide range of public options and restraints that need weighing in attempting design a balanced energy budget for the nation. No policy task is more challenging.

title: Opera: Rival of Mozart
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 31 Billed as a North American premiere, the threeact opera Falstaff by Antonio Sailer was given this afternoon by the students and orchestra of the Philadelphia Musical Academy. The unknown opera timed out to be a facile and even elegant piece of writing, Mozartean without much Mozart, well worth reviving and fascinating as a specimen of opera popular in Vienna at the turn of the 18th century.

title: Kurdish deader, Facing Possible Civil War, Looks to West for Support
description: Iraq, March 29  Gen. Mustafa alBarzani, the Kurdish leader, said today that there was a strong possibility of war between the Kurds and the Iraqi Governinent and appealed for support from the West, suggesting that oil might be the reward.

title: FISHER HALL PACKED FOR A SILLS RECITAL
description: Beverly Sills's recital at Fisher Hall yesterday afternoon, with Charles Wadsworth at the piano, held few surprises except, perhaps, that by the end of the concert Miss Sills was singing spectacularly. The house was packed to the rafters, of course, for she is the city's own reigning operatic diva, and the program was just the sort one of today's leading bel canto specialists would put together.

title: Hearst Food Distribution Reported Beset by Theft
description: BERKELEY, Calif., March 31 (AP)  Randolph A. Hearst's program to distribute food to the poor to help free his kidnapped daughter was beset by internal thievery, lack of coordination and poor administration, representatives of a community coalition that monitored the food giveaway said today.

title: Solzhenitsyn Says Some Misinterpret His Ideas
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, March 31 (AP)Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn,, the exiled Russian author, said today that he had no plans now to visit the United States and was concerned that Americans did not understand his vision for the Soviet Union's future.

title: Israel Returns Body Of Sadat Stepbrother
description: TEL AVIV, March 31 (UPI) Israel has found and returned the body of the step. bripther of President Anwar elSadat of Egypt, a pilot whose plane was shot down during the 1973 Middle East war, an army spokesman disclosed today.

title: A jury Watcher Advises Mitchell's Defense on the Reactions of Panel Members
description: For the first six weeks of the conspiracy trial of former Attorney General John N. Mitchell and former Commerce Secretary Maurice. H. Stens, a man has been sitting in the spectator section of the courtroom, peering at 12 persons he has never met but whom he helped to select as jurors.

title: ELECTION FUND TO GO TO G.O P. COMMITTEE
description: NASHVILLE, March 31 (AP)  Guilford Dudley, a trustee for $3:5million of President Nixon's surplus campaign funds, said, today that he hoped to transfer the money to the Republican National Committee in two months.

title: A Possible Moon of Mercury Is Detected
description: PASADENA, Calif., March 31 An ultraviolet scanner aboard the Mariner 10 spacecraft has detected what seems to be a small moon in orbit around Mercury. It would be the first moon discovered orbiting either Venus or Mercury, the two planets between the sun and the orbit of earth.

title: R. KIRK ASKEW JR. OF DURLACRER, 70
description: R. Kirk Askew Jr., a successful art gallery director whose East Side residence became a wellknown gathering place for New York artists and intellectuals in the nineteenthirties, died Saturday, apparently of a heart attack, at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 110 East 57th Street and in East Greenville, Pa.

title: New Cattle in Feed Pens Off 20% as Profits Drop
description: HAWARDEN, Iowa, March 30 The boom is over for cattlemen. The steadily growing profits they were enjoying until a few months ago have turned to heavy losses, wiping out much of their capital and, in many instances, wiping out small Investors entirely.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, March 31 (AP)The world heavyweight champion, George Foreman, who successfully defended his boxing title here five days ago, relaxed at his hotel today, awaiting a decision from local tax authorities that would allow him to leave Venezuela.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Al Hours Given In Daylight Saving Time

title: Nixon's Gift to Archives Omitted Sensitive Files
description: WASHINGTON, March 31The prePresidential papers for which President Nixon claimed, a $576,000 tax deduction were culled to eliminate sensitive documents, even though Mr. Nixon turned the papers over to the National Archives with the specification that no unauthorized person could see them until after he left the White House.

title: The Light of History
description: BOSTON; March 31Once before in our history, in 186667, the House Judiciary Committee investigated a President with a view to possible impeachment. The study of Andrew Johnson's conduct lasted more than 10 months. Its scope was summarized in a recent Memorandum by President Nixon's Justice Department:

title: SEEN FOR EUROPE
description: GENEVA, March 31Western Europe faces the double setback this year of a considerable, slowing of its economic growth rate coupled with accelerating inflation, according to United Nations experts.

title: SCHOOLS IGNORING A BAN, LEVITT SAYS
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt charged yesterday that the Board of Education had failed to halt several illegal practices in its hiring of a private computer concern to process some payrolls, even though the Board had been warned to halt the practices 16 months ago.

title: Former Nixon Aide Disrupts Democratic Parley
description: RENO, Nev., March 31 A man who identified himself as a former member of the Committee for the Reelection of the President touched off an armtwisting, tiepulling, kicking incident at a Democratic convention here last night.

title: City Drug Agency to Offer Addicts Remedial Reading Program
description: CHICAGO March 31  Jerome Hornblass the new head of New York City's drug treatment agency, said today that his agency would provide remedial reading and ether basic educational training to thousands of adult addicts in New York treatment programs.

title: Allison Finishes First
description: HICKORY, N.C., March 31 UPI)  Bobby Allison in a Chevrolet won the Hickory 249 stock car race today. He averaged 72.197 miles an hour and finished a lap ahead of Tommy Houston, also in a Chevy.

title: Rangers Tie Leafs, 33, on Irvine Goal
The DC10 and Safety: Changes Drafted
description: The Government's system for assuring maximum safety In airline travel has proved inadequate and must be overhauled without delay, many air experts have concluded after four weeks of investigation of the crash March 3 of a DC10 jumbo jet, near Paris in which 346 persons died. Important initial measures to revitalize the accidentprevention system are already being drafted. They promise to affect all key segments of aviation, including the Federal Aviation Administration, which runs the airways and makes and enforces rules on aircraft design; the airlines, the manufacturers and the National Transportation Safety Board, which investigates accidents but has to limited a budget to maintain a staff large enough for effective actions.

title: Jones Gamble Pays Off Holzman Is'nt So Lucky
description: LANDOVER, Md., March 31 Jones gambled today and won. Red Holzman gainbled and lost.

title: Hart, Schaffner & Marx To SO 18 Clothing Stores
description: Hughes & Hatcher, Inc., a Detroitbased retail clothing chain, announced over the weekend that it had agreed to buy four groups of men's fashion stores, totaling 18 units, from Hart Schaffner & Marx, manufacturer and retailer of apparel.

title: Nadjari Momentum
description: When Governor Rockefeller followed up the key recommendation of the Knapp. Commission in 1972 by creating the office of state special prosecutor to root out corruption in New York City's criminal justice system, it was inevitable that such a superlawman post would be sniped at by political forces as well as by those in fear of investigation.

title: SOVIET ENDORSES HANOI TRUCE PLEA
description: MOSCOW, March 31The Soviet Union today endorsed North Vietnam's demand that, the United States halt violations of the ban contained in the Vietnam ceasefire agreement on shipments of armaments, munitions and other materiel into South Vietnam.

title: F.D.A. Chief Sees Rise In Prepared Food Use
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)Probably twothirds of the meals on American tables in 1980 will have been previously prepared outside the home, the head of the Food and Drug Administration said in an interview published today.

title: FLOODHIT TOWN IN BRAZIL STIRS
description: TUBARAO, Brazil, March 31 One week after raging floodwaters laid waste this farm center in southern Brazil taking hundreds of lives, the townspeople are beginning to make plans for reconstruction.

title: Kennedy Boy Out of Hospital
description: BOSTON, March 31 (AP)Edward M. Kennedy Jr., 12 years old, was released today from Children's Hospital Medical Center after the fourth in a series of treatments to prevent the recurrence of bone cancer. A hospital spokesman said the treatments and tests, which began. Friday, revealed no evidence of any recurrence or spread of the disease.

title: W.F.L. Gets 3 Dolphins
description: Larry Csonka, Jim Kiick and Paul Warfield of the Miami Dolphins signed threeyear contracts totaling $3million yesterday with the Toronto Northmen of the new World Football League. Details on Page 43.

title: Philipine Moslem Army: Separate Bands With Single Aim of Independence
description: JOLO, the PhilippinesDeployed in the jungled volcanic hills of the southern Philippines  on the sprawling island of Mindanao and the smaller green necklace of the Sulu chain  is a force of insurgents dedicated to the establishment of an independent Moslem nation.

title: FESTIVE CONCERT IS TRIBUTE TO IVES
description: This year marks the 100th anniversary of the birth of Charles Ives (on Oct. 20), and at Tully Hall on Saturday night the Dessoff Choirs presented festive concert entitled Ives: The New England Context.

description: Consolidated Edison's hope for the future, its vast program of streamlining, and modernizing its plants and equipment that the utility has long counted on to turn the company around in the nineteenseventies and nineteeneighties, is in serious trouble.

description: April 1, 1974

title: Man Slain With Knife He Used in Assault
description: An elderly man wrested a sixinch steak knife from an alleged thief who had accosted him on a Bronx street last evening and then fatally stabbed his assailant as they grappled, the police reported.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: NAIVE Naive painters used to be called primitive painters, Sunday painters, probably, offduty painters. They are often those who came to painting, or at least to recognition late in life (Grandma Moses, to cite one), and their themes often reflect country virtues and traditions.

title: Israelis and Syrians Exchange Fire on Golan for the 20th Day
description: TEL AVIV, March 31 (Reuters)Israeli and Syrian forces exchanged firece artillery, tank rocket fire for several hours on the Golan Heights today, a military spokesman here reported.

title: Williams Says He Favors Impeachment Proceedings
description: United States Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. said yesterday the while he had originally called for President Nixon to resign, he now felt that the impeachment inquiry being conducted by the House and the possibility of a trial of the President by the Senate represented the full constitutional applications of this situation.

title: Boxed In by Watergate
description: WASHINGTON  Commenting on Senator James L. Buckley's proposal that Richard M. Nixon resign the Presidency, Speaker Carl Albert said, with a smile as it was reported, I'd like to leave it up to the Republicans to argue that thing out.

title: Callas Recital Canceled
description: The joint recital of Maria Callas and Giuseppe di Stefano scheduled for tomorrow evening at Carnegie Hall has been canceled because of Mr. di Stefano's indisposition. No makeup concert has been scheduled. Ticket holders may exchange their tickets for the pair's April 15 concert or obtain refunds at the box office.

title: 2 Lead Moscow, Trade Drive in N.Y.
description: In its heyday the Amtorg Trading Corporation, the Soviet Government's buying and selling agency in New York, occupied all nine floors in a Madison Avenue office building. At the height of the cold war in the nineteenfifties it was down to one floor in a loft building in the garment district. Now the upsurge in EastWest trade finds Amtorg operating from a twofloor headquarters in midtown.

title: $700Million More Aid to Israel Likely
description: WASHINGTON, March 31President Nixon is expected to decide shortly that the United States will give Israel $700million in additional military aid, Administration sources said today.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Malone Paces Victory
description: PITTBURGH, March 31The United States allstar high school basketball team scored in the last eight seconds today to defeat the Pennsylvania allstars, 7776. The 6foot11inch, 210pounder from Petersburg, Va., scored with time running out before 13,000 fans at Civic Arena in the Dapper Dan Classic. Malone scored 31 points.

title: I.T.T. Ruling Revoked, I.R.S. Races to Collect Millions
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 The Internal Revenue Service is now working against time to collect millions of dollars in capitalgains taxes lost as a result of a ruling given to the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation in October, 1969, but revoked by the service three weeks ago.

title: WWDJ Drops Its Rock Format In Shift to Religious Programing
description: Bergen County's only commercial radio station, WWDJ, is switching its format today from rock n roll to nearly all religious programing.

title: McGovern Decides to Manage His Own Television Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, March 31Senator George McGovern has quietly broken his long and close political partnership with Charles Guggenheim, the television consultant and film maker, to become his own media adviser in his reelection campaign this year.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News SuMmary and index, Page 33

title: Bullets Top Knicks To Tie Series, 11
description: LANDOVER, Md., March 31Elvin Hayes continued his offensive assault on the New York Knicks today and this time he got enough help from Phil Chenier to propel the Capital Bullets to a runaway 9987 victory before a jubilant crowd of 16,522 at Capital Centre. A national television audience also saw Chenier score 35 points and Hayes 34 for a combined total of 69, only 18 fewer than 10 Knicks could manage.

title: Energy Office Investigators Seek Evidence of Fuel Overcharging by Big Oil Companies
description: WASHINGTON, March 31Price investigators of the Federal Energy Office disclosed this weekend that they were in the final, stages of an inquiry into alleged overcharging for gasoline and other petroleum products by some major oil companies.

title: Mrs. King Keeps Composure, Defeats Chris Evert.
description: Chris Evert believes Mrs. Billie Jean King, at the age of 30, finally is settling down.

title: Jones Gamble Pays Off; Holzman Isn't So Lucky
description: LANDOVER, Md., Mach 31 K. C. Jones gambled today and won. Red Holzman gambled and lost.

title: WILSON SAYS RISE IN SOCIAL SECURITY WON'T HELP AGED
description: Governor Wilson said yesterday that the nation's poorest] old people would not get any help from a 7 per cent increase in Social Security benefits that take effect today.

title: Miss Chamorro, Richard Taylor Bow in Traviata at City Opera
description: Both the Violetta and the Alfredo were making their debuts yesterday afternoon at the New York City Opera's La Traviate, and both could prove creditable additions to the company.

title: Venders Say Aluminum Penny Would Cause Machines to Jam
description: WASHINGTON, Match 31A request by Treasury Secretary George P. Shultz for authority to produce pennies Made from aluminum rather then copper encountered strong opposition in Congressional hearings last week.

title: KISSINGER CITES VIETNAM PLEDGE
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)Secretary of State Kissinger says that by signing the Paris agreement to end the Vietnam war the United States committed itself, politically and morally, to giving longterm military and economic aid to South Vietnam.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: News Summary and Index MONDAY, APRIL 1, 1974
description: The Soviet Union joined North Vietnam's demand that the United States halt violations of the section of the Vietnam ceasefire agreement that banned shipments of armaments, munitions and other matriel into. South Vietnam. The Soviet position, issued by Tass, the Soviet press agency, was the sharpest attack on the United States on the Vietnam issue in many months. [1:3.]

title: U. S. Officials Issue Appeal in Mexico On Missing Cansul
description: HERMOSILLO, Mexico, March 31  United States officials and the Mexican police appealed to the public today for information on the whereabouts of a missing American diplomat and the identity of the men who apparently kidnapped him.

title: The Linens Are Smaller, But Cost More Anyhow
description: Sheets and towels aren't what they used to be. In some cases, they're shrinking in size; in most cases, they're soaring in price.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Citizens Housing and Planning Council of New York, a leading civic group, urged yesterday the continuation of vacancy decontrol, which mandates the removal apartments from rent control and rentstabilization programs when their current tenants move out.

title: Stockton Defeats Hrebec In Tennis Final at Atlanta
description: ATLANTA, March 31 (AP) Dick Stockton won a tournament, today for the first time in two years on the World Championship Tennis tour. He defeated Jiri Hrebec, 62, 60.

title: Philadelphia Art Unit Has Last Laugh
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 30They laughed in this staid city when the I.C.A. was hatched, a brash little outfit that aimed to put Philadelphia in touch with advanced developments in the arts.

title: 441 Shot Captures Santa Anita Derby
description: ARCADIA Calif., March 31 Kenneth Opstein's Destreyet, a 441 shot, scored the biggest upset in Santa Anita Derby history today in defeating seven other 3yearolds.

title: BEAME REMAINED ON TOP OF TALKS
description: For Mayor Beanie, the announcement of a transit settlement last night took on something like the festive air of a celebration. It was also the culmination, for him, of a long day of close contact with negotiators that began when Mr. Beanie moved into a fiveroom suite of rooms at the Americana Hotel with his own advisers to keep on top of things.

title: Kissingers in Seclusion in Acapulco
description: ACAPULCO, Mexico, March 31It is the peak tourist season in Acapulco, with thousands of vacationing Americans enjoying the 88degree weather.

title: NIXON NAMES UNIT TO HELP VETERANS
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., March 31President Nixon announced in a 12minute radio broadcast today that he was creating committee to coordinate Federal programs designed to aid veterans.

title: WWDJ Shifts Format To Religious Programing
description: WWDJ, the only commercial radio station, in Bergen County, N. J., is switching its format today from rock 'n' roll to nearly all religious programming.

title: CAMBODIA DISSOLVES HER RULING COUNCIL
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 31 (Reuters)President Lori Nol tonight dissolved Cambodia's Supreme State Council, an emergency body with sweeping powers, and three ministers immediately resigned in pretest.

title: Thgeni Helps Italy Take 2d in. Skiing
description: RENO, March 31 (AP)Gustavo Thoeni of Italy raced to his fourth victory In the Nations' world series of skiling today, winning the giant slalom just before bad weather at Mount Rose forced cancellation of the women's giant slalom. Thoeni's victory, worth 16 points, helped vault the Italian team into second place in the final standings of the International Ski Federationseries.

title: Rigidly Moslem Saudi Arabia Relaxes a Bit
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, March 31This inland capital of Saudi Arabia, long isolated and sternly opposed to Western ways, is modernizing its outlook toward foreigners and relaxing its social taboos.

title: CRITERIA SOUGHT IN BRAIN SURGERY
description: WASHINGTON, March 31The National Institute of Mental Health has called for strict criteria for psychosurgery that would probably rule out most of these controversial brain operations for at least the next several years.

title: Fred Freed, N.B.C. Producer Of Prize Documentaries, Dead
description: Fred Freed, executive producer and writer of documentary news programs for the National Broadcasting Company television network, who won many awards for his shows, was found dead yesterday at his home, 1170 Fifth Avenue. His age was 53.

title: U.S. Stockpile Sale On Target for Year
description: WASHINGTON, March 31The Government is on target in its plan to sell more than $1.5billion worth of materials from the national strategic stockpile in the present fiscal year, but achieving a somewhat lower target in the new fiscal year may prove more difficult.

title: INTEREST RATES NEAR PEAK LEVELS
description: As the second quarter of the year opens, the credit and money markets are dealing with lofty interest ratesand these are bumping against some record levels posted last fall. The interest  rate logs, for example, include such items as: AArated utility bonds, 8.75 per cent, up 12 basis points in the most recent business week; threemonth Treasury bills, 8.55 per cent, as of last Thursday, up 44 basis points from the preceding Thursday; Federal funds, quoted in the 10 per cent area, and the prime rate for the most creditworthy corporate borrowers, 91 to 91 per cent.

title: London: Victoria and Albert Chief Clears the Attic
description: LONDON, March 26To visualize the Victoria and Albert Museum, think of turnofthecentury Britain as a tourist hauling home alabasters, bits of temple, screens, costumes, tongs, daggers, gongs and every other imaginable object. The Victoria and Albert is Britain's attic. It has six miles of galleries, an office that will give an opinion about Aunt Augusta's Dresden dogs, a tearoom, lectures and the devotion of a whole middleclass world that troops through as children and retirees, singly, when old.

title: Measuring Mercury
description: These past few days scientists have received not only their first clear closeup pictures of Mercury but also detailed measurements of the planet's unexpected magnetic field as well as of its bizarre and tenuous atmosphere.

title: Red Smith
description: There are 290 nominees for the 100th Kentucky Derby, and as far as their owners are concerned there is no reason why 290 horses should not go to the post. On the basis of form displayed by the 3yearolds up to now, any one of the 290 is capable of beating the other 289 on any given Saturday and especially on Saturday, May 4. To be sure, the cost of starting in the Derby has been raised from $4,100 to $7,600 but with 13 starters, which was the size of Secretariat's field last year, victory would be worth $199,000. The price, in short, is right.

title: SOVIET ENDORSES HANOI TRUCE PLEA
description: MOSCOW, March 31The Soviet Union today endorsed North Vietnam's demand that the United States halt violations of the ban contained in the Vietnam ceasefire agreement on, shipments of armaments, munitions and other materitel into South Vietnam.

title: Personal Finance: CreditCard Setoffs
description: Creditcard setoffs, in which a bank that has issued creditcard privileges deducts money from a person's checking or savings account to pay delinquent charges on creditcard billings, have come under court scrutiny. In one case, the California Court of Appeals has ruled that a basic state banking law is unconstitutional in that it permitted setoffs. The case has been appealed to the California Supreme Court.

title: N.Y.A.C. Crew Victor
15 Hurt as Bus Overturns
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 31 (UPI)Fifteen persons were in the hospital today, one in serious condition, after a bus carrying shoppers skidded on a snowcovered highway, spun around and landed on its side in a ditch, the state police said. Nineteen other persons were treated and released at Mountain View Hospital following the accident last night.

title: New Wilson offered
description: Quietly but nonetheless resolutely, Governor Wilson is trying to bury three images that were no problem, and maybe even an asset, as long as he was Lieutenant Governor and a virtual appendage of Nelson Rockefeller but that could haunt him now as he tries on his own to run for a full term as Governor.

title: Syrian TalkFight'?
description: Yesterday's apparent escalation of the war of attrition between Syrian and Israeli forces contrasts ominously with the hopes for disengagement on the Golan Heights voiced by Secretary of State Kissinger Saturday and echoed in Cairo.

title: U.S. Economists Divided On How to Curb Inflation
description: Milton L. Friedman, the celebrated conservative economist at, the University of Chicago, predicts that three or four years from now infladon in the United States will be soaring at a steady 10 to 12 per cent.

title: Bucks Triumph, 10990; Lead Lakers in Series, 20
description: MILWAUKEE, March 31 (AP)  The old pro, Oscar Robertson, showing flashes of his glory days, sparked a thirdquarter surge that carried the Milwaukee Bucks to a 109.90 National Basketball Association playoff victory over the Los Angeles lakers tonight.

description: Governor Wilson said yesterday that the nation's poorest old people would not get any help from a 7 per cent increase in Social Security benefits that takes effect today.

description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 31 (AP)Former Gov. Orval E. Faubus of Arkansas announced yesterday that he would seek the governorship again this year. The 64yearold Democrat was Governor from 1955 to 1966.

description: HAWARDEN, Iowa, March 30 The boom is over for cattlemen. The steadily growing profits they were enjoying until a few months ago have turned to heavy losses, wiping out much of their capital and, in many instances, wiping out small investors entirely.

title: Bitter Local School Dispute Reflects Citywide Concerns
description: What Community School Board 6 in upper Manhattan is contending is that, in effect, it has in order to preserve integration.

title: QUOTA HIRING SET BY JACKSON, MISS.
description: JACKSON, Miss., March 30In two important actions that could speed the elimination of job discrimination in the South, the city of Jackson, has agreed after long negotiation to grant hiring preference, to blacks and the highest Federal court in lower Dixie has come within a legal hair of setting blackwhite hiring goals, for the Mis sissippi Highway Patrol.

title: DONALD TANSILL, TEXTILES LEADER
description: Donald B. Tansill, who retired in 1970 as president of IM. Lowenstein & Sons, Inc., textile manufacturer, died Saturday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 923 Fifth Avenup.

title: About New York
description: Last Dec. 31, Carmen, who Is 10 years old, was taken to Bellevue Hospital. She was frightened and in pain, and a doctor found that she had been repeatedly raped and abused. Her brother, Carmen said, had attacked her.

title: NIXON NAMES UNIT TO HELP VETERANS
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., March 31President Nixon announced in a 12minute radio broadcast today that he was creating a committee to coordinate Federal programs designed to aid veterans.

title: TRANSIT PACT IS REACHED, AVERTING A STRIKE HERE; 35C FARE SAFE UNTIL FALL
description: The two transit unions and the Transit Authority reached agreement on a new twoyear contract last night, averting a strike threatened for today by 37,000 bus, and subway workers.

title: Dr. Schwartz, Jay Pasachoff Married Here
description: Dr. Naomi Schwartz was married here yesterday noon to Dr. Jay M. Pasachoff, director of the Hopkins Observatory at Williams College and chairman of the astronomy department there. Rabbi Emanuel Rackman performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Synagogue.

title: Newark Plans Fare Cat On Part of Subway Line
description: NEWARK, March 31 (AP) In an experiment to gain riders, the Newark subway will reduce the fare from Penn Station to Broad Street from 40 cents to 10 cents during the morning rush hour and from Broad Street to Penn Station in the evening.

title: Character
description: Deepseated in every individual is the desire to be held in high esteem by his fellowmen. What appeals to our fellows is our characterour honesty, our industriousness, our considerateness, the life we live, the way we tackle problems. Men see more of us than we like to admit. Building character a lifelong process in which the foundations are laid in our youth.

title: Boyd Smear
description: The appointment to the powerful post of United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York has become an unseemly battleground of political huggermugger. Second only in importance to the Southern District (Manhattan, the Bronx, Westchester and eight upstate counties), the Eastern District (Brooklyn, Queens, Staten Island, Nassau and Suffolk) covers counties which local governance occasionally resembles the fields of Runnymede before the barons laid down the law.

title: Compromise Expected On Goodyear Hiring
description: A compromise on a controversy involving the disclosure of equalopportunity policy and information on hiring of minorities appears likely today in an expected joint statement by the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and the Interfaith Center on Corporate Responsibility. The statement is to be released at Goodyear's annual meeting this morning in Akron.

title: DEMOCRATIC WOMEN END CAPITAL PARLEY
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)Democratic women laid the groundwork today in an effort to make the party more seriously attuned to women seeking elective offices on local and national levels.

title: Weekly List of Mutual Funds
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: Carolina Panel Weighs Stable Fire Convictions
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., March 31 The North Carolina Board of Paroles is expected to decide soon whether to recommend that Gov. James Holshouser Jr. commute the, prison sentences of three black men convicted in 1972 of burning a Charlotte riding stable.

title: Major Bills in Congress
description: March 31, 1974

title: Advertising: VoiceOver Stars
description: Sure it's Orson Welles doing the voice over for the Eastrent's TV commercials, Burgess Meredith for United's, and Lee J. Cobb for Pan Am's. But did you recognize. Gene Bury's voice, behind the Miller's bear spot41 and Richard Kiley's behind Standard Oil's?

title: Yanks Beat Mets on Hit By Nettles
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. March 31  Just as they'll share Shea Stadium this season, the Yankees and the Mets shared Fort Lauderdale. Stadium today. The teams don't figure to share a World Series, too, but this game was played in a miniWorld Series atmosphere.

title: Abourezk Says A.E.C. Hinders Development of Solar Power
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI)  Senator James G. Abourezk said today that the Atomic Energy Commission was apparently withholding evidence that solar energy can be developed far more quickly and cheaply than previously believed.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: WAYNE, March 31Two of the fastest blades in: tie East belong, to a pair of 19yearold sophomore fencers at William Paterson College. They are Iza Farkas, a coed from New Brunswick, and Paul Martino, a business major from Newark.

title: Louisiana Officials Seek to Halt Dumping by du Pont in the Gulf
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 31The political leadership of Loulsiana has risen en masse to try to stop E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. from dumping chemical wastes manufactured In West Virginia into the Gull of Mexico.

title: CHAPIN TRIAL OPENS IN U.S. COURT TODAY
description: WASHINGTON, March 31Dwight L. Chapin, President Nixon's former appointments secretary, is scheduled to go on trial in United States District Court here tomorrow on charges of lying to a Federal grand jury that was investigating political spying and sabotage during the 1972 Presidential campaign.

title: The Screen:A Social Satire From Brazil at Modern Art Where Is Daniel Vax ?'
description: Arnaldo Jabor's Brazilian film, "All Nudity Shall Be Punished" (Todo Nudez Sera Castigado), is an exuberant, sometimes slapstick social satire about a rich, self-absorbed, paunchy businessman named Herculano, whose wife has just died, leaving him so despondent he sits all day and night in his underwear, weeping over his fate.This gives a great deal of worry to his ancient maiden aunts and especially to his brother. It interrupts their television viewing, besides which Herculano is their meal ticket. Herculano's 18-year-old son so identifies with his dead mother that, after considering a joint suicide pact with his father, he has sworn him to celibacy for the rest of his life. Clearly, here is a family with problems.For much of the time "All Nudity Shall Be Punished" exaggerates and intensifies those problems for very funny and deadly serious effect, especially when Herculano falls madly in love with a whore who makes the one played by Melini Mercouri in "Never on Sunday" seem underfed and mean-spirited. Herculano simply must marry her, not only because she demands it but because he requires it. He has hangups."All Nudity Shall Be Punished" is a most curious and interesting film. Even when it pulls its punches, you are aware of the wit and the passion of the man who made it. The film was shown yesterday at the Museum of Modern Art in the "New Directors/New Films" series, sponsored in association with the Film Society of Lincoln Center. It will be shown again in the museum's auditorium today at 6 P.M.Although the film wouldn't seem to have an obvious political purpose, it's difficult not to associate some of the butts of Mr. Jabor's satire with right-wing military regimes that have been all-powerful in Brazil.It isn't just that the society that Herculano inhabits is inhibited by the past, but that his life and feelings are constantly bent in various directions to deny the truth around him. This is dangerous business, as is a dictatorship that denies a nation's needs. When Herculano finally does marry the whore, beautifully played by an actress named Darlene Gloria, the results are catastrophic.Mr. Jabor's screenplay is based on a play by Nelson Rodrigues, but there is nothing in his direction of the film to suggest its theatrical origins.It is a tumultuous movie, handsomely photographed and set in locations in and around Rio de Janeiro. They do almost as much as the screenplay and the acting to suggest that peculiar mixture of sensuality and repression that marks so much Brazilian life. Herculano's bedroom, where we first see him on his bed of tears and sweat, looks like the inside of an old mahagony armoire, which is no place to live.

title: Nixon's Gift to Archives Omitted Sensitive Files
description: WASHINGTON, March 31The prePresidential papers for which President Nixon claimed a $576,000 tax deduction were culled to, eliminate sensitive documents, even though Mr. Nixon turned the papers over to the National Archives with the specification that no unauthorized person could see them until after he left the White House.

title: Quasar's Light Indicates It's Old, Exploding Galaxy
description: PASADENA, Calif., March 31Analysis of light from the diffuse halo around the nearest quasar indicates that, it consists of a normal and rather ancient galaxy whose core is undergoing a series of catastrophic explosions, according to astronomers of the Hale Observatories here.

title: Stage: My Fat Friend From B
description: Charles Laurence's comedy My Fat Friend, which opened at the Brooks Atkinson Theater last night, has no pretensions, nor any right to them. It is a scatterbrained anecdote about a fat girl who achieves thinness to get her manand then ... but although the outcome predictable enough, it would be unfair to spell it out.

title: A Possible Moon of Mercury Is Detected
description: PASADENA, Calif., March 31 An ultraviolet scanner aboard the Mariner 10 spacecraft has detected what seems to be a small moon in orbit around Mercury. It would be the first moon discovered orbiting either Venus or Mercury, the two planets between the sun and the orbit of earth.

title: Boat Sinks With 7 Aboard; Searchers Find 3 Bodies
description: A 25foot cabin cruiser carrying seven persons on a fishing trip sank in the Atlantic Ocean three miles off Cape May Inlet at midday Saturday in heavy seas and gusting winds. By late yesterday afternoon three bodies had been recovered and the Coast Guard was continuing its search.

title: Quiet Union President Ellis Van Riper
description: The man who must sell the transit settlement to bus and subway workers is quiet, introspective Ellis Van Riper, President since Jaan. 1 of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union and the direct opposite of the late Michael J. Quill, the flamboyant and showy labor leader who shut down the subway system in 1966.

title: Springer Spaniel Follows His Grandsire Is Named Best at Chicago
description: CHICAGO, March 31Just seven years after his grandsire, Ch. Salilyn's Aristocrat, was best in show at the. International Kennel Club fixture in the Amphitheater, Ch. Salilyn's Classic repeated the feat. Tonight, he was chosen from a field of. 3,581 for the top prize by Mrs. Anne Rogers Clark. A crowd of 18,961 watched, giving the twoday event a total of 34,519 spectators.

title: For Regular Customers and. Diplonomics
description: WASHINGTONHooray for the little girls who have tossed their caps over the wall of sex discrimination In Little League baseball. In time, we can expect to see some Jacqueline Robinson make it on her merits into the big leagues, taking pride in being a beanball target rather than a sex object.

description: To the Editor:

title: Stella Wright Project Is Closing
description: NEWARKOliver Todd threw a card down on the table in the middle of his cluttered livsing room as he sat playing ponk with a neighbor in the Stella Wright housing project.

title: Her Way of Making Soup: Look Back and Remember
description: There was no difficulty telling where the contest was. All you had, to do was follow the smell of chicken soup.

title: Pope Paul, Well Again, Gives Crowd Blessing
description: ROME, March 31 (AP)Pope Paul VI, looking fully recovered from what Vatican sources said was a recurrence of flu, addressed a crowd of 5,000 gathered in St. Peter's Square to receive his noon blessing today.

title: W.F.L. Gets 3 Dolphins
description: Larry Csonka, Jim Kiick and Paul Warfield of the Miami Dolphins signed threeyear contracts totaling $3million yesterday with the Toronto Northmen of the new World Football League. Details on Page 43.

title: PROTESTS EBBING ON SOLZHENJTSYN
description: MOSCOW, March 31  De spite the initial shock in the West over the forced exile of Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the Soviet leadership has been successful in ridding itself of tin country's most celebrated dissenter without serious policy repercussions. After the expulsion six weeks ago, protests were raised by Western intellectuals and even some Government figures. But the Solzhenitsyn affair has not become a point of contention in any important EastWest negotiations, or in discussions on the issues of human rights or freer flow of ideas between East and West.

title: New State Rule Will Cut Park Camping by 25%
description: New Jersey's growing number of campers may have to take a tuck in their summer plans. According to Olin White, chief of operations for the New Jersey Bureau of Parks, the number of persons who will be allowed to occupy a single campsite has been reduced from eight to six, one of whom has to be at least 18 years of age.

title: Byrd's Bad Day
description: Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, the assistant majority leader, is probably the wiliest parliamentary tactician and votecounter to emerge in the Senate since Lyndon B. Johnson gave up the leadership. If he chooses to make a public fight on an issue, it is rare for him to be on the losing side. Thus, the Senate vote to require the proposed Committee on the Budget to do all its work in open sessions was a small political event as well as a symbolic triumph for the cause.of open government.

title: Underground Inflation...
description: Federal default in the war against inflation has pushed New York City a step closer to insolvency. The costly wage package that purchased labor peace on the municipal transit system was made inescapable by the insensate rush of Administration and Congress to junk wageprice controls while living costs race uphill. Even if the city and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority had elected to take a devastating strike, the chances of lowering the settlement price would have been microscopic.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: NoFault Law Gets First Challenge

title: Times Employe Killed
description: John J. Doherty, an airconditioning engineer for The New York Times, was killed yesterday in a motorcycle accident in the rear of his home at 4570 Manhattan College Parkway, the Bronx. He was 42 years old. Surviving are his wife, Barbara: three sons, John 16, Charles 13 and Brian 12, and three daughters, Barbara, 14, Eileen 10 and Janet 7. Also surviving are his mother, Mrs. Nell Doherty, and three brothers and three sisters.

title: PORT BOND LIMIT IS JERSEY TARGET
description: TRENTON, April 1A legislative repeal of a 1962 bond covenant that precludes the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey from any involvement in mass transit projects that may lose money won initial and overwhelming approval herel today in the New Jersey Assembly.

The University of California, Los Angeles, star center who won the Associated Press college basketball playeroftheyear award the last two seasons finished second in this year's ballotting released yesterday, to David Thompson of North Carolina State, the national champion.

title: Judge Backs Publishing of C.I.A. Book If 27 of 339 Sought Deletions Are Made
description: WASHINGTON, April 1A judge has ruled that a controversial manuscript about the Central Intelligence Agency may be published if the authors and publisher delete 27 items. The Government had demanded 339 deletions.

title: SubSaharan Famine Clouds Tribe's Future
description: DORI, Upper VoltaA ragged line of men was stretched beneath a brutal sun for a quarter of a mile, alongside a brown mud wall and several poorly stocked market stalls made of desert palm fronds atop gnarled wooden poles.

description: TULSA, Okla., April 1 (AP)Petroleum refining capacity last year increased at its greatest rate in at least 10 years. The Oil and Gas Journal said today.

title: MARY EMERY
description: Mary Emery, a linotype operator at The New York Times from 1936 until her retirement in 1972, died Sunday at the Union Printers Home in Colorado Springs. She was 72 years old.

title: Robert W. Brown, Editor, Dies; Georgian Won Pulitzer in 1955
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 1 (AP)  Robert Woodrow Brown, managing editor of The Augusta Chronicle since 1968 and a Pulitzer Prize winner, died today at his home. His age was 62.

title: U.S FINDS RIGHTS VIOLATED BY LINES OF DISTRICTS HERE
description: WASHINGTON, April 1The Justice Department announced today that the composition of number of state legislative districts in Manhattan and Brooklyn and one Brooklyn Congressional district violated the Voting Rights Act of 1970 The district lines will have to be redrawn to eliminate discrimination before elections can be held there, the department said.

title: Gold Dust Stolen in Quebec
description: MALARCTIC, Quebec, April 1 (Reuters)Three hooded men stole 3,000 ounces of gold dust from a office of Canflo Mines, Ltd., near this northwestern Quebec community, a spokesman for the company said today.

title: DISTRICT 26 GETS NEW BUDGET PACT
description: An agreement on measures to meet a projected $635,000 budget deficit in School District 26 in northeast Queens was approved last night by the local board despite the board's dissatisfaction with the accord negotiated over the weekend with representatives of the central Board of Education.

description: WASHINGTON, April 1Congressional staff investigators have completed their examination of President Nixon's tax returns, for the years 1969 through 1972, but it was not clear today just how soon the public would learn what they found.

title: Schedules Still Down 23.5% From 1973
description: DETROIT, April 1American automobile plants are scheduled to build approximately 2,069,000 cars in the second quarter, down 23.5 per cent from a year ago but up from the first quarter's production.

title: WILLIAM F. GRIFFIN
description: William F. Griffin, who retired in 1972 as a printer at Tile New York Times, died Sunday at the age of 68. He lived at 3024 Kingsbridge Avenue, the Bronx.

title: 1980 Olympics Bids Closed
description: LAUSANNE Switzerland, April 1 (AP)Moscow and Los Angeles were confirmed today as the only official candidates to host the 1980 Olympic games, Bidders for the Winter Olympics are Chamonix, France; Lake Placid, N. Y., and VancouverGaribaldi, Canada, the International Olympic Committee announced. The deadline for submitting candidates expired midnight Sunday. The I.O.C.'s final vote is scheduled to be taken on Oct. 23.

description: The winning of costofliving escalator clauses by two transit unions in their new contracts with the Transit Authority Sunday night marked a breakthrough for major public unions here.

title: Bridge:

description: EAST ORANGE, April 1The women fought valiantly, but it was rather onesided. That was the general conclusion after the Ms. vs. Mr. tennis tournament at Upsala Collega last weekend pairing some of the leading men and women players in the Eastern area.

description: PARIS, April 1  International bankers said today that London, with its high interest rates and currency guarantees, ranks high among oil sheiks as a place to invest excess funds, at least over the short term.

description: The price of men's sportsWearcurrently the bestselling category of male apparelwill rise at least 10 per cent by next fall or even sooner, retailers said yesterday.

description: The number of divorced men in middie and upper economic brackets who evade support of their children, is truly scandalous, according to Rosemary Gunning, a member of the New York State Assembly.

title: HOUSING PROGRAM DISPUTED BY G.A.O.
description: WASHINGTON, April 1The General Accounting Office is sharply critical of experiments by the, Nixon Administration in housing allowances and has recommended a threeyear delay in implementing such a program nationally.

title: Trot rivers Trial Is Told
description: Forrest Gerry Jr. told a betting partner last summer that he had paid off the drivers in cash, a Government witness testified yesterday In the sportsbribery trial of 13 harness drivers.

title: Argentine Prosecutor Freed
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 1 (AP)  A Marxist guerilla group named the People's Revolutionary Army has released a military prosecutor unharmed after kidnapping him Friday, police sources here said today. The prosecutor, Juan A. Rivero, is in charge of a case against an. Argentine Army private who was involved in an abortive attempt by the guerrilla group to seize the army's medical corps headquarters last September.

title: Stage: La Mama Variety
description: One sometimes gets so angry over those illinformed and premature obituary notices on the theater by people who would scarcely recognize a theater if they fell into one on a foggy night. Last Saturday I spent an eveninga fairly typical eveningat La Mama, which remains one of the hotbeds of theatrical dissent in the civilized world. (And such hotbeds in the uncivilized world are regrettably, both rarer and colder).

title: BASF Wyandotte Expands
description: The BASF Wyandotte Corporation announced yesterday that it would spend more than $1million on a plant to make butanediol, a chemical intermediate, at its facilities at Geismar, La. Butanediol is used in the production of urethane polymers, engineering plastics, plasticizers and coatings.

description: BASKETBALL

title: Yanks Hear Owner Talk, Beat Mets
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April  the first time since his group purchased the Yankees their principal owner, George Steinbrenner, held a meeting with all his players tonight and prompted applause froth them with a 15minute talk.

title: DR JOHN R. OLIVE, 59 BIOLOGICALSCIENTIST
description: Dr. Olive was born in Richmond, Ohio, and received his doctorate in zoology from Ohio State. University in 1949. He was an instructor at that institution and a professor at Colorado State University before joining the institute staff in 1959 as deputy executive director.

title: Prices on Amex Show a Decline For the 12th Session in a Row
description: Tying the record for consecutive market declines, set in January of last year, prices on the American Stock Exchange fell for the 12th straight session yesterday. Prices also dedined in the overthecounter market.

title: Walking on New York's Water
description: Perhaps the most interesting advance in architecture and urban design in this city is that we are learning to walk, as it were, on water. We are building entirely new neighborhoods on concrete shelves over the East River and over the Hudson and on landfill all around the perimeter of Manhattan Island. Having gone about as far up as anybody in his right mind would wish to go, we are beginning to expand horizontally.

title: S.E.C. Official Cites Pressures To Avoid Embarrassing Nixon
description: A Securities and Exchange Commission official testified yesterday at the MitchellStans trial that he had been under considerable pressure from his superiors around the time of the 1972 election to avoid doing anything that would be politically embarrassing to President Nixon.

title: U.S. and Mexicans Admit Confusion in Case of Consul
description: HERMOSILLO, Mexico, April 1United States and Mexican officials admitted today that they were bewildered by the case of John Patterson, the American vice consul who disappeared from this northwest Mexican town 10 days ago and is presumed to have been kidnapped.

title: MILLS CRITICIZED ON CAMPAIGN AID
description: WASHINGTON, April 1A research group affiliated with Ralph Nader issued a report today on campaign contributions to Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Democrat of Arkansas, saying that much of the money came from groups that had some special interest in receiving favorable legislative treatment from the Honk Ways and Means Committee, which he heads.

title: Rangers and Canadiens Open Psychological War
description: The Rangers are going to have a damn tough time with us from now on, promised Scotty Bowman, coach of the Montreal Canadiens. For the first time since the month of January, we've got a Nil team.

description: WASHINGTON April 1The Supreme Court declined today to review a decision upholding an Miler by the Federal Trade Commission against the Kennecott Copper Corporation. As a result, Kennecott must divest itself, of the Peabody Coal Company, which it bought for more than $600million in 1968.

title: U.S. Lifts Controls In Variety of Fields

description: TRENTON, April 1 (AP) The State Energy Office today announced that if gasoline rationing was reinstated in New Jersey handicapped people would be exempted.

Brennan; Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger; Caspar W. Weinberger, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, and Roy L. Ash, director of the Office of Management and Budget.

title: A BELLEVILLE MAN HELD IN MOB INQUIRY
description: NEWARK, April 1 (AP)A 42yearold Belleville man, described as a key figure in special Essex County grand jury inquiry into gangland killings, is being held here after being unable to post $500,000 bond on a murder charge.

title: VESCO SKIRTS QUERY ON NIXON DONATION
description: Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier, declined last night to say whether he ever discussed with President Nixon his secret $200,000 cash contribution to the President's reelection campaign.

description: MIAMI, April 1For cigar smokers, Miami has become for the United States what Havana is for Cuba.

title: Nashville Music Delights and Puzzles Muscovites
description: MOSCOW, March 28 Streetcars rattled through the evening outside the Palace of Culture of the Railway Workers in Moscow, but inside the sound was strictly Nashvillesongs of love forlorn and good men gone wrong, of fastrolling diesel trucks and jambalaya; crawfish pie and a file gumbo.

title: BOYLE IS ACCUSED OF COVER EFFORT
description: MEDIA, Pa., April 1The prosecution in the murder trial of W. A. Boyle, famer president of the United Mine Workers Union, asserted today that six months before his arrest last September, he secretly exhorted another U.M.W. official to stick, to a denial of their alleged roles in the slaying of a Boyle election challenger. The contention that Mr. Boyle, 72 years old, had urged the union official, William J. Prater, to stick to the same story even if you're convicted was the major new point raised against Mr. Boyle as the state of Pennsylvania began presenting its case against him. He is accused of instigating and paying for the 1969 slayings of Joseph A. Yablonski, a reform leader in the union, and his wife and daughter.

title: 575,0000 STUDENTS FACE READING TEST
description: The city's 575,000 elementary and junior high school pupils will take part today and tomorrow in readingachievement testsa process that perennially causes as much consternation among, teachers and principals as among the youngsters.

title: Nets Put on Show in Routing Squires for 20 Playoff Lead
Britain Presses Market; Warns of Vote on Quitting
description: LUXEMBOURG, April 1Fifteen months after her entry into the Common Market, Britain met today with her European partners to tell them that unless major changes were made she would put the question of withdrawal to a popular vote.

title: Protests Against the Premier Spread Across Ethiopia
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, April 1 (AP)Protests against the new Government of Premier Endalkachew Makonnen spread across Ethiopia today, but the shaky civilian administration, pledged to moderate reforms, appeared to be surviving a weeklong labor and political upheaval.

title: Foreman Not Bound to Box Ali
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, April 1 (UPI)  The world heavyweight boxing charnpion, George Foreman, miffed at the way the promoters or his title defense against Ken Nerton here last week botched the job, said today he did not feel bound to honor his agreement to Meet Muhammad Ali in Kinshasa, Zaire.

title: Problems Plague Citizens Band Radio
description: WHITE PLAINS, April 1 White Plains police recently began investigating a tip from a citizens band radio operator that others were using the network to plan and execute the theft of radio equipment as well as its eventual sale.

title: Ill Officers Slow Courts in Middlesex
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, April 1The Middlesex County Courthouse was hit by a wave of illness today that left more than threequarters of the 111 Sheriff's officers away from their jobs.

title: McManus Sets Pace in Tennis
description: MUNICH, West Germany April. 1, (UPI)Jim McManus of Berkeley, Calif., defeated Patrick Proisy of France 46, 63, 64, today in a first round World Championship Tennis Red Group match.

title: TURETSKY LEAVES ENERGY POST HERE
description: Gerald J. Turetsky the outspoken and often controversial regional administrator of the Federal Energy Office here, has resigned to return full time to Ida, job as head of the regional office of the General Services Administration here.

title: HOUSE UNIT PLANS HEARINGS BY MAY1
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 Members of the House Judiciary Committee are conidering timetable that envisions beginning hearings on impeachment evidence by May 1 and completing committee action by midJune.

title: Summary of Actions Taken by the Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, April 1The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Colonialism 10:30 A.M.

title: Illinois Sues Ash and Butz
description: CHICAGO, April 1 (UPI) The State Attorney General, William J. Scott, sued two members of the Nixon Administration today for the release of $16million in antipollution funds earmarked for Illinois. The suit charges that the budget director, Roy L. Ash, and Agriculture Secretary Earl M. Butz illegally impounded a national total of $150million that which Congress had approved for sewagetreatment grants.

title: Bill Leaves Offkials' Residency to Local Option
description: ALBANY, April 1  The Senate voted today to allow each municipality throughout the state to, determine whether its policemen, firemen and all public officers must live within its municipal geographical limits.

title: Market Place: Fund Changing Goal to Income
description: Rampaging inflation has made investors more conscious of getting higher yields but of their dollars. The same fundamental factors are behind an interesting switch in investment objectives by the Whitehall Fund, a small mutual fund in, the big Union Service group.

title: Leviit Reports a State Surplus of $127Million
description: ALBANY, April 1State Controller Arthur Levitt reported today that the state had ended Its fiscal year yesterday with a cash surplus of $127million; but he noted that there was up to $500million that would be available, in the budget for new programs or for the enrichment of existing ones.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SPECIAL Museums usually educate us about mankind's antiquities and the new show at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street (5341672) is all about one of the oldest things made by man. It is a most tasteful yet imaginative exhibition about venereal disease and demonstrates the museum's concern with the world around it and its recognition that it can clearly recognize a major current concern.

title: Freed Funeral Tomorrow
description: A funeral service for Fred Freed, executive producer and writer of documentary news programs for the National Broadcasting Company television network, will be held tomorrow at 1 P.M. at Frank E. Campbell's, Madison Avenue and 81st Street. Paidel Patrick Moynihan, Ambassador to India; Frank McGee, N.B.C. news correspondent, and Len Govannitti, news Producer are scheduled speak. Mr. Freed was fotind dead Sunday of a heart attack at his home, 1170 Fifth Avenue. He was 53 years old.

title: City Appears Resigned to Pattern Set by Pact for Transit Workers
description: Leaders of municipal labor unions called yesterday for costofliving raises for their members similar to those won by the transit workers.

title: Herman of Jets Quits
description: Dave Herman announced his retirement from professional football yesterday and then issued a bleak series of views on the currant state of affairs in the sport.

title: DISABILITY RIGHTS WIDENED BY COURT
description: TRENTON, April 1 (AP)The New. Jersey Supreme Court broadened the rights of the workingman today in ruling that such factors as age and emotional condition should play a large part in determining eligibility for totaldisability workmen's compensation.

title: FATHER TO SUE CITY OVER DEATH OF SON
description: The father of a 20yearold black who was shot and killed by an offduty police officer in a Queens bar has filed notice that he will sue the city and the police officer for $6million in damages.

title: City Appears Resigned to Pattern Set by Pact. for Transit Workers
description: Leaders of municipal labor unions called yesterday for costofHying raises for their members similar to thing won by the transit Workers.

title: Meanly Attack on Nixon Cheered By Construction Union Leaders
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 Leaders of the hardhat building and construction unions applauded vigorously today as George Meany, president of the A.F.L.C.I.O., said that the American people have Completely lost confidence in President Nixon and his Administration. The leaders, representatives to a legislative conference of the Building and Construction Trades Department of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, also cheered when told their executive committee had voted unanimously this morning against any extension of wage controls in their industry.

title: British Football Results
Bank Robber Gets $700
description: A tall, thin man about 25 years old, wearing a brown raincoat and ski hat escaped yesterday with $700 from Chemical Bank branch at 204 West Fourth Street, at Grove Street, in Greenwich Village, after handing a teller a note saying he had a bomb.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: Steel Production Fell 0.1% to 2,872,000 Tons
description: Production of steel for the week ended Saturday declined by 0.1 per cent to 2,872,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel. Institute reported yesterday. This lowered the weekly production index to 117.7 from 117.8 the week before, when 2,875,000 tons of steel were poured.

title: Poor Nations Asking an Economic Document From U>N. Session
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 1  Developing countries that say they represent 70 per cent of the world's population are proposing that the forthcoming special General Assembly session on raw materials endorse a declaration on the sstbiishment of a new international economic order.

title: Books of The Times
description: FINAL ANALYSIS, By Lois Gould 194 pager. Random House $5.95.

title: Words Start to Mean Something
description: About 30 children bent over tables in the sunlit workshop at the Cloisters Museum recently, working with various degrees of preoccupation on very unusuallooking books.

title: Senate Votes to Delay Results of Presidential Election Returns
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 The Senate voted today to forbid the disclosure of Presidential election returns until midnight Eastern standard time on election days so the outcome in Western states would not be influenced.

title: Nighttime Checks on Police Find Conscientiousness and Violations
description: During the middle of the night for almost two weeks now, plainclothes police teams have been checking up on how the police have been performing their duties. Among their findings were the following:

title: Advertising Down on the Farm
description: Although a recent survey sponsored by the Department of Agriculture shows that the farmers are held in generally high regard, the agricultural industry and the businesses that supply it are concerned that constantly rising food prices will cause what a spokesman called slippage.

title: Moon Really a Star
description: A mysterious object described on Sunday as possibly a moon of the planet Mercury was declared by scientists yesterday to be really a distant and very hot star. Details on Page 19.

title: GOODYEAR TALKS SET OVER MINORITY JOBS
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, the world's largest tire maker, and the Atonement Friars of Chappaqua, N. Y., yesterday said that they had agreed to negotiate the controversial release of information and data concerning Goodyear's equal employment opportunity practices.

title: Search for a Human Cancer Virus
description: More than 60 years after the discovery that viruses can cause cancer in animals, the identification and isolation of a human cancer virus remains an elusive achievement. The search for such a virus has been studded with false claims and unfulfilled predictions, and last week at an American Cancer Society seminar, yet another prediction wa made. It was that this year would see the unequivocal would see the unequivocal discovery of a human cancer virus.

title: PEKING NEWS JARS FUTURES TRADERS
description: Reports that Peking had rejected three cargoes of West Coast wheat on finding that they contained fungus helped further unsettle the Midwest grain markets yesterday.

title: OILMENT SET BACK BY TAX COMMITTEE
description: WASHINGTON, April 1The House Ways and Means COMmittee, reversing a series of decisionas it made Foyer the last several weeks, voted today to bring an end to the controversial od depletion allowance, at least where major oil producers are concerned.

title: A Private Person in the Public Eye Nancy Maginnes Kissinger
description: Henry has said that she has been his lifeline and she is very much that, said a close associate of the woman who became Mrs. Henry A. Kissinger this last weekend. Most of the friends of the former Nancy Maginnes, respecting what one of them called her mania for privacy, are reluctant to have their names used, although their comments are with few exceptions, positive and flattering.

title: CANADA IS BARRING CHILDREN'S TV ADS
description: OTTAWA, April 1 (AP)A Canadian Government commission has banned as of next Jan. 1 all television advertising directed at children on the stateowned Canadian Broadcasting Corporation network.

title: Short Eyes to Beaumont
description: Short Eyes, the play written by Miguel Pifiero, a former prison inmate, will be the next production at the Vivian Beaumont Theater in Lincoln Center, Joseph Papp announced yesterday. The play, now at the New York Shakespeare Festival's Public Theater downtown, will replace Black Picture Show. Mr. Pifiero's play will open in Philadelphia at the Annenberg Center on April 22 and then at the Vivian Beaumont May 23 after previews beginning May 9.

title: HIGH COURT RULES BANKS MUST GIVE DATA ON DEPOSITS
description: WASHINGTON, April 1The Supreme Court upheld today the constitutionality of the controversial Bank Secrecy Act, overriding charges that the privacy of depositors is invaded by reports required, by the act.

title: 2d Woman Is Elected A Trustee of Columbia
description: Katharine L. Auchincloss, the vice president of the New Jersey State Board of Education, was elected a trustee of Columbia University yesterday, becoming the second woman named in the school's 220year history.

title: Chamber Society. Presents Karel Husa
description: Karel Husa's Sonata for Violin and Piano, which received its first performance Sunday afternoon by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center at Tully Hall, is a long ambitious piece of unusual merit.

title: Robbie's Expensive Xerox Machines
description: In their moment of truth, Larry Csonka, Paul Warfield and Jim Kiick were sitting in a Toronto hotel suite Sunday when their business representative, Ed Keating, looked up from the telephone.

title: Dolphins Go After Unsigned
description: The fallout from the signing of the Miami Dolphin stars, Larry Csonka, Paul Warfield and Jim Kiick, by the World Football League was considerable yesterday.

title: Contract Awards
description: Robintech, Inc., said that its 50 per cent??owned subsidiary, Shintech, Inc., had signed a contract with the Amoco Chemical Company to supply Amoco with certain raw materials over a fiveyear period. Value of the contract based on full sale of the products at present market values would exceed $60million. Amoco is a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana).

title: Corning Glass Earnings Off 1.7% in the Quarter
Integration And Innovation
description: Broadly speaking, the extensive integration of public schools which took place in some parts of the nation roughly between 1966 and 1971 has not resulted in improved educational achievement by minoritygroup pupils. This confounds the expectations of many liberals, even as it annoys many blacks that their children should be expected to read better merely because they sit beside white children.

title: OASIS LIBYA TO RUN NATIONALIZED SHELL
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, April 1 (Reuters)The American oil company, Oasis Libya, is to carry on the operations of the Shell Exploration and Production Company, nationalized by Libya over the weekend.

title: Rebel Chief Asserts U.S. Still Plays Role In War in Cambodia
description: PEKING, April 1 (Reuters)The commander in chief of the proCommunist forces in Cambodia charged today that the United States was as much in= volved as ever in the Cambodian war, and he ruled out any compromise.

title: NEW ORDERS ROSE DURING FEBRUARY
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 (Renters)New orders for manufactured goods rose $1.2billion, or 1,5 per cent, in February, to a seasonally adjusted $80,3billion following a gain of 3 per cent in January, the Commerce Department reported today.
