title: Segretti and Kalmbach Testify Against Their Friend, Chapin
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 Donald H. Segretti testified today at the trial of Dwight L. Chapin that he had reported regularly to Mr. Chapin about the bogus campaign literature he was distributing during primary elections in the name of Democratic Presidential candidates.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: MYSTERY Study of the occult has been occupying a good part of the population for several years, even long before The Exorcist came along.

title: Braves Defeat Celtics
description: BUFFALO, April 2Again the Buffalo Braves led the, Boston Celtics for three periods. But this time the Braves made it stick as they held on and won by 115105 to even their National Basketball Association Eastern Conference firstround playoff at one game apiece tonight.

title: 2 LIBERALS LOSE JOBS IN HUNGARY
description: BUDAPEST, Hungary, March 30The day after the Hungarian Communist leader, Janos Kadar, shuffled his key aides in this country's liberalized economic and cultural programs, an editorial appeared in Nepszabadsag, the party daily under the headline With unchanged policy.

title: Commissioner, in Dispute, Quits the Port Authority
description: One of the six New Jersey commissioners of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has resigned abruptly because of a disagreement with Governor Byrne's program calling for greater involvement of the agency in mass transit,

title: West German Unit of Exxon Denies Trust Charges
description: BERLIN, April 2At a public hearing here today before West Germany's antitrust authority the German subsidiary of Exxon denied charges of excessive gasoline and oil prices, of the funneling of profits out of West Germany and of collusion with other oil concerns.

title: CHIEF OF MILTARY RESIGNS IN ISRAEL; BLAMED IN INQUIRY
description: TEL AVIV, April 2  Lient. Gen. David Elazar resigned tonight as Israel's chief of staff shortly after an official commission investigating Israeli Setbacks at the start of the October war recommended that he and other senior army officers be removed.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: It was reported erroneously in The New York Times on March 19 that the Montana Legislature had approved a resolution endorsing the launching of Minuteman missiles from that state. The Montana House of Representatives voted down a resolution expressing opposition to the launchings, but took no affirmative action.

title: Nixon Lawyer Argues Against Release of Dean Tapes
description: WASHINGTON, April 2An attorney for President Nixon told the United States Court of Appeals today that public disclosure of five tape recordings of conversations between the President, and John W. Dean 3d, his fattier counsel, would have a profound impact on public opinion.

title: Head of Senate Is Interim President
description: PARIS, April 2Under the French Constitution, there is no Vice President to take over when a Presidential vacancy arises.

title: Hogan District Attorney 32 Years, Dies
description: Frank S. Hogan, the shy, courteous lawyer who became a legend in 32 years as Manhattan's District Attorney, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital. Mr. Hogan was 72 years old and lived at 404 Riverside Drive.

title: Problems of France's King of Cotton Distress Government and Workers
description: PARIS, April 2  Marcel Boussac, France's King of Cotton, an 85yearold industrialist who, runs one of Europe's biggest textile enterprises practically as a personal fiefdom, has financial problems that are causing some distress in the Government and among workers in some of the poorer regions of the country.

title: Red Smith
description: The day the Green Bay Packers won the first Super Bowl game their defensive end, Willie Davis, was asked what he was going to do with all that postseason swag. My creditors, he said, have plans. Presumably Mrs. Larry Csonka, Mrs. Jim Kiick and Mrs. Paul Warfield are helping their husbands make plans for the $3million the breadwinners expect to collect from the Toronto Northmen of the World Football League within the next four years. Joe Robbie has plans to sue somebody for alienation of affections, but can't decide who because Csonka, Kiick and Warfield plan to fulfill their contracts with Robbie's Miami Dolphins before jumping across the border. Ken Stabler will have two more seasons at quarterback for the Oakland Raiders, which gives him time to make plans about the loot he'll start getting in 1976reportedly $350,000from the Birmingham Americans of the W.F.L. In pro football, it seems, all God's chillun got plans or hope to have soon.

title: Boyle Trial Is Told How Yablonskis Were Killed
description: MEDIA, Pa., April 2 (AP)An admitted killer who provided the first major break in the murder of Joseph A. Yablonski and members of his family told today how he and two other men stalked their prey.

title: Hal Boyle Memorial Today
description: A memorial service for Hal Boyle, The Associated Press columnist who died here Monday, will be held at 1 P.M. today at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration (the Little Church Around the Corner), 1 East 29th Street. Wes Gallagher, president and general manager, of the news agency, and Saul Pett, an associate, will speak, and the Rev. Norman.J., Catir Jr., the rector, will officiate.

title: March British Reserves Show a $478Million Rise
description: LONDON, April (Reuters)The Treasury reported today that Britain's $478million in March after receipts of $682 million from foreigncurrency borrowing to stand at $6.444billion.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Reliable Sample Card Div. of Willcox & Gibbs makes Silent Salesmen for the wall covering industry (WGAMEX)Advt.

title: Speed Skating Mark Set
description: MOSCOW, April 2 (UPI) Tatyana Averina of Gorky set a world speed skating record fore 1,000 meters today covering the distance in 1 minute 26.4 seconds, Tass, the Soviet news agency, said.

title: U.S. Envoy Urged Withholding of Data Sought by Kennedy
description: WASHINGTON, April 2  Graham A. Martin, the United States Ambassador to South Vietnam, suggested in a confidential cablegram to the State Department last month that Senator Edward M. Kennedy not be given an honest and detailed answer to questions he had raised about American policy in Indochina.

title: Con Ed to Cut $40Million From Construction Plans
description: ALBANY, April 2The Consolidated Edison Company disclosed today that its problems in raising capital funds were forcing it to cut $40million of its construction program this year and requiring it to delay completion of an 800,000kilowatt generator in Astoria, Queens.

title: Captors' Message Hints Miss Hearst Is Near Freedom
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 2An underground newspaper said here today it had received a message from the kidnappers of Patricia Hearst saying that the exact time and place for her release would be announced within 72 hours.

title: Siricas and Jaworskis: Honor in American Life
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn.  The year 1973, among Its startling events, will be remembered as a time that people with such names as Sirica and Jaworski became guardians of the American ethos. Until then, this function remained strictly reserved for men with such names as Marshall, Holmes, Hughes  that is, names as welldefined as Black and White.

title: 2 FATALLY BURNED IN BRUCkNER CRASH
description: Two persons were burned to death last night hi a twocar collision on the upper roadway of the Bruckner Expressway near Longwood Avenue in the South Bronx, the police reported.

title: French Offices in U.S. Open for Condolences
description: The French Embassy in Washington said yesterday that anyone wishing to express sympathy at the death of President Pompidou could do so at the residence of the French Ambassador to the United States, 2221 Kalorama Road N.W., Washington, or at the Consulate General of France in New York, 934 Fifth Avenue, near 75th Street.

title: PRESIDENT POMPIDOU DEAD AFTER ALMOST FIVE YEARS AS DE GAULIE'S SUCCESSOR
description: PARIS, April 2  Georges Jean Raymond Pompidou, President of France, died tonight at the age of 62.

title: ALBERT JACCOMA SR.
description: Albert Jaccoma Sr., who retired in 1970 as art director for Bloomingdale's died yesterday of a heart attack, at St. John's Hospital, Elmhurst, Queens. He was 66 years old and lived at 3043 78th Street, Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: New York Delays MassTransit Bill On Port Authority
description: ALBANY, April 2Governor Wilson's office said today that it did not at this time have legislation ready similar to that in New Jersey that would permit the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to get involved in masstransit projects.

title: U.S. Order Restrains Holiday Magic on Pyramiding
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 2United States District Judge Cloyd H. Burke today approved consent decree here which permanently enjoins the Holilay Magic complex of corntattles from operating a byramid marketing operation Ind sets up a fund for the resitution of individuals derauded by the companies.

title: Students in Ethiopia Demanding Government Action in Famine

title: Steele Limits Gifts to His Drive To Be Governor of Connecticut
description: VERNON, Conn. April 2United States Representative Robert H. Steele, making his formal announcement of his candidacy for the Republican nomination for Governor of Connecticut, vowed today not to accept any individual contributions of more than $100.

title: Stage: Two by Foreman
Brandt Makes a Sharp Attack On Radical Left in His Party
description: BONN, April 2Chancellor Willy Brandt delivered a sharp warning today to the leftwing radicals in his Social Democratic party in the wake of the three defeats that the party suffered last month in state and local elections.

title: Mrs. Vincent Wed To Edwin Murphy
description: Mrs. Mary Amelia Avery Taylor Vincent, widow of Samuel Mitchell Vincent, was married at her home in Fairfield, Conn., yesterday afternoon to Edwin Serre Murphy, a widower, of Norwood Hill, Surrey, England. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert L. Bast, rector of St. Timothy's Episcopal Church in Greenfield Hill, Conn.

title: Assembly Leaders Back Wide VottingLaw Reform

title: City to Convert Plaza Hotel in Bronx Into Housing Project for the Elderly
description: The 50yearold Concourse Plaza Hotel, once an ornament of the Bronx but little more than a shabby relic in recent years, will be bought by the city for $2.6million and converted into housing for the elderly.

title: Short Sells Control of Texas Rangers
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., April  Bob Short, who bought the Washington Senators six years ago and then moved them West and named them the Texas Rangers, sold control of the team today to a group of business. men headed by Bradford G. Corbett, an industrialist from Fort Worth.

description: City College is assembling distinguished advisory council for its Leonard Davis Center for the Performing Arts, and acceptances have already been received from 11 persons prominent in arts and letters. Dunlap said tha first stage will be a $12million facility that will double the plant's tire production capacity and help meet increased demands for ra?? tires.

title: For Children, Giveaway Days at Shea
BELL BOND YIELD RISES TO 8.65%
description: The yield on Bell System bondsgenerally regarded as to drawer investments climbed yesterday to 8.65 per cent, their highest level in three and a half years. This mile stone of the current upsweep in interest rates was set by the Chesapeake and Fotomac Telephone Company of Virginia as it bor. rowed $100million by selling an issue of 35year debentures at an interest cost of 8.72 per cent, also the highest since November, 1970.

title: O'Dwyer and Goldin Oppose Bus Line Fare Increase
description: Three members of the Board of Estimate said yesterday that they would vote against a request by seven private bus companies to raise their basic fares to 50 cents. The board members said they were certain the board would refuse the request.

title: Stabler of Raiders Joins W.F.L. for '76
description: The World Football League took another player, Ken Stabler, from the National Football League yesterday, but for delivery in the 1976 season. The signing team was the Birmingham Americans.

title: Ann Arbor Votes $5 Fine For the Use of Marijuana
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., April 2 Voters in yesferday's municipal elections passed narrowly a proposal reducing the penalty for the use and sale of marijuana within the city to a $5 fine. A similar $5 levy for the violation was also passed yesterday in neighboring Ypsilanti.

title: Citizens Housing Council Names Executive Director
description: Allan R. Talbot, a member of the faculty at the City College School of Architecture and Environmental Design, was named yesterday as executive director of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council.

title: Scripps Medical Complex
description: LA JOLLA, Calif., April 2 (AP)Scripps Clinic and Re(AP)Scripps Clinic and Research Foundation, which treats some of the world's most famous people, says work will soon begin on a $30million medical complex. The new facility will deal mainly with imunology, inflammation and infection, cancer growth, maturation and aging and nutrition, a spokesman said.

title: Paddling of Pupils Curbed
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 2 (UPI)  Austin teachers, will be prohibited from beating pupils with a paddle beginning next fall under a new policy adopted by the school board. The policy, approved 61 last night, states that paddlings shall be administered only by a school principal or his designate, and shall be done in the presence of a witness and as soon after an offense as possible.

title: Russian Wrestlers Trounce U.S., 164
description: CHATTANOOGA, April 2 (AP)A strong Soviet team routed a group of United States wrestlers, 164, in freestyle competition tonight.

title: New Steinbrenner Motto For Yankees: Right On!
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., April 2Now that all the misunderstandings between owner and players have been eradicated, the Yankees can carry on and succeed in their pursuit of the pennant, right? Well, not so fastno matter how right things might be in the, players' minds they still have to convert those thoughts into hits and runs.

title: Stocks Rise Gradually; Dow Average Adds 3.13
description: Stocks were irregular yesterday in quiet trading as investors' apprehensions over increasing interest rates continued to discourage activity.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The New Jersey Board of Public Utility Commissioners yesterday ordered the Jersey Central Power and Light Company to postpone a proposed 23.5 per cent average rate increase for its 600,000 customers. April 25 was set as the first day of public hearings on the proposal. The company has also requested an emergency interim rate increase of about 18 per cent. A spokesman for the commissioners said that the board would probably make a decision by midMay. Then, he said, hearings on whether to allow a total permanent increase of 23.5 per cent will continue. The commission can grant none, some or all of the requests. The spokesman said the commission could further delay its decision on the permanent increase until Dec. 15. The delay on the 23.5 per cent proposal is effective until Aug. 15, unless the board is able to complete the hearings and rule earlier.

title: Nixon Brother Tells of Bid To Warn President in '72
description: F. Donald Nixon, a brother of the President, took the witness stand yesterday and testified that he had been asked to warn the President that a secret $200,000 cash contribution to his reelection campaign might be exposed before Election Day.

title: Schools' English Electives: From Sublime to Ridiculous
description: O.K., Renee Kelvin said, facing her students from a corner of the classroom, at Eastern District High School in Brooklyn, what are some symptoms of measles?

description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation expects this year's first quarter to be the best quarter in its history, Gabriel Hauge, chairman, told shareholders at the annual meeting yesterday.

title: 10 AGENTS FREED IN ILLINOIS RAIDS

title: For Capital Punishment
description: WEST DES MOINES, IowaIn the face of studies that claim to demonstrate that capital punishment does not deter potential criminals, American public opinion clearly favors a return to the death penalty. Advocates of capital punishment, without knowing precisely why, rightly suspect that the most crucial arguments on the other side are fundamentally unsound and misguided.

title: Guns and Society
description: The appalling statistics of death and injury from illegally used firearms provide convincing support for Governor Wilson's call for stiffening the penalties for illegal possession of handguns and other weapons. The additional proposal that tougher penalties be imposed on any person illegally carrying a firearm on school property is amply justified by the growing threats to the safety of teachers and students.

title: Cougars Gain Playoffs
description: CHICAGO, April 2 (AP) The Chicago Cougars, led by Jan Popiel's three goals, gained their first World Hockey Association playoff berth tonight by defeating the Jersey Knights, 73. The victory eliminated Quebec in the East Division.

title: Consumer Notes
description: Things are seldom what they seem, W. S. Gilbert wrote skim milk masquerades as cream.

description: CINCINNATI, April 3The Secretary of Transportation does not have to choose an alternative route if he refuses Federal funding for a proposed highway, the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit ruled today.

description: WASHINGTON, April 3 The staff of the Congressional Joint Committee on Internal Revenue Taxation, which conducted the massive, fourmonth study of President Nixon's tax returns, is a highly unusual gear in the Congressional, machinery that normally runs on politics.

title: Contract Awards
description: Middle, South Utilities, Inc., said yesterday that its operating subsidiary the Louisiana Power & Light Company, has ordered two nuclear power units from the General Atomic Company, a unit of the Gulf Oil Corporation. The two units, each rated at 1.2million kilowatts, are estimated to cost $1,2billion. They will be hightemperature gascooled units and are scheduled for operation in 1982 and 1984. United Engineers & Constructors, Inc., a subsidiary of the Raytheon Company, will design the plant.

title: GORDON FULLERTON OF GTE SYLVANIA, 53
description: Gordon L. Fullerton, senior vice president for electronic components of GTE Sylvania, Inc., died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Wyland, Mass. He was 53 years old.

title: EDUCATION STUDY HOPEFUL ON POOR
description: Daniel Klepak, the state's socalled led education watchdog, declarad yesterday that a study made by his office had demonstrated that schools can teeth,Innercity children to read and that it was time to scrap selffulfilling prophecies the disadvantaged children simply can't learn.

description: Bill Bradley, the New York Knickerbockers forward, announced last night that he had decided not to be a candidate for any elective office this year.

title: Hofstra Stickmen Win
description: PRINCETON, N. J, April 3 Jay Lupetin, a senior midfielder, and Peter Rose, a freshman midfielder, scored four goals apiece today to lead the Hofstra lacrosse team to a 1613 victory over Princeton on Finney Field. Peter George, a sophomore, scored three goals for Princeton.

title: Senate Amends Campaign Bill To Close Polls Simultaneously
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP)The Senate, amended the campaign reform bill today to require that polls throughout the country close simultaneously in Presidential election years.

title: Stage: Lear as Musical
description: There are bad shows you mourn, bad shows you pity and bad shows you writhe at. Pop, the musical at the Players Theater last night, was a writher through and through. It was living testimony to the dictum that there is no stopping a lack of talent if it is given an even break.

title: David Rockefeller Sees Arts in Peril
description: David Rockefeller, a founder of the Business Committee for the Arts Inc., told executive representatives of 100 major corporations that comprise the committee that the arts are in grave trouble on many fronts.

title: Sadat Says War Made Egypt Truly Free
description: CAIRO, April 3President Anwar elSadat tonight declared that the single most important lesson of the October war for Egypt was that she could act in complete independence from both superpowers, the Soviet Union as well as the United States.

title: Legislative Chiefs and Wilson Meet In Effort to Find SchoolAid Formula
description: ALBANY, April 3A meeting on state aid to education between Governor Wilson and leaders of the Legislature broke up after more than four hours tonight, with some participants saying agreement had been reached and others implying that disagreement on how to apportion an enrichhed stateaid package was as great as ever.

description: The Government rested its criminal conspiracy case yesday against John N. Mitchell and Maurice H. Stens, and the defendants Immediately filed motions for dismissal and mistrial,

title: Oil Billions for the Few. Sand for the Starving.
description: WASHINGTON  By the grace of Allah, a few Middle Eastern nations have become rich beyond even the wildest dreams of the fabled potentates of ancient Araby. Through little effort of their own, 55 million peopleor, more accurately, their leadersof Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Iran, Iraq, Abu Dhabi, Qatar and Libya earned $16billion in 1973 and are expected to earn almost $65 billion this year. The spice trade was but salt and pepper compared with commerce in black gold.

title: TAP AND BREAKIN BARRED BY CLARK
description: WASHINGTON, April 3Ramsey Clark told a Senate hearing today that he had denied a request to wiretap Abba Eban, the Israeli foreign minister, and to break Into a foreign mission at the United Nations when he was Attorney General in the Johnson administration id the late nineteensixties.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Maybe those multicolor golf umbrellas had something to do with it. At any rate, men no longer seem as insistent about buying umbrellas only in traditional black, and women don't mind carrying large umbrellas.

title: Pope Eulogizes Pompidou As Man of the First Order
description: ROME, April 3Pope Paul VI, in his general audience at noon today in the Vatican, praised the high qualities of the late French President, Georges Pompidou.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The property clerk division of the Police Department yesterday destroyed a variety of narcotics with an estimated street value of $2,346,625 in the Sanitation Department incinerator at Newtown Creek and North Henry Street in the Greepoint section of Brooklyn. The drugs, mainly heroin and cocaine, had been gathered from property clerk offices throughout the city, and were no longer needed as evidence by District Attorneys.

title: The Tax Report
description: WASHINGTON, April 3The sudden denouement of President Nixon's tax saga is another in a series of seemingly endless national shocks. It is not just the total amount the Congressional staff found due, a staggering $476,431 without penalties, or the $432,787 plus interest that the President has agreed to pay on demand of the Internal Revenue Service. It is the petty, the very petty, details of the ways tax was avoided.

title: LEGISLATION BACKED ON BANK SECRECY
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (UPI)  Responding to a Supreme Court decision Monday upholding the 1970 bank secrecy law, Senators Sam J. Ervin Jr., Democrat of North Carolina, and Charles McC. Mathias Jr., Republican of Maryland, are proposing legislation to protect an individual's financial records.

title: $40Million Penny Bid Set  Railroads to Seek Rate Rise
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 3 The trustees of the Penn Central Railroad, who last, month got the United States Transportation Department to pay off $10.8million of equipment trust debt so that the lenders would not repossess the equipment, plan to ask the Government tomorrow for $40million so they can maintain existing train service over the next five months.

title: Panel Expected to Focus On Public Standard Issue
description: WASHINGTON, April 3The impeachment Inquiry staff of the House Judiciary Cornmittee immediately began a study today of the report on President. Nixon's income taxes to, determine whether his tax matters provide grounds for iweachment.

description: James A. Cavanagh, a rumpled, confidently relaxed graduate of the city's Civil Service, has come to dominate the triumvirate of deputies that Mayor Beanie said would be a team of City Hall equals.

description: HONG KONG, March 30Seeking acceptance for their country as a member in good standing of the third world, Chinese diplomats now seem to be more active in Africa than anywhere else. Their theme is that China and the African natons have identical interests as developing countries struggling to preserve their independence.

title: British Petroleum Drilling
description: LONDON, April 3 (UPI)The British Petroleum Company, Ltd., and the National Iranian Oil, Company have completed drilling operations on the first well on their, jointly owned North Sea blocic 1613, B.P. said today. The data obtained from this Well are being evaluated, B.P. stated.

The Prince met with his halfbrother, Prince Souphanouvong, the leader of the Pathet Lao yesterday. Page 3.

title: ANTINE MAURY
description: Antine Maury, director for the last 18 years of Sprout Lake Camp, a free camp for children with heart disease at Verbank, N. Y., died Tuesday at French Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 850 Amsterdam Avenue.

title: ASSEMBLY VOTES TO SAVE PENSIONS
description: ALBANY, April 3  The Assembly voted today to protect the pensions of all workers in private industry in the state by guaranteeing their rights to benefits after 15 years In a pension plan. Also, the State Superintendent of Insurance would be required to audit periodically every pension fund.

description: BOSTON, April 3The C?? ties have been an irresistil?? force to the Buffalo Brave since the New York team came into the National Basketball Association four years ago.

title: Chapin Says He Ignored Most Segretti Data
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 Dwight L. Chapin took the witness. Stand in his own defense today and testified that he had paid little attention to the political sabotage activities car, ried out by Donald H. Segretti.

title: British Petroleum Predicts $1.2Billion Capital Outlay
description: LONDON, April 3 (AP)The British Petroleum Company, Ltd., said today it expected to spend $1.2billion this year in capital projects, most of it on deveiopment of oil fields in the North Sea.

title: Imbecile Tradition
description: The Senate is scheduled today to make one, of its rare efforts to stop a member from forcing a majority of his colleagues to surrender to him by talking them into a coma. Today's move is directed against Senator James B. Allen, an Alabama Democrat. Apparently unable to make a persuasive case against the public financing of Federal, elections, Senator Allen has fallen back on his right under the rules to kill that reform by filibustering it to death.

title: Bridge: World Bidding Contest Give Noneperts Chance Tonight
description: Many players would admit that they are not in the expert class when it comes to endplays and squeezes, but at the same time would contend that they can bid a hand as well as anyone. Such persons have an opportunity to prove their point tonight, for the World Bidding Contest of the International Bridge Academy will be staged under the auspices of the International Bridge Academy.

title: Gold Price Jumps To $197 in France
description: PARIS, April 3The death of President Georges Pompldou of France yesterday and uncertainties about his succession raised money fears in France today and touched off a new rush into gold, pushing it to record levels here.

title: COMMON MARKET FACES CONFUSION
description: LONDON, April 3The death of President Pompidou of France has thrown Western Europe into confusion and doubt about the future of the Common Market.

title: 4 Truck Drivers Indicted In Death of a 5th in Strike
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (UPI) A grand jury has indicted four Rennsylvama truck drivers on a charge of conspiracy in the death of another driver during the gasoline protest strike earlier this year, the Justice Department announced today.

title: Pontoon Bridge Opens
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C., April 3 (AP)A pontoon bridge was opened today connecting Hilton Head Island to the mainland for the first time in a week. Army engineers placed the floating structure beside the damaged James F. Byrnes Bridge late yesterday and early today and let the first vehicles cross it at 9 A.M..

title: Sales of Savings Bonds Rose Slightly in March
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP)The Treasury Department said today that sales of United States Savings Bonds during March totalled $587million, up slightly from $569million a year earlier. Total redemptions were $411million, for a net gain in sales of $176million in March.

title: RAZING PLAN STIRS COREY RESIDENTS
description: The city's plans to condemn nearly 100 properties in the western part of Coney Island provoked heated debate before the City Planning Commission yesterday.

description: Tornadoes struck nine states in the Middle West and South last night, then swirled into Canada. More than 200 people were killed.

title: NEW VOICES ENLIVEN CITY OPERA CARMEN
description: Two of the season's new faces on the New York City Opera's soprano roster, Ruth Falcon and Yoshi Ito, appeared in Tuesday night's fifth Carmen of the spring schedule. Miss Falcon, as Micaela, one of opera's least interesting people, could do little to suggest her potential in the dramatic department. But she sang capably in a sweet, rather light, lyric voice, and looked aptly timid as Don Jose's insipid country girlfriend.

title: Instead of RunandShoot Game, Knicks Playing StandandMiss
description: What's wrong with the Knicks? They're in a shooting slump. Their concept of team offense and movement has disappeared. They are standing around; oneonone basketball has taken over.

title: WELLS CHURCH, 72, EXC.B.S, NEWSMAN
description: Wells Church, a former news correspondent for the Columbia Broadcasting System and a C.B.S. news executive, died Tuesday at the Anne Arundel General Hospital in Annapolis, Md. He was 72 years old.

title: Nixon Vow Is Cited
description: WASHINGTON, April 3The White House said tonight that while President Nixon would pay the full amount of back taxes requested by the Internal Revenue Service, he could have, and perhaps should have, contested the finding.

title: 4 Specialists on Taxes Who Advised President
description: One of President Nixon's tax lawyers . . . Partner 14 the Cleveland law firm of Jones, Day, Cockley & Reavis . . . Born in Columbus, Ohio, Feb. 11, 1907 . . . Admitted to Ohio bar 1955 . . Graduated from Princeton in 1928 with an A.B. degree and from Harvard Law School in 4931 . . . While at Princeton Mr. Rose was chairman of The .Daily Princetonian, the college newspaper . . . He also belonged to the debating society, was president of the undergratuate council, and member of Phi Beta Kappa . . . Married Katherine Cast Oct. 1, 1938 . . . Their son, Jonathan, is now Associate Deputy Attorney General of the United States . . . Horace Rose was a law clerk for Supreme Court Justice Oliver Vendell Holmes in the Court's 1931 term and served as Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, 195355, and Under Secretary of the TreaSury, 195556 . . . Mr. Rose has been a troubleshooter for the President since Mr. Nixon arrived at the White House . . . Send for Chappy was an oftrepeated cry at the White House when problems began to mount . . . Considered quiet, effective, softspoken and highly intelligent . . . An associate says Mr. Rose is the epitome of the work ethic .. . Mr. Rose, who donated more than $10,000 to the President's 1972 campaign, is active in Ohio Republican politics, where his counsel is often sought.

title: Market Place: MIP Biting Dust Amidst New Plan
description: With stockbrokers now free to experiment with rates on orders involving $2,000 or less, a famous Wall Street venture is slipping quietly into oblivion. This is the Monthly. Investment Plan, launched amidst fanfare 20 years ago.

title: Grassland Fires Contained
description: LOVINGTON, N.M., April 3 (AP)Two range fifes that rampaged over nearly 400 square miles of grassland in southeastern New Mexico were reported contained today.

title: WesternStyle Flexibility Rejected By Chief Soviet Economic Planner
description: MOSCOW, April 1The Soviet Union's chief economic planner has rejected proposals of some Westernminded Soviet economists for a new, more flexible approach to national planningbut he has acknowledged the need to sevise Moscow's current method to make them more effective.

title: Report Says Nixon Owes Tax on Home Improvement

description: In the present miasma of dissension among the member governments it is all too easy to forget what a success the Atlantic Alliance has been. On the 25th anniversary of the signing of the North Atlantic Treaty in Washington it may be in order to recall some of the bench marks of that success in addition to assessing the future prospects of the Alliance.

title: Antipoverty Bill Offered
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) Three Michigan Republicans have sponsored legislation to extend the Office of Economic Opportunity for three years and transfer jurisdiction for its programs to the Department of Health, Education and Welfare. The measure was introduced Tuesday by Representatives Melvin L. Esch, Garry Brown and Philip E. Ruppe.

title: Hofstra Stickmen Win
description: PRINCETON, N. J., April 3 Jay Lupetin, a senior midfielder, and Peter Rose, a freshman midfielder, scored four goals apiece today to lead the Hofstra lacrosse team to a 1613 victory over Princeton on Finney Field. Peter George, a sophomore, scored three goals for Princeton.

title: NEWSMEN WILL PAY JERSEY FOR PHONES
description: New Jersey has reversed longstanding policy and will begin charging newspaper, broadcast and wire service bureaus at the State House for telephone service retroactive to April 1, according to Richard C. Leone, state treasurer.

title: Con Ed Explains Avaerage Bill But Customers Do a Slow Burn
description: There are, undoubtedly, people somewhere who sometimes speak kindly of Consolidated Edison. Undoubtedly.

title: LIEDETECTOR USE BARRED IN HIRING
description: TRENTON, April 3  The State Supreme Court unanimously upheld the constitutionality of a state law that prohibits employers from giving lie detector tests to employes.

title: No Word Is Heard in Argentina Despite Ransom Paid for Oilman
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 3There is growing concern here about the failure of Marxist guerrillas to release a kidnapped oil executive despite the payment, three weeks ago, of a $14.2million ransom.

title: ANTITRUST ROLE SEEN IN FEE EXPERIMENTS
description: The New York Stock Exchange warned brokers yesterday that, in complying with Securities and Exchange Commission orders to experiment with commission rates on small orders, they face possible violation of Federal antitrust law.

title: Oscar's 3Hour Show Is Short on Surprises
description: LOS ANGELES, April 3After a run of controversial, dramatic shows over the last few years, with politics and artistic catfights unnerving the participants, the Academy Awards ceremony this year reverted to form, providing few surprises in a show that ran for more than three hours.

title: WHEAT CONTRACTS ADVANCE BY LIMIT
description: The sudden reappearance of major export buyers in the Chicago Board of Trade wheat pit yesterday sent grain prices up by their permissible daily limits within minutes after the opening bell.

title: Liverpool Gains Final
description: BIRMINGHAM, England, April 3 (AP)Liverpool, England's Soccer League champion, reached the final of the English Knockout Cup tonight with a 31 victory over Leicester City before a crowd of 55,619 at Villa Park Arena.

title: L.I. VILLAGE AIDS POVERTY AGENCY
description: BAXTER ESTATES, L. I., April 2The trustees of this small affluent village voted last night to give $1,000, 20 per cent of their revenuesharing funds, to the local antipoverty agency for social services.

title: Detente: Some Qualms and Hard Questions
description: PITTSBURGHDetente, I believe, poses the potentially gravest danger to our nation of all the problems we face. Whether it is to prove a siren's call to lure us to our destruction, or the first long step toward defusing the terrible threat of nuclear warfare and worldwide holocaust, no man can today predict with any assurance.

title: Hanoi Rearranges Cabinet For Apparent New Tasks

title: The Manager in the Middle
description: CINCINNATI, April 3Over at Riverfront Stadium, the leftfield fence had been restored to its proper posture. High winds Monday night had blown down part of it, although baseball psychiatrists had another explanation. The leftfield fence, they believed, had suffered a nervous breakdown from the anticipation of Henry Aaron's aiming at it when the Atlanta Braves open their season against the Cincinnati Reds tomorrow. He was supposed to aim at it today in a workout, but a noontime shower canceled his target practice. Instead, the 40yearold outfielder went to the airport to meet his bride, Billye, while his manager, Eddie Mathews, sat on a TV set in his suite at the Netherland Hilton Hotel and announced that he was not announcing if the man with 713 home runs would be in the Braves' openingday lineup.

title: Spirites 'Threee Musketeers' (No. 6)
description: Richard Lester, the man who gave us "A Hard Day's Night," "Help!," "Petulia" and "How I Won the War," now rips into "The Three Musketeers" with such high good spirits that I feel somehow lacking not to be able to respond with the same reckless enthusiasm.The film, which opened yesterday at the Columbia I, the Guild and other theaters, is, according to the records, the sixth to be based on the Alexander Dumas adventure novel. Here they are again: Athos, Porthos and Aramis, who, with the short-tempered D'Artagnan, loyally defend a muddle-headed Louis XIII and his adulterous Queen, Anne of Austria, against what I've always suspected was the perfectly reasonable, statesmanlike treachery of Cardinal Richelieu. Even as a boy I felt that way, which may be why the book was never my favorite.Photographed in Spain, with lots of name-actors showing up in smallish roles (rather like an Oscar show), Mr. Lester's interpretation of "The Three Musketeers" looks like an evening in a bump-o-car arena, with magnificently costumed people in place of cars. The adventures are less swashbuckle than slapstick.The narrative, mostly concerned with the efforts of the musketeers to retrieve the Queen's diamonds given to the Duke of Buckingham, moves forward through a series of physical collisions, man with man, man with woman, man with windmill, woman with inkwell.D'Artagnan (Michael York) and Constance (Raquel Welch), the married seamstress he loves, are particularly accident-prone. When D'Artagnan swings on a rope to attack a man on horseback, he lands not on the man but in a puddle. For all his worthy spirit, D'Artagnan is a terrible judge of distances.The three musketeers whom D'Artagnan aspires to join are played by Oliver Reed, Richard Chamberlin and Frank Finlay. Boisterously However, it took me almost the entire film to figure out which actor was playing which musketeer. I suppose such identification is not all that important, but the difficulty says something about the screenplay written by George MacDonald Fraser. It's, extremely light on character.Mr. Lester seems almost exclusively concerned with action, preferably comic, and one gets the impression after a while that he and his fencing masters labored too long in choreographing the elaborate duels. They're interesting to watch, though they are without a great deal of spontaneity.Another of the director's fascinations is period detail, which is sometimes more fun than the comic action sequences.The movie is chock-full of research into the ways in which the upper crust of 17th-century France spent its leisure time (in tennis, gambling, falconry and jousting, among other things). Richelieu's dungeons are filled with prisoners enclosed in what look like decorative metal bird cages. While the King and Queen enjoy a country picnic, the court musicians stand apart from them, almost hidden by the high grass, sawing away at their instruments.Some of the other prominent performers in the cast include Charlton Heston as Richelieu, Simon Ward as Buckingham, Jean-Pierre Cassel and Geraldine Chaplin as the King and Queen, and Faye Dunaway as Richelieu's beautiful English spy. Nobody plays it for laughs, which is as it should be.If the story doesn't seem to go anywhere much, it may be because this film is, according to the trade press, just half of the film that was shot. Instead of releasing it as one three-hour movie, the producers decided instead to make it into two. The second part reportedly will be released at the end of the year.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The mortgage loan commitment for a 238unit housing development for the elderly in Jersey City has been approved by the state's Housing Finance Agency. Community Affairs Commissioner Patricia Q. Sheehan announced that $6,175,000 would be used to build Battery View Senior Housing, sponsored by the Battery View. Senior Housing Corporation.

title: Testimony Offered Court to Support Maheu's Contention He Gave Humphrey $50,000
description: LOS ANGELES, April 3 Testimony from three witnesses was introduced in Federal court here today to support the cone tention that $50,000 of Howard Hughes's money in an attach case was placed at Hubert H, Humphreys, feet in a limousine during the political campaign of 1968.

title: ASSEMBLY VOTES TO SAVE PENSIONS OF ALL WORKERS
description: ALBANY, April 3  The Assembly voted today to protect the pensions of all Workers in private industry in the state by guaranteeing their rights to benefits after 15 years in a pension plan. Also, the State Superintendent of Insurance would be required to audit periodically every pension fund.

title: Haldeman Says Nixon Didn't Know
description: ACAPULCO, Mexico, April 3 (AP)H. R. Haldeman says that President Nixon didn't know a damned thing about Watergate and he didn't know about a coverup of Watergate.

title: Guards at 4 Prisons Out; State Obtains Court Order
description: TRENTON, April 3Attorney General William F. Hyland moved in State Superior Court today to get an injunction barringthe continuation of a sickout by a majority of the guards at four of he state's penal institutions. They are protesting a proposed pay increase of 6 per cent for state employes.

title: JUDSON F. FALKNOR
description: Judson F. Falknar, dean of the law school of the University of Washington from 1934 to 1951, died last Friday in Seattle, where he made his home. He was 77 years old.

title: Advertising: Solow as Phoenix
description: The way Martin Solow, the former president of Solow/ Wexton, explained it yesterday, he had little control over the demise of his agency.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: SUMMIT, April 3In 1969 Joan Hennas was the topranked platform tennis Women's doubles player in the country. Today her aspiration is to be the best tennis teacher.

title: Soviet Data Show Cancer Death Rise
description: Soviet cancer statistics recently, issued in Moscow show a steady increase in the rate of deaths from cancer over the last 12 years in a trend similar to that in the United States.

title: Miss Hearst Says She Joins Terrorists
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 3Patricia Hearst said in a taperecorded message received today that she had chosen to join the forces of the Symbionese Liberation Army and fight for the freedom of oppressed people.

title: TAIWAN WORRIES ABOUT ECONOMY
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 3During recent years of anxiety about Nationalist China's eroding international political position, people here have drawn confidence from spectacular economic growth. Now the picture is changing.

title: Charles W. Smith, Olin Officer, Dies
description: Charles W. Smith, former vice president of the Olin Corporation in charge of its chemicals group, died yesterday at his home in Wilton, Conn., after a long illness. He was 53 years old.

title: Foreman Wants Ali In Jungle
description: HOUSTON, April 3 (UPI)Saying it's fitting that knock him out in the jungle, George Foreman declared today he would fight Muhammad Ali in Africa for $5million.

title: The Panamanian Cook's Paella Was an Irresistible Temptation
description: CORAL GABLES, Fla.We had a communique recently from an acquaintance, a connoisseur of sorts (how much nicer to be labeled a connoisseur of sorts rather than gourmet) who told us he'd just eaten the best paella he'd ever had in the world.

title: Goich Ponders: His Freedom or Giants
description: A longdistance telephone call may have saved the New York Giants from losing another defensive regular, Dan Goich.

title: FEDERATED LISTS EARNINGS DECLINE
description: Federated Department Stores, Inc., the nation's largest departmentstore chain, reported yesterday that its profit in the final quarter of its fiscal year ended Feb. 2was down, because of inflation.

title: Yanks Still Trying to Make Deal for a 2d Baseman
description: NORFOLK, Va., April 3While the Mets approached the opening of the season in a calm settled manner, the Yankees headed in the same direction today in a more feverish, frustrated fashion.

title: Canadian Board Watches Wheat Intently
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, March 16A few weeks ago the towering grain elevators that dot the vast flatlands of Manitoba, Alberta and Saskatchewan, the Canadian wheat belt, contained so much empty space  44 per cent by one official's estimate  that the Canadian Wheat Board wrote to each of the more than 176,000 registered farmers, urging them to get their crops moving faster.

title: 300 AT MEMORIAL FOR HAL BOYLE
description: Hal Boyle, the Pulitzer Prizewinning war correspondent and columnist for The Associated Press, was eulogized yesterday as a writer who will live on in the legends he created. He had died of a heart attack at his home here Monday at the age of 63.

title: Israeli War Report Broadly Criticized
description: JERUSALEM, April 3The initial findings of the official sommission investigating the October war were attacked from both the left and right today as overly severe on the Military command and overly lenient toward the political leadership.

title: People in Sports
description: Norm Sloan, who says his team just finished the toughest two seasons in college basketball history, was rewarded with The Associated Press's coach  of  the  year crown yesterday. Sloan's North Carolina State squad took the national championship, ending he sevenyear rein by the University of California, Los Angeles.

title: Times, News and Post Present Full Offer to the Printers' Union
description: Negotiators for The New York Times, The Daily News and The New York Post yesterday presented a complete offer, including proposals on wages and automation, to Typographical Union No. 6.

title: Indian Election Postponed by. U.S. Suit Alleging Vote Tampering
description: WASHINGTON, April 3  In the first court suit filed under the Indian Bill of Rights, the Department of Justice has accused the governing council of the San Carlos Apache tribe in Arizona of tampering with the voting process.

title: Sketched of 5 Major French Presidential Contenders
description: Now 59 years old and former Premier ... When only 29 served as general with Free French forces in World War II ... At one time in charge of all Resistance military operations in occupied France ... Top civil servant at the Information Ministry at 30, deputy in the National Assembly at 31 and Mayor of Bordeaux at 32 ... President of the country's second chamber through all 11 years of de Gaulle era and Pompidou's Premier for three years ... Got along with Bordeaux's wartime collaborators as well as with such liberals and Socialists as Pierre MendsFrance and Guy Mollet, whose Cabinets he joined while de Gaulle was out of power ... Considered to be on left wing of Gaullist Establishment ... ProEurope and proAmerican, he is nevertheless endorsed by such oldline Gaullists as Michel Debit and Alexandre Sanguinetti, party secretary ... Darkly handsome and, as befits former member of national tennis team, slim ... May be handicapped for having taken advantage of legal loopholes to avoid paying taxes for several years.

title: Nixon Expects to Fly to For Pompidou Service
description: WASHINGTON, April 3Adto fly to Paris to attend a ministration officials said today that President Nixon expected memorial service on Saturday for President Georges Pompidou, who died yesterday.

title: Laotian Coalition Near
description: The Premier of Laos, Prince Souvanna Phouma, announced yesterday that the longexpected coalition government with the Communistled Pathet Lao would be presented to the King tomorrow. The Prince met yesterday with his halfbrother, Prince Souphanouvong, the leader of the Pathet Lao. Page 3.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, April. 3 (Reuters)The United States Terrif Commission rejected today a request by Treasury Secretary George. P. Shultz that it reconsider a decision that said American industry was likely to be injured by the sale of lead from Canada and Australia at less then fair value.

title: Goldman Tied to Paint Concern Named in State's Shubert Suit
description: The paintselling company of Irving Goldman  the city's Cultural Affairs Commissioner and president of the Shubert theatrical empire  was incorporated for 12 years with a painting corporation that the state's Attorney General has charged received unexplained, unjustified and excessive payments of more than $1million from the Shubert organization.

title: Political Leaders' Health: Should the Public Know?
description: Why do political leaders deceive their employers, the public, about the status of their health? The question is raised anew by the deaths earlier this week of two politiciansPresident Georges Pompidou of France and former District Attorney Frank S. Hogan of New York County. Mr. Hogan died of cancer at the age of 72 years. President Pompidou died at age 62 of an illness of an undisclosed nature. He was presumed to have had cancer.

title: AMERICAN ELECTRIC SUES WESTINGHOUSE
description: The American Electric Power Company and four of its operating subsidiaries filed a $75million suit in Federal District Court here yesttrday against the Weitinghouse Electric Corporation. The suit alleges that an 830,000kilowatt Westing. house turbin generator had failed to meet Its operating specifidations through inadetpate design and construction, and that Westinghous had failed either, to repair or to replace the defective unit.

title: LAG IN FERTILIZER THREATENS INDIA
description: NEW DELHI, April 3India, a nation where food supplies and political stability are crucally linked, is facing a fertiliter shortage, that alarms Government officials.

title: Newark's New Archbishop Includes Suburbs in Plans
description: NEWARK, April 3The newly designated Archbishop of Newark, the Most Rev. Peter L. Gerety, kept a hectic schedule today as he started an overnight visit to one of the most heavily urbanized Roman Catholic archdioceses in America, whose 1.7 million people will soon be under his spiritual guidance.

title: Fuel Award on School Buses
description: BOSTON, April 3 (AP)The State House of Representatives gave final approval today to increased payments to school bus operators for higher fuel costs. On a voice vote without debate the lower chamber authorized school boards to reimburse the bus operators for the increased costs without further public bidding on exiting contracts.

title: City Asks Business to Provide 20,000 Summer Youth Jobs
description: Businessmen joined the city government yesterday in a program to place at least 70,000 students in summer jobs, with emphasis on disadvantaged youths. The venture was announced by Mayor Beame at news conference at the Pierre Hotel.

title: Nassau's Democratic Chairman And 17 on Panel Back Samuels
description: Howard J. Samuels' campaign for the Democratic nomination for Governor received a substantial boost yesebterday when he was endorsed by Stanley Harwood, the Nassau County chairman, and 17 of the county's 24 state committee members.

title: Upturn Is Forecast
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 Herbert Stein, chairman of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers, said today that antirecession plans are much less prominent in our thinking than in January and February.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Meta, preseason at Richmond, Va. (RadioWMCA, WHN, 1:30 P.M.)

title: BARRAGES REPORTED IN GOLAN HEIGHTS
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, April 3 (Reuters)  Syrian and Israeli forces exchanged tank and artillery fire for more than nine hours in the Golan Heights today for the 23d consecutive day, a Syrian military spokesman said.

title: MERRILL LYNCH HELD LIABLE ON INSIDERS
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit ruled here yesterday that Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner. & Smith, Inc., the nation's biggest brokerage firm, was liable for damages arising out of a stockholder suit involving the use of inside information.

title: Bill for Vietnam Arms Aid Suffers a Double Setback
description: WASHINGTON, April 3Administration efforts to increase military aid to South Vietnam were set back today in both the Senate and the House.

title: Oil Field in Egypt Opens
description: CAIRO April 3 (AP)  An oil field with an estimated production of 150,000 barrels a day was opened yesterday by Egypt's Oil Minister, Ahmed Hilal, press reports said today. Mr. Hilal was quoted as saying the oil field July, situated in the Suez Gulf, had an estimated reserve of 600 million barrels valued at $6billion at current prices.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, APRIL 4, 1974

title: Stracey to Box Mason
description: LONDON, April 3 (UPI) The British welterweight boxing champion, John Stracey, will meet Vernon Mason of Baltimore, Md., on April 23 here in his final contest before challenging Roger Menetrey of France for the European title in June.

title: FRENCH PROCLAIM POHER PRESIDENT
description: PARIS, April 3Alain Poher, centrist president of the Senate, was officially proclaimed the Acting President of France today in an atmosphere of grave uncertainty and political confusion.

title: Liverpool Gains Final
description: BIRMINGHAM, England, April 3 (AP)Liverpool, England's Soccer League champion, reached the final of the English Knockout Cup tonight with a 31 victory over Leicester City before a crowd of 55,619 at Villa Park Arena.

title: Naps Reject a Plan On Fiscal Assistance To Save Old School
description: Parents of 151 children have begun seeking alternative elementary schools after the Sisters of Charity rejected their pleas and protests to keep open St. Joseph's Academy in Greenwich Village.

title: Eisenhower Nephew Dies: Drug Overdose Report
description: LOS ANGELES, April 3 (AP)  Lloyd Edgar Elsenhower 49 years old, nephew of President Dwight D. Eisenhower, was found dead today of an apparent drug overdose, sheriff's deputies said.

title: Youth Slain in Jamaica
description: A 17yearold youth was found shot to death last night in a parking lot in the Jamaica section of Queens, according to the police. He was identified as Bernard Jackson of 11209 158th Street, Jamaica, and according to the police had been shot at least once in the right temple.

title: Portrait Gallery Given 761 Mellon Engravings
description: WASHINGTON, April 3A rare and complete collection of 761 engraved portraits of the elite in America from 1796 to 1814 by the French artist SaintMemin has been given by Paul Mellon to the National Portrait Gallery, the museum announced today.

title: QE2 Passengers Arrive, Joking About Adventure
description: Laughing and joking about their rescue adventure on the high seas, passengers from the disabled Queen Elizabeth came home yesterday.

title: Sands, of Angels Injured
description: ANAHEIM, Calif, April 4 (AP)Charlie Sands, the California Angels' top hitter during spring training, will miss the first four or five weeks of the season with sprained ligaments in his right knee, a spokesman, for the American League club said today. Sands is the team's secondstring catcher.

title: Advertising: Of Clogged Drains
description: Ever wonder What fashionable folks discuss over lunch at the 21 Club? Well yesterday in the thirdfloor Jack Room, the subject before, during and after lunch was clogged drains, which once again proves the old adageHe who picketh Up the tab picketh also the topic.

title: Biaggi Asks Death Penalty
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (UPI) Representative Mario Biaggi, Democrat of the Bronx, who is a former policeman, introduced legislation yesterday to restore the death penalty for certain crimes, including killing a policeman.

title: The TaxBill Decision
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 Richard Nixon Invested half a million dollars In the Presidency last night.

title: Homer Interrupts Soap Opera, Senate
description: Thirtynine years after Babe Ruth's 714th and last home run, Henry Aaron tied a record and ended a controversy yesterday the first time he swung the bet in 1974.

title: TORNAD0ES' TOLL IS PLACED AT 323; 1BILLION DAMAGE
description: Cones of vicious winds that slashed across 11 states of the South and Middle West pushed the death toll to more thin 300 persons yesterday and evoked tornado watches for six additionale states, in the worst tornado disaster in 49 years.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: S.E.C.'S BAN TO END FOR REPUBLIC LIFE
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission said it was terminating the suspension of trading in the securities of the Republic National Life Insurance Company of Dallas, effective at midnight Sunday.

title: Pro Transactions
description: CALIFORNIA (AL)Placed Charlie Sands, catcher, on supplemental disabled list for five weeks with strained ligaments in right knee.

title: Martial Lave Helps the Philippines, but Doubts Remain
description: MANILAAntonio Rojas is a poor 27yearold farmer in the village of Tulungatung, 12 miles front Zamboanga, in the southern Philippines, Before martial law, he says, there was a lot of crime. Thieves used to steal our coconuts and sometimes they would take clothes from our houses. Now crime is much less.

title: HOUSE BARS RISE IN VIETNAM AID
description: WASHINGTON, April 4The House, by a vote of 177 to 154, tonight rejected the Administration's request for a $474million increase in military aid to South Vietnam.

title: School Workers Demonstrate at Board of Education to Force Action on New Contract
description: Several thousand schoolroom aides, lunchroom workers and other school employes demonstrated in front of the central Board of Education at 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn, yesterday, demanding action on what they said were delays by the board in negotiating new cotracts with their union.

title: Authorities Impugn Hearst Message
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 4Although they could offer no evidence, Federal authorities said here today that they believed Patricia Hearst was forced to record the message saying that she had joined the terrorist Symbionese Liberation Army.

title: Ferment in MassTransit Agencies
description: There are signs of ferment in the two regional superagencies concerned with transportation: the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. The yeast in the mixture is the issue of expannea masstransportation facilities in this, region plus possible leadership changes affecting both authorities.

title: City to Pay Half the Cost Of Restaurant Promotion
description: A $150,000 campaign to entice New York area residents to dine out more often was begun yesterday when the Board of Estimate voted to spend half that amount in city funds to finance a yeararound promotional drive sponsored by the restaurant industry.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (Reuters)The Federal Energy Office said today it would lift price controls on asphalt, road oil, refinery gas, petroleum wax and petroleum coke.

title: STATE PENSION BILL IS TIED TO U.S. MOVE
description: ALBANY, April 4State Senator John R. Dunne said today that he was awaiting word from Washington as to the status of Federal bills guaranteeing workers' pension rights before releasing for Senate action a state measure approved yesterday by the Assembly.

title: NIXON TAX INQUIRY IS CLOSED BYIRS AND CONGRESS UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, April 4The Internal Revenue Service and the Congressional Joint Coinmittee on Internal Revenue. Taxation formally closed today their inquiries into President Nixon's tax payments for his first four years in the White House.

title: French Presidential Race Is On Hours After Pompidou Burial
description: PARIS, April 4The race for the presidency of France was begun today by Jacques ChabanDelmas, a liberal Gaullist and former Premier under President Georges Pompidou.

title: Screen: Treat for Young
description: A genuinely delightful, hourlong program of short films for children is being shown through Monday at the Whitney Museum of American Art. Furthermore, youngsters under 12 years old are admitted free, with adults paying only $1 and $1.50 on weekends. The afternoon screenings start at noon.

title: British Woman Wins Skate Title
description: JACA, Spain, April 4 (AP) Lorna Brown of Britain compiled 48.7 points to win the world professional figure skating championship on the final day of competition today.

title: Armstrong Unit Closing
description: LANCASTER, Pa., April (AP)The Armstrong Cork Company announced today it would discontinue manufacturing operations at its Pittsburgh plant about July 1. The company said the plant's 250 employes have been notified. The Pittsburgh plant makes corkbased fabricated gasket products.

title: Help for the Afflicted
description: Part of every dollar you give to Aster Seals trengthens be fight against crippling conditions by supporting repsearch into their causes while finding new means relieve those afflicted. Any supplement to existing senates like yearround recreational programs can make life easier for the physically disadvantaged. And therapy programs for those with serious speech and hearing problems can help these people learn and grow.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Talks Halt N. F. C. On All Key Issues
description: The owners and players of the pational Football League agreed to disagree yesterday affter a fourhour negotiating The in the Drake Hotel. The two, sides found themselves in virtual total disagreement on grounds of principle, and the meeting broke, up without a date set for future negotiations.

title: The Pop Life
description: There were no printed ads or advance formal advertising of any kind. But the four concerts scheduled at Madison Square Garden for June 10, 11, 13 and 14 by the Who are already sold out.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Burns Asks Economic Caution; Loan Demand Is Still Strong

title: A's Paced By Jackson Win Opener
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., April 4 (AP)Reggie Jackson slashed four hits, including a home run, and the world champion Oakland A's opened the American League season tonight with a 72 rout of the Texas Rangers.

title: Neaman Bids at Interstate Dropped
description: Samuel Neaman, the former chairman and chief executive officer of the McCrory Corporation, is no longer involved in negotiations for either his appointment as president and chief executive of Interstate Stores, Inc., or for the pending sale of 1,200 McCrory and S. Klein stores to Interstate.

title: Bridge: 2 Spring Nationals Winners Join Up for Las Palmas Tilt
description: One of the partnerships that will represent the United States in Las Palmas, the Canary Islands, next month, comprises Ron Andersen of Parsippany, N. J., and Hugh MacLean of Minneapolis.

title: 3 Sentenced in Holdup
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., April 4 (AP)Three men who pleaded guilty this week to armed, robbery in the $297,000 holdup of the Holyoke National Bank were sentenced yesterday to from 12 to 20 years at Walpole State Prison. They are Elbie Johnson, 30 years old, of Boston, George J. Kleczka, 41, of Worcester and Paul G. Callahan, 38, formerly of Chicopee.

title: Democrats in Stale Races Pledge to Keep Peace
description: Democratic candidates for statewide office, in an effort te avoid the factional fighting that has disrupted their party in the past, pledged yesterday of to attack one another and to support the, party nominees.

title: Alliance Plans on Lightly Manned New Weapons
description: When, on April 4, 1949, 12 governments signed the North Atlantic Treaty, their resources for defending Western Europe amounted to 20 understrength divisions, less than a thousand operational aircraft, 20 air bases and a promise that United States atomic bombers would retaliate to Soviet aggression.

title: BRAZIL CRARGES A CONGRESSMAN
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 4An opposition Brazilian Congressman appeared before the Supreme Court in Brasilia today to be charged under the national security law with public offense to Chile's chief of state.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: News Summary and Index.
description: FRIDAY, APRIL 5, 1974

title: Students in Ethiopia Start Hunger Mike And Boycott Classes
description: ADDIS ABABA, April 4 (Reuters)  Students boycotted classes here today and handed out food to hundreds of destitute peasants milling outside Parliament.

title: CONSUMERS' CHIEF GETS WMCA SHOW
description: Consumer Affairs Commissioner Elinor Guggenheimer began a weekly onehour radio program last night over WMCA taking calls from listeners on subjects of interest to consumers.

title: Nixon Papers Stay in Archives
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 The prePresidential papers that President Nixon submitted to the National Archives in an attempt to take a $576,000 tax deduction will apparently remain in the Archives as the property of the American people, even though the deduction has been disallowed.

title: Passover Messages Back Israel And Note Plight of Soviet Jews
description: The weeklong festival of Passovercelebrating the liberation of the ancient Israelites from the Egyptian bondage begins at sundown tomorrow in Jewish households, and religious and secular leaders yesterday cited its meaning of human freedom.

title: Knick's Fans Sure of Victory in Series
description: Robert Redford, the actor, did not win the Oscar, but he isn't giving up. Russell Rowe was kept out of the Knicks' practice yesterday at Pace College, but lie isn't giving up. Walt Frazier was soundly booed Tuesday night, but he isn't giving up.

title: Chief of Tax Staff Laurence Neal Woodworth
description: WASHINGTON, April 4In the final hectic days before yesterday's release of the report by the staff of the Congressional Joint, Committee on Internal Revenue Taxation about Prestdent Nixon's income taxes, some members were already looking ahead to other legislative work. One of them handed the staff director, Laurence Neal Woodworth, a sheaf of memorandums about the tak pect of a proposed energy measure.

title: ST. PETERSBURG ENDS ITS POPULATION CURB
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 4After listening for two hours to citizen protests at a public hearing, the St. Petersburg City, Council today reversed its decision setting a population ceiling for the city so low that it would require 25,000 present residents to move away.

title: $50,000 in U.S. Aid Sought For New Kinnelon Library
description: KINNELON, April 4  The board of trustees of the library in this, exclusive suburb in Morris County will submit a request tomorrow for a $50,000. Federal grant for the planning of a new library, thus meeting the April 5 deadline for such requests.

title: Boxer Is Hospitalized
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, April 4 (AP)Hugo Chansa, middleweight boxing champion of Zambia, was hospitalized yesterday, six hours after being knocked out in the fifth round of a bout against Don McMillan of Scotland on Tuesday night. He had staggered to his corner, where he told his seconds he felt dizzy and confused. Then he collapsed.

title: MAEU TESTIFIES ON HUMPHREY GIFT
description: LOS ANGELES, April 4Robert A. Maheu testified today that by prearrangement he delivered $50,000 in cash to Hubert H. Humphrey, in 1968 when Mr. Humphrey was Vice President.

title: Fed Revises Its Roles On BankMerger Role
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) The Federal Reserve Board announced today revised rules under which its 12 district Federal Reserve banks can approve bank holding company formations, bank acquisitions and bank mergers.

title: Todd Reported Recovering From Slight Heart Attack
description: TRENTON, April 4 (AP) The Republican state chairman Webster B. Todd, suffered a slight heart attack on Monday and is recovering at ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center New York, it was disclosed to day.

title: Presidential Panel's Report Calls for an Expanded Effort Against Heart Disease
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 The report of a Presidential study panel calling, for a much expanded national effort against heart disease was made public today a year and a half after it was completed.

title: Countersuit Is Filed by A.T.&T. Against MCI Communications
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company accused MCI Communications, Inc., yesterday of unfair competitive practices and attempts to monopolize the privateline communications business that A.T.&T. dominates.

title: 2 Arrested in Abduction
description: BUFFALO, April 4 (AP)A West Virginia couple wanted in the kidnapping of a Roanoke, Va., woman was arrested near here yesterday. Larry G. Cole, 27 years old, and his wife, Bonnie, 23, are accused of abducting Betty Ann VanBalen last March 6. She was released unharmed the next day after her husband paid a $25,000 ransom demand.

title: Assembly Votes Against Barring Girls From Little League Teams in the State
description: TRENTON, April 4  The state's Little League baseball teams lost their fight to bar the admission of girl players by a score of 38 to 39 in the State Assembly today.

title: Shut Out By Parent
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 4 (UPI)Bernie Parent recorded his 12th shutout in goal and set two National Hockey League records tonight as the West Division champion Philadelphia Flyers achieved their 49th triumph, beating the New York Islanders, 40.

title: A Proper Day For Homer 714
description: CINCINNATI, April 4 Henry Aaron, who wears number 44, hit his 714th home run today on the fourth day of the fourth month. It was his 96th home run against the Cincinnati Reds, and the 54th here  43 at nowleveled Crosley Field, 11 in Riverfront Stadium. He has hit more homers against the Reds than against any other National League team.

title: Soviet Attacks U.S. Press on Kissinger
description: MOSCOW, April 4Pravda today accused The New York Times, The Washington Post and other American newspapers of obvious political sabotage of SovietAmerican negotiations because of pessimistic reports that Secretary of State Kissinger bad failed to achieve negotiating breakthroughs during recent talks here.

title: City Seeks Most of State Fund To Support Private Bus Lines
description: The city is moving quickly to claim the bulk of $5.9million in state funds to aid private bus lines under the masstransit assistance legislation signed last Monday by Governor Wilson.

title: JapaRhodesia Trade Link Are Alleged
description: TOKYO, April 4  Japan has become involved in a controversy over charges that Japanese companies are secretly trading with Rhodesia in violation of United Nations sanctions against such trade.

title: RETURN OF YUGOSLAV IN SLAYING IS SOUGHT
description: The office of the Bronx District Attorney, Mario Merola, is to dispatch evidence today to a court in Yugoslavia, where the police have detained a man wanted for the slaying last year of a man in a bar in the Bronx.

title: Albany Assembly Acts
description: ALBANY, April 4The State Assembly today voted overwhelming approval of broad new controls, of campaign practices in a bill whose language conceded the prevailing lack of confidence and participation of the citizens of this state in the election process.

title: HELLER DEFENDS ROTHKO ESTIMATE
description: Lawyers defending the contract selling and consigning 800 paintings left by Mark Rothko to Marlborough Gallery tried yesterday in Surrogate's Court to discredit the art expertise of a witness called by the state's Attorney General.

title: 3Minute Hearing Frees Prisoner in Death Case
description: William A. (Tony) Maynard was freed on bail yesterday after six and a half years in jails in Germany and the United States for a crime he has steadfastly maintained he did not commit, and when he walked out of a State Supreme Court hearing, his knees momentarily buckled.

title: Wood, Field & Stream
description: ROSCOE, N. Y.  Dear Marianne Olmstead Lewis:

title: Contract Awards
description: The Honeywell Into mation Systems division Honeywell, Inc., said that the state of Michigan had ordere an $11rhilliom Honeywell computer system for use by its Department of Social Services.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: Page

title: Hussein and Sadat Confer
description: CAIRO, April 4 (Reuters)King Hussein of Jordan arrived in Alexandria, Egypt, today for talks with President Anwar elSadat.

title: ExMember of Parliament Found Dead Near London
description: LONDON, April 4 (Reuters)Desmond Donnelly, a former member of the House of Commons, was found dead today in a hotel room near Heathrow Airport. He was 53 years old.

title: BISHOP IS FACING EXPANDED INQUIRY
description: Immigration authorities say they have enough new information now to open an expanded investigation into charges that Bishop Valerian D. Trifa of the Rumanian Orthodox Episcopate of America participated in atrocities as an Iron Guard student leader in Fascist Rumania and misrepresented his record to gain naturalization.

title: Theater: Strindberg's Dance of Death
description: August Strindberg's The Dance of Death is one of the most horrifying pictures of hell and marriage that modern literature has given us. It is a duet for two people, ironic, macabre and horrid. It suggests that while marriage is most people's destiny, it is also a battleground for love and hatred and merely to be a survivor is worth some kind of longservice medal.

title: Backers of on sumer Bill Are Hopeful
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 Supporters of a proposed consumer protection agency; which was approved by the House last night, are confident that the legislation can overcome conservative opposition in the Senate.

title: Bill Backed in Jersey
description: TRENTON, April 4A highly controversial measure mandating the public financing of gubernatorial elections in New Jersey received initial legislative approval this evening in the Assembly.

title: Aaron Is Scheduled To Play Tomorrow
description: CINCINNATI, April 4Henry Aaron, whom the Atlanta Braves originally had hoped to hold out of their opening threegame series here so that he would tie and break Babe Ruth's record in Atlanta, announced after his 714th homer today that he'd be in the lineup for Saturday's nationally televised game.

title: E.C.A.C. Rule Allows OneSport Pros
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 4The Eastern College Athletic Conference voted today to permit its athletes to play professionally in one sport without losing intercollegiate eligibility in any other sport. This action at the, E.C.A.C.'s annual membership meeting follows the pattern established by the National Colleglate Athletic Association, which enacted a similar rule at Its convention last January.

title: Briefs on the Arts

Fortyone women were among the 70 new members inducted into the chapter, which has members in Pennsylvania and New Jersey. The fraternity's national bylaws were changed recently to allow women members.

title: All Aspects of Giacometti Reflected in Major Show
description: The art of Alberto Giacometti, the Swissborn painter and sculptor who died in 1966 at the age of 64, occupies a special place in the history of modern art. Whereas many of the most celebrated exponents of the modern movement were concerned to suppress all evidence of immediate experience in the interests of a more detached formal perfection, Giacometti persevered in an effort to align his art as explicitly as possible with Its existential sources. To realize this ambition, he radically altered the character of his art in midcareer, and in his last decades produced a body of work that came to symbolize for many people the universal modem life.

title: Books of The Times
description: Americans who are just beginning to rediscover China after 25 years of estrangement since the Communists took over the mainland In 1949 have been provided with a highly informative and attractive guide by Professor Hsieh, a Chineseborn geographer, who is on the faculty of the University of Pittsburgh. Atlases are generally viewed as bound collections of maps that help locate the obscure or notsoobscure place mentioned in dinnertable conversation or news broadcasts. The Atlas of China is not that kind of reference atlas. Instead it seeks to portray the physical environment of the world's most populous country, together with its cultural and historical evolution, in 273 blackandwhite maps that are tied together by a wellwritten text, designed both for research and for enjoyable reading. The reader eager to learn about China will find a wealth of information ranging from the frequency of coastal fogs and the habitat of the giant panda to a history of the country's railroad development and 28 city maps showing the configuration of old city walls and the urban spread of modern expansion.
