title: Film: 'The Christian Licorice Store'
description: Every concept of box-office poison admits to exceptions; from "Gone With the Wind" to "M*A*S*H," supposedly toxic subjects have yielded hits. And with all respect to the exhibitor who once stated, "I don't want any more movies where people write with feathers," even the currently despised costume picture could have a comeback. But some in Hollywood suspect that sports movies (along with films about writers) rarely do well. "The Christian Licorice Store," which is playing today and tomorrow at the First Avenue Screening Room, offers some clues about potential sports flops.The movie, which was made in 1971 by James Frawley, who later directed "Kid Blue," follows the fortunes of "the new golden boy of tennis," Beau Bridges, all floppy hair and ceaseless smiles. There's no excitement afoot while he smashes his way to victory, because we know we're watching actors and not a real game. So the grunts of effort fail to generate suspense. The camera does all the work; the players aren't athletesit's the movie maker who decides who will lose or win.Admittedly, "Licorice Store" has other problems. The tennis star has a soupy sense of alienation and a beautiful, adoring girlfriend (Maud Adams) who was given no character whatsoever. Eventually, he's corrupted by lush offers for hairspray ads and movie roles. Decadence is his destinyas established by a party scene where he strokes two young women (a timid imitation of "Blow Up") in a house with an unfilled swimming pool. Empty pools always mean that all's not well in Hollywood.However, one vast, brief pleasure lurks within this picture: a visit with Jean Renoir. He talks about a book he's writing, and says that "it's going slowlybut I hope safely," adding that it's not an autobiography but "some souvenirs" from the present and the future, as well as from the past. That glimpse of the great man is worth the movie's oppressively lyrical soundtrack, and a script crammed with lines like "This is a damn good racket," or "I think the nicest things in life happen when you're naked." There's also one gallantry that wipes the eye of history: A young woman says, "I would have loved the thirties," and is told, "The thirties would have loved you."

Nebody could even draw a walk. Nations lost the art of doing wild they had done well for centuries. Old friends and allies fell apart, and all heroes vanished from the face of the earth.

title: The Nixon Precedent
description: Maybe Gerald Warren, the White House spokeman, is right about the public attitude toward Richard Nixon's tax problems. Mr. Nixon has promised to pay the more than $400,000 the Internal Revenue Service says he owes in back taxes, and Mr Warren said that he thought most people in this country will consider it a closed case.

title: SERATORS CLASH WITH SCHLESINGER
description: WASHINGTON, April 4Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger and several Senators clashed today over American nuclear strategy and whether the Administration's new policies would make nuclear war more or less likely.

title: Cyclist Absolved In Drug Use Case
description: BRUSSELS, April 4 (AP)An international commission on drugging in sports ruled today that Eddy Merckx, a Belgian cycling star, did not intentionally take dope before participating in the Tour of Lombardy in 1973.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Guards at four state penal institutions resumed their normal duties yesterday after a oneday sickout protest over pay raises. A spokesman for the state said the morning shift of guards reported as scheduled at Rahway State Prison, the Yardville Youth Reception and Correction Center, the Bordentown Reformatory and the Skillman Training School for Boys. Governor Byrne's administration, which has offered the guards a 6 per pay increase, obtained a temporary injunction against the walkout.

title: City in Ohio Stays Calm Amid Twister's Debris
description: XENIA, Ohio, April 4It was too soonor too latefor tears in Xenia today.

title: French Presidential Race Is On Hours After Pompidou Burial

title: Dance: Jamaica Company

At 8, in the Juilliard Theater, the Juilliard Dance Ensemble opens Its spring season, with new works by Kazuko Hirabayashi and Anna Sokolow and a Pork from repertory directed by Peter Leonard, with the hool's chamber ensemble and piano soloist, Pawel hecinski. Repeated tomorrow at 8, Sunday at 3. Admission: $3, $4.

title: Bitter Pill Sweetened

The suggestion had something of an avalanche effect, as the Committee for Economic Development followed up with a proposal that would have resulted in a doubling of fees in public institutions over a fiveyear period. The private colleges' fear of competition from many lowcost public sectors, at a time of decline in the pool of applicants, added an element of acrimony, to the debate.

The House Banking Committee yesterday followed the lead of its Senate counterpart in shutting the door on any extension of wageprice controls beyond their scheduled expiration at the end of this month.

title: You Can Take the Fans Out of Yankee Stadium, But You Can't Take the Stadium Out of the Fans

But the story becomes nonfiction today when the Yankees open their Season against the Cleveland Indians at Shea Stadium. Homeless because Yankee Stadium is being renovated; the Bronx Bombers will play half their games in Queens. Long devotion to the Yankees and a cursory scouting of Shea, suggest it won't be a happy match.

title: Canadians Offer 'Ordinary Tenderness':The Cast
description: Jacques Leduc's "Ordinary Tenderness" (La Tendresse Ordinaire) is a French-Canadian film of complex sweetness, a truly poetic film that describes love entirely in terms of loneliness, friendship, boredom, the anticipation of reunion and the momory of moments of absolutely no apparent importance. The movie was shown yesterday at the Museum of Modern Art in the "New Directors/New Films," series and will be repeated there today at 11 P.M.Unlike most filmmakers who mistake pretty or bizarre images for poetry, Mr. Leduc uses images of sometimes stunning banality to describe the contradictory emotions of Esther and Jocelyn Levesque, the young couple who, in the course of the film, are meeting after a separation of four months. Jocelyn, who has been working in northern Canada, is returning to his home in Quebec by train and car. The move cross-cuts between their separate present states and their memories.The details of the film are as precise as good journalism, but the cumulative effect is as stunning and ambiguous as a nightmare. "Ordinary Tenderness" is, in fact, a film editor's dream, being composed of dozens of fragments that have one meaning alone and quite another in their various associations.Mr. Leduc, who is in his early 30's and began his career as a cameraman, seldom traffics in scenery for its own sake. The movie is set mostly insidein cramped kitchens, dining rooms, motel bedrooms and bars, in supermarkets and on trains. Like the early Andy Warhol, but less spectacularly so, Mr. Leduc is fascinated by the smallest, most common gestures, the drinking of a glass of beer or the maneuvering of a shopping cart through a supermarket. The gestures are not ends in themselves. They are the coded messages of lovers and friends."Ordinary Tenderness" is quite unlike any movie I've ever seen. I'm not sure it sustains its feature length. Yet it is a courageous attempt to create a narrative of the emotions tied only loosely to events. Conventional narrative cinema works just the other way around.

title: M'KENNA JAZZ PIANO HAS A LYRICAL FLOW

title: Screen:For Holidays, 'Sinbad' Sails Into Town
description: "The Golden Voyage of Sinbad" is one of those hardy perennials of the movie businessthe juvenile film that seems to sprout overnight in every imaginable neighborhood theater just in time for Easter, Passover and spring vacation.For the record, the plot calls for Sinbad (played by John Philip Law) in the service of the Grand Vizier (Douglas Wilmer) to race against the evil prince Koura (Tom Baker), through perils impressively created by the co-producer and special effects artist, Ray Harry-hausen, to the fountain of destiny, where youth, a shield of darkness and a crown of untold riches await.Children who revel in clean-cut heroes, villains given to spells and incantations and the kind of special effects that breathe life into mandrake root, ships' figure-heads, centaurs, griffins and statues of Kali (always a deity beloved of evil forces) will probably find it a happy concoction for passing a rainy afternoon.Intellectually, "Sinbad" sails on shallow waters polluted with such nickel-wisdom as "He who walks on fire will burn his feet," "Trust in Allah but tie up your camel" and "He who is patient, obtains."For older audiences, "The Golden Voyage" is not so much an excursion into the ancient past but into the modern past, when Raymond Massey was fomenting dissidence in northern India, Basil Rathbone was practicing condescension in Cartagena, and heroes, villains and bit-players spat pithy wisdom across clashing swords, like seeds at a watermelon-eating contest.In the presence of such fare as "The Golden Voyage of Sinbad" one feels constrained to close with a warning from the sage Santayana: "Those who cannot remember the past are condemned to repeat it."

description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) The President's Council on Environmental Quality has recommended steering offshore oil development away from the Southeastern Coast and the Gulf of Alaska in favor of areas off New England and the MarylandDelawareNew Jersey area.

title: MISS WOODS TIED TO HUGHES FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, April 5The Senate Watergate committee has heard testimony questioning a contention by a Presidential confidant, Charles G. Rebozo, that he had kept a $100,000 contribution from Howard R. Hughes intact and untouched, Les Whitten and Jack Anderson reported today.

title: U.S. Will Supply Arms And Factories to Saudis
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 The United States and Saudi Arabia announced today that they had agreed to expand economic cooperation and to negotiate an American supply of weapons for Saudi defense requirements.

title: Richard Crossman, 66, Is Dead; Leading Thinker of British Left
description: LONDON, April 5Richard Crosssman, an upperclass academic and an intellectual of politics, who was one of the Labor party's top leaders, died today at his home in Banbury, Oxfordshire. His age was 66.

title: International Car Show Opens, With Stress on Fuel Economy
description: The International Imported Automobile show opens a nineday run at the Coliseum today with a strong emphasis on fuel economy.

title: Mrs. Fenwick Quits Consumer Post To Seek Frelinghuysen's House Seat
description: TRENTON, April 5  Mrs. Millicent H. Fenwick resigned today as director of the State Division of Consumer Affairs, and will announce on Monday that she will seek the Republican Bean Congressional nomination in New Jersey's Fifth District.

title: An Owner of Yankees Indicted In Ship Concern's Election Gifts
description: WASHINGTON, April 5George M. Steinbrenner 3d, chairman of the American Shipbuilding Company and principal partner in the New York Yankees, was indicted today on felony charges growing from illegal campaign contributions to both Republicans and Democrats.

title: KUH WILL REVISE PLEA BARGAINING
description: District Attorney Richard H. Kuh of Manhattan said last night that he hoped to improve the pleabargaining system by ensuring that more information about defendants and their alleged crimes be made available to prosecutors, judges and defense lawyers before such bargains are struck.

title: Nixon Plans to Campaign In Michigan House Race
description: WASHINGTON, 5In the face of his Watergate and incometax troubles. President Nixon decided today t WASHINGTON, April 5In the face of his Watergate and incometax troubles, President Nixon decided today to campaign in Michigan next week in hopes of salvaging a Republican victory in a closely contested special election.

title: 6 Hurt in Oil Refinery Fire Are Awarded $12.2Million
description: CHRISTIANSTED, St. Croix, April 5 (AP)  A United States District Court has awarded six electrical workers more than $12.2million in damages as a result of injuries they suffered in an oil refinery fire on St. Croix in 1971.

title: Ousted Fireman Wins Plea On Job Lost Over Petition
description: RICHMOND, April 5 (UPI)The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit has ordered a South Carolina fireman reinstated with back pay, ruling that his dismissal infringed on his constitutional right to free speech.

title: French Output Index Rises
description: PARIS, April 5 (Reuters) The French quarterly industrial production index rose to 195 in the fourth quarter of 1973 from 185 a year earlier (1962 equals 100), the Finance, Ministry said today.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES IN SHARP DECLINE
description: Soybean prices dropped sharply yesterday, despite the fact that India was in the market for an unspecified amount of edible oils, such as that from soybeans.

title: U.S. to Broaden the Base Of Consumer Price Index
description: WASHINGTON, April 5The Labor Department, in devising modernized version of the Consumer Price Index, has decded to use the spending patterns of a broader segment of the population than in the past because 50 million persons now have their incomes pegged in whole or part to the index.; The disclosure of the 50million figurean entirely new estimatecame in a statement today by Julius Shiskin, Commissioner of Labor Statistics, explaining the change in the index that he plans. The new index will not be published until April, 1977.

title: LITTLE LEAGUE VOTES APPEAL OVER GIRLS
description: WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., April 5 (AP)  The executive board Little League Baseball, Inc., unanimously voted today to appeal to the New Jersey Supreme Court an order requiring that girls be allowed to participate this year.

title: TV: The Story of Jacob and Joseph
description: If successful Biblical dramatizations are at all possible, The Story of Jacob and Joseph deserves credit for a sincere effort. Filmed in Israel, the twohour production will be presented tomorrow evening at 8:30 on the American Broadcasting Company network as a major entry in television's EasterPassover scheduling.

title: EDWARD LILLEY, 86, DIRECTOR AND ACTOR
description: Edward Clarke Lilley, a director and former actor, died Wednesday at the Actor's Fund of America nursing home in Englewood, N. J., at the age of 86.

title: New Technology Uses Glassy Electronic Units
description: WASHINGTON, April 5A new technology in the electronics field is represented by two inventions using glassy Materials patented this week by Dr. Seymour Merrin and assigned to the Patents Innotech Corporation of Norof the walk, Conn., of Week which he is vice president. Patent 3,801,879 is for the first recorded diode made with glassy materials. The diode is the basic building block for

title: Market Averages
description: STANDARD & POOR'S INDEX

title: City Officials Put Festive Head on Reopening of Rheingold in Brooklyn
description: The reopening of the Rheingold breweries in Brooklyn, Orange, N. J., and New Bedford, Mass., was celebrated yesterday at a beer party in one of the 25 buildings of the Brooklyn plant at Stanwix and Noll Streets in the Bushwick section.

title: Bangladesh, India and Pakistan, in First Talks, Seek Normal Relations
description: NEW DELHI, April 5The Foreign Ministers of India, Pakistan and Bangladesh met today in a delicate effort to ease fric tions and shape normal relationships anion the three nations.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 1.6 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index for foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 234.6 from 233.0 last week.

title: DEMOCRATIC PANEL HEADED BY WAGNER
description: WASHINGTON, April 5Robert F. Wagner, the former Mayor of New York, was unanimously elected today to head the Democratic party's 25member Compliance Review Commissionthe group that will implement the new rules for selecting delegates to the 1976 convention.

title: CHAPIN CONVICTED OF LYING TO JURY ON SEGRETTI LINK
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 Dwight L. Chapin, President Nixon's former appointments secretary, was found guilty today on two counts of lying to a Watergate grand jury.

title: Service Merchandise Gets 7 Catalogue Showrooms
description: The Service Merchandise Company, Inc., has acquired for about $10million in cash and notes seven catalogueshow room operations from Malone & Hyde; Inc., which is discontinuing such activities to concentrate in other fields.

title: Ford Motor Canceling St. Louis Plant Layoffs
description: The Ford Motor Company announced yesterday that it had canceled its previously announced weeklong layoff of 1,300 workers at its St. Louis, Mo., assembly plant. The layoff had been scheduled for the week beginning April 15.

title: For Israelis, a CrisisPlagued Passover
description: JERUSALEM, April 5  Israelis began the Passover weekend this evening confronted with a tense military situation on the Syrian front and a political crisis at home.

title: Dialogue for the White House
description: WASHINGTON, April 5Did you say?

title: W. GURNEE DYER, MUSEUM LEADER
description: W. Gurnee Dyer, vice president of the American Museum of Natural History, died here Wednesday at the age of 71. He lived at 10 East 70th Street and in Portsmouth, R.I.

title: Edward Nixon Rebuts Stans Prosecution
description: Edward C. Nixon, the President's youngest brother, yesterday became the first witness for the defense in the MitchellStans trial, and promptly contradicted the testimony of two of the Government's chief witnesses.

title: STEWARDESSES WIN BACK PAY TO 1965
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) A Federal judge has ordered Northwest Airlines to pay back salary and interest to all stewardesses Who have been dismissed since 1965 for being overweight or who since 1968 have received less money than men doing the same work.

title: Dame Barbara's Colloquy of Forms
description: There is a quality of obdurate aloofness about the sculptures of Barbara Hepworth. Her component forms those rounded, abstracted shapes that look rather like polished sea stonesseldom interact or intermesh. Each structural element in one of her sculptures insists upon its own uniqueness, its perfected individuality. The forms may converse; they never conjoin.

title: 6 Ounces of Explosive Found at Paris Airport
description: PARIS, April 5 (Reuters)The police discovered six ounces of TNT in the basement of Orly Airport today as dozens of, foreign leaders were arriving for tomorrow's memorial service for President Pompidou, officials said.

title: RABBI NURENBERGER CALLIGRAPHER, DIES
description: Rabbi Bernard Nurenberger who devoted his life to the exacting art of reproducing by hand sacred scrolls and other ritual writings, died yesterday at the Booth Memorial Hospital, Flushing, Queens. He was 84 years old and lived at 14122 70th Road, Flushing.

title: 3 Newspaper Publishers Offer Package to Printers
description: The publishers of the city's three major dailies made public yesterday their full package offer to the Typographical Union, including a proposal that would give the newspapers the right to automate their composing rooms while protecting the jobs of regular fulltime job holders and also giving new guarantees to nonregulars, or substitutes.

title: Tragic Hoax
description: Either Patricia Hearst shares her captors' distorted views of the world or she has been coercedby drugs or terrorinto adding an exceptionally cruel twist to the suffering that her family has borne these past two months.

title: Fred Snodgrass, 86, Dead Ball Player Muffed 1912 Fly
description: VENTURA, Calif., April 5 (UPI)Fred Carlisle Snodgrass, who muffed an easy fly that helped to cost the New York Giants the 1912 World Series, died today at the age of 86. Mr. Snodgrass played nine years in major league baseball with the Giants and the Boston Braves before moving to California, where he became the Mayor of Oxnard, a banker and rancher. He described himself once as a quick tempered 20yearold kid, when he joined the Giants in 1908 for $150 a month.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Humane Society of Bergen County has warned parents who are considering purchasing baby chicks or ducklings for Easter that the young birds could transmit the highly infectious disease of salmonella to young children who handle them. The society also said that the practice of giving such gifts it Easter often results in cruel deaths for the pets, many, of which are ultimately thrown out or abandoned when their novelty wanes. The society also warned against giving turtles as gifts because, it said, they too transmit disease.

title: John J. Kenny Conviction Voided on Immunity Issue
description: TRENTON, April 5A state appeals court today overturned the 1973 extortion and misconduct conviction of John J. Kenny, former Hudson County Democratic chairman, on the ground that his testimony under a grant of immunity in an unrelated Federal corruption trial extended to the state's case against him.

title: Housing Critic flans Helm at H.D.A.
description: If apartment towers could be framed with irony and if wit could be mixed with sand and gravel to make concrete, then Roger Starr, the new Housing and Development Administrator, would be well on his way to solving what has invariably been described for the last 20 years as the city's housing crisis.

title: TeacherDefends Showing  Of Explieit Sex Flmstrip
description: A biology teacher at Monroe High School, under in vestigation by the Bronx District Attorney for showing his classes a filmstrip depicting sexual intercourse: and oralgenital sex, defended his acLions yesterday as a needed part of instruction in a human reproduction unit.

title: Inquiry Yields No Charges In Inmate Scalding Death
description: A grand jury that has bee investigating the scalding death of a 21yearold inmate at the Trenton State Prison failed hand up any indictments yes terday as it concluded the mail part of its inquiry.

title: Food Coop Helps Them Satisfy Those Park Avenue Tastes
description: Ebenezer Pinchpenny and Park Avenue Poverty aren't clubs where bankrupt millionaires clip supermarket coupons and eat peanut butter off tarnished silver spoons. They are Manhattan food cooperatives formed by uppermiddleclass consumers who decided that buying in bulk from whole sale markets is the best way to cope with low quality food and rising prices.

title: DR. SALVATORE D'AMICO
description: Dr. Salvatore D'Amico, a shipping and banking executive, died Thursday at his home in Rome. He was senior partner of D'Amico Societ di Navigazione of Rome and president of the Bank del Cimmino, also of Rome.

title: Thursday's Fights
description: Los Angeles  Ray Lampkin, 134 pounds, Portland, Ore., knocked out Chuchu Padilla, 135, Mexico, 9 rounds.

title: Hope for Energy From Inside Earth Rises
description: Several recent developments have increased hope that, despite major technological difficulties, energy extracted from the earth's deep interior can ultimately make a substantial contribution to the nation's power needs.

title: Popularity on Upswing For Metals as Powder
description: Sales of metals in powder form topped $350million; in 1973up 8.5 per cent from 1972and setting a record, the Metal Powder Industries Federation reported yesterday. In the past seven years, sales have risen by more than 50 per cent and the industry sees more expansion coming.

title: Nestegg Lottery Drawn
description: ALBANY, April 5 (AP)The winning number drawn in the New York Lottery's $2 Nestegg Special was 124362. Those with all six digits in the exact sequence win $200 a week for life. Those with fewer in se quence win smaller prizes.

title: WINE TALK
description: Passover seemed like the appropriate time to do a story on Manischewitz, probably the most famous name in kosher wine. Then came a letter from one of the company's agents outlining some of the more unusual facts about the concern.

title: Mediator to Enter Talks At the Washington Post
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI)  Negotiators for the Washington Post and the WashingtonBaltimore Newspaper Guild will meet tomorrow morn ing with a Federal mediator in hopes of averting a strike by 860 editorial and cornmerc alemployes of the newspaper.

title: COALITION REGIME INSTALLED IN LAOS
description: LUANG PRABANG, Laos, April 5  For the third time since 1957, a coalition GovernMent of neutralists, rightists and the proCommunist Pathet Lao was established today in Laos.

title: Music: Prolific Ginastera
description: Alberto Ginastera is a oneman music factory, with a production record that must make his a profitable enterprise. He turns out one new piece after another, each glittering with musical equivalents of chrome and gadgetry guaranteed to attract attention wherever they go. The Underpinnings may not always be the strongest, but you could hardly ask for more dazzling surfaces.

title: U.S. Will Supply Arms And Factories to Saudis
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 The United States and Saudi Arabia announced today that they had agreed to expand economic cooperation and to negotiate an American supply of weapons for Saudi defense requirements.

title: LONDON METAL MARKET
description: (In pounds sterling oar metric ton)

title: Old Times There Are Not Forgotten
description: ELBRIDGE, N. Y.I grew up on a back road in Georgia. The Sardis Road began in Millen, whose chief distinction was that Gen. William T. Sherman burned the train depot on his way to Savannah. It ended in Sardis, where there was a sawmill and little else when I grew up.

title: Nixon Plans to Campaign In Michigan House Race
description: WASHINGTON, April 5In the face of his Watergate and incometax troubles, President Nixon decided today to campaign in Michigan next week in hopes of salvaging a Republican victory in a closely contested special election.

title: Jamieson, Mahaffey Pace Golf
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., April 5 (AP)  John Mahaffey fashioned a fiveunderpar 66 today and tied Jim Jamieson at 133 for a onestroke lead in the, $220,000 Greater Greensboro golf tournament.

title: Delaware's Undoing?
description: While Delaware's former Governor, Russell W. Peterson, conscientiously presides over the nation's Council on Environmental Quality, the environmental quality his own state, ironically, is in peril. The high point of Dr. Peterson's governorship was the Coastal Zone Act, which barred certain heavy industries from a twomile strip of the state's 115mile coastline. Under his successor, that model conservation law has come under fire.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, APRIL 6, 1974

title: Notes on People
description: After two weeks of fruitless investigation, the Mexican police appear to have all but abandoned the search for John Patterson, the United States vice consul in Hermosillo, who vanished mysteriously on March 22. Miguel Nazar, assistant directer, of the Federal Security Agency, has returned to Mexico City after leading the search for Mr. Patterson, Who was presumed to have been kidnapped. In Hermosillo, the local Federal Judical police chief, Francisco Sahagun Baca, has resumed, his normal work in the antidrug campaign in that northwest Mexican city.

title: WorstHit Town Recalls Its 30 Seconds of Terror
description: BRANDENBURG, Ky., April 5This little river town, battered by a massive tornado on Wednesday, began trying to put Itself together today.

title: 200 on Haile Selassie's Staff Demonstrate for Benefits
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, April 5 (Reuters)About 200 members of Emperor Haile Selassie's palace staff  including the keepers of the palace lions  demonstrated today for better pay and the removal of certain court officials.

title: Soviet Skiing Starts From Bottom Up
description: DOMBAI, U.S.S.R.  The once upperclass and more recently bourgeois sport of Alpine skiing has begun to find favor in the land of the proletariat.

title: PhoneRate Proposal Stirs Wide Concern
description: It must have been gratifying to officials of the New York Telephone Company to hear witness after witness testify for three days this week that unlimited use of the telephone was indispensable to the old, the young, the homebound, the urbanite, the lonely and the involved. But the very importance of the telephone also made it clear that the process of utility ratemaking goes far beyond technicalities of equipment and arcana of dollars and cents; it goes to the heart of modern life and its quality.

title: U.S. JOBLESS RATE STEADY IN MARCH FOR THIRD MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, April 5The nation's unemployment rate took a slight dip in March, dropping from 5.2 per cent of the labor force to 5.1, the Labor Department reported today.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: London and Dublin Agree to Form AllIreland Council Despite Ulster Protests
description: LONDON, ?? 5Britain and the Republic of Ireland have agreed to move quickly to set up a Council of Ireland, despite the overwhelming opposition that Ulster Protestants have shown to the agreement.

title: Dr. Arthur Ippen, Expert On Harbors and Coastlines
description: Dr. Arthur Thomas Ippen, institute professor emeritus of water resource engineering at the Masshachusetts Institute of Technology, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home in Belmont, Mass. His age was 66.

title: STOCKS DECLINE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices closed lower on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market yesterday on news of a general rite by banks in their prime rates to 9 per cent.

title: Police Raids Upheld
description: The acquittal of ten narcotics agents in Alton, Illinois, who had forcefully invaded six homes in the course of what turned out to be mistakenidentity drug raids underscores the danger inherent in existing laws which sanction such abuse of police power. The case also offers new proof of the fundamental flaws in trials on charges of conspiracy. Conspiracy is equally vague and capricious a concept whether the alleged conspirators are dissenting from, or in support of, governmental policies.

title: Moheu Asserts Humphrey Called to Thank Hughes
description: LOS ANGELES, April 5 Robert A. Maheu testified here today that on the morning after the election in November, 1968 the Vice President, Hubert H. Humphrey, called to express his thanks for $100,000 in campaign contributions from Howard R. Hughes, then Mr. Maheu's employer.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: Williams Listening To Offer by W.B.A.
description: Dick Williams, former manager of the. Oakland A's, is considering the job of commissioner of the new World Baseball Association, the Associated Press reported last night.

title: 18 Horses Entered in Divided Gotham
description: A baker's dozen of eligibles for the Kentucky Derby are listed to perform in the Gotham Stakes at Aqueduct today. However, not all will be in common competition. The lack of a standout among the current crop of 3year  olds has prompted so many trainers and owners to think they have a chance for bigger and better things that the Gotham has attracted 18 entrants, only five nonDerby prospects. The New York Racing Association thus split the mile event into two divisions of nine horses each.At the Race Tracks

title: Record Price Is Set On Shipping Grain From Gulf to Soviet
description: A record charter rate of $31.54 a ton for shipping United States grain to the Soviet Union was disclosed yesterday by the Overseas Shipholding Group, Inc., a major ocean charter operator.

title: MRS. WITKOWSKI
description: Mrs. Jeanette Witkowski, chairman of the board of the Paderewski Foundation, which was founded in 1948 to provide scholarships for gifted musicians, died Monday at her home, 1215 Grand Concourse, the Bronx. Her age was 83.

title: CHAPIN CONVICTED OF LYING TO JURY ON SEGRETTI LINK
description: WASHINGTON, April 5Dwight L. Chapin, President Nixon's former appointments secretary, was found guilty today on two counts of lying to a Watergate grand jury.

title: People and Business
description: Donald F. Cawley, who resigned as Police Commissioner of New York City as of last Jan. 11, has been named to a senior position at the Chemical Bank. He will be a group vice president in charge of all aspects of securityplus purchasing and communication services.

title: 28 CHARGED IN SALE OF ILLICIT FEATHERS
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, April 5 (AP)  Illegal trafficking in the feathers of migratory birds for frandulent sale as Indian artifacts has been uncovered in Oklahoma, the Government announced today.

title: U.S. JOBLESS RATE STEADY IN MARCH FOR THIRD MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, April 5The nation's unemployment rate took a slight dip in March, dropping from 5.2 per cent of the labor force to 5.1, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Fund to Aid Guinea Rebels
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, April (AP)The Organization of African Unity said today it will set up a $450,000 fund for those guerrillacontrolled portions of Portuguese Guinea known to African nationalists as GuineaBissau, which has proclaimed its independence from Portugal. A spokesman said id Libya's delegation pledged an additional $500,009.

title: U.N. Delays Action On Extending Life Of Mideast Force
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 5A dispute between the Soviet Union and the United States forced the postponement today, of a Security Council session called to extend for six months the life of the 7,000man United Nations Emergency Force in the Middle East.

title: $16Million in Drugs Seized In Mexican Border Drive
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI)  Customs officers have seized $16million worth, of drugs, including 26 tons of marijuana, in a massive fiveweek operation along the United StatesMexican border.

title: Volkswagen Sees Loss
description: WOLFSBURG, West Germany, April 5 (AP)Volkswagenwerk, A.G., may have a loss in 1974, a company spokesman said today. He said that rising wages, materials and freight costs coinbinde with declining sales make it possible that the company will go into the red this year.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Grumman Aerospace Corporation, a unit of the Grumman Corporation, has received $11million in Navy awards, including $8.5million to modify the EA6B electronics aircraft and $2.5million for support equipment for the E2C electronics aircraft.

title: DR. MURIEL FARRELL
description: Dr. Muriel Farrell, professor of education at Lehman College of the City University of New York, died of cancer Thursday at her home, 469 Oak Street in Ridgefield, N. J She was 67 years old.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Saturday, April 6, 1974

title: Housing Critic Mans Helm at H.D.A.
description: If apartment towers could be framed with irony and if wit could be mixed with sand and gravel to make concrete, then Roger Starr, the new Housing and Development Administrator, would be well on his way to solving what has invariably been described, for the last 20 years as the city's housing crisis.

title: W. R. Grace Discussing Sale of F.A.O. Schwarz,
description: F.A.O. Schwarz, the famous American toy chain, was reported yesterday to be for sale to Franz Carl Weber, the Swiss toy retailer.

title: Albert Staehle, 74, Creafor Of Smokey the Bear, Dies
description: MIAMI, April 5 (AP)Albert Staehle, creator of Smokey the Bear, died of a stroke today at the age of 74. He lived in North Miami.

title: Bulls Win,  In Playoffs
description: CHICAGO, April 5 (AP)Chet Walker's two free throws in the final 14 seconds and the inspired, defensive play of Jerry Sloan led the Chicago Bulls to an 8483 victory over the Detroit Pistons tonight and 21 lead in their National Basketball Association playoff series.

title: TARIFF AGREEMENT EXPECTED IN E.E.C.
description: BRUSSELS, April 5Common Market diplomats now believe they can reach agreement with the United States within a month on tariff concessions to compensate the United States for trade losses caused when the European Economic Community accepted three new members last year.

title: 7 Killed in Bangladesh
description: DACCA, Bangladesn, April 5 (AP).More thus 24 gunmen dragged seven students from Dacca University today imed them up against a wall and shot and killed them, officials said. The killers got away by walking quietly out of the university area. There wasr no immediate explanation for the killings.

title: Knicks' Surge in Overtime Top Bullets, 10193, Evens Series
description: LANDOVER, Md., April 5The talent, determination and poise under pressure of the Knicks surfaced just in time tonight. A howling crowd of 19,035the largest in Maryland history for a basketball gamesaw the defending National Basketball Association champions magically rally from a 9point deficit with eight minutes to play and go on to stun the Capital Bullets in overtime, 10193.

title: Gas Stations Selling Bikes
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 5 (AP) A number of gas stations here are selling bicycles as well as fuel to motorists. Bob Seidman, president of Liberty Bell Tire Corporation, an automobile tire and parts distributor now offering bicycles to stations, said he turned to selling bikes to help customers keep above water during the gas shortage.

title: A.P. TO PHASE OUT ITS LOCAL SERVICE
description: Associated Press Local, a news service covering New York City affairs and operated by The Associated Press for newspapers and radio and television stations here, will be phased out over the next several months, it was announced yesterday.

title: Washington and Moscow Get Regular Airline Link
description: MOSCOW, April 5 (UPI) An Aeroflot airliner departed for Washington today, inaugurating regular weekly air service between the two capitals, the Tass press agency said.

title: Yanks Open/Here ets Visit hils
description: Using the Jets' locker room and the Mets' field, the Yankees officially, slipped into their status as the stepsisters, of Shek Stadium yesterday.

title: Backing GuineaBissau
description: At the recent Conference on the Law of the Sea sponsored by the United Nations, the world's newest republic was included as one of the participating countries. The inclusion of a representative of GuineaBissau did not pass unnoticed in Africa, in the anticolonial world, or indeed at the United Nations. But it was overlooked officially by the United States because this republic was not recognized by Washington.

title: Pope, Noting Worry, Asks Aid to Church in Holy Land
description: ROME, April 5  Pope Paul VI urged. Roman Catholics today to help strengthen the church in the Holy Land and to increase pilgrimages to Jerusalem.

title: 26 Senators Again Move To Halt Election Bill Debate
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI) Senate supporters of the controversial bill to provide public financing of Federal election campaigns, presented a new closure motion today to halt a filibuster against the bill.

title: Palestine Guerrilla Official Calls for Peace Negotiations
description: LONDON, April 5  The London representative of the Palestine Liberation Organization called for peace talks between Israel and the organization in an interview published here today in The Jewish Chronicle.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: More Supervision Demanded Over Sites of Liquefied Gas
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI) Representative John M. Murphy, Democrat of New York, today called for detailed and expanded Federal Power Commission authority over the locations of liquefied natural gas storage facilities.

title: MORTON IN SHIFT ON POWER PLANT
description: WASHINGTON, April 5The Department of Interior, which for nine years has supported the construction of a huge hydroelectric station on the New River on the North CarolinaVirginia border, has reversed itself.

title: Toyota Raises the Price of Cars and Trucks by 4.8%; Corolla 2Door Sedan Will Now Cost $2,199, Up $100
description: Toyota Motors Sales, U.S.A., announced yesterday in Torrance, Calif, that it had raised the price of its automobile and truck lines by 4.8 per cent. The price increase on the largest line of Japanese cars sold in the United States ranges from $100 to $300 with the average increase amounting to $1.51 The new price of the Corolla 1200 twodoor sedan was set at $2,199, up $100 from the former suggested retail price, and leaves it still the lowestprice new car sold in the United States. This compares with the current list price of $2,625 for the Volkswagen Beetle and $2,442 for the twodoor Pinto made by the Ford Motor Company.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: HOPATCONG, April 5Basketball, the game of the inner city, has found its way to New Jersey's lakes region and to Hopatcong High School.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: DALLAS, April 5 (AP)Steve McFarland of the University of Miami and Lori Wettlaufer of Ann Arbor, Mich., paced qualifiers today into tomorrow's finals in the 10meter platform event at the National. Amateur Athletic Union indoor diving tournament.

title: Peronist Leader Murdered In Third Killing in 24 Hours,
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 5 (Reuters)A Peronist leader was shot dead in a shantytown early today in the third political killing in Argentina in less than 24 hours. The police said that 27yearold Fernando Quinteros was dragged from his home and killed in the northwestern suburb of San Martin by two men claiming to be policemen.

title: Concert: Dorian Quintet
description: The Dorian Wind Quintet, resident these days at Brooklyn College, sallied forth from those academic cloisters on Thursday night for a concert at Alice Tully Hall, a concert that left little in its wake but admiration.

title: Cherry Blossom Rite Cut
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI) Faced with a second postponement because of rain, the National Cherry Blossom Festival yesterday canceled traditional lighting of the Japanese lanter by the daughter of Japan's Ambassador.

title: REBELS SET BACK CAMBODIA FORCE
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, April 5 (AP)  Insurgents besieging the coastal town of Kampot blew up all 10 of the garrison's artillery pieces with one shell, informed sources reported today.

title: Books of The Times
description: BUD: The Brando I Knew. By Carlo Fiore. 294 pages. Delacorte Press. $7.95. This week, Marlon Brando turned, 50. Marlon Brando at halfcentury? For almost 30 years, from A Streetcar Named De sire to Last Tango in Paris, Mr. Brando has captured the imagination and teased the curiosity of the American people. Is he our greatest, or merely our most influential, actor? The more he has removed himself from his public, the more he has been written about, much of it masquerading as unanthorized, in his case a euphemism for unauthoritative.

title: QE2 Easter Cruise Canceled as Liner Heads for Bermuda
description: As seagoing tugs took the crippled luxury liner Queen Elizabeth 2 under tow yesterday off Bermuda, the Cunard Line here announced cancellation of the ship's Easter cruise.

title: Dave Anderson
description: CINCINNATI, April 5For now, the old Netherland Hilton is the only hotel to have housed baseball players with 714 home runs. Babe Ruth slept here and now Henry Aaron is a guest. He Stood in a corner of the carpeted lobby, today, ext to some huge potted plants and below a weird wall design, He had returned from a promotional luncheon for Magnavox, the electronics company for which he is an ambassador, and he was wearing their light blue blazer under a raincoat. It was an off day in the National League schedule for the Atlanta Braves but there no longer is an off day in Henry Aaron's schedule. As a man of history, he is in demand for a word, a pose, an autograph. Two dozen newsmen surrounded him but so did several adult bystanders and teenagers. Small children slid through them for a closer look at the 40yearold slugger who, is expected to be on display against the Cincinnati Reds in tomorrow's nationally televised game.

title: PRICE INDEX BASE TO BE BROADENED
description: WASHINGTON, April 5The Labor Department, in devising a modernized version of the Consumer Price Index, has decided to use the spending patterns of a broader segment of the population than in the past because 50 million persons now have their incomes pegged in whole or part to the index.

title: Pam Grier Typed as'Foxy Brown':The Cast
description: Pam Grier, the well-endowed black beauty whose clothes, if not her good intentions, have been torn away in several bargain-basement epics such as last year's "Coffy," is in a rutto judge by "Foxy Brown," which crashed into the Cinerama and the 86th Street Twin theaters yesterday.In "Coffy," it may be recalled, she played a nurse who destroyed legions of bad guys and gals, both black and white, in a good fight accentuated by a plethora of gutter dialogue, against hoods, drugs and pushers who hooked her kid sister and blasted her boyfriend.Well, Jack Hill, the writer-director of "Coffy," has come up with no appreciable changes in doing the same for "Foxy Brown." This time, it's her kid brother, a pusher himself, and her man, an undercover narcotics agent, who are done in by those dope-dealing dastards. And, naturally, Miss Grier, who can handle a lover, a gun, a car, a plane, four-letter language and her enemies with ease, again emerges victorious over mobsters, a bigtime madam, pimps and rapists. Miss Grier is obviously durable but, unfortunately, is fast becoming a bore despite all the sex, brawls and gore in "Foxy Brown."

title: Interest Rates Climb Again As the Reserve Fails to Act
description: Interest rates continued to soar yesterday as the Labor Department reported a slight decline in unemployment and the Federal Reserve did nothing to relieve cramped conditions in the banking system.

title: Jamieson, Mahaffey Pace Golf
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., April 5 (AP)  John Mahaffey fashioned a fiveunderpar 66 today and tied Jim Jamieson at 133 for a onestroke lead in the, $220,000 Greater Greensboro golf tournament.

title: All Rangers Healthy and Playing
description: For only their third game in the last two years the Rangers expect to have all their regulars dressed for tonight's nexttolast regularseason National Hockey League game in Detroit against the Red Wings. Jerry Butler, the rookie forward who was put out of commission with a strained left knee on March 24, says he's ready to play the last two games. The 7:30 P.M. contest will be televised locally on Channel 9.

title: MAYOR OF DETROIT HOPEFUL ON CITIES
description: Mayor Coleman Young of Detroit said here last night that he saw a new commonality of interests developing in the attitudes of whites that would stem their flight from the nation's large cities.

title: Business Briefs
description: HARTFORD, April 15 (AP)  Four Connecticut banks were ordered today by a federal judge to give the Internal Revenue Service immediately, the names of former Hartford Fire Insurance Company shareholders who must pay capital gains gains taxes in the company's merger with the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

title: Pro Transactions
description: MONTREAL (NL)Sold Bill Stoneman, righthanded pitcher, to California for undisclosed amount of cash.

title: Orioles Top Tigers, 32, On Hit in 8th
description: BALTIMORE, April 5 (AP) Don Baylor, after failing on a squeezebunt attempt, hit a checkedswing single in the eighth inning, driving in the winning run today to give the Baltimore Orioles a 32 victory over the Detroit Tigers in the season opener for both teams.

title: For Cats, Part of the Remedy Is a Total Absence of Dogs
description: Hundreds of cats, thousands of cats, millions and billions and trillions of cats, wrote Wanda Gag in her classic children's book. Well, not exactly billions and trillionsbut it is estimated that 24 million cats are currently lording it over American households.

title: Defense Dept. Seeks Aid for Cattle Industry
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (Reuters)The Defense Department has asked the armed services to increase beef purchases where possible in order to help the depressed cattle industry.

title: Art: American Pop at the Whitney
description: About every new develop ment in the arts, both critics and the public tend to take sides. But few developments in the art of the last quarter century have generated quite so much division and debate as the pop art movement provoked when it first burst upon the scene in the early nineteensixties. For some faithful observers of modern art, pop represented the end of seriousness and the rise of a new vulgarity. For others, of course, it marked a sudden ascent to esthetic paradise. Whatever else pop art may have lacked, it quickly demonstrated its power to command attention.

title: Grenades Kill 11 in Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 5Two separate grenade explosions killed 11 people tonight and wounded 101, the South Vietnamese command reported. It blamed Vietcong terrorists in both incidents. No one was apprehended.

title: News Summary and Index
description: France will vote on May 5 for a President to succeed Georges Pompidou. The date was set at a meeting of the Cabinet. More than 40 chiefs of state or government, including President Nixon, will attend a requiem mass for Mr. Pompidou in the Cathedral of Notre Dame in Paris today. [1:4.]

title: BASF to Double Its Investment In U.S.
description: The BASF group of companies, the large West German Chemical combine, announced here yesterday that it would double its United States investment over the next several years from its present $400million.

title: Review of Tony Award Rules Called by Theater League Chief
description: Richard Barr president of the League of New York Theaters and Producers, said yesterday he would call a meeting of the Tony Administration Committee after this year's awards are presented on April 21 to reexamine the method of nominations for the awards as well as the method of voting.

title: Brezhnev Reported to Address Special Meeting of Party Aides
description: MOSCOW, April 5Leonid I Brezhnev has given a secret address to an unusual meeting of organizational officials of the Soviet Communist party held in Moscow from Tuesday to Thursday, the Soviet press disclosed today.

title: State Police Group Asks Superintendent to Resign
description: EAST BRUNSWICK, April 5 (UPI)The NewJersey State Troopers Fraternal Association has demanded the resignation of Col. David B. Kelly, as superintendent of the state police, charging that the failed to back troopers during a contract dispute.

title: INQUIRY IS SOUGHT ON BILL'S SPONSOR
description: TRENTON, April 5 (AP) The Legislative Joint Ethical Standards Committee today notified Assemblyman Morton Salkind, Democrat of Monmouth, that a citizens petition had been filed asking for an investigation of his sponsorship of a utility bill.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: Open Interest
description: Friday, April 5, 1974.

title: TAPE COMPROMISE FAVORED BY FORD
description: DENVER, April 5  Vice President Ford expressed concern today that a headtohead confrontation between the White House and the House Judiciary Committee over requested taps recordings might increase the chances of impeachment of President Nixon.

title: ROBERT LIVINGSTON, ELECTRONICS LEADER
description: Robert C. Livingston, former president of International Instruments, Inc., of New Haven, died Tuesday at his home in New Canaan, Conn. His age was 65.

title: For Israelis, a CrisisPlagued Passover
description: JERUSALEM, April 5  Israelis began the Passover weekend this evening confronted with a tense military situation on the Syrian front and a political crisis at home.

title: Miss Rassas Wed To John McAuliffe
description: Miss Margot Frances Rassas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George James Rassas of Winnetka, Ill., was married to John McAuliffe of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. McAuliffe of Cohasset, Mass., in SS. Faith, Hope and Charity Roman Catholic Church in Winnetka yesterday evening. The Rev. George J. Rassas, the bride's brother, performed the ceremony.

title: LAWYER REPORTS F.B.I. HEARST PACT
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 5 A prominent San Francisco lawyer said today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation agreed last week to give the kidnappers of Patricia Hearst time tol make a getaway if they released her inharmed.

title: PRESIDENT MOVED BY TAXFUND OFFERS
description: A group of Louisiana Republicans and an Illinois attorney announced yesterday separate fund drives to help President Nixon pay almost $500,000 in back taxes.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Appellate Division of the New Jersey Superior Court overturned the 1973 extortion and misconduct conviction of John J. Kenny, former Hudson County Democratic chairman, on the ground that his testimony under a grant of immunity in an unrelated Federal corruption trial extended to the state's case against him, The court ruled 2 to 1 that Mr. Kenny's testimony in the Federal case, touched on and thus invalidated the state's prosecution of him. The New Jersey Attorney General's office indicated it would appeal today's decision.

title: Key Men in the Laotian Coalition
description: A favorite of the royal Household since birth, Prince Souvanna Phouma was trained to assume leadership, and as a neutralist in the EastWest struggle he has long been regarded as the one man who could forge unity among the divergent Laotian factions. His shrewd and sophisticated continuation of a family tradition of public service has brought his divided country through a decade of recurrent crisis.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: BLACK ARTISTS The history of black artists and their art in America is as long as the country's history. Tomorrow, two events will take note of that history in appropriate surroundings.

title: OIL REFINERY URGED IN NEWINGTON, N.H.
description: OIL REFINERY URGED IN NEWINGTON, N.H.

title: Iowa State, S. Hug Lead Gymnastics
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., April 5 (UPI)Iowa State and Steve Hug of Stanford defending champions, carried narrow leads into the secondround optional exercises in the 32d annual National Collegiate gymnastics championships.

title: Nixon Paid No Employer Tax on Maid in '69 but Took Deduction
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 President Nixon neglected to pay Social Security taxes for a maid he employed at his San Clemente home in 1969, though he took one quarter of the wages he paid her as a busiiness deduction on his own tax return, according to the Congressional study of Mr. Nixon's taxes.

title: CONED ASKS STATE TO RUN NEW PLANT
description: ALBANY, April 5The Consolidated Edison Company's chairman, Charles F. Luce, has asked that the state take over one or more of the utility's generating plants now under construction and that it provide substantial tax relief for the company.

title: NEW ELEVATOR UNIT AT WESTINGHOUSE
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yesterday development of a computercontrolled, solidstate elevator system that is said to provide energy savings of at least 25 per cent in most installatons.

title: MORATH PIANO RAGS MIXED WITH PATTER
description: Max Morath's first appearance in New York in five years at the Town Hall Interludes series on Wednesday could not have been more timely. Mr. Morath, whose affectionate performances of Scott Joplin's piano rags for the last 14 years helped to stimulate the current interest in Joplin and ragtime, was able to tell his listeners that Scott Joplin won the Oscaran allusion to the fact that the musical background for The Sting, based on Joplin compositions, won the Academy Award as the year's best score.

title: Whose Ambassador?
description: The tendency for ambassadors abroad to lose contact at home after a while and to become in effect the spokesman to their own country of the government which they are accredited is common and probably unavoidable. The extent to which this affliction has impaired the judgment of the American ambassador to South Vietnam, Grahani Martin, is evident in, his proposal that Senator Edward Kennedy not be given an honest and detailed answer to questions the Senator had raised about American policy in Indochina.

title: Fire Chief Picks Aide
description: CHICAGO, April 5 (AP)Coach Jim Spavital of the World Football League's Chicago Fire completed his staff of assistants today with the appointment of Chuck Dicker??, former University of Ilinois tatkle, as defensive line coach.

title: F.B.I.'s Action in '61 Called Still Harmful To Hopes of Blacks
description: The president of the cowltry's largest allblack organization of scholars in African and AfricanAmerican affairs, charged yesterday, that an F.B.I. program reportedly put into effect in 1961 to block the development of black leadership and unity had created in blacks a sense of depression and hopelessness.

title: Jewish Congress Asks That Saxbe Resign From Post
description: WASHINGTON, April 5The chairman of the national governing council of the American Jewish Congress said today that Attorney General William B. Saxbe should either resign or be removed from office by the President because of comments Mr. Saxbe made Wednesday regarding the Jewish intellectual.

title: The Hidden Political Hand
description: PARISApart from the fact that it was his nature to fight to the end, President Georges Pompidou had a special reason for remaining at France's helm in the Elyse palace until, almost at the last instant, he stole off like a wounded bear to die in his own lair on Paris's lovely Ile St. Louis.

title: HANOI'S CHIEF VISITS YUGOSLAV LEADERS
description: BELGRADE, April 5Premier Pham Van Dong of North Vietnam arrived here today for four days of talks with Yugoslav leaders.

title: Federal Centers to Open Today To Coordinate Tornado Relief
description: WASHINGTON, April 5The secend stage in Federal relief efforts in Southern and Middle Western states that were ravaged by tornadoes on Wednesday will begin tomorrow when field offices of the Federal Disaster Assistance Administration are established to coordinate relief operations in the stricken areas.

title: Music: Menuhin Is Poised and Artistic
description: Erich Leinsdorf, who has been, having a heavy New York season, was the conductor at the New York Philharmonic concert on Thursday evening. For a change, he did not have to step in at the last minute to replace a missing conductor; this was his scheduled stint. He had as his violin soloist Yehudi Menuhin, who played the Second Concerto by Bla Bartok. The other two works were Weber's Oberon Overture and Schumann's Second Symphony.

title: Youth, 18, and His Nephew, 10, Slain; Son of Bradley Beach Policeman Held
description: NEW SHREWSBURY, April 5  An 18Yearold youth and his 10yearold nephew were shot to death early today in a densely wooded area here, in what the police described as dispute stemming from a rivalry over a girl.

title: Reported City Settlement Ends SheetMetal Workers Walkout
description: Sheetmetal workers who had walked off their jobs on municipal construction projects returned yesterday as a settlement was reported between their union and the city over the hiring of black and Puerto Rican trainees.

title: Liner France to Stay in Service Despite Financial Difficulties
description: PARIS, April 5The liner France, whose future has been in the balance since the increases in oil prices beginning late last year, will resume scheduled service between Le Havre and New York next month, its owners announced here today.

title: Fire Disrupts IRT Service
description: A smoky fire believed caused by a thirdrail short circuit just east or the Grand Central Station of the IRT Flushing line caused a 25minute interruption of service on the line during the rush hour yesterday. The fire was reported at 4 P.M. in the tunnel beyond the eastern end of the platform. No injuries were reported.

title: Robert J. McNitt, inventor Aided George Westinghouse
description: Robert J. McNitt, a retired. scientist and engineer, died Thursday in a nursing home in Middletown, N.J., at the age of 94. He lived at 486 Sycamore Avenue, Shrewsbury, N.J.

title: Bridge: Vancouver Spring Nationals Were Triumph for Canadians
description: The Spring National Championships in Vancouver, British Columbia, last week were in every way a Canadian triumph. The organization Was outstanding, thanks to a local team headed by Norman Chapple and Phil Wood. And Canadians did unexpectedly Well in the Vanderbilt Knockout teams.

title: An Owner of Yankees Indicted In Ship Concern's Election Gifts
description: WASHINGTON, April 5George M. Steinbrenner 3d, chairman of the American Shipbuilding Company and principal partner in the New York Yankees, was indicted today on 14 felony charges growing from illegal campaign contributions to both Republicans and Democrats.

title: Edward Nixon Rebuts Stans Prosecution
description: Edward C. Nixon, the President's youngest brother, yesterday became the first witness for the defense in the MitchellStans trial, and promptly contradicted the testimony of two of the Government's chief witnesses.

title: LAWYER REBUTS NIXON ON '69 TAX
description: LOS ANGELES, April (UPI)Frank DeMarco, Jr., President Nixon's tax lawyer, says it is ridiculous to believe that the President did not know about his tax returns. The lawyer is worried that he may be made a scapegoat.

title: Con Ed Seeks State's Aid In Easing Financial Plight
description: ALBANY, April 5The Consolidated Edison Company's chairman, Charles F. Luce, has asked that the state take over one or more of the utility's generating plants now under construction and that it provide substantial tax relief for the company.

title: COALITION REGIME INSTALLED IN LAOS
description: LUANG PRABANG, Laos, April 5  For the third time since 1957, a coalition Government of neutralists, rightists and the proCommunist Pathet Lao was established today in Laos.

title: Market Place: Golden Cycle Moves Upward
description: Gold stocks are in vogue now, and one of the late bloomers in Wall Street is the Golden Cycle Corporation, which did net derive any its profits last year from goldmining activities.

title: Kennedy Assails Nixon for Forgetting Cities
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy accused the Federal Government yesterday of having forgotten the cities, whose problems along with the problems of the poor and of veterang, he said, are the shameful results caused by those who believe that property is more important than human life.

title: Insurer Backs NoFault Bill
description: WASHINGTON (AP Experiences in four key states that had planned to introduce nofault insurance in 1973 demonstrate the need for speedy Federal action on this question, according to a spokesman for the nation's largest automobile Insurer.

title: Health Plan Progress
description: The new National Health Insurance Bill sponsored by Senator Edward M. Kennedy and Representative Wilbur D. Mills constitutes a sensible compromise between President Nixon's proposal and the earlier, more costly, Kennedy plan. While responsive to the serious deficiencies in the delivery of existing health services, the new measure has the virtue of also being fiscally feasible. Its total cost of about $40 billion annually would be virtually the same as that of the Administration's plan.

title: Wide Range of Funeral Prices Found Here in Consumer Study
description: A consumer group's study of funeral homes in New York City and on. Long Island has found a wide disparity in price and frequent refusal or reluctance to give prices by phone.

title: Study Asserts Informal Quota Limits Women on School Boards
description: HOUSTON, April 6The National School Boards Association was told today that there were not enough women on school boards and that their underrepresentation was no accident.

title: Making it in Atlanta
description: ATLANTA. In the heart of town, tourists line up for the Gray Line's black Atlanta tourthe only one of its kind in the country. It touches all the bases of what may be the single most prosperous black community in the Unitd States: the pseudoGeorgian facade of the 69yearold Atlanta Life Insurance Co., the largest privately held black business in the country, with $85million in assets; the gleaming new 12story Citizens Trust Company Bank Building, housing the 53year old black bank; Ebenezer Baptist Church on, Auburn Avenue, where young Martin Luther King Jr., was raised and later preached through a decade of Southern history; Paschal's Motor Hotel on Hunter Street, famous for its fried chicken, its jazz lounge and the unofficial black political clubs that congregate there almost daily for breakfast; the nearby redbrickandrnagnoha campuses of the Atlanta University complex, with 6,000 students in four colleges, one graduate school and a seminary; the fancy new Pacesetters apartment complex, where young black singles enjoy the kind of posh clubhouse and spacious swimming pool common to dozens of whitedominated apartment developments on the north side of town; Down the, Hatch, a fondueandwine, spot in the entertainment district of Underground Atlanta, popular with blacks who come to take in the easy jazz sounds of the Paul Mitchell Trio. And now, of course, Dr. King's gravesite.

title: Albany Prepares for Redistricting to End Racial Inequities Here
description: The State Legislature's political leaders and staff experts are preparing for one of the most delicate and potentially controversial redistricting projects in years in terms of New York City race relations.

title: Dance
3Day Holiday Advances
description: BOSTON, April 6 (AP) Patriot's Day would be a threeday holiday next year under legislation given initial approval an the Massachusetts House Thursday. The usual April 19 holiday would be extended through April 21.

title: Russians Find Artifacts Like American Indians'
description: MOSCOW, April 6 (AP)Soviet scientists have discovered archeological, evidence supporting the theory that ancient. Asian tribes migrated to the American continent over what is now the Bering Strait, according to the official press agency Tass.

title: The man who made parks FLO
description: A Biography of Frederick Law Olmstead. By Laura Wood Roper. Illustrated. 555 pp. Baltimore: Johns Hopkins University Press. $15.

title: SPRING BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: The world of commerce, like nature, observes its peculiar rites of spring.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Pro Track Meet Draws 20,000 in Japan

title: Motorman Is Slain When He Interrupts Holdup in a Bright
description: A Transit Authority motorman was shot and fatally wounded early yesterday when he inadvertently interrupted a holdup by four armed men in a Queens brothel, according to the police.

title: Nixon Sent Bill to Increase Federal Retirement Income
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) The Senate sent to President Nixon this week a bill to provide increased monthly payments for retired Federal employes and their survivors.

title: Program at Upsala To Benefit Nurses
description: EAST ORANGE  Educational opportunities for registered nurses will receive a shot in the arm in a new program to be offered at Upsala College this fall.

title: Auto Ads Stress FuelSaving ClaimsSpecific or Implied
description: Looking at some of the car advertising around these clays, it's easy to imagine a Meeting between a car maker and an ad maker with the former saying, For God's sake, Charlie, can't we get some sort of gas mileage claim in there?Great, J.B. But do you have one?

title: SmallTown Realities With a Touch of Fantasy
description: OF the American Scene painters of the nineteenthirties and forties, Charles Burchfield (18931967) remains an atypical case. Although his art was, in fact, based on realitymore specifically, on the realities of smalltown America; the dour November light on frame houses, trees burdened with winter, fields ablaze with summer sunthere was, too, a gentle, but uncompromising, vein of fantasy in his work. Burchfield's aim was not usually verismilitude. He seemed to have a penchant for the symboliceven the visionaryaspects of the American landscape.

title: Johnson Track Aide
description: CARBONDALE, Ill., April 6 (UPI)Jan Johnson, a winner of the bronze medal in the pole vault for the United States in the 1972 Munich Olympics, has joined the track and field coaching staff at Southern Illinois University, Coach Lew Hartzog announced today.

title: Letters: More on The New Brutalism
description: To the Editor:

title: DR. SYDNEY SCHWITZ
description: Dr. Sydney Schwitz, assistant clinical professor of orthodontics at the Brookdale Dental Center of New York University, died Friday of a heart attack at his home, 8 Fox Meadow Court, Woodbury L.I. His age was 50.

title: CHANGE REPORTED IN QADDAFI'S ROLE
description: CAIRO, April 6The official Egyptian press agency reported tonight that Col. Muammar elQaddafi, Libya's intensely nationalistic and unpredictable leader, had been relieved of his political, administrative and traditional duties.

title: McFarrand, Miss Ely Win
description: DALLAS, April. 6 (UPI)Steve McFarland of the University of Miami, retained his 10meter platform title and Janet Ely survived a poor final dive to take the women's platform event in finals of the Amateur Athletic Union national indoor diving championships tonight.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: If Panel Urges Impeachment, Tentaive Plans Call for House Vote in July and Senate Trial in August
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 Congressional leaders are quietly malting arrangements for a House vote in late July on whether to impeach President Nixon and a Senate trial, if necessary beginning in late August.

title: F.B.I. Tactics at Issue in Indians' Trial
description: ST. PAUL, April 6Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation are Under heavy attack in Federal District Court here for their investigation of last year's invasion of Wounded Knee, S.D., by Indians.

title: Mrs. Sophy Regensburg, 88, Primitive Painter, Is Dead
description: Mrs. Sophy Pollak Regensburg, an American primitive arlist, who began painting in her mid60's a few years after the death of her husband, Melville E. Regensburg, a cigar manufacturer, died yesterday at her home, 200 East 71st Street. Her age was 88.

title: Nancy Brookfield, a Designer, Married to Brian D. Fitzgerald
description: Miss NancyBarber Brook field daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel L. Brookfield, and Brian David Fitzgerald, son of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Fitzgerald of Brooklyn, were married yesterday afternoon at Christ Episco pal Church in Rye.

title: Violent Mystery Of the Tornado
description: The winds in the funnel of a tornado may swirl at 300 miles an hour or morefour times as fast as those in a hurricane. At the edge of this funnel, trees are uprooted; in the center, build= ings explode and railroad cars are blown over. No storm is more violent, none so little understood. A series of these twisters swept across a large part of the South and Midwest last week, killing at least 350 persons, highest tornado toll in 49 years. Thousands of persons were made homeless and damage was put at more than. $1billion.

title: Miss Judy A. Darr Wed to C. P. Eaton
description: Miss Judy Ann Darr, a systems analyst with the New York consulting firm of Delta Resources, was married yesterday afternoon to Charles Paterson Eaton, an institu tional salesman with H. C. Wainwright & Co., a New York brokerage firm. The Rev. Donald Campbell performed the ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church in Stamford, Conn.

title: Yanks Win Shea Debut Amid Spitball Controversy
description: After having lost their last four season openers in such places as Boston, Baltimore and Yankee Stadium, the Yankees tried a new place yesterday for their 1974 opener, and the move worked as they defeated the Cleveland Indians, 61.

title: Princeton The Famous Teach Modestly
description: PRINCETON Like most Princeton professors, Errjc Goldman generally promotes class discussion by asking, questions of his students. But when Dr. Goldman, who teaches, history, reaches the period during which  he happened to serve as a special consultant: to President Lyndon, B. Johnson, he becomes unusually reserved and suggests that the students direct queries at him.

title: MRS. WILLIAMS. SANDS
description: Mrs. Shelagh Doherty Sands an Englewood, N. J., civic work. er and wife of William S. Sands, president of the New York overseasrealestate firm bear. ing his name, died Friday of cancer in St. Luke's Hospital She was 52 years old and lived at 18 Brayton Street, N. Engle. wood.

title: Divorce Cases On Rise In Nassau
description: MINEOLA A sharp rise in the number of matrimonial cases handled by the State Supreme Court in Nassau County was reported in the 1973 annual report of the courts in the county.

title: Ordinary, Very Ordinary
description: WHEN a playwright wants to write a play about very ordinary people he is, of course, not obliged to make them extraordinary just to interest us. But he should have a few extraordinaryor at least mildly illuminating perceptions of his own to offer, whether he is report ing on the boors, of suburbia in their pinepaneled prisons or any other miserable species known to inhabit the earth today. Jay Broad, author of The Killdeer at the Public, is no man to put himself to such afterhours work. He is content to indicate, in very barebones form, the routine family battles that bedevil a failing salesman (does the elder son the car tonight, and what time must he be home?), the stupefying conversation of his boss (one anecdote about a car chase through Manhattan is reported block by block), the disaffection of his wife and the drunken invasions of his neighbors.

title: News of the Stage
description: The allmale production of Shakespeare's As You Like It that Britain's National. Theater put on in 1968, will open a North American tour at the Geary Theater in San Francisco on July 8 preparatory to a limited Broadway engagement this winter.

title: THEODORE M. SCHWARTZ
description: Theodore M. Schwartz, former chairman of the. Employes Compensation Appeals Board of the Department of Labor in Washington, died in Miami on Friday evening, apparently of a heart attack. He was 65, years old and had lived in Miami since his retirement last year.

title: Cutting the Energy Cots in a House Is a Snap ...
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y. To a passer by's eye, the spacious house on Weiworth Avenue  white clapboard, arched doorway, brass knoekerpioects a solidity that is comfortable if a bit dowdy, To the more specialized eye of Norman D. Kurtz, the: place is a giant sieve, leaking 5cent kilowatt hours and 35cent galof heating oil.

title: Sewer Line Sought, In Gardiner Estate
description: ALBANY Suffolk's Southwest Sewer District plans to cut an 80footwide swath across the entire northern border of the Gardiner estate parkland in Bay Shore, it was disclosed here last week.

title: Alive in The City
description: In 1967, when August Heckscher agreed to step into the expansive (or shall we say expanded) shoes of Robert Moses, Newbold Morris and Thomas Roving as New York's fourth Parks Commissioner, he was quite fully justified in wondering whether he was master of all the trades he would be asked to practice.

title: Jan Dysart Is Bride
description: Miss Jan Hazen Dysart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Dysart Jr., of Needham, Mass., and Douglas John DiLaura, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nuncio A. DiLaura of Westwood, N. J., were married yesterday afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church in Needham. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Harold Chase, assisted by the Rev. Charles Cushing, the bridegrooin's uncle

title: Mrs. Dillingham Married to a Justice
description: Mrs. Constance Shepard Dillingham of St. Paul was married there yesterday afternoon to Associate Justice James C. Otis Jr. of the Minnesota State Supreme Court.

title: Junior League Unit Plans a Symposium
description: CRANFORD  In observance of its 50th anniversary, the Junior League of Cranford and Elizabeth will hold a symposium at the Ramada Inn in Clark on April 24. The theme will be Growth and Its Implications for Union County.

title: Course in English Asset for Hospital
description: MORRISTOWNMrs. Magdalena Sassano came to New, Jersey from her native Argentina in 1970, planning to learn English as soon as she got settled here.

title: Marine Biology Students Attempting to Cut Pollution
description: At John Dewey High School in Brooklyn, the activities of the Marine Biology Club go far beyond the usual collecting of samples and putting them in glass jars.

title: A President's predicament
description: If you want to keep your secret, don't get elected President Ail the United States. Thomas Jefferson was probably not much more divided between his private passions and his public professions than other politicians in what is supposed to have been America's Age of Reason. But he was by temperament and philosophy a natural opponent of slavery who owned 10,000 acres and belonged to a slaveowning, pretentiously aristocratic, selfindulgent Virginia gentry who found the possession of slaves natural to their economy and their selfimportance. So he owned many slaves. One of these slaves, a lovely, almost white, quadroon, Sally Hemings, became at 16 (after Mrs. Jefferson's death) Jefferson's concubine. She eventually bore him five children, four of whom lived, all of whom knew, who their father was. It was only after Jefferson's death that, by his will, they were either freed or allowed to leave voluntarily. If Jefferson had freed them and their mother during his lifetime, they would have had, by law, to leave the state of Virginia.

title: Restoration in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 6 (AP) The Federal Government is investing $9million to restore a dozen colonial buildings around Independence. Hall for the 1976 Bicentennial. The house where Thomas Jefferson drafted the Declaration of Independence will be rebuilt, and the tavern where bonquets for the Continental Congress were held will be restored.

title: O.E.O. GAINS FAVOR WITH OLD CRITICS

description: PARAMUS  Consumer complaints here are now being handled by teenagers in a pilot project sponsored by the Federal Trade Commission.

title: OIL NATIONS SEEK TO AID POOR LANDS
description: WASHINGTON, April 6Officials of 13 oil exporting countries are to meet tomorrow in Geneva to discuss a proposal to establish their own development aid fund for needy countries and use the skill and facilities of the World Bank.

title: Europe's Market In Crisis
description: PARISThe European Common Market, founded in the uncertain years after World War II, has in the past often reacted to crisis by fostering closer cooperation among its members, but, as the community now confronts the gravest threat since its foundation, its future is far from hopeful.

title: ATOMTHEFT CURB URGED IN REPORT
description: WASHINGTON, April 6The Government should establish a security force to prevent thefts of nuclear material that could be used to fashion a crude bomb and blackmall society, a study for the Ford Foundation's energy policy project recommends.

title: Televivion
