title: Accountant Says White House Ordered Deductions Later Called Improper
description: LOS ANGELES, April 7President Nixon's tax advisers were ordered by the White House to take some of the deductions from his taxable income that were later declared improper by Congressional investigators according to Mr. Nixon's personar accountant.

title: 2 More Garrisons In Cambodia Taken By the Communists
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, April 7 (UPI)  Communist forces overran two more Government positions north of Phnom Penh today bringing to six the number of Cambodian garrisons that have fallen to, the insurgents in five days.

title: JERSEY CITY TAKES STEPS TO RENEW WATERFRONT AREA
description: Jersey City, a factory town chronically afflicted by a declining tax base and high unemployment, is in the process of hammering out what Abraham Wallach, its planning director, calls the first tangible signs of a proposed industrial park on 700 acres of waterfront land.

title: Mastodon's Bones Draw A Throng to Reservoir
description: NORWOOD, April 7A throng of sightseers came to the site of a reservoir expansion today to see the bones of a Dwarskill mastodon that perished in a clay bog here 9,000 to 10,000 years ago.

title: Bobby Unser Triumphs in Trenton 200
description: TRENTON, April 7  Bobby Unser, won the Trentonian 200 today. Auto racing lost.

title: Advertising: That Sporting Life
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., April 5  To a certain select group of admen  most of them in the middlemiddle to upper middle age bracketthe first Friday of April means only one thing  the annual Colihan Cup matches.

title: Theater: Touches of Urban Poetry
description: Has every generation sought for a New York lost, or, a youth mislaid on the way to the cleaners? Probably.. At least nothing of particular originality. emerges froth Herb Gardner's Thieves, which opened last night at, the Broadhurst Theater, Yet there are moments of insight and even touches of urban poetry as Mr: Gardner paints a nocturne of a city and a threnody to a relationship.

title: Strollers See Magic in Midtown Plaza
description: A pinkeared human bunny in a white fur suit strolled Fifth Avenue in midtown yesterday as city streets and parks, warmed to life by April sunshine, opened their new season as the best show in town. Anybody who blinked, however, could have missed both the scheduled and unscheduled performances in Grand Army Plaza, where the avenue crosses 59th Street.

title: ETHIOPIAN TROOPS IN A NEW UPRISING
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, April 7 (AP)Rebel troops took over a government radio station in eastern Ethiopia today and demanded the resignation of the country's deputy chief of staff.

title: Censorship Guidelines for Jails Issued by U.S. Judge on Coast
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 7 A United States district judge has issued unusually comprehensive guidelines for prison officials on the extent they can censor the mail and reading material of inmates.

title: PLANS ARE STEADY FOR INVESTMENT
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 Although nearly one out of five United States companies altered its capital Investment plans up or down because of the sudden energy shortage that emerged last year, the overall total of planned investment for 1974 was hardly changed, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Alimony, Child Support or the Civil Jail
description: Sol Greenberg was so well liked at Brooklyn's Samuel J. Tilden High School back in the late nineteenforties that his class voted him Mr. Tiden when they graduated. A lot of those people would be surprised, he said the other day, to know that Mr. Tilden is in jail.

title: Research Group Says Farmers in Giant Coops Have Lost Control to Managers
description: WASHINGTON, April 7Giant agricultural cooperative that operate like corporations often subvert the interests of farmer members for whom they were formed, a report by a public interest research grout charged today.

title: 13 Doctors in Chile Reportedly Slain After the Coup
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 7At least 13 doctors are believed to have been killed and 40 reportedly placed in detention centers by Chile's military junta in the aftermath of the violent coup that overthrew the Marxist coalition last September.

title: War Without End, Amen
description: Since the United States first intervened in Vietnam, we have had two broad alternatives of policy. One is to try to impose our desired pattern on the area by force of arms. The Other is to withdraw, leaving the Vietnam problem to the Vietnamese and doing only what we can to encourage accommodation.

title: OPPONENTS SPEAK AGAINST OIL PORT
description: DOVER TOWNSHIP, April 6 The proposal for a publicly constructed deepwater oil port off New Jersey drew a good deal of opposition today during a special hearing of the State Senate Committee on Energy, Argiculture and Environment.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Against the white walls of Bergdorf Goodman's fourth floor plant shop hang a Variety of potted plants suspended inside macram hangers. The Garden Path, as the shop is called, is having them all done by a young woman named Carolyn Bell.

title: CONEY I. AWAKENS FOR A 146TH TIME
description: Arthur Kramer; who has been on the job in his greasestained overalls most days now for 40 years, watched with satisfaction yesterday as the Thunderbolt climbed toward the Coney Island sky and then thundered down the rollercoaster rails in a tumult of clattering wheels and children's shouts.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Gun incidents in the city's public schools involving students and outside intruders in 1973 more than doubled Over 1972, according to a report submitted by the office of School Chancellor Irving Anker to the State Commission of Investigation. The study reported that 58 separate incidents involving guns that fire a pellet of some kind had been recorded since 1968, with a high of 24 incidents in 1973, compared with nine in, 1972.

title: Basis for College Student Aid Is Periled
description: The timehonored assumption that parents have the primary responsibility for the college education of their children is being increasingly challenged, creating a situation that could shake the financial base upon which American higher education is built.

title: Cologne Museum Shows Treasures of Roman Past
description: COLOGNE, Germany The city of Colonia Claudia Ara Agrippienensium has just opened a spectacularly successful RomanGerman museum, so informal that a small library in the middle of ancient tombstones, columns and vases features copies of Astrix, the French comic book about two Gauls who pun their way anachronistically through Caesar's Rome.

title: TENOR FROM ITALY NEW FOR RIGOLETTO
description: There was a new Duke in the otherwise familiar cast of the New York City Opera's Rigoletto yesterday afternoon. Milking a generally positive impression in his American debut was Tullio Pane, a tenor with considerable experience in San Carlo, Florence and other opera centers in his native Italy.

title: Alimony, Child Support or the Civil Jail
description: Sol Greenberg was so Well liked at Broolyn's Samuel J. Tilden High School back in the late nineteenforties that his class voted him Mr. Tilden when they graduated. A lot of those people would be surprised, be said the other day, to know that Mr. Tilden is in jail.

title: I.R.S. HERD SILENT ON NIXON PENALTY FOR BACH TAXES
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 Donald C. Alexander, the commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service, refused today to say yes or no when asked if the $432,787.13 owed in back taxes by President Nixon may have included a negligence penalty of 5 per cent.

title: Sun Oil Raises Gas Price By One Cent at Wholesale
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 7 (UPI)  The wholesale price for Sun Oil Company gasoline went up one cent a gallon over the weekend.

title: Benar Heifetz, Cellist, Dead; Taught at Manhattan School
description: Benar Heifetz, the cellist, died Friday night in Manhasset (L.I.) Medical Center Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 30 Deepdale Drive, Great Neck, L.I.

title: Spain Seeking 10 Basques For Murder of Premier
description: MADRID, April 7  A short Item in the newspapers here day reminded the Spanish that the killers of Premier Luis Carrero Blanco are still at large, more than three months after the assassination Dec. 20.

title: About New York Susan Looks, Carefully, for Susan
description: Susan Welsher was waiting for a bus at 79th Street and Fifth Avenue on a raw gray day recently, when a man approached her. He carried a briefcase, and was ordinary looking in a pleasant way, and when he drew near he said, Hello, Susan.

title: Israeli Leadership Considering a Plan To Shuffle Cabinet
description: TEL AVIV, April 7Leaders of Premier Golda Meir's Labor party tonight discussed a plan to shuffle the Cabinet as a way to forestall a theatened vote this week in Parliament of no confidence in the Government.

title: Passover on the Golan Heights Brings Another Artillery Duel
description: TEL AVIV, April 7 (Reuters) Israeli and Syrian artillery blazed all day today in the Golan Heights area.

title: Klansman to Get New Trial In Killing of Black Minister
description: GADSDEN, Ala., April 7A Gadsden KKu Klux Klansman, Aubrey Gene Arledge, accused in the killing of a black minister last November, will get a new trial in June. A Circuit Court jury of 11 white men and one black man said Friday that it was hopelessly deadlocked, 7 to 5, and the judge declared a mistrial.

title: Aaron: Hitless 3 Times
description: CINCINNATI, April 7Henry Aaron, playing under orders of the commissioner of baseball, did not hit a home run today  or even hit the ball out of the infield  and thereby won a change of venue back home to Atlanta for his attempt to break Babe Ruth's record.

title: Five Proposals Analyzed For West Side Highway
description: A moderate reconstruction of the elevated West Side Highway from the Battery to 72d Street, smoothing out the kinks, would cost only 20 to 25 per cent as much as a proposed six  lane expressway built to Interstate highway standards.

title: Brinegar and Frelinghuysen Are Guests in Soviet Union
description: MOSCOW, April 7 (AP)The Soviet Government flew a group of American officials to Moscow yesterday on its stateowned airline's inaugural flight from Washington for an allexpensepaid look at the Soviet Union.

title: 7 A's Runs Knocked In By Jackson
News Summary and Index
description: President Nixon, one of the chiefs of state who attended memorial ceremonies in Paris for President Pompidou on Saturday, conferred with other heads of government over the weekend, including leaders of the Soviet Union and Japan, said au revoir to a friendly crowd of Parisians and returned to Washington. His aides said that the trip demonstrated that Mr. Nixon, even though he is under an impeachment inquiry at home, is needed in the Presidency if the United States is to continue as a leader for world peace. They were clearly relieved at the absence abroad of opposition and criticism that the President sometimes encounters at home. [1:45.]

title: Ulasewicz Says His Work Did Not Involve U.S Data
description: HADLEY, N. Y., April 7 (AP)  Anthony T. Ulasewicz said today that his role as a private investigator for the White House did not give him access to Government documents.

title: Council Predidency Getting New Look Under O'Dwyer
description: It was his second day as City Council President and Paul O'Dwyer hadn't even honked up the phones in his office. A distraught delegation of Rheingold Brewery workers was on the doorstep with something else in mind for him. They would all lose their jobs, they said, unless be came to their aid.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: On March 22, Richard Nixon sent to the Congress a package of proposed amendments to the Clean Air Act of 1970 that would seriously weaken the act. Among these proposals are measures to postpone for no longer than ten years the implementation of transportation control plans required for 38 cities and extend interim vehicle emission standards required for 1975 model year passenger cars through model year 1977. Should the Congress adopt these proposed amendments, then New York and other major U. S. cities will be burdened with high levels of unhealthy vehicularrelated air pollutants for many more years than necessary.

title: Concorde Grounded?
description: When he was Minister of Technology in the previous Labor Government, there was no more enthusiastic champion of the BritishFrench supersonic Concorde aircraft than Anthony Wedgwood Benn. Now back in office as Secretary for Industry, Mr. Benn has taken another look at the joint project; he describes what he has found as frightening.

title: Nixon Is Back From Paris After Talks With Leaders
description: WASHINGTON, April 7President Nixon returned to Washington today after conferring with Soviet and Japanese leaders and saying au revoir to a friendly crowd of Parisians on the street this morning.

title: Richard Gets 27th Goal and Record
description: ATLANTA, April 7 (AP)Jacques Richard scored his 27th goal as the Atlanta Flames won their last regular game of the National Hockey League season today, defeating the Pittsburgh Penguins, 63. The firstperiod gal gave him the team's season scoring record.

title: The Energy Crisis and Clean Air: Situation Yields Mixed Benefits
description: A 12yearold girl says she sees the stars and the moon for the first time. A pregnant woman is startled to see the Empire State Building stand out so sharply against the sky. A heavyset man (a former airpollution control official) says he is convinced that air pollution is down in New York City because there is less traffic.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: CON ED TO RESUME MONTHLY READING OF MOST METER;
description: Consolidated Edison will begin eliminating estimated billing throughout its system within the next month and read most of its customers' meters monthly, the company's chairMan, Charles F. Luce, said yesterday.

title: Pope Cautions the Young on Protests
description: ROME, April 7  Pope Paul VI, in a Palm Sunday rite in St. Peter's Basilida, called on young people throughout the world to give witness to Christ but warned them against what he described as puritanical zealotry.

title: Dakota Indians' Lawyers Allowed to Call Officials
description: ST. PAUL, April 7Federal District Judge Fred J. Nichol agreed today to allow defense attorneys to call former highranking officials in the Justice Department to find out whether agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation had used illegal means in investigating the takeover of Wounded Knee, S. D., by dissident Indians last year.

title: Kingman Slams Homer
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 7 (AP)  Dave Kingman hit a threerun homer in the first inning and Bobby Bonds hit a tworun double in the third to give the San Francisco Giants an 84 victory over the Houston Astros today.

title: Moritz Bows in Final
description: HASTINGS  ON  HUDSON, N.Y., April 7The first Hastings Cup tennis tournament was won today by Marcelo de la Serna of Jamaica, Queens. He defeated Kirk Moritz of New York, 76, 75, in the final. Mimi Kanarek of Hastings beat Debbie Campbell of Old Greenwich, Conn., 76, 62, in the women's final. The matches were at the River Club.

title: Free Libertarian Slate Given
description: The Free Libertarian party, whose first Mayoral candidate, Francine Youngstein, outpolled all other minor parties with 8,818 votes here last November, yesterday announced a statewide ticket: Jerome Tucille, of White Plains, a teacher at the New School for Social Research, for Governor; Percy L. Greaves Jr. of Dobbs Ferry for State Senator; Louis. J. Sicilia of Manhattan for Lieutenant Governor, Bob Flanzer of Brooklyn for Controller and Leland Schubert of Manhattan for Attorney General.

title: Fuel Oil Cantracts To Be Traded Here
description: Any large user of fuel oil, such as an electric utility, that wants longterm price guarantees on both the cost of that commodity and its tanker freight rate will soon be able to obtain themfor the first time.

title: Study on Atlantic Eruptions Hints Gain in Ore Search
description: Within the deep valley that bisects the Atlantic Ocean evidence has been found of current eruptions of the type that it is now widely, believed have been responsible for many of the world's ore deposits.

title: Sweaters for the Fall: Very Thick, Very Long
description: PARIS, April 7  Next fall, after you acquire your new nearanklelength full skirt and your kneehigh Cossack boots, the next piece of fashion equipment you will need is a sweater. That's the word from the French apparel producers who have just concluded their semiannual presentations of their collections.

title: Newcombe Captures Net Final
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 7 (AP)John Newcombe fought off an early challenge by unseeded Jeff Borowiak for a 64, 61 victory in the final of a $50,000 World Championship Tennis circuit tournament, today.

title: Personal Finance: IncomeTax Hints
description: Preparing income tax forms is not exactly the greatest indoor sport in the world, but if you have a legitimate reason to postpone the day of reckoning, the Internal Revenue Service can be very accommodating.

title: From Spalding to Reach to AaronThere's Been Only One Baseball
description: Henry Aaron's historic 714th home run that satisfied many a fan was something special to a group of people in Chicopee, Mass.the people at Spalding, the nation's second largest sportinggoods manufacturer, and maker of all baseballs used by both major leagues.

title: Nixon Is Back From Paris After Talks With Leaders
description: WASHINGTON, April 7President Nixon returned to Washington today after conferring with Soviet and Japanese leaders and saying au revoir to a friendly crowd of Parisians on the street this morning.

title: Padres Victimized, 92
description: LOS ANGELES, April 7 (AP)Jim Wynn and Steve Garvey homered and Ron Cey drove in three runs with two doubles and two singles today, carrying the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 92 victory and a threegame sweep of the San Diego Padres.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Monday, April 8, 1974

title: Daily News Employe Killed
description: An employe of The Daily News was killed yesterday when a company delivery truck, in which he was riding collided with an auto and overturned in Brooklyn, the police reported. Luther Speller, 45, years old, of Roosevelt, L. I., a driver filling in for the regular helper on the truck, was fatally injured after being thrown, out of the truck and pinned beneath it, the police said. The accident occurred at 7:40 A.M. at Quincy and Patchen Avenues.

title: Sandtman Campaign Debt Involved in Court Action
description: The split in the New Jersey Republican party generated by Representative Charles W, Sandman Jr.'s gubernatorial candidacy last year has continued to plague the party, precipitating a legal squabble and a political confrontation over his campaign debt.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: News Summary and Index
description: President Nixon, one of the chiefs of state who attended memorial ceremonies in Paris for President Pompidou on Saturday, conferred with other heads of government over the weekend, including leaders of the Soviet Union and Japan, said au revoir to a friendly crowd of Parisians and returned Washington. His aides said that the trip demonstrated that Mr. Nixon, even though he is under an impeachment inquiry at home, is needed in the Presidency if the United States is to continue as a leader for world peace. They were clearly relieved at the absence abroad of opposition and criticism that the President sometimes encounters at home. (1:45.)

title: S.C.I ASKS CHANGE IN COMPENSATION
description: TRENTON, April 7 (AP)The Workmen's Compensation System in New Jersey is a massive and complex monolith that should be overhauled to eradicate the pattern of irregularities, abuses and even illegalities, according to a report by the State Commission of Investigation.

title: Pearson, on Late Surge, Takes Rebel 500 Again
description: DARLINGTON, S.C., April 7 (UPI)With 10 laps of the Rebel 500 stock car race remaining today, David Pearson dipped low going into the first turn, took the lead from Bobby Allison and raced on to his third consecutive victory in the event.

title: Music: Polish Program
description: Postwar Poland has produced some of the finest music of this century. So the New York debut yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall of the Warsaw String Quartet Bacewicz with a Polish program took on more than ordinary interest.

title: OIL NATIONS FAIL TO AGREE ON AID
description: GENEVA, April 7The oil exporting countries decided today to set up a special fund to help developing countries, but they failed to agree on how much money to put into the program.

title: OIL NATIONS FAIL TO AGREE ON AID
description: GENEVA, April 7The oil exporting countries decided today to set up a special fund to help developing countries, but they failed to agree on how much money to put into the program.

title: FESTIVAL STAGED BY PUERTO RICANS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, April 6On the Douglass College campus today, two giant flagsone, the lone star Puerto Rican ensign and the other a banner symbolizing Puerto Rican independencehung from the rear of the Hickman Hall auditorium.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April, 8, 1974

title: Morses & Equipment
description: WANTED horse lender & voterinary assistant. Must hove knowledge of diseases, riding, & showing. 8384581.

title: Rangers Topple Canadiens, 64, in Playoff Preview
description: In what New York fans hope was a preview of coming attractions, the Rangers handled the Montreal Canadiens surprisingly well last night, beating their upcoming foes in the playoffs, 64, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Libyan Aides Say Qaddafi Is Still Undisputed Leader
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, April 7 (AP) Diplomatic and Government sources said today that Col. Mummer elQaddafi remained the undisputed leader of Libya despite reports elsewhere in the Middle East that he had been stripped of his power.

title: 600 in Troubled Indian Tribe A wait 50Million Payment
description: KLAMATH FALLS, Ore.I am perfectly capable of managing $120,000 myself, said the Indian woman. My brother here is not.

title: Field Guide Author Turns to Painting
description: OLD LYME, Conn.Probably by the time most people Teach the age of 65 they would be content to have written, illustrated and/or edited 14 books that have sold 7 million copies in 12 languages.

title: Senate Aides Study Talk By Rebozo and Abplanalp
description: WASHINGTON, April 7Investigators for the Senate Watergate committee have established that Charles G. Rebozo, the Presidential confidant, flew to the Catskill fishing retreat of Robert H. Abplanalp, President Nixon's millionaire friend, about a week before a controversial $100,000 campaign contribution was returned last year, wellplaced sources said today.

title: Music: Symphohy's Malcolm Tribut
description: The Symphony of the New World, which is so sympathetic to minority musicians that it even makes room in Its firstviolin section for a left  handed, player, paid homage at lid concert on Sunday in Avery Fisher Hall to one of the heroes of minority history in this country. With Leon Thompson conducting the orchestra and Betty Allen singing and declaiming the strenuous vocal part, T. J. Anderson's In Memoriam Malcolm X had its first performance.

title: ROBBERY SUSPECT TRAPPED IN CAB HERE
description: A robbery suspect was seized by the police yesterday after a cab driver locked him in his taxi and a passerby helped to block his escape. The police gave the following account of the incident:

title: End of G.M. Strike Voted
description: LORDSTOWN, Ohio, April 7 (UPI)Local 1714 of the United Automobile Workers approved a contract offer today and voted to return to work, ending a strike at the General Motors complex here that began Friday.

title: India, Pakistan and Bangladesh Unable to Resolve Bihari Issue
description: NEW DELHI, April 7India Pakistan and Bangladesh struggling to calm tensions or the subcontinent, differed sharply today over the tense is sue of the Bihari minority in Bangladesh.

title: Hearing in Texas Slayings
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 7 (Reuters)A pretrial hearing into the case against a 17yearold alleged mass slayer begins sere tomorrow. State District, Judge Preston Dial has indicated he wants a closer look into disclosures made by Elmer Henley Jr. to the police when they dug up the bodies of 27 young victims in Houston last August. Mr. Henley is charged with six murders.

title: Kathleen Taft, Student, Is Bride
description: Miss Kathleen Laura Jeanne Taft, daughter of Mrs. Francine Moulignie Reid of New York and Patrick Taft, a lawyer, was married yesterday afternoon to Stephen Eberly Thompson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Thompson of Portland, Ore. The Rev. Robert Martin of the Christian and Missionary Alliance performed the ceremony in the Yorktown Community Church in Yorktown Heights, N. Y.

title: A TAPES AGREEMENT REPORTED BY RHODES
description: WASHINGTON, April 7, (Reuters)The White House and the Congressional impeachment committee were reported today to have worked out a way to break a deadlock over the committee's demand for tapes of President Nixon's conversations.

title: AROUSTAMIAN GIVES KAMANCHEH RECITAL
description: Andranik Aroustamian, a kamancheh virtuoso from the Soviet Union who recently moved to America, gave, a nicety exotic recital Saturday night in Tully Hall. The kamancheh dates back to Persian times and is an ancestor of the violin. It has four strings and a spherical soundbox that rests on the left thigh of the seated performer, who plays it with a disproportionately long bow held horizontally by the right hand. At forte, the sound is not all that far removed from the violin; in softer moods, the effect is softer, drit er and more overtly oriental.

title: A Fortress Is Dented By Women
description: WASHINGTON, April 7Women have still to storm. the allmale fortress of the Gridiron Club, and while they, did not bring it down last night, they Certainly tunneled under the walls.

title: Books of The Times
description: THOMAS JEFFERSON. An Intimate History. By Fawn M. Brodie, 591 pages, Illustrated, Norton. $12.50.

title: ExKing Idris I of Libya Gets Egyptian Citizenship
description: CAIRO, April 7 (Reuters)President Anwar elSadat of Egypt has granted former King Idris I of Libya and his family Egyptian citizenship, according to the Middle East News Agency.

title: Toros Beat Crusaders In Playoff
description: TORONTO, April 7 (AP) Shutout goaltending by Gilles Gratton and two goals by a rookie center, Wayne Dillon, led the Toronto Toros to a 40 victory over the Cleveland Crusaders in the opening game of their World Hockey Association quarterfinal playoff.

title: Council Presidency Getting New Look Under O'Dwyer
description: It was his second day as City Council President and Paul O'Dwyer hadn't even; hooked up the phones in, his office. A distraught delegatian of Rheingold Brewery workers was on the doorstep with soinething else in mindfor him They would all lose their jobs, they said, unless he came to their aid.

title: Democrats Demand New Chief of V.A. In Reply to Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) Unsatisfied with President Nixon's promise of a full review of Veterans Administration problems, the Democratic Congressional leadership has called instead for replacement of Administrator Donald E. Johnson and other top management officials.

title: JAWORSKI PREDICTS YEARS OF WATER GATE
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (UPl) Leon Jaworski, the Watergate special prosecutor, said today that it may be two or three years before we've heard the last of Watergate.

title: KINKS FANS SHOW THEY'RE ZANY TOO
description: Of all the important, British rock 'n' roll bands of the nineteensixties, the Kinks are probably the best named. The Beatles, the Rolling Stones, the Who: All of them are really names of, convenience. But the Kinksthat is a name that evokes a delectable train of associations, simultaneously zany and rbellitms. And the group's appearances Saturday night at the Felt Forum did nothing to alter the image.

title: Charles Is Victor By Shot
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., April 7 (AP)Bob Charles of New Zealand came through with a 68 today and won the Greater Greensboro golf tournament by one stroke with a 270 total.

title: New Mood in Laos: Leftists Promote Conciliation
description: VIENTIANE, Laos April 7In the last few days, Laos, which has embarked on her third attempt at a coalition government in less than two decades, has been basking in a happy mood of homecoming and national reconciliation. Prince Souphanouvong, the tiitular Pathet Lao leader, returned to the capital after 11 years of sefimposed exile in the rugged hills of eastern Laos; he and his halfbrother, Prince Souvanna Phouma, emotionally reunited, traveled to Luang Prabang, the royal capital, where the King invested them as the pivotol figures of the new political arrangement; and then leftists, neutralists and rightists, attired in traditional sarongs and highbuttoned tunics, took their oaths of allegiance at Vientiane's most sacred pagoda.

title: Hearsts' Mexican Trip Called Unrelated to Abduction
description: HILLSBOROUGH, Calif., April 7 (AP) The parents of Patricia Hearst left San Francisco today for a trip, to Mexico.

title: Senator Bayh Urges Inquiry Of Motorola and Matsushita
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (Reuters)  Senator Birch Bayh, Democrat of Indiana, urged the Justice Department today to investigate the proposed acquisition of the television division of Motorola, Inc., by Matsushita of Japan for possible antitrust violations.

title: Kennedy Starts European Trip; Confers With Brandt on Europe
description: The Massachusetts Democrat who flew here from New York, arrived early this morning on a threeday factfinding visit, West German and American spokesmen said they had no details about the meeting, which was also attended by Egon Bahr, Minister for Special Affairs, and Foreign Minister Walter Scheel.

title: A. HAROLD FROST, 71, LED TRIAL LAWYERS
description: A. Harold Frost, past dean of the International Academy of Trial Lawyers, died Friday at his home, 101 Central Park West. He was 71 years old.

title: ELECTION FINANCING VOTED IN MARYLAND
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 7The Legislature of Maryland, a state in which there has been widespread allegations of political corruption, approved yesterday a measure providing partial public financing of elections in state and local campaigns.

title: Striking Newsmen, Voting On Latest Offer by U.P.I.
description: Striking editors, reporters, photographers and other new personnel for United Press International began 24 hours of voting at 2 P.M. yesterday on the latest contract offer by news syndicate, which it hopes will end the threeweekold strike.

title: Metric System Replacing Varied Measures in Asia
description: SYDNEY, Australia, April 1in Hong Kong, a syllabus has been introduced in primary schools to prepare children for the metric system that should be operating in the British crown Colony by the time they are adults.

title: Rangers Topple Canadiens, 64, in Playoff Preview
description: In what New York fans hope was a preview of coming attractions, the Rangers handled the Montreal Canadiens surprisingly well last night, beating their upcoming foes in the playoffs, 64, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Soviet Reports on Trade
description: MOSCOW, April 7 (AP) The Soviet Union now has agreements with 177 American companies for a wide range of scientific and technical projects, Dzhermen Gvishiani, deputy chairman of the Soviet Committee for Science and Technology, said over the weekend.

title: Beame's Defeated Rivals Are Among Those Giving Mayor Generally High Marks
description: Impatient about small things, but serenely confident that the big things are Moving the way he wants them to workmanlike but indifferent to the point of near invisibility about his public image, May, or Beame completes this week his first 100 days in office.

title: Christians and Jews Share Spirit of Their Holidays
description: On a day befitting the promise of April, Christians and Jews gathered in homes, houses of worship and outofdoor settings yesterday for Palm Sunday and Passover observances that recalled the bitterness of bondage and the hope of redemption.

title: Fisher Wins in Jipcho's First Defeat
description: TOKYO, April 7 (AP)Ben Jipcho of Kenya suffered his first loss of the track season today. Chris Fisher, of Australia, with a strong finishing kick, beat him in a onemile run in the International Track Association meet.

title: G.A.O. Sees Still Higher Costs On Destroyers Litton Is Building
description: Additional cost increases are likely in Litton Industries' multibillion  dollar destroyer program, largely because of labor problems for which no solution is in sight, according to a report from the General Accounting Office.

title: Weekly List of Mutual Funds
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: Donnecticut College Student Found Suffocated in Room
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., April 7 Eric G. Kidweli of Parsippany, N. J., a 20yearold senior at Connecticut College here, was found dead in his domitory room last night.

title: Yugoslavia Chiding Her moslems for Nationalism of Their Own
description: SARAJEVO, Yugoslavia, Moslem nationalism, a phenomenon rarely found outside Yugoslavia, is coming under increasing criticism by Communist leaders here who view it as a potentially dangerous and divisive force.

title: Bucks Rout Lakers and Take Series
description: MILWAUKEE, April. 7 (AP) The Milwaukee Bucks, with Kareem AbdulJabbar pouring in 21 points and sparking a fast break and relentless team defense, buried the Los Angeles Lakers, 11492, tonight to gain the National Basketball Association Western Conference playoff final,

title: Hi her Education for All, Through Old Age
description: ALBANYFor American higher education these are troubled times. The generous budgets are long gone, the baby boom has peaked, and applications are tapering off. Colleges everywhere are cutting back, trimming costs and, in some instances, grimly fighting for survival.

title: Pearson, on Late Surge, Takes Rebel 50 Again
description: DARLINGTON, S.C., April 7 (UPI)With 10 laps of the Rebel 500 stock car race remaining today, David Pearson dipped low going into the first turn, took the lead from Bobby. Allison and raced on to his third consecutive victory in the event.

title: OilExport Nations Face Internal Strife, Economist Reports
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countriesthe cartel of nations that has pushed up the price of oil by 400 percent in the last yearfaces serious internal problems and possible breakup by 1980 because of potential sharp conflicts of interests among its members, according to Walter J. Levy, the prominent and influential oil economist.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: HELSINKI, April 7 (UPI)The Soviet Union's world champion team exploded for five goals in the second period to rout Finland, the host nation, 71, today in the world ice hockey Championships.

title: Bridge:
description: The foursome that won the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship a week ago in Vancouver, British Columbia, is the youngest team ever to win this honor. The team captain, Joe Silver, a public defender in Montreal, is the old man of the squad at 33 years of age. His partner, Eric Kokish, also of Montreal, is a 26yearold mining analyst.

title: Israel Less Vocal on Europe but Unwilling to Forgive
description: TEL AVIV, April 4Israel's relations with Western Europe, one of the casualties of the October war, appear slowly to be emerging from the state of shock occasioned by what was regardedhere as Europe's proArab stance during the fighting.

title: Basis for College Student Aid Is Periled
description: The timehonored assumption that parents have the primary responsibility for the college education of their children is being increasingly challenged, creating a situation that could shake the financial base upon which American higher education is built.

title: Bill Threatens Influence of Fat Cats
description: The bipartisan campaign finance bill passed by the Assemby last week has far more impact than its ostensible purposethe reform of campaign financing in the wake of Watergate. The measure, if it be comes law, would have the ultimate effect of strengthening the role of the political party organizations in the nominating process by cutting down the impact of personal wealth and outside contributions.

description: Consolidated Edison will begin eliminating estimated billing throughout its system within the next month and read most of its customers meters monthly, the company's chairman, Charles F. Luce, said yesterday.

description: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union and deputy Premier Teng Hsiaoping of China arrived in New York yesterday for the United Nations General Assembly's special session on raw materials and development. The session will begin tomorrow.

description: CINCINNATI, April 7The afternoon began as baseball afternoons in April are supposed toas a rite of spring, full, of buoyancy and cheer and the anticipation of good things to come. No trace lingered of the heaviness of the night before, when Atlanta Braves officials announced with summitconference solemnity that they had been ordered by Bowie Kuhn, the Commissioner of baseball, to start Henry Aaron today.

title: Moritz Bows in Final
description: HASTINGS  ON  HUDSON, N.Y., April 7The first Hastings Cup tennis tournament was won today by Marcelo de la Serna of Jamaica, Queens. He defeated Kirk Moritz of New York, 76, 75, in the final. Mimi Kanarek of Hastings beat Debbie Campbell of Old Greenwich, Conn., 76, 62, in the women's final. The matches were at the River Club.

title: Scanner Automates Checkout Counters
description: A peek into the not too distance future of the automated supermarket was of fered by the International Business Machines Corporation when it unveiled its electronic checkJersey out counter last week at New York's WaldorfNotes Astoria Hotel. I.B.M. is one of more than 10 corporations in the field.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 37

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Pro Football's Gathering Storm
description: In the years since Sept. 17, 1920 when the National Football League was born in. Ralph Hays's garage in Canton, Ohio, the business of professional football has encountered more crises than Richard Nixon, and now comes the biggest crunch of all. If Theodore Kheel, the club owners' labor counsel, doesn't get squashed like a bug between the World Football League and the National Football League Players' Association, then Pete Rozelle should hire him to pilot Pete's 60foot ChrisCraft on pleasure cruises between Scylla and Charybdis. The trail from Hays's garage to the commissioner's throne room at 410 Park Avenue is marked by the whitening bones of scores of franchises Where, for example, are the teams represented in that original meeting in the garagethe Canton Bulldogs, Cleveland Indians, Dayton Triangles, Akron Pros, Massillon Tigers, Racine Cardinals, Hammond Pros, Rochester Kodaks, Rock Island Independents, Decatur Staleys and Muncie Flyers. What ever happened to the Duluth Eskimos, Milwaukee Badgers, Pottsville Maroons, Providence Steamrollers, Frankford Yellow Jackets, Oorang Indians, St. Louis Gunners, Louisville Colonels and Hartford Blues?

title: Newcombe Captures Net Final
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 7 (AP)John Newcombe fought off an early challenge by unseeded Jeff Borowiak for a 64, 61 victory in the final of a $50,000 World Championship Tennis circuit tournament today.

title: Sick Leave an Issue Where Preknancy Is Concerned
description: Linda Mattlin, who is 23 years old and single, saw no reason why her pregnahcy should interfere with her duties as a fork lift driver for Kenner Products toy factory in Cincinnati. Her employer and her doctor agreed.

title: ABORTION POLL FINDS PUBLIC EVENLY SPLIT
description: The issue of permitting a woman to obtain an abortion during the first three months of pregnancy still evenly divides the American public a year after the United States Supreme Court decided the matter, according to a Gallup Poll survey released yesterday.

title: Audit of Bronx School District Shows Financial Irregularities
description: A state audit, which was undertaken last year despite strong objections by some local officials, has reported number of weaknesses and deficiences in the financial and operating practices of a Bronx school district.

title: Cooke and 10 Deaf Children Stuck in Elevator an Hour
description: Cardinal Cooke, four other adults and 10 deaf children were trapped for more than an hour yesterday afternoon in an elevator stalled between the first and second floors of a Times Square building.

title: Tocks Island Dam Given Environmental Clearance
description: TRENTON, April 8  The New Jersey Department of Environmental Protedtion was reported this evening to have informed Governor Byrne that it believed that environmental conditions had been satisfied and that the $325million Tocks Island Dam should be constructed across the upper Delaware River.

title: Saudi Arabians Perplexed by Surplus Revenue
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, April 3Saudi Arabia is perplexed land looking for help in deciding how to use the enormous new wealth from oil that is flowing into this oncepoor desert kingdom.

title: Treasury Bills Rose At the Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, April 8Rates on threemonth and six  month United States Treasury bills rose to their highest level since last Sept. 17. The average rate for threemonth bills in this week's sale is 8.648 per cent up from last week's 8.358. On Sept. 17, 1973 the rate was 8.786 per cent.

title: Production of Steel In Latest Week Rose To Record for 1974
description: Steel production for the week ended April 6 reached its highest weekly level this year at 2,914,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This was a gain of 1.5 per cent over the 2,872,000 tons poured in the preceding week. The production index rose to 119.4 from 117.7 in the week ended March 30.

title: PARIS CRASH LAID TO FAULTY DOOR
description: PARIS, April 8 (Reuters)A faulty cargo door that was torn off in flight caused the world's worst air disaster, according to the report of an investigating commission given today to French authorities.

title: STRONGER U.S. ROLE URGED ON FUTURES
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 (Reuters)  The House Agriculture Committee filed its formal report today endorsing a bill to strengthen Federal regulation of the commodityfutures markets, and the measure should reach the rules committee tomerrow.

title: Castle of Purity'
description: Arturo Ripstein's Mexican-made "The Castle of Purity," the story of a man who locked his family within urban walls for 18 years, had been hailed as extraordinary before its showings last weekend at the Museum of Modern Art. It is indeed extraordinary and haunting.Mr. Ripstein arranged his drama in a stately flow of lucid, exquisitely colored images that edge toward doom. The acting is so good that it is hardly noticeable as such. There is not one note of music, only the pelting rain, blending with Alex Phillips's photography and Manuel Fontanals's set design (a spacious but tottering house, not a chamber of horrors).This bizarre, burrowing movie has been called an attack on Latin family tradition, a metaphor of Christian society and a suspense thriller. To one viewer, it is all three. With his small cast, headed by Claudio Brook and Rita Macedo, and his co-scenarist Jos Emilio Pacheco, the 34-year-old director has subtly shaped a remarkable film. Mr. Ripstein is a young man to the movie camera born.

title: People in Sports
description: Jimmy Piersall whose sports career has been filled with controversy, has been enlivening the scene in Arlington, Tex., where he is the promotions director for the Texas Rangers. After an argument with Mike Shropshire, a sports writer, he was dismissed on Sunday by Bob Short, the operating head of the team.

title: IMPACT OF CHANGE IN LIBYA UNCLEAR
description: CAIRO, April 8The true dimensions of Col. Muammar elQaddafi's loss of political power remained uncertain today, two days after it became known that he had been divested of his political, administrative and traditional duties but remained commander in chief of the armed forces.

title: Randy Johnson to Join Honolulu in '75
description: Randy Johnson has decided to join the World Football League for the 1975 season.

title: Defoliation Was Weighed In Fight on Yellow Fever
description: Tropical disease specialists fighting yellow fever in the Republic of Panama last month considered using herbicides sprayed from planes to defoliate a five to 10mile wide strip of jungle across the Isthmus of Panama.

title: 2 Who Set Out for Watkins Glen Are Still Gone
description: Bonnie Bickwit, 15 years old, and her boyfriend, Mitchell Weiser, 16, thanked the man for the ride into Narrowsburg, N.Y. and climbed down from his truck, The driver remembered that as he drove off he saw the two teenagers dressed in jeans and Tshirts standing at the side of the road, sleeping bags on their backs, holding a cardboard sign that read, Watkins Glen.

title: Butz Values Food Sale To China at 1.2Billion
description: SMANILA, April 8 (Reuters) Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz said today, that the sale of American farm products to China during the fiscal year ending June; 30, 1974, would approach $1.2billion.

title: Witness Says He Heard Boyle Order Yablonski Death
description: MEDIA, Pa., April 8The prosecution closed its case tonight in the murder trial of W. A. Boyle, the former head of the United Mine Workers of America, after the state's key witness testified that he had heard Mr. Boyle give the orders in 1969 to take care of Joseph A. Yablonski.

description: Four Canadian companies involved in the Sarnia Olefins and Aromatics Project (SOAP) announced yesterday in Toronto the formation of a new company, Petrosar, Ltd.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Small Claims Court Called Weak The Community Service Society of New York, in report on the city's Small Claims Court, recommended improvement yesterday in what it called an extremely weak system of collecting judgments from defendants. A study by the society concluded that 82 per cent of all complainants were successful in collectnig what they were owed in cases where settlements were reached with defendants; but when a judge or arbitrator had to render decision, only 50 per cent were able to collect under system that makes the winner of a judgment responsible for collecting.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Briton Defeats Scott in Court Tennis Howard Angus, the British open court tennis champion from London, outscored Gene Scott, the United States open and United States amateur champion from New York, 64, 62, 5.6, 64, yesterday at the New York Racquet and Tennis Club. The match resumed their court tehnis series to determine a challenger for the world open title.

title: Stage: O'Neill's Hughie
description: CHICAGO, April 8Chicago is having a very lively theater season. There is a moderndress version of Shakespeare's Henry IV at the Goodman Theater  which earlier this season gave Broadway its production of Brian Friel's The Freedom of the Cityand George Keithley's excellent Ivanhoe Theater has a fine revival of William Inge's The Dark at the Top of the Stairs, which I will report on later.

title: Blinded in Beating, Photographer Still Presses a Crusade
description: It is 40 years now since W. Eugene Smith used to dash out of the classroom, clutching his camera, when the great brownish pallor that preages a dust storm wouldstart its sweep across the Kansas sky. In the years since then, his photographs of World War IIrecording the bloody invasions of Tarawa, Guam and Iwo Jimaand his intense photojournalistic essays have ranked him among the greatest living photographers.

title: Dance: Jamaica Warmth

Selecting dances that represent this diverse practice, the Jamaica National Dance Theater Company presented its Program II on Sunday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

description: HOUSTON, April 8 Local lay control of public education is distinctly an American invention, one of democracy's taproots, reads a flyer being passed around here this week by West Virginia delegates to the convention of the National School Board Association.

title: Congress's, Low Rating
description: According to a recent opinion poll, only 21 per cent of the American people give Congress better than a poortofair rating for the work it does. President Nixon's standing, low as it is,. is still a few points highera statistic that gives his defenders a trifle more nourishment than they were able to draw from the only fact they had previously relied on for comfort: that President Truman once hit an even lower point on the barometer of public approval.

title: AMERICAN'S DEATH A BANGKOK PUZZLE

On Sunday, Yainicho Tabuchi, one of the 1972 winners, was given the honor of a (Town Hall debut and showed herself worthy of the confidence.

title: Shapiro Exercises Firm Control at du Pont Meeting
description: WILMINGTON, Del., April 8If finesse in running an annual meeting after only three months in office is indicative of a person's ability to run a major company, then du Pont is in good hands.

title: GASOLINE SALES RESTRICTED AGAIN
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, April 8Gasoline stations on the New Jersey Turnpike and the Garden State Parkway have resumed restrictions on the amounts of fuel that drivers may purchase, and state energy officials are warning that the driving public apparently is using up this month's fuel supply at an alarming rate.

title: W. R. Grace & Co. Increases Coal Bid
description: W. R. Grace & Co. disclosed yesterday that it had bettered its offer to the Blue Diamond Coal Company by at least $10million more than its former agreement in principle for their coal operations.The new proposal still calls for the issuance of two shares of a new cumulative convertible preferred stock of Grace for each of the 200,000 Blue Diamond common shares currently outstanding. Now, however, each share of the new Grace preferred will be entitled to cumulative annual dividends of $3 a share for the first year; $3.50 a share for the second, and $4 a share at an annual rate thereafter.

title: G. E. IS EXPANDING HOUSING. OPERATION
description: The General Electric Company announced yesterday it plans to enter the international housing market with the punchase of a 40 per cent interest in the Yakult General Housing Company, Ltd., of Japan.

title: Wood, Field & Stream

title: Sadat and Soviet: Ties Are More Strained
description: CAIRO, April 8A Soviet official, gazing at the stony desert Just outside Cairo, said with a sigh the other day: You cannot grow roses in this soil. He was acknowledging the inescapable fact that Soviet policy had been set back in Egypt and that Egyptians generally, given half a chance, prefer the United States to the Soviet Union. President Anwar elSadat, a man in a hurry, accepted a calculated risk in November when he went along with Secretary of State Kissinger and, in the Secretary's words, agreed to focus on the big things rather than the small, immediate problems such as ceasefire lines between Egyptian and Israeli forces in Sinai.

title: Newark, in Suit on Funds, Cites U.S. Census Error
description: WASHINGTON, April 8The city of Newark has filed suit here, seeking additional revenuesharing funds because of a population undercount by the Bureau of Census.

title: U.N. EXTENDS LIFE OF MIDEAST FORCE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 8  The Security Council, after some behindthescenes wrangling, voted today to extend the life of the 7,000man United Nations Emergency Force in the Middle East until Oct. 24.

title: Syrian Says Israel Seeks To Fortify Golan Position

Rebozo, acknowledged today that Mr. Rebozo had discussed, at President Nixons suggestion, a controversial $100000 campaign contribution by Howard R. Hughes during a White House meeting last April, with Herbert W. Kalmbach.

title: Film of Simon Gray's 'Butley' Is Full of Verbal Wit
description: Are masochists more destructive than sadists? (Answers by Friday, 25 words or less.) It's easy to brush off sadists if you don't like them, and they're always terribly dependent on the cooperation of their victims. However, those who pursue pain or punishment are nearly always successful, and they tend to drag their friends or intimates along with them.Of course, the most effective human time-bombs are larded with both ingredients. Alan Bates, in his superb performance in Simon Gray's victim and a helpless mugger "Butley," is both a dangerous  who forces others to abandon him. Few actors can embody that style of paradox. The American Film Theater's presentation of "Butley," directed by Harold Pinter, opened yesterday at selected theaters.The play, which rings with loud echoes of John Osborne's "Look Back in Anger" and "Inadmissible Evidence," also recalls the hero of Kingsley Amis's "Lucky Jim"  the teacher who recoils from teaching, plagued by irksome students who demand to be taught. But while Mr. Osborne and Mr. Amis used their protagonists as part-time social critics, Simon Gray is concerned only with the inner man."Butley" focuses on a sizzling depressive who gets "news of two divorces in the same day": Both his wife and the man he feels married to are leaving him for someone else. He doesn't seem to care at all about his marriage, and he has no apparent affection for the young man. But he can't stand rejection, "Butley" hasn't much emotional depth. However, there's plenty of verbal wit for Mr. Bates to mount and ride on, and the play's energy springs from one-liners, such as "I'm a one-woman man, and I've had mine, thank God," or "Toadying is the sincerest form of contempt."Mr. Bates's performance has changed since I saw him on stage in London nearly three years ago. Then, he was all fury and disgust. Here, he has subtly toned himself down for the camera, and the characterization seems to be far more varied. As he sheds the layers of an excruciating hangover, he displaces more and more air  his bulky presence looms with the authority of rage, although he never quite has the total tantrum that we're expecting.The mood keeps shifting, as he chants nursery rhymes, plays interrogator, strums on others' guilts, assumes an elegant upper-class voice to distill his exasperation and luxuriates in confrontation. Coughing hideously, bursting into song, he weaves complex webs of misunderstanding and revels in them.Beaming with malice, he also runs through an anthology of smiles: faint smiles of pain or huge, dimpling flashes that contradict what he's just said; bland smiles to underline an insult; subdued, gleeful smirks as he closes in for the attack; grotesque, challenging grins. Butley is deft at self-mockery, as well as mimicking others. Meanwhile, whatever he feels is apt to be contagious for them. Gradually, he's converted from a giant, cackling gnome to a muted loserbereft because he's driven everyone else away.On stage, Butley's lengthy monologues were hard on other actors; you were aware of their efforts to keep responding while listening. But the camera can rest on his face to an advantage; many of his speeches seem just right for close-ups. On several occasions, Butley makes someone stay and hear him out who longs to escape his office; again, this works well in the movie, as it didn't in the theater.Simon Gray has slightly altered his own text, and it flows smoothly onto film. And Jessica Tandy  crisp and direct, simmering against her will, stern but not grim  Richard O'Callaghan and Michael Byrne are all very fine as Butley's sparring partners. Along with "The Homecoming" and "The Three Sisters," this movie represents the American Film Theater's best work so far.

title: News Summary and Index
description: President Nixon's talks with world leaders and his activities on the streets of Paris this weekend brought sharp criticism in France, as well as some grudging acknowledgment of continuing United States power. A letter circulated to journalists in Paris by a high official of the French Ministry said that Mr. Nixon had shamelessly substituted a publicity campaign for the mourning of an entire nation, introducing an atmosphere of loud feverishness, the discourtesy of which is equaled only by its clumsiness. title: Black Holiday'
description: "Black Holiday," the Italian feature directed by, Marco Loto that was screened last night and will be repeated tonight as part of the New Directors series at the Museum of Modern Art, Iilluminates a somber past that, like old wounds, is real but has receded beyond pain. The 42-year-old director's concern with the moralities of fascism and antifascism is, in essence, an intellectual drama that disturbs but does not excite an intelligent observer.He focuses basically on a young history professor who refused allegiance to Il Duce's regime in 1931, the carefully bureaucratic police commissioner and the others in the group of Communists, anarchists and apologetic liberals incarcerated under the commissioner's jurisdiction on a small island for their crimes against the fascist state. Their enforced "holiday" is relegated largely to an exposition of political credos that still stir the mind and heart, if not, a viewer's pulse.Adalberto Maria Merli is properly introspective as the pedantic professor confused by conflicting viewpoints until he is finally committed to action by unnecessary bloodshed. Adolfo Celi is bland and wily as the commissioner who befriends the professor and even allows him to teach and the added comforts of a villa, his wife, infant daughter and his books in order to stress his seemingly decent stewardship. And John Steiner is forcefully natural as the militant worker-leader of the prisoners who is murdered as a result of the commissioner's discreetly oblique orders."Black Holiday" has been photographed in black and white but its divided principals, their emotions and politics are neither black or white nor simple, as the English subtitles help make abundantly clear. The passage of time has dimmed a drama that is sometimes too talkative, but its ideas and people remain vivid and provocative.

title: Dave Anderson
description: ATLANTA, April 8In the decades to come, the memory of the scene might blur. But the memory of the sound will remain with everyone who was here. Not the sound of the cheers, or the sound of Henry Aaron saying, I'm thankful to God it's all, over, but the sound of Henry Aaron's bat when it hit the baseball tonight. The sound that's baseball's version of a thunderclap, the sound of a home run, in his case the sound of the 715th home run. The sound momentarily was the only sound in the expectant silence of 53,775 customers at Atlanta Stadium and then, as the sound faded, the ball soared high and deep toward the leftcenterfield fence. And over it. On the infield basepaths, Henry Aaron was trotting now, trotting past Babe Ruth into history in his 21st season. On his first swing in tonight's game; the 40yearold outfielder of the Atlanta Braves had hit another home run, Just as he had hit his recordtying home run on his first swing at Cincinnati in last Thursday's season opener. At home plate, surrounded by an ovation that came down around him as if it were a waterfall of appreciation, he was met by his teammates who attempted to lift him onto their shoulders. But he slipped off into the arms of his father, Herbert Sr., and his mother, Estella, who had hurried out of the special box for the Aaron family near the Braves' dugout.

title: William H. Martin, 84, Dead; Directed Research for Army
description: William H. Martin, the Army's first civilian director of research and development, died Sunday in Sibley Hospital, Washington. He was 84 years old and live in Washington and formerly in Short Hills, N.J.

title: Environmental Clearance Reported To Be Given Byrne on Tocks Island
description: TRENTON, April 8 The New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection was reported this evening to have informed Governor Byrne that it believed that environmental conditions had been satisfied and that the $325million Tocks Island Dam should be constructed across the upper Delaware River.

title: LAYERS TESTIFY IN MITCHELL CASE
description: Three lawyers testified for the defense in the MitchellStans trial yesterday, and in the process the jurors learned a lot about the daily practice of law and the delicacies of lawyerclient relationships.

title: Couple Indicted in Abduction
description: ABINGDON, Va., April 8 (AP)A Federal grand jury today indicted Larry G. Cole, 27 years old, and his wife Bonnie, 23, on charges of kidnaping and extortion in the abduction for ransom of a Roanoke, Va., businesswoman. The couple isl accused of kidnaping Mrs.; Frank Van Balen at gunpoints March 6 in Roanoke. She was released in West Virginia the next day after her husband paid a ransom of $25,000.

title: Progress Is Seen at New Delhi Talks
description: NEW DELHI, April 8India, Pakistan and Bangladesh appeared tonight to be moving toward an agreement on 195 Pakistani soldiers charged with war crimes and on repatriation of nonBengali Moslems, from Bangladesh.

title: FRANK TRUE
description: SARASOTA, Fla., April (UPI)  Frank True, sports writer and columnist, died Saturday night at the age of 80.

title: Black Pastor to Head  Seminary in Chicago
description: The Rev. C. Shelby Rooks, executive director of the Fund. for Theological Education in Princeton, N. J., has been named president of Chicago Theological seminary.

title: Chances Are the Student Will Have to Work to Help Out
description: To students of middle income families, soaring college costs are as real as the dishes they wash and the garbage they haul to help pay the tab.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Raytheon Company said yesterday it had received a contract from the Government of Saudi Arabia for about $260million to update that nation's Hawk defense system, Work would be done at its missiles system division at Bedford, Mass. The contract was endorsed by the State Department and the Deferise Policies Department of the United States Government.

title: A Case of Impropriety
description: The National Association of Securities Dealeis  the industry group that prescribes the conduct for the overthecounter securities marketrecently discovered that 13 of the foreign companies whose shares traded through its facilities were not in compliance with Federal law. At least two of the companies apparently do not care.

title: Washington Post Publishes Despite Strike by Guild
description: WASHINGTON, April 8Edi oriel and commercial employes truck The Washington Pqst oday, but the paper nevertheess published what was de. cribed as a full Tuesday edition by Benjamin C. Bradlee, he executive editor.

title: Iceland in Talks on, Baser
description: WASHINGTON, April. 8 (Re?? tens)Iceland's Foreign Minister, Einar Aguatsson, began talks at the State Department today in a renewed effort to secure closure of the United States air baseat Keflavik, Iceland, by the end of 1976. Iceland has been threatening to I evict the United States, which considers Keflavik a vital link in its surveillance activity in the North Atlantic.

title: Worry Grows for Safety. Of Black History Library
description: Smoke filled the reading room of the Schomburg Collection of Negro History and Literature last week as a fire set in an empty tenement next door threatened the irreplaceable collection of memorabilia, art, history and literature housed in the old library building.

title: Beef Price Swing May Follow Grain
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 4 The panic buying of corn and wheat that began in late February has ended, and prices of these essential grains have been falling.

title: Giscard d'Estaing and Mitterrand Enter French Presidential Race
description: PARIS, April 8The Socialist party leader, Franois Mitterrand, and Finance Minister Valry Giscard d'Estaing today formally announced their candidacies for the, presidential elections next month.

title: PRIME RATE IS 10% AT BANKERS TRUST
description: The Bankers Trust Company raised yesterday its prime rate on loans to corporations to 10 per cent, and a large New Jersey bank joined it.

title: Wilson Faces Parliament In Storm Over Land Deal
description: LONDON, April 8  Prime Minister Wilson went before the House of Commons today in an effort to calm, a raging political controversy Over property dealings involving his private secretary and mernbers of her family.

title: F.D.R. Drive Joins West In Creating Traffic Jams
description: Manhattan motorists, still grumbling about monthsold West Side Highway detours, ran, into a new tangle yesterday after trucks and buses were barred from the Franklin D. Rooseyelt Drive below 23d Street:

title: DU PONT EXPECTS EARNINGS RISE
description: WILMINGTON, Del., April 8 E, I. du Pont de Nemours Fe Co., Inc., estimated today that its profits in the first quarter of this year were about 4 per cent higher than a year earlier.

title: Impeachment, as Viewed Abroad
description: PARISI hear Americans say that the impeachment of President Nixon would have disastrous consequences for the image of the United States in the world. But inside the United States, they add, the crisis would not be very serious, particularly as a result of the appointment of Gerald R. Ford as the new Vice President.

title: Polluted City
description: Procrastination, indifference and outright hostility in Washington, Albany and City Hall are threatening to undermine a comprehensive plan to reduce pollution to federallyaccepted standards in New York City by 1976.

title: Computer Purchase by Rutgers Rekindles Debate on Autonomy
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, April 8The purchase of a $600,000 medical computer by Rutgers University, over the vehement objections of the state's Chancellor of Higher Education, has rekindled the debate over the autonomy of the state university from the Department of Higher Education.

title: Apologizing, Con Ed Says Cuts in Billing Will Be Minuscule
description: The Consolidated Edison Company, apologizing for unfortunate errors in calculations, said yesterday that fuel adjustment charges in April electric bills would not be cut by 10 per cent, as announced over the weekend by the company chairman, Charles F. Luce.

title: Downing on the Homer: It Just Kept Carrying
description: ATLANTA, April 8 (AP)When he first hit it, I didn't think it might be going but it kept carrying, carrying, said Al Downing, moments after surrendering Henry Aaron's 715th home run tonight.

title: Avco Corp. Earnings Declined Modestly in Quarter
Kahn Misses Homer 715 For a Date in Cleveland
description: CLEVELAND, April 8 (AP) The baseball comniissioner, Bowie Kuhn, did not see Henry Aaron become baseball's home run king..

title: Chess 3 Top Record Field in Vegas; Bisguier Primus Inter Pares
description: Arthur Bisguier, Norman Weinstein and Eduardo Celorio outstripped a recordbreaking field of 301 entrants to share first prize in the 1974 National Open at the Stardust Hotel in Las Vegas.

title: STATE'S LABOR AIDE SCORES U.S. POLICY
description: TRENTON, April 8 (AP) State Labor and Industry Commissioner Joseph A. Hoffman says a $2million Federal cutback means the State Employment Service will make 24,000 fewer job placements this year than it did last year.

title: Virgin Islands Couple Slain; Suspect on St. Croix Seized
description: CHRISTIANSTED, V. L, April 8 (UPI)  The bodies of Mr. and Mrs. Howard D. Hansley each shot in the head, were found early today in the driveway of their suburban home here.

title: TASTE MARKS SONGS OF MET'S MISS KWAK
description: Shinja Kwak is no stranger to the musical stage here  the Korean mezzosoprano has been a member of the Metropolitan Opera chorus since 1971. But for the first time, she stepped forward in her own character Sunday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, where she gave her debut recital.

title: DENVER SCHOOLS TOLD TO INTEGRATE
description: DENVER, April 8 (UPI)A Federal judge ordered today the integration of Denver's 70,000 schoolchildren by next fall, primarily by redrawing boundaries and pairing requiring white, black and Mexican. American students to share classrooms on a halfday basis.

title: President's. Latest Counterattack
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 Last Wednesday evening, after the White House put out a statement saying the President would pay his back taxes, the stooped, familiar figure of Richard M. Nixon was seen moving along the drive beside the West Wing, a man like millions of others trudging home after a long day's work.

title: People in Sports
description: Jimmy Piersall whose sports career has been filled with controversy, has been enlivening the scene in Arlington, Tex., where he is the promotions director for the Texas Rangers. After an argument with Mike Shropshire, a sports writer, he was dismissed on Sunday by Bob Short, the operating head of the team.

title: BOUMEDIENE TO SEE NIXON ON THURSDAY
description: WASHINGTON, April 8President Houari Boumediene of Algeria will visit Washington on Thursday for talks with President Nixon and Secretary of State Kissinger, a State Department official said today.

title: Mental Health Included In State's New Priorities
description: TRENTON, April 8  The State Health Planning Council has added mental health to its top priority medical goals in New Jersey's comprehensive health plan for 19751976.

title: Addis Ababa Promises Sweeping Land Reforms
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, April 8 (AP)Emperor Haile Selassie's Cabinet promised today sweeping land reform and other priority legislation aimed at improving the living stand increasingly violent riots In the countryside by landless peasants, the new Premier, Endalkachew Makonnen, and his cabinet promised to adopt a landtothetiller policy that

title: Hoff es Lawyer Says Case Against Nixon Could Show Alleged Abuse of President's Power
description: WASHINGTON, April 8James R. Hoffa's case against President Nixon goes to the courtroom tomorrow and it could open a new area of evidence alleging the abuse of Presidential power, Mr. Hoffa's attorney said today.

title: Boycott of California Crops Supported by A.F.I.C.I.O
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP)  The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Indus. trial Organizations endorsed today a nationwide boycott of California lettuce and table grapes to aid the United Farm Workers of America in its decadelong struggle with the state's produce growers.

title: Sir Hudson Fysh, 79, Dies; CoFounder of Qantas Line
description: SYDNEY, Australia, April (AP)  Sir Hudson Fysh, cofounder of Australia's international airline, Qantas, died Saturday at the age of 79.

title: School ReformNow
description: The reform plan for the city's community school board elections, submitted last year by Max J. Rubin, has been translated into a comprehensive legislative proposal by the State Education Department. The bill represents realistic effort to transform corruptionriddled chaos into a democratic electoral process.

title: DR. LESTER UNGER, HEMATOLOGIST 85
description: Dr. Lester J. linger, a hematologist who headed the Blood and Plasma Exchange Bank serving more than 100 hospitals here in World War II, died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived at 1192 Park Avenue.

title: Additional Funds Sought
description: WASHINGTON,. April 8 (AP) President Nixon asked Congress today for $1.4million in a supplemental appropriation for the fiscal year 1974, which began last July 1, to handle expenses of increased sales from the nation's stockpiles authorized by Congress last, year. The President also asked for an additional $352,000. to help pay expenses of the Panama Canal Company.

title: Aaron Hits 715th, Passes Babe Ruth
description: ATLANTA, April 8Henry Aaron ended the great chase tonight and passed Babe Ruth as the leading homerun hitter in baseball history when he hit No. 715 before a national television audience and 53,775 persons in Atlanta Stadium.

title: Guild to Resubmit An Offer by U.P.l. To 950 on Strike
description: Negotiators for the Wire Service Guild, on strike for three weeks at United Press International, said last night that the membership had voted to reject the terms for a new contractbut by such a narrow margin that the union would submit the contract to a second vote and recommend. approval.

title: Tornado Cost Is Estimated
description: Initial estimates of its insurance losses from last week's tornadoes were placed by the INA Corporation yesterday at $16million. The St. Paul Fire and Marine Insurance Company estimated its losses at $4.5million. Crum & Forster placed its tornado losses at an estimated $5.5million.

title: NIXON TAX STUDY IN HOUSE TO TOUCH ON POSSIBLE FRAUD
description: WASHINGTON, April 8The impeachment inquiry staff of the House Judiciary Committee is investigating whether fraud may have been involved in President Nixon's handling of his income taxes.

title: DEERE INCREASES ITS PRICES BY 5%
description: Deere & Co announced yes terday at Moline, Ill., that was raising prices on its agri cultural and industrial product: by an average of 5 per cent The company, which is one of the nation's largest makers of farm equipment said the increases were approved under Federal Phase 4 regulations and were needed to recover increased material and labor costs. Two oil companies announced that they were increasing prices in line with Federal Energy Office regulations on passing along increased costs of raw materials.

title: Giants Down Reds, 43, for 4th Straight
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 8 (AP)Garry Maddox knocked in four runs with a threerun homer and a single, and the unbeaten San Francisco Giants rolled to their fourth victory today, a 43 decision over the Cincinnati Reds.

title: JUDGE RESTRICTS MITCHELL DEFENSE
description: Judge Lee P. Gagliardi made two rulings yesterday that seriously restricted the defense of John N. Mitchell and Maurice H. Stans in their criminal conspiracy trial.

title: A different Breed of Youth Makes a Mecca of Boston
description: BOSTON, April 9To Mike Daly it's a good place to crash on your fantasies. For Richard Brown and Margaret Gerteis it's a tolerant place where an unmarried interracial couple can find happiness. And to Robert Adkins, the Boston area is so attractive that he prefers to sacrifice some of his lawyerly ambitions to stay here rather than plug into the New York hype.

title: LOANS DEFENDED BY SECURITY BANK
description: HUNTINGTON, L.I., April 9 The chairman of the Security National Bank defended today his company's loans to. Arthur Young & Co., independent auditor for the bank since 1963.

title: Italy Sets Campaign Funding
description: ROME, April 9 (Reuters)The future expenses of Italy's political parties are to be met from public funds, the Chamber of Deputies decided today.

title: Marlboro Music Festival Lively In Brahms Clarinet Series Here
description: The aging Brahms had been planning to stop composing, when in 1891 he happened to hear a phenomenal clarinetist named Richard Muhifeld and was aroused to write a series of chamber pieces for his instrument, including the great Quintet (Op. 115). A. full program of these afterthoughts would be good to hear sometime, but on Monday night at Alice Tully Hall one could at least sample the first and least immediately attractive work, tile Trio in A minor (Op. 114).

title: Labor Strife Looming in Italy As a 9Month Truce Collapses
description: ROME, April 9The possibility of new labor unrest is threatening in Italy following warnings from trade union leaders that an unofficial ninemonth truce is over.

title: A Rearguard Action
description: Swiss bankers are waging a rearguard action to limit the exceptions to secrecy enjoyed by the Swiss in, their banking and other business dealings that would be permitted under the legal assistance treaty between the United States and Switzerland. Pate 61.

title: FamilyPlan Aid Found Up Sharply
description: WASHINGTON, April 9The number of American women using the services of family planning clinics has increased almost fivefold in six years, according to a study by Planned ParenthoodWorld Population.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Classified pages distributed in metropolitan New York and adjacent territory.

title: Sink Without Trace
description: A bill has bobbed up in the State Legislature calling for pay increases of $12,000 a year for the three lifetime members of the New York City Board of Water Supply. Although there was some early mystery about the bill's sponsorship, there is no mystery about what ought to be done with the measure. The right course would be an amendment abolishing the whole useless board, along with its requested budget of $11 million for the next fiscal year. Whatever work the board does could readily be transferred to the city's Department of Water Resources. Even if the city did not have an oceandeep budgetary deficit, the Board of Water Supply would represent an indefensible extravagance.

title: State Panel Calls Judiciary Lax On Efforts to Discipline Judges
description: The State Commission or in vestigation charged yesterday that by and large the judiciary in New York City and seven surrounding counties has failed to fulfill its obligation to properly discipline judges.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: DALLAS, April 9 (UPI)Seven defending champions see action tomorrow when the first eight of the 30 titles in the national Amateur Athletic Union men's and women's shortcourse indoor swimming championships will be decided. There were 1,100 entries for the fourday meet. Returning to bid for crowns over the 25yard course were Melissa Belote and John Naber in the 200yard backstroke; Cathy Carr and Mark Chatfield in the 100yard breast stroke; Deena Dearduff and Bruce Robertson in the 100yard butterfly and Jack Tingley in the 500yard freestyle.

title: SURRENDER OF 261 REPORTED BY SEOUL
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 9 The South Korean Government said today that a total of 261 people had surrendered to investigating authorities for having been involved in an outlawed student organization.

title: Ronan Due for Nomination As Port Agency Chairman
description: TRENTON, April 9Dr. William J. Ronan, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, is expected to be nominated Thursday as chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: 2 SEIZED IN RAID ON BURGLARY LOOT
description: The arrest of two burglary suspects in Brooklyn led to the recovery of at least $1million worth of antiques, works of art and other valuables yesterday in a twostory house in the borough's Sea Gate section, the police reported.

title: HOLLOMAN SEEKING RESIGNATIONS OF 54
