description: Dr. John L. S. Holloman, the new president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, has sent letters to 541 top corporation officials asking them to submit proforma resignations.

title: STUDENT KARKETING PLANS SETTLEMENT
description: CHICAGO, April 9 (AP)The National Student Marketing Corporation announced today it had agreed to settle the class actions instituted against it in 1970.

title: 2 Children Killed in Car Fire
description: CHICAGO, April 9 (AP)Two children left unattended in the rear seat of a car burned to death yesterday while their mother shopped, the police said today. Renetta Stubbs, 4 years old, and her brother Hank, 2, were found in each other's arms after rescue efforts by passersby failed. Patrolman P. Mason said the victims were left unattended in the auto.

title: Woman Inspector to Head Police Information Division
description: Deputy Inspector Gertrude Schimmel, the highestranking woman in the Police Department, will be named commanding officer of the department's Public Information Division today.

title: EARNINGS REPORTED ON VENEZUELAN OIL
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, April 9 (Reuters)  Foreign oil companies operating in Venezuela earned profits totaling $5.4billion from 1962 to 1972, the Venezuelan Federation of Public Accountants said today.

title: Nixon Pledges Aid in Tour Of Tornado Area in Ohio
description: XENIA, Ohio, April 9President Nixon made a surprise tour of this tornadoravaged. town today and pledged whatever Federal aid was necessary for rebuilding.

title: Celtics Win, Lead by 32 In Playoffs
description: BOSTON, April 9There wasn't anything artistic about the Boston Celtics roughandtumble, 10097 victory over the Buffalo Braves in their National Basketball Association firstround playoff tonight.

title: YearRound Staggered Deadline Urged for Filing Income Tax Returns to Improve Help From I.R.S
description: WASHINGTON, April 9The present April 15 deadline for individual Federal income tax returns should be changed to a yearround staggered deadline so that the Internal Revenue Service can offer more effective help to bewildered taxpayers, a Senate subcommittee was told today.

title: WIFE HOUSE ASKS STAY TILL APRIL 22 ON TAPE REQUEST
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 The White House told the House Judiciary Committee tonight that it needed more time to decide how to respond to the committee's request for tape recordings of 42 Presidential conversations relating, to Watergate.

title: EXCESSES POUND IN LUNCH PROGRAM
description: A state audit has found that the number of free lunches reportedly served to needy pupils in some schools here actually exceeded the number of pupils attending these schools and resulted in excessive Federal and state payments of possibly $4,343,000 in a year to the city school system.

title: Yen Power Reflects Sound Economy
description: TOKYO, April 9The floating Japanese yen has been defying most of the accepted laws bf economics for the last month or more.

title: Prime Minister's Stanch Aide
description: LONDON, April 9  When Harold Wilson lost the 1970 election and was subjected to the hasty and humiliating eviction procedure adopted here when a Prime Minister makes way for his opponent, a crowd of Conservative supporters gathered in front of 10 Downing Street to celebrate the departure.

title: Republic National Credits Cold Coins For Record Profit
description: The Republic National Bank of New York announced yesterday that it had record earnings In the first quarter, largely as a result of trading, in gold coins.

title: WALDHEIM URGES ECONOMIC REFORM
description: UNITED. NATIONS, N. Y., April 9  Secretary General Waldheim, addressing the opening meeting of a special General Assembly session on raw materials and development, called on the members of the United Nations today to work out a more equitable world econornie system. He warned that if they did not the wellbeing and prosperity of all nations would, be in peril.

title: SAVE ASIASTIC LION, ALBANY BILL URGES
description: ALBANY, April 9The Asiatic lion was nominated today to a select listthe state's list of endangered species.

title: Robert Youngson, Producer, 56, Who Won 2 Oscars in 50's, Dies
description: Robert G. Youngson, a producer, director and writer whose shortsubject films won two Oscars and six Academy Award nominations from 1948 to 1957, died. Monday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived at 29 Washington Square West.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: CLOSTER, April 9Because Tom Gorman is a conscientious umpire, the never gets out of shape during the offseason. As senior umpire in the National League, Gorman keeps his booming voice in tune, with three or four speaking engagements week. He keeps his legs in shape by working out on a stationary bicycle five minutes a day his home on Closter Dock Road.

title: BREZHNEV PUSHES LOWER TARIFFS
description: MOSCOW, April 9  Soviet leader Leonid I. Brezhnev stressed anew to the Nixon Administration the importance Moscow attaches to gaining. Congressional approval for lower tariffs and larger credits from the United States.

title: College Results
description: BASEBALL

title: Rockwell Merger Backed by Holders Of Admiral Stock
description: Shareholders of the Admiral Corporation, a fullline manufacturer of consumer electronic products and major home appliances, approved a merger with the Rockwell International Corporation at a meeting in Chicago. The merger is effective immediately. It calls for the exchange of 0.50 share of Rockwell common stock for each outstanding common share of Admiral. Admiral's 1973 sales were $523million. Rockwell's fiscal 1973 sales were $3.2billion.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Swimming Titles on Line Today

title: Briton Says He Destroyed Key Letter in Land Deal
description: LONDON, April 9The political controversy over realestate deals involving associates of Prime Minister Wilson was enlivened today with the reported destruction of a crucial letter.

title: SAUDI OIL CAME IN DESPITE EMBARGO
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (Reuters)  Saudi Arabia shipped oil to the United States throughout the Arab oil embargo, although supplies from her Arab neighbors almost completely dried up by the end of December.

title: Ronan Due for Nomination As Port Agency Chairman
description: TRENTON, April 9Dr. William J. Ronan, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, is expected to be nominated Thursday as chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: 8,000 Season Tickets Sold, W.F.L. Stars Say
description: The New York Stars of the World Football League said yesterday they had sold 8,000 season tickets and were prepared to spend $500,000 for new seats and lights in Downing Stadium at Randalls Island.

title: The Foreign Ministers Return
description: PARISA political phenomenon marking, the early nineteenseventies was diminishment in the role of foreign ministers. Everywhere there seemed increased tendency by the executive to assume direct control of policy while leaning less upon the normal diplomatic apparatus.

title: Byrne Signs Bill for Study Of Public Education Phrase
description: TRENTON, April 9 (AP)Governor Byrne today signed the first legislation dealing. with a court mandate for new means of financing public education in New Jersey.

title: Coal Mine Safety Pledged
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) Dr. Thomas V. Falkie, director of the Bureau of Mines, vowed today not to slacken Government research on mine safety in a rush to make the nation selfsufficient in energy production. Dr. Falkie told an advisory panel on coal mine safety, There won't be any reduced emphasis on health and safety research.

title: Mass Said Aboard Commuter Train to New York
description: RED BANK, April 9 (AP)New Jersey commuters heard a Roman Catholic mass aboard a train today.

title: The Dance: Festa Brazil
description: Festa Brazil, an unusual company from the Brazilian northeastern state of Bahia that encompasses both folk and pop material, opened last night at the Felt Forum for a run through April 21. The troupe is the last in the series of ethnic groups that has performed there since October, under the heading of an International Festival of Entertainment.

title: Prices on Amex Slip as Volume Rises
description: Stocks edged lower yesterday in an indecisive day on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Boyle on Witness Stand, Denies Plotting Murder of Yablonski
description: MEDIA, Pa., April 9W. A. Boyle, former president of the United Mine Workers of America, took the witness stand in his own defense today and denied all charges that he had plotted the murder of Joseph A. Yablonski, a reformist rival for his $50,000ayear union post.

title: Swiss Banks Ask Limits In Exceptions to Secrecy
description: GENEVA, April 9Swiss bankers are waging a reap guard action to limit the exceptions to secrecy enjoyed by the Swiss in their banking end other business dealings that would be permitted under the legal assistance treaty the United States and Switzerland concluded last May.

title: Saigon Says Vietcong Kidnaps 90 From Plantation and Villages
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 9 (Reuters)The Saigon Government said today that 90 civilians were kidnapped by the Vietcong yesterday and last night at the Michelin rubber plantation and in five Mekong delta villages.

title: About New York Guarding the City's Buck Yard
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I., April 9The South Fork of Long Island begins at the Shinnecock Canal and extends to Montauk Point. It is a back yard of New Yerk City full of quiet beauty most of the time, summer people some of the time and realestate developers, all of the time.

title: New Canada Rule Barring Hormone In Meat Imports Halts U.S. Trade
description: OTTAWA, April 9 New Canadian regulations on meat and livestock imports have halted, at least temporarily, trade with the United States that has been worth more than $150million a year to the American export industry.

title: Twins, Paced by Carew; Defeat White Sox, 3 to 1
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., April, 9 (AP)Rod Carew, singled twice; stole two bases and scored two runs today to lead the Minnesota Twins to a 31 victory over the Chicago White Sox.

title: Burmah Shell Notified Of Indian TakeOver
description: NEW DELHI, April 9 (Reument has officially notified Burmah Shell, the largest foreign oil company operating in India, that it wishes to acquire 74 per cent of the company, Government sources said today.

title: Printers Are Voting in Favor of a Strike
description: Members of Typographical Union No. 6 were voting heavily in favor of strike action against one or more of the city's major daily newspapers in preliminary returns reported last night.

title: Rangers Pin Playoff Chance on Defense
description: MONTREAL, April 9Frank Mahovlich thinks the goalies will decide the issue in the RangersCanadiens firstround series, which opens tomorrow in the Montreal Forum. (Televised on Channel 11 in New York at 9:05 P.M.).

title: Senate Breaks Filibuster On Campaign Reform Bill
description: WASHINGTON, April 9The Senate, breaking an 11day fillbuster, voted today to shut off debate on a major campaign reform bill that would use public funds to finance Presidential and Congressional elections starting in 1976.

title: Coney I. Whale Still Believed Pregnant After Check
description: Two veterinarians and 10 helpers went into the pool of Coney Island's white whale yesterday and came out still convinced that she was pregnant.

title: Ford Defends Nixon Action on Tapes
description: TROY, Mich., April 9Vice President Ford defended tonight the White House decision to continue reviewing tapes and other materials requested by the House Judiciary Committee.

title: U.P.I. Walkout Ends As Employes Back Cantract in 2d Vote
description: Reporters, editors, photographers and other editorial employes voted yesterday to end their 23dayold national strike against United Press International and to return to work at 12:01 A.M. today.

title: SYRIA SAYS ISRAELIS WERE BEATEN BACK
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, April 9 (AP)  The Syrian command said today that it had beaten back Israeli forces with groundtoground missiles in intensified fighting on the Golan Heights.

title: Closure
description: The Senate vote of 64 to 30 to impose closure on the debate on the campaign finance bill is an important victory for political reform. It is also a triumph for Senators Mansfield and Scott, the respective party floor leaders, both of whom have been steadfast supporters of the principle of public financing of political costs that is embodied in the bill. Senator Scott, in particular, has had the courage to differ with President Nixon on this issue and to take a more advanced position than the majority of his G.O.P. colleagues in the Senate.

title: Yanks Beat Tigers, 30, for 4th Straight
description: DETROIT, April 9  The Yankees remained undefeated today following a tidy 30 victory over the Tigers for their fourth triumph in the young baseball season. Not since 1945 has the New York club begun a campaign so auspiciously, although the Yankees have 158 opportunities remaining to lose a game.

title: FRED WATERS
description: Fred Waters, an account executive and a partner in the ShorlaneBenet Company, Inc., an advertising agency, died Sunday at his home, 126 New York Avenue, Freeport, L. I. He was 73 years old.

title: ROSENBERGS' DATA REPORTED MISSING
description: The United. States Attorney's office has said that Government exhibits in the case of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, who were executed in 1953 for conspiring in atomic espionage, have disappeared, acording to a suit filed in Federal Court yesterday.

title: An Economic Quandary
description: In the promised land of economics it would not be the lion and the lamb that exist side by side but full employment and stable prices. The search for a way to twin these two policy these two policy goals seems to have become more frustrating than ever. A wicked combination of changessome economic, some politicalhas boxed Washington policy makers further and further into a corner from which there seems to be no easy exit. Any direction the President's advisers turn, the options are more limited now than a decade ago, the risks somewhat greater.

title: Dr. Alfred Stillman 2d Dies; ExRoosevelt Chief Surgeon,
description: Dr. Alfred Stillman 2d, retired chief of surgery at Roose velt Hospital where he had first interned in 19117died there on Monday. He was 93 years old and lived at 610 Park Avenue.

title: TV: Harlequin, a Ballet for Children
description: Among the more encouraging network contribution to children's programing, even if presented only on an occasional basis, is the Columbia Broadcasting System's Festival of the Lively Arts for Young People. So far the series has included such unusual quality content as an adaptation of the D'Oyly Carte H.M.S. Pinafore and a quite lovely Theater of the Deaf interpretation of Dylan Thomas A Child's Christmas in Wales.

title: 51Story Tower Tops Minneapolis Skyline
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Taped to the wall of a service elevator in the new 51story IDS Center here is a postcard view of the Foshay Tower, the eccentric nineteentwenties obelisk which, until the completion of IDS, was Minneapolis's tallest building. Scrawled beside the picture are the words. To my good friend IDS  best wishes, Mr. Foshay.

title: BAR UNITS REPORT ON JUDGES SCORED
description: A committee of State Su preme Court justices charged yesterday that the release or a report by a committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York critical of five justices was irresponsible.

title: Camden to Tax Properties Now Exempt From Levies
description: CAMDEN, April 9 (AP)City tax officials say they will assess and tax the previously taxexempt properties of the Delaware River Port Authority and Rutgers University to increase the city's shrinking tax base.

title: Strike Callus Cancellation Of Many Air France Flights
description: PARIS, April 9 (AP)About 80 per cent of Air France pilots apd flight engineers went on strike today, forcing the company to cancel 138 of its 159 scheduled flights.

title: Vienna Talks on Reduction of Forces Begin a Recess
description: VIENNA, April 9 (AP)Delegations of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact held their last Sission today before a fourweek recess.

title: Mr. Saxbe's Myths
description: The Attorney General's list of subversive organizations is, like all punitive rosters drawn up by fearful governments, a shameful page in the nation's annals. An Attorney General with the good sense to scrap that useless and vindictive document need offer no, explanation or apology. How, then, is one to explainghe thought process, if any, that prompted Attorney General William B. Saxbe to justify his sensible action by suggesting that the list had been rendered obsolete because Communism has lost its attractiveness to the Jewish intellectual, who was in those [McCarthy] days very enamored of the Communist party?

title: Kennedy Back From Bonn
description: WASHINGTON, April 9, (Reuters)Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, returned here today from a weekend trip to Bonn, which was a prelude to planned visits next week to the Soviet Union, Yugoslavia and Rumania. He flew back to Washington for an important vote on an election campaign reform bill, which he is cosponsoring.

title: MAHEU TRIAL IS TOLD OF GIFT FROM HUGHES
description: LOS ANGELES, April 9Testimony before the staff of the Senate Watergate committee alleging that Howard R. Hughes ordered a campaign contribution to Hubert H. Humphrey was made public here today in Federal District Court.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Senate Breaks Filibuster On Campaign Reform Bill
description: WASHINGTON, April 9The Senate, breaking an 11day filibuster, voted today to shut off debate on a major campaign reform bill that would use public funds to finance Presidential and Congressional elections starting in 1976.

title: G.E. EARNINGS RISE 7% IN THE QUARTER
Concert
description: When Leonard Hindell, New York Philharmonic bassoonist, decides to give a concert he gathers around him some worthy colleagues and plays chamber music. Because the bassoon turns up in an uncommon repertory, his programs are fresh and novel. This was the case on Monday, night in Carnegie Recital Hall, and the pleasure of the evening was in hearing not only an expert player but also fine unfamiliar music.

title: Flat Racing Brings $76Million in '73
description: New York State realized almost $76million in revenue from thoroughbred racing last year, the State Racing and Wagering Board said yesterday in its annual report.

title: People and Business
description: Edward, G. Harness was named yesterday as chairman and chief executive officer, of the Procter & Gamble, Company, effective May He succeeds Howard Morgens, who will become Chairman of the executive committee.

title: Edwin Nourse, 90, Dies; Truman's Economic Aide
description: WASHINGTON April 9EdWin G. Nourse, the first chair Man of the President's: Council of Economic Advisers following enadtment of the Employment Act 1946, died Sunday, after a brief Illness at Suburban Hospital in nearby Bethesda. He was 90 years old.

title: Flyers Defeat Flames In Playoff Opener, 41
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 9 (AP)Goals by Gary Dorn hoefer and Tom Baldon paced a 41 victory for the Philadelphia Flyers over the Atlanta Flames tonight in a firstround National Hockey League playoff game.

title: WHITE HOUSE ASKS STAY TILL APRIL 22 ON TAPE REQUEST
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 The White House told the House Judiciary Committee tonight that it needed more time to decide how to respond to the committee's request for tape recordings of 42 Presidential conversations relating to Watergate.

title: Purported China Papers on Nixon Visit Are Released in Taiwar.
description: HONG KONG, April 9Sources on Taiwan have re leased a set of documents, said to have been procured from Yunnan province in South China, in which Chairinan Mao Tsetung's, decision to invite President Nixon to Peking is defended as a snortterm accommodation with an enemy.

title: Nastase Is Sharp On Clay
description: MONTE CARLO, April 9 (UPI)Ilie Nastase of Rumania, looking to take his fourth straight tennis tournament, cruised through the opening round of the $5000 Monte Carlo open today by crushing Georges Goven of France, 60, 60.

title: Soviet Launches Supertanker
description: MOSCOW, April 9 (Reuters) The Soviet Union today launched its first supertanker, the 150,000ton Krym. The Government daily, Izvestia, said the vessel had a double hull to avoid seepage of oil in the event of the outer skin's being broken. A 350,000ton tanker in projected.

title: W.F.L. Gets Calvin Hill Next Year
description: The World Football League lost the cover of Sports Illustrated magazine to Henry Aaron this week, but landed another heavy hitter for the 1975 season, Calvin Hill of the Dallas Cowboys.

title: JUPITER'S RED SPOT TERMED CLOUD MASS
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) The planet Jupiter's great red spot is apparently a towering mass of clouds.

title: 9 GRUMMAN AIDES ADMIT KICKBACKS
description: Nine former employes of the Grumman Aerospace Corporation and seven officers of companies that did work for Grumman have pleaded guilty to an elaborate kickback scheme in the awarding of millions of dollars worth of Navy subcontracts, the Acting United States Attorney in Brooklyn announced yesterday.

title: Some Experts Here Turn a Chilly Eye. on MeatFreezer Sales Plans.
description: When meat prices climbed out of sight last year, millions of consumers began buying beef at wholesale.

title: COMMODITY MEN EVALUATE MARK
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April. 9  Speculation on the possibility of another revaluation of the West German mark preoccupied many of the commodity experts gathered here today for the opening of the United Nations General Assembly's special session on the world crisis in raw materials.

title: Excerpts From Text of Waldheim's Speech to U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N, Y., April 9  Following are excerpts from the, prepared text of a statement made by Secretary General Waldheim to the General Assembly today:

title: U.S. Marshal Is Rebuffed at Doris Duke Estate
description: HILLSBOROUGH, April 9An attempt to serve copies of a civil complaint against Doris Duke and two members of her staff was rebuffed this morning at the gates of her estate here in northern New Jersey.

title: Dayan's Ouster Sought Within Party
description: TEL AVIV, April 9  Top of ficials of the govenning Labor party conferred here late tonight to seek a way, according to a source who participated in the meeting, to oust Moshe Dayan as Defense Minister without splitting the party and risking a loss of power.

title: Manischewitz Diet Matzoh Is Found to Be Mislabeled
description: A Federal Judge in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that dietthin matzoh crackens, manufactured by the B. Manischewitz Company, Inc., were mislabeled because they contained as many calories as regular matzoh.

title: Big Losers in the HotStove League
description: All women work in America, possibly with the exception of the disabled and some of the very wealthy. Yet only very recently has nonsalaried work in the home been measured in terms of dollars and cents. The results are startling.

title: Stock Prices Up Slightly In Continued Dull Trading
description: Stock prices managed a modest technical advance yesterday in continued dull trading.

title: Harkness Is a Testament To City and Landmarks
description: Lincoln Center, in the years since its completion, has stimulated an enormous amount of construction in the blocks surrounding it on Manhattan's upper West Side  often to the disinay of residents of the area who, like so many New Yorkers, regret that neighborhood improvement often means a new, larger scale and the disappearance of familiar landmarks. From this standpoint, then, the Harkness Theater should be welcorned into the Lincoln Center neighborhood. Instead of erecting a new building, Rebekah Harkness spent $5million to renovate an old one, the Colonial Theater on Broadway between 62d and 63d $treets. It is a testament not only of faith in the city, but also of the faith both architects and clients are increasingly expressing in the creative reuse or recycling, of viable older structures.

title: Measles Outbreak Strikes At TeenAgers in Bergen
description: Dr. William J. Dougherty, Acting State Commissioner of health, said yesterday that 252 new cases of measles169 more than usualwere reported from last September through last March in an outbreak that was spreading rapidly and affecting teenagers, particularly in Bergen County.

title: Books of The Times
description: COGAN'S TRADE. It George V. Higgins. 216 pages. Knopf. $5.95.

title: International House Opens Fund Drive
description: David Rockefeller opened a fundraising appeal last night for International House, the twintowered residence on Riverside Drive his father built to house graduate students from all nations In the hopes of raising $7,5 million to operate the house and its programs.

title: Zurich Bank Indicted By U.S. in Fraud Case
description: A swiss bank and one of its offices became defendants yesterday in a Federal inquiry into dealings by United States promoters through setret Swiss bank accounts.

title: Undertaxed Commuters
description: When Mayor Beanie travels to Albany tomorrow seek state authorization for desperately needed additional taxes to balance the city budget, he will face stiff resistance against an increase in a tax that offers a reasonable source of new revenuesthe commuter tax.

title: Mobil Attacks A.B.C. on TV Oil Special
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation has filed a 22page paper with the National News Council, a 15member watchdog for national news media, alleging 32 particularly inaccurate or unfair statements in a recent American Broadcasting Company television news special on the energy crisis.

title: Bank Votes 2for1 Split
description: Stockholders of the First Chicago Corporation, parent of the country's 10th largest bank, voted yesterday to split the corporation's common stock two for one. A similar split was made two and a half years ago in September, 1971.

title: Sedykhar Sets Mark
description: MOSCOW, April 9, Reuters Yuri Sedykhar, an 18yearold Soviet hammer thrower, set a world junior (under20) record today for the hammer throw with a toss of 232 feet 5 inches at a meet in Alusia, according to Tass, the Soviet press agency.

title: Landlords Vote to Void Contract in Manhattan
description: Landlords of 1,600 Manhattan apartment houses announced yesterday that, they had voted to cancel their contract with Local 32B of the Service Employes Union because the city was planning to repeal laborcost rent increases now permitted to the owners.

title: 8 Killed on Bus in Brazil
description: BELO HORIZONTE, Brazil, April 9 (AP)A bus plunged down a hill and overturned near Caratinga in the interior of Minas Gerais State, killing eight persons and injuring 20, the police reported yesterday.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: City Purchase of Building Authorized

title: Impeachment Politics
description: WASHINGTON, April 9You can hardly pick up a paper thesedays without reading about some move or countermove in the White House or the Congress that is sepposed to influence the outcome of impeachment proceedings against President Nixon.

title: Aaron: Sleepless but Relieved
description: ATLANTA, April 9It was the day afterthe day after he had made baseball historyand Henry Aaron eased into the Atlanta Braves' locker room, slipped some soft music into the cassette inside his cubicle, sat down on a wooden stool, yawned and said:

title: TEXAN ACQUIRING STARNEWS STOCK
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 A 49yearold Texas millionaire with Strong Democratic, political ties is buying a substantial and perhaps controlling interest in The Washington StarNews, the capital's only surviving afternoon newspaper.

title: Trust Law Offenses Laid to Oil Groups
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 Witnesses before a Congressional subcommittee charged today that major oil companies had been breaking antitrust laws for years with the knowledge and sometimes the approval of the Justice and Interior Departments.

title: Monday's Fights
description: New York (At Felt Forunt)Art Kettles, 146 pounds, Asbury Park, N. J., and Miguel Barreto, 144, San Juan, Puerto Rico, drew, 10 rounds.

title: NIXON TAX ISSUE SENT TO JAWORSKI
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 The question of whether there was fraud in the preparation of President Nixon's tax returns has been referred to the special Watergate prosecutor by the Internal Revenue Service, Attorney General William B. Saxbe said today.

title: U.S. TAKES 91 BIDS FOR OFFSHORE OIL
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 9 (AP)  Interior Department officials have announced acceptance or 91 offshore oil lease bids totaling $2.092billion.

title: Business Briefs
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation filed suit yesterday in Federal District Court in Wilmington, Del., to overturn an Internal Revenue Service revocation of its 1969 tax rulings that facilitated the I.T.T. acquisition of the Hartford Fire Insurance Company.

title: People in Sports Patriots Name Marr President
description: Bob Marr, a Boston scaffolding contractor, was named president of the New England Patriots yesterday, succeeding Billy Sullivan. Sullivan, the president of the club since it was formed in 1959, will remain with the club as director,

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: To Get to Times Square, Turn Left at Sodom
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn.The author Seroma Weidman, in a recent interview on public television shown here, spent a few moments dismissing his role as president of The Authors League of America and the league's legal brief in the Carnal Knowledge obscenity appeal to be argued Monday before the United States Supreme Court.

title: Advertising: Aaron's Big Blast
description: If it weren't for that exclusive fiveyear $1million contract with Magnavox, there would probably be a lot of advertisers lined up on Henry Aaron's doorstep with hopes of using the new national hero.

title: Lackawanna, N. Y., Ordered by Nyquist To Integrate Pupils
description: ALBANY, April 9The State Education Commissioner today ordered racial integration in, the schools of Lackawanna, the steelmill city adjacent to Buffalo.

title: City Says Tax Deadline Will Not Be Extended
description: City taxpayers were warned yesterday that there would be no oneday extension for the filing of city returns.

title: Contract Awards
description: Procon, Inc., a subsidiary of the Universal Oil Products Company, and Campagnie Franaise d'Etirdas et de Construction Technip, announced yesterday plans for building Europe's largest oil refinery for Petrosul Sines, Portugal, 84 miles south of Lisbon. It would cost a total, of $250million and have an initial capacity of 224,000 barrels a day. Procofrance, S. A., of Paris, Prenth subsidiary of Procon, would be an equal partderd with Technip in the project.

title: Lefkowitz Looking Into Nassau Ticket Sale
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz's office said Yesterday that an inquiry was under way into the controversial sale of tickets for this week's three concerts by Frank Sinatra at the Nassau Coliseum.

title: Democrats to Let St. Clair Observe Inquiry on Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, April 9The Democratic majority on the House Judiciary Committee has informally agreed to support at least a limited role in the impeachment inquiry for the President's counsel, James D. St. Clair.

title: NIXON TAX ISSUE SENT TO JAWORSKI
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 The question of whether there was fraud in the preparation of President Nixon's tax returns has been referred to the special Watergate prosecutor by the Internal Revenue Service, Attorney General William B. Saxbe said today.

title: The Watergate Summit
description: Watergate, after a considerable lag, now has begun to impinge increasingly on President Nixon's ability conduct the nation's foreign policy.

title: News Summary and Index WEDNESDAY, APRIL 10, 1974
description: India, Pakistan and Bangladesh reached a major breakthrough and signed an agreement to repatriate 195 Pakistani prisoners of war. The warcrimes trial planned for the prisoners is to be dropped by Bangladesh. The pact opened the way for normal diplomatic and economic relations between the three nations and the easing of tensions and hostilities that followed the Bangladesh war in 1971. [1:5]

title: Technique Found to Grow Skin May Aid SevereBurn Victims
description: AKRON, Ohio, April 9An Akron doctor and a researcher in physiology have developed a method of growing human skin in a laboratorya technique that could revolutionize the treatment of burns.

title: Virus flits Gianelli, May Hurt Knicks In Tonight's Game
description: LANDOVER, Md., April 9A touch of intestinal virus may have an important bearing on the Knicks' attempt to wrap up their opening round National Basketball Association playoff series against the Capital Bullets tomorrow night at Capital Centre.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The State Department is understandably disturbed at the VanikMills trade bill. I say understandably because Congress thus frustrates the accumulated research and work of doubtless many worthy people in the department. Who knows, there may be a number of resignations in disgust should Congressional resistance prevail and the department's plans be consigned to limbo.

title: Robert Goldstein, 70, Dies; ExRroduotion Chief at Fox
description: GLENDALE, April 9 (UPI)Robert Goldstein, a motionpicture producer and former production chief at Twentieth CenturyFox Studios, died of a cerebral hemorrhage, in his home in London yesterday, his family announced here today. He was 70 years old.

title: Marcis a Good Bet for Seat in Matador
description: Dave Marcis, who entered this season with 171 races in Grand National stock cars and no victories, may have won himself a car last Sunday at Darlington, S.C., in the Rebel 500.

title: Positive Growth Predicted For U.S. Economy by Ash
description: The United States economy took a dive during the first three months of the year, but should bounce back somewhat in the current quarter, according to Roy L. Ash, director of the Office of Management and Budget.

title: In Henry Aaron's Footsteps: The Man Who Isn't There Yet
HOUSE ENDS STUDY OF OCTOBER ALERT
description: WASHINGTON, April 9The House of Representatives voted early today to end further inquiry into the worldwide American military alert ordered by President Nixon at the height of the Middle East war last fall.

title: Citibank in Moscow Branch
description: The First National City Bank, announced yesterday it had opened a representative branch in Moscow. Citibank said the office would develop commercial contacts and assist American businessmen dealing with the Soviet Union and other East European countries.

title: Massachusetts Candidate
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 9 (AP)Marc Furcolo, the son of former Gov. Foster Furcolo, has entered the race for the Democratic nomination for State Treasurer. In making his announcement, Mr. Furcolo critidized the incumbent treasurer, Robert Q. Crane, who is also seeking the Democratic, nomination in September's primary.

title: Rudi's Hit In 9th Wins. For A's, 64
description: KANSAS CITY, April 9 (IIPI)Joe Rudi's tworun double with the bases loaded in the ninth inning broke open a 44 tie and gave the Oakland A's a 64 victory over the Kansas City Royals tonight.

title: BREAK FORESEEN IN HEARST CASE
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 Attorney General William B Saxbe said today that he expected to get results in solving the Patricia Hearst kidnapping now that the lid is off.

title: One Crewman Dead, 9 Missing In Tanker Blast at Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 9 (UPI) A tanker that had pumped off most of its 200,000 barrels of heavy asphalt oil from Venezuela exploded at pierside and foundered in the Delaware tonight. At least one crewman was killed and nine were missing.

title: Coal Mine Safety Pledged
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) Dr. Thomas V. Falkie, director of the Bureau of Mines, vowed today not to slacken Government research on mine safety in a rush to make the nation selfsufficient in energy production. Dr. Falkie told an advisory panel on coal mine safety, There won't be any reduced emphasis on health and safety research.

title: Air Safety Official Sees Moves To Undercut Prevention Work
description: WASHINGTON, April 9  A Government air safety official suggested today that there Would have been a better chance of preventing the recent DC10 crash near Paris had not White House maneuvers undercut accidentprevention work of the National Transportation Safety Board.

title: National Banks Put Money Into System
description: PARIS, April 9  Despite political differences there is a new monetary entente an the Atlantic world.

title: WATER AIDES FACE DEFEAT ON RAISES
description: ALBANY, April 9  A bill to give $12,000ayear pay increases to three members of New York City's Board of Water Supply, which was quietl introduced late last week, appeared today to be headed toward an equally quiet demise even before it reached the floor of the Assembly for debate.

title: Goldman Denied Business Tie to City Concessionaire
description: Irving Goldman, the city's Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, told the counsel to the Board of Ethics, when he was being screened for the post, that he was not an officer of a candy company supplying the major subway vending concessionaire when, in fact, he was president.

title: New England Power Cut Ends
description: BOSTON, April 9 (AP)The New England Power Pool will end the 5 per cent evening voltage reduction that took effect last November as a means of saving fuel, a spokesman said yesterday. We feel that the oil supply situation has stabilized, the spokesman, James Lydon, said. The 4 P.M. to 8 P.M. voltage reduction saved about 40,000 barrels of fuel a month, Mr. Lydon said.

title: Judge Rejects Disqualification Plea By Defense at RaceFixing Hearing
description: One defense lawyer asked the judge to disqualify himself and another accused the chief prosecutor of lying in a stormy daylong hearing yesterday at the racefixing trial of 13 harness drivers.

title: Nadjari to Get Data On Methadone Loss At Rikersl. Hospital
description: The Special State Prosecu tor, Maurice H. Nadjari, said yesterday that his office would receive all documents and evidence on the disappearance of 200 methadone tablets from the city prison hospital on Rikers Island.

title: CORPORATE BONDS SHOW PRICE RISE
description: Breaking something of a drought, corporate bond prices showed, modest improvement yesterday. Taxexempt obligations were mostly steady. The Government market, after registering some early gains, closed little changed on the day. The upturn in the porate market, some specialists suggested, in part reflected the arrival in the market of several new offerings. These were for the most part accorded a cordial reception, with several of them sold down to tag ends or reportedly sold out completely.

title: ROSENBERGS' DATA REPORTED MISSING
description: The United States Attorney's office has said that Government exhibits in the case of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, who were executed in 1953 for conspiring in atomic espionage, have disappeared, acording to a suit filed in Federal Court yesterday.

title: Nuclear Arms Conference Is Set for May of 1975
description: GENEVA, April 9 (Reuters) The 26nation preparatory session of the Geneva disarmament conference today set May 5 of next year as the date for opening fullscale talks on stopping the spread of nuclear weapons.

title: Coast Repertory Theater Gets $2Million Ford Aid
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 9The American Conservatory Theater has announced grants from the Ford Foundation totaling $2million, which are aimed at giving the resident repertory company longterm financial and artistic stability.

title: 9 GRUMMAN AIDES ADMIT KICKBACKS
description: Nine former employes of the Grumman Aerospace Corporation and seven officers of companies that did work for Grumman have pleaded guilty to an elaborate kickback scheme in the awarding of millions of dollars worth of Navy subcontracts, the Acting United States Attorney in Brooklyn announced yesterday.

title: Sinatra Fans do L.I. Relive Winter of '42
description: UNIONDALE, LI., April 9 There were among the Nassau burghers here tonight those who came to recall the winter of '42 that December when they or their friend stamped in frosty 43d Street waiting for a seat in the old Paramount in Times Square to revel and swoon over the new sensation of song, Frank Sinatra.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: HealthFood Suit Dismissed

title: Savings Banks Cite Gain
description: Savings banks in New York State reported yesterday that they had gained $133million in deposits in March. The net deposit inflow was smaller than the $154million they reported for February or the $153.9million for March, 1973.

title: Potato Futures Seesaw and Close Off Daily Limit
description: Mey potato futures gyrated yesterday, moving up the daily limit to a record high and then slumping the daily limit for 100 of $1 a hundred pounds. Traders called it one of the wildest days ever on the New York Mercantile Exchange, and they described the sharp decline as an inevitable technical reaction after a long, sharp rise.

title: Spring Storm Spills 8 Inches Snow Over Albany
description: A spring storm laden with cold air from Canada dumped a band of snow across half a dozen Eastern states yesterday, disrupting air traffic, forcing some schools to close and causing numerous traffic accidents.

title: Bridge:
description: The only major world bridge title now held by American players will be at stake next month in the Canary Islands when Mary Jane Farell of Los Angeles and Marilyn Johnson of Houston defend their women's pair laurels. They will face strong opposition from Europe, South Africa and the United States. Four players from the New York metropolitan, area will compete: Marietta Passell of Yonkers, with Bette Cohn of Birmingham, Ala.; Dorothy Hayden Truscott of New York with Emma Jean Hawes of Fort Worth; Sallie Johnson of Westport, Conn., with Karen Allison, formerly of New York and now of Toronto; Jan Stone of New York with Barbara Brier of Miami.

title: JUDGE RESTRICTS MITCHELL DEFENSE
description: Judge Lee P. Gagliardi made two rulings yesterday that seriously restricted the defense of John N. Mitchell and Maurice H. Stans in their criminal conspiracy trial.

title: INDIA, BANGLADESH AND PAKISTAN END PRISONER DISPUTE
description: NEW DELHI, April 9India, Pakistan and Bangladesh reached a major breakthrough tonight and signed an agreement to repatriate 195 Pakistani prisoners of war.

title: NEW PRIDES CITED BY OIL COMPANIES
description: Price adjustments continued yesterday among major petroleum producers.

title: NIXON IS DROPPED FROM HOFFA SUIT
description: WASHINGTON, April 9A Federal Judge dismissed President Nixon as a defendant today in a lawsuit filed by James R. Hoffa, former president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: Special Session in Brief
description: The General Assembly's special session on raw materials, which opened yesterday, represents an attempt by the underdeveloped nations to correct the imbalance in the world's economy: 70 per cent of the population receive 30 per cent of the income.

title: Red Smith
description: You don't have any trouble getting excited about this one, Arnold Palmer told The Associated Press in Augusta, Ga. It's the Masters, isn't it? Failing to make the cut in the Greater Greensboro open last week, Arnold showed up earlier than expected at the Augusta National Club, that green garden in the pines where the Palmer Era of golf began. It was there among the azalea and dogwood, the redbud and flowering peach, that Arnold won his first major championship and there he won his last 10 years ago. It was the gallery at the Masters that first came to know and idolize the young man with the wrynecked followthrough, the unruly forelock and the easy. friendliness of the boy next door. Fans at the Masters were the first to be thrilled by the closing rush that came to be his trademark. (When Mr. Palmer puts his head down and starts welkin' fast, said Iron Man, his caddie in those days, I know we ain't out of it.)

title: Assembly Votes to Curb Gas and Electric Cutoffs
description: ALBANY, April 9  The As sembly voted sharper restriction today on the cutoff of gas and electric service by the stat's utllities during the cold weather months, prohibiting entirely on Friday, Saturday Sunday and holidays.

title: Rescuing Con Edison
description: Kicking around Consolidated Edison is both popular and easy; the danger is that it will blind New Yorkers to the reality that the utility on which they depend fog all their light and power is in a critical financial bind. Despite its soaring electric rates, Con Edison's attractiveness to investors is so low that it despairs of finishing two generating plants now under construction unless the state takes them over.

title: Virus Hits Gianelli, May Hurt Knicks In Tonight's Game
description: LANDOVER, Md., April 9A touch of intestinal virus may have an important bearing on the Knicks' attempt to wrap up their opening round National Basketball Association playoff series against the Capital bullets tomorrow night at Capital Centre.

title: French LineUp Unchanged After Day's Maneuve
description: PARIS; April 9After a dizzying, whirligig of a day during which men in high places announced, renounced and reflected upon their candidacies for the presidency of France, the lineup now remains essentially the same.

title: Mets Try Again Today As Rain Puts Off Opener
description: Yogi Beira sat in his office in the Mots' clubhouse in Shea Stadium yesterday, pondering what he might do with his unexpected day off. I got a haircut and picked up a couple of suits yesterdasr [Monday], the manager said,. today, I might go out to the club and play cards. It's a good, day for it.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Lackawanna Told To Integrate Pupils

title: 8CENT SALES TAX PROPOSED BY CITY TO CUT FISCAL GAP
NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and index, Page 43

title: State U. Will Exchange Students With Moscow
description: MOSCOW, April, 9Chancellor Ernest L. Boyer of the State University of New York today announced agreement with the Moscow State Institute of Foreign Languages for an exchange of undergraduate language students starting this fall.

title: FALSE REARMS UP 30% IN ONE MONTH
description: An unexplained 30 per cent rise in false alarms here in March led yesterday to the start of a threepronged attack on the problem by the Fire and Police Departments and the Board of Education.

title: Newark Tax Notes Given To Rating for Investors
description: NEWARK, April 9This city's image as a decaying urban center has undergone a change. Moody's Investment Services, Inc., has given the city's recent issuance of $3million in taxanticipation notes its top rating.

title: STATE UNIT URGES STIFF DRUG LAWS
description: TRENTON, April 9  The State Commission of Investigation recommended stiff new penalties today for pushers of hardcore narcotics similar to but more flexible than those in New York State's tough and controversial laws.

title: Husband of Drug Program Head Wounded by Detective in Harlem
description: The husband of the director of a Harlem drug rehabilitation program was critically wounded by a detective early yesterday morning when the man reportedly pointed a pistol at the detective, who was investigating a report of a shooting in a tenement at 152 West 144th Street.

title: Market Place: City Bond Issue Stirs Big Hopes
description: At 11 A.M. today, the bondmarket men in Wall Street are apt to cast their eyes in the direction of the Municipal Blinding, a few blocks away. That is the deadline for Controller Harrison J. Goldin, in Room 530, to receive sealed bids on the sale of $436.6million in city bonds the biggest municipal financing ever.

title: ALBERT TERMS U.S. AT RECESSION BRINK
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (UPI) House Speaker Carl Albert, insisting it was not a partisan attack, accused the Nixon Administration today of disastrons economic policies that have led the nation to the brink of recession.

title: Students Protest At N.Y.U. Delays Talk by Shockley
description: A group of students yelling derisive slogans, blowing whistles and banging Chairs, were threatened with arrest yesterday at New York University before sufficient quiet could be obtained to permit Dr. William B. Shockley to expound his controversial views about intelligence and race.

title: Rangers Pin Playoff Chance on Defense
NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 43

title: 8CENT SALES TAX PROPOSED BY CITY TO CUT FISCAL GAP
description: A penny increase in the sales tax paid in the city to 8 cents a dollar, a half billion  dollar borrowing repaid by an increase in the stock transfer tax and the dismissal of at least 2,000 city employes are in the budgetbalancing package that the city is likely to urge, upon Albany at a crucial summit meeting tomorrow.

title: Democrats to Let St. Clair Observe Inquiry on Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, April 9The Democratic majority the House Judiciary Committee has informally agreed support at least a limited role in the impeachment inquiry for the President's counsel, James D. St. Clair.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ASTRAL TURF The city has two planetariums turning day into night and each has a show going at the moment: Up at the majorleague stargazer, the Hayden, Central Park West and 81st Street (8738828), the program is It's About Time, and the big dome, with accompanying narration, fills you in for an hour about different calendars, different ways of reckoning time and why 1972 was two seconds longer than most years. Mondays through Fridays at 2 and 3:30; Saturdays at 11, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5; Sundays at 1, 2, 3, 4, 5; through May 6. Admission: $1.75; 18's and under, and students, 90 cents; senior citizens, $1.25.

title: Celtics Win, Lead by 32 In Playoffs
description: BOSTON, April 9There wasn't anything artistic about the Boston Celtics' roughandtumble, 10097 victory over the Buffalo Braves in their National Basketball Association firstround playoff tonight.

title: An Explosion Rocks A Lisbon Troopship; 2 Are Slightly Hurt
description: LISBON, April 9 (Reuters)A bomb blast tonight rocked a troopship about to sail from Lisbon for Portuguese Guinea with more than 1,000 men aboard, an Interior Ministry spokesman said.

title: Trust Law Offenses Laid to Oil Groups
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 Witnesses before a Congressional subcommittee charged today that major oil companies had been breaking antitrust laws for years with the knowledge and sometimes the approval of the Justice and Interior Departments.

title: On First Try, the Voice Conquers Carnegie Hall
description: As he strolled casually out on the stage, his head cocked to one side and his tanned features lit by the familiar, quizzical sliver of a smile, the audience that filled Carnegie Hall rose to greet him with a roaring cheer. Ol' Blue Eyes was back. Frank Sinatra, at 58, was giving his first Carnegie Hall concert on Monday evening  his first appearance in the metropoliarea in nine years.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: A recent article on fish and pollution prompted Toby Lelyveld of Manhattan to write us concerning an English woman's reaction to an item of local food a hundred or more years ago.

title: International Paper Lifts Earnings 39% To Peak in Quarter
description: The International Paper, Company told 500 stockholders at its annual meeting at the Essex House, yesterday that profits climbed 39 per cent to a record $41.2million, or 93 cents a share. Sales rose 18 per cent to $650.6million.

title: WINFIELD RIEFLER, MONETARY EXPERT
description: Winfield, W. Riefler, former assistant to the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board at his retirement in 1959, died Friday in Sarasota, Fla., where he was living. He was 77 years old.

title: INDIA, BANGLADESH AND PAKISTAN END PRISONER DISPUTE
description: NEW DELHI, April 9India Pakistan and Bangladesh reached a major breakthrough tonight and signed an agree meat to repatriate 195 Pakistan prisoners of war.

title: INDIAN STUDY SEES TIES IMPROVING
description: NEW DELHI, April 9India said today that relations with the United States had steadily improved in the last year but noted that the nations in the region were deeply disturbed about the American decision to expand naval facilities in the Indian Ocean.

title: GUILDPOST TALKS FAIL IN WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) Negotiations were recessed today between The Washington Post and representatives of about 900 striking editorial and commercial employes, with no pregress reported toward a new contract.

title: Buckley. Wants President To. Put Off Trip to Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) Senator James L. Buckley, Conservative  Republican of New York, said today that President Nixon should no go to Moscow while impeachment proceedings were pending.

title: Effective Mortgage Rates Were Mixed Last Month
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (Reuters)Effective interest rates on conventional home mortgage loans closed in March were mixed, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.

title: Ballet: The Harknesss in Its Own Home
description: Rebekah Harkness's dream of a peacockblue dance theater in New York City came to fulfillment last night, when the new theater, named the Harkness, opened its Ornate doors to the public. This reconstituted 70yearold vaudeville house has been lushly decorated, and the mural surrounding the proscenium arch, showing nude dancers in various poses of choreographic ecstasy could well become a New York landmark, like the Staten Island Ferry.

title: Briton Says He Destroyed Key Letter in Land Deal
description: LONDON, April 9The political controversy over realestate deals involving associates of Prime Minister Wilson was enlivened today with the reported destruction of a crucial letter.

title: HOUSE UNIT ENDS OIL TAXES ACTION
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) The House, Ways and Means Committee finished its basic work today on a petroleum tax reform bill after voting to keep a depletion allowance of 22 per cent for most natural gas.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 10, 1974

title: A Matter of Identity: Women Who Keep Their Maiden Names
Astros Beat Padres
description: SAN DIEGO, April 9 (AP) Cesar Cedeno drove in four runs and Larry Dierker, battling back from arm and shoulder problems, held San Diego to six hits and two runs in seven innings as the Houston Astros defeated the Padres tonight, 95.

title: Litvinov Says lie Left Under Duress
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 9Pavel M. Litvinov, the Soviet dissident, said today that he had emigrated under duress from the Soviet Union.

title: People in Sports
description: Bob Marr a Boston scaffolding contractor, was named president of the New England Patriots yesterday, succeeding Billy Sullivan. Sullivan, the president of the club since it was formed in 1959, will remain with the club as director.

title: MurderPlot Hearing Put Off
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 9 (UPI)A state judge postponed today until April 22 a pretrial hearing for Elmer Wayne Henley, 17 years old, who is accused of taking part in six of 27 slayings of teenage boys in a sextorturemurder ring. Judge Preston H. Dial Jr., who granted the delay at the request of the defense, was understood to have set a tentative trial date for July 8.

title: MARTEN DE JONG
description: Marten E. A. L. De Jong, former director of Air Express International for Europe and the Far East, died Sunday at his, home, 7057 Park Drive East, Kew Gardens, Queens. He was 75 years old.

title: LEFTIST MAGAZINE CLOSED BY PERON
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 9 The leading magazine of the Peronist left wing has been shut down on order of President Juan Domingo Pertn.

title: Notes on People
description: I did not have my mind in an undivided way on the Middle East in the last week, said Secretary of State Kissinger upon ending a 10day honeymoon in Acapulco yesterday. After a stopoff in Mexico City, where he and his bride, the former Nancy Maginnes, met with President Luis Echeverria Alvarez and his wife, it was back to Washington last night, where a full, schedule awaited him.

title: M'CRANE REQUESTS DISMISSAL OF CASE
description: NEWARK, April 9 (AP) Judge Lawrence A. Whipple was asked in Federal District Court today to dismiss Federal taxfraud charges against Josephi M. McCrane, the former New Jersey treasurer, on the ground that Mr. McCrane had been the victim of an orchestrated circus of unconstitutional preindictment publicity.

title: Byrne Action on Casinos Called Ploy by Dumont
description: PHILLIPSBURG, April (AP)  State Senator, Wayne Dumont, a leading backer of legalizing casino gambling, charged today that a Byrne administration move to restrict casinos to Atlantic City is simply a ploy to defeat the referendum.

title: ROGER FERGER, 80, PUBLISHER, DEAD
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., April 9 (AP)Roger H. Ferger, who retired in 1965 as president and publisher of The Cincinnati Enquirer, which, in 1952, became an employe. owned newspaper, died at a nursing home here on Monday. He was 80 years old.

title: Councilman Urges Use of Nameplates By City Employes
description: City Councilman Michael De Marco yesterday introchiced a bill that would require city employes to wear name tags and identify themselves in telephone conversations.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Mrs. Elinor Guggenheimer, commissioner of the Department of Consumer Affairs, has charged the Paramount Theater, Broadway and 60th Street, with violating the city's Consumer Protection Law by falsely advertising that patrons paying a $6 admission would receive a reserved seat for the current attraction, The Great Gatsby. The film also is being shown at $4 admission at Loews State 1 and 2, Orpheum and Tower East Theaters.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: My, naivet may be showing, but I fail to comprehend why rising rates and state aid constitute the sole means of alleviating the alleged financial plight Of. Con Edison, while dividends to stockholders remain invulnerable.

title: Women Studying Women: An Upstate Group's Trip to the City
description: Like other tourists, they windowshopped along Fifth Avenue, strolled through Chinatown, visited the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and tapped their tired feet in rhythm with the Rockettes at Radio City Music Hall.

title: Reinecke Asks Trial Before Primary
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 Lieut. Gov. Ed Reinecke of California asked a Federal district judge today to give him a chance to establish his innocence of perjury charges before June 4, the date of the California primary in which he is seeking the Republican nomination for Governor.

title: Byrne Aide Took Fifth Amendment
description: TRENTON, April 10Pressure within the Byrne administration for the resignation of Secretary of State J. Edward Crabiel increased today following official confirmation that Mr. Crabiel had misled the public when he denied invoking the Fifth Amendment before, a state grand jury here last month.

title: Canada Acts To Keep Out New League
description: OTTAWA, April 10Health Minister Marc Lalonde introduced legislation in the House of Commons today to keep the new World Football League out of Canada.

title: BOYLE CASE GOES TO THE JURY TODAY
description: MEDIA, Pa., April 10  The murder trial of W.A, Boyle, former president of the United Mine Workers of America, neared its conclusion today with a long, angry confrontation before the jury by the prosecution and defense lawyers.

title: HENRY TOPPER
description: Henry Topper, a business representative and former executive board member of Lodal 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, died Tuesday at his home, 1797 East Second Street, Brooklyn. He was 74 years old.

title: SAUDIS WORRIED OVER NIXON ROLE
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, April 3  Saudi Arabia, which has been confident that the United States will bring about a settlement in the Middle East, is now increasingly concerned that the peace effort might be weakened if President Nixon is impeached.

title: Simon Says Gas Supply Is Again Near Normal
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI)  The Federal, energy chief, William E Simon, said today that the nation's gasoline supply was near nominal and predicted that Americans would be able to take their usual summer vacation trips.

title: Lachman Bids Anker Act On ReadingTest Cheating
description: Dr. Seymour P. Lachman, president of the Board of Education, asked School Chancellor Irving Anker yesterday to take action to stamp out cheating on the citywide reading tests by teachers and principals who want to make the scores of pupils  and consequently their own accomplishments look better.

title: NIXON VESCO MEETING HINTED BY CORNFELD
description: LONDON, April 10 (Reuters) Bernard Cornfeld, deposed head of the International Overseas Services mutual funds empire, said tonight he had information indicating that Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier, met President Nixon secretly in Salzburg, Austria, two years ago.

title: A Gifted Leo Sayer Blends Fine Voice With Stage Antics
description: Leo Sayer is a slight, 5foot4inch Englishman who sings rock music dressed in Pierrot makeup and a clown costume. It might seem just a little coy and a little limiting. But at his first New York appearance, Mondaythe first of two days of performances at the Bottom Linehe confirmed that he is actually a far more wideranging, evocative musical artist than the clown metaphor might suggest.

title: Pro Transactions
description: FOOTBALL

title: Rents Cut at Newark Project
description: NEWARK, April 10 (AP)An Essex County Court judge, William Harth, granted a rent abatement today of between 60 and 80 per cent to tenants in the Columbus Homes public housing project.

title: Reds' New Tactic in French Race
description: The decision of the French Communists snot to run a presidential candidate in the May 5 elections reflects the complex paradox of politics on the French Left. The Communist party has announced its support for the Socialist leader, Franois Mitterrand who will be the only candidate of the Left.Normally, the Communists put up their own candidates in the first round of elections, and then support leftist or antiGaullist candidates if their man fails to make the runoff.

title: POOR LANDS URGED TO CONTROL GOODS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 10President Houari Bournediene of Algeria, addressing the special General Assembly session on raw materials and development, called on under: developed countries today to wrest control of their resources from foreign domination.

title: Orange Utilities' Electric Sales Drop
description: SPRING VALLEY, N. Y. April 10Orange and Rockland Utilities, Inc.'s, electric sales volume has decreased by 3 per cent in each month from November through March, Charles H. Tenney II, chairman, told about 200 stockholders at the annual meeting in company headquarters here today.

title: BIG SURPLUS SEEN IN STATE BUDGET
description: ALBANY, April 10  Democrats on the legislative fiscal committees asserted today that the state had anticipated a budget surplus of $568million that could be put to use for expanded programs of state aid to locale governments or for broad tax cuts in the 197475 fiscal year.

title: Market Place:
description: The growthstock concept has taken its lumps within the last year, but Don A. Hessler remains firmly rooted to this investment approach.

title: TIMES PRINTERS APPLY PRESSURE
description: Bertram A. Powers, president, and other leaders of Typographical Union No. 6 were directed to show cause in State Supreme Court today why they should not be found in contempt for holding a union meeting at The New York Times during working hours yesterday.

title: March Retail Sales Rose 2% Following Flat Period
description: WASHINGTON, April 10Reatil sales rose 2 per cent in March after being essentially flat since November, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: SalesTax Reduction Voted in Hartford
description: HARTFORD, April 10The Connecticut General Assembly voted today to cut the state sales tax by half a percentage point and approved a record, electionyear budget of $1.38billion.

title: Mets' 32 Victory Over Cards Saved By Apodaca's TwoPitch Relief in 9th
description: On the same day the Mets started a new season at home, Bob Apodaca gained what he felt was a new start on his major league career yesterday.

title: Sports New Briefs
description: Jerry Quarry will meet Joe Alexander in a 10round heavyweight bout on May 8 at the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L. I. It will be the first of six proposed cards at the Coliseum this year tube staged by Top Rank Coliseum, Inc.

title: James L. Saphier, 67, Dies; Bob Hope's Business Agent
description: James L. Saltier, business agent singe 1936 for Bob Hope, then a relatively unknown radio comedian, died Tuesday in Los Angeles. He was 67 years old and lived in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: BREAST CANCER LINK TO HEREDITY HINTED
description: Women under age 40 run a far higher than average risk of developing breast cancer if their mothers andor sisters had the disease, a new study reports, according to The Associated Press.

title: Notes on People
description: Dear Abby: The Federal Trade Commission wants you, Mark Spitz and Vida Blue to tone down the content of your advertisements extolling the virtues of milk drinking. In a complaint filed in Washington yesterday yesagainst the California Milk Producers Advisory Board, for which the three of you have made commercials, you would be prohibited from saying in ads that milk consumption can reduce the frequency of colds, is beneficial to everyone or that everyone may consume the beverage without any adverse effects.

title: NIXON TAX STUDY REPORTED SOUGHT BY HEAD OP I.R.S.
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 Donald C. Alexander, the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, has asked that the special Watergate prosecutor's office initiate a grand jury investigation into a possible criminal conspiracy stemming from President Nixon's claim of a $576,000 tax deduction for his VicePresidential papers, wellplaced sources said today.

title: A New Election Is Called in Australia
description: SYDNEY, Australia, April 10 Prime Minister Gough Whitlam announced plans today to hold a national, election for both houses of Parliament.

title: Easter Parade Plans
description: Fifth Avenue from 44th Street to 57th Street will be closed to vehicular traffic from noon to 4 P.M. on Sunday for the traditional Easter parade, Mayor Beame announced yesterday. Crosstown streets will remain open.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Jerry Quarry will meet Joe Alexander in a 10round heavyweight bout on May 8 at the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L. I. It will be the first of six proposed cards at the Coliseum this year to be staged by Top Rank Coliseum, Inc.

title: Deadlock Hinted as Vienna Troop Talks Recess
description: VIENNA, April 10The troopreduction talks between the North Atlantic, Treaty Organization and the Warsaw. Pact have recessed with a spokesman reaffirming NATO's proposal for a twophase reduction of ground forces in Central Europe.

title: PENNSY SUES U.S. FOR $280MILLION
description: The Penn Central Company which owns the company that runs the railroadsued the Federal Government yesterday, for $280million, charging taking of Penn Central property.

title: Senators Query Environment Chief on Reversal of Policy Against Filing Impact Statement
description: WASHINGTON, April 10Russell E. Train, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agencya became ensnarled in apparent contradictions today as he attempted to plain to a Senate subcommittee why die had reversed the agency's policy against filing statements on the impact its regulatory activities have upon the environment.

title: Pakistan Offers Apology to Bangladesh
description: NEW DELHI, April 10Pakistan apologized today for her army's violence during the 1971. Bangladesh war. The apology, which coincided with the decision by Bangladesh to drop the proposed warcrimes trials of 195 Pakistanis, was disclosed with the release of the agreement signed last night by the Foreign Ministers of India, Pakistan and Bangladesh.

title: Conservative Conscience
description: ABROAD AT HOME

title: For a Nobel Geneticist, Always Questions
description: Now that the code of life has been cracked, what is the answer? One of the great puzzlesolvers replies that there it no final answer, there are only, to paraphrase Gertrude Stein, new questions.

title: GOLDA MEIR QUITS AND BRINGS DOWN CABINET IN ISRAEL
description: JERUSALEM, April 10 Premier Golda Meir announced her resignation tonight, bringing down her monthold coalition Government and making new national elections likely in the next several months.

title: Troy Says Council Will Vote to Give Beame Taxing Power, but Reluctantly
description: The county political leaders will have to help with the greatest armtwisting act in history, but a reluctant City Council still will vote to give Mayor Beame the taxing and borrowing authority he wants in the new fiscal year, Matthew J. Troy Jr., the Council's Finance Committee chairman, predicted yesterday.

title: PIZZA HUT SEEKING PIZZA CORPORATION
description: Pizza Hut, Inc., announced yesterday it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire the Pizza Corporation of America in a share exchange involving $22.5million.

title: Bridge: Bidding Championship Gives New Yorkers a Pine Score
Regis College Chooses Head
description: WESTON, Mass., April 10 (AP)Sister Therese Higgins, an assistant professor of English, has been elected president of Regis College, the board of trustees announced. She will assume the office July 1,

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Salting Time

title: A Canadian Railroad Saga Bolsters National Identity
description: MONTREAL, April 10 In the continuing quest for a national identity, Canadians have become enchanted with the story of their railroad.

title: MITCHELL DENIES VESCO FIX CHARGE
description: John N. Mitchell took the witness stand in his own defense yesterday and swore that he never tried to fix or impede a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation in return for a contribution to President Nixon's reelection campaign.

title: Patricia Collinge, 81, Actress In Many Leading Plays Dies
description: Patricia Collinge, an actress who started her career in London in 1904 and came to New York four years later to become an important part of the American theatre, died yesterday at her home, 30 Beekman Place. Her age was 81.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: A Black Driver on the Road to Indianapolis
description: We want to retell the Jackie Robinson story one more time, said Len Miller, president of Black American Racers, Inc., yesterday at news conference announcing that Randy Bethea would drive for the team this season in the Volkswagen Gold Cup, series for Formula Super Vee cars.

title: Nicklaus: Old Master Old Favorite
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 10The softly rolling fairways of the Augusta National Golf Club, bordered with trees and scented with flowers, may be immutable, but not nearly so much as Jack Nicklaus.

title: CONNALLY IS LINKED TO BRIBERY INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) John B. Connally, former Treasury Secretary, is under investigation by Watergate prosecutors for bribery, Jack Anderson, the columnist, said today.

title: PORT BODY DELAYS ACTION ON ROM
description: TRENTON, April 10A move to nominate Dr. William J. Ronan, the chairman of the Metro politan Transportation Authority, as chairman of the per Authority, of New York and New Jersey was temporarily abandoned today when Governor Byrne angrily denounced the effort.

title: O'Dwyer's Power Is Challenged As Council Votes Residency Bill
description: City Council President Paul O'Dwyer's role as presiding officer was noisily challenged yesterday by Councilmen who accused him of attempting to debate a bill after the measure was adopted overwhelmingly.

title: Brown Lacrosse Victor
description: PROVIDENCE, R. 1, April 10Scott Livie scored three goals today to lead Brown's lacrosse team to a 61 victory over Connecticut. The victory was Brown's second straight. Livie put the Bruins in front with two goals in the opening period.

title: Rice and Sugar Prices Offset Other Food Cues
description: Rising prices for suc staples as sugar and rice, which more than offset small declines In some meats, eggs and ice cream, and a scattering of other food items, caused the cost of feeding a family of four in New York City to go up, 0.3 per cent, Elinor Guggenheimer, Consumer Affairs Commissioner, reported yesterday.

title: Bruins Beat Leafs, 10, in Cup Opener
description: BOSTON, April 10 (UPI)Gregg Sheppard scored a secondperiod goal and Gilles Gilbert made ft stand up tonight as the Boston Bruins defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs, 10, in the opening game of their Stanley Cup playoff quarterfinals.

title: F. DEWEY EVERETT
description: F. Dewey Everett, who retired as an investment banker in 1973, died at his home, 179 East. 70th Street, on Tuesday. He was 85 years old,

title: Head of Fort Worth Club Known as Mr. Dog Show
description: Herman Cox in Fort Worth is Mr. Dog Show. He has been president of the Fort Worth Kennel Club in 1937, 1938, 1941, 1943 and, 1973. When I started; he recalled, we had an entry of 250. Handlers would come down to make champions of their secondrate dogs. That's past history. Last month, the Texas fixture drew 2,346, including some of the topwinners in the country.

title: French CatholicOriented Union in Shift, Backs Leftist for the Presidency
description: PARIS, April 10France's second biggest labor union has announced its support for the single candidate of the Left for the Presidency, Francois Mitterrand. This new development on the French political scene is one that perhaps most worries the already frazzled government coalition.

title: ... How to Meet It?
description: Unfortunately, Mayor Beame still does not appear to heed the sound advice of Controller Beame. To a budget already overburdened with debt he proposes adding $520 million more in longterm borrowing. He again plans to roll over some current obligations into the next budget. And he is proposing to eliminate the rainy day fund altogether.

title: PRINCIPAL IS KILLED IN AN ULSTER SCHOOL
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 10 (UPI)Gunmen burst into a primary school near the border of the Irish Republicduring classes today and killed the Protestant principal, the police said.

title: More Big Banks in U.S. Set Prime Rate at 10%
description: Several of the country's major banks raised their, prime rate yesterday from 9 per cent to 10 per cent, following the move to the 10 per cent figure by Bankers Trust Company of New York on Monday.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 37

title: U.S. WILL PRESS ON FOR GOLAN ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, April 10Diplomas and Administration officials said today that they expected the American effotts to bring about a troopSeparation agreement between Israel and Syria would continue despite the political crisis in Israel.

title: Gasoline Crisis Was WorsenedBy Con Men, Panel Discloses
description: WASHINGTON, April 10A Senate subcommittee investigating the energy crisis disclosed today that it had found that con men and fly by night companies had tried to take advantage of the gasoline shortage by claiming to act as brokers for nonexistent fuel.

title: ContainerCurb Hearing Set
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) Senate hearings will be held April 30 and May 1 on whether to have a national ban on nonreturnable beverage containers. Sponsor of the bill, Senator Mark 0. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, said, The people of Oregon have shown that we can reject the throwaway society exemplified by snaptab, fliptop, throwaaway cans and bottles.

title: Surviving Murphy Art Is at the Modern
description: It would take a very good novelist to tax our credulity with the sequence of events by which the six surviving paintings of Gerald Murphy have ended up as the nucleus of a Museum of Modern Art exhibition that is a distinct contribution to the history of modern American painting. Murphy himself left most of them in France, rolled up and abandoned, more than 40 years ago; yet here they are piked with memorabilia and accompanied by a catalogue exemplary in its thoroughness. (Give William Rubin, director of painting and sculpture the first chapter of the Book of Genesis, and he could be counted upon to come up with a revised chronology.)

title: J. FRANKLIN VAN DEREN
description: J. Franklin Van Deren, a partner in the New York law firm of Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft, died, apparently of a heart attack, last evening at his home, 7 Gingko Lane, Greenwich, Conn. He was 65 years old.

title: Top Chinese Who Made Comeback
description: HONG KONG, April 10A year ago this week, Teng Hsiaoping managed to scramble off what Trotsky and Communists after him have called the dust bin of history. He had been discarded there at the, height of the Cultural Revolution in 1966, when he was purged for supporting a bourgeois reactionary line in opposition to Chairman Mao Tsetung. For five years, he was not seen in public and was mentioned only to be vilified as a demon or freak.

title: OIL CONCERNS SET EXPANSION PLANS
description: Expansion projects costing close to half a billion dollars were announced, yesterday by major oil companies.

title: Personal Finance
description: Fred Brown, a young and promising freelance writer, carries a credit card issued to him in his business capacity. He used it in his travels in search of information for articles.

title: Subway Builder Is Killed; 2 Hurt as Walk Collapses
description: A construction worker was killed and two women were injured yesterday afternoon when a sidewalk collapsed on them as they were in an excavation site for the Second Avenue Subway at 119th Street.

title: CITICORP RAISES IS EARNINGS 26
description: Citicorp, parent of New York's largest bank, the First National City, Yesterday reported that firstquarter operating earnings rose 26 per cent to $73.2million, or 60 cents a share, from $58.2million, or 50 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1973.

title: Beinecke Library Mounts a Display
description: NEW HAVEN, April 11 The Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library at Yale University marked its 10th anniversary yesterday with a special exhibition of materials; from its collection.

title: House Republicans Warn Of Subpoena Over Tapes
