description: WASHINGTON, April 10Republican members sent word to the White House today that the House Judiciary Committee was virtually certain to subpoena material requested in February unless some concession was made before tomorrow.

title: Stand By Tape Message Signals Computer Snarl
description: Stand by read the New York Stock Exchange tape as it flashed over the exchange floor and into the 2,750 firms from Wall Street to Hong Kong yesterday. Resumption of service is expected shortly.

title: SHOP TALK
description: A La Vielle Russie, the antiques shop at Fifth Avenue and 59th Street, doesn't have any Faberge eggs this year, but even without such masterpieces, there is a representative selection of the kinds of eggs that affluent people in prerevolutionary Russia used to give as Easter presents.

title: 2 Reputed Mafia Figures Freed in TaxEvasion Trial
description: DETROIT, April 10 (AP)A United States District Court jury has acquitted two reputed Mafia figures, Anthony and Vito Giacalone, on five counts of incometax evasion.

title: Lawyer Given 30 Years For Trenton Robbery Plot
description: TRENTON, April 10 (AP)Lawrence Stein, a lawyer, has been sentenced to 30 years for the kidnapping of a dentist's wife and daughter in a robbery at their Trenton home.

title: Et Tu, Gerry?
description: WASHINGTON, April 10In President Nixon's news summary this morning, the story causing dismay and outrage is a summary of an article in The New Republic entitled Ford's Future, by John Osborne.

title: PHILIP H. WILLKIE BANKER, IS DEAD
description: RUSHVILLE, Ind., April 10 (AP)  Philip H. Willkie, the only child of Wendell L. Willkie the 1940 Republican Presidential candidate, died today at his home near here. He was 54 year old.

title: Britain Floats New Bond
description: LONDON, April 10 (Reuters) Britain announced today a, new Government bond issue, Treasuiy 11 per cent of 1977, totaling 600million. The bond; at a price of 98.25 per cent cash, carries a redemption yield of 12.13 per cent Application lists will open and close on April 18.

title: GOLDA MEIR QUITS AND BRINGS DOWN CABINET IN ISRAEL
description: JERUSALEM, April 10 Premier, Golda Meir announced her resignation tonight, bringing down her monthold coalition Government and making new national elections likely in the next several months.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: SILVERBERG SEEN INTERSTATE CHIEF
description: Lorence A. Silverberg, chairman and president of the Kenton Corporation, is expected to become president and chief executive officer of Interstate Stores, Inc., when its pending purchases of more than 1,100 McCrory stores is completed. Consummation of Interstate's $150million acquisition of McCrory's G. McNew, S. Klein and Britt's stores is due shortly, according to authoritative sources.

title: Fighting Breaks Out in Southern Laos, First Since Accord
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 10 (AP)About 150 North Vietnamese and Pathet Lao soldiers have made a series of attacks along a strategic highway in southern Laos, sources in this capital said today. It was the first ceasefire violation reported since the Pathet Lao joined a coalition Government with the rightists and neutralists in Vientiane Friday.

title: Celanese Gets Proposals of Feminists
description: The first, shareholder proposals to be submitted by feminitts at a major company's annual meeting were voted on yesterday by stockholders of the Celanese Corporation at the Essex House.

title: Syria Asserts Israeli Shells Nearly Hit U.N. Commander
description: DAMASCUS, April 10 (AP)  Syria said today that Israeli shells nearly hit the new commander of United Nations truce observers in the Middle East.

title: The Computer Snarl
description: Yesterday's computer delay on the New York Stock Exchange was the fourth computerrelated incident in two years. Details on Page 50.

title: BENJAMIN LEVY
description: Benjamin Levy, who served in the New York Fire Department from 1907 until his retirement in 1954, died in Coney Island Hospital on Tuesday evening. He was 89 years of and lived at 1900 Quentin Road, Brooklyn.

title: Tenor, Mayor Make Their Pitch
description: On the 10th anniversary of the Mets' arrival at Shea Stadium, Ed Kranepool reflected yesterday on the disaster of 1964.

title: Contract Awards
description: Wheelabrator Frye, Inc., said yesterday its subsidiaries had received contracts with a total value of $363million for two projects. As most shoppers know, products of all kinds  but especially foodsfrequently turn up in smaller quantities without notice. Shoppers often do not realize, until they get home, that the chocolate bar, for example, is not the same size it used to be.

title: Moscow: The Pursuit of Dtente
description: MOSCOW  No politically active person can be indifferent, in a positive or negative sense to the joint determination, proclaimed by Moscow and Washington two years ago to pursue a course of peaceful coexistence and expanding cooperation in solving urgent international problems. Taking into account the significance of this move for the destinies of millions of people, it is easy to understand why the rest of the world continually watches the pulse of SovietAmerican relations.

title: SALT in Detente
description: In his Moscow visit, Secretary Kissinger sought without success to lay the basis for a second strategic arms limitation treaty (SALT II) by seeking conceptual agreement on establishing essential equivalence for the two sides in strategic offensive forces. Two years after SALT I, an agreed concept is still lacking. The fundamental problem is that the two sides have very different forces quantitatively and qualitatively and both are engaged in vigorous modernization programs that will further alter the force relationships.

title: 1,200 Winners of National Merit Scholarships Are Announced
On the Lam With Perky Pair in the West:The Cast
description: Two graceful bank robbers, an antique car jouncing through the landscape to larky music, outlaws who wonder what history will say about themno, this isn't a carbon of "Bonnie and Clyde," although some parallels are powerful. "Thomasine and Bushrod," which opened yesterday at the Penthouse Theater and the 86th Street East, is a black Western of considerable freshness, directed by Gordon Parks Jr. It's dated between 1912 and 1915, when a number of black people dwelled throughout the West.Bushrod, (Max Julien, who wrote and co-produced the picture) and Thomasine (Vonetta McGee) live on the lam in the wilderness. Between stickups tnd shootouts, they share many of their spoils with Indians, Mexicans and poor whites, for whom they become folk heroes. Pursued by a fabulously evil white sheriff (George Murdoch), who vows to kill them, Thomasine and Bushrod are both cowboys and Indians, the hunters and the hunted.The movie is somewhat thin on plot, but the script gives some fresh twists to old formulas, especially the sex roles. Thomasine is an independent, feisty woman, who craves equal billing on their WANTED postersand gets it. Bushrod, although lethal to his enemies, is a reluctant outlaw who yearns for another way of life, and he's characterized as a man who's not afraid to be gentle or sensitive. Meanwhile, these lovers fight with gusto. But they're definitely partnersin a way that's rare on screen, or among cow-persons.There are some slow moments, but the picture is carried by the talents of the two performers. Their style is utterly contemporarynot that it really matters. Miss McGee  laughing or raging, reveling in risks  alternates a luxurious cool sass with a rebel's defiance, and Mr. Julien's beguiling humor and flexibility make him all the more formidable when he's behind a gun.

The more hides he pulled the more money he got, so he pulled hides furiously and that made his back hurt and he began to perceive that anybody who would choose to strain himself to make a living must be stupid.

title: Dragging Out Watergate
description: President Nixon has persistently charged that the House Judiciary Committee is guilty of fishing expeditions in its request for tapes and documents needed for the impeachment inquiry. title: Having at the AvantGarde
description: DEATH, SLEEP AND THE TRAVELER. By John Hawkes. 170 pages. New Directions. $6.95. On page three of Death, Sleep and the Traveler, I came across a sentence which confirmed my worst fears about the book. Speculating on his given name, which is Allert, the Dutch narrator writes: But in Dutch and despite the accent on the first syllable, my name is clearly repository for the English word alert, as if the name is a 1,000yearold clay receptacle with paranoia curled in the shape of a child's skeleton inside. On page 17, describing the sun setting on a house and a car parked outside it, he writes: The setting sun was licking the hard bright machine like some great invisible beast on its knees. On page 26, he informs us that the thought of salt water is unbearable to me.

Foreign Relations Committee, has painted a gloomy picture of the current state of Middle East negotiations, Western EuropeanAmerican relations and the nuclear arms talks with the Soviet Union.

title: Jersey Warned on Gas
description: New Jersey's energy chief warned that the alterpateday gasoline sales program would have to be put back into effect if gasoline consumption in the state continued to increase. In Connecticut there were signs that more stations were, going dry. But in New York gasoline supplies appeared to remain adequate. [Page 62.]

title: N.B.A. Playoffs
description: Knicks vs. Capital

title: $800Million Plant Set By American Electric Power
description: The American Electric Power Company announced yesterday plans for building an $800million electric power plant in Sullivan County, Ind. Donald C. Cook, chairman, said the plant would be built by an operating subsidiary, the Indiana and Michigan Electric Company of Fort Wayne, adjacent to its existing breed station on the Wabash River near Sullivan, Ind.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: BOOK BY MONROE TO APPEAR IN JUNE
description: In the early nineteenfifties, according to Milton H. Greene, the photographer, Marilyn Monroe gave him an autobiography of her life from her childhood spent in orphanages to her marriage to Joe DiMaggio.

title: VOTE ON HOLCOMB FOR F.C.C DELAYED
description: A Senate Commerce Committee vote on the nomination of the Rev. Luther Holcomb for a Democratic seat on the Federal Communications Commission has been held up until after the Easter recess, partly because of questions raised concerning his political affiliation, according to Senate sources.

title: DUPONT ESTATE SET TO SELL BANK STOCK
description: Edward Ball, a trustee of the Alfred I du Pont estate, said in Jacksonville, Fla., yesterday that the trustees of the estate had agreed to sell its 2,330,638 shares of Florida National Banks of Florida, Inc.

title: NIXON AIDE HINTS PARTIAL RESPONSE
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 The White House indicated tonight that President Nixon would probably turn over some, but not all, of the materials subpoenaed earlier today by the House Judiciary Committee.

title: RISING PRICES FAIL TO SPUR INCREASE IN OIL PRODUCTION
description: A Nixon Administration program introduced last summer to spur greater production of domestic crude oil by allowing its price to rise has failed to provide more oil. It has, however, enabled the nation's big oil companies to raise the prices of their own crude oil Sharply and pass those higher prices along to consumers of gasoline and fuel oil. It has also provided soaring profits for oil companies.

title: LITTLE LEAGUE HQ PRODDED ON GIRLS
description: NEWARK, April 11A State Superior Court judge today issued, an order directing the national Little League organization to use its best efforts to insure that local Little League teaths comply with both the letter and spirit of a New Jersey regulation directing integration of girls into the historicaily allboy baseball organization.

title: Mrs. Meir Steps Down
description: The irrevocable resignation of Premier Golda Meir is the direct result, somewhat delayed, of Israel's setbacks in last October's war. Extraordinary strains have been imposed on the country's fragmented political structure by a difficult psychological adjustment to the nation's new and fundamentally altered situation in the world. The recriminations over responsibility for the military losses in October, which triggered the current Cabinet crisis, are important mainly as they suggest further splintering of the national consensus and, with it, a weakening of confidence in the future.

title: HOUSE SUBPOENA BIDS PRESIDENT TURN OVER TAPES, OTHER MATERIAL; WHITE HOUSE MAY YIELD SOME DATA
Contract Awards
description: Honeywell, Inc., said yesterday that Its areospace division's contract with the Rockwell Internatianal Corporation for flight controls for the space shuttle had a dollar value of $58million and add reach $74million over the next eight years.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: East German Six Beats Poland, 53HELSINKI, Finlind, April 11 (AP)East Germany scored four goals in the second period and beat Poland, in the world hockey championships. Poland had a 31 lead after the first period. But midway through the second, Reinhard Karger and Bernd Karenbauer scored within two minutes of each other for East Germany. Karger then put East Germany ahead,, 43, and Ruediger Noack added the other score with just two seconds to go in the period.

title: New Summary and Index
description: Three Arab terrorists stormed an apartment building in Qiryat Shemona, Israel, near the Lebanese border, and killed 18 people, mostly women and children, before the terrorists were themselves killed. It was the worst such attack since 1972, when 27 penpie were killed at the Tel Aviv airport. [1:23.]

title: SWIDLE BACKED BY STATE SENATE
description: ALBANY, April 11Joseph C. Swidler, chairman of the State Public Service Commission, was confirmed by the Senate tonight for reappointment amid pledges by the Republican, leadership that shakeups in the commission would be considered before the end of the legislative session next month.

title: GROMYKO IN TALKS IN CAPITAL TODAY
description: WASHINGTON, April 11President Nixon and Secretary of State Kissinger will meet tomorrow with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, to work out areas of agreement and to build public support for Mr. Nixon's planned visit to Moscow in June.

title: Joseph B. Stack, 83, Is Dead; RareCoin Dealer and Collector
description: Joseph B. Stack, a dealer in rare coins, died on Wednesday evening, apparently of a coronary attack, at his winter home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 83 years old and lived also in this city.

title: SAIGON RANGER UNIT REPORTED OVERRUN
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, April 12 (AP)North Vietnamese and Vietcong forces apparently overran the Tong Le Chan ranger camp 50 miles north of Saigon early today after a seige of nearly 14 months, Government military sources reported.

title: Peter Gets 30Day Term For Lying on Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 Herbert L. Porter, a former aide in the reelection campaign of President Nixon, was sentenced today to 15 months in prison for lying to the Federal Bureau of Investigation in its Waterdate Inquiry. But a Federal istrict judge suspended all except 30 days of the sentence.

title: Beame Seeks More Aid; Governor Is Uncommitted
description: ALBANY, April 11  Mayor Beame made a fourhour plea to Governor Wilson today for additional state aid to close the city's projected budget gap. But the Governor gave no indication of what he would do, except, sources said, to show anger over being portrayed as trying to force the city to raise its realestate taxes.

title: County Executives' Body Urges Study of State Retirement Fund
description: MINEOLA, L.I., April 11The New York County Executives Association called on the State Legislature today to establish a study commission to overhaul the retirement fund and scrutinize the State Controller's investment policies.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS
description: April 11, 1974

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: L.I.R.R. TIMETABLE TO ADD 47 TRAINS
description: Beginning May 20, the Long Island Rail Road will put into effect new timetables on all of its branches, adding 47 trains a daymany of them expresses and speeding up most of its trains, the line's president, Walter L. Schlager Jr., anpounced yesterday.

title: POLICE OBJECT TO ROCK FESTIVAL
description: The police, after an unusual (meeting in the Police Commissioner's office yesterday morning, have refused to block off a West Side street for a rock festival that is expected to draw tens of thousands of fans in connection with the world premiere of a Rolling Stones movie on Sunday evening.

title: Aaron Gets His 3d Hit, Another Homer
description: ATLANTA, April 11 (AP) Hank Aaron drilled his 716th career home run tonight in the seventh inning, snapping a tie and helping the Atlanta Braves to a 64 triumph over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: The Forgotten. Realities
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 11  The nations of the world are gathered here at the big peace palace on the East Rivet to discuss one of the most fundamental questions of the futurethe supply, price and distribution of food, oil and the other essential raw materials of lifeand the odd and tragic thing about it is that very few people, newspapers, or networks are paying any attention to the debate.

title: An ExMilitary tactician Uses Skills to Run Briarcliff College
description: BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., April 10Last summer, at the edge of despair, the women's college that has stood above this town for several decades went looking for a new president. Enrollment was falling, morale was low  We were not sure we'd survive, a faculty member recalled.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 33

title: CORN PRICES FALL THE DAILY LIMIT
description: Heavy selling of corn futures by two leading exporters the Bunge Corporation and the Louis Dreyfus Corporation, helped depress corn prices yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Brezhnev Criticizes Ersatz Plans for Mideast
description: MOSCOW, April 11Leonard I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, today warned the visiting Syrian President, Hafez alAssad, that the United States and Israel might try to substitute a SyrianIsraeli disengagement agreement, for a genuine peace settlement in the Middle East.

title: Hell to Pay in the Hamburger Hutch
description: Roy A. Cork was a feisty old guy of 71 who had made his stack in the baseball business. Growing up in Chicago, he had held a variety of jobs, selling Lily cups, promoting a machine that made six or eight malted milks at a time, and it was comparatively late in life before he found his metierbaseball. When he did, he made a resounding success of it and by the time he was 70 his personal fortune was said to be at least $500million. He still considered Chicago his home but also maintained a plush winter residence in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: Arab Guerrillas Kill in Israeli Town, Then Die in Blast at Apartment House
description: QIRYAT SHEMONA, Israel, April 11  Eighteen people, mostly women and children, were killed here today by three Arab guerrillas who stormed fourstory residential building.

title: Harris, Upham & Co. Weighs Assuming Hutton Lease
description: Henry U, Harris Jr., president of Harris, Upham & Co., Inc., said yesterday that his firm has discussed taking over one brokeage office lease to be vacated by W. E. Hutton & Co. In New York City.

title: Japan Steel Output Up
description: TOKYO, April 11 (AP)Japan's crude steel production totaled a record 120 million metric tons in fiscal 1973, which ended March 31, 1974, 16.6 per cent over the proceeding year, the Japan Iron and Steel Federation said today.

title: People in Sports
description: Willie Stargefl, the Pittsburgh Pirates' slugger who led the major leagues last year in home runs with 44, runs batted in (119), doubles (43), Slugging percentage (646) and, gamewinning bits 28) but was passed over as. the National League's most valuable player in favor of Pete Rose of Cincinnati, received a trophy he said he can identify with yesterday. Bowle Kuhn, the baseball commissioner, presented him with the Roberto Clemente Humanitarian Award for exceptional service to baseball.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: CRESSKILL, April 11Ken Rabat has reached most of his goals in life. But now the pleasant, articulate Rabat kids his sights on winning the Kentucky Derby of 1975. That may prove to be the hardest obstacle of all, he said. The competition is enormous.

title: A VOLLEYBALL GAME IS PLAYED NONSTOP
description: MATAWAN, April 11 (UPI) A group of 18 New Jersey high school volleyball players, despite sore hands and blisters, passed the twothirds mark today in their effort to break the world's record for continuous volleyball play.

title: HENRY PEARLMAN, COLLECTOR, DEAD
description: Henry Pearlman, a collector of impressionist and postimpressionist art whose private collection has been widely exhibited, died Wednesday at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at 993 Park Avenue.

title: Jersey Aide Warns of New Gasoline Curb
description: New Jersey's energy chief said yesterday that the state's alternateday gasoline sales program would have to be restored if gasoline consumption continued to rise as it has so far this month.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Can Ed Warns Users To Pay in 2 Months
description: The Consolidated Edison Company said yesterday that to speed the collection of overdue bills, it had begun sending out disconnection notices one month earlier.

title: Jury Finds Boyle Guilty In 3 Yablonski Murders
description: I MEDIA, Pa., April W. A. Boyle, the deposed president of they United Mine Workers of America, was found guilty tonight of three charges of firstdegree murder in ordering the assassination of Joseph A. Yablonski, a reformist election rival in the union.

title: Birdies Sing a Record for Irwin
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 11On the 15th green at the Augusta National Golf Club today, Hale Irwin was lining up a fourfoot putt when he realized what another birdie would mean.

title: Meehan to Stump Against Lefkowitz In All 62 Counties
description: Robert R. Meehan, who is serving his third term as Rockland County District Attorney, said yesterday that he would campaign in all 62 of the state's counties in pursuit of the Democratic nomination for State Attorney General.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page, 33

title: Dismissing of Indictments On Alleged Vote Plot Upheld
description: The Appellate Division yesterday upheld a decision by State Supreme Court Justice Burton B. Roberts last January dismissing indictments against Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea, Republican of Montauk, Li., and other politicians who were charged with violating an electionlaw provision that prohibited anonymous electioncampaign literature.

title: Country's Hasidim Honor Schneerson on 72d Birthday
description: Rabbi Menachem M. Schneerson, spiritual leader of the Lubavitcher Movement  the worldwide body of Hasidic Jewswas honored by his followers yesterday on his 72d birthday with gifts from installations of the movement the country over.

title: Judge Rebuffs Thaler Suit As New Highin Chutzpah
description: NEW HAVEN, April 11Former New York State Senator Seymour R. Thaler, now serving a year in jail for selling stolen securities, was denounced by a Federal judge today for filing a $52.5million suit that, in effect, accused a bank of negligent failure to catch him at his own scheme.

title: The Court Ought to Decide for Mr. DeFunis'
description: WASHINGTONSome time this spring, the United States Supreme Court will decide the reversediscrimination DeFunis case. If the Court decides the case on the merits at all, it ought to decide for Mr. DeFunis.

title: RCA Earnings Drop 17% in First Period
description: The RCA Corporation reported yesterday a 17 per cent drop in first quarter earnings, while sales climbed by 7 per cent.

title: Campaign Reform Bill Passes Senate, 53 to 32, Amid Predictions That It Will Never Become Law
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 After 13 days of debate and 51 rollcall votes, the Senate passed today a sweeping campaign reform bill that would use taxpayers' money instead of large private contributions to pay for Presidential and Congressional election campaigns starting in 1976.

title: Yankees Lose to Tigers
description: DETROIT, April 11Joe Coleman of the Tigers ended the Yankees' ministreak of four victories today with a strong pitching performance that had the New York team hitless and runless into the eighth inning. Detroit won the game, 41, as the Tiger bats made 12 hits off Mel Stottlemyre and Tom Buskey.

title: Harness Tip Backfired, Court Told
description: Forrest Gerry Jr. often told him he had to meet Del or Buddy for lunch, the former manager of, an Offtrack Betting Corporation shop testified yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court.

title: Weekly Retail Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $1.005billion, up 10 per cent from the yearearlier $912million. Total retail store sales were about $10.106billion, up 8 per cent from last year's $9.345billion.

title: Wood, Field & Stream
description: Arriving at this writer's desk on the same day recently were two communications that dramatized the plight of the Atlantic bluefin tuna, one of the world's truly magnificent game fishes, and an important commercial species as well.

title: British Bank Rate Cut
description: LONDON, April 11 (Reuters) The Bank of England cu?? its minimum lending rate today for the second time in seven days, but the move had little effect on international sterling dealings. The lending rate was reduced by onequarter of 1 percentage point to 12 per cent, (after earlier cuts from the crisis level of 13 per cent. The rate is now the lowest since November.

title: New Music, Some Cute, Some Serious
description: There was, at least, one cute piece on the Evenings for New Music program Wednesday night at Carne gie Recital Hall. It was Christian Wolff's Burdocks, though there may be a little doubt whether the composer intended it as a light divertissement. The players certainly went through it deadpan. But when Julius Eastman, sitting on the stage in profile like a catatonic, gravely started his narration with My mother told me always to brush my teeth early in the morning  the audience started chuckling and kept chuckling throughout 15

title: Stock Prices Mixed in Dull Trading
description: Stocks were irregular yesterday in the slowest trading in almost eight months as investors' concern over rising interest rates inhibited activity.

title: British Football
description: SCOTTISH LEAGUE

title: Markets Are Closed
description: Securities exchanges and commodity markets will be closed today for the Good Friday holiday. Banks will be open in New York today, but closed in Connecticut and New Jersey.

title: Israel Cautions Lebanese After Raid by Terrorists
description: JERUSALEM, April 11Premier Golda Meir warned the Government of Lebanon today that Israel would hold it responsible for the Arab terrorist attack in northern Israel this morning in which 18 Isarelis were killed.

title: Soviet Increases Target for Oil Output
description: MOSCOW, April 11The Soviet Oil Minister, Valentin D. Shashin, has revealed an increased target for Soviet oil production this year of 458 million tons, a potential increase of 37 million tons over production in 1973.

title: EXTAX AIDE TERMED WHITE HOUSE SOURCE
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) The White House obtained sensitive tax information on its friends and enemies from a highly placed official of the Internal Revenue Service according to secret testimony given under oath by a former law enforcement adviser to President Nixon.

title: Texasgulf Earnings Climb 193% As Sales Gain 46% in Quarter
Drolet Is Keeping the Horses in Shape As Filion Drive to Surpass Records
description: YONKERS, April 11Everybody at Yonkers and Roosevelt Raceways know that Herve Filion is the top moneywinning harness driver in North America. The name of Jean Drolet is less familiar and yet the 28yearold trainer must share in much of Filion's success. Drolet is in charge of Nerve's 40 horses, the largest number on the grounds here. He has a crew of 18 working for him and reports directly to Herve night.

title: Texts of House Panel Memorandums on Subpoena to Nixon on Watergate Data
description: WASHINGTON, April 11Following is the text of a memorandum presented today to the House Judiciary Committee by counsel outlining the legal and historical precedents for the subpoena to President Nixon for documents in the Watergate case:

title: CORPORATE BONDS DECLINE IN PRIGE
description: Prices eased somewhat in quiet, preholiday trading in the corporate bond market yesterday, Wednesday's upturn in the taxexempt market extended it self modestly and the Government market also showed some gains. In the Governnment market itself the trading pace remained sub dued with prices firming, as several specialists described them, in the shorter maturities through the intermediate couissues.

title: Bill on Death Penalty Is Stalled; House Vote by Fall Held Unlikely
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 Legislation to reinstate the death penalty, approved decisively by the Senate a month ago, appears unlikely to clear the House before this uneasy electionyear session of Congress adjourns.

title: Algerian President Sees Nixon on ThirdWorld Ties
description: WASHINGTON, April 11President Houari Boumediene of Algeria spent more than an hour today at the White House in talks with President Nixon. American and Algerian officials said that most of the discussion dealt with changes in the economic relations between rich and poor countries.

description: WASHINGTON, April 11At the time of the Cuban adagio, crisis an 1962, Secretary of Detense Robert S. MeNamara told his colleagues that a missile iS a missile is a missile and that having more or less was not critical.

description: WASHINGTON, April 11Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor, has subpoenaed the Federal income tax returns of Charles G. Rebozo and Robert H. Abplanalp, two of President Nixon's closest friends, in the investigation of a $100,000 campaign contribution from Howard R. Hughes, wellplaced sources said today.

description: Indiana vs. San Antonio

title: TV: Easter Week Will Offier Predictable Fare
description: There is little terribly special about the television schedule of Easter programing. Wednesday evening on the Columbia Broadcasting system, Perry Como conchided his Sunshine Hone singing the Lord's Prayer. The rest of the program was generally business ad usual, but the business was distinctively attractive. With frank Sinatra reaping publicity these days, Mr. Como deserves kudos of his own, having survived with physique and voice considerably more intact. Evidently, the lowkey approach has its energysaving assets.

title: Senate RollCall Vote On Campaign Reform
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP)Following is the rollcall vote by which the Senate passed a major campaignreform bill today:

title: consumer Unit Moving To Regulate Pet Shops
description: Under regulations proposed by the city's Department of Consumer Affairs, operators of pet stores would be required, at the time an animal is sold, to provide health certificates signed by city veterinarians and proof of any pedigree.

title: Westar Launching Delayed
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, April 11 (UPI)The launching of Westar, America's first domestic communications satellite, was postponed today because of problems with the Delta booster rocket.

title: Bridge: Half  Hearted Preemption Can Lead to Some Trouble
description: A player contemplating preemptive action should bear in mind that halfhearted preemption is often worse than none at all. If you fail to shut the opponents out of the auction and they buy the contract, the declarer will have distributional clues that may help him make a contract that would otherwise fail.

title: Yorkville Fighting Loss of Old Flavor
description: Those Yorkville residents who have long campaigned to stem what they call the slow creep of commercialism over one of the last polyglot middle European neighborhoods in the city feel they have finally won a victory.

title: JUDGERACE SHIFT IS VOTED FOR CITY
description: ALBANY, April 11All 120 Civil Court judges in New York City would be elected by districts rather than boroughwide under a bill approved today by the Senate and sent to the Assembly.

Miss Bleything had retired from the advertising business in 1940.

Luther Holcomb for a Democratic seat on the Federal Communications Commission has been held, up until after the Easter recess, partly because of questions raised concerning his political affiliation, according to Senate sources.

description: A. 56yearold male patient jumped to his death yesterday at Triboro Hospital, at Parsons, Boulevard and Goethals Avenue in Jamaica, Queens. The Ipolice identified him as Wyatte Robinson of 11746 Springfield Boulevard, Queens Village, an asthma sufferer who was admitted on Tuesday. He reoortedly jumped from a fifthfloorl landing, landed one floor below, then picked himself up and jumped again, landing oni the second floor.

description: DETROIT, April 11  American auto production is scheduled to total 133,882 units this week, a drop of 7.6 per cent from the 144,856 built last week because the plants are only working four days due to Good Friday.

title: Bottom Up
description: The long wait for a higher Federal floor under wages has ended with President Nixon's signing of a wage law only slightly different from the one he vetoed last fall. Inflation's inroads on the living standards of the working poor, soon to be intensified by total abandonment of controls, clearly necessitated a rise in the $1.60anhour minimum established six years ago.

title: Yorkville Fighting Loss of Old Flavor
description: Those Yorkville residents who have long campaigned to stem what they call the slow creep of commercialism over one of the last polyglot middle European neighborhoods in the city feel they have finally won a victory.

title: Vivid Revivals for Ibsen and O'Neill
description: Intelligence, imagination and practical adjustments can vivify a theater antique without streamlining the original sould of the drama to death. Take Ibsen's Brand (1866) and O'Neill's Desire Under the Elms (1924) at two Off Off Broadway showcases.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Fifteen persons were arrested in organized raids in three Essex County communities on charges of selling and possessing drugs. Bloomfield Sgt. title: Laver, Borg Win Gam Quarterfinal

title: Fishermen Say Strike Saved Loss Situation
description: BELFORD, April 11  Jersey Shore commercial fishermen reported today that their twoweek strike last February against the New York wholesale market, from which they withheld their catches, had resulted in better prices for whiting and ling, the principal catch of the season.

description: TOKYO, April 11 (UPI)Rod Laver of Australia and Bjorn Borg, a Swedish teenager, advanced today to, the quarterfinals of the $50,000 Kawasaki classic, becoming the only seeded players to survive a series of upsets in the World Championship Tenis tournament.

title: South Asian Example
description: The agreement of Pakistan and Bangladesh in New Delhi to forgive and forget the bitter antagonisms and bloody deeds that tore them apart two years ago is an exemplary act of statesmanship.

title: Exxon Lifts Price On Wholesale Gas 1.6 Cents a Gallon
description: The Exxon Corporation announced yesterday that it had raised its wholesale prices of gasoline by 1.6 cents a gallon. At the same time the company reduced it middle distillate prices by 2 cents a gallon. Distillate products affected by the reduction include diesel fuel and homeheating oil.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Senator Buckley in his much publicized statement said: If the President withdrew, this crisis would be resolved. It would not. On the contrary, the real crisis would only begin. The President's resignation would deal a devastating blow to the legitimacy of our form of government, and not only to the office of the President, but also to the very genesis of our countryits Constitution.

title: Cards Chase Seaver, Beat Mets Twice
Weather Reports and Forecast
Judge Says Reinecke Trial Will Start Before Primary
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (UPI)A Federal judge said today that Lieut. Gov. Ed Reinecke of California would go to trial on perjury charges before the state primary election in which he is seeking the Republican gubernatorial nomination.

title: Pope Washes Feet Of Crippled Boys In Holy Week Rite
description: ROME, April 11  Pope Paul, in a Maundy Thursday rite tonight, washed the feet of 12 boys from an institution for crippled children and saluted priests all over the world.

title: Jobholders Get Chance to Air Gripes at PitneyBowes
description: STAMFORD, Conn, April 11 Is there a corporate policy on streaking? asked one employe.

title: Trapnell Loses His Appeal Of '73 Hijacking Conviction
description: The United States Court of Appeals has upheld the planehijacking conviction of Garrett B. Trapnell, who had been sentenced here to life in prison.

title: Leila Novak Is Remarried
description: Mrs. Leila Novak, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Z. Novak of Lincolnwood, Ill., was married yesterday evening to James Francis Lasser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Lasser of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Maurice Davis and Rabbi Manuel Gold performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: WaiterDiner Confrontation
description: People are always writing books about how to get along with your boss, how to get along with your spouse, and even how to get along with yourself, but nobody yet has put the waiterdiner relationship under analysis. It is a complicated and hazardous confrontation, demanding attention to spot reactions, tactful changes of attitude on instant notice, specialized vocabulary according to circumstances, and sometimes a talent for deception.

title: Business Brief
description: Erosion in Consumer Attitudes Grows

title: TIMES SQ. CASINOS CALLED A BAD BET
description: ALBANY, April 11  The proposal of Times Square merchants to revive their area with legal gambling casinos received is decidedly negative reaction among legislative leaders today, some of whom voiced the opinion that it would amount to substituting Sodom for Gomorrah.

title: Books of The Times
description: ALIVE: The Story of the Andes Survivors. By Piers Paul Read. 352 Pages. Illustrated. Lippincott $,10.

title: PETE WENDLING, 85, SONG WRITER, DEAD
description: Pete Wendling, composer of Oh! What a Pal Was Mary and other popular songs, died Sunday at his home here. He was 85 years old.

title: Nets' Honeymoon Over: Colonels Next Opponent
description: UNIONDALE, L.L, April 11 The Virginia Squires, whom the New York Nets eliminated in five games in their American Basketball Association semifinal series, were just a warmup for what the Nets can expect next.

title: Baseball Roundup
description: Elrod Hendricks scored from second base on a wild throw during an attempted double play in the 11th inning to give Baltimore a 76 victory over Boston. Hendricks had opened the inning with a single and went to second on a.walk to Rich Coggins, Bobby Grich hit a. grounder to Mario Guerrero at shortstop, Guerrero forced Coggins at second but Doug Griffin's relay to first bounced into the Red Sox dugout allowing Hendricks to score the deciding run.

title: Attica,' Moving Doucmentary of Riot:Comment on Stills
description: The place is the Attica, N.Y., prison on a September day in 1971. The prisoners mill around the yard, improvising tents, sleeping, looking uneasily at cameras, which, equipped with telescopic lenses, can see them far more clearly than they can see the cameras.The prisoners at Attica are in the middle of rebellion. They've issued a manifesto demanding reforms dealing with treatment of blacks and Puerto Ricans, with food, medical care, education. Says one prisoner: "They [the prison authorities] think we're just shucking and jiving." Says another: "We're not advocating violence. We're advocating communication and understanding."Four days after the rebellion began, troopers armed with shotguns and rifles, some using dum-dum bullets, stormed the walk to secure what is genteelly called the correctional facility, leaving 32 inmates and 11 of their hostages dead, most from shots fired by the state police."Attica," produced and directed by Cinda Firestone, who also edited the film with Tucker Ashworth, is an exceptionally moving, outraged recollection of that terrible event. It's a documentary record of the event itself, the conditions that helped prompt it, and some of the things that have (and haven't) happened since. Though it asks questions that go unanswered, it is surprisingly temperate in tone."Attica" opened yesterday at the First Avenue Screening Room and it is, like "I. F. Stone's Weekly," a superior example of committed film making.The thing that made Attica such a consciousness-raising event is preserved on film in the voices of the prisoners, both during and after the event, in interviews with the hostages, and in coverage of the official inquiries that followed it. We see it in the unity of the prisoners, in the discipline they maintained during the fruitless negotiations with correctional officials, in the faces of civilians who served on the unofficial "observers' committee," as well as in the faces of the men who made the decision to retake the prison by force.Does a commitment to a desperate cause make a man lean and strong? Does representing an established system make another man look sort of swollen, overfed, the way the sheriff of Nottingham is always portrayed? I was beginning to think so while watching "Attica" until we are presented an interview with one especially articulate, passionately angry black prisoner who is in fact, almost plump. Stereotypes do not hold in "Attica."Nor is its anger self-defeating. One of the most moving sequences in the film is composed of interviews with the members of the family of one black prisoner who, post-rebellion, has apparently embarked on a self-improvement binge. "You wouldn't be able to walk into my cell, for all the books I got," he has written his sister.Eloquence keeps turning up in the midst of jargon, and there is nothing so eleoquent as the last line of the film, spoken on the soundtrack by an ex-inmate who would shake the public out of its historic disinterest in penal reform. "Wake up," he says, "because nothing comes to a sleeper but a dream."

title: 32 MISSING AS SHIPS COLLIDE OFF JAPAN
description: WAKAYAMA, Japan, Friday, April 12 (Reuters)Four ships, including one American vessel, collided in two separate incidents before dawn today, leaving 32 seamen missing, the Japanese Coast Guard said.

title: U.S. Families to Adopt Lepers' Children
description: Eight children born to patients in the leper colonies of South Korea are being adopted by American families under Operation Outreach, a program believed to be unprecedented in the world history of adoption.

title: Supply and Cost of Money And Credit Proxy Climb
description: The nation's money supply climbed steeply in the week ended April 3, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday.

title: COMMODITY BILL VOTED BY HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, April 11The House of Representatives passed today a bill to create a new and more independent agency to govern trading or the nation's booming commodity markets.

title: Market Place: Rate Rise Hits
description: Electric utility Issues, hailed years ago on Wall Street as growth stocks, have been slipping again in recent weeks in the wake of climbing interest rates.

title: Manufacturers Hanover And Chemical Post Gains
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation and the Chemical New York Corporation, which control the fifth and sixth largest banks in the nation, reported yesterday substantial, firstquarter increases in net income, with Manufacturers reporting the best quarter in its history.

title: R. W. Pressprich & Co., High Roller of the Sixties, Tries to Regain Its Traditional BondHouse Role
description: Vincent C. (Bindy) Banker, a twotime Marine and vice chairman of the old Wall Street bond house of R. W. Pressprich & Co., Inc., rides the subway to appointments These days, and if he gets stuck with a luncheon tab, he pays it out of his own commissions.

title: Algerian Village Lad: the Third World's Voice
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 11  When President Houari Boumediene of Algeria was a schoolboy, the story goes, his parents wanted desperately for him to have a French education, a steppingstone to pingstone to success in Algeria when it was under French rule.

title: GEN. JAMES B. CRAWFORD
description: AUBURN, Ala., April 11 (AP) Brig Gen. James B. Crawford, a 1911 graduate of the United States Military Academy at West Point, died Monday. He was 85 years old.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming Passenger and Mail Ships

title: RECEIVER APPOINTED FOR CHRISTIANPAINE
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed yesterday that a temporary receiver had been appointed to handle the affairs of ChristianPaine & Co., of Hasbrouck Heights, N.J., a firm it described as the largest brokerdealer in overthecounter stocks in the East.

title: NIXON AIDE HINTS PARTIAL RESPONSE
description: WASHINGTON, April 11The White House indicated tonight that President Nixon would probably turn over some, but not all, of the materials subpoenaed earlier today by the House Judiciary Committee. Ronald L. Ziegler, the President's press secretary, said in a questionandanswer session with reporters:

title: Champion of Shopkeepers Joins the Presidential Race in France
description: PARIS, April 11Jean Royer, one of France's most controversial cabinet ministers and n political maverick with popular appeal, today declared his candidacy for the presidency.

title: Committee's Move: Testing Power Balance
description: WASHINGTON, April 11With only three members dissenting, the House Judiciary Committee began today an unprecedented constitutional adventurethe supoenaing of a President as part of an inquiry into whether or not that President should be impeached. The outcome of that adventure will add chapters to the lawbooks. But, more than that, some lawyers said today, it could affect the balance between two of the branches of government for years to come.

title: Crude Oil Shipments Clarified by Aramco
description: The Arabian American Oil Company and two of its components, the Mobil Oil Corporation and Texaco, Inc., said yesterday that the only crude oil shipped from the Arab countries after the embargo of October, 1973, was that which had already been loaded on ships, or in terminals before the embargo.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS
description: April 11, 1974

title: LUGO WILL DIRECT ANTIPOVERTY UNIT
description: Peter Lugo, a 63yearold court clerk, was appointed by Mayor Beame as expected yesterday as Commissioner of the Community Development Agency, a $40millionayear antipoverty agency.

title: Wilson and Byrne to Meet Today With Ronan on Port Unit Post
description: Governors Wilson of New York and Byrne of New Jersey will meet with Dr. William J. Ronan at an undisclosed site today to discuss Dr. Ronan's anticipated nomination as chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: BONN ACTS TO CUT DIESEL OIL PRICES
description: BERLIN, April 11  The West German antitrust authority told four multinational oil companies today to lower prices for diesel oil at the pumps by at least 8 cents a gallon by April 19.

title: The Pop Life,
description: Crosby, Stills, Nash & Youngperhaps the biggest of the American supergroupswill reunite this summer, their manager confirmed yesterday. They got together two months ago in Hawaii, said Eliott Roberts by telephone from Los Angeles. Everybody wanted to do it, but there were problems about prior commitments. Neil Young was the last to confirm: he was going to be in Japan in June, at the time needed to rehearse.

title: Murtagh Yields One Job: Court Administration Post
description: Justice John M. Murtagh of State Supreme Court resigned yesterday as a deputy administrator of the city court systent after serving in the post for less than a month.

title: Wider I.R.S. Force Sought
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP)  Treasury Secretary George P. Shultz asked Congress today for funds to hire 2,400 more Internal Revenue Service personnel to audit more returns.

title: Game 7: Do or Die For Knicks
description: The Knicks and the Capital Bullets meet tonight at Madison Square Garden in the deciding game of their National Basketball Association playoff series. In the previous six games, the team that won the battle of the boards won the game.

title: STEEL UNION FAILS TO REACH ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, April 11Union and management negotiators in the steel industry failed tonight to meet a selfimposed deadline for a new threeyear wage contract but still hoped to reach a settlement tomorrow.

title: People in Sports Stargells Is Honoredfor OfftheField Efforts
description: Willie Stargell, the Pittsburgh Pirates Slugger who led the major leagues, last year in home runs with 44, runs batted in (119) doubles slugging percentage (.646) and gamewinning hits (28) but was passed over as the National League's most valuable player in favor of Pete Rose of Cincinnati, received a trophy he said he can identify with yesterday, Bowie Kuhn, the baseball commissioner, presented him with whet Roberto Clemente Humanitarian. Award for exceptional service to baseball.

title: H.E. HILLEBOE DIES, MEDICAL COUNSEL
description: TAMPA, Fla., April 11 (UPI) Dr. Herman E. Hilleboe, former Assistant United States Surgeon General and New York State Commissioner of Health, died today, apparently of a heart attack. He was 68 years old and had lived here since 1971.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Times Wins an Extension Of Writ Restraining Union
description: State Supreme Court Justice Harold Baer yesterday extended for a week an injunction bar. ring printers at The New York Times from interfering with op. erations at the newspaper.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: City officials are studying a proposal to extend for the first time a city bus route into Nassau County, Queens Borough President Donald R. Manes said. The proposal, subject to approval by Mayor Beame, Controller Harrison J. Goldin and Nassau County officials, would send the Q44A bus across the city line to Lake Success, L. I., and would provide service to Long Island JewishHillside Medical Center.

title: SYDNEY M. PREVORE
description: Sydney M. Prevore, owner oft the National Network of Community Publications, advertising representatives for 150 weekly newspapers, died here Wednesday of a heart attack. He was 61 years old and lived at 28 East 12th Street.

title: ...With Responsibility
description: Representative Rodino, the committee chairman, has meanwhile acted responsibly with regard to the difficult issue of Mr. St. Clair's participation in the work of the committee. Under Representative Rodino's leadership, the committee Democrats have tentatively agreed to allow Mr. St. Clair to be present when the committee staff outlines possible charges against the President and the evidence for them. Mr. St. Clair would thereby gain complete overview of the case against his client, a quite considerable advantage that many on the committee were initially reluctant to grant him. His subsequent role in the inquiry has been left for later determination pending the committee's decision on whether to have hearings and, if so, the scope of such hearings.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 16.3 billion tonmiles, 0.8 per cent above the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same week totaled 511,035 cars, 0.2 per cent below last year. The American Trucking Association, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 2.9 per cent below last year.

title: PUBLISHER OFFERS TO BUY STARNEWS
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) A Michigan newspaper publisher has disclosed that he made an offer early this month to buy The Washington Star News.

title: Notes on People
description: Joining the ranks of the noted jurists Charles Evans Hughes and Harlan Fiske Stone, Joseph Solomon, the estate lawyer, yesterday had a professorial chair, named for him at the Columbia University School of Law. The chair, the Joseph Solomon Professorship in Wills, Trusts and Estates, has been made possible by Mr. Solomon's friends, who contributed more than $500,000 toward its establishment. Columbia's first professorship in estate law, the Solomon chair is probably the first the university has ever named for someone who never finished elementary school. Mr. Solomon, one of eight children in a poor Russian immigrant family in New York, worked as a child and at one point was a $10aweek errand boy in a Wall Street firm that was a predecessor of Lehman, Rohrlich, Solomon & Heffner, of which he is a senior partner. He read law while working and passed the bar qualifying examinations before spending three years attending the New York Law School at night.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: JUST FOLKS There is a score of people, all made of linenmach thronging the Fairtree Gallery, 924 Madison Avenue, near 74th Street (8614942). This delightful assortment of almost lifesize figures has been sculptured by Carol Anthony, who has the perceptive eye of a goodnatured cartoonist and has fashioned representatives of nonstrident America.

title: F.T.C. Acts to Halt Deceptive Job Ads By Driver Schools
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP)  The Federal Trade Commission took steps today to curb a string of Midwestern truck driver schools, alleging that they had taken up to $895 each from men who thought they were applying for onthejob training.

title: May 18 Australian Vote Set As Parliament Is Dissolved
description: CANBERRA, Australia, April 11 (AP)  The Governor General, Sir Paul liasluck, dissolved both houses of Parliament today, and Prime Minister Gough Whitlam announced that a general election would be held May 18.

title: U.S. Families to Adopt Lepers' Children
description: Eight children born to patients in the leper colonies of South Korea are being adopted by American families under Operation Outreach, a program believed to be unprecedented in the world history of adoption.

title: Cathy Graves Wed To Peter J. Morrell
description: Miss Cathy Clark Graves, development coordinator for the Eugene ONeill Memorial Theater Center in Waterford, Conn., was married here last evening to Peter J. Morrell, president of Morrell & Co., wine and spirits merchants in New York. Justice Theodore B. Kupferman of the State Supreme Court Appellate Division performed the ceremony at the Four Seasons restaurant.

title: Babashoff Breaks U. S. Swim Mark
description: DALLAS, April 11 (AP)Shirley Babashoff shattered her second American swimming record in two days tonight in the Amateur Athletic Union's indoor shortcourse championships, while 15yearold Jenni Franks of Wilmington, Del., turned in & stunning medley upset.

title: Play: Music! Music! From '95 to Now
description: Tedium was continually threatening to run riot at the City Center Theater last night. The occasion was a strange anthology called Music! Music! It purported to take the story of the American popular theater from New Orleans in 1895 to the present day. It missed a few songs along the route.

title: News Summary and Index FRIDAY, APRIL, 12, 1974
description: International

title: Jersey Aide Warns of New Gasoline Curb
description: New Jersey's energy chief said yesterday that the state's alternateday gasolinesales progrant would have to be restored if gasoline consumption continued to rise as it has so far this month.

title: KISSINGER GLOOMY ON 3 MAJOR ISSUES
description: WASHINGTON, April 11Secretary of State Kissinger, conducting a closed briefing for members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, has painted a gloomy picture of the current state of Middle East negotiations, Western EuropeanAmerican relations and the nuclear arms talks with the Soviet Union.

title: Canadiens Beat Rangers, 41, And Pull Even, 11, in Playoffs
James W. Ivy Is Dead at 72; Edited Crisis for N.A.A.C.P.
description: James W. Ivy, who retired in May, 1966, as editor of The Crisis magazine, the official publication of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, died of cancer yesterday at his home, 90 LaSalle Street. He was 72 years, old.

title: Unishops, Inc., Files Petitions For Reorganizing 12 Units
description: Unishops, Inc., filed petitions for reorganization yesterday of 12 of its subsidiaries under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, bringing to 13 the number of subsidiaries seeking protection of the court. Earlier this week Unishops filed a petition for Nescott, Inc., a subsidiary that operates stationery and beautyproduct departments.

title: Japan Is Crippled by Record Strike
description: TOKYO, April 11  Japan came to a virtual halt today as the biggest strike in the nation's history crippled transport and other services.

title: HOMOSEXUAL BILL SET FOR HEARING
description: Four members of Mayor Beame's cabinet, former Mayor Robert F. Wagner and Robert M. Morgenthau, candidate for the Democratic nomination for Manhattan District Attorney, will testify on behalf of a city rights bill for homosexuals, spokesmen for a coalition of homosexual groups said yesterday.

title: N.F.L. Trades Cut by Player Raids
description: The recent player raids by the World Football League have created more than publicity problems for the established National Football League. In such critical areas as trades and personnel planning, a holding pattern has emerged for the 1974 season.

title: Anker Warns ReadingTest Cheaters
description: School Chancellor Irving Anker said yesterday that he was investigating reports of possible irregularities in the conduct of the recent citywide reading tests at 10 schools in seven local districts.

title: State Democrats Vow a Balanced Slate For National ParleyWithout Quotas
description: TRENTON, April 11  The leadership of the state Demoloratic committee pledged today to send a balanced and broadened delegation to the 1974 midterm national party convention in December, but said.that the quota system had been abadoned.

title: Jaworski Reportedly Subpoenas Rebozo, Abplanalp Tax Returns
description: WASHINGTON, April 11Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor, has subpoenaed the Federal income tax returns of Charles G. Rebozo and Robert H. Abplanalp, two of President Nixon's closest friends, in the investigation of a $100,000 campaign contribution from Howard R. Hughes, wellplaced sources said today.

title: City Is Studying Goldman Statement on Vending Machine Links
description: The city's Department of Investigation has begun taking testimony on transactions involving subway vending concessions by Irving Goldman, the Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, witnesses disclosed yesterday.

title: Tuskegee's Black Mayor Backs Wallace in Bid for Reelection
description: TUSKEGEE, Ala., April 11 (AP)  The black Mayor of Tuskegee endorsed Gov. George C. Wallace for reelection today and Predicted that the Governor, once a symbol of resistance to integration in the South, would get more black votes in Alabama than ever before.

title: Bill Would Curb Utility Ads
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) Public utilities would be prohibited from advertising to attract more customers during energy shortages under a bill introduced today by Representative William F. Walsh, a Republican from upstate New York. The bill would also bar any regulated public utility from charging a preferential rate on the basis of the amount of electricity or gas bought from such a utility.

title: Sagner Urges Port Body To Operate Penn Station
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey ought to take over, modernize and operate. Manhattan's Pennsylvania Station to handle a lot more trains from Jersey, according to Alan Sagner, New Jersey Transportation Commissioner.

title: Nixon's Shadow In Illinois
description: CHICAGO, April 11  After Ab Mikva, the Democratic candidate for Congress in the Tenth District of Illinois, spoke this morning to history students, at the Evanston Township High School, the same questions kept coming at him in differing forms: How could the students be sure he was an honest man? Why should they trust him?

title: Rev. Basile Luyet, Expert On Freezing of Living Cells
description: The Rev. Basile J. Luyet, a scientist noted for his extensive studies on the preservation of living cells and tissues by freezing, died March 30 in Madison, Wis., where he lived. His age was 76.

title: RELIEF ROLLS CUT BY 8,6% IN STATE
description: Governor Wilson yesterday reported a decrease of 154,817 persons, or 8.6 per cent, in the statewide welfare rolls at the end of last year, compared with the year beforean overall decline of 196,153 since the record peak of March, 1972.

title: M. C. Weisman Weds Mrs. Lawton
description: Milton C. Weisman, senior partner in the New York law firm of Weisman, Celler, Spett, Modlin & Wertheimer, married Mrs. Margot Lawton of Palm Beach, Fla., widow of Lewis M. Lawton, on his 79th birthday yesterday. State Supreme Court Justice Nathaniel T. Heiman performed the ceremony in the bridegroom's apartment at the Beekman Hotel here.

title: Pistons Top Bulls, 9288; Series: 33
description: DETROIT, April 11 (AP)Bob Lanier, who had only 4 points before intermission, scored 24 in the second half to lead the Detroit Pistons to a 9288 victory over the Chicago Bulls tonight and send the National basketball Association playoff series to its sevengame limit.

title: When Insanity Holds the Scepter
description: Craziness occurs in kings. Psychotic emperors, presidents, prime ministers and dictators have left their smudged marks on every page of history. Some rule today. An inquiry in depth into the role of madness in human affairs would provide a fascinating field to be cultivated by a team of historians and psychiatrists. The harvest of bizarre events wrought by deranged leaders would be a rich one.

title: Times Writ Extended
description: An injunction barring printers at The New York Times from interfering with operations at the newspaper was extended for a week. Details on Page 28.

title: ISRAELIS DISARRAY WORRYING EGYPT
description: CAIRO, April 11Bad news in Israel is usually regarded as good news in the Arab world, but today things were not so simple.

title: Dance: Harkness Ballet in Residence
description: After the ball was over, after the break of day, after the Harkness Theatera peacockblue island slightly to the east of Suez and Lincoln Centerhad opened on Tuesday night, it had to face a new program by the resident Harkness Ballet On the following Wednesday,

title: Pro Transactions
description: FOOTBALL

title: RISING PRICES FAIL TO SPUR INCREASE IN OIL PRODUCTION
description: A Nixon Administration program introduced last summer to spur greater production of domestic crude oil by allowing its price to rise has failed to provide more oil. It has, however, enabled the nation's big oil companies to raise the: prices of their own crude oil sharply and pass those higher, prices along to consumers Of gasoline and fuel oil. It has also pro, vided soaring, profits for oil companies.

title: John Fey to Join Equitable Life
description: The Equitable Life Aasurante Society announced yesterday that John T. Fey, president of the National. Life Insurance Company, would join Equitable in August as vice chairman. A year from now, according to the company's expectatibn, Mr. Fey will become chairman.

title: Yorkville Fighting Loss a Old Flavor
description: Those Yorkville residents who have long campaigned to stem what they call the slow creep of commercialism over one of the last polyglot middle European neighborhoods in the city feel they have finally won a victory.

title: Willkie Funeral Set
description: RUSHVILLE, Ind., April 11 (AP)The funeral of Philip L. Willkie, son of Wendell L. Willike, Republican candidate for President in 1940, will take place in the First Presbyterian Church here on Saturday. Mr. Willkie, a lawyer and banker, died at his home here yesterday. Survivors include his widow, five sons, a stepdaughter and his mother, Mrs. Wendell L. Willkie.

title: Times Writ Extended
description: An injunction barring printers at The New York Times from interfering with operations at the newspaper was extended for a week. Details on Page 28.

title: Excerpts From Chinese Address to U.N. Session on Raw Materials
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 11 Following are excerpts from the official translation of the speech yesterday to the General Assembly by Teng Hsiaoping, head of the Chinese delegation:

title: Bruins Beat Leafs, 6 to 3, For 20 Edge
description: BOSTON, April 11 (AP)Phil Esposito scored Once tonight and set up Ken Hodge and Wayne Cashman for two other goals as the Boston Bruin's defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs, 63. The victory gave Boston a 20 lead in their National Hockey League quarterfinal playoff series.

title: About New York When Diplomats Take a Break
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. April 11The Ambassador from Kuwait marched up and ordered a beer last night. It's the Ambassador from the state of oil, another man said, and made room for the Ambassador at the bar.

title: M.T.A. Assailed by Reid on Safety of New Cars
description: Representative Ogden R. Reid charged yesterday that there had been, a number of catastrophic fires on the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's new commuter cars and that the cars were unsafe.

title: No Lottery Drawing Today
description: TRENTON, April 11 (UPI)Charles C. Carella, director of the New Jersey Lottery, has announced that there will not be a drawing of the daily lottery tomorrow, Good Friday. There are no drawings of the daily lottery also on New Year's Day, Thanksgiving Day and Christmas Day.

title: Advertising: Psychology Today
description: I've got a good Madison Avenue story for you, said Hal Dunchin as he prepared to Make a pitch for Psychology Today at Leber Katz Partners yesterday morning.

title: S.E.C. TO SUSPEND 48 OTC STOCKS
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered today temporary suspension of overthecounter trading in stocks of 48 small companies that have been delinquent since 1972 in filing annual and quarterly reports with the agency.

title: DRASTIC CHANGES ON OIL LEASES DUE
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 Federal regulations governing oil leasing of public lands are about to be revised drastically to increase the share of petroleum royalties retained by the Government, Congressional sources said today.

title: Atlantic Sewer?
description: The sorriest aspect of New York Harbor's sludge problem is that other ways to get rid of the waste material seem to be as bad, environmentally, as dumping it into the sea. A society that can send recording instruments to the planet Mercury should be able to do better than line the bottom of its harbors with what is left over when treatment plants have extracted and purified the water content of its sewage. Because no better method is yet at hand, regional officials of the Environmental Protection Agency have had to make a few tentative motions which will delay the crisis but not solve the problem.

title: SOVIET TELLS U. N. DETENTE AIDS ALL
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 11Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko declared today that improvement in SovietAmerican relations would also bring economic benefits to the world's underdeveloped it countries.

title: WESTGATE AGREES ON SALE OF UNITS
description: SAN DIEGO, April 11 (AP)The WestgateCalifornia Corporation agreed yesterday to sell most of its subsidiaries and remain in business as a seafood processing company.

title: Juy Finds Boyle Guilty In 3 Yablonski Murders
description: MEDIA, Pa., April 11  W. A. Boyle, the deposed president of the United Mine Workers of America, was found guilty tonight of three charges of firstdegree murder in ordering the assassination of Joseph A. Yablonski, a reformist election rival in the union.

title: Russo Freed After Pledge To Testify on Jersey Crime
description: TRENTON, April 11  Anthony Russo, a reputed Mafia member, left prison today, after he agreed to testify in closed session April 25 before the State Commission of Investigation.

title: Parking Rules Eased
description: Alternatesideofthestreet parking regulations have been suspended for today and tomorrow because of the Good Fiday and Passover holidays, the Traffic Department announced yesterday.

title: U.S. Aide Leaves Geneva
description: GENEVA, April. 11  U. Alexis Johnson, the United States negotiator at the strategic arms talks here with the Soviet Union, left today with the meinbers of his delegation for consultations in Washington.

title: Meeting the Issue ...
description: By an overwhelming bipartisan vote, the House Judiciary Committee has subpoenaed the tapes of Presidential conversations that it has beeen seeking. By this action, the committee met squarely the issue of President Nixon's obstruction of the impeachment inquiry.

title: 4 Libraries Scored on Copying Plan
description: The Association of American Publishers, which speaks for most American book publishing companies, has denounced a plan by four Eastern libraries to combine some of their operations in ways that would entail cutting back purchases of many publications and systematically exchanging photocopies of previously published writings.

title: Marzio Ciano, a Grandson Of Mussolini, Dies at 36
description: ROME, April 12  Marzio Ciano, a grandson of Mussolini, died in a private clinic here yesterday, it was announced today. Diabetes was given as cause of death. He was 36 years old.

title: Rage of Bereaved Is Vented at Burial
description: QIRYAT SHEMONA, Israel, April 12The residents of this exposed border town poured out their grief and anger today in an emotional and violent funeral for 16 of the victims of yesterday's attack by Palestinian terrorists.

title: SYRIAN COMPLETES TALKS IN MOSCOW
description: MOSCOW, April 12The Soviet Union today announced new agreements for strengthening Syria economically and militarily as President Hafez alAssad quickly completed two days of talks with the Soviet leadership.

title: CAMDEN CARS HALT IN REHIRING DISPUTE
description: CAMDEN, April 12 (UPI)The more than 60 Yellow Cabs here stopped running yesterday when a strike was called in a dispute over the rehiring of a taxi driver.

title: With a Hey, and a Ho, And a Hey Nonino
description: WASHINGTON, April 12Spring, why do you make tomcats howl under bedroom windows at three in the morning?

title: Boston Indicts Doctors in Fetus Cases
description: BOSTON, April 12A leading Boston doctor has been indicted for manslaughter in the death of a fetus in connection with a legal abortion, and four other doctors have been accused of violating a 19thcentury law against graverobbing for using tissue from aborted fetuses for medical research.

title: Statesman, Farmer, Architect, Scholar, Surveyor, Educator
description: Sooner or later Jefferson was to be called a Protean man. But this word is as elusive as the mythical figure whose name it bears, for as means a man of many appearances, this meaning itself is hard to take hold of. It can and does denote a manysided man of universal stature; a man of many gifts, competent in each; a man of many appearances, yet centered in a true identity. But it can also mean a man of many disguises; a man of chameleonlike adaptation to passing scenes; a man of essential elusiveness.

title: Byrne Approves a Plan To End Passaic Floods
description: TRENTON, April 12A $700million floodcontrol project for the periodically ravaged Passaic River Valley has moved a step nearer realization with Governor Byrne's approval of basic plan, contingent on compliance with environmental protection standards and maximum participation by the community interests affected.

title: 2 YOUNG DRUMMERS LEAD JAZZ COMBOS
description: By a quirk of booking, both of the most widely hailed young jazz drummers of the last 10 year are in town this weekend leading, their own groups. Billy Cobham, 29 years old, ?? playing with Miles Davis and the Mahavishnu Orchestra, has formed his own eightpiece gropp, which is making its local debut at the Bottom Line. Tony Williams, 28, who preceded Mr. Cobham as Mr. Davis's drummer, is leading a quartet, the latest Version of the group he calls Lifetime, at the Village Vanguard.

title: Australians Pressing Varied Research
description: SYDNEY, Australia, April 12  Possibly the most industrious worker for the CommonLwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization of Australia is a foreigner with an impolite name.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, APRIL 13, 1974

title: RUSSIANS REPORT IMPEACHMENT BID
description: MOSCOW, April 12The Soviet press, in a new sign of uneasiness, over President Nixon's future, reported today for the first time in months on Congressional moves for impeachment.

title: Thursday's Fights
description: TokyoSusuki Ishimatsu, 135 pounds, Tokyo, knocked out Rodolfo Gonzalez, 134, Long Beach, Calif.; 8 rounds.

title: KISSINGER DOUBTS BROAD ARMS PACT BY END OF YEAR
description: WASHINGTON, April 12Secretary of State Kissinger virtually ruled out today another comprehensive agreement on limiting strategic arms with the, Soviet Union this but said a more limited accord curbing some offensive arms might be signed during President Nixon's expected visit to Moscow is June.

title: Fox Rejects Merrick's Bid for Board Representation
description: LOS ANGELES, April 12 The Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corporation has turned down the regigest of David Merrick, the Broadway producer and the company's largest stockholder for representation on the board, it was learned today.

title: Celtics Top Braves, Win Series, 42
description: BUFFALO, April 12The Boston Celtics finally won their Eastern Conference playoff with the Buffalo Braves tonight when Jo Jo White made two free throws after the final buzzer sounded, giving the Celtics a 106104 victory in the sixth game of this National Basketball Association series.

title: Nixons Assessed $4,302 By California Tax Board

title: Raids Are Revenge for Arab Terror

title: The F.C.C.: A Question of Its Nominations
Morgenthau Endorsed

title: CRISTINA DEUTEKOM SINGS ELENA AT MET
description: Cristina Deutekom returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Thursday night to sing her first Elena here in the season's 11th performance of I Vespri Siciliani. She is not the ideal Verdi soprano by any meansthe voice is strong, flexible and attractive on top but weaker in the lower regions where a great Verdian spirito voice can carry great dramatic impact. But Miss Deutekom improved as she went along. She turned the last act into a triumph with her superbly controlled singing in the duet with Arrigo and in Elena's knockout number, Merce, dilette amiche, usually known as the Bolero.

title: AUDIT VARIATIONS BY I.R.S ARE NOTED

title: Dave Anderson
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 12Johnny Miller looked as if he had stepped out of one of his Sears Roebuck television commercials. He was, wearing a maroon shirt, modly flared knit slacks with a maroon and gray design and red, white and blue golf shoes. His blond mane sloped down around his sharply featured face, befitting a young lion. With his putter in one hand, he was striding toward the first tee the Augusta National Golf Club where Sam Snead waited for today's second round of the Masters Tournament. At the age of 61, golf's oldest lion couldn't hide a paunch under a green sweater. But his cocoanut straw hat And his swing haven't changed. In golf, duffers always are talking about new clubs and new theories but they can go into a pro shop and buy Sam Snead's swing, most of the problems would be solved.

title: Screen:Jckal of Nahueltoro, Strong Chilean Film
description: When a murderer seems as vulnerable as his victims, that's proof of the film maker's talent. "The Jackal of Nahueltoro," written and directed by Miguel Littin of Chile, is a remarkable picture, based on a real case. It was made before the election of Salvador Allende Gossens; while he was president, Mr. Littin was the head of the state-owned film company. The movie, which was a vast success in Chile, is playing at the First Avenue Screening Room today.The picture's strength springs from the extreme simplicity of the narrative, which was clearly designed for an audience of all classes. The acting style is plain, some of it close to pantomime; the plot, rather than the actors, is the star. A burly peasant kills a farm woman and her five children for no apparent reason. The one clue is the grinding poverty that both had always knownwhich serves as a reminder that the poor can turn on one another.In jail, the illiterate murderer is educated, converted to Catholicism, taught to value life as he never did beforeand then executed. It's the agonizing buildup to his death that gives this film its emotional and political depth. The director condemns institutions (the church and the state) rather than individuals, and the system that perpetuates poverty and ignorance is cited as the true killer. Throughout, a benevolent prison system appears just as cruel as its most brutal counterparts.
