title: Japanese Strike Situation Eases Despite Renewed Protest Threat
description: TOKYO, April 12 (AP) Japan's transportation strike eased somewhat today, but workers on the Governmentrun rail and bus lines said they would continue their protest for another 24 hours unless talks between the unions and Government made substantial progress later tonight or early tomorrow.

title: 115 Insurgents in Cambodia Reported Killed in Clashes
description: PHNOM PENH, April 12 (Reuters)Cambedian Government troops killed 115 Communistled insurgents and suffered six dead in three clashes in three provinces, a military spokesman said today.

title: EDWARD COWETT, 44, CORNFELD ASSOCIATE
description: Edward M. Cowen, a lawyer who had been associated with Bernard Cornfeld, founder of the Investors Overseas Services complex, died of a heart attack in Fort Worth, Tex., on Thursday. He had been en route by plane from Denver to his home in Miami when he was stricken, The, plane Made lit stop at Fort Worth, where Mr. Cowett died.

title: 9 Shots Fired Here In Office of Police
description: At least nine shots were fired inside the Police Department's former headquarters building early yesterday in an office area used for the last year as an operational base by the task force investigating the theft of 398 pounds of narcotics from the office of the department's property clerk.

title: Metropolitan rids
description: Only onethird of the students tested in New York City and found needing extra help under special compensatoryaid'programs are presently receiving this service, the State Education Department reported yesterday. The department, releasing the first results of a new program intended eventually to evaluate schools on a statewide basis, said the finding was based on a test last fall of 25,000 students in the city's community school districts. No details on the study were contained in the fivepage report released by the department.

title: Groups Ask Wilson to Veto Help for Parochial Schools
description: ALBANY, April 12Governor Wilson was urged today by Pearl, a coalition of groups opposed to state aid for parochial schools, to veto the $8.2million aid bill now before him.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: Summary and index, Page 27

title: LEGISLATORS LOSE RECESS IN CANADA
description: OTTAWA, April 12Discord between Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's minority Liberal party Government and other parties has forced the House of Commons to forgo its customary Easter recess. The development occurred in a fractious atmosphere that seemed to indicate a delicate time ahead so far as the Prime Minister's tenuous hold on power is concerned.

title: Panel Urges Four New Agencies For Federal Energy Regulation
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) A Presidential study team recommended today the establishment of four new Federal offices to coordinate government energy activities, rather than consolidation of existing energyrelated agencies.

title: Monday Is the Deadline For Filing Tax Returns
description: The Internal Revenue Service yesterday reminded taxpayers in New York City, Westchester and Rockland Counties and all of Long Island and New Jersey that they must file their Federal returns by midnight Monday.

title: No Jersey Lottery Drawing
description: There was no drawing of the New Jersey daily lottery yesterday, Good Friday. There are also no drawing on hT anks giving Day, Christmas and New Year's Day.

title: BODIES OF 2 WOMEN FOUND ON WEST SIDE
description: Two Japanese women were found dead yesterday in a West Side hotel where they had been living, and the police said the women, both of whom had been bound and gagged, may have been strangled.

title: Aggression Defined At the U.N., Capping 24 Years of Debate
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. April 12After considering the matter for 24 years, the United Nations today finally came up with a definition of the word aggression.

title: Malcolm Hamilton Excels In a Harpsichord Recital
description: Malcolm Hamilton has been known on the West Coast for some years as a harpsichordist of merit, and he has made recording of music by Scarlatti and Handel, but until his recital Thursday night at Hully Hall, he had not played in New

title: Books of The Times
description: THE KENTUCKY DERBY: THE MST 100 YEARS. By Peter Chew, 303 pages. Hough. ton Mifflin. $15. In an editorial the day the Kentucky Derby was run last year, The Louisville CourierJournal commented with asperity: Out at the track, everything will be in Its place, with the patricians and the powerful safe in their boxes, and the rabble fenced, into the infield, It's a scene rescued out of the distant past, with the king mid his hangerson crowded into the royal box, with les miserables crowding around the sidelines in sackcloth...

title: NonSmokers' Lib
description: The Board of Health is to hold hearings and then vote Thursday on a proposal by Health Commissioner Lowell Bellin to segregate smokers from nonsmokers in public places where more than 25 people congregate.

title: Wilson Is Said to Disclaim Agreement on Port Bonds
description: Governor Byrne was said yesterday to have declared that Governor Wilson reneged on an agreement to support legislation to repeal a bond covenant preventing the Port Authority from undertaking masstransportation projects that could loses money.

title: Abducted U.S. Envoy Found Injured in Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 12An American diplomat who was kidnapped, by Marxist guerrillas today in Cordoba, Argentina's second largest city, was found alive but seriously wounded tonight.

title: MRS. LUDWIG SATZ
description: Mrs. Lillie Satz, widow of Ludwig Satz, an actor in the Yiddish Art Theater until his death in 1943, died Thursday at the Sarah Neuman Nursing Home in Mamaroneck, N.Y. Her age was 78, and she lived at 255 West 23rd Street.

title: Buoniconti Talks To W.F.L. Sharks
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 12 (AP)Nick Buoniconti, middle linebacker for the Miami Dolphins, Super Bowl champion, tentatively agreed to terms today with the Jacksonville Sharks of the. World Football League, according to Fran Monaco, Sharks owner.

title: Consumers in French Villages, Though, Are Paying Less
description: PARIS, APRIL 12Prices of French winesat least in the villages where they come from, though not necessarily in shops end restaurantsare falling more sharply this year than at any time since World War II, reflecting the resistance of buyers here and abroad to the high prices of 1973.

title: Flyers Lead series, 30 After Brawling Victory
description: ATLANTA, April 12 (AP) Two quick firstperiod goals tit Bobby Clarke and Don Saleski and a disputed score by Rick McLeish triggered the Philadelphia Flyers to a 41 victory in a penalty and fight marred National Hockey League Stanley Cup playoff triumph ovet the At. lanta flames tonight.

title: Relatives Vent Rage at Burial of 16
description: QIRYAT SHEMONA, Israel, April 12The residents of this exposed border town poured out their grief and anger today in an emotional and violent funeral for 16 of the victims of yesterday's attack by Palestinian terrorists.

title: Business Briefs
description: At least four major New York City banks have raised employes' salaries to help combat the steep rise in the cost of living.

title: E.P.A. AIDE BACKS A REORGANIZATION
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 Russell E. Train, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, thinks the nation's environmental concerns call for the creation of a Cabinetlevel department in the Federal Government.

title: 9 Shots Fired Here In Office of Police
description: At least nine shots were fired inside the Police Department's former headquarters building early yesterday in at office area used for the last year as an operational base by the task force investigating the theft of 398 pounds of narcotics from the office of the department's property clerk.

title: China Shows U.N. Modest Face
description: HONG KONG, April 12Western scholars have long debated the question of whether the Chinese view of world order is not somehow fundamentally different from that of any other country, simply becaltse it is Chinese. It is, pointed, out in this debate that the very name the Chinese give their country, Chungkuo, means central country and that it implies a Chinese belief that their nation has a unique place under heaven, with all other nations ranked below it, either in a tributary status or beyond the pale of civilization.

title: Falls After 411Day Siege
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, April 13  After surviving a siege of 411 days, a smal lby psychologically important South Vietnamese ranger outpost near the Cambodian border northwest of Saigon fell supported by tanks, the Saigon yesterday under a heavy assault of North Vietnamese troops Command announced.

title: Atlantic City Looks on Its Easter Parade as a Summer Portent
description: ATLANTIC CITY, April 12Towns and cities across the country will cap their celebrations of Easter tomorrow with promenades of fashion ranging, as they have in recent years, from the elegant to the outrageous.

title: 8% Interest Rate Adopted by F.H.A. For Home Loans
description: WASHINGTON, April 12The interest rate on mortgages insured by the Federal Housing Administration was increased today from 8 to 8 per cent.

title: Rolling Stones Street Fair Called Off After Court Orders It Moved to Park
description: A street festival that was expected to draw tens of thousands of rock fates to the world premiere of a Rolling Stones movie here tomorrow evening was abruptly canceled by its promoters yesterday when a judge ruled that the festival must be moved to Central Park.

title: Cordero Up On Favorite In Turf Cup
description: MIAMI, April 12The key number for both horse and rider will be No. 3 when Angel Cordero Jr., flying here from New York, handles tomorrow's riding assignment aboard Chance Hill's London company in the Hialeah Turf Cup.

title: Moscow Police Seize 2 Entering U.S. Embassy
description: MOSCOW, April 12  Soviet policemen today grabbed and marched off a middleaged Russian couple who tried to enter) the American Embassy, then drove them away in an unmarked black sedan apparently for interrogation.

title: 250 Note Anniversary of Petrarch's Death
description: WASHINGTON, April 12A group of 250 men and women ended today a weeklong consideration of the life, times, loves, language, philosophy and style of one Francesco Petrarcaprobably best known to nonspecialists as Petrarch, the other Italian poet, the one who perfected a sonnet form and celebrated the joys of unrequited love.

title: Engineers Prepare Course To Teach Police Trainees
description: WASHINGTON, April 12Several California electrical engineers have prepared equipment to teach police trainees to confront killers. The course is called the Spartan. Patent 3,802,099 was received this week by Carter Industries, Inc., Santa Ana, Calif., which has demonstrated a training apparatus used in the course before international meetings of chiefs of police and expects to receive orders for several sets. The inventors are Leonard E. Mell and David K. Krosser and two former staff associates.

title: New Gun Duels Reported By Syria on Golan Heights
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, April 12 (Reuters)  A Syrian military spokesman announced that artillery and tank fire raged for hours between Syrian and Israeli forces on the Golan Heights today. Shelling has broken out daily on the front for the last month.

title: Soviet Aide Concedes Problems In Development of Space Shuttle
description: MOSCOW, April 12  A leading official in the Soviet space program hailed today the importance of orbital stations for future space experiments but acknowledged that Soviet designers had not yet been able to develop a satisfactory space shuttle.

title: LAWYER FOR CHAPIN SEEKS A NEW TRIAL
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI)The lawyer for Dwight L. Chapin, the former Presidential appointments secretary, filed motions late today asking that his client's conviction be set aside and that he be granted a new trial away from Washington.

title: Easter Sales of Stores Better Than Expected
description: Retail sales are fluctuating widely across the country during the Easter shopping season, which winds up tomorrow. Nevertheless, overall results have been better then expected.

title: KISSINGER DOUBTS BROAD ARM PACT BY END OF YEAR
description: WASHINGTON, April 12Secretary of State Kissinger virtually, ruled out today another comprehensive agreement on limiting strategic arms with the Soviet Union this year, but said a more limited accord curbing some offensive arms might be signed during President Nixon's expected visit to Moscow in June.

title: TV About Impeachment
description: Adults whose heads are now spinning with bewilderment at the mention of the word Watergate would do well to watch What's Impeachment All About? at 1 this afternoon over the Columbia Broadcasting System network. Here is a splendid, crystalclear capsuling of the entire tangle, from the known facts, of the original breakin to the possibility of a Presidential impeachment, a Word itself badly in need of clarification. The program succinctly considers what, legally, can happen now.

title: 4 CHESS CANDIDATES BEGIN 2DROUND PLAY
description: Victor Korchnoi checkmated Tigran Petrosian and Boris Spassky held an advantage at adjournment against Anatoly Karpov yesterday in the opening games of the semifinal Candidates Matches to pick a challenger tor the world chess championship.

title: Acquisition Is Terminated
description: Negotiations for the acquisition of the Sierra Pacific IndusItries of California by the LouisianaPacific Corporation have been terminated, it was announced yesterday.

title: Bonnets Back for Easter Parade, But Without the Frills Upon 'Em
description: The days have past since ladies paraded down Fifth Avenue balancing fruit, cascades of flowers, and sometimes everything but the kitchen sink on their heads. But nevertheless, women were picking through the hat bars and millinery salons yesterday searching out modern versions of the traditional Easter bonnet.

title: As IncomeTax Deadline Nears, Sales of Small Calculators Rise
Dr. Benjamin Rosner, 44, Dies; Specialist on Teacher Education
description: Dr. Benjamin Rosner, former dean of teacher education at the City University, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home in Princeton, N. J. He was 44 years old.

title: Gianelli's Fittest Hour Comes in Time
description: You're a star, someone yelled to John Gianelli list night as he was shoved into the corner of the Knick dressing room.

title: A Yearning Man
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 About the only thing Arthur Krock did not write in his. 60 years as a Washington correspondent was his own obituary, and the irony of this is that may be he was about the only man who could really have got it right. In a way it's odd that he didn't take on this last assignmeat, for he was an orderly man, who hated loose ends, never missed deadline in his life and knew better than anybody else that even none of This old friends ever managed to get inside to his innermost thoughts.

title: Mike Palm, Assistant Coach Of Football, Giants in 40's
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP)  Mike Palm, former football player and coach with the New York Giants, died of a heart attack, Monday at the age of 74.

title: 2 Seized in Newark Killing After Hostages Call Police
description: FARMINGDALE, N. J., April 12State troopers burst into an apartment here early today and arrested two suspects in a Newark murder that occurred last Sunday.

title: Nixon Signs Order Clearing Federal Employe Pay Rises
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI)  Federal employe pay rises retroactive to Oct. 1, 1972, were cleared by an executive order signed by President Nixon, the assistant White House press secretary, Gerald L. Warren, announced today.

title: ABPLANALP SCORES SENATE UNIT AIDES
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 Robert H. Abplanalp accused investigators for the Senate Watergate committee of reekless conjecturing as he again denied today that he ever discussed a $100,000 donation by Howard R. Hughes to President Nixon's election campaign.

title: Rights Aide Loses Teaching Post Here
description: Ira Glasser, executive director of the New York Civil Liberties Union, has been dismissed from a parttime teaching post at New York University because he refused to swear that he would support the State and Federal Constitutions.

title: Andrew Rowley Weds Miss Andrea H. Baker
description: Miss Andrea Howard Baker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Howes Baker of North Attleboro, Mass., was married yesterday afternoon to Andrew Fulton Rowley of Brooklyn, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Rowley of Falmouth, Mass. The Rev. A. T. Kauffman performed the ceremony in the Second Congregational Church in Attleboro.

title: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles
Let's Fall In Love
description: Three women on men and women

title: Snow Cancels Relays
description: BOULDER, Colo., April 13 (UPI)A wetclinging snowstorm swept through today and dropped 12 inches of snow, forcing cancellation of the 50th annual Colorado track Relays.

title: Yank Games This Week
description: TodayAt Cleveland (2).

title: White Sox Win First Game, 54
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., April 13 (AP)The Chicago White Sox posted their first victory of the season tonight, edging the California Angels, 54, behind Wilbur Wood's fivehit pitching and Buddy Bradford's home run and sacrifice fly.

title: Miss Berman Plans Bridal
description: Richard L. Berman, director of educational media for Harper & Row, publishers, and Mrs. Berman of White Plains, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Berman, to Jeffrey Alan Schultz, son of Mrs. Jeanne Schultz of Lorraine, Ohio, and Erwin Schultz of Lakewood, Ohio. The wedding is planned for June.

title: Sharon Hefts Bat For Little League
description: THE SPRINGSIt was the black eye that did it for Sharon Greene.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Proponents of resignationcumaninesty to render unnecessary House impeachment and Senate trial of President Nixon rarely ponder the President's constitutional Power to grant . . . Pardons for Offenses against the United States.

title: Commodil Talks Rey Bitterness
description: UNTIED NATIONS, N. Y.We are all pressed. Things cannot go on like this. No ?? clear head and feeling heart should still be abcalmly: There is a growing feeling of frust inadequacy, of uncertainty and helplessness ??.

title: Considering the Taxes, Why Paint?
description: WHATEVER the outcome of the current dispute over Mark Rothko's estate, the trial itself has had at least one powerful effect: it's set a lot of artists to brooding over the disposition of works they'll leave behind at death. And well they might. The quirks of U.S. tax laws when applied to artists' estates can have a devastating impact, with the potential of seriously reducing the assets left to the artist's heirs. Nobody, one SoHo sage remarked recently, appreciates the work of artists like the Internal Revenue Serviceafter they die.

title: Miss Brauninger to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Smith Brauninger of North Haven, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret E. Brauninger, to John Ferguson Brink, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip E. Brink of Rockville, Md. The wedding is planned for Aug. 3.

title: To Him Who Hath
description: At least five Senators and more than fifty Representatives are engaged in trying to undo a grossly unjust provision of the Social Security law. This is the section of the law that limits the amount of money it is permissible to earn while still collecting Social Security. The law puts no limitation whatever on a recipient's unearned income.

title: Some Counterpoints
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation, having more business than it can handle, enters no kidnapping case without approval from the United States Attorney for the jurlsdiction. The prosecutor's job is to make a prima facie decision that the Missing person was in fact abducted.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Roger Cara, a naturalist and author, has been retained to make a oneyear study of the city's zoos to determine what changes are needed to upgrade conditions. Parks Administrator Edwin L. Weisl Jr. described the study as a massive project that would involve Manhattan's Central Park Zoo and Children's Zoo, Brooklyn's Prospect Park Zoo and Children's Farm and the Flushing Meadow Zoo and Farm in Queens.

title: Epilogue A'Gance Back at Some Major Stories
description: Boyle Convicted

title: Dance
CRIME REPEAT RATE IS STABLE IN SURVEY
description: WASHINGTON, April. 13 (AP) One of every three Federal offenders commits a new crime within two years after his release from prison, according to a new Justice Department survey.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON The impending departure of Paul A. Volcker as Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs provides an occasion to reflect upon the most turbulent period An international monetary affairs since the. Great Depression and on the legacy that this turmoil has left

title: Northeastern Crew Turns Back Rutgers and Yale on Housatonic
description: DERBY, Conn., April 13Northeastern's varsity crew built a comfortable lead, then held off a fast finish by Rutgers today to win its first outing of the rowing season. Yale wound up third as Northeastern captured this triangular competition for the third year in succession.

title: Rowing Won By Harvard And M.I.T.
description: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology crew took the two heavyweight races and Harvard won the three lightweight events yesterday in a regatta on the Harlem River.

title: Senate Unit Will Examine State Poke Controversy
description: TRENTON A State Senate committee plans to investigate a controversy. Over pro motional and disciplinary procedures involving the State Police.

title: Gas Shortages Remain Here; So Do OddEven Sales, for Now
description: ALBANY, April 12Gasoline stations in parts of New York City, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland and Ulster Counties and parts of the upper Hudson River Valley have reported serious shortages of gasoline in recent days, state officials said today.

title: Mrs. Angell Married To Clifford C. Nelson
description: Mrs. Evelyn Baker Angell of Mystic, Conn., was married yesterday noon at her home there to Clifford Colmer Nelson of Leonia, N. J., president of the American Assembly, a national public affairs forum at Columbia University. The Rev. Edward Adkins performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: Patriarch Renews Plea for Single Date for Easter
description: Demetrios I, the Ecumenical Patriarch in Istanbul, has renewed the appeal of his predecessor for a uniform date for the celebration of Easter by all Christians.

title: How Nancy Drew Grew: Fiction for Young Adults
description: THE SPRINGS  A young boy seduces his homosexual teacher. A teenager becomes pregnant and has to leave school. An 11yearold tries to keep her unwed mother from marrying the mother's lover.

title: Boyle Returned to Hospital Till Sentence Is Pronounced
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mo., April 13 (UPI)W. A. Boyle, convicted of ordering the murder of a nival for his post as president of the United Mine Workers, has been returned to the Federal prison hospital here to await formal sentencing.

title: Syrian Jews Suffering Under Harsh Curbs
description: PARIS, April 13About 1,000 Damascus Jews are reliably reported to have streamed out of the ghetto to which they are confined to demonstrate last Month against the slaying of four young Jewish women attempting to cross into Lebanon.

title: Easter Motif at the Museums: Elegant Eggs
description: Several of New Jersey's museums are offering special Easter programs for children and adults.

title: Headliner
description: Consider the contrast.

title: Bergen School Host To Biologists' Unit
description: PARAMUSBergen Community College will be the site on April 26 of the seventh annual conference of the Metropolitan Association of College and University Biologists.

title: Vietcong Contend They Took Outpost Without Big Battle
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam April 13 (Reuters)The Viet cong today denied Government reports that the Communist! had battled using tanks and infantry to capture the Tong Le Chan ranger base near the Cambodian border and said that they had just walked ir and found the camp deserted.

title: Smallpox in Bangladesh
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, April 13 (Reuters)A total of 125 people have died of smallpox in the Khulna area southwest of here in the last two weeks, according to the Dacca daily Ban;lar Bani. Health department officials denied that the outbreak had reached epidemic proportions.

title: Indians Rout Yanks, 85, With Eight Runs in Third
description: CLEVELAND, April 13 Giving up eight runs in the third inning, the Yankees lost their third straight game, and their second in a row to the Indians, today, by a score of 85. It was another sudden pitching collapse early in the contest that did in the Yankees, who had begun the season by winning four in a row.

title: Ideas & Trends Education, Science, Agriculture
description: In cases that could have broad implications for much critical methresearch, a Boston gynecologist has been indicted for manslaughter in the death of a fetus in a legal abortion, and four other doctors have been accused of violating a 19thcentury law against grave robbing for using tissue from aborted fetuses for research.

title: Laura L. Nash, Thomas Beale Plan Marriage
Rita A. Ninivaggio To Be Wed June 22
description: Mr. and Mrs. Angelo C. Ninivaggio of New York and Yorktown Heights, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rita Ann Ninivaggio, to Richard Thomas Wyatt, son of Mrs. Leon Stylka of Garden City Park, L. I.

title: Royals Beat Twins by 65 In 10 Innings
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., April 13 (AP)  Vada Pinson's single with two outs in the 10th inning scored Fran Healy from third base and gave the Kansas City Royals a 65 victory over the Minnesota, Twins today.

title: Mr. Krock
description: The basic statistics about Arthur Krock's career in American journalism are enough to inspire awe: sixty years on the filing line, forty years on this newspaper, twenty years as its Washington correspondent and bureau chief, editorial columnist for more than three decades. Impressive as they are, these facts only begin to tell the story of a remarkable professional lifeone that contained many distinctions beyond the stock ingredients of the American success story.

title: The most dangerous afternoon of his life
description: John Muir, sometimes called the West's Thoreau, was also a transcendentalist, born 21 years after Thoreau. He was primarily a conservationist, however, and, unlike Thoreau, was a professional botanist and geologist a student of glaciers and might be described as one of those hikers who find time to write, rather than a writer who found time to hike. Whereas Thoreau over a lifetime welded together one of the enduring prose styles of the 19th century, Muir left us Yosemite National Park and the Sierra Club.

title: Future Murky as StrifeTorn Suffolk Symphony Cancels Season's Last Concert
description: The Suffolk Symphony, in recent months torn by disserision, last week disclosed that it Was canceling its last concert of the season.

title: The painful DeFunis case raises the specters of racism and antiSemitism
description: The two men walking across the University of Washington campus in Seattle looked like any two professors just chatting away. But they weren't. They were lawyers. Suddenly, the older grayhaired man turned to his companion and said, You know, Jim, if the Regents don't let that kid into law school, I'm going to sue the university. It'll be a big case, and I'll take it all the way to the Supreme Court if I have to. And I'll win. The younger man smiled to himself, amused at his friend's saberrattling.

title: 8 FUND TRUSTEES AGREE TO RESIGN
description: Eight trustees of a unionmanagement fund on Long Island have agreed to resign, to pay fines of $500 each and to pay back $130,000 to the fund, after being accused of more than $500,000 in illegal expenditures, the State Department of Insurance disclosed last week.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Fisher Brothers has completed a land assemblage on the East Side through an exchange of properties with the National Urban League, Inc., and the United Negro College Fund, Inc.

title: Coins of Trevi Fountain Being Given to Red Cross
description: ROME, April 13 (AP)The municipal government of Rome is giving four sacks of coins from the Trevi Fountain to the Italian Red Cross.

title: Child Care Deduction Gains
description: BOSTON, April 13 (AP)The legislature's Taxation Committee has endorsed legislation grant child care deductions for working parents, similar the Federal income tax lowance. Representative Lois Pines, Democrat of Newton, chief spokesman on the bill, said Wednesday that this would permit deductions up $400 for the care of a child in or outside the home.

title: Glen Cove Boys Club Seeks $400,000 to Match Grant for a New Building
description: GLEN COVEOfficials of the Lincoln House Boys Club said last week that, they expected by midsunnier to fulfill the matchineund provisions of an $800,000 Federal grant to build a spacious $1.7million headquarters for its facilities.

title: 30% PAY RISE ENDS BIG JAPAN STRIKE
description: TOKYO, April 13Japan's biggest strike ended this afternoon after transport workers got 30 percent pay increases and the nation began to shake off the paralysis of the threeday walkout.

title: Castello to Be Honored Friday By His Friends in Fencing World
description: Naturally, he'll treasure the championships and the undefeated seasons but Hugo Castello's fondest memories of his 27year career as New York University's head fencing coach can't be catalogued into a record book.

title: Miss Heddy Sets 2 Marks
Passaic Striving For Economic Turnaround
description: PASSAIC This city of 55,000 people is facing all the problems of the timesUnemployment, high taxes, increasing minorities and lack of fundsand striving for a turnaround. Disputes range from the high cost of government to a move to construct multistory apartment houses in the Hill section, one of the better residential districts. And a new torm of governmentthe hird in six yearsis having difficulty, winning acceptance.

title: Gardens Trap Isects with Flowers and Save the Vegetables
description: NOW that many gardeners are really serious about not using hard pesticide sprays in their yards, interest is growing in trap plants, organic sprays and plants to repel insects.

title: New Federal Money For Model Cities Put At 6Million for City
description: S. William Green, regional administrator of the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, said yesterday that New York City would have $11.7million to operate its Model Cities program during the threemonth period from April 1 to June 30.

title: Patricia Sheeran to Wed
description: Mrs. James Parker Haney of New York and Rumson, N. J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Patricia Ann Sheeran, to John Rawson Atwood, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rawson Atwood of Rumson. Miss Sheeran also is a daughter of the late Gerard Francis Sheeran, who was president of the McCabe and Sheeran Machinery Corporation.

title: Recordings Rock That's Not Just for Kids
description: ABOUT a halfdozen years ago when psychedelia and San Francisco were in full flower blanketing the music scene in dense and frantic sound, two English singer/songwriters gave me hope that contemporary music could achieve some elegant sophistication without losing its energy. Those two were Alan Price and Cat Stevens. Although Price had been one of the original Animals and heard on their first He House Of The Rising Sun, his own efforts with nis Alan Price Set were not well known here because he never had a U.S. hit nor did he tour the States. After Stevdns's initial two albums, Matthew & Son and New Masters, he had to drop out of the music scene for nearly two years because of tuber.

title: The New Plays
description: THE DANCE OF DEATH, the New York Shakespeare Festival's production of Strindberg's play, got 6 favorable reviewa (Watts, Post; Wallach, Newsday; Lewis, Bergen Record; Harris, WCBSTV; Scudder, WINS  Radio; Woodruff, WMCARadio), 5 mixed (Barnes, Times; Gottfried, Women's Wear; Gayer, UPI; Novick, Village Voice; Stasio, Cue) and 6 negative (Watt, News; Raidy, Newhouse Newspapers; A. Klein, WNYCRadio; Morrow, Time; Gill, New Yorker; Hewes, Saturday Review/World).

title: 85 Years of a Show: From Park to a Dance Floor
description: Eightyfive years ago the Rhode Island Kennel Club, which had been organized in 1886, held its first show in Freebody Park, Newport, So that the exhibitors, dogs and spectators from Providence could reach the show site, the club chartered a steamboat. Today the organization moves to a dance floor, as it stages its show at Rhodes on the Pawtuxet in Cranston. We are using two old ballrooms, said Eleuterio Fonseca, the show chairman. Because of the limited space, we have held the entry to 1,290.

title: Ellen Lunden to Wed
description: The engagement of Miss Ellen Gail Lunden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon L. Lunden of Coram, L.I., to David William Feinsilber, son of Mrs. Frank Feinsilber of Chevy Chase, Md., and the late Mr. Feinsilber, has been announced by the future bride's parents.

title: New Hatchery Is Planned
description: HACKETTSTOWN  The state's Bureau of Fisheries is planning to replace its hatchery here with a new one on 1,300 acres along the Pequest River in Liberty, Mansfield and Oxford Townships. All of the communities involved are in Warren County.

title: Music in Review
description: The 17th season of Clarion Concerts ended at Tully Hall on Wednesday night with a program devoted to 18thcentury vocal music. There were two Mozart arias in it and Pergolesi's Stabat Mater, but since Clarion's music director, Newell Jenkins, specializes in the minor masters of the period, they were well represented, too.

title: Scars on The Soul
description: It has taken me years to come to appreciate Franoise Sagan's kind of smoothness. I pick up one of her books and think, how trite; why do they like her so much? Then against my puritanical will I get involved, slide over the shining marble floors on her seemingly effortless construction.

title: Consulting Guru For Managers

title: Design

It is more than high camp or current chic, more than tasseled cigarette cases and streamlined statuettes, more than a passing vogue for one in a series of sentimental stylistic revivals. title: Getting in Dutch With Mud Makes Some Types Ooze With Pleasure
description: IT is just after sunrise in the net village of Wie rum, which is on the coast of Holland's northern province of Friesland and about 200 miles northeast of Amsterdam no music Bach floats out into the bright morning from a radio in one of the redbrick cottages. A blond girl holding a baby miles at a stranger as he passes her window, and a teenaged boy leading goat and two kids clatters along the cobblestones in wooden shoes. It's scene of almost medieval calm  until, down at the end of the street, in front of the grassy dike that holds back the North Sea, three small cars drive up, top, and deliver to the Cafe Kalkman a dozen young men and girls dressed in tack suits. They order coffee and toast and butter as more cars arrive outside. These are the wadlopers, mud sloggers who are about to slurp and slosh their way five miles out into the soggy tidal flats of the sea to a sandbar called Engelsmanplaat. Then they will turn around and thrash their way back to shore before the tide can rise and sweep them all out to sea.

title: The soncrous spring
description: Twelve years ago Rachel Carson jolted the nation with a chilling indictment of the indiscriminate use of chemicals to control insects, weeds and fungi. A scientist with impeccable credentials, as well as a gifted writer, Miss Carson warned in her bestselling Silent Spring that pesticides were killing birds by the millions and that the poisoning of the environment might be irreversible. She opened the chapter called And No Birds Sing, by quoting a Metter from Mrs. Claudia M. Fallert of Hinsdale, Ill. In 1958, Mrs. Fallert, had written in despair to Robert Cushman Murphy, curator emeritus of birds of the American Museum of Natural History, that, as a result of spraying stricken elm trees with DDT, the town is almost devoid of robins and starlings, chickadees have not been on my shelf for two years, and this year the cardinals are gone too ...  Will they ever come back? Mrs. Fallert said the children were asking.

title: The music that is new again
description: Three men in tuxedosa pianist and bassist in their early 60's and a drummer in his late 20'swere improvising on Runnin' Wild. The pianist, dignified in bearing, his hair and neat mustache graying, showed no discernible emotion as he played with swift precision, his touch, so light that the keys seemed barely to go down. Yet each note was being clearly and flowingly knit into an airborne design which kept building momentum, made all the more exciting by a series of ringing octaves in the right hand that conjured up the image of a full, standing trumpet section playing ill unison.
