title: Riverside Drive, Brussels' Flourishes
description: Riverside Drive is a, boulevard of qualified success. Bent on evoking Paris, it achieved at the turn of the ?? a bit of Brussels. The drive wits productand, perhaps, victimof New Money in an era when Stanford White was down at the docks offloading entire facades from French and Florentine palaces to sate a taste for taste.

title: Richard Lewis to Wed Lenore Strauss
description: Miss Lenore Janover Strauss and Richard B. Lewis plan to be married here July 28 at Delmonico's. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. James Raver of Brooklyn, stepfather and mother of the bridetobe, whose fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Moe Lewis of Flushing, Queens.

title: The Killing Has to Stop
description: ON the top floors of their giant gray and black monoliths, the yawns of the network heads are barely stifled. They are shorthand for Here we go again, boys, as they look at the headline: New Senate Hearings on TV Violence Begin.

title: Red Sox Top Tigers, Behind Wise
description: BOSTON, April 13 (AP)Tommy Harper, the designated hitter, triggered a six. run first inning with a leadoff double today and the Boston Red Sox went on to an 81 victory over the Detroit Tigers.

title: Counting beaks
description: Some of the best work in checking birdpopulation trends in the United States today is being done by Chandler S. Robbins, one of the authors of Birds of North America, the fieldidentification book now rivaling Roger Tory Peterson's A Field Guide to the Birds as the birders' bible. As chief of migratory nongame bird studies of the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Mr. Robbins has supervised a survey of breeding birds that is far more scientific than the annual winter censuses conducted by the Nations Audubon Society.

title: Nun Forced to Quit in Dispute Over Mass
description: BOSTON, April 13A Roman Catholic nun has been forced to resign her position here after the local archdiocese accused bier of saying the mass.

title: Yacht Record Broken
description: PERTH, Australia, April 13 (Reuters)The world 24hour distance sailing record was broken today by Cherub Class yachtsmen at the Mouts Bay Sailing Club in Perth. Greg Hilton completed 132.4 nautical miles to beat the previous record of 125 nautical miles set by Squid Class yachts off the coast of France in 1972.

title: Fate of $32Million in Rothko Art Unresolved as Estate Suit Resumes
description: When Mark Rothko, one of the leading abstractexpressionist painters of the 20th century, committed suicide in his East 69th Street studio, he left 800 paintings now valued as high as $32million.

title: Calendar of Dog Show Events
description: TodayRhode Island K.G. allbreed and obedience, Rhodes on the Pawtuxet, Cranston, R.I.; 1,290 dogs; 9 A.M.

title: Argentine Guerrillas' Victim Recovering After Surgery
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 13An American diplomat who was shot and briefly kidnapped by Marxist guerrillas in Crdoba yesterday was reported today to be recovering from his wounds.

title: Hamsters Killed To Prevent Spread Of Mild Meningitis
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 13 (UPI)Health officials say that thousands of hamsters are being destroyed around the country in an effort to prevent the spread of a mild form of meningitis that has already affected 93 persons in seven states.

title: JUDGE LEWIS GOLDBERG
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., April 13 (AP)  Judge Lewis Goldberg, who served on the Massachusetts Superior Court for 41 years until 1943, died at his home Thursday. He was 86 years old.

title: DAYAN SAYS RAIDS AGAINST LEBANON WILL BE CONTINUED
description: JERUSALEM, April 13Defense Minister Moshe Dayan warned the Lebanese Government today that if it failed to police Arab guerrillas, Israel would continue its punitive raids until all of southern Lebanon was, abandoned.

title: KUNSTLER TO SEEK HALTING OF TRIAL
description: ST. PAUL, April 12William M. Kunstler said today that he would seek a dismissal of all charges in last year's Wounded Knee violence on the ground that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had monitored telephone calls of Indian suspects without court permission and then tried to conceal that fact.

title: Miss Barker Plans Bridal
description: Miss Clarissa Holden Barker, a student at the Villa nova Law School, and A. Kenneth Edelston, a mathematics instructor at the Radnor (Pa.) High School, have made plans to be married in August.

title: Kerr On The National Health Joe Egg, Soft
description: WHEN I saw the second Peter Nichols play to be produced in this country, I wondered that the author of the brilliant Joe Egg could write anything as undramatically discursive as ForgetMeNot Lane. Now that I have seen a third Peter Nichols play, The National Health at the Long. Wharf in New Haven, I wonder that the author of The National Health could ever have written anything as forceful Joe Egg.

title: Letters Horsefeathers
description: To the Editor: After reading the heartwarming story of James Morris's triumph over genetic destiny (James and Jan by David Holden, March, 17), I felt emboldened to share a similar story, of my own.

title: Conrad Albert to Wed Miss Presbrey
description: The engagement of Miss Elizabeth Martin Presbrey to Conrad Preston Albert has been announced by Mrs. Natalie Martin Presbrey of New York, mother of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alpheus Homer Albert Jr. of Clinton, N. J.

title: For Once, the Rolls Have Declined.
description: If last year's statistics are any indication of trend, the era of steady increases on the region's welfare rolls has ended and been replaced with period of leveling off and decline.

title: World News Briefs
description: LONDON, April 14 (Reuters) Enoch Powell, a rightwing Mavrrick in the Conservative party, is giving up his membership in the party, it was disclosed today.

title: Unusual Vegetables Challenge the Gourmet
description: WHILE making plans for the vegetable garden this summer, just for fun, save room for a few unusual kinds. Some different varieties of lettuce such as Ruby, Red Salad Bowl, Deer Tongue which is similar to Bibb but with leaves oblong to triangular, are fascinating to grow. Or a midget lettuce, such as Tom Thumb produces heads the size of a tennis ball.

title: CleanAir Violators on Rise
description: NEWARKThe number of cleanair violators uncovered in the first two months of this year increased sharply over the comparable 1973 period, according to a special project undertaken by the state's Bureau of Air Pollution Control. The targets of the special effort were dirty smokestacks emitting black smoke.

title: Spassky Sets Back Karpov For 1.0 Lead in Chess Match
description: LENINGRAD, April 13 (AP) Boris Spassky defeated Anatoly Karpov today to take 10 lead in their semifinal match of the world chess challengers tournament. Spassky, seeking another chance at the world championship he lost to Bobby Fischer, of the United States, forced the 22yearold Karpov to resign on the 64th move.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: I read with interest The Economic Scene column on, inflation (Grin and Bear It, March 31).

title: Better Mass Transit Sought in Colorado Desert Tests
description: PUEBLO, Colo.Clumps of tumbleweed dance over the bleak desert. A herd of antelope dashes by. On the horizon between the mounds of desert called Prairie Dog Town and the spot where seven rattlesnakes were killed within three hours one autumn afternoonsomething glistens in the sun.

title: AutoRepair Complaints Rising
description: In 1970 Mrs. Cynthia Elman of Brooklyn paid $3,500 for new Volkswagen Ssluareback and decided to have service done only by factory authorized dealerships to avoid problems and assure good service.

title: Nuptials for Miss Wilson
description: Miss Fiona Fraser Wilson and Francois Tibor Balogh were married this afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church in Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. Jon Freeburg, The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Sandford C. Smith of Greenwich and Andrew H. Wilson of Los Angeles. She is a granddaughter of the late United States Representative Joseph Clark Baldwin of New York. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Tibor Balogh of Greenwich.

title: Sports News Briefs N.H.L.W.H.A. Sought in Europe
description: HELSINKI, Finland, April 13 (UPI)The National Hockey League and the World Hockey Association are negotiating with the new Izvestia Cup European League for a playoff tourament at the end of their seasons, Jobn F. Ahearne, head of the International Ice Hockey Federation, said today. Sweden, Finland, the Soviet Union and Czechoslovakia are M. the new league.

title: FiredUp Cooks Get Apology From Player
description: HOUSTON, April 13 (UPI)  Doug Rader, Houston Astros' third baseman, apologized today to the country's shortorder cooks.

title: Miss Mirabile Plans Nuptials
description: State Supreme Court Justice Thomas J. Mirabile and Mrs. Mirabile of Brooklyn and Stony Brook, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eloise Kathleen Mirabile, to William Thomas Bellard 3d, son of Judge William T. Bellard Jr. of the New York City Civil Court and Mrs. Bellard of Brooklyn.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: No Praise for the U.S. Senate or Henry Aaron's Manager
Mrs. Gross Remarried
description: Mrs. Rita Rogers Gross of Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., widow of Lieut. Col. Robert H. Gross, who was killed six years ago while serving with the Army in Vietnam, was married yesterday afternoon to William E. Byrne Jr. of Ossining, N. Y., a widower. Msgr. Herman L. Heide Jr. performed the ceremony in the Our Lady of Loretto Roman Catholic Church in Cold Spring, N. Y. The bridegroom retired as a vice president of the Public Service Mutual Insurance Company.

title: Television
description: SOMETIMES It's just a matter of packaging. If The Little House on the Prairie, shown on the National Broadcasting Company network a couple of Saturdays ago, had been presented as a 90minute afterschool special for young people, the program and the network might have been praised for doing something good in an area begging for something good. Instead, the production was stretched to two hours and run in the adult primetime slot of 9 to 11 P.M., demanding a different evaluation and considerably less praise.

title: CANADA IN SHIFT ON AID IN AFRICA
description: MONTREAL, April 13The Government of Canada, in a significant departure from its past policy, has decided to give humanitarian aid to the insurgents who are fighting guerrilla wars against Africa's white governments.

title: Kismet Scheduled By Montclair Club
description: UPPER MONTCLAIRA professional dramaticbaritone who starred in Fiddler on the Roof, one of the Montclair Operetta Club's most successful musicals in its 49year history, will return to play a leading role in the semiprofessional group's production of Kismet. The show will be presented on April 26, 27, 28 and May 3 and 4.

title: States Tackle Bills On Officials' Ethics
description: Impelled by the Watergate scandal, by the President's income tax woes and by widespread cynicism among voters about the conduct of elected officials at all levels, legislatures in major states are ranking campaign spending regulation and ethics law reform as major items of business this spring.

title: A Great Deal of FunBut Is It Worth Doing?
description: IF ONE were to arbitrarily smack a label on the sixties, the Age of Camp might not be appropriate from a cultural standpoint, for it was, after all, the sixties that brought us James Bond, Twiggy, Andy Warhol, and the war in Vietnameach in its own way a kind of puton, dreadful or sublime. By the end of the decade, movies at least seemed to have developed beyond Camp's cynical reign, an advisable progression since the artistic potential of the tease would appear to be rather small. Recently, however, anchored in the mire of the somber seventies, one has begun to notice a possible recurtracing of the old sixties puton and nowhere is that resurfacing more evident than in the current movie version of The Three Musketeers.

title: Lucien Pohl, 89, Specialist In Oriental Art, Naturalist
description: Lucien L. Pohl, an authority on Oriental art and a naturalist, died Friday in Doctors Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived at 311 East 72d Street.

title: Film Turns Small Town Into Mecca
description: MARRAKESH, Morocco Some 15 miles out of this teeming commercial and tourist center of southern. Morocco, an isolated farming village called, Ait Bouchent has been turned into a new Mecca, complete with Islam's holiest shrine, the Kaaba, where Mohammed fought and won his battle against paganism.

title: R. H. HUNGERFORD, AIDED RETARDED
description: Richard H. Hungerford, director of the city's Board of Education's bureau for children with retarded mental development from 1942 to 1953, died Friday in Jackson, Mich. He was 70 years old and formerly lived in Brooklyn.

title: Pablo Casals
description: Play the rests, my piano teacher would say. The silences in music are part of the music: the lifting of the bow to release the phrase, the taking of breath to shape the plume. A player does not just count as he pauses; he listens.

title: Point of View
description: Last month the City Council unanimously reenacted the rent stabilization law, and with Mayor Beame's signature the stabilization system was extended for five years. This testifies to the success of the Rent Stabilization Association in regulating the rents of apartments built in the city between. June 1947 and May 1968.

title: Opera: Parsifal Returns
description: After having been dropped for a season, Parsifal was returned to the Metropolitan Opera's repertory on Good Friday, evening. The soldout performance of Wagner's consecrative work was notable in that it brought back to the company William Steinberg as conductor, and there were also members of the cast singing their roles for the first time here.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: EDWARD J. DINKEL JR.
description: Edward J. Dinkel Jr., a lawyer and associate director of pensions and welfare of the Prudential Insurance Company, died yesterday in Mountainside Hospital in Montclair, N. J. He was 63 years old and lived at 145 Watchung Avenue in Montclair and at Shelter Island, L. I.

title: This Regatta Takes All Kinds
description: They have assumed the blueblazered, suntanned look of the yachtsman, but not too long ago these gentlemen were the little neighborhood bullies who liked to yell, My daddy can beat up your daddy.

title: Wider Authority Urged For County School Chief
description: TRENTON While Governor Byrne is trying to determine, what county superintendents of schools do, the state's Department of Education has recommended that their authority be broadened and their staffs greatly expanded.

title: Paperbacks Of the Month.
description: Fiction

title: Elaine B. Finbury To Marry in June
description: Miss Elaine Beth Finbury and Hugh Willett Samson plan to be married June 16 in Menemsha on Martha's Vineyard, Mass. Their engagement has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert W. Finbury of Haverhill, Mass., and Martha's Vineyard.

title: The Way We Were: A Look Back at the Late Great Gas Shortage
description: IN Hartford, Conn., during the more hectic days of the recent gaioline shortage, Charlie Regini, an Exxon dealer, hung up his hose in disgust at one point and said he'd had enough  enough of motorists shouting, honking, bribing, threatening and actually jeopardizing life and limb for a few gallons of gasoline. Then he did what a good many other filling station men must have felt like doing  he barricaded himelf in his station behind a tow track, a blue sedan, a panel truck, a purple Jeep, a red Volkswagen, a blue and white pickup truck, two garbage oil drums and a sawhorse. When someone asked him what he was doing in this improvised bunker. Regini exploded. THEY'VE BEEN SCREAMING AT ME! he cried.

title: STEEL AND UNION TO ADOPT A PLAN ON JOB EQUALITY
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 Labor and management in the steel industry, after long negotiations with the Federal Government, have adopted a voluntary nationwide plan to end racial and sex discrimination in hiring, employment and pay practices, sources close to the negotiations disclosed today.

title: Raising Children In a Difficult Time
description: Dr. Benjamin Spock is one of the great utopians. His newest book, Raising Children in a Difficult Time, reasserts (and, on some points, reasserts in identical sentences) the vision presented in his classic, Baby and Child Care. A just and decent society can be produced through common sense, a strong family, values, and, most of all, love. He still believesafter a long life experiencethat those things are accessible, even natural, to human beings. His vision, or faith, springs from a basic compassion, a highly idealized memory of 19thcentury smalltown life, and the perspective of hiss own, apparently immutable, existence as a white, uppermiddle class, American male.

title: Apprentices Renew Craft Tradition
description: FLEMINGTONThe 18thcentury apprentice system, modified somewhat to meet the needs of the 20th century, is flourishing at Liberty Village, Flemington's 17acre living museum on Church Street.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Many businessmen, lawyers and accountants if asked whether stockholder approval of the appointment of independent auditors was important would answer. probably not.

title: The View From the Window
description: BOSTONFrom his office in the Boston City Hall, one of the great public buildings in America, Mayor Kevin White has an unobstructed view of the old market area around Faneuil Hall, where Revolutionary orators once defied King George. Now the Mayor can watch the restoration of the brick market buildings to their former glory; aeon the area will be bustling with shops and offices.

title: Four Ask Sirica's Removal From Case
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 Four of the seven then indicted in the Watergate coverup have asked Federal District Judge John Sirica to step down from the case.

title: How to Keep Cool Under Pressure on the Golf Course
description: Sam Snead:

title: Movies
description: SANTA SUSANNA, CALIF. RAOUL WALSH'S white clapboard farmhouse stands high above sea level in the Santa Susanna Mountains some 50 miles northwest of Los Angeles. Outside the windows, orange trees are blanketed in late afternoon mist, horses whip flies with their tails, and ten Fats and four dogs perform arabesques on the lawn.

title: Eleanor Hall Harvie Fiancee Of Gregory Miner Gustafson
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Beverly Harvie Jr. of Upper Nyack, N.Y., and Chatham, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Hall Harvie, to Gregory Miner Gustafson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thor B. Gustafson, of Brookside. N.J.

title: Bethea, a Black, Has Map For Trail to Indianapolis
description: Randy Bethea has not won a race in anything higher than a hobby car. He has never raced on a road circuit; never made a right turn in competition, never shifted. And no black driver has ever started, the Indianapolis 500.

title: Bridge
description: Leading fourthhighest from a long suit is one of the few technical legacies that bridge players owe to the whist experts of a century ago. Then in 1890 R. F. Foster in this country and E. M. F. Beinecke in England made a useful arithmetical discovery simultaneously. The FosterBeinecke inspiration is known as the Rule of Eleven. After a fourth best lead it allows the leader's partner and the declarer to calculate each other's highcard total in the suit, that is, higher than the one led. Subtract the numerical value of the card led from eleven, and further subtract the number of high cards visible elsewhere. Consider this example:

title: Abandoned Houses Get New Owners:
description: A nonprofit community group in Sunset Parkwhich has been plagued by continuing decay in the last few yearshas rehabilitated sevrr abandoned houses, sold four of them and is in the process of rehabilitating eight more.

title: In Hiding 29 Years, Dutch Collaborator With Nazis Found
description: THE HAGUE, April 13 A Dutchman, sentenced to death in 1950 for collaboration with the German occupation forces in World War II and for serving in the Waffen SS, the combat arm of the Nazi lite guard has been arrested in The Hague He had been hidden for 29 years in his parents' home here

title: The New Brand Game Is Private Labels
description: Private brands (merchandise bearing littleknown labels or labels with the retailer's name) are in the spotlight this year because of a fuzzy economic climate and uncertain consumer buying.

title: The State of the National Morale
description: JERUSALEMIn her speech announcing her resignation to the Israeli Parliament, Premier Golda Meir concluded with a message for the Israeli people: I call on the nation to live and act, not as a defeated community, but as nation and state with a secure future.

title: Edward Byron Smith Jr. Fiance of Maureen Dwyer
description: Miss Maureen Dwyer, picture editor at the American Heritage Publishing Company here, plans to be married this summer to Edward Byron Smith Jr., an investment officer at the Northern Trust Company of Chicago, of which his father is chairman.

title: Lamb's poor relatives
description: It has long been our aim on this page to reflect the gamut from the wholly exotic to the simply good; from truffled pts to earthy meat loaves; from caviar to omelets. This issue is devoted to two relatively inexpensive dishes made with breast of lamb. The recipe Burgundystyle is a peasant dish, great for buffets. The other is a sophisticated rib dish to eat with the fingers.

title: A Store Shortage Felt on East Side As Apartment Growth Spreads
description: Residents of the Upper East Sidethat Manhattan bastion of the high income and the high middle incomehave a new complaint these days: overcrowding in the area's retail establishments, particularly convenience stores.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTON  For about three months now, Governor Byrne has had to ride around in an unimpressivelooking; lightblue Plymouth, sedan, while his lesser Cabinet aides lean back and relax in the relative splendor of the highestpriced Mercurys and Chryslers that the state can afford.

title: The Figure Is Always in the World
description: THERE are moments in the history of certain artistic careers that remain almost unbearably poignant to contemplate. One of these, surely, occurred in the life of Alberto Giacometti some time during the winter of 194445. Giacometti was then 43 years old. For some yearsfrom around 1930 to the beginning of the warhe had been a highly esteemed member of the Surrealist circle in Paris. Earlier on, he had produced some remarkable sculpture reflecting the influence of Cubism, and of Brancusi and Arp. He had, moreover, the good fortune to be born into a family of serious artists who had supported his endeavors from the start. He had moved with an enviable speed from his apprenticeship in the atelier of Bourdelle to the acclaim of the Parisian avantgarde. No artist of his time, to judge from the purely external facts of his life, seemed more securely and creatively entrenched in his vocation than Giacometti.

title: The Y Looks Ahead
description: THE Y.M.Y.W.H.A. at 92d. Street and Lexington Avenue has long been a performingarts center, with the emphasis shifting over the years from one cultural area to another. At one time in its congenial Theresa L. Kaufmann Concert Hall, one Could hear artists of the caliber of Josef Hofmann. It flourished in many directions under William Kolodney, who became educational director in 1935, with dance and poetry finding an important place. When Kolodney left, the role of music dwindled. Now, after a couple of decades, it looks as if music will come into its own again there.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Bygone Days
description: Wearying of the wellpresented but depressing revelations of an ecological tome I was reading the other day, I reached for an anthology of English poetry and in it found a yellowing envelope containing nine negatives of a mountaintop fishing trip a friend and I made 15 years ago.

title: China Won't Get the Globetrotters, We won't Get Yin
description: SHORT time ago RCA released that musical example of Chinese ideology named The Yellow Rivor Concerto Daniel Epstein was the soloist and Eugene, Ormandy conducted: the Philadelphia Orchestra. This was the work that Ormandy andthe Chinese pianist Yin ChengChung had featured in China but September, wheis the Philadelphia. Orchestra visited Peking and Shanghai.

title: Jefferson Caffery Dean of Diplomatic Service, Dies
description: LAFAYETTE, La., April 13 (AP)Jefferson Caffery, ranked as dean of the United States diplomatic corps before his retirement in 1955, died here this afternoon at the age of 87.

title: Book Ends
description: Streaking. You have to move fast to cash in on streaking. As a fad, it's liable to be bare today and gone tomorrow. At any rate, the raceor is it streakto get out a book on streaking has been won by Bantamby a day. Their book, The Streaking Book, was on the stands by April Fools' Day, while Ballantine's, The Joy of Streaking, was officially out April 2. Actually we should probably call a tie. The reason for the unholy haste Is to catch the college students while they're still in school (and still streaking). Bantam's streaking book is by Gerald Gardner, chief balloon writer for The Watergate Follies, and consists of photos of bigwigs reacting to streakers; Ballantine's emulates the cover of The Joy of Sex, but not the rest of the book, and consists mostly of photographs of streakers with funny captions. As far as other streaking books are concerned, Pinnacle was going to do one (a magazine called The Streaker's Handbook), couldn't get it out fast enough and passed it on to Marvel Comics, who will bring it out. Dell will distribute The Altogether in the Altogether, by Hugh Ranier (French speakers are supposed to recognize a pun in the name of the pseudonymous author), prepared by the Tobey Publishing Company. This Is all putonan astrological guide to streaking, streaking records, etc.and will be out in May. There will probably be more and an editor tells us she received three streakingbook proposals last week alone. We understand that the burning esthetic (legal? moral?) question for publishers of streaking books is, to show or not to show the male genitals? Too bad the streakers didn't think of that.

title: Greenery for Summer Salads
description: ANYONE with a window sill, balcony, or doorstep can have a mini garden for salad greens. Just acquire containers, soil, fertilizer and seed.

title: Catholic Clergy Declines; Protestants' on Increase
description: The Rev. A. Donald Wiesner, an Episcopal priest here, could not find a parish job, so he is selling insurance.

title: Arthur Krock, Dead at 87, Hailed By Nixon as a Great Journalist
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 President Nixon paid tribute today to Arthur Krock as one of America's greatest journalists and one of her finest sons.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: May I point outin reply to David Cairns's review of my book A Decade of Music (Feb. 17)that I did do in the book the things he faulted me for not doing.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: April 17Datsun Owners Club technical session at Bob Sharp Motors, Route 7, nine miles north of Merritt Parkway, Wilton, Conn., 8 P.M. Information: Peter S. Slater, phone, 2035448375 day (203)4380222 night.

title: Hooray, Another Awful Oscar Evening
description: THANK heavens for John Huston. If it hadn't been for his wise words the other night during the telecast of the 46th annual Academy Awards presentations I'd probably be writing something small, mean and peevish at this very minute. Even cruel. However, after listening to Mr. Huston I was forced to rethink my gilt reactions to the show and to the awards themselves.

title: JAPAN UNCERTAIN IN EROTICA BOOM
description: TOKYOJapan, where kissing in public is considered indecent, has entered the age of erotica in a state of paradox, contradiction and ambiguity.

title: Art in London
description: LONDON.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Boston Red Sox, who let go two of their aging starsOrlando Cepeda, lately a designated hitter, and Luis Aparicio, the shortstopbefore the season began, play a threegame series with the Yankees Tuesday through Thursday in Shea Stadium. Game time is 2 P.M. daily.

title: QE2 Docks After a Memorable, if Not Bon, Voyage
description: The Queen Elizabeth 2 ended her memorable Caribbean misadventure yesterday morning, edging into her Hudson River berth at 42d Street for final repairs before a scheduled departure for Southampton next Tuesday.

title: Syria Says She Downed 3 Jets Over Golan but Israel Denies It
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, April 13 (Reuters)  Syria shot down three Israeli planes above frontline tank and artillery battles today, a Syrian military spokesman said.

title: The Region
description: Mayor Beame, who says he needs $1.5billion to balance New York City's budget, journeyed to Albany to solve his fiscal problem and returned to New York with a political one as well.

title: Lawyers' Group Sending 2 to Observe Chile Trials
description: A group known as the Lawyers Committee on Chile has announced that it will have legal representatives on hand as observers in Santiago tomorrow when leading officials in the government of the late President Salvador Allende Gossens go on trial.

title: A Dancer Who Had A Dream
description: BLACK children in ballet practice clothes slip through the hallways of the Dance Theater of Harlem. The telephone rings constantly, and at one point the quiet receptionist dials the Police Emergency number  a child has called for help because her aunt is being mugged. That somber note aside, there is an intermittent, cheerful litany of morning greetings.

title: The Easter Bunny Factory
description: NORTHPORT, L.I.As hundreds of children on Long Island unwrap their Easter bunnies today and munch on the chocolate, Peter Panarites will be enjoying his first real holiday in more than five months.

title: Consumers Union Changes View on G.E. Dishwashers
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) Consumers Union says it has changed its mind about two models of General Electric dishwashers that it says do not appear to be hazardous after all.

title: Maestro Halasz Gets Ready for a Magic Flute With Brotherhood
description: Laszlo Halasz, who is staging and conducting The Magic Flute at Hofstra University later this month, is hoping that his magic wand will continue to produce much more good opera for Long Island in the years to come.

title: A BUDDHIST SECT HOLDS CONVENTION
description: SAN DIEGO, April 13With a parade, a huge fireworks display and an ice extravaganza in the San Diego sports arena, it looked more like a Mardi Gras than a religious convention.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Dave Anderson
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 13Most golfers take lessons on the practice tee. Others do it froth books or magazines. But the Masters leader entering tomorrow's final round, Dave Stockton, does it by telephone.

title: Photogfraphy
description: THE bizarre and disturbing photographs of Judy pater, and Jack Welpott at the Witkin Gallery, 243 East 60th Street, through May 11, ought to prove that there is such a thing as a woman's eye. They ought to prove that women photographers see differently than men photographers, or if the camera is neutral and impartial, at least that women sitters react differently to men and women photographers.

title: California Is Ordered to Equalize School Financing
description: LOS ANGELES, April 13California, with the biggest and one of the best public school systems in the nation, was ordered this week to find an alternative to the districtbydistrict property tax system of school financing as a means of eqaulizing the quality of education in its more than 1,000 school districts.

title: Riddle Composition In Debut at Shore
description: WEST LONG BRANCHA new Nelson Riddle composition will be heard for the first time next Friday in a twopiano recital to be presented at Monmouth College by Dr. Ralph D. Lambert, Professor of Music at the college, and Willard MacGregor of New York.

title: The Diary of Anais Nin
description: In the new volume of Anas Nin's diary, begun when she was 11 as a communication to her runaway musician father and continued with little interruption for the next 50 years, a vivid world continues to be disclosed. On goes the voice, obsessive and incessant. It recalls, chides, laments, advises, resolves, pontificates. Sometimesoftenthe voice implores the diary as if it were father and could console: Kimon Friar included Djuna Barnes in an anthology of poetry, but not me, when it was he who invited me to Amherst College as a writer of poetic prose; and What makes my work so difficult to understand? And often the diary is confronted as if it were a mirror where a reminder of identity is sought, as though the seeker, ignored by so many, were invisible: There is a very real, very opaque silence around my work.... The world is silent.

title: Of Primitive and Enigmatk Mysteries
description: MOST of the great avantgarde movements and ideas of this century have reflected a searek, for certain fundamentals of art in particular or of human experience in general. Whether engaged in reducing Painting to an austere formalism or in cramming the art context with nonart references, the modernist creator has thus often been characterized by a kind of willful primitivism  taking primitive in its double connotation of something basic and of something barbarous. Strong statements in modern art havetended to display one or the other of these qualities, either undercutting or overwhelming conventional expectations.

title: Game to Aid Victims
description: TERRE HAUTE, Ind., April 13 (UPI)Indiana State University's annual spring football gape April 27 will be a benefit for Indiana tornado victims.

title: Race Track Flavor at Trial
description: Del Insko chews a toothpick, shakes his head in disbelief at some of the testimony and says he'll absolutely take the stand to defend his reputation.

title: Grant in Final Of Easter Bowl
description: Mike Grant and Mary Carillo, two of the East's best young players, made their way to the finals of the 18year division in the annual Easter Bowl indoor junior tennis tournament here yesterday.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Rising interest rates weakened the stock market last week as prices finished mostly lower in continued quiet trading.

title: Exercising Freshperson Power
description: WASHINGTONRecent years have seen all kinds of people on the outskirts of power flexing their muscles. We hear of black power, senior power, women power, Indian powerto name a few.

title: VD Clinic Treated 400 in First Year
description: LAKEWOODMore than 400 people have visited the VenerealDisease Clinic at Paul Kimball Hospital during its first year of operation, and there are indications that the facility is helping to keep the VD rate in the Ocean County area down.

title: Notes: Sky Shuttle To LondonWhen?
description: VISIONARIES have been saying for years that the time will come when catching a plane will be just like catching a bus. In the eyes of Frederic A. Laker, the 51yearold British aviation pioneer, that tinte, so far as transAtlantic air travel is concerned, has arrived, and all that stands in the way of his instituting buslike shuttle service between New York and London is final authorization by the Civil Aeronautics Board and the signature of President Nixon on a foreign air carrier permit.

title: Chimera of Controls
description: John T. Connor, who had some experience with such things when he was Secretary of Commerce in the Johnson Administration, is pleased that the Nixon Administration's program of economic controls incoming to an end. He feels it has become unjust to industry.

title: About the Mets ...
description: Tug McGraw said for sure he'd be available if needed for today's doubleheader against the Phils. The twinbill, starting at 1:15 P.M., resulted from yesterday's rainout ... McGraw had been nursing a fever from a chest cold. The reliever sat in the clubhouse during last Thursday's double loss to the Cardinals, when he was needed. Since the games weren't on radio, he had messengers running in and out giving me the score, . . . Neither McGraw nor Met fans will need messengers anymore this season. Bowing to the pressure of dozens of phone calls, radio station WIN (1050) has decided to broadcast all remaining Met games. Originally, 23 gamesall weekday afternoon affairsweren't going to be broadcast ... Bob Apodaca, who sported an earnedrun, average of 0.50 in camp, was named the winner of the John J. Murphy award as the Mets' top rookie of spring training. The previous winners were John Milner and Harry Parker.

title: June M. Goldweitz To Be Bride Aug. 4
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Gold weitz of Muttontown, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss June Mira GoldWeitz, to Peter Lewis Schneider, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ira Schneider of Jericho, L. I.

title: OPINION: Equal Rights for Marathon Runners, Too
Jersey Sets Race Dates
description: (Reprinted from yesterday late editions)

title: Camera World
description: THE Metropolitan Motion Picture Club of New York will be holding its 41st annual 16mm Gala Night Film Festival this coming Saturday, April 20, at 8 P.M. The program will consist of 12 prize winning short films (all made by amateurs) which have been selected for excellence in various categoies  including drama, comedy, travel, documentary and animation. The event will take place at the School of Art and Design, 57th Street and Second Avenue, and admission will be $2. Tickets can be purchased at the door.

title: E. L. Loblein Wed Virginia P. Kayser
description: Miss Virginia Phyllis Kayser daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Kayser Jr. of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday afternoon to Eldon Lawrence Loblein of Searsport, Me., son of Mrs. Ned Bergen of Delray Beach, Fla., and the late Eldon Oram Loblein. The Rev. Craig Burlington performed the Episcopal ceremony in the chancel of the Princeton University Chapel.

title: Claudia Versfelt Plans Marriage
description: Mr. and Mrs. William E. Versfelt of Scarborough, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Claudia Holly Vetsfelt, to Robert Dewain Swhier Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Swhier of Portland, Ind.

title: United Fund and Hospitals Unit To Merge FundRaising Drives
description: Two of the city's prime charitable fundraising groups have agreed to consolidate their annual philanthropic campaigns within New York's business community.

title: Knicks, Celtics Renew Annual Playoff Rivalry Today
description: It's time again for Dave Cowens, the newbreed center, and John Havlicek, the old Boston Celtic who keeps running. It's also time for the Dave DeBusscherePaul Silas battle of the boards, for a couple of Mr. Cools, Walt Frazier of the Knicks and Jo Jo White of Boston, and the bench antics of Tom Heinsohn, the Celtic coach.

title: INVESTING
description: Barring eleventhhour Congressional action, restraints on the amount of dividends corporations can pay to the holders of their common stock will end on April 30 as the Economic Stabilization Act of 1970 expires.

title: Test for Brazil's Inflation System
description: RIO DE JANEIROSome American economists have been flirting lately with Brazils unusual approach to the problem of runaway price increases: We don't fight inflationwe live with it, says Alvaro Brit Bezerra de Mello a Brazilian businessman.

title: Everton II, $8.20, First in Excelsior
description: The Chileanbred Everton II showed a great liking for the track that had turned sloppy during the afternoon at Aqueduct yesterday. Guided by Marco Castaneda and carrying 117 pounds. Everton II raced to a 1length triumph in the 1mile Excelsior Handicap over the favored Prince Dantan.

title: Kenny Sues on Meadowlands
description: NEWARKJohn V. Kenny, the aging former political boss of Hudson County, has filed a suit in the Chancery Division of Superior Court in which he claims to have been a silent partner in a corporation that bought and sold valuable tracts of the Hackensack Meadowlands over the last 15 years.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: John Dewey states in, his book, Schools of Tornorrow: The chief effort of all educational changes is to bring about a readjustment of existing scholastic institutions and methods so that they shall respond to changes in general. social and intellectual conditions.

title: Kerry 13. Noll, T. J. Muzyka Set Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert T. Kenworthy of Greenwich, Conn., have made known the engagement of Mrs. Kenworthy's daughter, Miss Kerry Barbara Noll, to Thomas Jay Muzyka. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Muzyka of Dover, Mass., and Southampton, L. I.

title: The Tactless Tactic
description: Whether or not by design, the actions taken by President Nixon and his impeachment counsel, James St. Clair, have consistently served a broad strategic purpose: delay as much as possible and, with the time gained, try to diminish the public stature of the House Judiciary Committee and divide its membership last week, in the latest tactical move in pursuit of that apparent strategy, the White House got exactly the opposite of what it wanted.

title: News Summary and Index SUNDAY, APRIL 14, 1974
description: Defense Minister Moshe Dayan of Israel warned the Lebanese Government that if it failed to police the Arab guerrilla groups operating from its territory, Israel would continue its punitive raids into southern Lebanon until the entire area would have to be abandoned. He made the warning in an unusual Sabbathmorning press conference in Tel Aviv in which he explained the motives behind Israel's latest raid into Lebanese territory. [1:8.]

title: Numismatics
description: THE Director of the Mint, Miss Mary Brooks, has bad news for all those dealers and speculators who have been trying to stir up a panicmarket in 1974 copper cents. Their activities began several months ago, shortly after the Treasury Department asked Congress for standby authority to make the cent out of aluminum instead of increasingly costly copper. These opportunists used this proposal as the springboard for an advertising campaign which offered the smart collector a chance to get in on the ground floor of a coming boom by investing in rolls and bags of scarce 1974. cents.

title: Cynthia Brown to Wed
description: Miss Cynthia Jean Brown plans to be married May 25 in St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Mount Kisco, N.Y., to Craig Linzy Howe, a reporter with The NewsTimes in Danbury, Conn. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Chapman Brown of Chappaqua, N.Y., parents of the bridetobe, whose fianc is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles A. Howe of Hamburg, N.Y., and Cocoa Beach, Fla.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: NEGOTIATORS for the steel industry and the United Steelworkers of America have reached a tentative agreement for a new threeyear labor contract beginning, July President Nixon signed a bill raising the minimum wage from $1.60 an hour to $2 an hour on May 1, then $2.10 hour on Jan. 1, 1975, and $2.30 an hour on Jan. 1, 1976. ... The House Ways and Means Committee said it would clear a bill to increase oilindustry taxes by more than $16billion over the next six years.

title: Miss Sindorf Is Wed
description: The marriage of Miss Pamela Merle Sindorf, daughter of Mrs. Ruth Bachall Sindorf of Wilmette, Ill., and Robert Leon Sindorf of Barcelona, Spain, to Jonathan Slade Dingman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Peter Van Cleef Dingman of Middlebury, Conn., took place yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Richard A. Stoehr of the Congregational Church of South Dennis, Mass., performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Beveridge Dingman of Dennis.

title: Role of V.A. Reassessed In Clash on Major Policy
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 When more than a dozen disabled Vietnam veterans occupied an office in a Federal building in Los Angeles last month to protest the policies of the Veterans Administration Donald E. Johnson, the agency's administrator, first refused and then agreed to meet with them.

title: Parent and Child: A child's garden of malocclusion
Restrictions Ease for Clergymen's Wives
description: Of all the women who were expected to share their husbands' lifetime workbut unsalaried, unsung, often unappreciated, and almost around the clockthe wives of farmers and clergymen were examples par excellence. And what they did as helpmates was in addition to keeping house and taking care of the children, often with very little money.

title: What to Do With All Those Tankers
description: LONDON According to the professionals, the outlook for the world tanker market is grisly indeed.

title: Nixon and Mr. Micawber
description: WASHINGTON, April 13In his of the Watergate affair, President Nixon seems to act more and more these days like Mr. Micawher in Charles Dickens's David Copperfield. He Is a great projector of bubble schemes that are Supposed to Solve all Ms troubles but always end even more trouble: Still, he never des Pairs but, feels sure, like Micawber, that something will turn up.

title: Same Closet More Room
description: ALTHOUGH if is not always feasible to enlarge an existing clothes closet, there is one way to create more usable space inside almost any conventionalsize closet: Remove the existing single door (usually about 30 inches in width), enlarge the opening so that it goes from floor to ceiling and across the full width of the interior of the closet, their install new bifolding doors that are the full height and width of this opening.

title: Ulrich Froehlich to Wed Diane Brown
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur T. Brown of Plainfield, N. J., and Sag Harbor, L. I., have made, known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Diane Lynn Brown, to Ulrich Rudolph Froehlich, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Heinrich Froehlich of Dsseldorf, West Germany.

title: Talbert to Play Scott
description: Bill Talbert, a member of the Tennis Hall of Fame, will meet Gene Scott, the national 35yearandolder champion, in an exhibition today at Chateau D'Vie in Spring Valley, N.Y. The match will start at 3:30 P.M.

title: When the New York Critics Damn You . . .
description: AS composer Gian Carlo Menotti speaks, a sense of disillusionment hovers over him. The morning I saw him, he had again suffered at the hands of a New York Times music critic, who; in reviewing the New York City Opera's current revival of The Consul, called Menotti's score serviceable. (The work, which has not been seen in New York since 1966, is being performed again this evening at the State Theater, and also. on Friday night and Sunday afternoon, April 28.) The Times critic went on to say that the music of The Consul was not of a kind to arouse, admiration for inspiration or refined workmanship.

title: Stars Foil Pacers In Opener, 10596
description: SALT LAKE CITY, April 13 (AP)Willie Wise put in 34 points tonight to spark the Utah Stars to a 10596 victory over the Indiana Pacers in the first game of their American Basketball Association Western Division playoff series.

title: Sunday Observer
description: The last important human activity not subject to taxation is sex. Why this curious exemption? When we are. compelled to pay taxes for food, clothing and shelter, does it make any sense to leave sex taxfree, like municipal bonds?

title: Letter from Saigon
description: The place is named after Specialist 4 James Thomas Davis, the first American to be killed in South Vietnam, in an ambush near Saigon, on Dec. 22, 1961, so there is a certain irony, today, in Camp Davis's housing the military delegation of the Provisional Revolutionary Government of the Republic of South Vietnam, which more than a year ago came to Tan Son Nhut air base to implement the still imimplemented Paris peace agreements.

title: Job Security Is Big Issue in Hawaiian Sugar Strike
description: LIHUE, Kauai, Hawaii, April 13  The sun was hot. Where they sat the shaded, flower  banked porch was cooled by the trade wind that had shifted back to the northeast after the weekend's heavy storms.

title: Katherine Weir to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Victor Weir of Plainview, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherine Ann Weir, to Timothy Kane McFarlan, on of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore McFarlan of Scottsdale, Ariz., formerly of Brookville, L.I. Miss Weir, a junior at St. John's University, was graduated from Our Lady of Mercy Academy in Syosset, L.I. Her fianc, a senior at Marquette University, was graduated from LaSalle Military Academy in Oakdale, L.I.

title: Upstate Area Divided by Atomic Project
description: ATHENS, N. Y., April 10The impending construction of an atomic power plant by the State Power Authority, :either here or about 10 miles to the south in Cementon, has thrown the village and town of Athens, in Greene County, and much of the surrounding area into controversy and conflict.

title: E. J. McCrossin 3d Will Marry Miss Sheila Wolff in August
description: Miss Sheila Miner Wolff, a teacher at the Montessori International School in Washington, and Edward John McCrossin 3d of New York, who is with the law firm of Miller & McCarthy here, plan to be married in August in Rumson, N. J.

title: East German Flees to West
description: MUNICH, West Germany, April 13 (UPI)A young East German worked his way through barbed wire and mines in the fortified area along the EastWest German frontier to reach safety in the West late last night, the Bavarian border police said today.

title: Met Games This Week
description: TodayPhiladelphia at Shea Stadium, (2), 1:15 P.M. TomorrowOpen date. TuesdayAt Montreal. WednesdayAt Montreal. ThursdayAt Montreal. FridayPittsburgh at Shea Stadium, 2:05 P.M. SaturdayPittsburgh at Shea Stadium, 2:15 P.M.

title: Nontraditional Methods Appear to Be Fading Away
description: Among the many debates during the sixties on education in theory and education as practiced, one of the noisier was on grading. Passfail in particular, and nontraditional grading in general, seemed to be the trend.

title: Susanne West To Wed in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Vincent West of Sands Point, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susanne Tilghman West, to John C. Preneta, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Preneta of Rome, N. Y.

title: Easter Bunny Wasn't Good to Rangers
description: One Bunny is going to have a rough time getting out of bed this Easter morning after the hard night's work he put in on Easter Eve in Madison Square Garden.

title: Now Up to the House
description: The impressive votes in the Senate last week to impose closure in the campaign finance bill debate and then to pass the bill itself are convincing evidence that campaign reform has become a powerful political issue. Across the nation, informed citizens have made it plain to their Senators and Representatives that they expect a cleansing of the oldfashioned, lobbyistdominated, corruptionbreeding system of financing campaigns.

title: Bruins Top Leafs, 63, For 30 Lead
description: TORONTO, April 13 (UPI) Gregg Sheppard scored a pair of second period goals and set up a linemate Johnny Bucyk for another to lead the Boston Bruins to a 63 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: If...?
description: THE GODWHALE. By T. J. Bass. Ballantine, $1.25. Eerie concept of intelligent machines in search of man. Good.

title: A Remedy for Potholes Tested
description: SPARTA  Tests being made on streets here and in Trenton are aimed at curing permanently a seemingly incurable problem: the repair of potholes.

title: The Nation
description: The economic news doesn't always signify what it seems to and it was misleading in two developments last week, one on the top and the other on the bottom of the economic ??

title: CostofLiving Increases Urged in Social Security
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (UPI) Twentyseven lawmakers proposed legislation today to provide special costofliving increases in Social Security for older Americans in areas where living expenses exceed the national average.

title: Ideas & Trends Education Science Agriculture
description: Two Swiss scientists have succeeded in analyzing the chemical structure of a natural sleep factor. When drawn from the blood of one sleeping animal it can induce sleep in another.

title: Cubs Beat Expos, 74, Lose, 133
description: CHICAGO, April 13 (AP)Ron Fairly's fifth grandslam home run ofhis career capped Montreal's eightrun fourth inning to give the Expos 133 victory over the Chicago Cubs and a split of today's National League doubleheader.

title: AROUND THE Garden QUESTIONS
description: Exuberant growth on potted plants  begonias, impatiens, geraniums, coleus, ivy, succulents mike fine cuttings to root now for bedding plants this summer. Use a sterile mixture of perlite and peat moss, keep it moist and the cuttings will root swiftly for planting time outdoors.

title: DOUBLE SLAYING IS STUDIED HERB.
description: The manager of a West Side residential hotel yesterday described two Japanese women who were found slain in a 12thfloor room on Friday night as respectable people with steady jobs who always paid their rent on time and kept their rooms spotless.

title: A Woman in College Point Leads Battle Against Illegal Dumpers
description: Mrs. Joan Vogt's collie, a dedicated watchdog, was killed by poison. A chunk of concrete was thrown through the windshield of her car and another time the car was smashed, while parked. The damage totaled $600.

title: THE WEEK IN REVIEW Sunday, April 14, 1974
description: SAGINAW, Mich. A Republican state party official in Michigan recently said this about the 8th Congressional District election to be held this Tuesday:

title: A Spring Bouquet of Bike Tours In and Around the City
description: YOU believe in vigorous exercise. You enjoy cycling. You applaud the people who point out that bicycles are 28 times as energyefficient as cars, But, you moan, the New York area isn't a congenial place for the bicycle.

title: Zambia Marks Completion Of First Part of Rail Link
description: MWENZO, Zambia, April 13 (Reuters)  A Chinesebuilt train came from Tanzania through a tunnel into Zambia this week, the first to run the completed part of the 1,163mile Great Uhuru Railway.

title: White House to Hold An EggRolling Contest
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP)For the first time since the early days of Easter egg rolling on the White House grounds, there will be a contest for the youngsters eight years and under for the annual Easter Monday event.

title: Jarre A. Barnes, George Betts 3d To Wed June 22
description: Miss Jarre Ann Barnes and George Whitefield Betts 3d, graduates of Eisenhower College in Seneca Falls, N. J., plan to be married June 22 in the First Church of Christ in Bristol, Conn.

title: Veterinarian Will Wed Betsy Buchanan
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Cooper Buchanan of Valley Forge, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betsy Kern Buchanan, to Dr. William Davis Fishback Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Fishback of Versailles, Ky. Mr. Fishback raises horses and tobacco.

title: Strindberg Can't Be Played for Laughs
description: Yet even as I admired what the actor, director A. J. Antoon, and designer Santo Loquasto were doing to make the madness total, I had an Irreverent thought. In theory, Mr. Shaw's hands are held so tightly over his ears to shut out the endlessly reverberating echoes of his quarrels with wife Zoe Caldwell, the sounds of loathing and spite and majestic contempt that have made an unholy clamour of his marriage. I wondered if he might not also be trying to shield himself from the unwanted laughter that had been rippling across the auditorium all night.

title: View on Birth Curbs
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 13 (AP)A black educator says that minority groups will continue to fear that birth control is intended to reduce their population until programs are placed under local community control. The statement was made here by William A. Darity, dean of the school of public health of the University of Massachusetts at Amherst, Mass.

title: I'm Proud to Have Created Kung Fu
description: To THE EDITOR: IN response to Frank Chin's personal and professional attack on me (Kung Fu Is Unfair to Chinese, March 24), having read other of Mr. Chin's critiques, it occurs to me that he appears a malcontent in residence.

title: Great Neck Center to Open
description: GREAT NECKGreat Neck House, this community's newest recreational facility, will open tomorrow in a renovated building at 14 Arrandale Avenue that served as a library for 75 years.

title: Lupo Scores Four, Aeros Lead by 30
description: HOUSTON, April 13 (AP)Houston's center; Larry Lund, scored four goals, two in the first period and two in the third period, to lead the Aeros to a 101 rout of the Winnipeg Jets tonight. The victory gave the Aeros a 30 lead in their World Hockey Association quarterfinal playoffs.

title: Marilyn Feder to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry Feder of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marilyn Ruth Feder, to Frederick A. Margolin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo H. Margolin of New York. Miss Feder is a teacher in the New York City school system, and her fianc is an associate counsel to the public administrator of Kings County and is with the Brooklyn law firm of Hesterberg & Keller.

title: Hastings Keith Fianc of Miss Jackson
description: Miss Frances Bland Jackson and Hastings Keith of Brockton and Marion, Mass., who served as a United States Representative from Massachusetts from 1959 to 1973, plan to be married in late June in Christ Episcopal Church in Washington.

title: CAMPAIGN. SPENDING REPORTED BY CAREY
description: Representative Hugh L. Carey of Brooklyn, a candidate for the 1974 Democratic gubernatorial nomination, said yesterday that he had spent more than $148,000 on his campaign since December, 1973.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: Kennedy Accident

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Critical 3 Years for Grains Is Foreseen
description: WASHINGTON, April 13Dr. Norman E. Borlaug, widely known as the father of the green revolution, believes the world faces a critical period during the next three years.

title: Miss Warnock Plans Nuptials
description: Miss Suzanne Capstick Warnock and Richard Alan Merkt plan to be married Sept. 7.

title: Who's Who, and Why, in Campaign Reform
description: WASHINGTONBig corporate campaign contributors have already pleaded guilty to criminal violations; two for. mar Cabinet officers are now on trial for allegedly mixing money and favoritism; the President and his closest friend may be in serious trouble because of a secret $100,000 cash contribution by billionaire Howad Hughes.

title: Leslie E. Amster Will Be a Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sol Amster of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Leslie Ellen Amster, to Robert Franklin Katzberg son of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Katzberg of Laurelton, Queens.

title: MOST IN U.S. FOUND AT SAME TAX RATE
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 Almost all American families, except for those at the very bottom and the very top of the income scale, pay about the same percentage of their income in taxes, according to new study by two economists at the Brookings Institution.

title: I'm a Yankee Doodle Dainty
description: PHILADELPHIAOn the afternoon of Easter Sunday, 1939, the black contralto Marian Anderson; stood at the marble feet of Abraham Lincoln in America's capital city and sang Schubert, spirituals and My Country Tis of Thee to an audience of 75,000 people.

title: The French Election
description: With almost thirty candidates In the race, France's 28million registered voters would appear to face a confusing choice when they go to the polls May 5 to elect a new president. But the real choice will be which of two leaders of the Government coalition is to represent the centerright forces in the runoff two weeks later against Socialist Franois Mitterand, the candidate of a united left coalition with the Communists.

title: News of the Stage
description: June Havoc is returning to the New York stage next fall, after an eightyear absence, as star of It new comedy, The Lydia Lamont Fan Club Will Please Come to Order. It was written by Arthur Whitney, a former staff writer for the Columbia Broadcasting System and author of last season's play The Divorce of Judy and Jane. Dudley Field Malone is the producer.

title: Sculptor Helps To Give Sparta Cultural Touch
description: SPARTACulture is alive and kicking in this bucolic Sussex County town and its environs, and the person chiefly responsible is Jock Manton, a sculptor who is also executive director of the county's Arts Council.

title: Satellite Launched By Western Union For Communication
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., April 13The nation's first domestic communications satellite was launched into orbit successfully tonight by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration for a private industrial concern.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR: REGARDING Who Says College Kids, Dig Movies? by Vincent Canby (March 24): The problem of why so many college kids keep away from little cinema showings of Fassbinder, Ozu, Rivette, etc., is easily enough answered if you talk to the young who op for The Sting instead of Berrgman.

title: L.I. Population Gains 1.65% in a Year
description: MINEOLA  Long Island's population grew by 1.65 per cent between Jan. 1, 1973 and Jan. 1, 1974 against a national growth rate of 0.7 per cent, according to the Long Island Lighting Company's annual Population Survey released last week.

title: Smith Upset By Fillol in Semifinals
description: ORLANDO, Fla., April 13 (UPI)7Jaime Filial of Chile upset Stan Smith today to mach the final against John Newcombe in a $50,000 World Championship. Tennis Blue group tournament The scores were 64; 36, 6.4.

title: Run Record 3:06.34
An APlus for B and BLodgings in Ireland
description: WE walked out of the airport terminal building and into a cold fog that seems to plaster itself to our faces. Night was coming on and the gray air made the stone of uneasiness within me weigh heavier. This gloom sometimes descends on me when I arrive in a city, for the first time, a mutant kind of homesickness, I suspect. We got into a taxi for the ride into Dublin. The driver, bearded, twentyish, cool, said he'd spent six months hustling a living around Fort Lauderdale. Barbara told him we hoped to tour the west of Ireland and stay at B and B's.

title: Bathers in Florida Are Bitten by Fish In Feeding Frenzy
description: MIAMI BEACH, Fla., April 13 (AP)They were really ripping chunks of flesh out, said Jeff Fuller, a lifeguard who was one of about a dozen bathers slashed and bitten by fish caught up in a feeding frenzy yesterday.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was

title: School Hammer Mark Set
description: NORTH BERGEN, N.J., April 13Gene Mancino of North Bergen broke his New Jersey state hammerthrow record today and Monsignon Farrell High of Staten Island remained unbeaten in major relay competition in the rainmarred West New York scholastic relays at North Hudson Stadium.

title: Nadiari Gets Extra Guards After Threats on His Life
description: Threats on the life of Maurice H. Nadjari, the state's special anticorruption prosecutor, have led to the assignment of extra bodyguards for his protection during the last several weeks, sources close to the prosecutor disclosed yesterday.

title: Criminals At Large
description: First, the Old Masters in paperback this month, and it is only right to start with Rex Stout and his SOME BURIED CAESAR (Pyramid, 95 cents), a reprint from the 1930's and hence from his greatest period. Another Stout, somewhat more recent, is MIGHT AS WELL BE DEAD (Bantam, 95 cents), and that too is well worth having. Then there is Agatha Christie, without whom the paperback book industry would shrivel up and die like a scallop left on the beach too long. If Christie is your dish, look for THEY CAME TO BAGHDAD (Dell, 95 cents) and SECRET ADVERSARY (Bantam, 75 cents).

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: THE embattled American economy emerged from this year's puzzling and traumatic first quarter with more scars than expected as well as some rather surprising accomplishments. The general economy appears to be basically sound at this point, though not yet quite ready to stage that significant rebound the economists have been predicting after its brief period of negative real growth.

title: Paperbacks
description: Mass Market Paperbacks

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I propose that landlords of buildings containing a certain minimum number of apartment units be required to maintain security forces from the hours of 6 P.M. to 6 A.M. The security force should be composed of licensed private police equipped with adequate weapons or attack dogs, scooters or cars, and walkietalkies connected to the local police precinct.

title: Trimming the Military Waistline
description: The debate over the Administration's new $86billion military budget seems to be limited to two polar views those who urge an upturn in defense spending to counter the Soviet Union, and those who oppose the larger budget because they believe that our military arsenal is adequate.

title: Stockton Retains Stroke Lead in Masters
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 13Gary Player, who wears black sports clothes because they give me strength, travels all over the world from his home in South Africa to compete in pro golf tournaments. He also can travel vast distances to catch a leader, as he almost did today in the third round of the Masters.

title: Britain Says to Expect Really Warm Welcome
description: LONDON, April 13 (Reuters)  The Governmentfinanced British Tourist Authority has begun a $500,000 project to counteract concern in the United States over the measures taken by Britain to combat the energy crisis.

title: News of the Screen
description: The directorproducer team of James Ivory and Ismail Merchant, who have fashioned seven features mainly on Indian themes such as the wellreceived Shakespeare Wallah, fare about to start their first Hollywood musical in association with Edgar Lansbury and Joseph Beruh. James Coco will star in the film, titled The Wild Party, which is to go before the cameras entirely on location at the Riverside (Calif.) Mission Inn on April 29.

title: Hofstra Beats Army In Lacrosse, 125
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., April 13  Hofstra University, ranked eighth in the nation, defeated the Army lacrosse team for the first time in 20 years, 125, today.

title: Families of 56 Dead Miners Seek $12Billion in Damages
description: BOISE, Idaho, April 13 (AP) Almost $12billion in damages is sought in a suit filed by the families of 56 miners killed in the Sunshine Mine disaster.

title: Rebirth and Resurrection
description: Now comes the festival of spring, of rebirth, of resurrection, The whole earth celebrates. The religious holiday we call Easter is its spiritual symbol, but even the grass in the meadow and the trees in the woodland participate, even the beasts of the field and the birds of the air. This is the time when the winter of the earth, as we know it, as well as the winter of the soul, yields to the universal urgency of life and more exalted being.

title: A BUDDHIST SECT HOLDS CONVENTION
description: SAN DIEGO, April 13With a parade, a huge fireworks display and an ice extravaganza in the San Diego sports arena, it looked more like a Mardi Gras than a religious convention.

title: For 3 Mothers, a Children's Boutique. Is Like a Child
description: ROSLYNThere's a time for jeans and a time for lace, and the Wild Child, a new Children's boutique here, is for both those times.

title: Braves Hit Homers, Rout Reds
description: ATLANTA, April 13 (AP) Ralph Garr drove in four runs with a double and triple, Dave Johnson hit a threerun homer and Marty Perez and Mike Lum had home runs with the bases empty, powering the Atlanta Braves to a 103 victory over the Cincinnati Reds tonight.

title: DR. WIPRUBEY, 75, GEOIAGIST, IS DEAD
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., April 13 (UPI)Dr. William W. Rubey, a noted geologist, died of cancer yesterday at St. Johns Hospital. His age was 75.

title: Funeral Fee Is $600
description: The New York Public Interest Research Group, whose survey of funeralhome prices was the subject of an article in The New York Times last Sunday, said it had learned that the figure it used for the basic funeral charge, $1,120, at Hirsch & Sons had been given by an unauthorized person not familiar with the actual charges. Principals of the concern reported that the basic charge actually was $600.

title: Concert
description: In recent seasons, the Youths Symphony Orchestra of New York seemed a model student orchestra. It learned and played a wideranging and often difficult repertory with remarkable correctness, precision and style, and it was obvious that the young instrumentalists were being taught to solve the fundamental problems of orchestra work  attack, intonation, phrasing, etc.

title: Humphrey Is Active After XRay Ordeal
description: WASHINGTON, April 14Senator Hubert H. Humphrey has resumed a full schedule of work, travel and speeches after what he calls the most terrible experience of my life.

description: PATERSON  Thomas Rooney Jr. is the first to concede that he has stirred up lot of opposition in the months that he has been Mayor of this sootscarred old textiles town.

title: Jacques Esterel, 56, Is Dead; Couturier Known for Novelty
description: PARIS, April 14 (UPI)Jacques Esterel, the French couturier and musical, composer, died today at the age of 56, from a blood clot in the brain, a spokesman for his fashion house said.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 14 (UPI)Joginder Singh, Kenya Asian driving a Japanesebuilt Colt Lancer, built big lead in the closing stages of the East African Safari rally today, outdistancing his nearest rivals along Kenya's Indian Ocean coastline. With only a few hours of the fiveday rally left, Joginder, winner of the 1964 event, was more than 100 points ahead. Course officials predicted heavy rains and footdeep mud on the final few hundred miles of the course. Only 18 of the original 99 starters were left.

title: City Opening Drive On U.S. Employes Who Evade Taxes
description: As the first move in a crackdown against Federal emnloyes who do not pay their New York City income taxes, the city's Finance Administration has begun to collect from postal workers a potential $1million in back taxes and penalties.

description: HONG KONG, April 14Bits and scraps of evidence from China indicate that the movement against Lin Piao and Confucius is reaching the moment of truth in which it starts to identify live targets for mass criticism. The indications are that the first targets are military commanders in the provinces.

title: Sports Today

title: CONGRESS MAY SEEK BEEF IMPORT CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP)  A new push for curbing mi. ports of foreign beef may soon be undertaken by farm belt members of Congress miffed over an announcement by Canada earlier this week to ban U.S. cattle and beef.

description: MEXICO CITY, April 14The Mediterranean features and blue berets quickly identified them as exiled Spaniards, but their harsh Castilian accents had been softened by their long years in Mexico.

description: BOSTON, April 14Patrick Caddell, the public opinion analyst, rummaged through the papers mounded on his desk and read out some figures.

title: Dent Warns Price Increases Would Lead to New Controls
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (UPI)  Commerce Secretary Frederick B. Dent warned today that if businessmen pushed through a new round of price increases when economic controls expire April 30, they will be virtually asking for pervasive controls, stronger than anything we have ever seen.

title: Whalers Tie Series With Cougars, 33
description: CHICAGO, April 14 (AP)The New England Whalers scored twice in the third period today and defeated the Chicago Cougars, 20, tying their Association playoff series at three games each.

description: Knicks vs. Boston

title: Debts Beset Hospital in Miami That President Called a Model
description: MIAMI, April 14  The Cedars of Lepanon Hospital of Miami, described in February by President Nixon as a model for his privately financed national health insurance plan, is in deep financial trouble.

title: With Costs Rising, Fewer Americans Are Reported Planning Trips Abroad
description: Discouraged by increased air bras, concerned about fuel shortages, deterred by inflation at home and abroad, fewer Americans are planning vacations in Europe this summer.

title: Rangers' Miracle Man Discovered on Bench
description: Who is Ron Harris and why was everyone yelling for him?

title: ARTHUR GARDINER
description: Arthur H. Gardiner, who had been with the office of special education of the New York City Board of Education, died of a heart attack Thursday on a trip to Bermuda. He was 66 years old and lived at 19 East 92d Street and in East Hampton, L.I.

title: Poles Flock to Easter Mass in Barracks
description: WARSAW, April 14  Seeking to induce the Communist Government here to issue more building permits for churches, Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, Roman Catholic Primate of Poland, today celebrated the Mass of the Resurrection in a converted Soviet Army barracks that has been used for the last 20 years as a temporary church.

title: Ford Asserts He Sought Compromise Over Tapes
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., April 14Vice President Ford said today that he sought to work out a compromise last week between the White House and the House Judiciary Committee to avoid a confrontation over tape recordings sought by the impeachment panel.

title: Bridge: Local Organizers seek Help For Summer Nationals Here
description: The world's biggest bridge tournament is three months away. All the omens suggest that the Summer Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League to be played here in midJuly will top the world record of 16,043 tables set last summer in Washington and may reach 18,000 tables. Play will take place simultaneously at the New York Hilton and Americana Hotels.

title: Fund Drive Is Planned To Save Grace Houses
description: The four gothicrevival houses on Fourth Avenue that make up part of the Grace Church grouping received another reprieve from the bulldozer yesterday, as Grace Church officials and preservationists announced an agreement to work together for the first time to raise funds to preserve the structures.

title: Globetrotting Golf Champion Gary Jim Player
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 14Walking up the 17th fairway at the Augusta National Golf Club today, Gary Player turned to his caddie, Eddie McCoy. In all the years I've played here, the Man 37yearold South in the African golfer said I've been News on this green only about six times. But when I won the Masters in 1961, this is where I won the tournament and this year it's going to win it for us again.

title: Redrawing the Lines
description: The cynicism with which politicians and political observers in Albany have received a Justice Department order to redraw a number of legislative districts in Manhattan and Brooklyn is understandable in view of the Legislature's past record in redistricting.

title: West Highland White Scores in Rhode Island
description: CRANSTON, R. I., April 14 A West Highland white terrier, Ch. Braidholme White Tornado, strutted across the floor today and caught the eye of Ray Perso, the judge of the final of the Rhode Island Kennel Club fixture which drew 1,288 dogs. The little dog was named best in the Rhode's ballroom, where Rhode Island belles danced to famous orchestras in the Nineties.

title: Film Stirs Controversy on Carolina Isle
description: DAUFUSKIE ISLAND, S. C., April 14There is a strong sense of pride in the eyes of 84yearold Mrs. Sarah Grant that belies her simple and meager existence. A midwife since 1932, she has delivered more than 100 children on this isolated barrier island in coastal South Carolina.

title: Woman Is Fatally Stabbed Outside a Park in Bronx
description: Five youths attacked two young women walking by a South Bronx park Saturday might, fatally stabbing one and beating the other severely, the police reported.

title: ULSTER MOB KILLS A BRITISH CAPTAIN
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 14 (UPI)A Catholic mob in Londonderry today shot and killed a British captain in civilian clothes who had been assigned to watch their Easter march. A Protestant youth died of wounds received in a clash with the police last night.
