description: SAGINAW, Mich., April 13President Nixon's first campaign venture of 1974a motorcade through the sparsely populated, monotonous farmlands of Michigan's Eighth Congressional Districthad ended only a few hours before.

title: TV Review
description: Thursday's Game, last night's Sunday movie on the American Broadcasting Company network, had its faults, primarily in an unevenness of tone and an overindulgence of certain gag routines. But it also happened to be unusually perceptive, marvelously acted and very funny. When a critic, sitting alone in a network screening room, finds himself laughing aloud with some frequency, you'd better believe its funny.

title: 60Day Extension Is Given Nixon on 1973 Tax Return
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., April 14 (UPI)The Internal Revenue Service has given Presidents Nixon a normal 60day extension in filing his 1973 income tax return because of his backtax bill of almost halfamillion dollars, the White House said today.

title: 3 Killed hi Bremen Blast
description: BREMEN, West Germany, April 14 (AP)Three workers were killed and a fourth was injured yesterday when a steam boiler exploded at the Kloeckner Foundry here, a company official said today.

title: The Dance: Getting to Know the Harkness Theater
description: Getting to know a new theater is rather like to know a ship on its maiden voyage. The first night out might tell you something  especially about the quality of the champagne and the garishness of the fittings, but it is only when you are well out to sea that you learn about the menu, the heat of the cabins and, occasionally, that the name on the lifebelt is S. S. Titanic.

title: Rhythm and Spirit Of Cecilia Valdes Warm Latin Show
description: When a community decides to celebrate itself, criticism become irrelevant. The production put on by the Alliance of Latin Arts yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall clearly gave a good deal of pleasure to the assembled audience, mostly of Latin background.

title: SISTER ROYCE DEAD; LAWYER, TEACHER
description: CINCINNATI, April 14 (AP)  Sister Frances Catherine Royce, who for 26 years in secular life had been a lawyer for the Michigan Legislature, died Friday. She was 74 years old.

title: Strike on Bourse Moves Gold Trading Into Street
description: PARIS, April 14The strike that has closed the Paris Bourse, the second largest exchange in Europe after London, has moved gold into a lively street market, nicknamed the market of wet feet.

title: Celtics Take 10 Lead on 11388 Triumph
description: BOSTON, April 14With their renowned keen attention to detail, the Knicks plumbed the depths of failure today. Not content to merely lose, they improvised a brilliant parody of their customary skills while the Boston Celtics were zipping to a 11388 victory before a national television audience and a surprised crowd of 14,101 at Boston Garden.

title: FORD AND G.M. SET TRUCK OVERTIME
description: DETROIT, April 14Truck sales have long been considered a better barometer of economic health than car salesand some truckmanufacturing plants are working overtime this month as the auto industry strives to pull out of the sales slump caused by the energy crisis.

title: New England Voltage Rise
description: BOSTON, April 14 (AP)With the Arab oil embargo over and conservation efforts faltering, New England utilities return their voltage to full power tomorrow after a winter cut back to save fuel. A 5 per cent voltage cut was ordered between 5 and 9 P.M. each day beginning last Nov. 27.

title: Music: Shirley Verrett
description: Since Shirley Verrett has reached that point in her career where everything seems to be coming up great and glorious  the voice, the opera productions, the adulation, the feesit is scarcely surprising that the recital she sang Saturday night at Hunter College Assembly Hall was bigger than life from start to finish.

title: Cornfeld, Out of Swiss Jail, Is Chipper
description: LONDON, April 12Bernard Cornfeld, heavily bearded and chipper after 11 months in a Geneva prison, tilts back in a tattered but elegant armchair, smiles benignly at the two shapely young women draped around his shoulders and says, This is the smallest of my houses.

title: Kirk Douglas and Crew Roam Town
description: High on a rocky hill in Central Park, Kirk Douglas embraced Deborah Raffin, patted her back and then stood, aside while a makeup man applied a tearmaking solution to her eyes. Miss Raffin, cast as Mr. Douglas's daughter, unleashed her pain and revulsion concerning his marriage to a rich woman. He retorted, Marriages made in Marbella have a better chance than marriages made in heaven. In the teeth of her reproaches, Mr. Douglas remained affable and ironic.

title: Bruins Beat Leafs, 43; Win Series
description: TORONTO, April 14 (AP) Ken Hodge's second goal of the game, at 1 minute 21 seconds of a suddendeath overtime, gave the Boston Bruins a 43 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight and a 40 sweep of their National Hockey League quarterfinal Stanley Cup series.

title: TONY AWARDS PARTY IS SALUTE TO STAGE
description: Sardi's resounded last night with rollicking Broadway show tunes as a couple of hundred supporters of the American Theater Wing, including an array of show business stars past and present, gathered to salute the awarding of the annual Tony awards and to raise money for the Wing's public service activities.

title: Guild Strike at Washington Post Is in 2d Week, With Outlook Dim
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 An unusual strike by members of the Newspaper Guild against The Washington Post, one of two major daily papers in the nation's capital, enters its second week tomorrow with no agreement in sight.

title: In 'Love and Anarchy,' Lust Excels:The Cast
description: Despite her Germanic name, Lina Wertmuller is one of Italy's rare distaff director-writers, a biological distinction that has no bearing on the fact that "Love and Anarchy" is a solidly professional work. Her anti-Fascist drama about an abortive attempt on Mussolini's life in the nineteen-thirties, which opened at the Little Carnegie yesterday, is a mite closer to love and lust than to anarchy. However, it is passionate and stirring in its hatred of oppression and its love of the indomitable battlers against tyranny.Miss Wertmuller obviously is stressing that some of the anonymous masses did a good deal of the fighting and dying against dictatorship by concentrating on such disparate principal plotters as a confused, timorous country bumpkin and a pair of prostitutes in one of Rome's poshest bagnios.But her vignettes grow in tension and meaning as she develops an awareness of the time, the place and her driven people in a succession of vigorous, coarse and violent scenes. Tunin, her callow hero, is simply a freckled, bearded young farmer, who has come to this bordello on vague instructions from an anarchist friend who has been murdered by Fascists. Salome, the blonde, outspoken queen of the establishment and his mentor, isit turns outa dedicated revolutionary who joined the oldest profession after her anarchist lover was slain.Of course, there are comlications. Our hero and Tripolina, another of Madame Aida's girls, fall in love. And, Spatoletti, one of Mussolini's rough enforcers who bears a surprising resemblance to Il Duce and is a regular patron of the "maison," also is on hand to mess up the plan. However, Miss Wertmuller and Giuseppe Rotunno, her cinematographer, manage to give these bare outlines substance and color that underline the irony and tragedy of unrequited sacrifice.Perhaps there is more here for the voyeur than the historian. But the scenes inside the bordello that are reminiscent of Toulouse-Lautrec, as well as having explicit, four-letter dialogue, are vividly multidimensional. The physical aspects of Rome, its streets, squares, monuments and the green countryside also evoke the period and the the effects of the dictatorship.As Salome, Mariangela Melato wears her blond, Jean Harlow coiffure to the manner born. But above all, she is an inflexible patriot who projects idealism as grossly and fervently as she purveys her charms. Giancarlo Giannini's portrayal of Tunin is a shaded stint ranging from the shy peasanta tender, love-smitten swain to the man driven to a fatally violent act in a cause he has failed. Lina Polito is pitiably real as the pretty, anguished, brunette Tripolina, whose unwittingly selfish love helps push him toward self-destruction. And, Eros Pagni is properly vicious as the bullying Spatoletti."Love and Anarchy" may be slightly biased in its view of Fascist Italy, but Miss Wertmuller has illustrated it with enough power and style to make it memorable and often moving.

Byrne of New Jersey has available a readymade answer to the disturbing recommendation of his principal environmental adviser that he approve the longproposed Tocks Island Dam on the Delaware. He need only repeat what he said in his election campaign last fall: New Jersey should not approve the project unless serious unanswered questions concerning transportation, pollution, development and economy of the area are resolved. They have not been.

title: Screen: 'Lovin' Molly':Texas Farm Woman Not True to Type
description: "Molly always stood where you left her, as long as she could see you," says Gid, one of the three narrators of "Lovin' Molly," which opened yesterday at the 68th Street Theater. That's the sort of thing you or I might say about a well-trained, apartment-bound Labrador retriever, one that wags its tail at the sight of a leash and stays the proper distance when told to heel.But Gid is not talking about a brain-washed dog. He's talking about Molly Taylor (Blythe Dannner), the independent, headstrong Texas farm woman who, in the course of the 40 years covered by "Lovin' Molly," is so overflowing with love she can give herself equally to Gid (Anthony Perkins), an uptight farmer, and Gid's best friend Johnny (Beau Bridges), a footloose cowboy, without anyone feeling even a mite peeved or jealous.Molly is one of those great, life-affirming fictional characters that you may or may not be able to believe. I can't, any more than I can believe most of this movie. I'm not sure whether it's because of the performances, the direction by Sidney Lumet, a born-and-bred city fellow, or some of the nonsense the characters have been given to say in Stephen Friedman's screenplay, adapted from Larry McMurtry's novel "Leaving Cheyenne."Much, I suspect, has to do with the screenplay, which comes across just as rural phony as the apostrophe in the new title. Molly, sitting on her porch at evening, is likely to reminisce about her various lovers: "My menfolk began rising with the moon."This is definitely not meant to be funny. A kind of patronizing poetry has been imposed upon her. In an earlier scene she has been so overwhelmed by the miracle of birth that she has kissed a new-born calf, after-birth and allexactly the sort of gesture that would make any real-life, no-nonsense farm woman roar with unkind laughter.There also seems to be a real problem in the film's continuity. Inportant motivations have either been left on the cutting room floor or perhaps they were never shot. This puts a further burden on the credibility of the three leading performers, who also must overcome some of the worst make-up ever seen in a first-class movie.As Beau Bridges gets older, his eyebrows simply become thicker until, as an old man, they look like Groucho Marx's. As Blythe Danner ages, she turns increasingly pale and appears to chop off her gray hair with sheep shears. Anthony Perkins, who doesn't look like the young man in his early 20's he is supposed to be at the beginning, returns to his "Friendly Persuasion" mannerisms. He acts mostly with his jawbone as the young Gid, then ages in the stiff-faced manner of a person who's had too many facelifts.Undermining the film, however, is a more important fault of San Andreas dimensions: Who loves whom and why? Mnages  trois are difficult propositions, in fiction as well as life, unless you can believe in the heightened sensitivities of the participants. Truffaut managed it successfully in "Jules and Jim" through a soaring lyricism of style and by having the extraordinary Jeanne Moreau at the mysterious center.Miss Danner is attractive in short takes but lacks the dynamism that could have given the film a focal point. It is so literally staged and acted that one begins to question the true psychological relationship between the two men. Is Molly important to each of them as herself or as a kind of sexual surrogate for the other? The Molly of the novel possesses a splendid self-assurance and a will to self-determination that the movie talks about but never successfully demonstrates.The backgrounds of "Lovin' Molly," which was filmed entirely in Texas, look right. In the foreground, however, are all those city-folk-actors playing make-believe.

title: Jersey Poll Shows Estimate of Nixon Continues to Decline
description: President Nixon's standing with New Jersey voters is still falling, according to a poll released yesterday by the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University.

title: Thai Army Officers Freed
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 14 (AP)The Thai Government today released all army officers imprisoned two years ago by the Government of Thanom Kittikachorn on charges of corrupt army recruiting. Premier Sanya Dharmasakti has pledged to abolish all tyrannical decrees of the ousted leader.

title: Profits of Oil Companies Up 71% Over Last Year
description: The 1973 worldwide profits of a representative group of 30 petroleum companies increased 71 per cent over the previous year, a Chase Manhattan Bank study shows.

title: Death of God Theologian Now Sees Hope in Easter
description: One of the three principal theologians identified with the death of God movement a decade ago preached an Easter sermon at St. Clement's Episcopal Church yesterday that he said represented a change in hig thinking.

title: BRIDGE IS REPAIRED AFTER BARGE CRASH
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S. C., April 14Highway access to this offshore resort island was provided this weekend for the first time in more than two weeks as automobile traffic rolled across the James F. Byrnes Bridge.

title: Colonels' Coach Lauds Nets on Eve of Battle
description: Babe McCarthy of the Kentucky Colonels was either being sincere or giving a lesson from the kill em with compliments school of coaching when he poured lavish praise on the New York Nets after their 119106 victory over the Colonels in the first game of the American Basketball Association Eastern Division final playoffs Saturday night.

title: Humphrey Is Active After XRay Ordeal
description: WASHINGTON, April 14Senator Hubert H. Humphrey has resumed a full schedule of work, travel and speeches after what he calls the most terrible experience of my life.

title: White Merchants in South Sue Civil Rights Activists in Effort to End Shopping Boycotts by Blacks
description: PORT GIBSON, Miss.Eight years ago, when the rights to vote and to sit at any lunch counter were still volatile issues in Mississippi, disgruntled local Negroes turned to a tactic already tried with notable success by their black brothers and sisters elsewhere across the South.

title: ISRAEL AND SYRIA BATTLE FIERCELY ATOP MT. HERMON
description: JERUSALEM, April 14Israeli and Syrian forces fought their heaviest engagement since the October war early this morning atop strategically vital Mount Hermon.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: BOOKISH There is theater for lunch, music for lunch, food for Lunch and, now, the Brooklyn Public Library and the Brooklyn Y.W.C.A. have come up with hooks for lunchtime. On two Mondays a month, through June, you can go to the Y's Memorial Hall, 30 Third Avenue, at Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn (8751190) and digest an author and other caloric items at the noon break.

title: Books of The Times
description: SCARS ON THE SOUL. By Francoise Sagan. Translated from the French by Joanna Kilmartin. 141 pages. McGrawHill. $6.95.

title: JON D. LEARY, 62, CHRYSLER EXECUTIVE
description: John D. Leary, who retired in 1971 as vice president in charge of administration for the Chrysler Corporation, died Saturday in Phoenix, Ariz., where he lived. His age was 62.

title: Art History Colleagues Honor Millard Meiss
description: A reticent man who likes his privacy, Millard Meiss, professor of the history of art at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N. J., has been hit with a wave of public plaudits.

title: Global Interdependence
description: In his opening address to the special session of the United Nations General Assembly, Secretary General Waldheim dealt persuasively with issues whose urgency has unfortunately been overshadowed by divisive international politics. Many of Mr. Waldheim's arguments in support of a rational approach to the production and consumption of the world's resources deserve a sympathetic response from Washington when Secretary of State Kissinger speaks to the Assembly today.

title: Kissinger Gives Proposal Of Syria to Israeli Envoy
description: Secretary of State Kissinger handed over to the Israeli Ambassador yesterday the latest Syrian plan for troop separation in the Golan. Heights and then flew from Washington to New York to hold his first extensive meeting with a senior Chinese official in five months. He is to address the United Nations General Assembly today.

title: Bronx Man Killed in Crash
description: MADISON TOWNSHIP, N.J., April 14 (AP)David Schwarzmann, 44 years old, of the Bronx, was killed today when his car went over an embankment into a cement culvert on the Garden State Parkway here. The police said Mr. Schwarzmann had been alone in the northbound car.

title: PREMIER OF FRANCE URGED TO JOIN RACE
description: PARIS, April 14Four conservative Gaullist cabinet members issued a new appeal today for a single candidate, Premier Pierre Messmer, to face the sole contender from the left for the presidency of France.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Our nation, if not our world, seems poised on the edge of disaster. We have despoiled our forests and streams, and even the air we breathe. Through reckless waste and bloated consumption we are suddenly short of oil, short of energy and out of gas, spiritually as well as physically.

title: MINEREMOVAL AID OUTLINED FOR SUEZ
description: CAIRO, April 14  American operations to sweep the Suez Canal of mines will begin before the end of the month aria last six to eight weeks, said the man in charge, Rear Adm. Brian McCauley, today.

title: ISRAEL AND SYRIA BATTLE FIERCELY ATOP MT. HERMON
description: JERUSALEM, April 14Israeli and Syrian forces fought their heaviest engagement since the October war early this morning atop strategically vital Mount Hermon.

title: About New York And Now the Din Is Done
description: East 72d Street is one of the wider cross streets of Manhattan, and consequently it has manhole covers that spout steam and a plague of potholes on it, too. On the block between First and Second Avenues, there is one excessively deep pothole, which the city thoughtfully has covered with a steel plate.

title: Westar Opens Drive to Cut U.S. Communication Costs
description: The launching of Westar 1, the first United States domestic communications satellite, signals a fierce commercial competition in the next few years that could drastically reduce the cost of private voice circuits and longdistance transmission of television programs and computer data.

title: Pope Paul, in Easter Message, Condemns Pursuit of Pleasure
description: ROME, April 14Pope Paul VI, in an austere Easter message, to the world today, statssed what he called the gospel of the Cross, the law of duty, of service, of sorrow, of love, of sacrifice.

title: Goodman Panel to Weigh Reform Ideas at Retreat
description: The state commission that is figuring out how to rearrange New York City's government will go into retreat the first weekend in May to try to pull out all the pieces, according to its chairman, State Senator. Roy M Goodman. The pices that are likely to emerge are somewhat surprising.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Pro Transactions
description: FOOTBALL

title: Dense Fog Causes Snags at Kennedy; Jet Flights Diverted
description: More than 50 flights arriving with thousands of domestic and international travelers had to be diverted from fogbound Kennedy International Airport last night to other local airports and sites as far away as Boston and Bangor, Me.

title: Greeks Gain East Final In Soccer
description: They cracked red Easter eggs and banged blackandwhite soccer balls et Metropolitan Oval in Queens yesterday. It was not determined who won the egg  cracking competition, but the New York Greek Americans left no doubt about the soccer game as they defeated New Britain of Connecticut, 41.

title: Langdon Favors a Rate Rise
description: The new president of the Penn Central Railroad has a. formula to keep the bankrupt line's freight and passenger trains rollingan acrosstheboard freightrate increase of 10 per cent by May 2 and restoration of plant and equipment at Government expense.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, APRIL 15, 1974

title: Major League Baseball
description: Monday, April 15, 1974

title: ROBBER ESCAPES U.S. PRISON HERE
description: A 28yearold convicted bank robber, charged with setting bomb in a Union Square bank last fall in which 10 persons were injured, escaped last night from the Federal House of Detention at 427 West Street in lower Manhattan.

title: Tocks Squatters Back to Plant Seed
description: SHAWNEE, Pa., April 14Dozens of former squatters, their friends and families returned to the Delaware River Valley today for the first time since being evicted by Federal marshals nearly two months ago.

title: Wounded U.S. Aide Improves
description: CORDOBA, Argentina, April 14 (AP)Alfred. A. Laun, the 36yearold head of the United States Information Service in Crdoba, who was kidnapped, shot and abandoned by a Marxist terrorist group on Friday, was reported today in serious but slowly improving condition.

title: THOMAS MUNRO, 77, ART SCHOLAR, DIES
description: Dr. Thomas Munro, a leading art scholar and esthetician, died yesterday In Sarasota, Fla., where he had lived after his academic retirement in 1967. His age was 77.

title: FlowerDecked Cow Leads Animal Parade in Los Angeles for Easter Blessing
description: LOS ANGELES, April 14There is a saying here that Los Angeles, the city of the angels, should be referred to as the city of the cows.

title: Kuwait Studied as Key to Arab Oil Policy
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 11A final settlement of Kuwait's bid to acquire majority control of its largest foreignowned oil company is regarded by all Persian Gulf producers as the key to ownership and prices for crude oil in the region.

title: Sports Playoffs
description: The New York Rangers defeated the Montreal Canadiens, 6.4, yesterday at Madison Square Garden and tied their fourofsevengame National Hockey League playoff series at two apiece. The East Division semifinal resumes tomorrow in Montreal.

title: DUCHESS OF AOSTA
description: FLORENCE, Italy, April 14 (AP)Duchess Irene of Aosta, daughter of the late King Constantine I of Greece, died after a long illness today at her villa in Fiesole, her family announced. She was 70 years old.

title: Yankees Blast 9 Home Runs in Split With Indians
description: CLEVELAND, April 15Could they possibly be called the Queens Bombers?

title: Garrido Upset At Eastern Net
description: Hubert Hoyt, an unseeded 18yearold from Newburgh, N.Y., upset secondseeded Rey Garrido, 26, 64, 76, to reach the quarterfinals of the Eastern men's indoor tennis championship here yesterday.

title: Navy Torpedo Mine Hunts Down Subs
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 The Navy has developed a novel torpedo mine that it hopes will help win any battle for control of the Atlantic by sealing off the Russian submarine fleet at the Norwegian Sea.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 15, 1974

title: Selina Strong, Dr. Blumenfeld Wed in Tucson
description: Miss Selina Clark Strong, daughter of Harold Clark Strong Jr. of New York and of Mrs. John Wood Brooks of Bedford Hills, N.Y., was married in Tucson, Ariz., yesterday afternoon to Dr. Ronald Blumenfeld, a resident in the department of pediatrics at University Hospital, the University of Arizona Medical Center.

title: INACTION FEARED FOR TRADE BILL
description: WASHINGTON, April 14There is a distinct possibility that Congress will not enact the sweeping new trade bill this year despite fairly widespread support for it after more than a year's work on it by the Admiistration and Congress.

title: Banking Group to Expand
description: PARIS, April 14 (Reuters)The Midland Bank of Britain, the Amsterdam  Rotterdam Bank, the CreditanstaltBankverein, and the Belgian Bank, Ste Generale de Banque, are to join the economic interest grouping Finerg, which was formed in November by Credit Suisse, Ste Generale, S.A., and Banque de Paris et des Pays Bas to finance nuclear and oil projects.

title: VIETNAM ATTACK SEEN AS INFLATED
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 14  The Saigon command apparently exaggerated the scope of a Communist attack Thursday night and early Friday morning on an encircled ranger outpost near the Cambodian border, according to in formation provided by informed sources today.

title: The Politics of Art
description: As a visitor enters New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art, the first object confronting him is a statue of the mythical Perseus, sword in hand, triumphantly holding out the severed head of Medusa.

title: Red Smith
description: Saturday night the Rangers were so bad the clients reviled John Halligan, the public relations director, and the climate had not improved noticeably yesterday when the teams, returned to Madison Square Garden for the fourth match of the playoff series. The first two games had been split with the Canadiens in Montreal, but then the action moved south of the border where, as the saying goes, the Rangers smelled on ice. Home ice. It was high time, a man on the radio was saying, that New York had a team that would make an honest effort to give the customers their money's worth. He implied that there was something basically wrong with an organization whose team, though strong on paper, went 34 years without laying a hand on the Stanley Cup.

title: 6 MAGAZINE AWARDS POSTED BY COLUMBIA
description: Six National Magazine Awards for 1974, including two to The New Yorker, were announced yesterday by Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism. It is the first year a magazine has won two of the awards since they were established in 1965.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Clifford L. Giddings, a 31yearold convict who escaped from an armed guard at his brother's funeral Asbury Park, turned himself in yesterday. Mr. Giddings was serving two to three years at Leesburg State Prison for receiving stolen goods.

title: Plainfied Police Seek Closer Community Ties
description: Each community has to decide what it wants, said Patrick B. McColgan, Plainfield's chief of police, and we can enforce it. In Las Vegas, gambling and prostitution are wide open because that's what people want, but it's not what we want here. Chief McColgan, a contemplative, nononsense official, was speaking during a panel discussion last week for the heads of women's groups, parentteacher associations and others on crimes against women.

title: REBEL ATTACKS KILL EIGHT IN CAMBODIA
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, April 14 (UPI)  Communist forces fired 17 rockets into Phnom Penh yesterday and today and raided a New Year gathering, killing at least eight people and wounding 87 others in the worst such attacks in two months.

title: M'GOVERN TO PUSH TAX REFORM PLAT
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) With many Americans still scurrying to meet the income tax deadline tomorrow, Senator George McGovern said today he would renew the fight to cut the future burden for most and still pump another $20billion into Federal revenues.

title: BROOKLYN JUDGE UNDER SCRUTINY
description: The office of Brooklyn District Attorney Eugene Gold investigating charges that State Supreme Court justice helped perpetrate an election fraud by signing blank tour orders allowing voters whose registration had been challenged to cast their ballots in a primary election in 1972, it was learned last night.

title: U.S. OPENS DOORS TO MORE CUBANS
description: MADRID, April 13  The United States has widened its doors to Cubans and they are pouring through at a record rate after years of waiting in the Spanish capital.

title: Cowens LetterPerfect, He Destroys Knicks
description: BOSTON, April 14D has become synonymous with defense in basketball, but today at the Boston Garden it had a different meaningthe destruction of four Knick centers.

title: Patrolmen's Association Honors Photographers
description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association yesterday named Chris Borgen of WCBSNews as the winners of two of its 1974 P.B.A. awards for photography and reporting.

title: Call His Agent
description: Give Sophocles the plot: the doomed royal house, The lying courtiers bared, the addertape Writhing its hissing way through files and courts, Charge and rebuttal. Let hint cast old men, Fat faces set in power, small mouths shut; Young men long groomed for the heroic roles They dreamed of, worked for, failed. Oh Sophocles, What better tale of a curse that spread its stain Far, far across a land, seeping in minds Doubting or drifting or long since corrupt With private lusts! Great Gods, the plot is there, The crowds, the amphitheatre, the despairing cry For catharsis! On whatever terms, sophocleswrite!

title: Interest Levels Climbing With Prime Rate at 10%
description: Throughout the interestrate spectrum  short, intermediate and long termlevels not seen since 1970 are dotting the charts and graphs, and furrowing the brows of some market participants. For example, doubleA  rated utility bonds were yielding 9 per cent on an index basis at the end of last week, or 10 basis points above the level for the previous week.

title: HEARST NOW SEES A BRAINWASHING
description: LA PAZ, Mexico, April 14 (AP)Randolph A. Hearst now believes that his daughter Patricia has been brainwashed by her kidnappers and says that if he were starting hit dealings now with the abductors he would approach then differently to try to avoid a long captivity.

title: Nixon Supporter Used Password to Kiss Him
description: DETROIT, April 14 (UPI) Mrs. Robert Zako of Detroit managed to kiss President Nixon during his campaign swing through Michigan last week by murmuring M.C.S.P. 227 to one of his advance men.

title: Layer Tops Gisbert in Tokyo Final
description: TOKYO, April 14 (AP) Rod Laver of Australia overcame a heavy wind and beat Juan Gisbert of Spain, 5.7, 62, 60, for the $10,000 first prize in the World Championship Tennis Green group tournament today.

title: SRI LANKA ADVISED TO TAKE OVER BANKS
description: COLOMBO, Sri LankaThe nationalization of all banks has been recommended by a special committee appointed by Prime Minister Sirimavo Bandaranaike to review the Government's Common Program.

title: Good Start in Steel
description: The success of the United Steelworkers of America and the major steel producers in negotiating a new wage agreement on their own represents an encouraging start for their joint venture into substituting reason for tests of strength in collective bargaining.

title: Hailu and the Very Old Lion
description: BRIDGETOWN, Barbados  Some years ago in the distant African kingdom of Ethiopia, there lived in the capital city, Addis Ababa, a very strong man named Hailu. Hailu was on the very bottom of the social ladder in a land known for its depths of poverty and human misery. But he was powerful and proud.

title: To Brooklyn Democratic Party Belong the Power and the Spoils
description: I've got nephews I haven't seen in 14 years and now they're coming out of the woodwork, growled Meade H. Esposito as he explained his busier schedule dealing with job supplicants now that a longtime Brooklyn Democratic district captain, Abraham D. Beame, has been elected mayor.

title: City Opening Drive On U.S. Employes Who Evade Taxes
description: As the first move in a crackdown against Federal employes who do not pay their New York City income taxes, the city's Finance Administration has begun to collect from postal workers a potential $1million in back taxes and penalties.

title: Westar Opens Drive to Cut U.S. Communication Costs
description: The launching of Westar 1, the first United States domestic communications satellite, signals a fierce commercial competition in the next few years that could drastically reduce the cost of private voice circuits and longdistance transmission of television programs and computer data.

title: New York Is Found Safest Of 13 Cities in Crime Study
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 New Yorkers were the victims of violent crime considerably less frequently than the residents of Chicago, Detroit, Los Anielesi Philadelphia and eight other selected smaller cities during 1972.

title: Kurds Cut Off Second Iraqi Stronghold
description: KURDISH HEADQUARTERS, Iraq, April 13Kurdish rebel forces fired at Iraqi helicopters airlifting reinforcements into beleagured 3,000man garrison near this headquarters in Northern Iraq and immediately imposed a total blockade on the garrison's supplies, Kurdish commanders said today.

title: CAFFERY FUNERAL IS SET FOR TODAY
description: LAFAYETTE, La., April 14 (UPI)A funeral service was scheduled tomorrow for Jefferson Caffery, former dean of the United States diplomatic corps and the first Ambassador to newly liberated France after World War II. Mr. Caffery, 87 years old, died yesterday following a long illness.

title: Soviets Fly to U.S.
description: MOSCOW, April 14 (Reuters)Four Soviet astronauts left here today for Houston to continue preparation for next year's joint United StatesSoviet manned space mission. United States personnel connected with the program are expected to come to the Soviet Union in July for training.

title: MRS. ANNA MEANEY
description: Mrs. Anna E. Stewart Meaney, widow of Brig. Gen. Martin H. Meaney, a retired deputy police commissioner here, died Saturday at her home, 1224 East 32d Street, Brooklyn.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 33

title: Paul Schoenstein, Newsman, 71, Who Won Pulitzer Prize, Dead
description: Paul Schoenstein, a Pulitzer Prizewinning newspaperman and the nearly legendary last managing editor of The New York JournalAmerican, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 85 East End Avenue and in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Volleyball Endurance Record Broken at Matawan
description: MATAWAN, April 14By score of 8,284 to 8,275, the Netterboppers defeated the Streakers at 3 P.M. today in the final minutes of a 192hour volleyball game at Matawan Regional High School.

title: Controversy on Rutgers Appears Near Showdown
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, April 14 The simmering dispute between Ralph A. Dungan, the state's Chancellor of Higher. Education, and Dr. Edward J. Bloustein, Rutgers University president, over autonomy for the university appears headed for a showdownwith Governor Byrne playing a pivotal role.

title: ISRAEL PICKS GM AS CHIEF OF STAFF
description: TEL AVIV, April 14  The Israeli Cabinet today selected Maj. Gen. Mordechai Gur to succeed Lieut. Gen. David Elazar, as Israeli Chief of Staff.

title: Sports Playoffs
description: The New York Rangers defeated the Montreal Canadiens, 64, yesterday at Madison Square Garden and tied their fourofsevengame National Hockey League playoff series at two apiece, The East Division semifinal resumes tomorrow in Montreal.

title: Libya's Premier Denies Qaddafi Has Been Stripped of Powers
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 14Premier Abdel Salam Jalloud of Libya was said today to have described as lies and malicious propaganda reports that Col. Muammar elQaddafi, the country's leader, had been stripped of his powers.

title: Student Aid Impasse
description: Skyrocketing college costs are threatening to reverse a centuryold trend toward equitable access to higher education. Inflation increasingly jeopardizes the educational opportunities of children from poor and even from middleclass families. As soaring tuition charges price the private colleges out of reach, public institutions are under severe pressure to narrow the gap in the competition for students by jacking up their fees as well. Such a course sharpens the divisiveness between the private and the public sector as it worsens inflation and shuts out more students.

title: M'Gregor Nets Deciding Goal in 64 Victory
description: The team that scored four goals didn't win yesterday. By putting six pucks past Michel (Bunny) Larocque, the Rangers were able to outscore the Montreal Canadiens, 64, and even their playoff series at two games apiece.

title: New York Is Found Safest Of 13 Cities in Crime Study
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 New Yorkers were the victims of violent crime considerably less frequently than the residents of Chicago, Detroit, Los Angeles, Philadelphia and eight other selected smaller cities during 1972.

title: Shultz Tells of Attempt To Quit Post Last Year
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (UPI)The outgoing Treasury Secretary, George P. Shultz, tried to resign a year ago when President Nixon instituted a second round of price freezes, according to a newspaper report today.

title: Cuts That C.I.A. Sought in Book Touch on Official Slips
description: The C.I.A. tried to censor from a forthcoming book about the agency slips of the tongue by the then Vice President Agnew and the then C.I.A. chief, Richard M. Helms, that seemed to betray ignorance of foreign affairs, a New York publisher has disclosed.

title: Connecticut Rite Shows Change Religion Faces
description: WILTON, Conn., April 14 The 370 members of the Wilton Presbyterian Church here celebrated Easter today in much the same way they always do, with joy and awe at the miracle of Christ's resurrection.

title: Soviet Starts Work on an Arctic Mine To Produce Metals in Platinum Group
description: The Soviet Union has started work on an Arctic mine that is expected to become the world's largest producer of platinum.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: New Jersey Sports
description: CRANFORD, April 14It isn't often that a firstyear team plays for a state championship; but, thanks to Carol Blazejowski, that's just what the Cranford High School girls' basketball team did this winter.

title: Personal Finance: Seizure of Property
description: The Government's right to demand immediate payment of back taxes and then to seize property to collect them is under serious scrutiny in the wake of opposing court rulings that may yet send the issue to the Supreme Court for final determination.

title: Soviet Hails Yugoslavia's Conservatism
description: MOSCOW, April 14In a major press commentary, the Soviet Union has expressed its first substantial public approval of the political and economic trends toward Communist orthodoxy in Yugoslavia.

title: Advertising: Analyst Sees Gains
description: While he's not exactly jumping up and down with enthusiasm, Andrew J. Melnick, a securities analyst interested in publicly held agencies, isn't all gloom and doom either.

title: U.S. AND SAUDIS SIGN ACCORD ON WEAPONS
description: AMMAN, Jordan, April 14 (UPI)Saudi Arabia and the United States have signed an agreement for the development and modernization of the Saudi Arabian national guard, the Riyadh radio, monitored here, said today.

title: COL. JOHN L. WILKIN
description: Col. John L. Wilkin, a retired Army officer and educator, died Saturday at his home in Sturbridge, Mass. He was 65 years Fold.

title: Weekly List of Mutual Funds
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: WILLIAM CADDOO
description: William H. Caddoo, who retired in 1970 as vice president of the Continental Can Company and general manager of its division making boxboard, paperboard and craft paper, died Friday at his home on Forest Hill Road in Darien, Conn. He was 65 years old.

title: Americans, Hit by High Cost of Gas and Recalling shortage, Rely Less on Autos
description: DETROIT, April 14  The great gasoline shortage has abated in most of the country, but its effects on the nation remain, and life for millions of people may never be the same again.

title: Profits Up Sharply At Cook Industries On Grain Exports
description: MEMPHIS, April 14 (AP) Cook Industries, Inc., a diversified company, which ranks third in American grain sales, reported last week that net profits for the nine months ended Feb. 28 were more than $39million, more than a threefold increase from the yearearlier period.

title: Kuh and Judge Dispute An Incident of Assault
description: The Manhattan District Attorney and a State Supreme Court justice in. Manhattan clashed yesterday over the conduct of another judge who failed to report an assault he had witnessed near his courthouse.

title: A.B.A. Playoffs
description: Nets vs. Kentucky

title: Project Gives Remnant of Lonely Jews on Lower East Side New Motivation
description: Resting his weight on two wooden canes, 78yearold Fredric Hein shuffled over to a kitchen cabinet in the small Lower East Side apartment that he shares with his 80yearold sister, Selma, and pulled out a large piece of paper folded in quarters.

title: Kissinger Gives Proposal Of Syria to Israeli Envoy
description: Secretary of State Kissinger handed over to the Israeli Ambassador yesterday the latest Syrian plan for troop separation in the Golan Heights and then flew from Washington to New York to hold his first extensive meeting with a senior Chinese official in five months. He is to address the United Nations General Assembly today.

title: Northern Lights Is Show Winner
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 14Mrs. J. C. Penny's Northern Lights won both classes over fences to score 10 points and captured the local working hunter championship today at the Boulder Brook horse show.

title: Wounded U.S. Aide Gains
description: CORDOBA, Argentina, April 15 (AP)Doctors declared Alfred Latin III, chief of the United States Information Service, out of danger today, more than 72 hours after Marxist guerrialas shot him in the stomach, kidnapped him and abandoned him.

title: UTILITY CONFIDENT ON POWER SUPPLY
description: NEWARK, April 15  The Public Service Electric and Gas Company foresees no problem in meeting our customers' peak [electric] demands this summer, Edward R. Eberle, the chairman, told 600 stockholders at the annual meeting in the Robert Treat Hotel here today.

title: Birth, Fertility Rates At a New Low in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 Birth and fertility rates in the United. States dropped to their lowest points in history last year, according to a summary report by the National Center for Health Statistics.

title: BRITISH PREPARED TO DROP CONCORDE
description: LONDON, April 15The British Government is moving toward canceling two major prestige projectsthe supersonic Concorde airliner and third London airport.

title: Syria and Israel Are Firm; Kissinger Is Still Hopeful
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 15Syrik and Israel remain far apart in their proposals for separating their forces in the Golan Heights, but wellplaced diplomats said today that Secretary of State Kissinger believes he can narrow the gap on his coming Middle East trip.

title: This Space for Doodling
description: Dear Editor:

title: 4 San Franciscans Suing On Pacific Gas Contract
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 15Four residents of San Francisco filed suit in United States District Court here today alleging that the city's contract Iwith the Pacific Gas and Electric Company for power distribution violated a 1913 Federal law.

title: Viruet Steps In, Wins
description: Edwin Viruet, substituting for his brother, Adolfo, on short notice, scored, a unanimous 10round decision over Felix Morales last night in a juniorwelterweight bout at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum. Viruet weighed 135 pounds, Morales, 140.

title: Syrian Challenge
description: Syria is confronting Israel with a major military threat and a difficult political challenge.

title: Excerpis From Secretary Kissinger's Address to the Special U.N. Assembly
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 15Following are excerpts from the address to the General Assembly today by Secretary of State Kissinger. The text was made available by the United States Mission to the United Nations.

title: Junk Collector Found Dead
description: A junk collector, Daniel J. Hannon, was found dead yesterday by four boys in a garage where he apparently lived behind 15014 88th Street, Jamaica, Queens, the police reported. An autopsy was scheduled to determine the cause of death, which occurred about a week ago, the police speculated.

title: ST. CLAIR CONTROL OF CASE DOUBTED
description: WASHINGTON, April 15James D. St. Clair, special counsel to President Nixon for Watergate matters, was pictured today by a former member of his staff as an attorney not in complete control of his case.

title: F.B.I. Hunts Escaped Bank Bomber
description: A nationwide manhunt began yesterday for a man who, convicted of bombing a savings bank, wriggled out of the Federal House of Detention here Sunday night by sawing a 9by9inch gap in an air vent.

title: NEWSPAPER TALKS OFF INDEFINITELY
description: Contract, talks between the printers and the city's three major daily newspapers were recessed indefinitely yesterday after the two sides reached a new impasse.

title: How to Become a Tennis Pro on $475
description: COLUMBIA, Md., April 15 It was an odd bunch of tennis nuts: a selfstarting tennis instructor from Manhattan, the ski instructor from Grossinger's, an insurance claims adjustor from. Hartford looking for a new life, a South American Davis Cup coach, a Marine Corps captain from Philadelphia.

title: Refunds to Holders Asked Of Steinbrenner by S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 The Securities and Exchange Commission charged the American Ship Building Company today with making illegal political contributions and asked a Federal court here to require George M. Steinbrenner 3d, its chairman, to reimburse stockholders by more than $120,000.

title: LOUIS J. HOLLANDER
description: Louis J. Hollander, who retired in 1953 from A. Hollander & Son, Inc., fur dyers of Newark, after 36 years and became an independent fur consultant, died last Tuesday in Berlin while on a business trip. His age was 76 and he lived in East Orange, N. J.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Democrats Sue by the Numbers

title: KISSINGER, AT U.N., TELLS POOR LANDS TO AVOID THREATS
description: IJNITED NATIONS, N..Y., April 15Secretary of State Kissinger pledged today that the United States would mike. a major effort to assist developing countries, but he cautioned them against any use of the politics of pressure and threats.

title: Store Chain Acquired
description: DAC Stores, Inc., has acquired the 19unit Gus Mayer Stores, Inc., whose shares previously were held by Warnaco, Inc. No price was disclosed for the stores, which are mostly in the South and Southwest.

title: Martha Graham Back With Chants
description: Even Martha Graham probably forgets whether life began at 40 for heralmost certainly long before, and it has been beginning at what one hopes have been convenient intervals ever since. It seems to have begun again. Last night she brought her dance company to the Mark Hellinger Theater for the opening of its threeweek spring season.

title: TV: Shanker Portrait on Bill Moyers' Journal
description: Tonight, from 8 to 9 o'clock, public television's Bill Moyers' Journal presents a portrait of Albert Shanker, the 45yearold president of New York's United Federation of Teachers, the largest local union in the country, and the youngest member of the executive council of the A.F.L.C.I.O. The labor leader is powerful, and Mr. Moyers examines the sources, uses and possible future expansions of that power.

title: Feud on Utility's Energy Ads Goes to White House
description: A battle reaching to the White House is raging between the Council on Environmental Quality and the American. Electric Power Company over its energy crisis advertising.

title: Nixon Reported Owing No '73 California Tax
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 15 (AP)  President Nixon, filing his, first California income tax return in a decade, owed no state taxes for 1972, Dean Butler, his tax lawyer, said today. Mr. Butler said he planned to mail the return late today against a midnight deadline.

title: Storm Around Prosecutor Fails to Dampen Inquiries
description: When Edward J. Boyd 5th was appointed chief of the criminal division of the Unitec States Attorney's office foi the Eastern District of New York in the summer of 1971, he said he was a lawandorder man who had decided to become a prosecutor after spending a summer working in the office of Nassau County District Attorney William Calm.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Wilson Aides Deny Agreement on Bonds
description: ALBANY, April 15  Aides to Governor Wilson today denied the assertion of New Jersey Democratic leaders that he had been party to an agreement with Governor Byrne to seek repeal of bond covenants that prevent a broader masstransit role for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: BUENOS AIRES
description: (In Aroonline Pesos)

title: Canton Trade Fair Opens In New Exhibition Center
description: CANTON, China, April 15 (Reuters)  The Canton Trade Fair opened in a huge new glassaidconcrete exhibition center today with a barrage of firecragqkers, slogans and revolutiondry songs to welcome foreign buyers.

title: Trash Pickups After 3 Are Suspended by City
description: Evening and nighttime collection of garbage has been suspended for the duration of the warm weather, the city's Sanitation Department announced yesterday.

title: Wilson Offers Election Bill With Oahinet Enforcement
description: ALBANY, April 15  Governor Wilson submitted his own campaign reform proposal this evening. It differs basically from the measure already passed by the Assembly in that its enforcement would be placed in the hands of one of the Governor's cabinet officers, the Secretary of State.

title: Profit Record at Cyanamid
description: The American Cyanamid Company, a diversified producer of chemicals, pharmaceuticals and construction products, reported yesterday that its firstquarter results were the best ever for any threemonth period.

title: J. C. Penney and T. Eaton Plan Canada Retail Study
description: The J. C. Penney Company and the T. Eaton Company, Ltd., Canada's largest generalmerchandise retailer, have announced a joint study of retailing opportunities in Canada. Their objective is an eventual joint retailing effort in that country.

title: Fix Witness Ties Drivers To Gerry
description: A Government witness testified yesterday he was told that Forest Gerry Jr., the alleged mastermind of a ring to fix superfecta races, had bribed such drivers as Del. Insko, Carmine Abattiello, and Ben Webster.

title: Mitchell Admits Calling Casey on Vesco's Behalf
description: John N. Mitchell testified yesterday that while he was Attorney Gerieral he willingly contacted the chairrnan of a Federal agency in behalf of a man that agency was investigating. He said, however, that this had not been improper.

title: Dave Anderson.
description: AUGUST, Ga., Apri1,15As Gary Player was winning the Masters on a TV screen Jest night, Jack Nicklaus watched and, probably was winning the Masters next year. Not far away, on the big scoreboard at the Augusta National Golf Club, the numbers alongside Nicklaus's name were in red, denoting under par. The hackles on his neck also were in red. He had lost by three strokes. He usually is a gracious loser, but last night he Was an angry loser. Angry at himself. In his frustration, perhaps without realizing it, he had permitted people to look inside his head at his ego and his obsession. With a champion of his stature, ego isn't a flaw, it's an attribute. All the great ones have it. They all have an obsession, too. With him, it's winning golf's grand slam of the Masters, the United States Open, the British Open, and the, Professional Golfers' Association tournament in the same year. He tries to minimize that obsession. But last night it was obylous. Because now he can't do it this year.

title: 3 Wanted Women Have Links to S.L.A.

The coalfired units are to be built at a site north of Macon, Ga., near the Ocmulgee River. They are scheduled for delivery in December, 1978, and one year later.

title: LONGTIME LEADER DEPOSED IN NIGER

Rear Adm. Joseph C. Wylie, retired, president of the U.S.S. Constitution Museum Foundation, said that $1million would carry us through the Bicentennial.

title: People and Business
description: Robert A. Slater, a former president of both the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company and I.O.S., Ltd., will be taking early retirement this summer as chairman and chief operating officer of the National Liberty Corporationan insurance holding company. The company said that Mr. Slater, who is 57 years old, is leaving for reasons of health which are expected to clear up with an extended period of rest. No successor has been designated yet.

Earlier this year the Audio Media Corporation, which sells commercial time in instore audio systems was mentioned in this space. Now along comes InStore Television, which is going to install video surveillance systems that will also show TV commercials. Show and tell!

description: ATLANTA, April 15 (AP)Phil Niekro, a knuckleballer, baffled the San Diego Padres on four hits tonight and struck out 13 in leading the Atlanta Braves, to a 60 National League triumph.

description: The Supreme Court refused yesterday to review a lower court decision that upheld President Nixon's bombing of Cambodia without approval of Congress. Page 10.

The agreement in principle, proclaimed jointly, did not specify how many shares were involved, and a Kellogg spokesman said the details of the exchange were being wonted out by the two companies.

title: New Times Square...
description: Times Square is the traditional heart of New York. Its magnetism continues to work in spite of sordid decay. But unless the Beame administration mounts an immediate attack on the problems it has inheritedpotholes, pornography, prostitution and physical deteriorationthe few springlike signs of regeneration are doomed. The beginnings of new construction and renovation, the economic health of the theater district, the continued vitality of the area as an entertainment center for crosssection of New York and the world, hang on an effective action program.

description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (UPI)The Agriculture Department announced today a proposal to quadruple the pricesupport loan fees paid by tobacco growers.

title: ... and Old New Orleans
description: A few cities are national treasures. New Orleans is city that has known the arts of living for three centuries, and those arts, from gustatory to political, have produced a rich culture and a striking heritage. Visitors, lulled by the sanctity of the protected French Quarter, think that heritage is safe. They could not be more wrong. Frohi the Quarter's narrow streets one can watch the bulldozers in the business district demolishing blocks of buildings of equal style and value. One out of every five structures that stood in this area in 1970 is gone; parking lots prevail.

title: ISMAEL TAYLORKAMARA

title: Blast Hits Israeli Bus
description: JERUSALEM, April 15 (Reuters)An explosive device was set off tonight in a bus en route from the center of the city to the Hadassah Hospital on the city outskirts, slightly injuring a passenger. The explosion took place on the corner of Maimon Street, several yards from Premier.Golda Meir's residence. The police said she was not home at the time. Several suspects were detained.

title: Koch Says Nixon Made Trade To Block Bill Saving 35c Fare
description: Representative Edward I. Koch asserted yesterday that the Nixon Administration had made a $60million grant for highway construction in February to the home district of the House Rules Committee chairman, Ray J. Madden, so that Mr. Madden would block legislation that would help save the 35cent fare here.

title: HOSPITALS PUSHING LOSSSHARING BILL
description: Voluntary hospitals in the state, saying they expect a deficit of $60million this year in their emergencyroom and outpatient departments, have started a drive for passage of a bill in Albany that would require Blue Cross, and possibly Medicaid, to pay a prorated share of the losses.

title: A Man Of the Old South
description: From a vacation house at Newport, Arthur Krock once wrote that a shore from which the ocean stretches unbroken to an unseen landfall in the other hemisphere is perhaps the place where a vacationing Washington observer of the ways of Government is most likely to keep them, however unwillingly, in mind. For, like the ocean as seen from such a shore, only their surface changes. In the depths, there is no change.

title: YALE PROTESTERS SILENCE SHOCKLEY
description: NEW HAVEN, April 15  A chanting, stomping, handclapping demonstration at Yale University tonight by about 150 members of an audience of 400 prevented William B. Shockley, professor of physics at Stanford University, from debating his theories on the hereditary basis of intelligence.

title: Police Head Pleased By City's Standing In U.S. Crime Study
description: Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd of New York said yesterday he was very gratified with the results of a Federal study showing that the city had the lowest crime rate of 13 large cities surveyed. He also said the most significant finding of the report, published Sunday, was that in most of those cities the actual number of crimes was two to three times higher than that reported to the police by the victims.

title: Anniversaries
description: ABRAMSLoret. My darling sweetheart. Our seventh brings us closer to my promise of togetherness for fifty years. Your loving husband, Hy and our darling children, Rose, Mitchel and Melissa.

title: Dodd Is Acting Governor
description: TRENTON, April 15 (UPI)The President of the State Senate, Frank J. Dodd, Democrat of Essex, was sworn in today as Acting Governor. He will be Acting Governor for the next seven days, during the absence of Governor Byrne, who is vacationing in Arizona before attending the Democratic Governors Conference in Chicago next Monday.

title: Ted & Mary & Archie & Fido
description: I see that a lot of people are going bisexual this year. This seems to be different from going homosexual, Which was last year, in that the homosexuals weren't going, actually. Usually they were coming out, whereas the bisexuals appear to be going in, as in going into shock or going into town. I myself am going merely to the Cape, a duller distance; I seem never to be in the right place at the right time.

title: COVICTIONS OF 2 UPHELD ON NOTES
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) The Supreme Court refused today to review the convictions of two Ohio men charged with the sale of unregistered securities in a scheme that netted $11million.

title: Chess:
description: At the famous New York International Tournament of 1927, the haughty. Capablanca went up to the tournament referee during his game with Nimzovich to complain aboutof all things his opponent's weak play. The great Cuban, having run away with the first prize three rounds before the finish, had announced generously that he would concede his remaining opponents' draws. However, Nimzovich's bad moves were proving a source of embarrassment: a few more of them and Capaplanca would be morally obliged to win and thus renege on his promise.

title: Gas Station Owner Fined
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., April 15 (AP) Richard A. Burr, a Springfield gasoline station owner, was fined $4,000 and ordered to roll back prices today in a court appearance brought on complaints that he had charged service fees for pumping gas.

title: PAINE, WERBER POSTS PROFIT FOR QUARTER
description: Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis, Inc., reported net earnings yesterday for the second fiscal quarter ended March 30 of $648,000, in contrast to a loss of $507,000 a year earlier.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX DECLINE SHARPLY
description: After showing a gain at the opening, stocks on the American Stock Exchange closed sharply lower yesterday in light but slightly increased trading. Prices also fell in the overthecounter market.

title: Court Bars War Appeal
description: The Supreme Court refused yesterday to review a lower court decision that upheld President Nixon's bombing of Cambodia without approval of Congress. Page 10.

title: Will Real Knicks Be in Action Against Celtics Here Tonight?
description: The Knicks will be out to prove tonight it wasn't the real Knicks who lost Sunday to the Boston Celtics. The real Knicks couldn't be that bad, they reason. But in case they thought the Easter Sunday massacre Boston was a bad dream, they learned otherwise at yesterday's workout at Pace College.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Toros Win by 41, Advance in Playoff
description: TORONTO, April 15 (AP) The Toronto Toros, led by Tom Simpson's two firstperiod goals, gained the World Hockey Association semifinal playoffs tonight with a 41 victory over the Cleveland Crusaders.

title: Steel and Union Accept Job Equality
description: WASHINGTON, April 15Nine Major steel companies and the steel workers accepted today what was hailed as the the most sweeping program to end job discrimination in the history of American industry.

description: The Consolidated Edison Company and the Committee for an Adequate Supply of Energy, an organization of 55 labor and business groups formed in 1972, presented energy saver awards to 11, of the utility's commercial customers yesterday for outstanding energy conservation, The recipients  whose usage was cut by an average of 23.8 per cent in January, February and March, compared with the same period last year  were listed, with savings, as follows:

title: BankAmerica Margin Cut
description: Three of the nation's leading banking concerns  including the BankAmerica Corporation, the world's largest privately owned banking concern  reported yesterday higher profits for the first quarter.

title: Film: Blues Like Showers of Rain
description: A marvelously indigenous short movie combining photographs of underprigileged Negro life in the Depressionera Deep South, reminiscences by blues singea end blues songs is the highlight of the new program at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

title: WARNER BUYS RIGHTS TO NEW MAILER BOOK
description: Norman Mailer has sold the film rights to an unfinished novel tracing a family from ancient times to the future to Warner Bros for a minimum of $250,000.

title: Birth, Fertility Rates At a New Low in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 Birth and fertility rates in the United States dropped to their lowest points in history last year, according to a summary report by the National Center for Health Statistics.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: G & S Gilbert and Sullivan are having something of a record week here with five productions, a fantastic run even for these hard perennials, Here's the rundown on the mass revival: At 8 tonight, the Gilbert and Sullivan Society convenes to do a concert version of Iolanthe, and bring your own scores to singalong, even for the solos. At Steinway Hall, 111 West 57th Street, Admission is free; information: 8775747.

title: For Many, Amnesty Is Still a Fighting Word
description: WASHINGTON. April 15 A Baptist minister from Florida said, These men should be tried as they are captured and then executed for their traitorous actions.

title: ENVOY ACCUSES ANTIWAR CLERIC
description: Graham A. Martin, the United States Ambassador to South Vietnam, has accused the president of the New York Theological Seminary of implicit responsibility for the deaths of 32 South Vietnamese children and the wounding of 50 in a mortar attack last month.

title: Patricia Hearst Placed at Bank Robbery
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 15The Federal Bureau of Investigation said tonight that Patricia Hearst participated in a bank robbery here this morning, but it strongly indicated that she may have been acting under duress.

title: Paris Juan Gris Retrospective Upsets Accepted Image
description: PARISAlthough Guillaume Apollinaire called him the integral cubist, Juan Gris is still far less known and pop ular than his colleagues Picasso and Braque, or evendelaunay and Lger. Thus the remarkable retrospective currently at the Muse de Lorangerie is the first held in France, and the first major Gris exhibition anywhere since the Museum of Modern Art show in 1958. Its immediate effect will be to upset the artist's accepted image, which he himself did his utmost to establish: that of the man who made Pierre Reverdy's definition of cubism as A methodical adventure come true by transforming the empirical adventure of Picasso and Braque into a rigorous method. Menne he assertedand, we might add, Picasso or Braque as wellturned a bottle into a cylinder; I, on the other hand, start from the cylinder... to make a bottle. Thus a picture, according to the onetime engineering student, is a problem solved by what he called pictorial mathematics, Whereas Picasso and Braque still relied on instinct, for Girs, to paint is to plan.

title: BUCKLEY ASSAILS RACE DECREE HERE
description: Senator James L. Buckley joined aroused white residents of the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn yesterday in assailng a recent sweeping Federal court order to encourage racial balance at Mark Twain Junior High School by increasing the number of white students.

title: Estep Bows in S. Africa Nett Upset
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 15 (UPI)Mike Estep of Dallas was knocked out of the $50,000 Clows tennis tournament in the first round today by John Yuill, an unheralded South African, 46, 61, 62. The tournament is part of the World Chainpionship Tennis Red group circuit.

title: Recital
description: Throughoutt her astonishing career, Maria Callas has attracted two invaluable types of admirers: first, dismally unmusical people who can't tell how precarious her vocal state has been for most of the last 20 years, and second, highly musical listeners who know, but don't believe it really matters.

title: Kurds Say Iraqi MIG's Attacked Troops
description: The following dispatch was written from behind Kurdish lines in Iraq by Gwynne Roberts, a former Reuters correspondent who is now a freelance reporter.

title: Danger to Education
description: The news about education today is largely confined to questions of money. The high cost to the taxpayer, skyrocketing college tuition, university budget deficits and fundraising campaigns, dominate the greatly reduced attention that education commands in the newsand in public discussion. Questions of substance and content, of ideas and goals, of experimentation and reforms are not being raised.

title: Boys Town Has an Embarrassment of Riches
description: BOYS TOWN, Neb.,Somehow, 36 years ago, when Spencer Tracy and Mickey, Rooney were running the place, it did not seem likely that the biggest problem at Boys Town would ever be an embarrassment of riches.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: 2 FAMILIES' HOMES RUINED BY TORNADO
description: LEBANON TOWNSHIP, April 15 (AP)  Two families were homeless today following tornado that swirled through this Hunterdon County community last night, heavily damaging their homes.

title: Pro Transactions HOCKEY
description: PHILADELPHIA (N.H.L.)Recatled Larry Goodenough, defenseman; Michel ?? meur, goalie, and Alen MacAdam and Serge L??unesse, wings, from Richmond of American Hockey Lemma.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP)The Treasury Department has imposed a ban against melting or exporting copper pennies in an attempt to head off hoarding and destruction of pennies for their copper content. Any person convicted of melting or exporting pennies will be subject to a maximum penalty of $10,000 and five years in prison, the Treasury Department said today.

title: Tennis Roundup: Laver Servos Notice He's Set
description: Rod Layer sent chills down the spines. Of his rivals as he continued his comeback surge over the weekend; Me Nastase played like a gentlemanand lost, Chris Evert taught Evonne Goolagong another lesson in daycourt dynamics and John combe clinched a berth in the World, Championship Tennis finals in Dallas May 8.

title: Bridge: A Game That Got Away Makes an Expert Brood
LONGTIME LEADER DEPOSED IN NIGER
description: BAMAKO, Mali, April 15 The army of Niger, one of the West African countries hardest hit by drought and famine, seized power today and announced in a broadcast that it had acted because of the nation's catastrophic situation.

title: HEALTH DEPARTMENT CITES 16 FOOD PLACES
description: Sixteen more food stores, restaurants and other establishments in the city have been cited by the Health Department for uncorrected HealthCode violations found on a second inspection.

title: Mitchell Admits Call on Vesco's Behalf
description: John N. Mitchell testified yesterday that while he was Attorney General he willingly contacted the chairman of a Federal agency in behalf of man that agency was investigating. He said, however, that this had not been improper.

title: At 21, She Keeps Ulysses Going
description: Alisa Jill Adler arrived at the Winter Garden 45 minutes before curtain time, walked directly to her sieuldup desk at stage right in the wings, checked her headset, two electronic signal boxes and oversead TV monitor and opened the large cue book through which she would signal the more than 250 separate lighting, sound, staging, music and specialeffects cues required in Ulysses in Nighttown.

title: 18 of 21 Counties Comply On Juveniles' Detention
description: TRENTON, April 15  Officials of the State Department of Institutions and Agencies reported here today that juvenile authorities in 18 of New Jersey's 21 counties had begun the first change in the system of housing noncriminal juvenile. offenders in 53 years.

title: MRS. JAMES W. RILEY
description: GREENWICH, Conn., April 15  Mrs. Eugenie Ward Root Riley, widow of Col. James Wilson Riley, who had been a partner of the New York brokerage firm of Vilas and Hickey and president of the Southern Society of New York, died today at her home here. She was 84 years old.

title: SAIGON SUSPENDS TALKS IN PRANCE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 16The South Vietnamese Government announced today that it had suspended its participation in the political talks with the Vietcong at La Celle St. Cloud outside Paris because of what it termed steppedup Communist violations of the ceasefire.

title: Brezhnev Leaves For Warsaw Talk With Eastern Bloc
description: MOSCOW, April 15Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet party leader, journeyed to Poland today for an important East European meeting that is expected to press for an EastWest summit gathering in Helsinki soon to conclude the European security conference.

title: BIG BOARD LOSES BID ON 40% RATE
description: WASHINGTON, April 15The Securities and Exchange Commission rejected today a New York Stock Exchange proposal to make brokermanagers of large institutional investor laccounts ineligible to receive the 40 per cent nonmember commission discount on such transactions.

title: Marsh of U.S. Sets Pace in World Trot
description: BERLIN, April 15 (AP)Joe Marsh of the United States won three of five races today and took the lead after the first round of the Harness Tracks of America world driving championship.

title: James McCaffrey Dead at 74; Covered City Politics for Times
description: James P. McCaffrey, who retired in 1964 as a reporter for The New York Times, died yesterday in South County Hospital in Wakefield, R. I. He was 74 years old and had been living in Narragansett, R. I.

title: First Quarter Revenue Up
Tennis Roundup: Laver Serves Notice He's Set
description: Rod Laver sent chills down the spines of his rivals as he continued his comeback surge over the weekend; Ilie Nastase played like a gentle manand lost; Chris Evert taught Evonne Goolagong an other lesson in clay court dynamics and John Newcombe clinched a berth in the World Championship Tennis finals in Dallas May 8.

title: Robbed of Life Savings
description: PHILADAPHIA April 15 (AP)A 75yearold man was robbed of his life savings here over the weekend, $6,750 that he was carrying to pay for his and his wife's funerals. The police identified the man as Alexander Tkattheff, a retired real estate, salesman. The police said three men attacked him and took his money. Mr. Tkatcheff received hospital treatment for cut and bruises and was released.

title: Industrial Output Down 0.5% in March; Drop Smallest of Any in 4Month Slide
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 Industrial production declined further in March, but the dip was the smallest since the current downward slide began last December, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Van Berg Extends Racing Success to Local Tracks
description: Jack Van Berg demonstrated yesterday that he had found the winning rhythm for successful New York thoroughbred racing. The nationally known trainer from Columbus, Neb. tried local racing last year and was far from successful. This season, though he has been making regular trips to the winner's circle. He saddled three winners, yesterday as well as a runnerup in six races.

title: SLAYING SUSPECT ESCAPES BRIEFLY
description: A 16yearold suspect in a robbery and a murder escaped last night from a police station in the BedfordStylvesant sec tion of Brooklyn by climbing through a station window and jumping 30 feet to the sidewalk below, apparently, seriously injuring himself, the police reported.

title: Thousands Demonstrate at City Hall To Ask Retention of Expiring O.E.O.
description: Thousands of employees and supporters of antipoverty programs here marched and held a rally yesterday to demand Federal, state and city support for Congressional action to extend the life of the Office Economic Opportunity beyond its June 30 deadline.

title: Oliver Quayle 3d Dies at 52; PublicOpinion Poll Specialist
description: Oliver A. Quale 3d, the publicopinion poll specialist and board chairman of Quayle, Plesser & Co., died of a heart attack Sunday at the Mary Hitchcock Memorial Hospital in Hanover, N.H. He was 52 years old and had lived here in semiretirement for the last year.

title: Stage: The Sea Horse
description: James Irwin's The Sea Horse, a tender, wistful play about two outwardly abrasive characters, opened last night Off Broadway at the Westside Theater after a limited engagement at the Off Off Broadway Circle Repertory Theater Company.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, April 15The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended April 9.

title: Market Place: Decline Is Seen In Steel Profit
description: After several days of reading news stories about the steel industry, securities analysts are assessing the impact on steelcompany earnings of two developmentsone recent and the other imminent.

title: Shubert's Grants To Drama Schools Tied to Paint Deal
description: An annual grant from the Shubert Foundation to the Yale School of Drama was cut from $30,000 to $10,000 this year after Irving Goldman, Shubert's president and owner of a paint company, complained that Yale was not buying paint from his company, according to the dean and an instructor at the school.

title: Once They Were Simply Old Crates
description: Practically the whole apartment, it was explained, had been decorated with old crates.

title: People in Sports
description: It appears that revenge for a Flames' defeat, and not money, was the reason behind the weekend mugging in Atlanta of Fred Shero, the Philadelphia Flyers' coach.

title: City Widens TaxEvasion Drive To 2 More Federal Departments
description: The city broadened its drive yesterday against Federal employes who have not paid their city income taxes to cover Defense Department and General Services Administration employes working here.

title: Vinyl Chloride Found to Cause Rare Cancer of Liver in Mice
description: An industrysponsored study of vinyl chloride has indicated that when mice are exposed to the amount, of the chemical that workers are currently permitted to inhale, the animals develop a rare fatal cancer of the liver that has been found in 12 vinyl chloride workers.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Production of Steel Shows Drop of 0.3% For the Latest Week
description: Production of steel last week totaled 2,904,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This was a decline of 0.3 per, cent from the 2,914,000 tons poured the week before, and caused the production index to drop to 119.0, from 119.4 during the week ended April 6.

title: President Rejects $47,000 In Gifts to Pay Tax Debt
description: MIAMI, April 15President Nixon has received more than $47,000 in unsolicited cash and pledges to help him pay his back income taxes, but he has decided to pay every penny himself, the White House said today.

title: COTTON FUTURES CLIMB BY LIMIT
description: Floodsoaked cottonfields in Mississippi were a factor in forcing the futures price up the limit in most contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange. July, an active month, closed at 66.55 cents a pound, up the 2centapound limit.

title: President Rejects $47,000 In Gifts to Pay Tax Debt
description: MIAMI, April 15President Nixon has received more than $47,000 in unsolicited cash and Pledges to help him pay his back income taxes, but he has decided, to pay every penny. himself, the White House said today.

title: TALLEY INDUSTRIES SETTLES 2 LAWSUITS
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., April 15 (AP)  Talley Industries Inc., has reached outofcourt settleMents in a $75million classaction lawsuit and another filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission, the company announced today.

title: Greeve and Turkey in a Dispute on Oil
description: ATHENS, April 15Western embassies here are worried that the dispute between Greece and Turkey over the potentially rich oil deposits in the Aegean Sea could weaken the Atlantic Alliance's defenses in the eastern Mediterranean and even infect the Middle East situation.

title: Newspaper Talks: Clash of Compuisions
description: A collision of union and management compulsions is complicating efforts to end the yearold contract impasse between New York City's three daily newspapers and their 2,000 unionized printers.

title: Park Police Officers Take a Turn at Birdwatching
Newspaper Talks: Clash of Compulsions
