description: A collision of union and management compulsions is complicating efforts to end the yearold contract impasse between New York City's three daily newspapers and their 2,000 unionized printers.

title: Liquor Board Nominee Michael Roth
description: ALBANY, April 15Today, as Westchester County voters have been hearing and reading for weeks, was to have been the day that Michael Roth formally announced whether he would run for the seat in Congress held now by by Representative Ogden R. Reid.

title: Resources for Mankind
description: Secretary of State Kissinger's stress at the United Nations on the interdependence of developed and developing nations points the way to progress on excruciating resource problems now facing mankind.

title: NELSON L BOND, 70, OF M'GRAWHILL UNIT
description: Nelson Leighton Bond, former president and director of the publications division of McGrawHill, Inc., died Friday at his home in Orleans, Mass. He was 70 years old.

title: Syria Reports Success in Bombarding Israeli Units on Mt. Hermon
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, April 15 (Reuters)  Syria and Israel today kept up their artillery and tank duel on snowcapped Mount Hermon, with the Syrians claiming to have inflicted heavy losses.

title: Rangers and Canadiens Staging Tightest Series
description: Hockey fans can thank New York and Montreal for making at least one of the quarterfinal Stanley Cup series close. The Boston Bruins wiped out the Toronto Maple Leafs in four straight, the Philadelphia Flyers did the same to the Atlanta Flames and the Chicago Black Hawks took three in a row before the Los Angeles Kings staged an uprising Sunday night by winning, 51.

title: Passaic Capitol Theater: Concerts + Convenience
description: PASSAICThis is so convenient, it's unbelievable, said Bob Delcalzo of Hasbrouck Heights as he, walked into the Capitol Theater here on a recent Friday evening to hear a concert by Melanie. There are more acts to choose from in New York. And if it's a good act, you don't care where it isyou go see it. But this is only 10 minutes from where I live.

title: All Hallows First In Distance Relay
description: Gene McCarthy ran his anchor onemile leg in 4 minutes 15.1 seconds yesterday to lead All Hallows to victory in the distance medley relay in the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association New York Diocese Relay Carnival at the Mount St. Michael track in the Bronx.

title: Notes on People
description: Carl Bernstein and Bob Woodward, The Washington Post investigative reporters, have sold paperback rights of their book about Watergate, All the President's Men, for $1million. Their share in the sale is about half the full, amount, with their hardcover publisher, Simon and Shuster, receiving an equal share.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Police Auction Produces Bargains Some Good and Some Bad
description: In a gray, cavernous garage on Broome Street yesterday, some of the bestand, decidedly, worstbargains in town could be had at auction.

title: SAIGON SAYS A POLE ASKS FOR ASYLUM
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, April 17 (AP)The Smith Vietnamese Government said today that a member of the Polish delegation to the International Commission of Control and Supervision had asked for asylum in South Vietnam.

title: PENTAGON ERROR WILL AID SAIGON
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 The Pentagon has found an accounting error, that will allow it to provide $266million extra for military aid to South Vietnam in the fiscal year ending June 30, and this granting of aid has been approved by key committees in both houses of Congress.

title: YALE WEIGHS ACTION IN SHOCKLEY JEERING
description: NEW HAVEN, April 16Officials of Yale University are studying possible disciplinary action against some 150 students who took part in a noisy demonstration last night that prevented William B. Shockley, professor of physics at Stanford University, from debating his controversial theories on the hereditary basis of intelligence.

title: Lists Are Closed in Paris For Presidential Election
description: PARIS, Wednesday, April 17 The French Constitutional Council closed its candidate lists, for the presidency at midnight.

title: CITY'S FOOD BILL SHOWS 5,6% DROP
description: The city government's biweekly foodpurchase bill has gone down 5.6 per cent for the April 15to28 period, reversing a preEaster increase and contrary to the city's earlier gloomier expectations.

title: Court Clears Way for Rule On Strikers' Jobless Pay
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 The, Supreme Court cleared the way today for resolution of a long and heated national controversy over whether striking workers should be eligible for Welfare benefits.

title: Where Women Go to Find JudaismAnd Themselves
description: ST. PAUL  Friday at sundown. The Sabbath comes in cold and clear during early spring in Minnesota. In the warm shelter of the Chabad House, the young women greet it with flickering Shabbes candles set on glistening white tablecloths.

title: American Airlines Will Put Six 747's Back in in June
description: American Airlines announced yesterday that six of the seven Boeing 747 jumbo, jets it put in mothballs in the midst of the fuel emergency early this year would be back in the air June 15.

title: BUTZ SAID TO ASSURE TANAKA ON EXPORTS
description: TOKYO, April 16 (Reuters)Secretary of Agriculture Earl Butz assured today Japan's Premier, Kakuei Tanaka, that the United States would not restrict exports of wheat, soybeans or raw cotton this year, Japanese sources said.

title: State Dept. Voices Its Full Confidence In Envoy to Saigon
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (UPI)The State Department expressed its full confidence today in Graham A. Martin, the Ambassador to South Vietnam.

title: Armed Forces' Problem: Finding Good Volunteers
description: The United States volunteer forces, nine months after the end of the draft, are in a period of transition marked by manifold problems and some encouraging successes.

title: With Prime Past 10%...
description: Is breaking the 10 per cent prime like breaking the 4minute mile?

title: About New York
description: Maurice H. Nadjari spoke at the City Club the other night, and he spoke with the strength of ten because he knew his heart was pure. We search for stars in the eyes of the people we hire, he said, and then be said that his office had, hired 40 lawyers, and that they all had those stars. Mr. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor, is the hottest prosecutor in town.

title: PORTUGAL'S MOTE ANGERS VATICAN
description: ROME, April 16  The Vatican's relations with Portugal have apparently worsened since the expulsion of a Roman Catholic Bishop and a group of missionaries from Mozambique.

title: WALTER G. BUNZL
description: Walter G. Bunzl, retired president of the Prometheus Electric Company which manufactured hospital supplies in New Rochelle, N.Y., diedyesterday in Scottsdale, Ariz., where he had been living. He was 79 years old.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 45

title: Pay Rise Seen Unlikely To Hurt Japan Exports
description: TOKYO, April 16  Last week's rise in Japan's hitherto relatively low national wage bill is not likely to lead to a substantial decline in Japan's competitive power in export markets soon, according to Japan's official Economic Planning Agency. The wage bill soared 30 per cent in the week after the country was paralyzed by a national strike.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: CUBAN EXILE FOUND SHOT TO DEATH HERE
description: A 31yearold former leader of the antiCastro movement among Cuban exiles was found shot to death in his Washington Heights apartment yesterday afternoon, the police reported.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I am astonished at your garbled editorial of April 11 in which you attempt to rewrite history and dilute my predecessor's responsibiliry for leaving me with a budget deficit of record proportion.

title: Lamonica Jumping to W.F.L.Club
description: The World Football League snared its 25th National Football League player yesterday by persuading Daryle Lamonica to leave the Oakland Raiders after his option year is finished this coming season.

title: ARTHUR G. HESSEL
description: Arthur G. Hessel, for many years an executive of the Continental Baking Company, died yesterday In Sarasota Memorial Hospital in, Florida. He was 74 years old.

title: Advertising: Tight Job Market
description: You say you've got a kid in college interested in an ad agency career? Suggest he try plumbing. You say he's a she? Tell her to try the cops.

title: Leaders of Israel's Ruling Party Decide Against New Elections
description: TEL AVIV, April 16The leadership of. Israel's ruling Labor party decided tonight not to move for new elections. It resolved instead to try to set up a new coalition Cabinet to replace the Government of Premier Goida Meir, who resigned last week.

title: CON EDISON FACING POWER SHORTAGES
description: ALBANY, April 16Consolidated Edison's ability to meet heavy summer power demands has been placed in jeopardy by the failure of a key supply link.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: WEST ORANGE, April 16In 1960, at the first Funorama on Ice, Don Jackson of Canada, a future world figureskating champion, and Carol Noir Wick of East Orange, a future United States junior champion, were two of the featured performers.

title: A Forecast That Interest Rates Will Soon Drop Serves as a Spur
description: The stock market made its best advance in six weeks yesterday, buoyed by investor hopes that interest rates would soon decline.

title: LAWSUIT IS FILED AGAINST PENNZOIL
description: A class action lawsuit against Pennzoil United, Inc., was filed yesterday by a bondholder in the United States District Court in St. Louis, Mo.

title: CALLEY SENTENCE IS CUT TO 10 YEARS BY HEAD OF ARMY
description: WASHINGTON, April 16Secretary of the Army Howard H. Callaway halved today the 20year sentence imposed on First Lieut. William L. Caney Jr., convicted at a courtmartial for the murder of 22 South Viet namese civilians at My Lai in 1968.

title: RODGERS, HARNICK TEAM UP FOR REX
description: Rex, a musical about King Henry VIII with music by Richard Rodgers and lyrics by Sheldon Harnick, will be produced here next season by Richard Adler. The musical, which is expected to cost more than $500,000, will have a book by Jerome Lawrence and Robert E. Lee, authors of Inherit the Wind and Mame.

title: Data on Zoned High Schools
description: The following table, based on Board of Education projections for next fall, give the capacity, estimated enrollment, building utilization rate and student ethnic composition of zoned academic high schools in the Bronx. The Bronx High School of Science, a apecialized school, and De Witt Clinton [for boys) and Walton [for girls) do not have regular zones and are not included.

title: A.F.L.G.I.O. BACKS CHAVEZ BOYCOTT
description: WASHINGTON, April 16George Meany, declaring that the plight of farm workers is of vital importance to the entire labor movement, acted today to mobilize the nationwide network of A.F.L.C.I.O. unions to support the boycott of grapes and lettuce organized by the United Farm Workers of America.

title: Seaver DefeatedFifth Loss in Row
description: MONTREAL, April 16 The New York Mets continued their generosity in helping the Montreal Expos open their home baseball season today.

title: Recital
description: Throughout her astonishing career, Maria. Callas has attracted two invaluable types of admirers: first, dismally unmusical people who can't tell how precarious her vocal state has been for most of the last 20 years, and second, highly musical listeners who know, but don't believe it really matters.

title: DONATION ARGUED IN MAHEU LAWSUIT
description: LOS ANGELES, April 16Whether Senator Hubert H. Humphrey was telling the truth in denying that he received $50,000 in $100 bills from Robert A. Maheu was argued before a Federal court jury here today.

title: BEAME CUTS BACK NUMBER OF POLICE TO BE HIRED IN '74
description: Mayor Beame retreated Yesterday from his electioncampaign pledge to hire 3,000 extra policemen this year, and he argued that a onepenny increase in the sales tax here, to 8 per cent, would hurt New Yorkers less than a rise in their income tax.

title: CALLEY SENTENCE IS CUT TO 10 YEARS BY HEAD OF ARMY
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 Secretary of the Army Howard H. Callaway halved today the 20year sentence imposed on First Lieut. William., L. Calley Jr., convicted at a courtmartial for the murder of 22 South Vietnamese civilians at My Lai in 1968

title: Stottlemyre WinsNettles Gets 3 Hits
description: Like the man who came to dinner, the Yankees nestled into Shea Stadium yesterday and won their fourth straight game in the home of the Mets by edging the Boston Red Sox, 21.

title: Slain Irishman Had Charged Plot by Scotland Yard
description: LONDON, April 16Three days before he was found murdered, an Irishman told a civilliberties lawyer a story of intrigue and deception by Scotland Yard in its fight against Irish terrorists.

title: Reforming the Banks
description: The Legislature at Albany has a farreaching opportunity this session to set in motion an orderly reform of the state's banking institutions, aimed at opening up sheltered and often anachronistic preserves to a more healthy competition from which savers and borrowqrs alike could benefit.

title: Manes in State Race
description: Borough President Donald R. Manes of Queens announced his candidacy for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination. He is the fourth major contender. Page 30.

title: Soviet Leaders, in Warsaw, Meet Polish Officials
description: WARSAW, April 16Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Communist party chief; Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin and other Soviet leaders arrived here this evening for three days of talks with their counterparts from all the European Communist nations except Yugoslavia and Albania.

title: NARCOTICS SALE LAID TO OFFICERS
description: The indictment of five city correction officers on charges of criminal possession and sale of dangerous drugs was announced yesterday. They were immediately suspended by Cor rection Commissioner Benjamin, J. Malcolm.

title: BANK STUDY WARNS OF TAX RISES HERE
description: A sharp warning on the danger of raising the already high tax burdens of middleincome and upperiricome New Yorkers is made in a new study of the region's economy by the First National City Bank.

title: Manes in State Race
description: Borough President Donald R. Manes of Queens announced his candidacy for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination. He is the fourth major contender. Page 30.

title: CONVICT IS NAMED IN COAST ROBBERY
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 16 The, Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that Donald D. DeFreeze, an escaped convict, was among the band of terrorists it believes may have forced Patricia Hearst to take part in a daring bank robbery here yesterday.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Extortion Trial Delayed
description: ATLANTA, April 16 (UFOThe Federal extortion trial of William A. H. Williams and his wife Betty, accused kidnappers of Reg Murphy, editor of The Atlanta Constitution, has been postponed to June 3 to allow itme to consider motions in the case.

title: Ashe Beats Panatta at River Oaks
description: HOUSTON, April 16 (AP) Arthur Ashe, with a 64, 64 victory over Adriano Panatta of Italy, advanced today to the second round of the 40th River Oaks tournament, a World Championship Tennis event.

title: HOUSTON STATES ANNOUNCES DEAL
description: The Houston States Gas Corporation, announced yesterday that It had acquired about a 50 per cent interest in two foreign companies that own or control contracts forthe construction of two large crudeoil tankers. The names of the companics were not disclosed, Houston States, Gas said the vessels, to be built under fixed, price contracts in a British shipyard, were scheduled to he completed in the first half cf. 1977. The American company added that, through a subsidiary, it had loaned $10.5million to the foreign concerns for progress payments and had issued a note for $11million payable to the other owner of the foreign companies either on delivery of the ships, or in 1977. An additional $12million loan for progress payments may be needed in 1976 or 1977, it was said.

title: Michigan Democrat Wins In Election for House Seat
description: SAGINAW, Mich., Wednesday, April 17J. Bob Traxler, a 42yearold member of the Michigan House of Representatives, yesterday became the first Democrat to be elected to Congress from Michigan's Eighth District since 1932.

title: MRS. GANDHI DENIES HUMPHREY ACCOUNT
description: NEW DELHI, April 16 (Reuters)India's Prime Minister, Indira Gandhi, denied today that she had ever told former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey, that it Was absolutely essential for United States troops to be in Vietnam.

title: FRENCH SELL KUWAIT TOP FIGHTER PLANE
description: PARIS, April 16 (Reuters)France has agreed to sell, Kuwait spohisticated Mirage F1 fighter planes, the French Defense Ministry said today.

title: Saigon Effort to Sway U.S. Aid Bill Seen
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 16  The Saigon Government's announcement that is was suspending the political talks, outside Paris with the Vietcong was seen by some diplomats here today as an attempt to heighten tension while a military appropriations bill for South Vietnam is working its way through the American Congress.

title: PORTUGAL'S MOVE ANGERS VATICAN
description: ROME, April 16The Vatican's relations with Portugal have apparently worsened since the expulsion of a Roman Catholic Bishop and a group of missionaries from Mozambique.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY APRIL 17, 1974

title: The Theater: Words and Music by Sammy Cahn
description: Why are such shows as Words and Music simple and enchanting, and other shows complex and morose?

title: Texas Oil Production 100%
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 16In creased supplies of imported oil in the United States were reported to the Texas Railroad Commission today as it extended 100 per cent production from Texas oil wells through May for the 26th consecutive month.

title: Housing Starts Decline After February Surge
description: WASHINGTON, April 16Housing starts in March dropped back to their January level after a spurt in February that apparently was a fluke, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Music: Superb Violist
description: Six years have passed since Marcus Thompson made his viola debut here under the sponsorship of Young Concert Artists. They have obviously been years of growth, for in his recital in the Hunter College Playhouse on Monday night, again under the same sponsorship, he played with the authority of a mature artist. He combined vigor and sensitivity, rhythmic power and tonal color, attesting to the complete interpreter.

title: U.S. Sees No Need to End Penn Central's Operations
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 16 (UPI)  The Government said today that the new Regional Rail Reorganization Act made it unnecessary for the Federal District Court here to end rail operations of the bankrupt Penn Central Railroad to protect creditors.

title: Ionesco's Roi Se Meurt by Parisians
description: Taking its cultural mission as seriously as ever, the French Government has again helped to send us Le Treteau de Paris, a statesubsidized drama troupe that has toured the United States since 1958 with Frenchlanguage productions of the classics and the Parisian avantgarde.

title: Belotti to Run for Office
description: BOSTON, April 16 (AP)Former Lieut. Gov, Francis I. Bellotti said today that he was giving up his private law practice to seek the Democratic nomination for state Attorney General.

title: TV Urged for Meetings Of Impeachment Panel
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP)  A member of the House Judiciary Committee urged today that House rules be changed to permit television coverage of current business meetings of the committee's impeachment inquiry.

title: C. SHELBY CARTER, 74, A FINANCIAL EXPERT
description: C. Shelby Carter, a retired adviser in corporate reorganizations, died Monday at Midtown Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at the Seville Hotel, Madison Avenue and 29th Street.,

title: Editor Warns of Peril In Bill on Secret Data
description: ATLANTA, April 16 (UPI) Ben Bradlee, executive editor of The Washington Post, said today that a Nixon Administration bill making it a crime to disclose classified information would emasculate freedom of the press and prevent disclosure of scandals such as Watergate.

title: A.P. Photographer Gave Data to F.B.I. At Wounded Knee
description: ST. PAUL, April 16 (AP)An Associated Press photographer told a Federal judge yesterday that he gave information to F.B.I. agents on one occasion, during the 71day occupation of Wounded Knee, S.D., last year.

title: CON EDISON FACING POWER SHORTAGES
description: ALBANY, April 16Consolidated Edison's ability to meet heavy summer power demands has been placed in jeopardy by the failure of a key supply link.

title: FORMER DEPUTY D.A. APPEALS CONVICTION
description: The bribery conviction of a former Queens assistant district attorney has been appealed on the ground that the presiding judge, State Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh, held an improper conference with Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor, in the case the day before it went to trial last October.

title: Harris's Goal Puts Canadiens Behind In Playoff, 32
description: MONTREAL, April 16After tying the game in the last 16 seconds tonight in the Forum, the New York Rangers beat the Montreal Canadiens in overtime, 32, and took the lead in their National Hockey fieague playoff series, 3 games to 2.

title: Parents in Brooklyn Ask Board ta Ease Crowding
description: Scores of parents, teachers and others  even 4yearold Leon Garrido, who willenter kindergarten next fall  appealed to the Board of Education last night to help ease school crowding in the Crown Heights and East Flatbush sections of Brooklyn.

title: AUTO SALES DOWN 15% FOR APRIL 110
description: DETROIT, April 16American auto makers reported today sales of 230,375 cars in the first 10 days of April, down 15.4 per cent from a year earlier but up 42 per cent from the first 10 days of March.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 45

title: Greenwood Shifts to High Gear
description: John Greenwood, who drives his race cars because he says he can't find anyone better, admits that Bobby Allison could hold me up pretty good if he wanted in their match race Saturday at Road Atlanta. And heaven knows, Mr. Allison will be so inclined while Mr. Greenwood won't want to put any scratches on his new $100,000 Corvette, especially since he has a sixhour endurance race the next day with the car.

title: DEAN IS DISPUTED BY KLEINDIENST
description: Richard G. Kleindienst, former Attorney General, took the witness stand yesterday in behalf of John N. Mitchellone of the closest, most intimate friends I ever had in my lifeand attempted to refute the testimony of John W. Dean 3d.

title: Cooper of Kentucky Expected To Be Envoy to East Germany
description: WASHINGTON, April 16President Nixon is considering nominating John Sherman Cooper as the first United States ambassador to East Germany high American officials said today.

title: Newark Murder Is Tied To a PrisonHatched Plot
description: NEWARK, April 16Assistant Prosecutor Joseph A. Hayden of. Essex County said today the state would attempt to prove that the murder last September of the Black Muslim leader Joseph McGregor Shabazz grew out of a conspiracy hatched in a state prison.

title: 2 Gunmen Rob Choir Rehearsing in Church
description: Two gunmen forced their way into a Harlem church during a choir rehearsal last night and robbed 30 choir members of $600 in cash and $2,000 worth of jewelry, the police reported.

title: Dissidents in Soviet Report Fatal Mental Hospital Riot
description: MOSCOW, April 16Two mental patients were beaten to death after the quelling of a riot in a mental hospital in the Soviet Far East, dissident sources said today.

title: Kahane Says He Is Quitting As J.D.L.'s Militant Chief
description: JERUSALEM, April 16 (Reutors)Rabbi Meir Kahane of New York, founder and chairman of the Jewish Defense League, said today that he was resigning as head of its militant arm, but would continue as its spiritual leader.

title: Curt Conway, Actor Who Played In Touch of Poet on Stage, Dies
description: Curt Conway, who made his debut as an actor here with the Group Theatet in 1935, died last Thursday of a heart at tack in Los Angeles.

title: Official Search Is: Ended For Child After Six Days
description: WEST DEPTFORD, April 16 The search for 4yearold Brenda Probasco was called off by the police today, six days after the blueeyed, brownhaired girl disappeared.

title: COURT DECLARES HOFFMAN FUGITIVE
description: Abbie Hoffman was declared a fugitive yesterday after he failed to appear for the third time at a court hearing in connection with his indictment on charges of selling cocaine.

title: ATLANTIC RICHFIELD REDUCES GAS PRICE
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company announced yesterday that it had reduced its wholesale prices for gasoline by 1 cent gallon iii all of the company's marketing areas in the country. The reductions became effective yesterday.

title: Armed Forces' Problem: Finding Good Volunteers
description: The United States volunteer forces, nine months after the end of the draft, are in a period of transition marked by manifold problems and some encouraging successes.

title: Court Rules C.B.S. Pirated Paladin From a Cowboy
description: A 65yearold cowboy from Rhode Island has won a court judgment against the Columbia Broadcasting System on his charge that he, and not C.B.S., created the character Paladin and essential ideas used in the popular television series, Have Gun, Will Travel.

title: Canada Weighing $20Billion Program to Develop Tar Sands
description: MONTREAL, April 16Canada is considering a $20billion crash program to develop her Athabasca tar sands, which contain one of the world's largest deposits of oil.

title: Bridge: Games Went On Despite Woes Of Liner Queen Elizabeth 2
description: The ability of bridge players to rise above discomfort and misfortune was strikingly demonstrated during the recent tribulations of the Queen Elizabeth 2. When power failure in midAtlantic created major problems with food, water, sanitation and lighting, and almost all activities came to a halt, the bridge games kept going.

title: Telefunken Sets U.S. Plant
description: The A.E.G. Telefunken Corporation, West Germany, Europe's largest conglomerate, will build its first Americanbased manufacturing facility in the Norwich Industrial Park, in Norwich, Conn. The announcement was made here by Oscar Stuhlweissenburg, president of the company's American subsidiary? in New York City, who said the facility would make power tools, cost $10 million and employ 500 persons.

title: 2 Divisions Loom for Saturday's Wood
description: There was Kenny Noe Jr., the racing secretary at Aqueduct, dommenting in his office yesterday about the topheavy list of candidates for Saturday's Wood Memorial at the Big A when along came word there was another possible starter  Eugene Grandon's Be A Native. That Grandon colt sure rounds out a bumper crop for our big 3yearold race, said Noe. And who knows? There may be even more turning up. I understand Bold and Fancy and Cumolo Nimbus may go for the Wood, too,

title: Herald Tribune's Files Are Offered to the City
description: The files of The New York Herald Tribune have been offered to the city for inclusion in the municipal archives.

title: BOSTON REFERENDUM ON BUSING IS BARRED
description: BOSTON, April. 16 (AP) The Massachusetts Supreme Court ruled today that a proposed binding referendum on planned busing to achieve racial balance in Boston schools would be unconstitutional.

title: Giants to Play Redskins In Opener at New Haven
description: New York football's new coaches will know immediately just how good their teams are.

title: A.T. & T. TO CUT OFF MCI'S CONNECTIONS
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP)The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today it would immediately arrange to disconnect the network of private longdistance facilities used by customers of MCI Communications Inc.

title: OIL DATA BACKED. BY ENERGY CHIEF
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP)  The major oil companies apparently are telling the truth about their supplies, based on audits by the Federal Energy Office, according to the office's chief, William E. Simon.

title: SILVER FUTURES SHOW PRICE RISE
description: Prices swung widely yesterday in heavy trading of silver futures on the Commodity Exchange. The metal, which underwent a sharp decline in price in recent weeks, rallied Monday and prices continued to move up early today.

title: Scoppetta Warned Mayor On Coldman Appointment
description: Investigation Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta warned Mayor Beame before he appointed Irving Goldman as Commissioner of Cultural Affairs that rumors about Mr. Goldman could result in embarrassing the Mayor, according to sources in the Beame administration.

title: Books of The Times
description: In his middle age, Robert Melrose is the sort of man on whom practical jokes are played. He can always be depended upon to go along with the gagnot because he is taken in, but because playing the fool, better than being left out altogether. To be laughed at is not so bad as being ignored. And for the brief period it takes to perpetrate the joke on him. Melrose can Imagine that the mysterious phone call summoning him to such and such a place is real, a genuine call to adventure:

title: BILLY TAYLOR'S TRIO PLAYS AT WALDORF
description: Two years ago the WaldorfAstoria made an experimental foray into jazz in its Peacoek Alley, using a quartet led by Ruby Braff, but the project was dropped almost before it was started. Now, after thinking it over, the hotel is trying jazz in its Alley once again, this time with Billy Taylor's Trio and some remodeling that has changed the once bright and airy room into an intimate, dimly lit setting for Mr. Taplor's piano.

title: OUTLOOK ORATES HELPS LIFT AMEX
description: Buoyed by a forecest that shortterm rates may have peaked, prices on the American Stock Exchange and on the Overthecounter Market posted strong gains in heavier trading.

title: Teachers Seized in Sitdown
description: HORTONVILLE, Wis., April 18 (UPI)Fifteen striking teachers, and their backers were arrested today when they sat down in a street in an effort to prevent nonstriking teachers from driving home. The teachers' strike began five weeks ago over a contract dispute.

title: MERRILL REPORTS 33% PROFIT DROP
description: Merrill Lynch & Co., holding company for the big brokerage firm Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., reported yesterday a 33 per cent decline in net earnings for the first quarter of 1974 to $7.1million, or 22 cents a share, from $10.8million, or 34 cents a year ago.

title: Dollar Censorship
description: State Senator John Marchi has introduced a bill which would ban the use of student activities fees for the operation of undergraduate newspapers on the campuses of the state's public colleges and universities. The explanation offered for this prohibition is that it would safeguard the civil liberties of students so that their contributions are not used to subsidize causes with Which they differ and which are advocated without regard to their approval or disapproval.

title: FRANCIS G. WILSON
description: Francis G. Wilson, a radio and television writer and a novelist, died yesterday in the Le Roy Hospital, 40 East 61st Street. He was 68 years old and lived at 67 Park Avenue.

title: 4 Public Law Units Get Ford Grants
description: The Ford Foundation, a major source of support for publicinterest law organizations, announced Sunday that it was granting a total of $2.3million to four such groups.

title: Some Bronx High Schools To Get New Zoning Plan
description: A new studentzoning plan for regular academic high schools in the Bronx, which is designed to bring about a better utilization of school space, was announced yesterday by School Chancellor Irving Anker.

title: BendixU.A.W. Pact Set
description: DETROIT, April 16 (AP)The United Auto Workers and the Bendix Corporation announced agreement today on a new threeyear agreement covering 8,500 workers at 10 auto and aero space parts divisions, The settlement averted a strike threatened by the union for 10 A.M, today. Details of the pact were withheld, pending submission of the pact to the U.A.W.'s Bendix Council and to the rankandfile for approval.

title: For Many Jewish Families, It's Time to Return to Tradition
description: In Manhattan, members of Congregatio Rodeph Sholom gather early on a Sunday morning to learn from their rabbis how to perform the rituals of the Sabbath.

title: Hawks Beat Kings, 10; Win Series
description: CHICAGO, April 16 (AP)Jim Papin's unassisted goal on a 40foot slap shot with 4:37 left in the game gave the Chicago Black Hawks a 10 victory over Los Angeles tonight and eliminated the Kings from the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LA MANGA, Spain, April 16 (AP)Gary Player, the Masters winner, was favored to take the 48th Spanish open golf tournament, which starts tomorrow with a field of 130. The South African was familiar with the 6,855yard La Mange course. He is the titular pro at the club. The field includes Tony Jacklin, Maurice Bembridge and Jerry Heard. The first prize in the $65,000 event is $8,500.

title: EXTRA FUND FOUND FOR AID TO SAIGON
description: WASHINGTON, April 16The Pentagon has told a Senate committee that it has found $266million extra for military aid to South Vietnam this year funds that military officials said they did not know they had.

title: EUTAW SAVINGS BANK BOUGHT IN MARYLAND
description: The Maryland National Bank, the state's largest bank, has acquired the Eutaw Savings Bank of Baltimore in an emergency move to prevent a faillure of the $138.8million mutual savings bank, the third largest in Maryland.

title: Oil Producers' Burden
description: With tantalizing deliberation, Middle Eastern oilproducing countries are gradually awakening to the wisdom and the necessity of spreading some of their windfall riches among their lessblessed third world partners. Regrettably the amounts of new development capital now under discussion still represent only a fraction of the anticipated need.

title: Bank of California Lifts Its Prime Lending Level to 10.25%
description: Rates on Treasury bills, which on Monday tumbled as much as onequarter of a point, reversed course yesterday and moved higher, despite forecasts by some economists that credit rates may have reached a crest and should be sharply lower this summer.

title: Massive ShakeUp Is Made In Chicago Police Command
description: CHICAGO, April 16 (AP)James Rochford, superindent of police, announced massive changes today in the Chicago Police Department's leadership, switching all but two of the present district commanders and naming a new deputy superintendent.

title: L.l.R.R. Strike Put Off As Issue Goes to Panel
description: A strike threatened for last midnight by 16 Long Island Rail Road unions was postponed when the unions decided to meet tomorrow in Washington to submit their. pension dispute to an impartial panel. The decision spared 90,000 commuters from an imminent shutdown of the railroad.

title: Floods in Brazil's Northeast Force 70,000 From Homes
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 16 (Reuters)  New floods in northeastern Brazil have left 70,000 people homeless and caused 12 deaths, according to state government reports today.

title: State Bill for Needy Held Inadequate
description: ALBANY, April 16  Social ervice, organizations today pressed their complaint that, espite proposed increases in mergency state aid for the ged, blind and disabled receivng Federal Supplementary Seurity Income payments, thouands of these individuals still ace hunger and deprivation.

title: Rothko Art Case Postponed
description: The trial of a suit involving the estate of Mark Rothko the abstract expressionist painter, has been postponed to Monday because of the illness of one of the lawyers. The sevenweek trial, in Surrogate's Court arises from efforts of Mr. Rothko's daughter, Kate, to dismiss three executors named in her father's will and to cancel a contract they made selling and consigning 800 Rothko paintings to the Marlborough Gallery.

title: MURDER LINKED TO A PRISON PLOT
description: NEWARK, April 16  Asaistant Prosecutor Joseph A Hayden of Essex County said today the state would attempt to prove that the murder Iast September of the Black Muslin leader Joseph. McGregor Shabazz grew out of a conspiracy run from behind bars at a New Jersey state prison.

title: Hofstra Names Provost
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., April 16 (AP)Dr. William J. Petrek has been named provost of Hofstra University, it was announced today. The post ranks second only to the university's president. For the last two years, Dr. Petrak served as dean of Hofstra's College of Liberal Arts and Sciences. He succeeds Dr. Harold E. Yuker, Who served as interim provost for the last year.

title: I.R.S. Aide Here Sworn In
description: Philip E. Coates, a career Government official who has served with the Internal Revenue Service for more than 20 years, was sworn in yesterday as director of the Manhattan district of the I.R.S. The oath was administered by Elliot H. Gray, whom he succeeds, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Mr. Gray is becoming regional commissioner of the I.R.S. North Atlantic region.

title: DRUG AGENTS CLEAR IN MISTAKEN RAIDS
description: ALTON, Ill., April 16 (UPI) Seven undercover narcotics agents were cleared yesterday of charges of perjury and conspiracy to obstruct justice in connection with mistaken drug raids at six homes in southern Illinois last spring.

title: Text of Jaworski Letter
description: WASHINGTON, APRIL 16 Following is the text of a letter of April 11 from the special Watergate prosecutor, Leon Jaworski, to the special Presidential counsel, James D. St. Clair explaining why he was going to seek a subpoena of White House material:

title: Vanishing Controls
description: The Administration's decision to end, wageprice controls over supermarkets and other fooddistributors makes it plaint hat there will be few sectors of the economy left to decontrol by the time the Economic Stabilization Act expires less than two weeks hence.

title: CONVICT IS NAMED IN COAST ROBBERY
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 16 The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that Donald D. DeFreeze, an escaped convict, was among the band of terrorist it believes may have forced Patricia Hearst to lake past in a daring bank robbery here yesterday.

title: Walls Fall in East Village Blaze
Arthur Miller Return to Genesis for First Musical
description: In a large room near Times Square, Arthur Miller was rehearsing his first musical, Up From Paradise (book lyrics, direction and narration by Mr. Miller, music by Stanley Silverman). Sitting at a table, Mr. Miller silently mouthed, all the dialogue and lyrics along with his actors, savoring the lines and smiling at the jokes.

title: Georgia Plant Planned By Brown & Williamson
description: MACON, Ga., April 16 (AP)The Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation of Louisville, Ky., announced plans today to construct a $150million plant in this middle Georgia city.

title: Alice Kleeman Wed To Thomas Keller
description: Mks Alice Anne Kleeman and Thomas C. Keller, both of Woodside, Calif., were married yesterday morning. Judge Roy W. Seagraves of the San Mateo Municipal Court in Redwood City, Calif., performed the ceremony in his chambers.

title: A Mississippi Sidewheeler Is Burned at Her Moorings
description: VICKSBURG, Miss., April 16 (AP)The 73yearold Sprague, a kingsized sternwheeler that gained fame on her Mississippi River runs, has been destroyer by a fire at her Vicksburg mooring.

title: Safeway Stores Net Rises 33%; Colonial and Kroger Also Gain
description: A profit improvement, larger new stores and generally better sales in existing stores brightened the results of Safeway Stores, Inc., for its first fiscal quarter ended March 23.

title: 14 Arrested After a Raid On Panther Home on Coast
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 16 (UPI)Fourteen persons were arrested today when the police raided a home occupied by members of the Black Panther party in response to a complaint from a young man who said he had been beaten with a pistol and baseball bat.

title: 3 Children Drown in Pool
description: MANKATO, Minn., April 16 (AP)  Three young girls drowned when they apparently went wading in the frigid water of an outdoor swimming pool at a city park. The victims included two sisters, Debra Ray Lohn, 8 years old, and Patricia Ann Lohn, 4. Tammy Heldman, 4, was the other child found last night in the deep end of the pool at Tourtellotte Park where water from melted snow had collected to a depth of seven feet.

title: ARRICALE ADMITS SLIP ON JOB LIST
description: The personnel director for the city's central Board of Education conceded yesterday that his office might have gone beyond Federal guidelines in sending to the heads of the 33 comnunity school boards a list of black and Puerto Rican teacher applicants who were available for hiring.

title: George Godfrey, ManagedOrpheum Vaudeville Circuit
description: George Godfrey, a retired casting director of Columbia Pictures in Hollywood and former general manager of the Orpheum circuit during vaudeville days, died Monday at the Ankara Hotel in Miami Beach, where he lived. He, was 88 years old.

title: U.S. and 2 NATO Allies Seek Common Tank Gun
description: RAMSTEIN AIR BASE, West Germany, April 16The United States, West Germany and Britain, in an effort to overcome one of the military weaknesses of the Western alliance, have agreed upon competitive selection of a common gun for their tanks.

title: Scoppetta Warned Mayor On Goldman Appointment
description: Investigations Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta warned Mayor Beame before he appointed Irving Goldman as Commissioner of Cultural Affairs that rumors about Mr. Goldman could result in embarrassing the Mayor, according to sources in the Beanie administration.

title: People in Sports
description: Paul Pawlak Jr., an assistant football coach at Cornell for the last eight seasons, will be the 20th head coach at Tufts University, officials at Medford, Mass., school announced yesterday. Pawlak, 33 years old, a native of Seymour, Conn., succeeds, Rocco Carib, who stepped down to devote fulltime to his duties in the athletic director's office.

title: Israel Names Armor Chief
description: TEL AVIV, April 16 (Reuters) Maj. Gen, Moshe Peled was tonight appointed commander of Israel's armored forces. The 47yearold general commanded a division that fought in the southern sector of the Golan Heights during the October war.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Houston Righting and Power Company has given a letter of intent the Babcock & Wilcox Company for two muitifuel boilers to provide steam for two 660megawatt geneliators to be constructed in Fort Bend County, Tex. The cost will be about $22million each. The Westinghouse Electric Corporation will supply turbine generators for the two unite at a combined cost of $32million.

title: Market Place:
description: Brokerage houses that began offering discounts on certain small trades two weeks ago say the new commissions are working fine. Firms that have ignored them say they're meaningless. In any event, unless the discounters are skinning their competitors' hides, the special rates have had little influence on the small investors' apathy. Apart from yesterday's blip, the market's volume hasn't budged.

title: JAWORSKI SEEKS COURT SUBPOENA FOR NIXON TAPES
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 The Watergate special prosecutor, Leon Jaworski, asked the United States District Court here today to issue a subpoena directing President Nixon to turn over tape recordings and other documents relating to 64 conversations between Mr.. Nixon and four of his former top aides.

title: Court Rules C.B.S. Pirated Paladin From a Cowboy
description: A 65yearold cowboy frost Rhode Island has won a court judgment against the Columbia Broadcasting System on his charge that he, and not C.B.S., created the character Paladin and essential ideas used in the popular television series, Have Gun, Will Travel.

title: Connally's Name Turns Up in Watergate Investigations of Big Political Contributions by Dairy Industry
description: WASHINGTON April 16John B. Connally, spoken of as one of the most possible Repubtican candidates for President in 1976, is being pulled, a bit at a time, into the Watergate backwash.

title: Premier Is Back in Hanoi
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, April (16) Agence FrannePres)Premier Pham Van Dong returned here today after a onemonth tour of Cuba, Algeria, Yugoslavia and Sweden.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Newark PreSchool Council said yesterday that it might be forced soon to close its 60 Head Start centers that serve 1,900 4yearold children and their families in the city unless the council's annual budget of $2.3million was met through a grant from the Office of Child Development, Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

title: Red Smith
description: On the first day of the hew baseball season, a righthanded batter named Mike Schmidt hit a home run off lefthanded Tug McGraw in Philadelphia and the New York Mets lost. Just about that time, maybe the same day, book arrived from Houghton Mifflin Company entitled Screwball. It is a beautiful book about a beautiful guy, it sensitive, emotional, demonstrative, genuine, outgoing, affectionate, exuberant, sad and sometimes irresponsible human being. It is Tug McGraw's story done in collaborawith Joe Durso, and it is to the standard baseball biography as Edgar A. Poe is to Edgar A. Guest.

title: India Is Sinking Deeper Into Crisis and Anguish
description: NEW DELHI, April 16 India, a democracy in anguish, is immersed In a deepening economic and political crisis marked by agitation, selfquestioning and drift.

title: AGENCY BACKED ON AIDE DISMISSAL
description: WASHINGTON, April 18The Supreme Court ruled today that a Federal agency could discharge a Civil Service worker without a hearing on the ground that bribery charges he made against his superiors had not promoted the efficiency of the service

title: World Bank Says Poor Nations Need $9Billion More in Aid
description: WASHINGTON, April 16Higher oil prices and the other economic events since last year have added more than $9billion to the needs of the lessdeveloped countries for aid and other outside capital to maintain progress in development in 1974 and 1975, a new analysis by the World Bank concluded today.

title: All Hallows First Distance Relay
description: Gene McCarthy ran his anchor onemile leg in 4 minutes 15.1 seconds yesterday to lead All Hallows to victory in the distance medley relay in the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association New York Diocese. Relay Carnival at the Mount. St. Michael track in the Bronx.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP)Saying that the United States Tariff Commission was provoking higher lead prices, Treasury Secretary George P. Shultz bowed today, to the commission's judgment that lead Imports from Australia and Canada were hurting American industry. He issued a finding that imports of primary lead metal from Australia and Canada were being dumped in the United States at low prices and were subject to special import duties if the price remained low.

title: 2 CAMERAS IN BANK REQUIRED BY '68 LAW
description: In the few minutes that Patricia Hearst and some members of the selfstyled Symbionese Liberation Army are alleged to have spent in the Sunset branch of the Hibernia Bank in San Francisco Monday, a pair of cameras took nearly 1,500 pictures of the scene, according to the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Ashe Beats Panatta at River Oaks
description: HOUSTON, April 16 (AP) Arthur Ashe, with a 64, 64 victory over Adriano Panatta of Italy, advanced today to the second mud of the 40th River Oaks tournament, a World Championship. Tennis event.

title: Mrs. Allen W. Dulles, 80, Widow of C.I.A. Director
description: Mrs. Clover Todd Dulles, widow of Allen W. Dulles, retired director of`the Central Intelligence Agency, died Monday at her home in Washington. She was 80 years old.

title: A.B.A. Playoffs
description: Nets vs. Kentucky

title: EARNINGS UP 10.4% AT GENERAL PHONE
Sun Oil and Chase Step Up Earnings
description: The Sun Oil Company reported yesterday that its profits in the first quarter of this year were 85 per cent higher than in the first quarter of 1973.

title: Judge Under Indictment, Defeats a Suit to Remove Him
description: A Bronx Civil Court judge who was indicted last December on charges of conspiracy to fix a murder case has defeated a civil action to have him removed from the bench on the ground that he does not live in the judicial district.

title: Gasoline Is More Plentiful But Price Keeps Climbing
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (UPI)The nation's motorists are finding It increasingly easier to purchase gasoline at service stations, but the cost is steadily climbing, the American Automobile Association reported today.

title: People and Business
description: Two major promotions were announced yesterday by the World Bank Group, which consists of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (the World Bank), the International Development Association and the International Finance Corporation. All three institutions are headed by Robert S. McNamara.

title: Boston Triumphs, 11199, to Lead Playoffs, 20.
description: Six men working diligently in unison, playing near the top of their form, was all the Boston Celtics needed last night to maintain their current playoff mastery of the Knicks. Requiring almost no help from the bench, the Celtics ran away from the Knicks in the third quarter and didn't stop until they had achieved a 11199 victory before a dismayed capacity crowd at Madison Square Garden.

title: Pet Hamsters Are Called A Possible Peril to Humans
description: TRENTON, April 16 (AP)The State Health Department warned today that pet hamsters might be causing illness among humans.

title: CHARLES H. M'LAUGHLIN
description: Charles H. McLaughlin, a retired executive in the aviation field who edited the 1959 Space Age Dictionary., died, Saturday at his home in Newtown, Conn. He was 70 years old.

title: Bar on Massages Dropped
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 16 (AP)The city of Philadelphia told, a Federal court today that it would not enforce a city ordinance forbidding massages by persons to those of the opposite sex. The Velvet Touch massage parlor filed a suit in United States District Court after several of its maaseuses had been arrested for violating the ordinance.

title: Against Naderism
description: NASHVILLEAmerica is experiencing an antibusiness binge in which every corporate mistake or impefection, from a defective can of tuna to a single oil spill off the California coast, becomes an excuse for slowing technological development, proposing new economic controls and urging nation alization of private enterprise.

title: WILSON CRITICIZED ON ELECTION BILL
description: ALBANY, April 16Three of the Legislature's four party leaders received Governor Wilson's campaignreform proposal with criticism today and the fourth hesitated noncommitally as talk of a compromise began.

title: Alabama Construction Set
description: The International Paper Company announced yesterday a $25million construction program for its mill in Mobile, Ala. The bulk of the funds, $18.5million, will be for environmental improvements.

title: RISK OF HEPATITIS REDUCED BY TESTS
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 The Food and Drug Administration has licensed two new products that are expected to help reduce the risk of transmitting a potentially dangerous hepatitis virus through blood transfusion.

title: UNICEF PLANS AID TO VIETNAM REDS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 16  The United Nations Children's Fund announced plans today for aid to North Vietnam and to areas held by the Vietcong in the South.

title: DEAN IS DISPUTED BY KLEINDIENST
description: Richard G. Kleindienst former Attorney leneral, took the witness stand yesterday in behalf of John N. Mitchellone of the closest, most intimate friends I ever had in my lifeand attempted to refute the testimony of John W. Dean 3d.

title: Woman Robbed of Jewelry
description: PITTSBURGH, April 16 (AP) The police said today that Francoise Bragont, a 60 yearold French woman, had reported shed was robbed of jewelry worth $56,585 outside the Webster Hall Hotel in the Oakland section.

title: Goldman Linked to Painting Concern Under inquiry for Excessive Fees
description: An audit of the Shubert Foundation shows a connection between a paint supply company owned by Irving Goldman, president of the foundation, and a painting company that the State Attorney General has charged received excessive and unjustified fees from the foundation.

title: Repeal of TransitBond Covenant Gains
description: TRENTON, April 16A proposal to repeal a bistate bond covenant that precludes the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey from undertaking mass  transportation projects that could lose money cleared a key State Senate committee expeditiously today.

title: Niger Broadcasts Hail New Leaders; Silent on ExChief
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, April 16 (AP) The official radio in neighboring Niger today broadcast numerous messages of praise for the military rulers who seized power yesterday, but remained silent on the fate of the deposed President and his family. It said the messages had been sent by individuals and organizations.

title: Pynchon, Singer Share Fiction Prize
description: Thomas Pynchon's noyef Gravity's Rainbow and Isaac Bashevis Singer's collectien of short stories A Crown of Feathers have. been chosen to share the prize for fiction in the 1974 National Book Awards.

title: JAWORSKI SEEKS COURT SUBPOENA FOR NIXON TAPES
description: WASHINGTON, April 16The Watergate special prosecutor, Leon Jaworskis asked the United States District Court here today to issue a ?? directing President Nixon to turn over tape recordings and other documents relating to 64 conversations between Mr. Nixon and four of his former top aides.

title: Utility Gets Rate Increase
description: BOSTON, April 16 (AP)The State Department of Public Utilities awarded the Boston Edison Company a rate increase of $13.5million today. The company had sought increases totaling about 36.1million.

title: Show of Picasso Art Collection Put Off by Louvre
description: PARIS, April 16 (AP)The Lourve has indefinitely postponed an exhibition of painting from Pablo Picasso's private collection, and art experts say the reason is that several works may be fakes and others only of minor interest.

title: Michigan Democrat Leads In Election for House Seat
description: SAGINAW, Mich., April 16 State Representative J. Bob Traxler, a Democrat, held a narrow lead tonight in his bid to win a traditionally Republican seat in the House of Representatives from Michigan's Eighth Congressional District.

title: Chrysler Gloomy on Quarter Profits
description: CENTERLINE, Mich., April 16  Top executives of the Chrysler Corporation had some disappointing news for customers and shareholders todaythey predicted a substantial increase in car prices for 1975 and a bleak outlook for earnings.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: DROPIN Dropouts, come home. There's an arts dropin from today through Friday, sponsored on campus by the Columbia University School of the Arts.

title: Printers Go Back Into Court Tomorrow
description: Typographical Union No. is scheduled to renew its efforts tomorrow to have the courts vacate two injunctions that have restricted the union's ability to put pressure on the city's three major daily newspapers in contract negotiations.

title: LILCO Net Drops As Revenues Rise
description: HICKSVILLE, LI., April 16  Firstquarter net income dropped despite a rise in revenues, the Long Island Lighting Company reported after its annual meeting today.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LA MANGA, Spain, April 16 (AP)Gary Player, the Masters winner, was favored to take the 48th Spanish open golf tournament, which starts tomorrow with a field of 130. The South African was familiar with the 6,855yard La Mange course. He is the titular pro at the club. The field includes Tony Jacklin, Maurice Bembridge and Jerry Heard. The first prize in the $65,000 event is $8,500.

title: MET ABOLISHES EDUCATION POST
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, which in 1969 with great fanfare upgraded its education department by creating the post of vice director of education, has abolished the post and will merge educational with curatorial activities.

title: So the P.S.C. Says, Maybe Deal With Youngman Isn't So Funny
description: Phone jokes? I got no phone jokes. Wait a minute, I'll give you a phone joke. Feller calls his broker on the phone. Any new dope on the market? Broker says. Yeah, my son.

title: People in Sports
description: Paul Pawlak Jr., an assistant football coach at Cornell for the last eight seasons, will be the 20th head coach at Tufts University, officials at Medford, Mass., school announced yesterday. Pawlak, 33 years old, a native of Seymour, Conn., succeeds Rocco Carz, who stepped down to devote fulltime to his duties in the athletic director's office.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Byrne Backs Referendum On State Casino Gambling
description: TRENTON, April 16Governor Byrne, in what legislative leaders regard as a major political retrenchment, has withdrawn his opposition to a statewide referendum on a constitutional amendment that would permit legalized casino gambling in New Jersey, a spokesman for the Governor said today.

title: After the Crisis
description: The oil crisis is over. But the serious and worsening energy problem remains.

title: Nelson Keeps Paying Dividends
description: The Boston Celtics gave Don Nelson a second chance nine years ago and he has been paying them back ever since, only more than ever this season.

title: SOVIET AND SYRIA AGREE ON GOLAN
description: MOSCOW, April 16The Soviet Union and Syria jointly asserted today that any disengagement of Syrian and Israeli forces in the Golan Heights must be part and parcel of an overall Middle East peace settlement.

title: Gibson Unveils a Plan to Build Biggest Park System in the State
description: NEWARK, April 16 (UPI) Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson unveiled a $6.2million plan today to create the largest municipal park system in the state, and he predicted the pride of residents would save it from vandalism.

title: Bank Merger Is Set
description: Directors of the Guaranty Bank in Dallas has approved an agreement in principle to merge that bank into the Houstonbased Allied Banchshares, a multibank holding company. As part of the concept of expanding Its service capability through the merger with Allied, new and improved quarters for Guaranty, now located in the southern part of Dallas, will be planned immediately.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: India Is Sinking Deeper Into Crisis and Anguish
description: NEW DELHI, April 16India, a democracy in anguish, is immersed in a deepening economic and political crisis marked by agitation, selfquestioning and drift.

title: RANDOLPH E. EVANS, ARCHITECT, 72, DIES
description: Randolph E. Evans the architect who, designed the buildings that make up the Brooklyn College campus, died of a respiratory illness yesterday at his home, 50 Park Mende. He was 72 years old.

title: 3 Die in Detroit Blaze
description: CLAWSON, Mich., April 16 (AP)A mother and two sons died early today, in a fire that burned out their brick home in this Detroit suburb, officials said. The police identified the victims as Lucille Czerwinski, 53 years old, and her sons, Gregory, 12, and David, 9.

title: BYRNE PULLS BACK CASINO OPPOSITION
description: TRENTON, April 16Governor Byrne, in what legislative leaders regard as a major political retrenchment, has withdrawn his apposition to a statewide referendum on a constitutional amendment that would permit legalized casino gainNag in New Jersey, a spokesman for the Governor said today.

title: CHINA BIDS COUNCIL CONDEMN ISRAELIS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 16China called on the Security Council today to sternly condemn Israeli Zionist aggression, and the Soviet Union demanded that the United States stop using its veto power to prevent the Council from taking effective measures against Israel.

title: Giants to Play Redskins In Opener at New Haven
description: New York football's new coaches will know immediately just how good their teams are.

title: Baseball Roundup
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 16 (AP)Mike Anderson's tworun double and Dave Cash's third run batted in highlighted a fiverun sixth inning and led the Philadelphia Phillies to a 103 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight. It was the Phils' fifth consecutive National League victory.

title: Problems Of a Nice Guy
description: WASHINGTON, April 16  Vice President Gerald Ford keeps saying he Is not a candidate for the Presidency but keeps talking like a oandidate, and in the process he is stumbling into trouble.

title: Arab Oil Nations in U.N.  Move to Limit Aid Outlay
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. April 16Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and Iraq, three of the world's top oil producers, told the special Gneral Assembly on raw materials and development to day that their Governments had given generously to help poorer countries. They insisted that the advanced industrial nations should shoulder the primary responsibility for aiding these countries.

title: Among the Amusements, a Museum Workshop for Children
Official Search ls Ended For Child After 6 Days
description: WEST DEPTFORD, April 16 The search for 4yearold Brenda Probasco was called off by the police, today, six days after the blueeyed, brownhaired girl disappeared.

title: Bill Requiring Registration of Auto Repairers Is Passed by Assembly and Sent to Wilson for Signature
description: ALBANY, April 16A bill that provides for broad stats regulation of automobile repairs received final passage in the Assembly today and was sent to the Governor for his sign.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Federal judge scheduled a hearing for Friday at 4 P.M. on a biology teacher's bid for reinstatement to his post at James Monroe High School in the Bronx. The teacher was transferred after showing his class filmstrips on sex. Lawyers for the New York Civil Liberties Union, after filing a complaint that school authorities had violated the teacher's academic freedom and right to due process, obtained an order for the hearing from Judge Harold R. Tyler Jr. in Federal District Court in Manhattan. Chancellor Irving Anker and two assistant superintendents were ordered to show why the teacher, whose name has been deleted from court papers, should not be reinstated.

title: Bucks Beat Bulls, Lead Playoffs, 10
description: MILWAUKEE, April 16 (AP) The Milwaukee Bucks, with a tough defense, trounced the Chicago Bulls tonight, 10185, in the first game of the National Basketball Association Western Conference final playoff.

title: MANES, 4TH ENTRY IN GOVERNOR RACE
description: Borough President Donald R. Manes of Queens announced his candidacy yesterday for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, becoming the fourth major contender for the designation.

title: Mother's Day Proclaimed
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., April 16 (AP)In an annual Mother's Day proclamation, President Nixon called today for diligent efforts to continue removing barriers to equal opportunity for women. Designating May 12 as Mother's Day, Mr. Nixon also hailed motherhood as a career in itself, saying there is no undertaking more challenging, no responsibility more awesome.

title: WHITE HOUSE DATA MAY BE SCREENED
description: MIAMI, April 16The White House is preparing to turn over to the House Judiciary Committee those portions of the subsubpoenaed tape recordings that the President's lawyers believe would serve as evidence in the committee's impeachment inquiry, according to Administration sources.

title: Italian Is Big Shamrock Shareholder
description: Stockholder's of the Diamond Shamrock Corporation are expected to elect Prof. Vittorio de Nora, a distinguished Italian electrochemist, to their board today. If they do not, one of the most surprised of all will be Professor de Nora himself, who controls what is believed to be the largest single block of the company's stock.

title: Butz Admits Error
description: Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz asserted in Tokyo that the cutoff by the United States of soybean exports last summer was a mistake. Details on Page 67.

title: Polish Truce Unit Demands Saigon's Return of Defector
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 17 (AP)  The Polish delegation to the International Commission of Control and Supervision today demanded that the South Vietnamese Government return a member of the delegation who defected two days ago. But Government sources said the South Vietnamese refused.

title: Issue and Debate
description: WASHINGTON, April 16The bookkeeping that the Pentagon said, had enabled it to discover $266million extra in previously appropriated funds to buy arms for South Vietnam seems to have for the moment avoided a collision between Congress and the Nixon Administration over immediate aid to the Saigon Government. But it will not silence the debate over the extent of the basic American commitment to support that Government.

title: Sports News Brief
description: Court Upholds N.EL. Ticket Deals

title: THOMAS M. CONNORS
description: Thomas M. Connors, who retired in 1963 as general manager of the Northeast sales region of the Eastman Kodak Company, died Monday of cancer at the home of his son, Thomas M. Connors Jr., in Omaha. He was 73 years old and formerly lived at 50 Sutton Place South.

title: Beame Still Hopes to Add 3,000 to the Police Force
description: Mayor Beanie expressed cam tious hope yesterday that he might be able to hire the 3,000 policemen he had promised in his election campaign rather than the 2,340 hi is listing in the 197475 city budget.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: For a copy of the 1973 Willcox & Gibbs Annual Report call 5657920 (WCAMEX)Advt

title: Chile Opens First Public Political Trial Since Coup
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 17 A military trial began today for 57 Air Force officials and 10 civilians accused of aid to Marxists parties, sedition and dereliction of duty in the days before the September military coup that overthrew the Marxist coalition government.

title: ANSWER TO PREVIOUS PUZZLE
How the Teams Stand
description: Thursday, April 18, 1974

title: Output of Gasoline Up for Week But Is Off From 1973 Period
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP)  The American Petroleum Institute reported today that estimated gasoline production, aviation andmotor, for the latest week amounted to 6,289,000 barrels a day, compared with 6,035,000 barrels in the previous week and 6,321,000 a year ago.

title: Parents of Kent Victims Can Sue, High Court Says
description: WASHINGTON, April 17The Supreme Court today authorized the, parents of three Kent State University students killed by National Guardsmen in 1970 to sue a former Governor, at Ohio and Guard officer for damages.

title: fees for Upkeep of Fieldston Enclave Stir Dispute
description: Along pebbled walks in the far North Bronx, behind screens of forsythia, and magnolias, the people of Fieldston have argued for years abut their community's proper link to the city.

title: Songwriting Judge Files Charge Against Nadjari
description: Judge Fred G. Moritt, the songwriting senior judge of the Civil Court in Brooklyn, filed criminal charges yesterday against the special state prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari.

title: Blossom Seeley, Vaudevillian, Is Dead
description: Blossom Seeley, a songanddance headliner in vaudeville and burlesque, died yesterday at the DeWitt Nursing Home, 211 East 79th Street. She was 82 years old.

title: OUSTER OF PRIEST STIRS UNIVERSITY
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  Outwardly, it is just another spring on the Georgetown University Campus. The trees are In bloom, students lounge on freshcut grass, and rows of bicycles glisten in the sunshine. But the peaceful facade conteals a ferment probably unmatched since the days of antiwar demonstrations.

title: Butz, in Tokyo, Admits Error on Soybean Cuts
description: TOKYO, April 17The Secretary of Agriculture, Earl L. Butz, said here today that the American cutoff of soybean exports last summer, was a mistake. It was a serious mistake and I admit it freely. He said that the decision was made under political pressures generated by shortages in the domestic market.

title: Rally at Syria's U.N. Mission Protests Treatment of Jews
description: A noontime protest rally and memorial service was held yesterday outside the Syrian Mission, to the United Nations, 150 East 58th Street, during which it was charged that Syria's Jewish community was being systematically destroyed.

title: COMMERCIAL BANKS SHOW A HIGHER NET
description: Net operating earnings of the first 100 of the nation's commercial banks to report firstquarter earnings averaged 12.6 per cent higher than in the first quarter of 1973. M. A. Schapiro & Co, Inc. estimated yesterday.

title: Ashe, Layer Winners at Houston Net
description: HOUSTON, April 17 (UPI) Arthur Ashe, winning the deciding tiebreaker point in the first set on a controversial shot, went on to subdue Roger Taylor of Britain, 76, 64, and move into the quartedinals of the River Oaks tennis tournament today.

title: Dance: Attracting the Young and Old
description: The Martha Graham Dance Company presented a revival of Miss Graham's Circe at the Mark Bellinger Theater on Tuesday night along with the season's first performance of Appalachian Spring and a repeat of the opening night's Seraphic Dialogue.

title: HUGH D. CAMP, 71, OF BAG COMPANY
description: Hugh, Douglas Camp, who retired in 1972 as chairman of the board of directors of the Union Camp Corporation, Wayne, N. J., died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital after a long illness. He was 71 years old and lived at 25 Sutton Place.

title: SIR HUGH TAYLOR, PRINCETON DEAN
description: PRINGETON, N. J., April 17Sir Hugh Taylor, former dean of the Princeton University Graduate School and a prominent physical chemist, died today at the Princeton Medical Center. He was 84 years old and lived here.

title: L. K. EMIRST, 80, ECONOMIST, DEAD
description: Leonard Knight, Elmhirst, an internationally known agricultural economist and educational innovator, died Tuesday in Beyerly Hills, Calif., where he had recently moved. He was to years old and had former lived at Dartington Hall in Devon, England.

title: At Tax Time, Group Says, Working Wives Might Be Better Off Single
description: The 15th of April has passed and Form 1040 has winged its way to the tax collector. But that's not the end of it.

title: Red Sox Overtake Yankees
GAGE OF TIMES GETS SILURIAN MEDALLION
description: Nicholas Gage of The New York Times was named the winner yesterday of the Society of the Silurians medallion for public service for discovering and reporting exclusively that Congressman Mario Biaggi, had invoked the Fifth Amendment some 30 times before a grand jury and then denied that he had to the Conservative party backing his, candidacy for Mayor.

title: NIXON PICKS SIMON AS TREASURY HEAD BUT LIMITS ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, April. 17 President Nixon named William E. Simon today to succeed George P. Shultz as Secretary of the Treasury but said he would leave unfilled Mr. Shultz's position as overall director of economic policy, for the Administration.

title: Jury Will Study Miss Hearst's in Robbery
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 17A Federal grand jury here was asked today to decide whether or not Patricia Hearst was a willing participant in an armed bank robbery that took place on Monday in the city's Sunset district.

title: A.B.A. Goes for Broke in Draft
description: People from the National Basketball Association scoffed, player agents saw dollar signs and Mike Storen, the commissioner of the American Basketball Association, walked around the ballroom of the Essex House like a proud new father.

title: Race in France Het Up as 2 Rivals Clash, in a Civilized Way
description: PARIS, April 17In a civilized, lively and occasionally heated 90minute debate, two of the leading French presidential candidates, the left alliance leader, Francois Mitterrand, and the former Gaullist Premier, Jacques ChabanDelmas, engaged in the campaign's first facetoface confrontation and came out about equal.

title: Affluence and Survival
description: If the strong attempt to impose their views; they will do so at the cost of justice. [Improving] the quality of life has become a universal political demand, a technical possibility and a moral imperative.

title: Dance Theater of Harlem at Home on Broadway
description: It takes more than mere money to make a ballet cornpany. It takes love, dedication, creativity, taste, time and luck. And money. On Tuesday night, Arthur Mitchell's Dance Theater of Harlem swept authoritatively into the ANTA Theater to begin its first Broadway season.

title: PHILIP WATERBMN, TOBACCO EXECUTIVE
description: Philip M. Waterman, who had retired as head of the International Tobacco Company and of Bunning & Co., Inc:, of Manila, died Tuesday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at 875 Park Avenue.

title: Gen. Alexander Saburov, Led Partisans Behind Nazi Lines
description: MOSCOW, April. 17 (Reuters) Maj. Gen. Alexander N. Saburov, a leader of partisan units behind the German lines in World War II and then for 10 years security police chief for the Zaporozhe and Drogobych districts of the Ukraine, has died at the age of 65, it was announced today.

title: Eli Lilly Is Expanding
description: Eli Lilly & Co., announced yesterday that it would spend $45million on expanding its biochemical manufacturing plant at Clinton, Ind.

title: From the Police Blotter:
description: Firemen found a Brooklyn woman stabbed to death in her burning apartment and a man who had been visiting her critically injured. The police identified the woman as Dolores Ivory; 23 years old, of 1238 St. Marks Avenue; her friend, who was found on the sidewalk, was identified as Rudy. Hill, 28. He apparently had jumped from the fourthfloor apartment. . . . A rookie transit police officer was charged with the murder of his pregnant wife. The suspect, William O'Connll, 29, was accused of shooting his wife, Alice, 28, in the head in their apartment at 2115 Cross Bronx Expressway. He said the shooting had been an accident. . . . Two armed men took $1,300 from a McDonald's hamburger stand at 508 West 259th Street, in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, after pretending they were looking for jobs and handcuffing the employes. . . A gunman hijacked $25,000 worth of liquor after holding up a truck driver in front of 225 Brook Avenue, the Bronx., The gunman pushed the driver from the truck and drove off with 390 cases of liquor.

title: L.I. Embezzler Gets Up to 14Year Term And $244,000 Fine
description: A 62yearold Valley Stream, L. I., man was fined $244,000 yesterday and sentenced to up to 14 years in jail, for masterminding a fraudulent scheme to get 20 students into medical schools.

title: F. T.C. SUBPOENAS BECTONDICKINSON
description: RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 17 (AP)  BectonDickinson, Inc., said today it had been served with a subpoena from the Federal Trade Commission demanding records of acquisitions over the last 14 years and sales practices over the last six years.

title: Debt and Taxes
description: City Hall officials are reportedly confident that Governor Wilson and the legislative leadership in Albany will go along with Mayor Beame's proposal to borrow $520 million to help cover an estimated $1,5billion deficit in the city's new expense budget. They are not so sure, however, that Albany is prepared to authorize the $64.6 million in new taxes that the Mayor has requested in order to retire the new debt.

title: Chess:
description: One of the most arguable pronouncements of Aron Nimzovich's classis My system is: A typical and very widespread misconception is the assumption of many amateurs that each single move must accomplish something directly; so that such a player will only seek for moves which threaten something, or for a threat to be parried, and will disregard all other moves such as waiting moves, or moves calculated to put his house in order, etc.

title: NCR and CBS Holders Approve Name Change
description: The namechange game among big corporations continues, with the latest entries being the NCR Corporation, which was known as National Cash Register Company, and CBS, Inc., which was the Columbia Broadcasting System.

title: COLSON JOINS PLEA FOR OF NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 Charles W. Colson, former special counsel to President Nixon and one of seven defendants in the Watergate coverup case, asked the United States District Court today to order the President to make available to Mr. Colson the same tapes and documents that the special Watergate prosecution is seeking for use in The trial.

title: 7 Guests Are Arrested At Presentencing Party
description: Seven reputed underworld figures arrested at a goingaway party for a friend about to be sentenced on a weapons conviction were charged yesterday with operating a $24millionayear loansharking business.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs
description: Knicks vs. Boston

title: HIRSCHFELD TERMS INFLATION KEY ISSUE
description: Abraham J. Hirschfeld, a builder who is seeking the Democratic nomination for United States. Senator, said yesterday that inflation and high prices would be the key issues in his campaign.

title: School Vote in Boston
description: BOSTON, April 17 (AP)  Mayor Kevin H. White signed today a petition that would allow the city's residents to determine in a referendum June 4 which of four plans they favor for the reorganization of the school committee.

title: The Bored Child Grew Up To Be Excited About Food
description: PAWLING, N. Y. When I was a kid on the West Side of Manhattan, Joseph Famularo said recently as he thumbed another blob of sausage meat into a hand stuffer, my parents would never think of buying prepared sausages in a store. I remember reading about other communities having sewing circles. He laughed. My mother had sausagemaking circles.

title: Partner of the Elements
description: This is going to be a garden year, as every seed seller can tell you. More people than ever before are going to grow vegetables, hoping to beat inflation or at least to hold it somewhat at bay in the kitchen.
