description: By Reuters ENGLISH. LEAGUE

title: FEW IN SURVEY FAVOR 4 OR MORE CHILDREN
description: The proportion of Americans who favor large families has declined dramatically since 1968, according to the Gallup Poll, and is now at the lowest point in the 38 years that regular surveys on the subject have been conducted.

title: New Hampshire Town Votes To Allow Onassis Refinery
description: NEWMARKET, N. H., April 17 (AP)  Less than twomonths after being rejected in the nearby town of Durham, Aristotle Onassis is ready to try again to build a $600million refinery in New Hampshire, an aide said today.

title: NIXON PICKS SIMON AS TREASURY HEAD BUT LIMITS ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  President Nixon named William E, Simon today to succeed George P. Shultz as Secretary of the Treasury but said he would leave unfilled Mr. Shultz's position as overall rector of economic policy for the Administration.

title: 2 Big U.S. Banks Raise Prime
U.S. Overtime Pay Law Is Called Costly for City
description: City officials are disturbed by a provision of the minimumwage bill signed last week by President Nixon that calls for cash payment, instead compensatory time off for overtime work by public employes.

title: MINE UNION TRIES TO BAR STOCK SALE
description: All day today, a dozen coal miners from the Duke Power Company's Brookside mine in Harlan County, Kentucky, plan to string a picket line across the front door of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Executive's Son Is the 12th Victim in Shooting Whites in San Franciseo Laid to Black Assailants
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 17Op Nov. 25 a series of apparently indiscriminate and senseless shootings began here, and last night the 18th victimthe 13th person to die  was slain by shots in the back.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your April 10 editorial describing Mayor Beame's plan to levy higher taxes on commuters' income earned in the city causes me no little fear.

title: L. I. Display on 2 Dance Adbentures
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 17 For anyone who cares for art, music and the dance Hofstra University, is distinctly the place to go in the next six weeks. For in the Emily Lowe Gallery two great adventures have been documented in an exhibition entitled Diaghilev/Cunningham.

title: Hambletonian Trot Escapes City Lights
description: The Hambietonian, perhaps, rural America's last great sports event, will remain, a rustic spectcular.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: LISTEN TO: The Little People

title: Watergate Is Called Factor In G.O.P Loss in Michigan
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 Republican and Democratic politicians agreed today that the Watergate scandals had contributed substantially to the Republicans' loss yesterday of Michigan's Eighth Congressional Districta House seat held by Republicans uninterruptedly for 40 years.

title: Mrs. Kissinger Called All Right by President
description: WASHINGTON, April. 17 (AP)  President Nixon welcoined Mrs. Henry A. Kissinger to the White House tonight and said of the Secretary of State's bride: She's a little liberal, but otherwise she's an right. The President drew laughter from Latin. American foreign ministers, whom he was addressing at a White House dinner.

title: Pro and College Players Selected in A.B.A. Draft
description: DRAFT LIST VIRGINIA

title: Advertising: CentsOff Coupons
description: Although the longrange benefits of centsoff coupons may be disparaged by some Marketing men, major package goods companies still believe they are the most effective marketing tool for getting people to try products.

title: A. T. & T. Reports 14.1% Income Rise
description: FLEMINGTON, N. J., April 17It Was, a good day for an annual meeting, especially if, you were a Borden, Inc., shareholder a bit hungry and in love with clean air and Elsie the. Cow.

title: State Raises Aid to Relief Clients 11%
description: ALBANY, April 17Governor Wilson today signed into law an 11.8 per cent increase in welfare payments, the first in four years.

title: AEROSOL SPRAYS RECALLED BY P.D.A.
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP)The Food and Drug Administration has announced the recall of 29 more brands of aerosol products containing vinyl chloride.

title: Ban on Pinball Machines Ruled Invalid
description: The city administratve code section that classifies all pinball machines as gambling devices was declared unconstitutional by the Appellate Division because the law does not distinguish between machines that are games of chance and amusement. The 4to1 ruling upset a lower court decision that had approved the refusal by the Department of Consumer Affairs to permit the sale and installation of pinball machines in the city by two manufacturers, Albert Simon, Inc., and the Seaboard New York Corporation. The companies sued the city and then appealed an adverse ruling by the State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: Shabazz's Son Tells of Call Warning of Assassination
description: NEWARK, April 17A son of James McGregor Shabazz said today that Mrs. Shabazz had been told by telephone two weeks before his murder that her husband would be killed The call apparently named the day on which the Black Muslim leader was shot down in the driveway of his home here.

title: Notes on People
description: Bowing to pressure from critics within the church, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Washington has abandoned plans to make a $525,000 mansion the archdiocese is buying his official residence.

title: NEWS INDEX
Beirut Sifts Defense Failure
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 171 (Reuters)A military investigation is under way into the failure of the Lebanese Army to resist an Israeli raid against six Lebanese border villages last Friday, it was officially announced tonight.

title: ITALY VOTES FUNDS TO MAJOR PARTIES
description: ROME, April 17Legislation to subsidize Italy's eight major parties, from the Communists to the neoFascists, was enacted today less than a month after it was introduced in Parliament.

title: DANES TELL U. N. AID MAY GO DOWN
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 7Denmark, which has been under an Arab oil embargo since October, said today that she might not be able to keep up foreign aid at planned levels.

title: HOMOSEXUAL BILL IS RECONSIDERED
description: A City Council committee will consider at a public hearing today a bill to bar discrimination against homosexuals in employment, housing and public accommodations. It will be the fifth such hearing.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Governor Wilson yesterday ordered state acquisition of the abandoned Penn Central railroad line through the Adirondack State Park. The 118mile line was being ripped up for salvage several months ago when the fuel shortage developed and aroused renewed interest in railroads. The demolition was stopped after the state appealed to a Federal District Court overseeing Penn Central bankruptcy proceedings.

title: Bridge:
description: One of the most popular and successful of the local players in Vancouver, British Columbia, in the recent Spring Nationals there was Mike Wilson, a 23yearold stockbroker. In the space of one week, he won a Vanderbilt Knockout match, reached the finals of the men's teams and men's pairs, and earned life master rank.

title: 700Mile Survey Points to 800 Road Perils in State
description: NEWARK, April 17  New Jerseyans whose cars bear bumper stickers reading Pray For Me, I Drive Route 31 and other concerned citizens had their worst fears confirmed today by a 700mile survey of state highways, municipal streets and country roads that revealed approximately 800 safety hazards, or more than one for every mile of roadway examined.

title: Stans Defends Secrecy on Vesco Fund
description: Maurice H. Stans took the witness stand in his own behalf yesterday and swore that he kept Robert L. Vesco's $200,000 cash contribution to President Nixon's reelection campaign a secret because privacy was his constitutional right under law.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 18, 1974

title: LISBON ARRESTS 12 MORE LEFTISTS
description: LISBON, April 18A dozen members of the leftwing political opposition, some of them journalists, were arrested by the police today as the Portuguese Government continued to show a tough attitude toward tbose who oppose its war policy in the nation's African territories.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, April 18The Federal Home Loan Bank Board rescinded today an earlier order that would have increased the liquidity ratio of savings and loan associations effective June 1.

title: Sets Seeking Pilic, Miss Wade
description: The New York Sets are making last minute attempts to land two of the world's top tennis playess, Nikki Pilic of Yugoslavia and Virginia Wade of Britain, before the start of the World Team Tennis season next month.

title: 44,000 Here Face Loss Of Families' Welfare Aid
description: About 5 Per cent of the welfare cases in the category of aid to families with. dependent children, the biggest component of the city's welfare case load, are being dropped because of failure to prove eligibility, state and city officials said yesterday.

title: 12 in Englewood Stage Protest on Sale Of Gulf Gas Station to Saving Institution By JOAN COOK
description: ENGLEWOOD, April 18 A. group of about 12 youngsters, braids bobbing, picket signs aloft, skipped hopped and skittered around in something resembling a circle at Dick's Gulf service station, at 39 Hudson Avenue, to protest Gulf Oil company's sale of the property.

title: FOREIGN SECURITIES
Old Fire Engine Due For New Life in South
description: A tiny Mississippi town whose only fire engine broke down in December will get a used but usable fire engine from New York City for $1.

title: New Subpoena for Tapes Delivered to White House
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 United States District Judge John J. Sirica ordered today the issuing of a subpoena commanding President Nixon to turn over tape recordings and other records of 64 White House conversations relating to the Watergate coverup.

title: HOMOSEXUAL BILL GAINS IN COUNCIL
description: After a threeandahalfyear battle, a bill to ban discrimination against homosexuals in employment, housing and public accommodations was voted out of the City Council's General Welfare Committee yesterglay evening.

title: Savoring Priestley Anew
description: For sheer, surprising Off Off Broadway satisfaction it would be hard to beat Dangerous Corner, a masterly, 1931 melodrama by J. B. Priestley now being served ever so smoothly at the enterprising Lolly's Theater Club, 808 Lexington Avenue (8327404). Here is a play, not an antique. No wonder the British theater is currently undergoing a Priestley revival.

title: Keenan and Worgan Win Promotions in Kuh's Office
description: District Attorney Richard H. Kuh of Manhattan yesterday promoted two longtime members of his office.

title: Fezler Captures Lead by a Shot
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., April 18  Forest Fezler, golf's heartbreak kid of a year ago, put together a fiveunderpar 66 today for the firstround lead in the $150,000 Monsanto open.

title: World of Books Presents Its Oscars
description: The National Book Awards were given to 14 authors last night and burlesqued at the same time by a standup comic who accepted the prize for Thomas Pynchon, the novelist, and a naked man who jogged through Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln Center shouting: Read books! Read books!

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Elinor Guggenheimer, the city's Consumer Affairs Commissioner, urged the Public Service Commission to suspend special charges by the New York Telephone Company for the use of privately purchased residential phones and answering equipment pending a commission review of the interconnect charging system. She called the charges unnecessarily restrictive and anticompetitive. The telephone company contends that such equipment not completely compatible with its network can impair service. Its fees range from $47 to $140 for the first year.

title: P.S.C. Orders Extra Insulation For All New GasHeated Homes
description: ALBANY, April 17All new residential buildings in New York State that use natural gas for heating and all those converting to its use were ordered today by the Public Service Commission to install adequate insulation, beginning next Jan. 1.

title: TV. Wisconsin Kibbutz
description: Kibbutz, Langdon contains 22 young Jewish people attempting a communal return to what they consider the roots of Jewish ritual and identity. This kibbutz, however, is not in Israel but on The Madison campus of the University of Wisconsin. It is the intriguing subject of a halfhour documentarywritten, directed and produced by Arthur Zegartthat will be presented, this Sunday at 1 P.M. on the American Broadcasting Company's Directions series.

title: STRIKES IN CANADA DISRUPT 2 SERVICES
description: OTTAWA, April 18 (Reuters)  Strikes by postal workers and airport firemen spread across Canada today, disrupting mail deliveries and air traffic.

title: Ethiopian Premier Orders Former Officials Detained
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, April 18 (Reuters)Ethiopia's Premier, Endalkachew Moltennen, announced today that security forces had been ordered to place Cabinet ministers of the former Government under house arrest.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE RACHEL PAPERS. By Martin Amis. 228 pages. Knopf. $5.95.

title: Jury Told Defendant Saw Shabazz as an Obstacle
description: NEWARK April 18  The prosecution in the murder trial of Lamont Calloway read into the record today a copy of the defendant's statement in which he allegedly said the victimJames McGregor Shabazz, a Black Muslim leaderhad to be eliminated because he was a major obstacle to the building of a new world of Islam.

title: 2 PROM AIR FORCE OPEN CHILE TRIALS
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 18The first two of the 57 air force men and 10 civilians accused of aiding Marxist parties went on trial today in a military court.

title: Goldin, as Controller, Tries to Shake Politics Tag
description: Harrison J. Goldin has been on the job as Controlle for a bare three months, but that has been time enough to convince virtually everyone at City Hall that he is already off and running for Mayor.

title: Ideas on school Financing Sought by Legislative Unit
description: TRENTON, April 18 The Legislature's Joint Education Committee, under pressure to act in time for a special legislative session scheduled for June, today set May 8 for public hearing to help define a thorough and efficient public education system for all New Jersey's schoolchildren.

title: Matter of Civil Rights
description: The big turnout at yesterday's City Council hearing on a bill to bar discrimination against homosexuals is another indication of the strong emotions generated by a question that has confronted and confounded the Council for several years.

title: REAL ESTATE MAN HELD IN BRITAIN
description: LONDON, April 18Scotland Yard said tonight that the police had detained a key figure in the controversy here over an alleged forgery of the signature of Prime Minister Wilson.

title: Births
description: TROMPETERAllan and Leslya are thrilled to announce the birth of Jason Gary and Michael Adam's beautiful sister. Farra Elise on April 17, 1974.

title: Miss Joan Blumenfeld Bride of John H. Bess
description: Miss Joan Blumenfeld, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Blumenfeld of West Orange, N.J., was married last evening to John H. Bess, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Bess of South Orange, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Ely E. Pilchik, rabbi of Temple B'nai Jeshufun in Short Hills, N.J., performed the ceremony at the Mountain Ridge Country Club in West Caldwell, N,J.

title: One Man Acquitted And One Convicted In Holdup Slaying
description: MORRISTOWN, April 18A man Was convicted today of murdering a Morris Township iquor store clerk during a holdup attempt in 1969. His codefendant was acquitted.

title: In Suffolk's Farm Country, She Does a Man's Job
description: YAPHANK, L.I.The baby pigs looked just adorable and Pamela Murtaugh crouched ?? them when one suddenly snapped at her leg and bit her. Most people would have howled at the pain, but Miss Murtaugh simply shrugged and walked away.

title: Hawks Stun Bruins, 42, In Opener
description: BOSTON, April 18 (AP)A Chicago defenseman, John Marks, split the Boston defense and scored with just over three minutes to play tonight, helping the Black Hawks to a 42 victory over the Bruins in the opener of their fourofsevengame semifinal series.

title: Corrections Aide Resigns
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., April 18 (AP)  Anthony P. Travisono, Rhode Island's corrections department director, said today that he was resigning effective June 30 to become executive director of the American Correctional Association.

title: DISSIDENTS VICTORS AT PACIFIC HOLDING
description: LAS ANGELES, April 18A group that took over control of the Pacific Holding Corporation about two years ago was deposed today by dissidents led by David H. Murdock, a Los Angeles realestate developer.

title: National's Net a Record
description: Trans World Airlines reported yesterday a corporate net loss of $47.3million for the first quarter of the year, and a loss for the airline alone of $62.6million.

title: People and Business Efforts Urged to Avoid Controls
description: Wage and price controls will probably be reimposed in two or three years unless business and labor break the present wave of inflation, according to C. Jackson Grayson Jr., former chairman of the Price Commission.

title: McGee Memorial Today
description: Four executives and broadcasters of the National Broadasting Company will address memorial service at 1 P.M. today for Frank McGee, at rank E. Campbell's Madison Avenue at 81st Street. They are Julian Goodman, chairman of the board; Stuart Schulberg, executive producer of the Today program; Eliot Frankel, executive producer of N.B.C. ewe, and Jim Hartz, WNBCTV news anchorman. Mr. McGee, the newsman who had been host of the Today show since Oct. 12, 1971, died Wednesday at the age of 52.

title: Japan and China to Sign Civil Aviation Accord
description: TOYKO, April 19 (Reuters) Japan and China will sign a civil aviation agreement in Peking tomorrow, a Foreign Ministry spokesman announced here today.

title: U.S. Seems to Ease Stand On Barring Cuba in Talks
description: WASHINGTON, April 18Four LatinAmerican countries proposed today that Cuba be invited to a meering of hemisphere foreign ministers next March. The. United States. did not object, but said that other counties involved should be polled on the issue first.

title: TRACK AND FIELD
description: Colleges

title: Petty Issues Appear to Hamper Ethiopians in Exploiting Big Chance for Reform
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, April 16For the first time in their livesand in the history of their ancient countryEthiopians have freedom. But it seems increasingly doubtful that they know what to do with it.

title: U.S. Ends More Controls
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (Reuters)Several industries tcluding textiles, glass, metal cans, soap, detergents and co:snietics were exempted today from Phase 4 wage and price controls.

title: The Pop Life Janis Ian, '66 Hit. Singer, regressing Nicely in '74
description: Janis Ian's comebackor more accurately her steady maturation as a singer and song writeris progressing nicely. The tiny Miss Ian, who from a distance looks hardly older than the 15 she was at the time of her first and biggest hit, Society's Child, in 1966, is at Max's Kansas City through Monday.

title: Hurdles Relay Mark Set
description: STANFORD, Calif., April 18 (UPI)A Stanford University team broke the world record for the seldomrun onemile intermediate hurdles relay with a time of 3 minutes 37.8 seconds. The old mark was 3:40.5, set two weeks ago by Occidental College.

title: Dance: Graham Protegee
description: With the stunning debut of Takako Asakawa in Martha Graham's original role in Clytemnestra, Miss Graham's fulllength masterpiece, the Graham Dance Company has entered into a new historic phase.

title: Byrne Urges State Pay for Primaries In Governor Races
description: TRENTON, April 18Governor Byrne today proposed extending to primary campaigns his controversial suggestion that the election campaigns of nominees for Governor of New Jersey be financed in part with public funds. His move forces a major legislative confrontation between the advocates of election reform and'the vested interests of the major political parties.

title: The Codding Myth
description: Fear and hatred, once aroused, do not die easily. Those that grew out of and to some extent causedthe revolt at the Attica Correctional Facility in September, 1971, are no different Twoandahalf years after that uprising ended in the deaths of 29 inmates and 10 guards, the bitterness and anger of the time have by no means subsided among those on either side of the prison walls.

title: EGYPT WILL END TOTAL RELIANCE ON SOVIET ARMS
description: CAIRO, April 18President Anwar elSadat announced today that Egypt had decided to end more than 18 years of exclusive reliance on Soviet arms supplies and to seek armaments from other sources.

title: '73 Profit Drop Reversed
description: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio), one of only two large oil companies that had a drop in profits in the last quarter at 1973, announced a 29 per cent increase in earnings for the first three months compared with the same period in 1973.

title: 2 Records Broken At Kansas Relays
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., April 18 (UPI)  Bruce Jenner, former Graceland College star, shattered the meet's decathlon record and Phil Ndoo of Eastern New Mexico set a meet standard for the sixmile run today in the Kansas Relays.

title: Gasification Venture Set
description: HOUSTON, April 18 (UPI)Fourteen American companies have formed a venture to build a coal gasification pilot plant at Westfield, Scotland, at a cost of $10million, it was announced today. The venture will test the new British high pressure slagging process of gasifying coal. It will be operated by the British gas company. The Continental Oil Company heads the, group of American sponsoring companies.

title: OUTPUT OF NEW CARS RISES 18.2% IN WEEK
description: DETROIT, April 18American auto plants are scheduled to produce 158,410 cars this week, down 2 per cent, or 3,250 units, from the 161,660 cars assembled in the corresponding week last year.

title: Searching of Visitors Begun at Tombs As Police Seek 4 Who Tried to Free 3
description: Body searches were put into effect for alt inmates' visitors at the Manhattan House of Detention for Men yesterday as the police hunted two men, and two women who tried to free three, prisoners Wednesday night with an acetylene torch.

title: Ransom Find Brings U.S. Indictment of 2
description: NEWARK, April 18 (UPI)Two Penn Central employes were indicted today on charges that they had found and illegally kept $50,000 in ransom money intended for the release of an 8year old Dix Hills, L.I., boy, and then had lied about the ransom money to a Federal grand perjury.

title: Hundreds of Coast Blacks Frisked in Hunt for Killers
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 18Hundreds of young black men were being stopped on the street, searched and questioned today as the police sought for suspects in a series of killings here.

title: Stocks on Amex Continue to Advance
description: Prices on, the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market continued to climb yesterday for the third consecutive session. Volume was slightly lower on the Amex and up somewhat on the counter market.

title: Penders of Tufts Takes Columbia Basketball Job By MICHAEL STRAUSS
description: In a move that it is hoped will enable Columbia University to regain Ivy League basketball prestige, Tom Penders was named as the Lions' new varsity coach yesterday.

title: Pay of G.M.'s Chief Up $48,037 To $923,000 in '73, a 5.5% Rise
description: DETROIT, April 18 The General Motors Corporation disclosed today that its chairman, Richard C. Gerstenberg, received a 5,5 per cent raise last year, lifting his total compensation by $48,037 to $923,000 and keeping him well in the lead as the highest paid executive in the country.

title: Dining OutNormally, the Comments Wouldn't Be Made
description: I have a few words to say, beginning with excellent and most pleasant, about Oggi, an Italian restauraht at 1606 First Avenue near 83rd Street, but I'd like to get around to them ?? a few less happy comments on Pescatore Veneto at 56 West 56th Street.

title: Alcoa's Profits Rose by 115% in Quarter
2 GROUPS DIVIDED ON JOBS PROGRAM
description: WASHINGTON, April 18The job training law enacted last December as part of the Federal revenue sharing program was praised by one organization today and attacked by anther.

title: Steinbrenner Aide Pleads Guilty To Hiding '72 Nixon Contribution
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (UPI)The executive vice president of the American Ship Building Company pleaded guilty today to concealing an illegal $25,000 contribution to President Nixon's reelection campaign.

title: Roger W. Rowland, Trustee Of Penn State 33 Years, Dies
description: Roger W. Rowland, president emeritus of the board of trustees of the Pennsylvania State University, University Park, Pa., died Sunday at the Jameson Memorial Hospital, New Castle, Pa. He was 79 years old and lived in New Castle.

title: OPEC HEAD EXPECTS LOWER OIL OUTPUT
description: LONDON, April 18 (UPI)The Secretary General of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries predicted today that there would be a significant cutback in oil production by the group's member countries.

title: U.S. Seems to Ease Stand On Barring Cuba in Talks
description: WASHINGTON, April 18pour LatinAmerican countries proposed today that Cuba be invited to a meeting of hemisphere foreign ministers next March. The United States did not object, but said that other countries involved should be polled on the issue first.

title: MRS. KERMIT KITMAN
description: Mrs. Claire Cohen Kitman, wife of Kermit Kitman, former outfielder with the Montreal Royals of the International League, died Tuesday of cancer in Montreal. She was 47 years old.

title: BANKING BILL KILLEL BY STATE ASSEMBLY
description: ALBANY, April 18The Assembly, after a vigorous debate, killed the reciprocal banking bill that would have allowed outofstate bankholding companies to acquire branches in New York and New York banks to operate in other states.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: MITTERRAND BIDS FOR CENTER VOTE
description: PARIS, April 18The Socialist leader, Franois Mitterrand, promised today to strengthen the franc, protect savers against the erosion of inflation reform the tax structure and promote expoits in a revised financial program that he hoped would attract votes from the center in the presidential election next month.

title: Split Wood May Draw 21 Horses
description: There are no two ways about it, the Wood Memorial tomorrow at Aqueduct will be run in two divisions. When the slips are put into the entry box this morning for the premier 3yearold race of the local thinoughbred campaign, the expectation is that a score of names, give or take one or two, will be submitted.

title: Hospital Emergency
description: The State Senate is considering a bill that would require medical insurers to underwrite part of the losses sustained by voluntary hospitals in the operation of their emergency and outpatient facilities. Since it appears that Federal law will not permit charging of such costs to Medicaid, the task would essentially fall to Blue Cross.

title: Project Sanguine Suspended by Navy; Pentagon Sees End
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)  Yielding to opposition, the Navy has suspended development of Project Sanguine, a vast underground system for sending emergency messages to missilefiring submarines.

title: U.S. Prisons to Ease Curb On Interviews With Inmates
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)  The Bureau of Prisons has decided to allow reporters to interview prisoners in minimum security Federal institutions.

title: GEORGE J. LENT DIES; SCHOOLS' SPOKESMAN
description: George J. Lent, who retired last year as a spokesman for the. Board of Education, died yesterday in St. Anthony's Hospital, Warwick, N. Y., after a long illness. He was 64 years old and lived at Greenwood Lake, N. Y.

title: Colombians Enthusiastic on Eve of Free Elections
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, April 18 Rafael Misas Bravo is a 50yearold mechanic who has voted with this nation's political Establishment all, his life. But he is planning to cast his ballot for the antiEstablishment opposition in next Sunday's presidential election because he feels the country needs a change.

title: 2 ExRivals Sue Rep. Rooney, On Their Defeats in Primaries
description: Two former political rivals of Representative John J Rooney of Brooklyn filed sep?? civil suits yesterday, ??ng that he had used ??gally derogatory information supplied by the Federal Bureau of Investigation to defeat them in Democratic primary election.

title: Backstage Fire at Shubert
description: Stagehands put out a small backstage electrical fire during last night's performance of Over Here! at the Shubert Theater on West 44th Street. The musical, starring the Andrews Sisters, was not interrupted and there was no panic, but several dozen patrons abandoned front orchestra seats to escape the effects of some smoke and watched the show from the back of the house.

title: KARPOV WINS GAME; CHESS MATCH IS TIED
description: MOSCOW, April 18 (AP)Anatoly Karpov, Russia's 22yearold chess champion, defeated Boris Spassky, a former world champion, in the third game of their semifinal world championship match today and tied the contest at 11.

title: Rodino Bars Compromise On Tapes Under Subpoena
description: WASHINGTON, April 18The chairman of the House Judiciary Committee ruled out today any comromise with the White House over the committee's demand for tape recordings of some 42 Watergaterelated conversations.

title: G.N.P. DROPPED 5.8% IN FIRST QUARTER AS INFLATION ROSE
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 The nation's total output of goods and services dropped in the first quarter of this year by the largest amount since the recession of 1958, the Commerce Department reported today. The decline was at an annual rate of 5.8 per centsomewhat more than had been generally forecast at the begining of the year.

title: Charges Against Rizzo Police Force. May Prove to Damag e Him Politically
description: PHILADELPHIA, April. 16 Over lunch one day last year, Frank Rizzo was listing a few of the things that bother him about being Mayor of the nation's fourth largest city.

title: Rangers Wipe Out 20 Deficit at Garden And Win, 52, to Eliminate Canadiens
description: Next stop, Philadelphia!

title: Home TV Backed By F.C.C.
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)The Federal Communications Commission, in a report to Congress, says the lifting of the television blackout on soldout home football games had a minimal effect on National Football League teams.

title: $582,000 AVIS LOSS LISTED FOR QUARTER
description: Avis, Inc., reported yesterday a loss of $582,000 for the first quarter, in contrast to a gain of $2million, or 33 cents a share, for the 1973 period.

title: JULIUS B. PERLMUTTER
description: Julius B. Perlmutter, who retired 15 years ago as head of J. B. Perlmutter Associates, Inc., merchandise brokers, died yesterday at Coney Island Hospital in Brooklyn. His age was 87, and he lived at 200 East 18th Street, Brooklyn.

title: Assembly Kills Move for Open Display Of Contraceptive Devices in Pharmacy
description: ALBANY, April 18  A bill that would have allowed contraceptives to be displayed on pharmacy shelves was defeated in the Assembly today after along debate in which opponents asserted that such displays would lead to greater promiscuity among the young.I'm surprised they allow People to sell beds in this state, the bill's sponsor, Mrs. Constance E. Cook, said acidly as she watched her bill being attacked from both sides of the aisle.

title: Antiques at Morristown Mix Old and NotSoOld
description: MORRISTOWN, April 18A pleasant blend of the old and notsoold, with collector's items in both groups, characterizes the annual antiques show that opened yesterday at the National Guard Armory here on Western Avenue. The show runs through Sunday.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS April 18, 1974
description: New York843097

title: A Grenade Thrown at Arabs in Tel Aviv Injures 13
description: TEL AVIV, April 18A hand gren de exploded this morning in group of Arabs on a street corner in a suburb of Tel Aviv, injuring 12 Arabs and one Jew.

title: Fezler Captures Lead by Shot
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., April 18 heartbreak kid of a year ago, put together a fiveunderpar 66 today for the firstround lead in the $150,000 Monsanto open.

title: People in Sports
description: Bill Shoemaker, one of America's premier jockeys, will endeavor to celebrate the 25th anniversary of his first victory tomorrow with a stakes triumph when he rides at Golden Gate Fields in California  the track at which he entered the winner's circle for the first time.

title: Notes on People
description: What's in a name? (1) Mrs. Susan Rowen, daughter of Senator George McGovern, has petitioned a court in Madison, Wis., to restore her maiden name legally, on grounds it would be adventageous both socially and in business. In a second petition, filed by Mrs. Rowen, a student and housewife, and her husband, James Rowen, assistant to the Mayor of Madison, the court was asked to change the name of their 2yearold son, Matthew David Rowen, to Matthew David McGovernRowen. As for Mr. Rowen, he plans to hang on to his name as is.... (2) The Appellate Division of the New York's Supreme Court has unanimously upheld the right of Charles F. Berlitz, a linguist and author of many language books, to use his own name in his work. The decision followed a protracted, sevenyear court fight between Mr. Berlitz, grandson of the founder of the Berlitz language schools, and Macmillan, Inc., the publishing company that acquired control of the schools in 1966 and claimed Berlitz as a trademark. Macmillan sought to prevent Mr. Berlitz from using his own name in connection with any books on language.

title: EGYPT WILL END TOTAL RELIANCE ON SOVIET ARMS
description: CAIRO, April 18President Anwar elSadat announced to day that Egypt had decided to end more than 18 years of exclusive reliance on Soviet arms supplies and to seek armaments from other sources.

title: Big Board Prices Edge Up on Mixed Economic News
description: The stock market posted its third consecutive advance yesterday despite mixed economic news.

title: People and Business
description: Wage and price controls will probably be reimposed in two or three years unless business and labos break the present wave of inflation, according to C. Jackson Grayson Jr., former chairman of the Price Commission.

title: Mr. Teng's Visit
description: WASHINGTON, April 18A few days ago, Teng Hsiaoping, the new 70yearold Deputy Premier of China, flew to New York, had a long private conversation with Secretary of State Kissinger and flew back to Peking again as suddenly as he arittred.

title: HUGHES JURY IS TOLD FUNDS WERE SHIFTED
description: LOS ANGELES, April 18Attorneys for the Summa Corporation contended today that Robert A. Maheu had spent $149,338 of HoWard R. Hughes's money to pay people who worked in Mr. Maheu's businesses.

title: Bradley Gaylord, Mrs. Nichols. Wed
description: Mrs. Lila N. Nichols of Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday afternoon in the nondenominational Unity Church of the Palm Beaches to Bradley Gaylord, retired president and chairman of the board of the Pennroad Corporation, now the Madison Fund, Inc. The Rev, Hal Rosencranz performed the ceremony.

title: The Wood Is Full of 'Em
description: The Wood Memorial, New York's richest and most searching test for Kentucky Derby candidates, has, its 50th and 51st runnings at Aqueduct tomorrow, or else its 53d and 54th. The race is 49 years old, and how you count its renewals depends on how you rank Grover Cleveland numericallyas our 22d and 24th. President? For the fourth time since it was inaugurated, the Wood has so many probable starters (21 up to last night) that it will be split into two divisions. It is, perhaps, a footnote on inflation that instead of halving the purse as well as the field, management will dip into its pants for the advertised sum of $100,000 in added money for each division.

title: Hundreds of Coast Blacks Frisked in Hunt for Killers
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 18Hundreds of young black men were being stopped on the street, searched and questioned today as the police sought for suspects in a series killings here.

title: Bridge: Playing in One Club Leads To Regret in Many Instances
description: An observer from outer space who embarked on a sociological comparison of the United States and Italy would collect some interesting if puzzling fragments of information. The Italians have older buildings but smaller cars, he would note, they use a spoon more in eating and they never play contracts of one club.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: WEST PATERSON, April 18For most of Marty Katzen's life, medical and nonmedical people have been advising him that he should not be too active physically because of childhood kidney surgery.

title: A GM IN TOURISM PREDICTED BY CITY
description: In the books of hoteliers and others who purvey pleasures to New York's visitors, 1973 was recorded as a good year and 1974 promises to be an even better year.

title: Electric Delivery Vehicles Planned for Postal Service
description: DETROIT, April 18  The American Motors Corporation announced today that its subsidiary, the A. M. General Corporation, had been awarded $2million contract to build 350 quarterton electric delivery vehicles for the Postal Service.

title: Chinese Troubled on U.S. Ties
description: TORONTOWhile many Western journalists have diligently attempted to report recent developments in relations between China and the United States and the Chinese domestic campaign,against Lin Piao and Confucius, the esoterica to which attention has been paid has often seemed ludicrous. They have overlooked the forest while focusing on each tree.

title: DR. A. WILLIAM BLUEM.
description: SYRACUSE, April 18 (UPI)Dr. A. William Bluem, professor of media studies at the Newhouse School of Public Communications at Syracuse University, died Tuesday at CrouseIrving Memorial Hospital. He was 48 years old.

title: Union Leaders Ask City to Reestablish Labor Department
description: Organized labor here is opening a campaign to get Mayor Beame and the City Council to reestablish a labor department in the city government headed by a commissioner.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: HELSINKI, Finland, April 18 (UPI)The Soviet Union rallied with three goals in the second period to defeat Czechoslovakia, 31, today and took sole possession of first place in the world ice hockey championships. Both teams have one more game to play Saturday. Should Sweden beat the Russians, along with Czechoslovakia beating Finland, the title would be decided on the goal average for the two SovietCzechoslovak games and Czechoslovakia would win. If the Russians win Saturday, they win the tournament.Today's game was rough and fast. Jiri Holik put the Czechoslovaks ahead at 3 minutes 20 seconds on a power play. The Czechoslovaks appeared content to protect the advantage with tight defense. The tactic worked until midway into the second period when the Russians exploded.Boris Mihailov made it 11, then Aleksandr Jakushev scored on a linedrive for the Russian lead.

title: Byron Still Greek Hero 150 Years After He Died
description: ATHENS, April 18Along with Zeus, Hermes and the rest of the crowd from Olympus, one of the great figures of Greek mythology is an Englishman who died here 150 years ago tommorowGeorge Gordon, Lord Byron.

title: 1st State Chairman Of G.O.P. Requests That Nixon Resign
description: BOSTON, April 18 (AP) The head of the Massachusetts Republican State Committee has become the first Republican state, chairman in the nation to ask for President Nixon's resignation.

title: CookPowell Team Wins
description: NORTH CALDWELL, N.J., April 18 Harry Cook and Miles Powell of Glen Ridge combined to capture the New Jersey Golf Association's Hickey Booster tournament today with a low gross score of 39, 3675. A total of 49 teams competed over the 6,298yard course with a par of 35, 3671, Jacques Cooper and John Palumbo of Colonia took netscore honors with a 30, 3565.

title: Guide GOING OUT
description: JAZZ Two of the longestrunning regular jazz series in town do their jamming from noon to 3 every Friday. Jazz at Noon, which turns loose in the Rough Rider Room of the Hotel Roosevelt, Madison Avenue and 45th Street (MU 69200), has a special guest on tap: Buddy Rich, who has just opened his own club in New York. It's a return for Mr. Rich, who has played this seminar before, as have other jazz notables. The players are usually jazz men who work in other fields and do this as a thankGodit'sFriday ritual. Admission: $1.75; you buy a sandwich or whatever and drink.

title: HEARST ASSAILS SAM REMARKs
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 18Randolph A. Hearst today denounced Attorney General Wilham B. Saxbe for referring his kidnapped daughter, Patricia Hearst, as a common criminal.

title: Bonn's Atlantic Decision
description: The critical debate on both sides of the Atlantic over the future relationship between the United States and a uniting West Europe has subsided under the uncertainties of the French presidential election. But, whatever the election's outcome, the shape of this relationship is more likely to be determined by the weight of opinion in the other eight nations of the Common Market, where resistance to French advocacy of a superindependent Europe has stiffened.

title: A.B.A. Playoffs
description: April 13Utah 105, Ind. 96.

title: Kraftco Dividend Up 3.8c
description: The Kraftco Corporation announced yesterday that it was increasing its quarterly dividend to 48 cents a share from 44.2 cents, a rise of 3.8 cents.

title: Franklin New York Shows Profit Drop To 2 Cents Per Share
description: The Franklin New York Corporation, parent of the Franklin National sank, announced yesterday that in the first quarter of this year its net income before securities transactions was $77,000, or 2 cents a share, compared with $3,038,000, or 66 cents a share, for the same period of 1973.

title: Wood, Field & Stream Turkey Hunting in Springtime
description: Spring turkey hunting might jar the sensibilities of those who think of an early settler trudging through a preThanksgiving snow with a handsome gobbler over his shoulder, but it is perhaps the loveliest time of year to hunt this country's wiliest game bird.

title: Vietcong Aides in Saigon Being Isolated, Hanoi Says
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 18 (AP)  Vietcong delegates say the South Vietnamese Government is isolating them in their compound at Saigon air base and sabotaging the TwoParty Joint Military Commission, Radio Hanoi said today.

title: Wednesday's Fights
description: By The Associated Press

title: Nixon and Kissinger Talk With Egyptian on Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, April 18President Nixon conferred with Foreign Minister Ismail Falimy of Egypt today on the Middle East situation, particularly the prospects for a troopsepration agreement between Syria and Israel.

title: Pro Transactions
description: FOOTBALL

title: Nixon Nominates Woman To Highest Education Post
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 President Nixon nominated a college official today as the first woman to be the Government's highest education officer.

title: PRINTERS AT NEWS START SLOWDOWN
Phillies' Streak Ended By a Hitting Pitcher
description: The National League's reluctance to adopt the designatedhitter rule was a benefit to at least one team, the St. Louis Cardinals, last night.

title: Western Oil Concerns Shift to Minority Roles Abroad
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 18 The acceptance by Exxon and Mobil of Libya's 51 per cent nationalization of their oil concessions signals an important shift by major Western oil companies toward minority partnership in foreign oil ventures.

title: Jaworski Said to Get Data On Nixon's Tax Returns
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (UPI) The Internal Revenue Service has submitted its records of the investigation of President Nixon's tax returns to the special Watergate prosecutor, Leon Jaworski, it was reported today.

title: Knicks Gamble on Trying It Without DeBusschere Tonight
description: With the Knicks trailing the Boston Celtics, 2 games to 0, and desperately needing a victory tonight at Boston in the National Basketball Association's Eastern Conference championship series, Coach Red Holzman will take a desperate gamble.

title: Oil Ownership Shifts
description: Acceptance by Exxon and Mobil of Libya's 51 per cent nationalization of their oil concessions is seen signaling an important shift by major Western oil companies toward minority partnership in foreign oil ventures. Details on Page 55.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS
description: New York843097

title: Music: 20th for Pollikoff
description: The violin recital that Max Pollikoff offered on Wednesday evening at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. was in a double sense celebratory, even if the music itself was mostly rather austere. The program was presented both in honor of the Y's 100th anniversary and of the 20th anniversary of Mr. Pollikoff's Music in Our Time series, which over the course of its existence has introduced more than 250 new works and a host of other worthy contemporary.

title: Penders of Tufts Takes Columbia Basketball Job
description: In a move that it is hoped will enable Columbia University to regain Ivy League basketball prestige,. Tom Penders was named as the Lions' new varsity coach yesterday.

title: Rockefeller Aide Denies Plan to Finance Wilson
description: ALBANY, April 18 Former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller's office denied today as absurd the contention that he intends to bankroll heavily Governor Wilson's election campaign this year.

title: POTATO FUTURES DECLINE BY LIMIT
description: Under the impact of 154 unfilled sell orders remaining from Wednesday's trading session, May potato futures dropped the 50point limit yesterday to close at 17 cents pound. The preceding day's close on the New York Mercantile Exchange was 17.50.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: Marcel Pagnol Dies at 79; Filmed the Fanny Trilogy
description: PARIS, April 18Marcel Pagnol, the filth director and playwright, died today of a long illness at his Paris mansion, on the Avenue Foch. He was 79 years bid.

title: MORRIS O. STRAUSBERG
description: Morris O. Strausberg, president of the Interboro Theaters Circuit, Inc., 1501 Broadway, for the last 12 years, died Wednesday of a heart attack at his home, 6 Turtle Cove Lane, Kings Point, L.I. His age was 62.

title: Manhattan Vistas and Debris, in Photos
description: Rapid changes in the urban environment may sometimes depress and disorient the average citizen, but there is one class of citizens for whom such changes have unquestionably served as a fecund source of esthetic inspiration: the photographers. Especially in Manhattan, where the combined energies of the wrecker's ball and the, realestate developer have made every surviving fragment of the past a sentimental souvenir, if not a priceless treasure, the photographer has emerged as both chronicler and curator of the city's visual history.

title: Abducted Italian, 16, Freed
description: MILAN, Italy, April 18 (Reuter)Kidnappers today released Fazio Longhi, 16yearold son of a Milan industrialist, after holding him for two months, the police said. The family was reported to have paid a ransom.

title: Fans' Lullaby: Good Night, Canadiens
description: The New York Rangers solemnly shook hands with the Montreal Canadiens and exited from the ice in singlefile, their eyes on the ground as if they were in a funeral procession.

title: Destruction by Iraq Of 11 Kurdish Towns Reported by Rebels
description: TEHERAN, Iran, April 18 (AP) The Kurdish rebel radio reported today that Iraqi planes destroyed 11 Kurdish villages in northern Iraq yesterday, and that the Kurds had killed 20 Iraqi soldiers including a general.

title: News Summary and Index
description: President Anwar elSadat of Egypt announced that Egypt would end more than 18 years of exclusive reliance on Soviet arms and seek arms from other sources. Mr. Sadat said he made the decision because the Soviet Union had not acted on Egyptian arms requests during the last six months. Though he did not name alternative suppliers, Arab diplomats indicated Egypt would seek arms from Arab oil nations. [1:8.]

title: REV. WILLIAM LINDGREN
description: The Rev, William W. Lindgren, director of television and radio for the Paterson (N. J.) Roman Catholic Diocesan communications center at Morristown, died April 11 of a heart ailment aboard the liner Rotterdam, on a cruise to Puerto Rico. His age was 47.

title: Mets Lose To Expos; 7th in Row
description: MONTREAL, April 18A disastrous road trip to Canada came to an end in cold, windy Jarry Park today when the Expos beat the New York Mets, 85.

title: Italian Ministry Rejects Judge's Bid to Have Met Vase Examined
description: ROME, April 18The Ministry of Justice has turned down a request by an investigating judge to have the disputed Euphronios vase in the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New, York examined by a team of Italian archeologists and scientists, it was learned today.

title: The Sins of Wages
description: Friends of Harold Geneen may rest assured that he will be able to get by Last year he got a $19 a week increase. If he had been paid at the Federal minimum wage rate, he would have been getting, for forty hours, $64. A $19 increase would then have meant a boost of 30 per cent.

title: Financial Dealings Investigated At Bankrupt Hospital in Miami
description: MIAMI, April 18The Dade County State Attorney, Richard E. Gerstein, began an investigation today into the bankrupt Cedars of Lebanon Hospital.

title: Off Off Broadway
description: It is advisable to telephone theaters for schedules and prices. Most, if not all, theaters accept Theater Development Fund vouchers.

title: Advertising: Executives' Edition
description: After two years of preparation and a $1million investment, Newsweek will this fall start its first major demographic editionExecutive News week.

title: Animal Feed Oils Tainted by Insecticide Recalled
description: Several hundred thousand pounds of vegetable and animal oils, intended for mixing with the feed of chickens and other animals but contaminated with the insecticide dieldrin, have been recalled from sale by dealers hi Mississippi ami Arkansas, spokesmen for the Food and Drug Administration said yesterday.

title: GEORGE BROWN
description: PORTLAND, Ore., April 18 (UPI)George Brown, an Oregon labor leader for 40 years and one of the early powers in the International Woodworkers of America, died Wednesday. He was 71 years old.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 39

title: Syrians and Israelis Using Jets in Battle For Mount Hermon
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, April 16 Syrian and Israeli forces battling for control of Mount Hermon today sent jet planes into action against each other. The Syrian command said It was its first use of aircraft since the October war.

title: ARE REINSTATED
description: BOSTON, April 18  In an apparent reaction to mounting outrage within the medical community, the Boston Board of Health and Hospitals reinstated today three doctors who were suspended last week from Boston City Hospital after they were indicted for their work on legally, aborted human fetuses.

title: Goldin, as Controller, Tries to Shake Politics Tag
description: Harrison J. Goldin has been on the job as Controlle for a bare three months, but that has been time enough to convince virtually everyone at City Hall that he is already off and running for Mayor.

title: Fund Redemptions Up
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (Reuters)Redemptions of mutual fund shares exceeded sales in. March by $49.7million, the Investment Company Institute reported today. This compared with net redemptions of $87.9million in February and $12.1million in March of last year.

title: NEWS INDEX
Betsy Cullen Leads in Golf by 2 Shots
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., April 18That Capricious west Wind, gathering force as it howls through San Gorgoniel Pass on its way to Indio, harassed the field today and put a premium on experience as the 72hole ColgateDinah Shore Win. ners Circle women's golf tournament got under way.

title: Syrians and Israelis Using Jets in Battle For Mount Hermon
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, April 16 Syrian and Israeli forces bate tling for control of Mount Hermon today sent jet planes into action against each other, The Syrian command said it was its first use of aircraft since the October war.

title: TIME INC RAISES ITS EARNINGS 23%
description: Time Inc. announced a 23 per cent increase in its firstquarter earnings at its annual meeting here yesterday, as strong performances by the publishing and forest products divisions pushed profits to a record $10.4million, or $1.01 per share.

title: Slipped DISC
description: The tax bill passed by Congress in 1971 provided for a tax device known as the Domestic International Sales Corporation (or DISC) aimed at spurring exports. Any American company selling some of its products abroad could set up a DISC, export through it and defer indefinitely the taxes on half of its exportrelated profits.

title: Dance: Rodin in Motion
description: The Harkness Ballet had a muchneeded success at the Harkness Theater on Wednesday night with the world premiere of Margo Sappington's. Rodin, Mis en Vie.

title: GRAFT PROSECUTOR LINKED TO THREAT
description: TRENTON, April 18A state police detective said today that he had been threatened by a deupty attorney general with a possible loss of pension if he testified for the defense in a Passaic County policecorruption trial.

title: Judge Moritt Indicted for Conspiracy
description: Civil Court Judge Fred G. Moritt was indicted and arrested yesterday on charges of consiracy, perjury, grand larcency and witnesstampering in what the 68yearold judge condmned as a vile conspiracy by the special state prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari.

title: RONAN IS ELECTED HEAD OF PORT UNIT
description: Dr. William J. Ronan was unanimously elected chairman of the Port authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday, and the prosperous bistate agency simultaneously announced its dedication to improve mass transit in the region.

title: Theater: Shrewd Look at Lives of British Royalty
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music is ending its threemonth British Theater Season with two anthology evenings from the Royal Shakespeare Cowpony. Last night the R.S.C. offered The Hollow Crown and on Sunday will come Pleasure and Repentance.

title: Energy Office's Tough Manager John Crittenden Sawhill
description: WASHINGTON, April 18John C. Sawhill faces a peculiar problem as the new head of the Federal Energy, Officeto prove that he is what other executives approvingly call a tough manager.

title: John Henry Lewis, Boxer, Dies; Ex LightHeavyweight Champ
description: BERKELEY, Cali., April 18 (AP)John Henry, Lewis, lightheavyweight boxing champion of the world from 1935 to 1939, died here, Sunday after a long illness. He held the 175pound title through five successful defenses. He was 59 years old.

title: Data Sought Fror Nixon.
description: WASHINGTON, April 18Following is a description of evidence being sought from President Nixon in separate subpoenas issued by the House Judiciary Committee, Judge John J. Sirica of the United States District Court and the Senate Watergate Committee:

title: New Subpoena for Tapes Delivered to White House
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 United States District Judge John J. Sirica ordered today the issuing of a subpoena cornmanding President Nixon to turn over tape recordings and other records of 64 White House conversations relating to the Watergate coverup.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: NoFault Command
description: The Vietnamese hamlet of My Lai has faded from American consciousnessa memory as distant and distasteful as the war itself. Thus, the reduction of First Lieut. William L. Calley's sentence from twenty to ten years, ordered by Secretary of the Army Howard H. Callaway, may seem faintly irrelevantunless a case involving coldblooded murder transcends questions of topicality.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Oral Roberts's Mother Dies
description: TULSA, Okla., April 18 (UPI)  Claudius Roberts, mother of Oral Roberts, the evangelist, died yesterday at the infirmary of University Village, where she was a resident.

title: CONTROL AND GRACE IN MISS ITO'S DANCE
description: With a backbone of welltempered steel and a wardrobe of gorgeous costumes, Sachiyo Ito conducted a tastefully exciting survey of Japanese dance on Wednesday evening at Japan House. Her guest artist, the koto player Fusakb Yoshida, provided musical interludes between Miss Ito's solos.

title: STANLEY M. WARD
description: Stanley M. Ward, a retired architect, who had been with Ferrenz & Taylor here, died yesterday in St. Mary's Hospital, Orange, N. J. He was 80 years cold and lived in East Orange.

title: 10% PRIME SETBY 3 MORE BANKS
description: The move to a 10 per cent prime ratethe interest charged top corporate borrowersgained further ground yesterday with three of the nation's 20 largest banks lifting their interest cost to that level from the 10 per cent rate that went into effect generally only a little more than a week ego.

title: Medich Sharp as Yanks Win, 61
description: When George Medich pitched in Cleveland last Saturday, he had Whitey Ford confused.

title: PRINTERS AT NEWS START SLOWDOWN
description: Typographical Union No. 6 began a slowdown at The Daily News yesterday after being released from two court injunctions that had enjoined the local from interfering with operadons at The News or The New York Times.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Angry inmates at the Vroom Building, a maximum security wing of Trenton State Prison, ripped up plumbing yesterday and scattered debris around a cellblock in the second consecutive day of disturbances at the facility. spokesman for the state Department of Institutions and Agencies, which operates the prison, said that between nine and 12 inmates on the first floor began tearing toilets up by the roots about 2 P.M.

title: ARGENTINA DECREES PAYMENTS ON BANKS
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 18 (Reuters)Argentina has set compensation sums to be paid to foreign banks for holdings here expropriated on March 25, la Presidential decree said today.

title: About New York Debating a Bill Called Intro 2
description: In general, it was the orthodox yesterday who opposed a bill to prohibit discrimination against homosexuals, and the unorthodox who did not. Still, the lines were blurred, and the testimony everyone gave was not always edifying. Sometimes, in fact, it was arcane.

title: G.N.P. DROPPED 5.8% IN FIRST QUARTER AS INFLATION ROSE
description: WASHINGTON, April 18The nation's total output of goods and services dropped in the first quarter of this year by the largest amount since the recession of 1958, the Commerce Department reported today. The decline was at an annual rate of 5.8 per centsomewhat more than had been generally forecast at the begining of the year.

title: Pay of G.M.'s Chief Up $48,037 To $923,000 in '73, a 5.5% Rise
description: DETROIT, April 18 The General Motors Corporation disclosed today that its chairman, Richard C. Gerstenberg, received a 5.5 per cent raise last year, lifting his total compensation by $48,037 to $923,000 and keeping him well in the lead as the highest paid executive in the country.

title: INFORMATION BILL BACKED IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, April 18Agreement on a freedomofinformation bill, which for the first time would mandate the opening of state and local government records to public scrutiny, was announced today and Republican sponsors in both houses of the Legislatures predicted passage of the measure late next week.

title: Man Survives 140Foot Fall
description: FALL RIVER, Mass., April 18 (UPI)A Warren, R. I., man fell 140 feet from a bridge into the Taunton Rivertoday and sur vived. The police identified him as Carl Casale, 50 years old. He told the police that he had felt sick and had, been leaning over a railing on the Braga Bridge when he fell. He was taken to St. Ann's Hospital, where his condition was listed as good.

title: Une De Mai Arrives Here
description: Une de Mai, the trotting mare, arrived here from Paris yesterday and will be manned today to Stoner Creek Stud in Paris, Ky, She is to mate with Nevele Pride, the great trotter.

title: Gertrude Williams, Writer And Educator, Dies at 89
description: Gertrude Marvin Williams, a writer and educator, who had been a reporter on The New York Evening Sun, died Tuesday at Stapeley Hall, a home in Philadelphia. She was 89 years old.

title: M'CRACKEN DOUBTS RECESSION THREAT
description: Business activity during 1974 looks better than it did a few months ago and a recession now looks unlikely, Paul W. McCracken, professor of business administration at the University of Michigan, said yesterday.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: About 5 per cent of the welfare cases in the category of aid to families with dependent children, the biggest component of the city's welfare case load, are being dropped because of failure to prove eligibility, city and state officials said.

title: Navy and Air Force Lag in Gaining Technical Sophistication
description: The Navy and the Air Force, though both are traditionally volunteer forces, have found the transition to allvolunteer status anything but simple.

title: 54 Officers Facing Police Trial After Sleeping on Job Inquiry
description: Fiftyfour police officers, ineluding six sergeants, will be brought to trial within the Police Department and 41 more face disciplinary action as a resuit of a cooping investigation last month in which police investigators roamed through all of the city precincts over a period of 10 nights to check on the performance of the officers on ditty.

title: MISTRIAL MOTION FOR 5 WITHDRAWN
description: Attorneys for the five men charged with murdering Police Officers Waverly Jones and Joseph Piagentini moved for a mistrial yesterday because of the attempted breakin at the Tombs, and then withdrew the motion after the jurors had been questioned.

title: Sets Seeking Pilic, Miss Wade
description: The New York Sets are making lastminute attempts to land two of the world's top tennis players. Nikki Pilic of Yugoslavia and Virginia Wade of Britain, before the start of the World Team Tennis season next month.

title: WILSON IN ULSTER ON SURPRISE VISIT
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 18Prime Minister Wilson paid a surplice visit to Northern Ireland today and warned terrorists that they would achieve nothing by violence.

title: Betsy Cullen Leads in Golf by 2 Shots
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., April 18That capricious west wind, gathering force as it howls through San Gorgonio Pass on its way to Indlo harassed the field today and put a piemium on experience as the 72hole ColgateDinah Shore Winners Circle women's golf tournament got under way.

title: Hell's Kitchen Is Caught in the Clash Of Urban Renewal and Urban Removal
description: The great potted azalea that covers Piccinini's window is in purple, bloom for the last time. The butcher shop is moving and the azalea will not go along. Outside, though, the sidewalks along Ninth Avenue have been pierced for treesperhaps the first since before the days of the El.

title: City SmokerSegregation Bill May Be Eased
description: Health Commissioner Lowell E. Bellin said yesterday that he was prepared to soften a proposed regulation to segregate smokers and nonsmokers as the regulation applied to restaurants.

title: Concert
description: Erik Satie will be dead half a century next year, but he refuses to lie down and be immortalized. The French, composer's peculiar artistic personality, which mixes humor with solemnity, secular banality with muddled mysticism and naivet with sophistication, continues to keep him from being a truly popular composer, and therefore perhaps has enshrined him as an idol of the John Cage wing of the avantgarde.

title: State's Sports Authority Makes Debut Next Week
description: PATCHOGUE, L. I., April 18  The New York State Sports Authority, which was created last year to encourage municipalities to build sports facilities, will start operation here next week, its chairman, Edwin M. Schwenk, disclosed today.

title: Shareholders Hear Watergate Echoes
description: Echoes of Watergate are being heard as the annual stockholder meeting season unfolds. At least 29 corporations have received shareholder resolutions that would limit political activities. This tally comes from the Council on Economic Priorities, a nonprofit research organization here that monitors the increasingly vigorous movement for corporate social re sponsibility.

title: An Instructor in Yonkers Is U.S. Teacher of Year
description: Vivian Tom, whose grandfathers both emigrated to Hawaii from China, was teaching at Wailuku on the sugarandpineapple island of Maui in 1959 when she got a oneyear exchange offer from a place with the exotic name of Yonkers.

title: RONAN IS ELECTED HEAD OF PORT UNIT
description: Dr. William J. Ronan was unanimously elected chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday and the prosperous bistate agency simultaneously announced its dedication to improve mass transit in the region.

title: The Proceedings, In the U.N. Today
description: April 19, 1974

title: POTATO. FUTURES DECLINE BY LIMIT
description: Under the impact of 154 unfilled sell orders remaining from Wednesday's trading session, May potato futures dropped the 50point limit yesterday to close at 17 cents a pound. The preceding day's close on the New York Mercantile Exchange was 17.50.

title: Georgia Hunt for Bodies Is Linked to Dixie Mafia
description: BRASELTON, Ga., April 16Under normal circumstances, the winding little tributary known as the Mulberry River attracts little attention as it wanders through the pine stands and under the blacktop roads in this section of north Georgia. Even the map makers often ignore it, and strangers must ask directions to find it.

title: Rail TonMileage Off 1.6%
description: WASHINGTON, April 18The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroad during the latest week totaled an estimated 16.1 billion tonmiles, 1.6 per cent below the corresponding week of a year ago. Carloadings in the same period totaled 504,447 cars, 3.5 per cent below last year. The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 3.9 per cent below last year.

title: HOMOSEXUAL BILL GAINS IN COUNCIL
description: After a threeandahalfyear battle, a bill to ban discrimination against homosexuals in employment, housing and public accommodations was voted out of the City Council's General Welfare Committee yesterday evening.

title: Telephone Concerns Ask joint Satellites
description: The nation's two largest telephone companies filed plans yesterday with the Federal Communications Commission to operate jointly a domestic satellite system.

title: 20 SPRAYS LISTED IN DRIVE BY E.P.A.
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (UPI)  The Environmental Protection Agency has named 20 aerosol pesticides containing an ingredient that may cause a rare form of liver cancer. Ten concerns have refused to let the names of other such products be pink lished.

title: Women Smokers: What Does Gender Have to Do With Problem?
description: Mrs. Kitty Panzer, a blonde, 65yearold Queens housewife, strolled down Fifth Avenue the other day, cigarette in hand. In fact, she has spent much of the last 30 years of her life with a cigarette in her yellowstained hand.

title: Caught in Burglary, 3 Men Kill Victim And Stab 5 Others
description: HOLLYWOOD, April 18Six men and women were tied up and stabbed after surprising three burglars at the apartment where two of the victims lived, the police disclosed today.

title: WARSAW PACT CALLS FOR RENEWED TALKS
description: WARSAW, April 18 (UPI)Warsaw Pact leaders ended two days of talks today and signed a communiqu calling for new efforts to revive stalled negotiations with the West on European security and troop reductions, conference sources said.

title: Bucks Take 20 Lead Over Bulls
description: CHICAGO, April 18 (AP)Kareem AbdulJabbar scored 44 points but the Milwaukee Bucks had to turn back a fourthquarter rally tonight to defeat the Chicago Bulls, 113111, in a National Basketball Association Western Conference playoff.

title: U.S. Adheres Fully to Detente, Kennedy Declares in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, April 18  Senstor Edward M. Kennedy arrived tonight and asserted that Soviet eladers should understand that American institutions would emerge stronger from the Watergate affair and that regardless of political party there is a continuing U.S. commitment on the main EastWest issues.

title: Duke Krantz, Circus Flier And Pioneer Airman, Dies
description: KEY LARGO, Fla., April 18 (AP)Aaron F. (Duke) Krantz, a pioneer aviator who was a member of the Gates Flying Circus, died Tuesday at the age of 77.

title: UPWARD PRESSURE ON RATES REMAINS
description: Key shortterm interest rates have, moved up again and business loan demand continues strong, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday, increasing the pressure on the banking industry to make the 10 prime rate initiated by the North Carolina Naional Bank last Thursday industrywide.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The Government set out yesterday to destroy the credibility of Maurice H. Stans, the former Secretary of Commerce, in a crossexamination that lasted nearly all day and will continue today.

title: Sherlock Holmes Saxbe
description: The freeforall guessing game about Patricia Hearst's battles may be inevitable in a case that has aroused popular outrage as well as morbid curiosity. Such futile theorizing, nevertheless, contributes nothing the chances of Miss Hearst's liberation either from her captors or from her hallucinations, whichever may be holding her in thrall. Nor are these amateur excursions into criminal psychology likely to facilitate apprehension of the terrorists.

title: Moritt is Indicted; Said to Have Used City Funds for Play
description: Civil Court Judge Fred Moritt was indicted and arrested yesterday on charges of conspiracy, perjury, grand larceny and witnesstampering in what the 68yearold judge condemned as a vile conseiracy by the special state prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari.

title: Market Place: Warrant's Role On phone Stock
description: The beauty about American Telephone, a broker said yesterday, is that here's a stock you can recommend to just about anybody and feel pretty safe about it.

title: Robert Stock Named Editor Of Times's Travel Section
description: Robert W. Stock was named yesterday by Max Frankel, Sunday editor of The New York Times, as editor of the paper's Sunday travel and resorts section.

title: U.S. Expected to Hold Off On Sale of Arms to Cairo
description: WASHINGTON, April 19A senior American official said today that while the United States was interested in President Anwar elSadat's stated intention to end Egypt's total reliance on Soviet arms, Washington had no current plans to begin selling Military equipment to Cairo.

title: Calloway Trial Is Halted; Guns Displayed by State
description: NEWARK, April 19  The murder trial of Lamont Calloway was halted abruptly this afternoon after the defense attorney discovered that prosecution lawyers had brought sawedoff shotgun and a 32caliber revolver into the courtroom although neither weapon had been shown to him during pretrial proceedings.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Officer Gets Award for Rescue

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, April 19The United States shoe industry has taken the unusual step of going to court to force Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz to take action on a complaint that shoe imports from Spain and Argentina are being subsidized by the governments of those countries.

title: Bulls' Coach Down, 20, But Not Out
description: MILWAUKEE, April 19 (AP)Dick Motta, coach of the Chicago Bulls, is far from ready to concede. The Bulls trail the Milwaukee Bucks, 20, in their fourofseven, Westen final in the National Basketball Association, and the Bucks will have the homecourt advantage for the nationally televised third genie tomorrow at 2:30 P.M. (Channel 2 in New York).

title: Finns Lead Turks
description: HELSINKI, April 19 (AP)George Berner and Matti Timonen took just 90 min utes today to put Finland ahead, 20 in European Zone Davis Cup singles competition against Turkey. Berner defeated Hasan Oezdemir, 60, 61, 60, in 40 minutes and Timonen beat Remzi Aydin, 61, 61, 61, in a 50minute match.

title: Police Seize Ethiopian City, Demand Ouster of Official
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, April 19 (AP)  Rebellious policemen took control of Ethiopia's second largest city today, saying that they would hold it until the country's top police official was dismissed, according to radio reports.

title: Trial Transfer Is Granted In Texas Murder Case
description: HOUSTON, Tex., April 19 (AP)District Court Judge William Hatten granted today a change of venue from Houston to San Antonio in the murder trial of 17yearold Elmer Wayne Henley.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: 2 COUNTS ENDES IN RINALDI CASE
description: The Appellate. Division of the Third Department yesterday dismissed two perjury counts of an indictment against State Supreme Court Justice Dominic S. Rinaldi of Brooklyn and let stand one perjury count and one count of obstructing governmental administration.

title: In India, a Farmer Moans Over Crop
description: RUNGUTA, India, April 14  Harvest time is over for Latha Ram.

title: W.H.A. Playoffs
description: Chicago vs. Toronto

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: EARNINGS DECLINE AT R. J. REYNOLDS
description: The report of R. J. Reynolds Industries, Inc., issued yesterday showed a 1.1 per cent decline in firstquarter earnings. It was the first quarterly decline by the company in more than a year and a half and compares with a 9.6 per cent fourthquarter profit gain.

title: Benihana Head Stresses Simplicity in Restaurants And Sekkyokuteki in His AllBusiness' LifeStyle
description: ENGLEWOOD 7 In New York it is referred to as chutzpa. In Japan it is sekkyokuteki. But in either place or language, Hiroaki Aoki, an entrepreneur with a very large affection for wealth has it and he has the wealth besides.

title: Herbert Harris Dies at 60; Labor Authority and Writer
description: Herbert Harris, president and board chairman of Connecticut Manpower Executives Association, Inc., a research and planning agency in Bridgeport, died Thursday of St. Vincent's Hospital, Bridgeport. His age was 60.

title: Antiques: Tiffany Rise
description: Lillian Nassau, the nation's top art nouveau dealer, bought her first Loius Comfort Tiffany wisteria lamp in 1956 for $175. She soon sold that lampa sinuous, bronze: based design crowned by a leaded, shade aswirl with vibrantly colored blossoms of laminated glassfor $275. She bought it back within a year for $500 and sold It again swiftly for $700,000.

title: Federal Funds Hit 11% Level Despite Move by Reserve
description: All the major New York Cit banks joined yesterday in th move to increase the prime, basic, lending rate on loans corporations to 10 per cent from the 10 per cent level tha had been in effect for only tw weeks.

title: Ashe Upset By Parun In 3 Sets
description: HOUSTON, April 19 (UPI) Onny Parun of New Zealand cama back after a terrible first set today and upset topseeded Arthur Ashe, 26, 62, 64, in the quarterfinal round of the $50,000 River OaksAmerican General tennis tournament.

title: Consumer Index Here Up 10.5% in OneYear Period
description: Propelled by soaring costs of food, fuel and housing, the Consumer Price Index for the New Yorknorthern New Jersey region in. March rose 1.2 per cent over February, resulting in a 10.5 per cent overall increase for the oneyear period ended in March, according to the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: American League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Saigon's Alarms Stir Skepticism
description: SAIGON, South. Vietnam April 19Once again, heavy fighting has erupted in scattered parts of the country..And, once again, the Saigon Government has been making apocalyptic predictions about a Communist offensive. Last year such predictions were taken with a degree of serrasness, at least at first, and mulotelove and for the most art finally rejected. This time most diplomats, journalists and informed Vietnamese do not believe the Government.

title: Thursday's Fights
description: Los AngelesMarco Gerardo, 153 pounds, San Diego, outpointed Armando Muniz, 153, Artesia, Calif., 10 rounds.
