description: BASEBALL Colleges

title: Brandt Arrives in Algeria. To Talk With Boumediene
description: ALGIERS, April 19 (Reuters) Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany arrived here todaythe first Western leader to visit Algeria since it won its independence from France 12 years ago.

title: In Greek Regime of Silence, Rumor Is King
description: ATHENS, April 19There is a joke going around Athens about a man who walks into a store to buy a shortwave radio. For several minutes he asks a clerk guarded questions about the set's power to receive foreign signals. Don't worry. the clerk says with a laugh. It gets Deutschewelle.

title: GROSS, CITING JURY, SEEKS A NEW TRIAL
description: NEWARK, April 19 (AP)Former Republican State Chairman Nelson G. Gross today asked for a new trial, charging that the jury that convicted him of taxfraud conspiracy was not drawn from his peersrich people.

title: Moscow Gives a Dissident Permission to Go to Israel
description: MOSCOW, April 19  A 63yearold Jewish, chemistry professor who went on a twoweek hunger strike in February to protest the Soviet Government's refusal to let him emigrate, has been, given permission to go to Israel, friends of his family said today.

title: FRAUD IS CHARGED IN BUILDING COOP
description: Charging one of the most egregious and systematic frauds in the entire history of coopeiative conversions, State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday that his office was seeking to return an entire cooperative apartment building on the East Side to rental status and place it under rent control.

title: ISRAEL AND SYRIA IN FIRST AIR FIGHT SINCE CEASEFIRE
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, April 19 Syria and Israel today fought their first air battle over the Golan Heights front since the October war. Artillery duels continued on the ground for the 39th day.

title: INDIAN AT U.N. SEES FOOD GAIN IN PERIL
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 19  Foreign Minister Swaran Singh of India said today that shortages of fuel and fertilizer were threatening to wipe out the major gains of his country's green revolution in agriculture.

title: SPASSKY AND KARPOV DRAW FOURTH GAME
description: Boris Spastky, the former world chess champion, and Anatoly Karpov, the 22yearold Soviet champion, agreed to a draw in Moscow yesterday in the fourth game of their semifinal match of elimination play to select next year's challenger to Bobby Fischer, the world champion.

title: Top Banks at 10 Rate
description: An upward move to 10 per cent from 10 per cent in the prime, or basic, lending rate on loans made by banks to their most creditworthy customers became general yesterday when the new level was put into effect by all major banks in New York as well as the Bank of American. [Details on Page 39.]

title: Groh Assailed on Plan For Women Sweepers
description: Robert T. Groh, the new Commissioner of Sanitation, who had ordained that women who pass the sanitationmen's Civil Service test should sweep the streets, was taken to task yesterday by Mrs. Carol Greitzer, a City Council member from Manhattan, who said the idea was not only insulting, but also illegal.

title: Notes on People
description: May 3 has been set as parole day for Mrs. Edith Irving, her lawyer in Zurich, Switzerland, said yesterday. When she is released from prison near Berne, the Wife of Clifford Irving will have spent 16 months in United States and Swiss jails for having used a false passport to deposit $650,000 worth of checks from the McGrawHill Publishing Company into a Swiss bank account. Her original sentence in Zurich, on fraud and forgery charges, was two years in prison.

title: ARLO WILSON
description: Arlo Wilson, a manager of trade associations, who was secretarytreasurer of the New York Society of Association Executives, died yesterday in Midtown Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 15 East 91st Street.

title: 25 Military Police Search in Rain for Brenda Probasco
description: WEST DEPTFORD, April 19  Twentyfive military policement from Fort Dix searched unsuccessfully through woods and marshland in the rain today for 4yearold Brenda Probasco, who disappeared nine days ago.

title: DOLLAR VALUE MIXED IN FOREIGN TRADING
description: LONDON, April 19 (UPI) The dollar's slow slide halted on some world money markets today, but its foreign exchange value eroded still further on most of them.

title: 5 Detectives Called Drug Extortionists In U.S. Indictments
description: Five detectives who served in the Police Department's special investigations unit were indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday on charges that they had extorted or stolen sums ranging from $70,000 to $230,000 from drug dealers.

title: Buffalo Philharmonic Is Different
description: Led by that determined innovator and accredited musical eccentric, Michael Tilson Thomas, the Buffalo Philharmonic dared to be not only different but also giddily different in its Thursday night Spectrum Concert at Carnegie Hall.

title: Bengals Get Writ Halting WFL Raids
description: CINCINNATI, April 19 (AP) The Cincinnati Bengals of the National Football League were granted a temporary restraining order today, blocking the new World Football League from raiding the N.F.L. team.

title: PENNSYLV ANIA BOYS MAKE UP FOR CRIME
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa. (AP)Some unidentified lids who admittedly broke, the patio door of a home are making restitution in a secretive way.

title: Bearish Economic outlook Sends Stock Prices Dow
description: Bearish economic news ended the threeday advance of the stock market yesterday as prices declined in slower trading.

title: Consumer Index Here Up 10.5% in OneYear Period
description: Propelled by soaring costs of food, fuel and housing, the Consumer Price Index for the New Yorknorthern New Jersey region in March rose 1.2 per cent over February, resulting in a 10.5 per cent overall increase for the oneyear period ended in March, according to the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: Art: Schwartz's Etretat
description: The American painter Manfred Schwartz first visited Etretat, on the Normandy coast of France, in 1950. He was then 40 years old, an artist of considerable experience and wide culture who was fully aware of what Etretat signified in the history efimodern painting. This extraordinary locale, where monumental cliffs meet the sea, had been an important theme in the work of Courbet, Monet and Matisse, among other Masters, and Schawartz knew he would be inviting the most hazardous comparisons when he decided to address his own painting to this legendary subject.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: TEANECK, April 19The 32d edition of the oldest and one of the most prestigious bowling tournaments New Jersey, the Golden Pins, gets under way tomorrow night at Feibel's Recreation.

title: HARRY F. SIMPSON
description: Harry F. Simpson, treasurer of James F. Fox, Inc., a New York publicrelations concern, of which he had been a founder in 1961, died Thursday at New York Hospital following a stroke. He was 78 years old and lived at 45 East 66th Street.

title: ETHYL EXTENDING VCA BID 3D TIME
description: The Ethyl Corporation extended yesterday for the third time its tender offer for the common stock of the VCA CorOration. The offer, which was scheduled to expire yesterday, has now been extended to May 3. Under its offer, Ethyl will pay $18.50 a share for VCA common and $19 a share for its cumulative preferred stock.

title: DEMOCRATS SPLIT IN HAWAII CONTEST
description: HONOLULU, April 19Re publicans are expected to make a major fight for the governor ship this November in a state whose voter registration is 3to1 Democratic.

title: 3 From Missouri Give Red Sox Winning Show
description: The Red Sox beat the Cleveland Indians, 63, yesterday, and in Boston the fans were saying Thank you Missouri. Three offseason acquisitions from that state played key roles in the victory in Boston.

title: WINE TALK
description: Here is a brief wine quiz. The first ten people with a perfect score will get absolutely nothing as a prize. The first ten with everything wrong will get the samealthough they might consider putting themselves on Cold Duck for 30 days.

title: ACCORD REACHED ON FLIGHT SHARING
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board gave today the nation's two largest international airlines permission to work out a plan for sharing revenues and operations on flights between the United States and Europe.

title: PHILIP KAZON
description: Philip Kazon, a partner in the law firm of Graubard, Moskovitz, McGoldrick, Dannett & Horowitz, died yesterday ?? Doctors Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived at 1120 Park Avenue.

title: Market Place: Gains Tax Shift Called Possible
description: Easing the tax bite in capital gains is a subject dear to the wallet of both investors and Wall Streeters. There has been a notable lack of progress on this front, principally because of a lack of electrified interestand votes in Congress.

title: Jobless Rate for Veterans Up to 5.1% in First Quarter
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI)The unemployment rate for Vietnam war, era veterans rose from 4.2 per cent to 5.1 per cent in the first three months of 1974, with an increase of 60,000 the Government said today. Younger veterans were particularly hard hit.

title: WILL SEEK SEAT MRS. MEYNER SAYS
description: TRENTON, April 19Mrs. Helen Stevenson Meyner his reconsidered her earlier decision not to run and will seek the Democratic Congressional nomination in the 13th District, a source close to her said today.

title: Rise in Travel Cost Fails to Faze Youths
description: While their parents are planning vactions closer to home this year, young Americansundeterred by the abolition of special youth fares by international airlines hereare still finding relatively inexpensive ways to go abroad this year.

title: CALIFORNIA CHURCH BECOMES LANDMARK
description: BENICIA, Calif (AP)The 114yearold St. Paul's Episcopal Church has been dedicated as a registered California State Historical Landmark.

title: People in Sports
description: Professional football players with three years experience should not be bound by contract option clauses, according to Larry Csonka, the Miami Dolphins' star fullback who must play out his option clause this year before switching to the new World Football League. Speaking in Montgomery, Ala., the National Football League hero said: A player with three to four years experience should be able to play for whomever he wants.

title: Dance: A Black Insight
description: With tins Dance Tehater of Harlem's seconet program of its current New York season first seen Thursday nighttile pattern of the company and its particular black accentof the classic dance vocabulary became even more apparent than at its gala opening.

title: Curbs on Fetal Research Impede Fight on Disease
description: Restrictions on fetal research that have been instituted in the last few weeks are sei iously impeding doctors in several medical centers in the United States in their efforts to develop potential cures and preventions for a wide variety of diseases.

title: Reading Association Prize Is Won by Ruffalo Reporter
description: Miss Camille Curro, education reporter for The Buffalo Courier Express, has won the International Reading Association's Media Award for outstanding reporting on reading, it was announced yesterday.

title: Poles Lead, 10, In Cup Tennis
description: WARSAW, April 19 (AP)Poland beat Hungary in tilt. first singles match of European Zone Davis Cup play today. The second match was suspended by darkness.

title: A SHAKER STANS DENIES ANYLYING AS DEFENSE RESTS
description: The defense rested yesterday in the MitchellStans trial with Maurice H. Stans, badly shaken and ashenfaced, conceding that there were discrepancies between his grand jury and trial testimony, but angrily denying that they were lies.

title: TV Programing for Fall Cuts Down on Violence
description: The television networks next fall will cut back in programs that deal with violence and stress series concerned with family life and personal relationships. That is evident from the new primetime schedules for September disclosed yesterday by both the National Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System.

title: J. Paul Getty's Pay Rose 6% Last Year
description: LOS ANGELES, April 10 (Reuters)  Even billionaires like J. Paul Getty need salary increases these days.

title: For a BeerCan House, The Designer Learned Every Litter Bit Helps
description: TAOS, N. M.Michael Reynolds is 28 years old, designs and builds homes and likes to, experiment. So he sleeps in an addition to his house that he modeled after Egypt's Great Pyramid of Cheops. And he designs houses built and heated with beer cans.

title: POTATO FUTURES DECLINE BY LIMIT
description: The pressure of a large number of leftover sell orders once again caused May potato futures to drop the 50point limit early yesterday. Despite a rally, the closing price was down the limit at 16.50 cents a pound, off from 17 cents on Thursday, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. There were 150 sell orders unfilled.

title: U. S. GROUP GIVEN SOVIET CONTRACT
description: MOSCOW, April 19The Soviet Union and an American consortium signed today an $8million design contract for a $110million international trade center designed to promote Western business in Moscow.

title: Palestine Guerrilla Group Warns Visitors to Israel
description: KUWAIT, April 19 (Reuters) A Palestine guerrilla group warned here today that any foreign tourists visiting Israel would be classed as enemies, except while at three specified holy places.

title: Graham Dancers in a Savage Portrait
description: Men will be embarrassed by Martha Graham's Deaths and Entrances. So much of what the women's movement is still fumbling to articulate was stated so brutally in this great ballet by Miss Graham 31 years ago that its impact today is still guaranteed to make some in the audience uncomfortable.

title: Knicks Beat Celtics, 103100, To cut Playoff Deficit to 21
description: BOSTON, April 19The unpredictable New York Knacks played at their fabled best for three quarters tonight, running up a 20point lead, then had to hold off the charging Boston Celtics down the stretch. The Knicks survived, 103100, in a heartpounding finish at Boston Garden to clamber back into contention in the playoff for the National Basketball Association's Eastern Conference championship.

title: SHOP TALK
description: You'd expect Sherry Cohen and Barbara Friedman to be past the sandbox stage. Two grown women with children at school! Yet here they are ordering sand in 800pound lots and spending a lot of their time sifting through the stuff.

title: Ames Prospers as It Marks 200 Years
description: PARKERSBURG, W. Va. Whatever the odds for an American corporation to remain in continuous operation for 200 years, the O. Ames Company has beaten them.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 33

title: DeNicola Tells Court How He Killed C. W. Post Coed
description: MINEOLA, L.I., April 19Taking the stand at his trial for murder, Samuel De Nicola described in detail today how he stabbed to death a C. W. Post College coed in her dormitory room last June 18 and related other crimes he committed.

title: 3 Oriole Homers Derail EnergySaving Yanks, 53
description: BALTIMORE, April 19 By riding Amtrak instead of flying United, the Yankees chalked up a victory over the energy crisis today, but weren't as successful against the Baltimore Orioles tonight.

title: Heroin Sentence 999 Years
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 19 (UPI) A district court has sentenced Henry Bedell to 999 years in prison for possession of heroin. District Judge Tom Blackwell formally sentenced Mr. Bedell yesterday in connection with a conviction on a 1971 incident involving four ounces of heroin. A jury had recommended the sentence.

title: JAMES E. DURKIN
description: James E. Durkin, who had been an investment counselor with Kidder, Peabody & Co., on Wall Street, died Wednesday of cancer at his home, 7 Fairview Road in Scarsdale, N. Y. He was 76 years old.

title: Forgery Charge Is Imminent In RealEstate Case in Britain
description: LONDON, April 19Ronald Milhench, an Insurance broker and realestate man who is a key figure in the, controversy over an alleged forgery of signature of Prime Minister Wilson, will be charged with forgery, his attorney said tonight.

title: Mets Are Beaten Again, This Time by Weatherman
description: The New York Mets lost an opportunity yesterday to break their losing slide of seven gamesor to make it eightwhen rain canceled the opening of a weekend series against the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: SLOWDOWN HURTS THE SUNDAY NEWS
description: The slowdown of printers at The Daily. News entered its second day yesterday, but primarily affected preparations for the Sunday issue. The first edition of todays 36page paper was only 25 minutes late in going to press last night.

title: Rise in Travel Cost Fails to Faze Youths
description: While their parents are planning vactions closer to home this year, young Americansundeterred by the abolition of special youth fares by international airlines hereare still finding relatively inexpensive ways to go abroad this year.

title: COUNCIL BRIEFED ON BUDGET PLIGHT
description: Mayor Beanie gave an unusual personal briefing on the city's budget plight to members of the City Council yesterday and warned them that he had absolutely no commitment from the state in giving us taxing powers.

title: 40 Armed Convicts Flee Into Crowded Rio Streets
description: RIO de JANEIRO, Brazil April 19 (AP)  Forty armed convicts fled from a downtown prison into crowded streets here today and fought gun battles with the police.

title: Top Banks at 10 Rate
description: An upward move to 10 per cent from 10 per cent in the prime, or basic, lending rate on loans made by banks to their most creditworthy customers became general yesterday when the new level was put into effect by all major banks in New York as well as the Bank of America. D[etails on Page 39.]

title: Felt Sculptures Dominate Robert Morris Exhibition
description: Robert Morris has, among much else, the gift of signal concision. Works of art don't come Much tauter than the ones he made in 1962. Sometimes the tautness was literal, as when a ball of lead, shot as if from a gun, seemed to force its way into a sheet of the same material. Sometimes it was metaphoncat: The idea was carried out with a laconic precision that left no room for argument. Around that time Mr. Morris as writer never wasted a word either; there is a piece by him called A method for sorting cows (1963) which is not far below Kafka in its nightmarish brevity.

title: Kennedy Bids Soviet. Hosts Explain Arms Tests
description: MOSCOW, April 19  Senator Edward M. Kennedy called upon the Soviet leadership today to explain the implications of the latest testing and deployment of sophisticated nuclear missiles.

title: 2D SCHOOLAID RISE PROPOSED IN STATE
description: ALBANY, April 19The Governor and the legislative leaders tentatively agreed today on an, additional $263million in state aid to Iocal school districts, or $42million more than proposed two weeks ago.

title: A. & P. and Industry Group Sue
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, the country's largest retail food chain, filed suit yesterday in the United States District Court hereto enjoin the Federal Trade Commission from further prosecuting A.&P. for alleged unavailability of or mispricing of advertised items in some stores.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Roman Catholic Archbishopdesignate of Newark says he will reside in Newark and thus become the first Roman Catholic archbishop to actually live in the city. The Archbishop designate, Bishop Peter L. Gerety of the Diocese of Portland, Me., said he would live in the rectory of Sacred Heart Cathedral.

title: A.T. & T. Workers Restless as Wage Talks Near
description: Viewed from a dank, smelly cave 30 feet below First Avenue, splicing cable for the New York Telephone Company is not very appealing work.This its the dirtiest job in the city, said Orlando William, one of a trio of hardhatted workers who were carefully putting together What looked like bunches of multicolored spaghetti. Actually they were bundles of wire that will form a new telephone cable linking Brooklyn and Manhattan.

title: Troubled Waters on Oil
description: LONDON (AP) The International Wheat Council said recently the current world oil shortage was seriously disrupting wheat movements.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Arm Electronics Command at Fort Monmouth, N. J., awarded the Corporation a $96.3million contract to build a worldwide net. work of 21 satellite communications, earth termnais. PhilcoFord would provide the terminals, plus support equipment and training. The terminals would be built by the company's Western Development Laboratories division in Palo Alto, Calif.

title: Farrell High Triumphs in 2Mile Run
description: Monsignor Farrell High School of Staten Island produced a swift anchor leg yes terday to win the championship twomile relay as the QueensIona Relays opened at Queens College in Flushing.

title: Anthrax Warning Issued
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP)  The Department of Health, Education and Welfare warned today that goatskin drums made In Haiti may carry potentially fatal anthrax germs. Persons traveling to Haiti were advised not to purchase drums there, and Importation of the drums was being prohibited, the Public Health Service said.

title: Switched Empire
description: The designation of Dr. William J. Ronan as chairman of the bistate Port Authority portends movement toward fulfillment by this powerful agency of its longneglected obligation to spur mass transit.

title: Stage: cummings's s him
description: When e. e. cunimings's him was first produced at the Provincetown Playhouse in 1928, there was a note in the program urging the audience to relax and to stop wondering what the message of the play was. The audience and the criticsapparently relaxed so much that the play closed after 27 performances.

title: Soviet Upgrades Cattle Farms
description: An ambitious Soviet full program that was unveiled last month by Leon?? I. Brezhnev, the Communist party leader, is part of a longterm effort to upgrade the Russian diet by, greater production of meat and dairy products.

title: A Walk on the Mild Side Costs the Soul Plenty
description: CHICAGOI'm sitting in a restaurant and up comes a black dude, sixfoottwo, shoulders so wide they're stretching the shoulders of his adexec's jacket, tapering to a 28 waist, with a longlegged fighter's stride. He's not about to start sparring. He's a TV interviewer and his pen is in his hand.

title: 11 DIE IN ATTACK ON CAIRO ACADEMY
description: CAIRO, April 19 (Reuters)The Egyptian prosecutor general said today that 11 persons were killed and 27 others injured when a group including students and leftists attacked the Egyptian Military Technical College here yesterday.

title: U.S. Warrant Charges Girlfriend Of Bomber With Aiding His Escape
description: A Federal warrant was is sued yesterday for the arrest of the 25yearold girlfriend of Peter Phillip Mauchlin, the convicted bank robberbomber, who escaped from the Federal House of Detention last Sunday.

title: People in Sports
description: Professional football players with three years experience should not be bound by contract option clauses, according to Larry Csonka, the Miami Dolphins' star fullback who must play out his option clause this year before switching to the new World Football League. Speaking in Montgomery, Ala., the National Football League hero said:A player with three to four years experience should be able to play for whomever he wants.

title: U.N. Report Sees Grim Prospect on Food
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 19Grain reserves in the main exporting countries will have all but vanished by next year, the Food and Agriculture Organization reported today. It said the world food outlook was precarious, a situation intensified by the energy crisis.

title: Tanaka Leads by 3 Shots
description: YACHIYO, Japan, April 19 (AP)Fumio Tanaka of Japan, overcoming a leg injury, took a threestroke secondround lead today posting a 68 for a 137 in the $50,000 Soby international open golf championship.

title: Wisconsin Conserves Fuel By Closing Up on Holidays
description: MADISON, Wis. (UPI) More than 80,000 gallons of fuel oil were saved in Wisconsin by closing state buildings during the Thanksgiving and Christmas hilidays, said Govt Patrick J. Lucey.

title: Alfred H. Morton, ExDirector Of 'Voice,' R.C.A. Leader, Dies
description: Alfred H. Morton, who diracted the Voice of America in the early nineteenfifties and participated in the formation of the Radio Corporation of America, died April 9 of smoke inhalation in a fire in his home in Heritage Village, Southbury, Conn. He, was 76 years old.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LA MANGA, Spain, April 19 (Reuters)Jerry Heard of Visalia, Calif., shot a twounderpar 70 today to increase his lead to five strokes in the $65,000 Spanish open golf championship. The 26yearold Heard achieved his subpar round despite an upset stomach that almost forced him to withdraw. It gave him a 54hole total 209, five strokes ahead of Gary Player of South Africa, the 1974 Masters champion who also had a 70 today for 214. Player was two strokes ahead of Peter Townsend of England, who shot a 75.

title: High Court Bars Union for Own Police
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 The Supreme Court, which has been ordering employers to bargain with unions for years, has refused to recognize a local that was organized to represent a 50member police force assigned to the Court.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, APRIL 20, 1974

title: TELEVISED TRIAL OF NIXON IS URGED
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 Common Cause urged today that the Senate hold an open, televised trial of President Nixon if the House votes to impeach him.

title: State Senate Hearing On Schools Postponed
description: State Senator Stephen B. Wiley, chairman of the Joint Education Committee, announced yesterday that a public hearing on educational guidelines for New Jersey's public school system will be held at 10 A.M. May 14 instead of May 8, as originally announced Thursday.

title: Wood Field: Crowded, Mediocre
description: The Wood Memorial at Aqueduct today will be run in two divisions. The turnout has been heavy for the famous 1mile test for 3yearolds, and 23 names were put into the entry box yesterday morning. Normally a $100,000added race, the Wood this year will be worth twice that sum. The New York Racing Association will put up $100,000 for each of the divisions. This lavish distribution could be interpreted as a reward for mediocrity, for, in the words of one cynic, never have so many run for so much with so little ability.

title: JOHN PELENYI DES; PROFESSOR WAS 89
description: John Pelenyi, turner Hungarian minister plenipotentiary to the United States and prolessor of political science emeritus at Dartmouth College, died yesterday at his home in Hanrover, It H. He was 89 years old.

title: Harkness Ballet Gives a Drifting Duet
description: After an evening of spineless ballets vibrantly danced, one feels like shaking the hands of those teachers who trained the dancers and chastisnng the choreographers who gave them so little to do. Thursday evening the choreographer Vicente Nebrada, one of the premier teachers at the Harkness school, presented the first performance of his pas de deux Memories at the Harkness Theater. It thus becomes a matter of belaboring the man and congratulating him at the time.

title: LOWKEYED CHARM MARKS BIKEL SONGS
description: Theodore Bikel, a stranger to nightlife entertainment since he gave up the coffeehouse circuit 10 years ago to devote himself to theater, films, television and concerts, is making his New York debut as a supper club performer in the Maisonsite of the St. RegisSheraton Hotel. For the occasion, he is less the folknik he once was and is concentrating on a more sophisticated repertoryJacques Brel, Fiddler on the Roof, a song about a hangover, a lovely observation of a small child by Fred Hellerman, the onetime Weaver who is Mr. Bikel's conductor, and even September Song.

title: A.B.A. Deal in the Works: WestWalton Team to L.A.
description: An arrangement to place an American Basketball Association team in Los Angeles with Bill Walton as center and Jerry West as coach is currently under negotiation, and it seems to be the only alternative to a possible Walton agreement to play for Portland of the National Basketball Association, sources close to the discussions reported yesterday.

title: N.F.L. to Play C.F.L. In Charity Contest
description: TORONTO, April 13 (Canadian Press)A game between Stars of the National Football League and the. Canadian Football becomes a reality May 11 at Canadian National Exhibition Stadium.

title: Teachers' Head Goes to Jail
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 19 (UPI)Norman Hudson, the president of the Kansas City Federation of Teachers, marched through downtown streets to jail today, accompanied by more than 1,800 signcarrying, hymnsinging supporters. Mr. Hudson began a 10day sentence for his union's refusal to honor a court order to end the city's 33dayold teachers' strike.

title: NEW LEADERSHIP SOUGHT IN ISRAEL
description: JERUSALEM, April 19When When Golda divided Labor party met in Tel Aviv this week to consider the choice of a successor to the 75yearcld Premier, a group of demonstrators marched outside the hall chanting and bearing placards inscribed, Not Dayan and not the kitchen cabinet.

title: Giants' McQuay Wants No Looney Tune
description: After having been branded as the Joe Don Looney of Canadian football, Leon McQuay wants to carry a different tune with the New York Giants.

title: MRS. NEAL S. BRICKER
description: Mrs. Miriam Thalenberg Bricker, a lawyer and the wife of Dr. Neal S. Bricker, chairman of the department of medicine at Albert Einstein College of Medicine, died yesterday of cancer in the college hospital. She was 43 years old and lived at 30 Eastwoods Lane, Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: Now a Tale of Mice and Bettors
description: Can a 69cent claiming mouse outrun a $1.98 ham ster and a wellbred $2.98 gerbil in a 30foot race for 2monthsolds and up?

title: New Anderson Trial Denied
description: BALTIMORE, April 19 (AP)A Federal judge refused today to grant a new trial to N. Dale Anderson and directed the Baltimore County Executive to appear May 1 for sentencing for extortion and income tax evasion, District Court Judge Joseph H. Young rebuffed a defense contention that Mr. Anderson's rights had been denied because the prosecution granted immunity to 16 Government witnesses.

title: U.S. Expected to Hold Off On Sale of Arms to Cairo
description: WASHINGTON, April 19A senior American official said today that while the United States was interested in President Anwar elSadat's stated intention to end Egypt's total reliance on Soviet arms, Washington had no current plans, to begin selling military equipment to Cairo.

title: ExMember of Parliament Said to Have Killed Himself
description: LONDON, April 19A coroner said today that Desmond Donnelly, a Labor party member of Parliament from 1950 to 1968, killed himself with an overdose of drugs.

title: COUSINS STOCK FES TO '74LOW
description: The price of stock in Cousins Mortgage and Equity Investments, another troubled realestate investment trust, fell to its lowest level this year, while officials of the Atlantabased concern were busy assuring creditors of their position.

title: 175 Stage Village Protest McDonald's
description: Greenwich Village residents opposed to the establishment of more tastfood restaurants in historic sections of the area have asked the Community Planning Board and the Landmarks, Preservation Commission to oppose plans by the McDonald's food chain to build outlets there.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 33

title: Nets Loose As Colonels Need to Win
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., April 19 The real playoff pressure now is on the Kentucky Colonels, who have to win their next game to keep from being swept out of their American Basketball Association Eastern final series against New York.

title: Tale of Two Schools
description: Pick two predominantly black schools with an enrollment that mirrors the poverty of their environment, and compare the children's achievements. Given the similarity of the pupils background, one might expect that those achievements would be equally depressed in both schools. At least, these might be the anticipated findings if the widespread theory were to be believed that the schools' effectiveness is largely preordained by the aioeconomic baggage the children bring with them.

title: Highs and Lows
description: FRIDAY, APRIL 19, 1974

title: Oregon Fishermen Complete A Record Catch of Shrimp
description: PORTLAND, Ore, (UPI)Oregon fishermen have completed a record annual shrimp catch, accompanied by record prices.

title: Nixon Called a Backer Of Warren for Court
description: ST. LOUIS, April 19 (UPI) Former Supreme Court Chief Justice Earl Warren was appointed to the high court in 1953 because then Vice President Richard M. Nixon wanted to get Mr. Warren out of California politics, according to Associate Justice William O. Douglas.

title: Woman Tends Furnaces
description: SEATTLE (AP)Mrs. Dorothy Brant, a 60yearold mother of two, has become the first woman to be employed by the Seattle School District to fire furnaces and maintain boilers at area schools.

title: Warsaw Pact Talks Finish on a Conciliatory Note
description: WARSAW, April 19Leaders of the seven Communist nations comprising the Warsaw Pact organization have gone home after a twoday meeting at which they declared themselves ready to continue seeking peace while remaining militarily vigilant.

title: Amex Stocks Decline in Slow Trading
description: Prices fell sharply on the American Stock Exchange yesterday in the slowest trading in eight months, after advancing three consecutive sessions. The picture was similar in the overthecounter market.

title: NIXON DEPARTURE FORESEEN ABROAD
description: WASHINGTON, April 19Many foreign leaders have concluded that President Nixon will probably have to leave office because of his Watergaterelated problems, a worldwitle survey by correspondents of The New York Times indicates. This appears to mark a significant switch in attitude since last year, when it was considered likely that he would ride out the political storm.

title: MILK COOP FINED $150,000 BY STATE
description: ALBANY, April 19The State Department of Agriculture and Markels fined the Dairylea Milk Cooperative $150,000 today for adulterating and mislabeling milk and milk products sold in the state, including metropolitan New York.

title: 2 Women Lead Golf by Stroke
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., April 19The desert wind died down today and the perfect golfing conditions that resulted made more difference to some than to other in the second round of the ColgateDinah Shore Winner Circle $200,000 tournament.

title: STORMPROYESAID TO BLACK SCHOOLS
description: WILBERFORCE, Ohio, April 14A tornado has given new life to two black colleges in this small farm community.

title: Candidate in Colombia
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, April 19  People don't consider me as a woman but as a leader, says Maria Eugenia Rojas de Moreno Diaz, who is running for the presidency of Colombia in next Sunday's election. Maria Eugenia, as she is generally known, is Latin America's first woman presidential candidate, and she says she has strong hopes of winning. Most polls, however, show her running second or third.

title: Hearst Says Notebook Clears Daughter
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 19Randolph A. Hearst said today that he had proof that his daughter did not conspire in her kidnapping. A Federal Bureau of Investigation spokes. man said, however, that the evidence cited by Mr. Hearst was not conclusive.

title: ASHAKEN STANS DENIES ANY LYING AS DEFENSE RESTS
description: The defense rested yesterday in the MitchellStans trial with Maurice H. Stans, badly shaken and ashenfaced, conceding that there were discrepancies between his grand jury and trial testimony, but angrily denying that they were lies.

title: Builder Challenges Ft. Lee and Tenafly On Zoning Statutes
description: Centex Homes Corporation challenged the validity of zoning ordinances in Fort Lee and Tenafly in separate suits filed yesterday in Superior Court in Bergen County.

title: Curbs on Fetal Research Impede Fight on Disease
description: Restrictions on fetal research that have been instituted in the last few weeks are seriously impeding doctors in several medical centers in the United States in their efforts to develop potential cures and preventions for a wide variety of diseases.

title: Books of The Times
description: ANNA PAVLOVA. By Oleg Kerensky. 160 pages. E. P. Dutton & Co. $6.95. Race horses have been named after Vaslav Nijinsky and Joe:Namath, and meringue dessert has been named after Anna Pavlova. Like Nijinsky, with whom she danced early in her career, Pavlova was one of the first pop stars of the century.

title: High School Notes Chauvinism Is the Loser When East Meets West
description: When Martin Proyect, chairman of the board of trustees at the Barnard School for Girls, first heard of the PingPong prowess of one of the students at the school, he was moved by the spirit of Challenge and competition.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: SORT INTEREST SHOWS INCREASE
description: Short interest advanced in the last month to the highest level in 16 months, the New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday.

title: Television
description: Obviously undaunted by the failure of Julie Andrews's expensive television series of last season, the same producers are now presenting a Britishmade, postscript special titled Julie and Dick in Covent Garden. With the ebullient Miss Andrews perhaps a bit more at ease in her native land, and joined by our Dick Van Dyke and Carl Reiner, the result is sprightly and charming. Too bad this hourlong segment, at 8 tomorrow night over the American Broadcasting Company network, wasn't in the original series.

title: Wilson Offers Legislators a Plan To Regulate Vacancy Decontrol
description: ALBANY, April 19Gover??or Wilson has presented to the legislative leadership a detailed formula for restructuring vacancy decontrol in New York City that leaves the program essentially intact and estabishes instead a series of adminstrative boards to pplice and regulate the system.

title: U.S. Controller Asks New Rules on Data of Bank Trusts
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (Reuters)The controller of the currency proposed today new regulations that would require the trust departments of national banks to make public substantially more information, about their activities.

title: ISRAEL AND SYRIA IN FIRST AIR FIGHT SINCE CEASEFIRE
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, April 19 Syria and Israel today fought their first air battle over the Golan Heights front since the October war. Artillery duels continued on the ground for the 39th day.

title: PARIS CANDIDATE OUTPIS REFORM
description: PARIS, April 19Valry Giscard D'Estaing, frontrunner on the right in the French presidential campaign, today announced plans to improve the life of workers, the aged and the poor and to ameliorate the overall quality of French life.

title: TV Programing for Fall Cuts Down on Violence
description: The television networks next fall will cut back in programs that deal with violence and stress series concerned with family life and personal relationships. That is evident from the new primetime schedules for September disclosed yesterday by both the National Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System.

title: For a New Approach to Rebuilding Cities
description: Before the Arab oil embargo so abruptly made us aware of our longbrewing energy crisis, most people were ready to solve the problems of cities by running away from them to suburban complexes of offices and homes. Now, with limited, expensive energy, what looked, like a pleasurable escape has become a trap.

title: 5 Detectives Called Drug Extortionists In U.S. Indictments
description: Five detectives who served in the Police Department's special investigations unit were indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday on charges that they had extorted or stolen sums ranging from $70,000 to $230,000 from drug dealers.

title: HUGHES JURY TOLD OF A MEXICAN LINK
description: LOS ANGELES, April 19Robert A. Maheu's grandson was born in Mexico in 1970 so that the child could own properties there, a Federal trial jury was told here today.

title: Canada Mails Virtually Halted Amid Spreading Labor Unrest
description: OTTAWA, April 19  Canadian postal services were brought to a virtual standstill today by union members protesting the effects of automation on job classification and pay.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: 2D SCHOOLAID RISE PROPOSED IN STATE
description: ALBANY, April 19The Governor and the legislative leaders tentatively agreed today on an additional $263million in state aid to local school districts, or $42million more than proposed two weeks ago.

title: Ashe Upset By Parun In 3 Sets
description: HOUSTON, April 19 (UPI) Onny Parun of New Zealand came back after a terrible first set today and upset topseeded Arthur Ashe, 26, 62, 64, in the quarterfinal round of the $50,000 River OaksAmerican General tennis tournament.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: People and Business
description: Sam Y. Cross, a 46yearold career civil servant, was named yesterday by President Nixon as United States executive director of the International Monetary Fund. His appointment is subject to Senate approval.

title: NIXON DEPARTURE FORESEEN ABROAD
description: WASHINGTON, April 19Many foreign leaders have concluded that President Nixon will probably have to leave office because of his Watergaterelated problems, a worldwide survey by correspondents of The New York Times indicates. This appears to mark a significant switch in attitude since last year, when It was considered likely that he would ride out the political storm.

title: Milk Lawyer Reported Ready to Testify
description: WASHINGTON, April 19Reports circulated here today that Jake Jacobsen, a former lawyer for the Associated Milk Prodecers, Inc., was preparing to testify to Watergate prosecutors that he gave $10.000 of the milk cooperative's funds to former Treasury Secretary John B. Connally.

title: Statue of Liberty Occupied By AntiNixon Protestors
description: A group of collegeage milltants barricaded themselves inside the Statue of. Liberty at closing time yesterday in a protest against the Nixon Administration.

title: Please Turn Off The Sports
description: In early March I became aware that something important had changed. I had stopped being a sports fan. News that the baseball teams were in spring training added no salt to life's daily routine (Nixon, taxes, bills and toil) and the approach of the basketball playoffs gave no lift to tired Wad.

title: Judge Weighs Use of School Sex Film
description: A Pederal judge reserved decision yesterday on a motion seeking the reinstatement of a Bronx high school teacher who was relieved of his teaching duties for showing a filmstrip depocting sexual acts to his biology classes.

title: U.S. and Agency Bonds
In Town and Country, a Return
description: MARSHFIELD, Vt.Yes, there is a movementyoung, alive and spreading roots in the country. It's not the same as the movement of the late nineteensixties psychedelic flowering and newleftism, although a number of people have made the transition.

title: MUSIC
description: Bernhard Klee, from Germany, found himself on the podium facing the New York Philharmonic on Thursday night. The 38yearold conductor was a replacement for Daniel Barenboim. Mr. Klee is one of the new breed, little known here, represented by very few if any records on this side of the water. Thus his American debut had an element of mystery. Would he provide the surprise of the season or wouldn't he?

title: SEARCH CRITICIZED IN SAN FRANCISCO
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 19The dispute over the police procedure of stopping and searching young black men in an investigation of at least 12 murders intensified today. Police officers began handing out identification cards that were in effect passes for those they had examined and released in the search for the killers of the 12 white persons.

title: Mayor, in Reprieve, Seks Way to Utilize Tweed Courthouse
description: The Tweed Courthousethe 103yearold building that sits behind City Hall, a drafty and sootsplotched monument to municipal corruption  was given a reprieve yesterday by Mayor Beame.

title: One Down, Flyers Up For Rangers
description: With the words, Goodby, Scotty and We want Shultz, still ringing in their ears, the. New York Rangers removed their speed skates, reserved for matching strides with the flashy Montreal Canadiens, and donned their sixounce gloves in preparation for their next Stanley Cup rivals, the fighting Philadelphia Flyers.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: IN THE DARK FUTURE The New York Science Fiction Film Society is six months old, but it is already into the series business. The club consists of a group of scifi fans who assemble from time to time to look at old reels and new reels that leave you reeling by dint of their fertile imagination about what may be or might have been.

title: SCHULER BACKED AS HEIR TO RONAN
description: ALBANY, April 19Key state legislators today praised Raymond T. Schuler, the Commissioner of Transportation, as a possible successor to Dr. William J. Ronan as Chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Bridge:
description: A player with a long minor suit should nearly always give way gracefully when his partner shows an urge to play game in notrump. A game in a minor is seldom desirable unless there are ruffs to be had in both hands.

title: BRITISH PRICES UP AS DEFICIT WIDENS
description: LONDON, April 19  The British Government reported today that retail prices were continuing to rise sharply and that the country's trade deficit in March set another monthly record.

title: Coup 32 in Africa
description: Reports from nearby countries tell of students racing with banners through the streets of Niamey to celebrate the military coup that has overthrown President Hamani Diori of Niger. Such festivities come easily in the early hours after the ouster of an African government; it only later, when the young officers who brought off the coup must come to grips with the intractable problems that beset nearly all new African countries, that disillusionment sets in and second thoughts are provoked.

title: Library Vans Parked In Way to Stop Siphoning
description: EL PASO, Tex. (AP)For many months, the El Paso Public Library's bookmobiles were losing gasoline while parked overnight.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Orders Shrink 2.1 % For Durable Goods
description: WASHINGTON, April 19New orders flowing to manufacturers of durable goods declined in March after two months of Increases but the unfilled order backlog continued to rise, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Mona Lisa on Display At Museum in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, April 19 (Reuters)  The Mona Lisa, the portrait with, the enigmatic smile, went on view today in a heavily guarded room at the National Museum here its second appearance outside France in more than 450 years.

title: Issues in Papers Dispute
description: PARTICIPANTS: The New York Times, The Daily News and The New York Post, negotiating as the Publishers Association of New York City, and, York Typographical Union No. 6, representing 819 printers, including 170 substitutes, at The Times; 945 printers, including 200 to 220 substitutes, at The News; and 312 printers, including 38 substitutes, at The Post.

title: Tigers' Ron Cash On Disabled List
description: DETROIT, April 19 (AP)The Detroit Tigers put Ron Cash, a rookie infielder, on the 15day disabled list today after he was admitted to Ford Hospital for what was described as nervous exhaustion.

title: Yalie FoxTrot at Pro, Five Years After It Was Dropped as OldFashioned
description: NEW HAVEN, April 19The men wore tuxedos and the women wore evening gowns as they danced to the music of a 15piece orchestra playing waltzes and fox trots. That was the way a college prom used to be and that was the way it was once again at Yale University tonight.

title: Work Ethic Proves Buoy to Japan Economy
description: TOKYO, April 19By now, almost everybody in the world knows that the Japanese are a hardworking people. The Japanese themselves like to talk about their work ethic and others charge them, partly in scorn and partly in envy, with being economic animals.

title: LOCAL BOARDS GET SAY ON PRINCIPALS
description: Chancellor Irving Anker said yesterday that all candidates for the jobs as principals in the city's public schools must first receive recommendations from local community school board superintendents before being appointed.

title: Chilean Court Rejects Claim It Lacks Power to Try 67
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 19 A military court today rejected a challenge from defense attorneys that it had no authority to try 57 Air Force men and 10 civilians charged with aiding Marxist parties and with sedition.

title: A Mechanical Partner For Karate Is Devised
description: WASHINGTON, April 19The operator of a New Jersey recording studio plans to offer the public a dummy kamechanical instructor in selfrate fighter 6 feet tall. The defense, as described in the patent granted for it this week, has one pair of movable legs and two separately moving pairs of arms, all under related electronic control. The inventor, who received Patent 3,804,406, is Eugene G. Viscione, an audio and video engineer who records music and runs his own publishing company under the name of Laser Dynamics, Inc., in Somerville, N. J.

title: Las Vegas East?
description: A group of high rollers from the Broadway Association, representing assorted wellintentioned businessmen, propose that the addition of gambling casinos would help revitalize Times Square into a glittering Las Vegas Square.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Charity has always been an attribute of hockey players. They never draw any more blood from an opponent than necessary. Well, seldom, anyway. An so it is not surprising that the New York Rangers will open their Stanley Cup semifinal round with the Philadelphia Flyers tonight on the first week's anniversary of Brad Park's 515,000 promise of philanthropy. After the Rangers lost to the Montreal Canadians last Saturday night, Brad Park was thinking more about arms than alms. The defeat had dropped the Rangers behind, 21, in their fourofsevengame series.

title: Defending Nixon. The Problems of St. Clair
description: WASHINGTON, April 19How do you defend the Presi dent? James Draper St. Clair, who was, hired by Richard; Nixon to do just that, raised the question himself not long, ago, notingwithout answering the question  that they don't, give courses in law, school on how todo it. Now, watching Mr. St. Clair, a number of other lawyers and many nonlawyers are also asking the question. They are finding, as the dean of one law school said, that we just never had much occasion to question the White House lawyer's role, and that as a result, there are no precise rules to cover all the situations in which Mr. St. Clair finds himself.

title: Catch 266,000,000
description: South Vietnam's President Thieu must be heartened at the degree of carelessness conveniently exposed some Pentagon accounting office.

title: Sparrows Build Their Nest Under Hood of Car in Iowa
description: NEWTON, Iowa (AP)  Mrs. Floyd Cooper noticed that a number of sparrows continued flitting around the automobile she had been using three or four times a day on errands.

title: Belgium Wins 2 Matches
description: BRUSSELS, April 19 (UPI) Belgium led Greece, 2.0, today after the opening singles matches of their secondround match in the European Zone B of the Davis Cup competition. Patrick Hombergen defeated Niki Kalaidis, 63, 64, 61, and Bernard Mignot beat Nicky Kalogeropoulos, 62, 7.5, 16, 6.4.

title: Lebanon, Pressed by Israelis and Palestinians, Seeks Way Out
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 19 The suicide attack last week by three Palestinian extremists on the Israeli settlement of Qiryat Shemona, in which 18 perFens were killed, has plunged the Lebanese Parliament into a weeklong debate.

title: PRICE INDEXR ROSE BY 1.1% IN MARCH; INFLATION IS 14.5%
description: By EDWIN L. DALE Jr. Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, April 19The rapid rate of inflation of consumer prices continued in March, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Evidence of Any Nixon Tie To Ellsberg Case Is Sought
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI)A Federal judge ordered the Watergate special prosecutor today to give him and the defendants in the Ellsberg breakin case any evidence the prosecutor might have about President Nixon's possible personal involvement.

title: Kissinger Urges Latin Nations to Seek Firmer Ties
description: ATLANTA, April 19  The 23nation Organization of American States began its general assembly here today with Secretary of State Kissinger calling for progress toward new horizons of hemisphere cooperation and understanding.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 1.2 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 231 from 229.8 last week.

title: Warsaw Ghetto Uprising Is Marked in Times Square
description: A handful of persons gathered in a chill rain yesterday noon in Times Square and heard a 13yearold youth sound taps in memory of those who died in the Warsaw Ghetto uprising 31 years ago.

title: Eclectic Reading
description: The only resemblance between the Motion Picture Academy Awards and the National Book Awards this season was the appearance of a streaker at both ceremonies. Movies are a group activity; books still oneman or onewoman creation. Both include lobbying for winners but with these book awards popularity not the main criterion. And this is one of the values of the publishing industry's awardsto call attention to worthwhile books that are seldom bestselling blockbusters.

title: Lucky Charge Is Victor In Junior Hunter Final
description: READINGTON, N.J., April 20  Lucky Charge, an 8yearold brown gelding with an outstanding record on the Midweste circuit, captured the junior working hunter championship today at the opening session of the twoday. Four Seasons horse show.

title: Cedar Grove Boxed In, but Thriving
description: CEDAR GROVEOnethird of the land in the four square miles of this township cannot be used for residential development because it is committed to Newark and Essex County. Newark owns a large parcel next to Montclair that is used for a reservoir, and the county has claim to acreage in the southwest corner, where Overbrook Hospital is situated. The result of this is that Cedar Grove has noway to expand and is fairly set in its housing and industrial patterns.

title: Highspirited sportswear rolls in
description: On the green, shirts and slacks team up for summer. Clockwise, from frontandcenter bowler: the flowersplashed shirt of unusuallyshaded Arnel is by Philippe Vend. $18.50 at Marty Walker. His extensionwaist knitted polyester slacks by Jaymar, $22.50 at Wallachs. ... A magnified houndstooth check in FourthofJuly colors explodes on Qiana. The shirt, by Robert Schafer for Burma Bibas, is $30 at Abraham & Straus. The jeanstyled polyester  and  cotton pants: Trousers by Barry. $30 at Whitehouse & Hardy.... A biplane wings its way across the front and back of a zigzagstreaked shirt of texturized nylon. $27.50. The sideringed polyester gabardine pants are $30. Both, by NikNik, at Macy's.... Wallpaper print flowers are displayed on Qiana for a shirt by Waldo. $16 at Mern's. Corbin's traditionally  styled, tattersallchecked slacks of Terylene and wool are $37.50 at Wallachs.... A stirrup design rides across Qiana. The shirt, by Simba, is $28 at Dolph's. Frontpocketed twilled slacks by Scofield are $25 at Altman's... Miniature awning stripes line up to shade a shirt of Ultressa by Givenchy. $27.50 at Field Bros. Polyester,  and  linen slacks, beltlooped and sidepocketed, by Majer. $38.50 at Altman's. The women's clothing by JerSea of Sweden.

title: Lack of a College Degree Limits Ministry in City Institutions
description: The Rev. Ray Rivera can reach from his pulpit in the Bronx, but he cannot minister to his fellow Puerto Ricans as an official chaplain in hospitals and prisons because he does not have a Bachelor of Arts egree.

title: Candace Martin Bride of Bruce Barefoot
description: In the Congregational Church of Manhasset, L.I., yesterday afternoon, Miss Candace Georgine Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Martin of Manhasset, was married to Bruce Leonard Barefoot, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Roy Barefoot Jr. of Warren, Ohio. The Rev. Alexander Ferguson performed the ceremony.

title: PAUL K. NIVEN
description: TOPSHAM, Me., April 20 (AP) Paul K. Niven, retired editor and publisher of The Brunswick Record, died yesterday at the age of 81 at a nursing home here.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: [The article in this section on April 7 on City Planning Commission hearings], captured many of the raging controversies in the latest. Coney Island urban renewal (or destruction) plan. However, lit] did not give both sides of the controvery concerning Mermaid Avenue, the business spinal column of Coney Island.

title: W.H.A. Playoffs
description: Chicago vs. Toronto

title: OATMEN
description: Breezy and coolcolorgear for Sunday seafarers.

title: POLITICS BARRED TO JUDGES' AIDE
description: ALBANY, April 20Law sec retaries and other members a judge's staff will be prohib ited from participating in poli tics under action taken here to day by the New York State Ba?? Association.

title: Yale Wins NoHitter
description: NEW HAVEN, April 20Don Gallagher, a senior righthander, pitched Yale's first nohitter in almost three decades today, beating Harvard, 21, in the first game of a doubleheader. Harvard won the second game, 80. Gallagher walked 12 and fanned four. Harvard scored its run on a wild pitch.

description: The creation of professionsports leagues has produced an intriguing side effectthe potential for the elimination of the hated reserve and option clauses in sports.

title: Harriet Henry, 77, Dead; Was Author of 16 Novels
description: TUCSON, Ariz., April 20 (AP) Countess Harriet Henry de Stench of New York, a writer known as Harriet Henry, died yesterday while vacationing here. She was 77 year old.

title: 18 Presented in Jersey

The proceeds of the event at the Tamcrest Country Club in Cresskill, N. J., including the $50 contributed by the parents of each debutante, will help pay the mortgage on the church building.

description: WASHINGTONDoes anyone still, think that economic policy making in this capital city is a rational and systematic process presided over by wise, wellinformed men and carried out by an experienced bureaucracy?

description: Tennis is about ready to burst out of those winterized bubbles and back onto outdoor courts. For the first few chilly days, warmup outfits serve handsomely.

title: Nets Oust Colonels in 40 Sweep
description: LEXINGTON, Ky. April 20  The New York Nets were sipping California champagne after their 10390 victory that swept the Kentucky Colonels out of the American Basketball Association's Eastern Division final playoffs 40, tonight at the University of Kentucky's Memorial Coliseum.

title: Inoculation Information Offered by Phone Here
description: As a public service, the Veterinary Medical Association of New York City, which is headed by Dr. J. Lloyd Tait, has prepared a special telephone message giving information about News inoculations for dogs and cats It recommends year ly vacinations to protect them from serious diseases. The phone number is 2122460363 and it is in service around clock.

title: Charles Ives had no use for Mozart, Haydn Mendelssohn, Tchaikovsky and Wagner
description: There is such a thing as a natural baseball player, a natural pianist, a natural cook, a natural dancer. There is also such a thing as a natural avantgardist, and Charles Edward Ives, who was born in 1874 and died in 1954, was one. From the very beginning, he was a natural musical rebel, a complete, uncompromising individualist who despised conventional thinking and conventional sounds. He would have loved to have been born in some future century, when the school children will whistle popular tunes in quarter toneswhen the diatonic scale wilt be as obsolete as the pentatonic now is. He spent most of his lifetime in business, running the most successful insurance agency in America, composing in his spare time a great quantity of incredibly novel, complicated, gratingly dissonant and curiously evocative music, almost none of which was published and little of which he ever heard played in public. It was not only the most unusual body of music ever composed by an American; it was probably the most unusual body of music composed by any musician in history.

title: Future Social Events
description: Get Up on Your Bach April 24Prof. Peter Schickele, pianist and lecturer, will discuss and perform the music of his own invention, P.D.Q. Bach (18071742?), at Japan House. The recital will benefit Young Concert Artists, a nonprofit management organization that helps gifted, young musiclans put the right foot forward on the road to fame. Professor Schickele will be assisted by John Ferrante, bargain counter tenor, and David Oei, harpsichordist. What's this, Professor? You didn't pluck a welltampered term for him?, Afterward, a champagne reception in the galleries. Tickets, $25 to $500.

title: Rematch of Glenn and Metzenbaum in Ohio Primary: Controversy on Tax Returns Reflects Watergate Impact
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 18  John H. Glenn Jr. is not satisfied that Senator Howard Metzenbaum, his opponent in an angry rematch of their 1970 primary, published his full Federal income tax return for 1973 this week.

title: Mary Hallinan Has Nuptials
description: Miss Mark Rogers' Hallinan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard James Hannan of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Jonathan Gates Ford. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton Gates Ford of Riverside, Conn.

title: Mine Union Says Officials Seek Eased Safety Law
description: WASHINGTON, April 20The United Mine Workers charged today that coal mine safety officials at the Interior Department had secretly prepared recommendations to Congress to weaken the Federal Mine Safety law in ways that would increase coal production but also hazards to miners.

title: A Vital Supreme Court Decision Is On the Way
description: The twentieth anniversary of the historic Supreme Court decision prohibiting segregation in the public schools is May 17. It will arrive with one of the mint significant social struggles of the century Substantially ended in the South but only just beginning in the North.

description: TRENTONMany New Jersey farmers, plagued by soaring costs, end shortages of supplies, fear that 1974 will turn out to be a disastrous year.

title: Suffolk Republicans Are Hopeful But Wary
description: HAUPPAUGEThe Republicans of Suffolk County officially opened their 1974 political campaign here with the usual hoopla last week, but there was anxiety mixed with the fanfare. The party's leaders warned that without earnest grassroots campaigning and solid financial contributions the Suffolk G.O.P. candidates would suffer the same fate as Republicans in special Congressional elections this year who were swept away by the effects of the Watergate scandal.

description: BASKING RIDGE When the Bonafides, a group of Somerset Hills women who support civic and charitable causes, decided to raise funds, they went bargain hunting.

St. Clair, the eminent Boston barrister, was brought in four months ago as President Nixon's chief Watergate lawyer, it appeared for a time that the man he replaced, J. Fred Buzhardt, a South Carolina conservative, had slipped quietly into the obscurity of overseeing routine White House legal matters.

description: The State Commission on acupuncture has recommended that educational and training standards be established here for those practicing the ancient art of medical treatment with needles.

title: 9 Sign for Golf Classic
description: DALLAS, April 20 (UPI)Bob Charles and Leonard Thompson, both 1974 tour winners, and the 1973 Masters winner, Tommy Aaron, have signed to play in the $150,000 Byron Nelson Golf Classic, Other players, announced today, who will play in the event May 2 through 5, are Orville Moody, Ken Venturi, Bert Yancey, Kermit Zarley Jr., Larry Hinson and Dewitt Weaver.

description: WASHINGTON, April 20 Investigators for the Senate Watergate committee have accused the Internal Revenue Service of obstructing the panel's continuing inquiry, into a $100,000 Presidential campaign donation from Howard R. Hughes.

description: Leo Morrison, who had been a Hollywood press agent since the early nineteentwenties, died Friday at French Hospital of complications following surgery. He was 75 years old and lived here.

title: In Cold Print: When Is a Book Dead on Arrival?
description: When Congress is profligate of the public wealth we are referred to the power of the Pentagon; when Congress is niggardly, we are referred to the power of the middle class taxpayer. When cities are neglected, we are referred to the countryside; when the countryside is neglected we are referred to the cities. When tax loopholes are given to millionaires, we are referred to the power of the rich; when racist politics flourish we are referred to the power of poor whites....

description: BEIRUTThe Palestinian refugees are a marginal, but important minority that Lebanon has not assimilated, but cannot ignore. And once again, the guerrilla forces they have spawned have brought Lebanon under attack from Israel because of a terrorist adventure.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A new prepaid group health centerthe first new prepaid plan in the city in more than 25 yearshas been officially opened in Brooklyn. The center, a joint venture between Connecticut General Life Insurance Company and a physician corporation, provides a full range of medical services, including psychiatric care, hospital emergency care and emergency transportation to the hospital, for $69.75 a month for a family. The plan is called Healthcare.

title: Two Records Broken As Kansas Relays End
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., April 20 (UPI)Larry Jones of Northeast Missouri State and Marshall Smith of Colorado State improved on their 1973 record performances today in the 49th running of the Kansas Relays. title: NEV SUBWAY CARS DEE BY LEVITT
description: ALBANY, April 20The office of State Controller Arthur Levitt said today that the performance of the Transit Authority's 300 newest subway cars was so poor that the authority should consider suing the manufacturer to recover the money it has spent trying to correct the problems.

title: 44 million years in the makingthen up in a puff of smoke
description: It is 44,000,000 B.C., the Eocene epoch. Mastodons and camels, deer and threetoed horses the size of dogs graze the grasslands of what will one day be the Texas Panhandle. To the south stretches the broad expanse of a shallow sea, the embryonic Gulf of Mexico. Beneath its waters, deep within the earth's .cruse, a fantastic voyage has begun: the odyssey of a barrel of oil.

title: CAMPAIGN TRENDS BUOY FRENCH LEFT
description: PARIS, April 20Less than a week after the formal start of trance's presidential election campaign, trends have begun to emerge showing an unexpectedly strong popular desire for farreaching policy changes.

description: Miss Marguerite Elaine Hamrick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Fullerton Hamrick of New. York, was married here yesterday afternoon to Day R. Shields, son of Mr. and Mrs: Charles R. Shields of Shaker Heights, Ohio.

title: Alampi Urges Tree Planting
description: TRENTON  Planting a tree on Arbor Day, next Friday, can have special significance this year, according to Secretary of Agriculture Phillip Alampi.

title: A method of madness
description: In a healthy cultural atmosphere, it would mean a great deal to say that Dan Jacobson upholds the tradition of craft in writing with this small but impeccably ordered and paced study of madness. As things stand, however, which is crassly, I hesitate to tell the truth about Jacobson's 10th book; for to say that it is complex, not easily summarized, cannot be imagined as a movie, will certainly not appeal to people looking for a good read, those unencumbered with respect for subtle weavings of perception in fictional form to say this is to consign this fine novel to quick if honorable obscurity.

title: New Colors and Sizes Brighten The Daffodils
description: EXCITING things are happening in the daffodil world. There are new color combinations, new flower forms and more amateurs are trying their skills at hybridizing. Daffodil enthusiasts in the United States have always been eager to acquire the newest flowers either for their gardens or show benches. For many years their bulbs came from abroad where there was great activ??y and interest in developing hybrids. In Southern Ire land, Mts. J. Lionel Richardton is noted for her double daffodils. The late Guy E. Wilson raised many outstanding white daffodils. W. I. Dunlop continues his work is Ballymena as well as three recent names: Rathowen, Ballydorn and Carncairn growers.

title: Shoemaker Up, Agitate Coast Victor
description: ALBANY, Calif., April 20 (AP)  Bill Shoemaker celebrated the 25th anniversary of his first racing victory by guiding Agitate to a threequarterlength victory in the $122,400 California Derby today at Golden Gate Fields.

Austen Newhall, an opportunity to shoot live models; The Plain People, a photo essay on the Amish by Lois Clarke and Roslyn MacNish; (and Synesthesia, by Chick and Anne Herbert, a presentation of color slides blended with interpretative music. The event will take place at the Hotel Commodore on May 5, and the charge will be $3 for nonmembers. For more information call Antoinette Grimes, publicity chairman, at (212) OR 34371.

description: MOSCOWThe common conception in the world at large is that NATO and the Warsaw Pact are rough equals, but the vast differences in the two defense systems was demonstrated anew last week.

title: Three novels
description: My general nostalgia pressure wavers somewhere around dull normal; I found The Last Picture Show unmemorable and stay dryeyed. at photographs of nowdead Presidents and movie stars. This information is in order because Bijou, set in 19 in smalltown Tennessee, stars Lucius, a 13yearold who is not only a movie freak but also an usher in one of the local theaters, where he gets to watch, over and over, the scenes he reconstructs and fantasizes about during the rest of his life And so the real details of his days  his role as the steady one in a family consisting, of his appealing, alcoholic father, his weird, spunky mother and two reformschool brothers, and his pursuit of a local bootlegger's daughter  are disguised, norrounded, submerged into Alan Ladd and Veronica Lake plots and Hedy Lamarr dreams.

title: Carly's Happy About Being Happy
description: CARLY SIMON has never been in motorcycle accident, nor freaked out on drugs. She didn't have to quit school at 14 to support her family by slinging hash nor has she made the front pages by throwing punches at paparazzi. Yet, by communicating basic huinan experiences, she has reached superstar status in the world of rock with her latest and fourth album, Hotcakes, selling just like Aunt Jemima's best, and her album betore that, No Secrets, having sold almost two million records. That album contained her millionselling single You're So Vain, the song that kept the pop world and its fans guessing whether it was Mick Jagger or Warren Beatty or just who it was that walked into the party like you were walking onto a yacht.

title: City Council Inquiry On Mental Patients Will Open Tuesday
description: The City Council will open an investigation on Tuesday into the problems created in the city by the release of thousands of mental patients from state institutions into communities here without adequate provision for their care and rehabilitation.

title: PRESIDENT TO SPEAK IN SOUTH AND WEST
description: CAMP DAVID, Md., April 20 (AP)President Nixon is planning public appearances in Mississippi and Arizona in the next two weeks as part of his campaign to blunt impeachment moves, sources reported today.

title: MassTransit Woes Bring Aerospace Down to Earth

description: TRENTON  For the first time in its history, the New Jersey State Museum is devoting itself to a oneman retrospective exhibition of the work of a living artist.

title: Green Again
description: The grass is green again, and that makes all the difference. Now all the flowers of spring can come to bloom, and all the trees can burst their buds and come into leaf. This won't happen overnight, but it is possible now. Until there was green grass in the meadows there couldn't be fresh green leaves on all the trees. That is one of the rules nature has made for itself.

title: ALVIN FRIELAND
description: Alvin Frieland, owner and president of the Coree Creations Corporation, a lingerie manufacturer here, died Thursday, apparently of a coronary attack, at the City Hospital Center at Elmhurst, Queens. He was 56 years old and lived at 320 South Harrison Street, East Orange, N. J,

title: U.S. Will Take Over Program for Children's Lunches
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 The United States Department of Agriculture notified New New York State today that it would take over administration of the state's summer food program for needy children.

title: Curb on Judges' Aides
description: The New York State Bar Association voted to forbid law secretaries and other members of a judge's staff from taking part in politics. The amendment to the State Code of Judicial Conduct was expected to have widespread effects on the judicial and political structures of the state. Page 31.

title: Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following events may obtained from the beneficiaries unless other wise indicated.

title: Headliners
description: Have thin, Will Travel was his calling card as he roamed through the badlands of New England giving pony rides to children. His name: Victor De Costa, also known as Paladin. Now a United States magistrate has ruled that the character Paladin, from the popular old television series Have Gun, Will Travel, was actually pirated from Mr. De Costa when he worked as a cowboy at horse shows and rodeos during the late forties and fifties. The show's writers said it didn't happen that way, but the judge was apparently convinced by Mr. De Costa's resemblance to the television character, as played, by actor. Richard Boone. Mr. De Costa, the magistrate ruled, is entitled to the proceeds of their wrong; which could, total more than $14million, C.B.S. has lawyers, will appeal.

title: Lake Superior Ore Plant Ordered Shut as Polluter
description: MINNEAPOLIS, April 20A Federal judge ordered the Reserve Mining Company today to shut down immediately its huge plant in northern Minnesota because its discharges of industrial wastes into the air and into the waters of Lake Superior substantially endanger the health of the people in five communities, including the city of Duluth.

description: Tidyman, Hancock Joining Talents

title: Newark: An Appealing Display of Folk Art
description: NEWARKEighteenth and 19thcentury American folk art, with its charm and vitality, has been gaining rapidly increasing acceptance. But not many admirers of folk art know that the Newark Museum began to collect and display it in the early 1930's.

title: APlant Is Getting U.S. Advice On Ecology
description: WASHINGTONThe Atomic Energy Commission is preparing to tell the Jersey Central Power & Light Company, which operates the only nuclear generating plant in New Jersey, what it must do to combat severe environmental problems.

title: Lubin and Gottlieb Offer Piano Duos In a Tully Hall Bill
description: Most pianists love to play fourhand music as a source of fun and relaxation, although few of them bother to team up for a formal recital. Ernest Lubin and Jay Gottlieb, composers as well as pianists, got together for a program of duets in Tully Hall yesterday afternoon, and even if they did not always succeed in disguising the difficulties of the medium, they were able to communicate much of the enjoyment.
