title: Abducted Florida Banker Free As He Swims Ashore to Safety
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 20 (UPI)  Albert L. Dantzler, a bank executive, told the Federal Bureau of Investigation today that he leaped from a boat in the Atlantic and swam ashore in the dark to escape two men who held him captive 25 hours and demanded $60,000 ransom.

title: Escaped Bomber Captured by F.B.I.
description: Peter Mauchlin, the convicted bank robber and bomber who escaped from the Federal House of Detention here last Sunday, was captured last night in Myrtle Beach, S. C., the F.B.I. announced.

title: MAUTICALS
description: Sailboats and anchors are certain to turn up every summer on shirts, sweaters and beachwear. This year, as always, the most popular colors for those classic, jaunty designs are navy blue and white.

title: Vinnie Taylor, 25, Guitarist For ShaNaNa, Found Dead
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., April 20 (UPI)Vinnie Taylor, lead guitarist of the singing group ShaNaNa, which jumped to national prominence by parodying nineteenfifties Rock n' roll idols, was found dead in a motel room here last night. He was 25 years old.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTON  According to Senator, James P. Dugan, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, the objective of the committee's unusual hearing last Tuesday was to show how really ignorant Tony Imperiale was.

title: A Study Urges Revisions In the U.S. Sugar Program
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) A private research group has urged that Congress undertake drastic revisions of the Government's sugar program, alleging that it is costly to consumers and taxpayers.

title: City's Elderly Held Victims of Inflation And Poor Housing
description: Despite growing public recognition of the needs of the aged, they, remain in desperate straits because of rising inflation and poor housing, according to the Jewish Association for Services for the Aged.

title: The World
description: The drought afflicting subSaharan Africa, which has already contributed to political disturbances in Ethiopia, apparently was a principal factor in the overthrow of Niger's President flamani Diori last week.

title: GoldRush, A Retriever, Best in Show
description: RESTON, Va., April 20A powerful dog, with a coat of rich gold, hit the jackpot at the Old Dominion Kennel Club's 62d show today which drew a record entry of 3,039. He was Ch. Cummings GoldRush Charlies, a golden retriever owned by Mrs. Robert V. Clark Jr. of Middleburg, Va., and Dr. L. C. Johnson, a research physicist at

title: Bergen Bar Offers Loans to Students
description: HACKENSACK  The Bergen County Bar Association has announced a program of interestfree loans for needy lawschool students.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Secretary of State Kissinger declared that the policy of the good partner would be the new United States approach to Latin America and the Caribbean. Addressing the General Assembly of the 23member Organization of American States in Atlanta, Mr. Kissinger said that we in the United States have come to realize that a revolution has taken place in Latin America. AS a result, he said, we convene as equals. [1:8.]

title: GOLF SHOTS
description: Golfers have never been known to show a lack of courage in sporting bright colors or bold patterns on the links. This summer's sport clothes may be slightly softertones, but the stripes and checks and plaids and zigzags are as outspoken as ever.

title: A kind of balance between nations
description: Since it led the way in exposing the disaster of the U.S. war in Vietnam, the American Left has mulled over two less clearcut questions than whether the U.S. should have left Vietnam alone. How many of Asia's troubles would go away if U.S. imperialism went away? Is U.S. imperialism by now a paper tiger as Mao Tsetung long ago said it was?

title: Our Falling Birth Rate
description: WASHINGTON, April 20The birth rate in the United States, according to the Government's National Center for Health Statistics, has now dropped to its lowest point in history, and judging by the bare facts all around us, this is not because sex has gone out of style.

title: Casts as Muchas 2 Round Trips by Air, 3 on Charter Flights
description: whenever someone hits a jackpot. The broad high windows of the Double Room that made the moody ocean a companionable element of every voyage have been blocked out. Where the traveler could once sit above the waves with a book or just stand with a dreamy stare; there are now rows of shops selling dolls in sailor suits and soup plates stamped with the faces of the royal family. The lime green and black Midships Lobby that was originally designed to house a sculpture by Henry Moore or Barbara Hepworth now offers the voyager an illustrated circle of advertisements for British cigarettes and gin. The high observation lounge called the Look Out, from which passengers used to watch the plunging bow and observe sea weather from windows on three sides, is gone altogether. In its old vicinity there is now a cluster of duplex staterooms costing so much more than $1,000 a day as to be available only to the moguls of mascara rock and the sheiks of (Saudi) Araby.

description: BATTING

title: RABIN GAINS IN BID FOR ISRAELI POST
description: TEL AVIV, April 20Minister of Labor Itzhak Rabin emerged tonight as the favorite to succeed Mrs. Golda Meir as Premier of Israel after he received the powerful support of Finance Minister Pinhas Sapir.

title: NEW SUBWAY CARS DECRIED BY LEVITT
description: ALBANY, April 20The office of State Controller Arthur Levitt said today that the performanceof the Transit Authority's 300 newest subway cars was so poor that the authority should consider suing the manufacturer to recover the money it has spent trying to correct the problems.

title: A Perfect Middlebrow malgam
description: THE Pop art movement, which blitzed the contemporary art scene in the early sixties and broke all records (at least for modern times) in the speed with which it established itself as an art of the museums, is a phenomenon that defies easy analysis. So much of its success belongs to a realm of social experience where esthetic values are not of paramount importance, and yet it was as art that Pop achieved its swift and (to many artists and critics) demoralizing renown. And it is as art that it remains for some of us an indigestible lump in the throat of high culture.

title: Making History by Talking
description: NEWARK It was in October or November of 1907 that I got a job in the laboratory of Thomas Edison in West Orange. I had left high school just before that, for I just wanted to quit and get a job.

title: College Aide Appointed
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 20 (AP)  Dr. Thomas P. Melady, former United States Ambassador to Burundi and Uganda, was appointed this week as executive vice president of St. Joseph's College.

title: The Men Who Help Presidents
description: You can, say one thing for Watergate: it has made us think a bit more carefully about the role of the White House staff. But so far we have focused mainly on personalities, not on the staff system itselfand for perfectly understandable reasons. The system can't testify, it can't pleabargain, it can't resign suddenly or even punch buttons on a tape recorder. Yet the shape of the White House organization chart, no less than the individuals named on it, helps determine what the President doesand how much he knows. As Richard Johnson says of Nixon in Managing the White House, If the President was unaware of the coverup, [his] information ated his unawareness. If he did know about the coverup, his system shielded him from the harsh reality of public exposure.

title: Red Smith
description: In language with a curiously familiar ring, the Federal Communications Commission complains that the National Football League has displayed something less than absolute forthcoming candor about the effect that televisionhad on attendance at games last season. The F.C.C. doesn't say that Pete Rozelle refused to deliver 42 tapes and documents that were reSports quested, but it says the commissioner and the 26 clubs were reThe Times luctant to provide financial data. The commission seems to imply that Rozelle and his lawyers wanted to decide unilaterally which portions of the material were relevant to its inquiry. In spite of these difficulties, the F.C.C. has delivered a 400page report to Congress declaring that Congress didn't hurt business a lick when it forbade TV blackouts of the home area on sellouts.

title: NASCAR Tinkers Again With Carburetor Rules
description: For the second time in two months, the National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing has changed its carburetor rules for Grand National cars. Last month, rules went into effect to restrict bigger  engine cars (367 to 433 cubicinch displacement) with smaller carburetor openings thus enabling smallerengine cars to become more competitive. After two races NASCAR officials decided last week that the smaller cars were too competitive. Starting tomorrow, the carburetors will be open slightly for the bigcars.

title: Poll Finds Shrinking Majority Still Opposes Amnesty on Draft
description: A shrinking majority of Americans continue to oppose amnesty for Vietnam draft evaders, but relatively few want to see them punished with fines or jail terms, according to the Gallup poll.

title: The Orchestra as Kibbutz
description: A WEEK from tomorrow night, when the American Symphony Orchestra presents the last of its five concerts this season, the Orchestra players will have good reason to be jubilant. Not only have they succeeded in resuscitating an orchestra that had been dead for an entire season, but in a city where finances, Competition and outsized egos all but preclude experiments in structural organization, they have made that orchestra selfgoverning. In the new ASO, a trumpet player bargains with creditors, a violist prepares the orchestra's tax returns, a cellist is personnel manager and everybody helps with fundraising and office work. The idea is to fuse two wildly different approaches to organizing and financing an orchestra: the timehonored elitist practice of patronage and the more egalitarian, cooperative principle of the kibbutz.

title: Martha Gates Wed to Christopher Hays

title: Letters to the Editor
description: An aspect of the abandonment situation that I believe is significant in producing neighborhood decay result from current practices of the courts [Abandonment of Housing Leaves Banks With Problems, March 17].

title: What's Doing in
description: THE ASSASSINATION SITEProbably the most visited area in Dallas is the site where Lee Harvey Oswald shot and fatally wounded President John Fitzgerald Kennedy as his motorcade turned toward the Triple Underpass in Dealey Plaza on a cold November day in 1963. The old school book depository, at Elm and Houston on the west edge of downtown, is the building from which Oswald fired. He opened up from a window on the sixth floor in the southeast corner of the building, and there are plaques on marble stones in Dealey Plaza that give a brief account of the assassination, Behind the old red courthouse between Elm and Main Streets is a huge cenotaph (empty tomb) commemorating President Kennedy. It is situated on a large grass and concrete plot known as the County Historical Plaza. The cabin of John Neely Bryan, the first settler in Dallas, is also located there. At 501 Elm, next to the book depository, is the John F. Kennedy Museum containing an exhibit of paintings, official police photographs and other items of interest pertaining to the assassination. An audiovisual exhibit, entitled The Incredible Hours, is open daily. from 9 to 5 and in the evening during summer. Admission is $1.50 for adults and 75 cents for children 6 to 11 years old. It is not unusual to see tourists wandering through the assassination area likepilgrimseven at midnight.

title: Boston vs the Doctors: Strange Case
description: BOSTONIn 1814, the Commonwealth of Massachusetts passed a law to deter the then common practice of robbing graves to supply medical schools with cadavers for research. Medical schools no longer lack cadavers, but the statute has stayed on the books, hard by other legal fossils such as a law against the exhibition of mutilated horses.

title: AFARIS TAKE NEW GROUND
description: Those plentifullypocketed, khakicolored safari suits which have been going great guns in recent seasons, will be getting a lion's share of attention this spring and summer. The relaxedbutdashing look has found favor with men for all kinds of casual occasions, even, if its only a Saturday safari, bargainhunting in Dry Dock Country.

title: Draftfree Army
description: With Selective Service calls halted since December, 1972, and draftees still in the armed forces down below 2 per cent of the military total, an initial evaluation the volunteer Army concept can now begin to be made. It is not encouraging.

title: Candace Leeds Plans Nuptials
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence Leeds of White Plains of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Candace Leeds, to Robert Wagenseil Jones, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Robert Bradford Jones of Providence, R. I.

title: Editors Concerned on Press Freedom
description: ATLANTA, April 20  The American Society of Newspaper Editors concluded its fourday annual meeting here yesterday with most of those attending in apparent agreement that, despite Watergate, serious challenges to the freedom of the press were not only continuing but also accelerating.

title: The Sociology of Emile Durkheim
description: In recent years a growing number of younger social scientists, in reaction to what they conceive to be the constricting and narrowgauged objectivism of their elders, have engaged in a veritable orgy of subjectivism. A concern with the nuances of private experience, and with the ineffable sensibilities of peculiar selves engaged in building personal constructions of reality, has seemed at times to have almost displaced concern with the public world and the structured social order. Personalistic relativism seemed to have taken command. Phenomenological sociology, ethnomethodology, reflexive sociology, cognitive anthropology and related schools of thought appeared ready to lay claim to much of the territory that earlier had been explored by students of public and objective social structures. But in the last year or two the harbingers of yet another turn in the shifts of the Zeitgeist have become discernible. The best indication of this reaction is the recent appearance of a whole series of books on the great French master of social structural sociology, Emile Durkheim.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: IN MARCH the consumer price index rose 1.1 per cent to 143.1 per cent of the 1967 base period... The British trade deficit in March reached a record $1.08billion, wider than the previous record of $1.01billion in February. . . The World Bank estimated that the growth rate of industrial countries this year would average 1.3 to 2.4 per cent, compared with a real growth rate of 6.8 per cent in 1973.

Hullo, Rose, said the guard. And Jean Marsh, the new Rose of England and the most famous Maid since Marian, knew that life below stairs was starting up all over again.

title: Surprise Me (Please!)
description: I AM afraid that my reactions to Music! Music! were a little peculiar. Music! Music!, in for a limited engagement at City Center, is a limping cavalcade of hot about every showbiz standard that ever, sold a million copies of something or other, and I came out at the intermission vigorously humming Harold Ronie's Franklin D. Roosevelt Jones. Not because it's in the show. Because, it isn't. And I couldn't explain why it wasn't. Here they were, these historial onstage, working their way through the Great Depressionmaking a very good thing of Jay Gorney's very good Brother, Can You Spare a Dime?and trying to find a musical way out of it. The best conceivable way out of it was the heartlifting energy of Harold Rome's Franklin D. Roosevelt Jones and they hadn't even thought of it. Struggled through half a dozen less relevant popular tunes instead. Well, you can see what I was doing. Arranging my own show in my head.

title: Even HighPriced Whiting Provides a Frugal Feast
description: FREEPORTThe fishermen and dealers around the weathered docks here say that whiting is in short supply and the price is high, an opinion that the frugal consumer who continually buys whiting at the fish store for no more than about 80 cents a pound may find hard to believe.

title: Bluefish Biting of Surfers Called Rare
description: The Good Friday assault on young urfers at Haulover Beach in North Miami by thousands of bluefish has surprised the country's fish experts. Reports in the press that a dozen youths were badly bitten and four hospitallied on the morning of April 13 were met with open skepticism by scientists, who said that they knew of no record of any such incident.

But Mr. Taylor happens to be a missionaryminded Bible paraphraser who plows most of the proceeds from The Living Bible back into his own publishing concern, Tyndale House, or gives them to evangelical causes.

title: The Pound Files
description: Late in 1943, following a Federal Grand Jury indictment for Ezra Pound's arrest, the F.B.L undertook what can best be described as the Literary Manhunt of the Age. Pound, the Dalai Lama of modern poetry, had chosen, by dint of his compliance with the Italian Radio Network (E.LAR.) to support the proponents of National Socialism. In the eyes of his countrymen he thus became a hardened war criminal whose proFascist, antiSemitic broadcasts knowingly, intentionally, wilfully, unlawfully, feloniously, traitorously, and treasonably did adhere to the enemies of the United States.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Is the baby going the way of the manned bomber and the nickel candy bar? The population figures suggest that such is the case. Increasing numbers of women decline to reproduce and those who proceed are cutting down on quantity, with the result that pediatricians are looking for other lines, of work and the night howl of the tooth cutter is becoming as rare as the mating call of the loon.

title: A Look at Two Men Mr. Nixon Chose for His Time of Trouble
description: WASHINGTONIt is nearly midnight in New York or Phoenix or Chattanooga, and there he sits at head table, puffing at his pipe as he listens to parade of dull speeches before taking his own turn at the podium. He has been up since dawn, and another dawn will be not far away when he walks down the steps of. Air Force 2 into the darkness Maryland's Andrews Air Force base to be greeted by a sleepyeyed general assigned to welcome him home, no matter what the hour.

title: REPORT ON MEN'S WEAR
description: While the wavering line that separates sportswear from suits and tailored clothing isn't exactly going to melt under the summer, sun, it's bound to blur a bit. The apparent pleasure with which an increasing number of men are relinquishing some of the more uptight dress rules has not gone unnoticed: The emphasis this summer is on comfortable, easytowear apparel. Styles and fabrics which until now had been benched as strictlyforleisure, are scoring mightily in the dressup division. Clothing makers have stopped crying the denimblues and come up with impressive, madefromdenhn suits and sport coats, while safari jackets, enjoying a roaring success mated with matching trousers, are set to trespass even further into dressy territory. As for those traditionally styled suits and jackets, they are not about to be abandoned; they're just trying harder to attract attention with fresh shades, feisty textures and showoffy unmatched sets. And with sportswear putting in a softly shaded, cool appearance, this will not be a summer to streak through.

title: WALDHEIM SEEKS URGENT AID FUND

description: The City Council will open an investigation on Tuesday into the problems created in the city by the release of thousands of mental patients from state institutions into communities here without adequate provision for their care and rehabilitation.

title: Truce Force in the Mideast To Be Cut, Waldheim Says
description: UNITED NATIONS, April 20 (Reuters)  Secretary General Waldheim reported plans today to reduce the strength of the United Nations Emergency Force in the Middle East, which has never attained its intended strength of 7,000 men.

title: Design: For the terrace, the lawn or tar beach
description: Everything, it seems, is going upgroceries, clothes, gasoline. One result is that many New Yorkers may find themselves stranded in town this summer. But they can go up too. Rooftops offer the great coopedup majority the same escape into the sun that penthouse dwellers and secondhome owners pay big money for. And a summer on tar beach can be enjoyed in style. Summer, furniture this year is sturdy, comfortable and handsome, and most of it can be hauled up to the roof as easily as onto the porch or terrace.

title: Diplomats Working to Sell Washington Fans Soccer
description: The Washington Diplomats are working hard to establish themselves, both in the North American Soccer League, which they will join this season, and with the people of the capital. Dennis Viollet, a fiesty Englishman, is the hardest worker of the Diplomats (please, don't call them Dips). Viollet is the coach, lecturer and ticketseller, whenever possible. For close to two months she has been conducting vigorous practice sessions, conditioning some veterans who have joined the Diplomats and sorting out ragtag freeagents, anxious to make the grade in prosoccer.

title: Clothes for Fall: Mostly Casual
description: A good portion of the clothes that people are wearing these days comes under the heading of sportswear. That's partly because everybody's dressing more casually and Partly because the concept of sportswear has expanded so much it includes practically everything. At any rate, as the first presentations of clothes for next fall and winter took place in New York last week, the sportswear concept was dominant, even though many styles were meant to be worn at night.

title: The Wanderers
description: This is a superbly written book about coming of age in a section of the Bronx.

description: Taking a trout on a fly you tied yourself is one of angling's sweetest experiences.

title: 4 Bronx Guardsmen Hurt As Bus Overturns Upstate
description: Several National Guardsmen were injured when their bus overturned and burst into Flames early yesterday in Cortland, N.Y.; but only four were hospitalized and their injuries were not listed as serious. Guardsmen in other buses broke windows and pulled out the trapped men. The Bronx unit was headed for Camp Drum, near Watertown, N.Y., for field artillery practice. The state police said a faulty steering mechanism apparently cause the bus to strike a guard rail and overturn.

Mondale, Democrat of Minnesota, announced today that they would push for $5.9billion income tax cut to bolster buying power.

title: Growth Reported In Sod Industry
description: TRENTON  the state's sod industry has tripled in the last decade, according to Roy M. Atkinson, who is in charge of the certified sod program of the Department of Agriculture.

title: Clyde and His Cool
description: When he shuffles onto the Madison Square Garden court today as the last member of the New York Knicks' start' ing team to be introduced, Walt Frazier will be accorded an ovation worthy of his 38 points in the 103100 victory over the Boston Celtics on Friday night. His reaction will be worthy of his cool. No expression, no perspiration. But inside he'll be proud. Inside he'll be smiling, too, because two weeks ago, whin he was struggling in the opening playoff series against the Capital. Bullets, the same people were booing him. Inside he's not always cool. Inside the basketball player known as Clyde is churning sometimes. Inside he discovered in high school that people are funny. Funny fickle. And he discovered it as as football player, not basketball

title: Television
description: IN THE ultimate scheme of things, if they have one, the fact that Dandy Don Meredith has Ieft ABC for NBC would seem to matter about ad much as halitosis. There was never any excuse for Monday Night Football in the first place, much less a teleological significance to the Terrible Triad of Meredith, Howard Cosell and Frank Gifford. Cosell is rumored to be thinking  why do I pause?  of running for the United States Senate against James Buckley. Lucky New York! That would leave the Giffer alone in the blabber booth, and we might actually have a chance to concentrate on the game.

title: SILK GETS ROUGHED UP
description: Above, blue and rust overplaid a nubbysurfaced brown and white jacket which joins Terylene and wool with silk. Center vent. By Mavest. $85 at Gimbels. At right, burlapwoven raw silk jacket is naturaltoned, flappatchpocketed, deeply centervented. By Majer. $170 at Bergdorf Goodman. Pastel plaided tie by Cricket. Her dress by Head. Smooth as silk? Not this summer. Alone or blended, silk takes on a toughtextured appearance for suits and sport coats. Above, a textured, handwoven silk jacket predominantly plaided in red, natural and gold. Lebow's centervented coat is $180 at Lord & Taylor, New York.

title: SPRINGTIME
description: NOW is a good time to invest in dwarf woody evergreens. Once they are planted in good soil, and given a good start, they will continue to live for many years without any attention.

title: Youth Revisited, or. Victory for Milton and Friends
description: Baseball season has been Winched. That's probably why my 7yearold's benevolent aunt presented him with a game glowingly described as a superior baseball game for fans of all ages.

title: Letters: Big Sky Defended
description: To the Editor: As one of the architects of Big Sky, I read James P. Sterba's account of his visit (Big Sky of Montana: Chet Hunt ley's Controversial Legacy, Travel Sec tion, March 31) with a great deal of interest. The writer's initial comment that Big Sky was a little less polished than its advertisements suggested sums up a great deal of his discontent, and I feel that many of his critical remarks can only be described as premature. Big Sky is not finished, and not only are many buildings and amenities yet to be completed but also transport systems, roads and other improvements.

title: E. S. Bursack Weds Joan Friebely
description: Miss Joan Stewart Friebely, daughter of Mrs. John Daniel Friebely of Plainifeld, N. J., and the late Mr. Friebely and a granddaughter of the late Norman Thomas, the Socialist leader, was married in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday afternoon to Elliott Stephen Bursack, son of Mrs. Betnard Bursack of Manchester, Conn., and the late Mr. Bursack. The nondenominational ceremony at the Cambridge Boat Club was performed by the Rev. Sidney Lovett, former chaplain at Yale University.

title: Tourism in Britain Drops Despite Promoters' Efforts
description: LONDON, April 20 (Reuters) Britain's tourist boom is showing signs of tapering off, although the country's industrial crisis has eased, British authorities; said this week.

title: Chavez's United Farm Workers Union Facing a Crucial Test as White California Grapes Near Harvest
description: THERMAL, Calif., April 20The slow ripening of the white table grape in the vineyards of the Coachella Valley is bringing the beleaguered United Farm Workers union closer to ability a crucial test of its ability to remain a potent force in the American labor market.

title: Future Oil Is Financing Britain's Current Deficit
description: LONDONWithin the next week or so the Bank of England will be organizing one of the most momentous ceremonies in its long ceremonial traditionthe formal signing of the record $2.5billion Eurodollar loan agreement announced by the British Government in last month's budget.

title: Kids to the rescue
description: Here it is. A big environmental education in one small, nifty package. A book created for kids that is clearly a boon to parents and teachers. Author Betty Miles and artist Claire Nivola in separate chapters lovingly describe the land, air and water around us, and offer simple ways for all people to save these renewable resources. They suggest easy experiments for kids to carry out to dramatize abuses of resources. The, last chapter is full of bowtodoitseverything from how to write a professional newspaper story to ways of forming a block association.

title: Field Marshal Ayub Dead; ExPresident of Pakistan
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, April 20Field Marshal. Mohammad Ayub Khan, President of Pakistan from 1958 to 1969, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home near Islamabad. He was 66 years old, and had, been living in quiet retirement since relinquishing power five years ago.

title: Soviet Five Set For U.S. Tour
description: A junior basketball team from the Sovitt Union rives here tonight for twd games this week against ropolitan area high school players. The Russians will play four other games in the United States on a tour conducted by the Amateur Athletic Union.

title: Is It Plain or Fancy?
description: ONE of man's most endearing traits (I'm not being chauvinist, it's just that I don't presume to speak for woman) is his compulsion to simplify life when it grows too complexand to complicate it when simplicity begins to pall. These apparently contradictory impulses actually reinforce one another, giving our lives an interesting ebb and flow. The only really stable person, as someone has pointed out, is a dead one.

title: Book Ends
description: Help! We didn't say it. A woman executive with a large bookstore chain did. What she said was that Americans apparently need help or as she put it, What people are looking for these days is a book that will change their lives in 9 minutes. In other words, the selfhelp book, as it's known in the trade is booming this spring. The term is a rattier vague and looselydefined one but generally it means books that promise greater physical, emotional, parental, sexual, professional, pecuniary, etc. wellbeing. A sampler of titlesall on or bubbling under the Best Seller Listwill give an idea of what we mean: How to Be Your Own Best Friend. The Joy of Sex, You Can Profit from a Money Crisis, Creative Divorce, Cellulite, Parent Effectiveness Training, Type A Behavior and Your Heart, How I Turn Ordinary Complaints into Thousands of Dollars. Selfhelp books aren't new; Poor Rtclrard's Almanack was probably a selfhelp book, and they've always been staple items, but there seems to be an uncommonly large number of them at the moment. One might add Jonathan Livingston Seagull, really more inspirational book than novel, to the list; one might even include the current Management. by busjness guru Peter Drucker, a large tome of more than 30 minutes reading time that does in a different way for businessmen what Up the Organization and The Peter Principle did in the such talktoyourplant titles as. The Secret Life of Plants and Plants' Are Like People, as well as more conventional gardening books such as The New York Times Guide to House Plants. The talktoyourplant idea suggests an emotional content to this hobby; if you can't be your own best friend or find joy in sex, bave a meaningful relationship with a rubber plant. Maybe that's stretching things (ahem) but certainly the psychologicaladvice books, such as I'm O.K.You're O.K. and the other transactionalanalysis titles are also doing well, plus others of the instant psychoanalysis genre in the Q. and A. format pioneered by Dr. David Reuben (who has a new book out) and continued by How to Be Your Own Best Friend. Q. Can you change life in 30 minutes? A.?

title: Legal Betting? Odds Favor It
description: TRENTONNew Jersey is edging slowly toward the possibility of legalized gambling. At first, there maybe just a few softly lit, air conditioned rooms in Atlantic City where the wheels can be. spun and the dice rolled. But the political cards are now on the gaming table, and Governor Byrne is reassessing his hand.

title: The Ending Begins
description: Both the pace and control of events affecting President Nixon's White House tenure appear to be passing beyond his ability to manage them, and he is now confronted by the demands of othersprosecutors, committee chairmen, even the votersto which he must respond.

description: With the easing of the gasoline restrictions, the members of the metropolitan sports car clubs are humming just like their welltuned engines. The greater availability of fuel, though, does not mean the clubs are planning to return to the fullscale operations of previous years.

description: Dr. and, Mrs. Frank Hamilton Constantine of Englewood, N.J., and Grenada, W.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Byrd. Constantine, to Robert Paul Feldman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard A. Feldman of New York. The wedding is planned for July 27 in Englewood.

It is beyond me. I was a fool.

title: As the Summit Approaches the Superpowers Remain Divided on Strategic ??
description: The Soviet Union feels that dtente is going well but that it must be carefully tended. Soviet leaders are apparently determined to do so, reports The Times correspondent in Moscow, despite President Nixon's possible impeachment. But those very political difficulties, reports The Tirries diplomatic correspondent in Washington, make United States officials unenthusiastic about a NixonBrezhnev meeting. They reason; that the President's political weakness may make him act too tough in negotiations on the crucial issues.

description: Tenants of a dozen large apartment complexes urged legislators yesterday to pass a bill that would prevent landlords from converting rental buildings into cooperatives or condominiums unless more than half of the tenants gave their consent.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: ATLANTA  Mills Lane, bankers in the Southeast are likely to remark, is a tough apt to follow.

description: King Van Nostrand and Warren Lucas reached the final of the Eastern men's indoor tennis championship yesterday at the Stadium Tennis Center in the Bronx.

title: The Guiltless
description: Twentythree years ago the Austrian novelist Hermann Broch died in New Haven at the age of 65, having fled Nazi imprisonment soon after Hitler took over Austria. Broth had been a remarkably suocessful manager of his father's textile concern in Vienna, a city Broth later described as the Metropolis of Kitsch, the Vienna of Freud, Robert Musil, Karl Kraus, OperettaWisdom and Hap. py Apocalypses. But in his early forties he began to study mathematics, philosophy, andpsychology at the University of Vienna, and in 193132 he published a threevolume novel, The Sleepwalkers. Its theme is the decline of Germany; its wideranging cast of characters and its varied styles evoke the ethical, intellectual and moral weaknesses that led to World War I and to Germany's decayed and fragmented state at the war's end.

title: Al Carmines Opera to Debut
description: Some of the Rev. Al Carmines' friends have accused him of being too optimistic in his new work. And even Mr. Carmines himself occasionally wonders if he is really as hopeful as he might appear.

title: City Weighs New Tourist Center And Malls for Times Sq. Area
description: A vastly expanded touristinformation center in Times Square and a series of pedestrian malls there are among the proposals being explored by city planners as ways to upgrade the area, the head of the City Planning Commission has disclosed.

title: The real rulers of Russia
description: What is the basic strength of Soviet Communism, the power which animates and sustains that huge fabric? It is not what we once thought it to be. The original appeal of Communism was material, moral and ideological. It claimed to improve the welfare of the workers, to restore their selfrespect, and to do so in tune with historical necessity. In fact, 50 years after the Revolution, real wages had hardly regained the level of 1913; rural serfdom, abolished, by the Czars, has been reimposed; and the ideology convinces no one. What the Bolsheviks have created is a new system of power: power that has no basis in society, no reference to consent, no moral justification. We used to think that Lenin gave to Marxism a temporary political form; now we recognize that he used Marxism as the temporary ideological justification of a new structure of naked political power.

title: New York Age, a Black Weekly, Publishing Again
description: The New York Age, a firebrand fighter of racial injustice that died in the nineteen fifties, its zeal spent, was born again Thursday with its demeanor changed but its aim primarily the same.

title: On the Road in Texas
description: LAMESA, Tex., April 19It's a good time to drive down the highways, rather than flying in and flying out, Mrs. Frances Farenthold told about fifty Democrats gathered this afternoon in the community room on the second floor of the Lamesa National Bank.

description: DETROIT, April 20 (AP) A suit charging the Ford Motor Company with age discrimination will go to trial in about 60 days, United States District Court Judge Damon Keith said yesterday.

title: Mr. Exxon on the energy future
description: On the 51st floor of Manhattan's Exxon building  the softcarpet floor as it's knownis the spacious, modern office of the single most powerful man in the American oil industry. John Kenneth Jamieson, 63, is chairman of the board and chief executive of Exxon worldwide. He is 6 feet 3 inches tall, Weighs 200 pounds, a serious man who speaks slowly and seldom dodges a question. He started out in Canada as a refinery engineer with a B.S. from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, joined the Canadian affiliate of Exxon in 1948, won his present post in 1969.

description: Brian McElroy, who is taking his final fling with Villanova, and Joe Savage, who has pumped new life into Manhattan, emerged as the surprising heroes in the QueensIona Relays yesterday.

title: NEWS ADS ARE CUT BY UNION'S TACTICS

title: Israel's crisis is also his
description: As a consequence of trying to decide its own fate in war and peace, Gallant Little Israel has been transformed for, the more credulous people of this world into Israel the Aggressor. Areversal of opinion bike this, indeed the total replacement of one promotional myth by another, manipulated without scruple to fit the aims of a Great Power, was the subject that obsessed George Orwell, and I know no better insight into these late Middle. East indecencies than the political expositions of 1984.

title: Editors' Choice
description: Fiction

title: Strip Therapy
description: Details pile up, creating a devastating impact, in this lurid tale of a San Jose bottomless bar. Dancers, blearyeyed and vulnerable during the day, are strippers at. Obie's Glove AGoGo at night. Beyond the footlights, customers, drunk and leering, shout obscenities and grab at the girls. But the dancers bump and grind like automatons, their identities lost in the fantasies they project. They enclose themselves in their orgiastic roles. If the facade cracks, however, the fears and the humilitation and anger which they feel are exposed. Should they forget their role, their careers end; they fall into mercantile hands  Raided by reality. And if they complain, attempt to rebuff a crude advance or assert their rights as persons, they face a manager as avaricious as the mythical usedcar salesman and a bouncer as sensitive as a whiplash. At Obie's the dancers cultivate numbness to dispell misery.

title: Black Plastic Mulch Solves A Few Problems
description: RATHER than fight weeds in my vegetable garden, I switched to black plastic mulch. That's how I discovered that there were plenty of other good reasons for growing vegetables in a plasticcovered garden:

title: ArcretSenans: A Frenchman's Utopian Dream Built on Salt
description: YOU Cross a drawbridge over a moat, go through an arched en trance in a 12foot wall and emerge into a great semicircle of huge cold stone building, the slate. of their sweeping roofs growing a soft gray in the cool sunlight. The 24pane windows in the dormers peer out implacably on an imposing central struc ture which is fronted by a threestory portico supported by six stone col umns ringed by a succession of 10 stone squares, like a series of nuts on a long Molt: The whole place exudes a severe, mysterious feeling, as if it were part of some halfknown civilzation May an, perhaps. This was, in fact; the site of a weird little commune that funt tioned until 80 years ago, a fantastic utopia called the Royal Salt Works of ArcetSenans, situated in the foothills of the Jura Mountains of eastern France.

SMALL, overboutiqued section of the hundredodd blocks of the French Quarter is about all the tourist ever sees of this remarkable city, except for an occasional foray into the garden district. Fanning out around the Quarter are seemingly endless neighborhoods of uncommon stylistic richness, in various stages of regeneration and decay. The sheer architectural quality here is astounding.

description: PRETORIA, South Africa, April 20 (Reuters)Prime Minister John Vorster said Friday the United Nations would not make South Africa withdraw from SouthWest Africa or drive it from the territory.

title: Talks Break Down In Teachers' Strike At Kansas City, Mo,
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 20 Negotiations broke down yesterday in a teachers' strike that has kept 98 schools closed since March 26, and no further talks were scheduled.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: World Football League, Television and Oversaturation
description: To the Editor: William N. Wallace, in his April 7 analysis of the World Football League television outlook, allowed himself to be used in an obvious competitive play to downgrade the W.F.L. and TVS.

title: Round Top on the Map
description: TEXANS have a way of going to extremes. Usually this means that they have to have the biggest of anything. But when James Dick decided a few years ago that he wanted to start a summer piano school and festival, he picked the smallest town in Texas. It is called Round Top (pop. 89). Size, however, wasn't the reason for the choice. Round Top is historic, one of the state's earliest settlements. In fact, it predates the Texas Republic. It was once visited by Dvork, when he was staying at an adjacent village with a large Czech population. Today, with few inhabitants, its buildings and grounds are being restored to their early19thcentury simplicity by the Texas Pioneer Arts Foundation.

title: Bayonne Urged as a Final Berth for the New Jersey
description: A famous battleshipshe is decorated with 14 medals and 16 battle starsis rusting away in a West Coast naval yard. The vessel is the New Jersey, known as BB62 on official records and as The Big J to the men who manned her.

title: Man Held in Murder Of a Chinese Couple In Restaurant Here
description: A 43yearold man was charged with the murder of another man and a young woman in a Chinese, restaurant on the Lower East Side early yesterday.

title: Numismatics
description: NATIONAL Coin Week begins today. Thousands (hopefully many thousands) of collectors will be launching group programs and individual campaigns to spread the good word about the numismatic hobby among noncallectors from coast to coast.

title: Assemblyman in the Know
description: When Robert C. Wertz was a boy in the Bellerose section of Queens, just down the road from Creedmoor, many of his friends were the sons of employes at the state mental institution.

title: Soviet Output Gains in First Quarter, but Consumer Goods Lag
description: MOSCOW, April 20  Eco nomic statistics for the firs quarter today showed that Soviet industry grew faste than planned during the firs three months of 1974 but that the consumer branch has no kept pace with the ambition targets set for this year.

title: Promise of Mining Riches Splits Historic Virginia Area
description: LOUISA, Va., April 19After 250 years of rustic prosperity here among the whitefenced plantations of Virginia's Green Springs Valley, an environmental time bomb is ticking.

title: Godfrey L.C. Henderson to Wed Victoria. A. Nicolson of England
description: David Lancaster Nicolson, chairman of British Airways, and Mrs. Nicolson of London and Dunsfold, England, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Victoria Anne Nicolson, to Godfrey Lowell Cabot Henderson, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Welles Henderson of Gladwyne, Pa., and Manchester, Mass.

title: Learn the Fundamentals for Good Lawnsmanship
description: SHORTAGES and higher prices afflict commercial agriculture this year and home gardeners may notice changes in supplies. However, materials needed this spring for suburban lawn care will be available at least. The fundamentals are cleanup, fertilizing, liming, seeding, weed control, and mowing.

title: Pollution Bill Facing Fight in Assembly
description: TRENTONFor more than three years now, environmentalists throughout New Jerseyhave been waging an uphill struggle to get the Legislature to approve a bill that would extend residents the right to initiate damage suits against polluters and any state and local agencies that refuse to do anything about them.

title: C.B.S. Hires Swoboda As a Commentator
description: Ron Swoboda, a baseball slugger, was signed yesterday as a television commentator by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Gary Player of South Africa, after winning the Master's and perhaps thinking of sweeping professional golf's four major titles in one year, a feat that has never been done, noted: This gives me the first leg on the grand slam. At least I am the only man with a chance this year to win it.

title: Nixons Spend Weekend Alone at Camp David
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 UPI)  President Nixon and his wife were alone today at Camp David, the Maryland retreat where the President has gone regularly in the past to make his most difficult decisions.

title: New Air Aide Slated
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP)  President Nixon has announced that he will nominate) Davie P. Taylor an official of the Office of Management and Budget since 1970, to be Assistant Secretary of the Air Force for manpower and reserve affairs.

title: Graffiti Cleanups a Lark for the Young
description: To the chagrin of the Transit Authority, teenagers sentenced by the courts to weekend graffiti cleanups have accepted the penalty as a lark, a high official said last week.

title: Babysitting by government, business and the lady next door
description: The movement for Universal day care bears a certain similarity to the battle for legal abortion. For one thing the warriors are the sameyoung women freed by the pill from unplanned motherhood are demanding newer and costlier freedoms. In the case of abortion, they want for the poor what rich women already have, an outright guarantee that no one need continue a pregnancy she is unwilling or unable to handle. Day care is at once a Simpler and a more complex issue; the rich already have it but so do the poor, as we shall see. The movement wants us to accept the reality of day care and then, at vast make the best of it.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Our nationwide efforts at stimulating minority enterprise have been very impressive. Federal funding and loan guarantees for minority business development reached $1.4billion in fiscal 1973 up from $212million in fiscal 1969. Federal contracts and subcontracts to minority businesses Were raised from $4million in 1969 to $523million in 1973. The 1973 figure was an increase of 117 percent over the figure of $242million in 1972.

title: JAPAN AND CHINA SIGN AIR ACCORD; TAIWAN CUTS LINK
description: TOKYO, April 20  After months of controversy, Japan signed an aviation agreement with Communist China today, setting up flights between the two countries. But in retaliation, the Chinese Nationalists in Taiwan immediately banned Japanese planes from their air space.

title: Girl Burned in Nightgown Wins. $850,000 Damages
description: DETROIT, April 20 (AP) Federal District Judge Philip Pratt has approved an outotcourt settlement in which five companies will pay a total of $850,000 to a 5yearold girl who was burned over 70 per cent of her body when her nightgown caught fire.

title: Music in Review
description: Arlene Portney, a pianist, and Robert Portney, her brother who is a violinist, gave a joint recital at Tully Hall on Wednesday night. She studied at Curtis, Juilliard and Yale and is now teaching at American University in Washington. He is now a Harvard student and has studied violin with Ivan Galamian.

title: The man who made photography a fine art
description: In 1934, in the essay he contributed to a volume of tributes called America and Alfred Stieglitz, Harold Clurinan wrote: In view of his greatness as an artist, and his importance as a cultural force, comparatively little has been written about Alfred Stieglitz. Forty, years later, alas, there is little reason to revise this observation. The practice of enshrining the lives of modern American eminences in gigantic biographical mausoleums has left this obvious candidate miraculously untouched. Nor does there exist a single recent essay that even hints at what a definitive account of his prodigious career might consist of Stieglitz remains today what he was in his own lifetimeenigmatic, immense, but unknown to all but a small circle of devotees, an artist whose achievement has not been fully charted and a man whose energetic earthly existence has been blurred by a general tendency to indulge in spiritual euphemisms.

title: CUT IN BIRTH RATE URGED FOR JAPAN
description: TOKYO, April 20  A Japanese Government advisory council has recommended that Japan, which already has one of the world's lowest population growth rates, cut that growth rate even further, possibly to zero.

title: Cutbacks at Picatinny Worrying Town
description: ROCKAWAY TOWNSHIP A planned cutback of more than 400 employes at the Picatinny Arsenal, scheduled to take effect by the end of June, is worrying local municipal officials. They are concerned not only about the economic effects, but also about the possibility of further job losses.

title: San Juan Aroused By a Court Dispute On Noise in Church
description: SAN JUAN, P. R. April 20 A recent Supreme Court decision ordering a church to cut down on the sounds from its services has touched off a controversy here.

title: ExWall Streeter Likes New Life as a Turkey Farmer
description: CRANBURY  Many a Walter Mitty commutes to New York, daydreaming about quitting the rat race and setting up his own business close to home.

title: Rotterdam and Oceanic Offer Slot Machines on the High Seas
description: Onearmed bandits are making a bit of a comeback on the high seas.

title: The Greatest Show, Almost
description: I DON'T know how that canny old showman Phineas T. Barnum would rate the current Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circusthe 104th edition of The Gmatest Show on Earthbut I do know I can vouch for the almost unqualified approval of a certain 4yearold of my acquaintance. I say almost, because if 4yearolds are anything, they're picky; nothing's perfect, not even the greatest show on earth.

title: Photography
description: THE current exhibit by Paul Diamond at the Floating Foundation of Photography (West 79th Street Boat Basin, through May 12), consists almost entirely of photographs whose source of energy is the conscious interaction between the photographer and his human subjects.

title: The Onion Clan
description: MANY members of the genus Allium (onions, leeks, garlic) whose flavors range from sweet and mild to overpowering, are ancient vegetables. Among the artifacts of a Pharaoh's tomb, onions were found, tied in a cluster, still satin  skinned, but dust inside. The Bible mentions leeks and onions. Shallots or eschalots, Mum ascalonictim, derive their names from Ascalon, a town of ancient Palestine. Wearing leeks for identification, as plumes in their helmets, Welsh warriors of the seventh century won a battle the leek became their national symbol.

title: Mrs. Wendy Ashworth Bride of R. B. Multer
description: Mrs. Wendy Horton Ashworth of Farmington, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Raymond B. Multer of Hartford, son of Mr, and Mrs. Charles Multer of Lawrence, L. I. Mrs. Carleton Z. Hanor, a Justice of the Peace in Essex, Conn., performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Carl F. Traub of Essex, friends of the couple.

title: Deodorizer Company Fights Bar On Products
description: PISCATAWAY  The Federal Environmental Protection Agency, which normally concerns itself with air and water pollution over vast regions, has moved to block the sale of deodorizers by a small company here. The concern, in turn, feels that it may be the victim of an overzealous bureaucracy.

title: Paradiso
description: Four ways to read a masterpiece

title: SHOP TALK
description: EAST BRUNSWICK  Far Away Places Imports is a store that has to be seen to be believed. Somewhere between an art gallery and a gift shop, it contains a wealth of relatively inexpensive foreign treasures that have been executed with skill and flair by native craftsmen.

title: Plan for a Teaching Hospital Is Stalled
description: TRENTON  This year, as the Rutgers Medical School prepares to graduate its first fouryear class, it finds itself embroiled in a bitter dispute with Governor Byrne over the construction of a promised 325bed teaching hospital on the Piscataway campus.

title: The Dance: Martha Graham's Variety
description: The variety of Martha Graham's choreography is typical of a great master. Equally typical within all this diversity, the Graham profile, the Graham vision, remain constant. Her work is as recognizable and identifiable as, say, music by Mozart or paintings by Braque. This was amply demonstrated at the Mark Hellinger Theater Friday night and yesterday afternoon, when five works were given, each distinctive and yet each bearing the Graham hallmark.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Time was when the spy enjoyed life and knew where he was going. The exemplar was James Bond. He was given an assignment and carried it through, nonchalantly knocking off whatever opposition that crossed him. He enjoyed good food, was one of the alltime connoisseurs of vintage wines, and slept with more girls than there are girls in Europe.

title: 3 Drown in Hawaiian Storm
description: HONOLULU, April 20 (UPI) Three persons died yesterday after a storm lashed the Hawaiian Islands, washing several homes into the sea and causing massive flooding.

title: Town Service Pools Weighed
description: NORTH BRUNSWICK The twoman police force and the parttime tax collector could become relics. of the past, if the state's Department of Community Affairs has its way.

title: June Bridal Set In Mount Kisco, By Miss Tripp

description: WEST CALDWELLMore than 6,000 students from 241 schools throughout the state are participating in workstudy programs, which have been part of New Jersey's secondary education curriculum for the last decade.

title: HOME FURNISHINGS
description: Furniture sales, after two of the biggest years on record, are in a serious slump, particularly in the lowprice and middleprice brackets.

description: Commercial construction nationwide in 1973 set records, according to a survey published by Shiefman & Associates of Detroit, but the boom was predominantly in the smaller market areas.

title: Air Guard Unit in Suffolk Is Safe Until Sept. 30
description: WESTHAMPTONThe Air National Guard will be, at Suffolk County Airport here at least until Sept. 30. Although, all flying will cease after July 1unless the unit's phasingout order is rescindedthe 106th Fighter Interceptor Group will continue to function, performing closingdown duties during these final 90 days, accordingto a spokesman for the National Guard Bureau.

description: East and West met, in a manner of speaking, on the stage of Avery Fisher Hall on Friday night. The occasion was a joint concert by Ravi Shankar, a virtuoso on the sitar, the Indian instrument resembling an exotic guitar, and Yehudi Menuhin, the American violinist.

title: S.O.S. . . . S.O.S. . . . The Great Ladies of the Sea Are in Distress
description: THERE is not a sailor . . . there is not a Frenchman, said Aymar AchilleFould, the French Minister of Transport, late last month, who will not consider with sorrow the prospect of no longer seeing the Tricolor fluttering over the France, bid we cannot ignore the pressing economic problems of the day. With these and a few other words he announced that his Government had decided to cancel the annual subsidy without which the largest liner on the high seas cannot long remain either afloat or solventat least under the Scarletonwhite pennon of the centuryold Compagnie Gnrale Transatlantique. Rumors began to circulate at once: the France was to be sold to the Arab League for the purpose of transporting pilgrims to Mecca or, for unspecified reasons, to shiphungry Taiwan, shipconscious Moscow, shippoor Peking.

title: Food; The marvelous mushroom (fresh)
description: The discovery of botulism in some batches of canned mushrooms during the past year not only has sent sales of the canned variety plummeting, but those of fresh mushrooms as well. This is a shame. The F.D.A., in fact, has recommended that people buy fresh mushrooms. On this page, we willingly rally to the support of the absolutely blameless fresh mushroom:

description: To the Editor: The recent Administration request for $2.4 billion of aid to South Vietnam in fiscal year 1975 is an expensive holding action in the Vietnam waran effective guarantee of a continuing stalemate that will shield the Nixon Administration from the onus of having lost Vietnam to the Communists before 1976.

They were temporary beneficiaries of the conscienceeasing spate of public attentions then being granted to minoritygroup Americans, a phenomenon whose most permanent legacy may be its effect on the casting of television commercials.

A few months ago, she succeeded admirably as Rosine at the Met in Rossini's Ii Barbiere di Siviglia, and Friday night she made a firstclass impression as Zerlina in Mozart's Don Giovanni.

title: From disciples of human dignity

description: EAST ORANGE  You are a housewife, and you have decided to spend the bleak, rainy day by canning (jarring) fruit or making cut tard. Suddenly, the jar lids pop or the custard curdles. What to do?

title: The Freud/Jung Letters
description: The relationship between Sigmund Freud and C. G. Jung had its bright beginning in 1906 and came to its embittered end in 1913. Its disastrous course was charted by the many letters the two men wrote each other. Of these a few have been lost but there are 360 extant, of which 164 are from Freud, 196 from Jung. In 1970 the Freud and Jung families made the enlightened decision that this correspondence was to be edited as a unit, and it is now published, simultaneously in German and in English. In no way does it disappoint the large expectation it has naturally aroused. Both as it bears upon the personal lives of the men between whom the letters passed and upon the intellectual history of our epoch, it is a document of inestimable importance.

title: A Boutique for Gourmets
description: MONTCLAIR  During these days of soaring prices and exorbitant living costs, firemen here moonlight as electricians, policemen weigh fruit and vegetables tit supermarkets and school teachers tend bar.

title: Music
description: WHATEVER the artistic results of the 197374 Metropolitan Opera season, it cannot be said that the period at the house from Oct. 22 to last night lacked excitement. The 89th season just concluded saw alarums and excursions both financial and musical, not to mention managerial and conductorial. Nor has the smoke of battle entirely cleared away. There remains tension on the board of directors. A musical director has not yet been named to replace Rafael Kubelik. Plans for coming seasons are a bit indeterminate. And there is the everpresent problem of money.

title: The Human Comedy in Wind and Rain
description: EVERYONE, of course, talks about the weather; but the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue at 42d Street, has done something about it. What the library has done is mount a lively and engaging exhibition of prints, titled Weather: Fair and Foul, which ranges over more than three hundred years of meteorological episodessqualls, storms, nipping winds, blizzards, and a few comparatively sunny days  as depicted in the graphic works of the Flemish artists of the 17th century and the Japanese masters of the 18th and 19th centuries, down through the pop artists of the present. The exhibition which includes some 72 works has been ably selected by Elizabeth Roth, curator of the library's Print Division. It will be on view through September 6.

title: STATE BAR UNIT CITES REPORTING WINNERS
description: Winners of the New York State Bar Association's annual media awards competition have been announced in Albany.

description: Miss Mary Noel Murchison, granddaughter of, the late Clinton Williams Murchison, the Texas oilman and financier, was married yesterday afternoon to William Max Lamont Jr. of Washington, a staff assistant to President Nixon.

title: Neiderhoffer Retains Trophy
description: Victor B. Neiderhoffer of the Harvard Club has retained the Edwin H. Bigelow Trophy as the metropolitan area's outstanding squash racquets player. Neiderhoffer is the national singles, national doubles and New York State singles champion.

description: WASHINGTON, April 20Highly placed United. States officials said this week there was a possibility that there would be an EastWest summit conference this summer.

description: WESTBURYFor the first Nassau County Republicans have named a woman to run for a Congressional seat.

description: PERTH AMBOY  Three years ago, the Perth Amboy League of Women Voters was a dying organization. Today, it is alive and well and has 70 members, 18 of whom are men with voting privileges.

description: Flip Sal and Rube the Great won the divisions of the Wood Memorial at Aqueduct yesterday.
