description: STONY BROOK, L. I.The State University Center here will start a new program this fall concentrating on the vocational and edurational problems of what it calls the forgotten Amen canthe middleaged work er who is dissatisfied with his or her career.

title: Letters to the Editor
A Haunting 'Conversation':'Conversation'
description: HAVE you considered the possibility that everything that's ever been said in this world might still be echoing somewhere, maybe rattling around within the interior of a stone, a tree trunk or at the bottom of the sea? Though becoming increasingly faint, the sounds shall never disappear entirely and one day, perhaps, there will be equipment Sensitive enough to retrieve and record mankind's oral history. In 24 abridged volumes it would make a perfect introductory offer to a book club. Or even a book club all of its own.In the meantime our technicians have developed eavesdropping equipment of almost staggering complexity and efficiency, to be used not for historical purposes (as we all now know, only the cheap stuff is used for that) or even to satisfy curiosity about human nature. Rather it's more often used for personal and corporate gain, which sometimes means murder.That's the idea behind Francis Ford Coppola's haunting and bothersome new film, "The Conversation," now at the Coronet. One of the lessons implicit in "The Conversation" is that private enterprise, as always, leads the way. Government breakthroughs, like break-ins, are usually a mistake.The film is haunting because its suggestion that technology has gotten out of hand, though not exactly new, is so convincingly and fastidiously detailed. It's bothersome because Mr. Coppola, the writer as well as the director, has nearly succeeded in making a great film but has, instead, made one that is merely very good. Among its virtues is a superb performance by Gene Hackman in a role that comes very close to being the uptight Watergate era's equivalent of the mad doctors in old-fashioned Vincent Price films.Harry Caul (Hackman) is pre-eminent in his field. His trade magazine is called "Security World" and sound is his universe. Harry Caul is an expert professional eavesdropper. He once placed a bug in a parakeet. When he is not planning and executing elaborate taps, mostly without wires, he returns to his bleak, furnished San Francisco apartment, which is protected by four locks on the front door as well as by a burglar alarm system, to relax by playing riffs on his saxophone to the accompaniment of records. Harry is a queer fish indeed. He is suspicious of everybody and everything. Rain or shine he always wears one of those transparent plastic raincoats, as if for prophylactic protection against society.Harry is unmarried and probably incapable of marriage, though not of desperate, anonymous sex. He keeps a sweet, none-too-bright girl in a small apartment that he visits when he can, turning the key in the lock slowly then pushing the door suddenly open, to mash anyone who might possibly be hiding behind it. A birthday present from his landlady, which she has somehow managed to put into his apartment without his knowledge, prompts a near-paranoid fit. If you're in the business of spying on other people, it's difficult to believe that other people are not spying on you. If you're in the business, it may also mean that the forbidden and the clandestine have an immense fascination for you.This, however, Harry vehemently denies. He tells an associate, a young man who admits that Internal Revenue assignments always send him to sleep with boredom, that he isn't interested in human nature, nor does he have any curiosity about the people whose conversations he bugs. It's just a business, says Harry, yet Harry is riddled with guilts. When he goes to confession, he asks forgiveness for having swiped several newspapers from a blind dealer and for having taken the Lord's name in vain and pleasure in impure thoughts. He's also bothered by the suspicion that the current job he's working on may well be endangering the lives of the two young people whose conversations he has recorded during their lunchtime tryst in a busy San Francisco park. More of the story I cannot reveal.Mr. Hackman is fascinating as this eccentric loner, and the character itself is thoroughly realized up to a point, when he becomes, if possible, overly realized. Harry isn't simply neurotic. He gives every indication of being psychotic, which lessens the impact of the story Mr. Coppola has written for him. Psychotics make unreliable heroes. No rules need apply to them. Then there are times when Mr. Coppola seems to have forgotten the sort of character he has created.At a crucial point in the film he allows Harry, who is constantly on his guard with strangers, to invite a group of drunk, newly made friends back to his loft, where he keeps all of his extraordinary equipment and tapes. Because it's about the last thing in the world Harry would ever do, you begin to hear plot-devices bumping around just off-screen.It could be that Mr. Coppola really wasn't aware how good a movie he was on the verge of making in "The Conversation." Perhaps he only wanted to make a better-than-average melodrama, which might explain some beautifully photographed but basically foolish dream sequences and hallucinations. Such devices, even in Hitchcock, are usually cop-outs of one sort or another, or such overly simplified Freud that they hardly bare scrutiny except as comic-strip psychiatry.Everything about "The Conversation" prompts you to demand better than that. The nightmare situation that Harry finds himself in is both funny and compelling, and although I'm not much taken by the sort of "Blow-Up" ambiguity that Mr. Coppola eventually has recourse to, the movie leaves you wanting more, which is a nice change from all the other movies that send you groggily from the theater feeling as if you'd been force-fed on jelly beans.The members of the supporting cast are almost as good as Mr. Hackman, particularly Allen Garfield as a surveillance expert from Detroit who bugged his first phone at the age of 12 and then went on to become famous in the trade as the man who told Chrysler that Cadillac was getting rid of its fins. America, America.

title: Miss Blanton Wed To Louis P. Seigel
description: Miss Nancy Dicks Blanton, an assistant vice president and investment officer with the First National City Bank, was married in Shelby, N. C., last night to Louis Pendleton Seigel, a vice president and. senior securities analyst with Drexel Burnham & Co., investment bankers here.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: PRESIDENT NIXON, as usual, has made one thing perfectly clear. William Simon is not George Shultz. But who is? Mr. Shultz is leaving the Administrationleaving his post at the Treasury and leaving his even higher post at the White House. Mr. Simon has been nominated to succeed him, but only as Secretary of the Treasury.

title: MURDER TRIAL DUE FOR VENUE CHANGE
description: SCRANTON, Pa., April 20The murder trial of Gerald Donnerstag, 41 years old, of Belleville, N. J., has been continued, with a change of venue to be granted because of highly inflammable news items that have been printed about the defendant.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: I was disappointed in Ted Morgan's treatment of Francis Barany and his family (Lord of the Venus flytrap, March 31). Morgan consistently attributes the Baranys' devotion to science and hard work to their being insecure foreigners. Typical of Morgan's explanations of the Baranys' behavior is his comment, apropos of Francis's raising his hand in class often: That too is a trait that might be traced to the insecurity of the displaced person.

title: Chorale Tuning Up for Trip Abroad
description: OAKLANDThe Pro Arte Chorale, which performed Bath's Mass in B Minor at Avery Fisher Hall in Lincoln Center on Good Friday evening, already has a new project cut out for it.

title: Steel May Set Pace of Price Rises
description: On April 30 most segments of American industry can be expected to heave a collective sigh of relief. The end of price controls that day has been eagerly awaited as the beginning of a process, industry feels, that will correct distortions gripping the economy in the recent past.

title: Canada wants out (of the United States)
description: As of this moment, Canada will become part of the United States of America. The Government of Canada is hereby dissolved. The provinces will become full member states of the Union. All necessary legislation will be presented to Congress to implement this decision.

title: THEATER OPENINGS OF THE WEEK
description: PLEASURE AND REPENTANCEToday, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 2. An anthology on themes of love, devised by Terry Hands. With Michael Redgrave.

title: Koosman Stops Pirates, 52
description: Playing variations oh an old then the New York Met ralled for three runs in the eighth inning yesterday and broke a sevengame losing streak by defeating the Pittsburgh Pirates, 52.

title: Future of Mansion In Oradell Doubtful
description: ORADELL  Bluefield, as family and friends have long called the house known popularly as the Blauvelt Mansion, is an anomaly in 1974.

title: NEWS FROM THE FRONT
description: Attention appears to be about equally divided between white or pastel and dark  grounded shirts. The softer tones look crisp and cool; the darker shades pay perfect complement to lightgrounded suits and sport coats. And a sprightly array of neckties follow suit.

title: Crime Follows Population From Cities to the Suburbs
description: SCHAUMBURG, Ill., April 20 Not long ago, this mushrooming suburb northwest of Chicago almost had its first homicide case. The body, however, was found to be 14 feet inside the boundary of a neighboring suburb.

title: Plan for Historic L.I. Building Delayed
description: BRIDGEHAMPTONPlans to turn the Bull's Head Inn, an historic building which was almost torn down five years ago to make way for a gasoline station, into an office sestaurantapartment complex were temporarily blocked last week when the Southampton Town Zoning Board of Appeals refused to approve the entire project.

title: She got over looking proper
description: Frangoise Kirkland is Douglas Kirkland's wife and partner. He's the photographer; she's the business manager. He's the filmmaker; she's the sound man. If he needs a blurred figure in the background or someone to hold an umbrella, she's that too. We work together, Frangoise says simply. That's the way our marriage is.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Knicks Seek Second Life Here Today
description: Walt Frazier thinks the Knicks are alive and kicking. Red Holzman, the coach, wants more proof.

title: COTTON PLAYS IT COOL
description: Still a man's best friend during the dog days, cotton comes up with some fresh new looks for summer of '74.

title: Election Down Under
description: During sixteen months in office, Prime Minister Gough Whitlam of Australia has often had projected economic and social reforms blocked by the Senate, where his Labor party is narrowly outnumbered by the combined opposition. When his opponents recently rejected even the finance bills necessary to run the Governmentthe first time this had happened in Australia's history Mr. Whitlam had no alternative but to dissolve both Senate and House and call new elections for May 18.

title: The Awful Arithmetic
description: WASHINGTONThe Republicans' jeopardy in the fall elections is still a matter of speculation, but after the Democratic victory in Michigan's 8th Congressional District last weekthe fourth Republican loss in five special elections this year, all in safe Republican districtsno less a Republican than Vice President Gerald Ford was speculating about a legislative dictatorship by the Democrats.

title: Small Railroad With Big Ideas Puzzles Over U.S. Bid to Kill It
description: FLEMINGTONThe Black River & Western Railroad has found that there's gold in Lilliputia.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Perhaps Easterners are more, friendly than the folks out West:

title: Homemaking Talents. Turned Into ProfitMaking Ventures
description: GREAT NECK  Statisticians have estimated that a woman's servicesin herhome have a market value of $13,000 to $17,000 a year. Two Long Island businesses were organized recently by women who are trying to turn that market value into actual cash.

title: 33 Communist Dead Reported by Saigon In 2 Engagements
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, April 21 (AP)  The South Vietnamese command said today that Communist troops poured hundreds of shells yesterday into Governmint positions northwest and east of Saigon in two engagements. The officials said that 33 Communist soldiers had been killed and that one Government soldier died and 20 were missing.

title: Death, Sleep & The Traveler
description: John Hawkes is a prince of the middleaged avantgarde. His earliest books had the character' of a brisk and slightly improvised tour through the surrealist region of mind: they were indeed, wrote an admiring Leslie Fiedler, the personal chronicle of this novelist as he pursued through certain lunar landscapes (called variously Germany or the American West or Italy) his vision or, horror or baffled passion. During much of the 1940's and 1950's Hawkes seemed to dwell in polite obscurity. A lateblossoming flower in the tradition of naive modernism, he could scarcely have hoped to create the shock of recognition that comes only for writers in proper season. Yet his reputation has grown in recent years, there have been signs of a modest vogue; and his publisher, now as in the past associated with the meretricious as well as the legitimate side of all that is new, has advertised Death, Sleep & the Traveler as a masterpiece.

title: News of the Stage
description: Jean Anouilh, the prolific French playwright, has agreed to a musical version of his play Mademoiselle Colombe, and talks are under way with Julie Harris to star in it. First produced on Broadway in 1954, it is the story of a highspirited young woman whose delight in gaiety and success separates her from ner husband, the son of a celebrated theater star who despises him. Miss Harris costarred in the play with Edna Best and Eli Wallach.

title: Nancy Goebel to Wed in September
description: The engagement of Miss Nancy Margaret Goebel to John Francis Rossi 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent J. Rossi of Utica, N. Y., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mrs. Patricia C. Goebel and Richard F. Goebel of New York. A September wedding is planned.

title: Newsday Goes to 15c
description: Newsday, the Long Island newspaper, announced yesterday that because of sharply rising costs, the daily price of the newspaper would be increased from 10 to 15 cents, effective tomorrow. The 25cent price of the Sunday edition remains unchanged.

title: Nine Named To Football Hall of Fame
description: The National Football Foundation named nine former college football players yesterday to its. Hall of Fame in the modern (after 1927) category.

title: Chess: The Solid Contender Meets The 1974 Version of Fischer
description: After four games in their semifinal Candidates Match unfolding in the Palace of Culture in Leningrad, Boris Spassky and Anatoly Karpov are tied 1 to 1, with two draws.

title: Smith Upset By Stockton In Charlotte
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., April 20 (AP)Dick Stockton upset secondseeded Stan Smith, 63, 26, 63, today in the semifinals of the World Championship Tennis Blue Group, tournament.

title: Once Again, the White Liberal to the Rescue
description: UNDOUBTEDLY Conrack is a cut above the black exploitation films that have recently befouled the screen and enriched the moviemakers. It is a serious attempt to deal with human relationships. It portrays genuine love between a fifthgrade class of black youngsters on Daufuskie Island, one of the Sea Islands off the South Carolina coast, and their young white Southern teacher  a teacher who shows his love by his untiring efforts to educate his charges in life as well as in letters and eventually by sacrificing his job.

title: The Region
description: Johnny Carson jokes about it. Europeans are horrified by it and New Yorkers are sure of it: New York is the crime capital of the United States of America. But according to a Federal report, New York is significantly safer than any other major American city and some of the smaller ones as well.

title: Derby Day Is a Big Gamble for Britain
description: A GIGANTIC crosssection of British humanity, including barking bookmakers, strident tipsters and gypsy fortunetellers, along with family groups, tweedy racing experts and Cockneys, will swarm among the beer and tea tents on the public grassland called Epsom Downs, 14 miles southwest of London, on June 5 and crane their necks for a fleeting glimpse of jockeys' silks and horseflesh. The occasion is Derby (pronounced Darby) Day, a boisterous carnival that invariably has the whole country holding its breath until one of a field of 30 or so threeyearold thoroughbred horses thunders past the finishing, post beneath the uninterrupted gaze of royalty and other bluebloods up in the grandstand's private boxes.

title: 'Alice' Returns, Curiouser and Curiouser
description: Los ANGELES. TIS Brillig! reads the psychedelic poster. Walt Disney's least favorite picturethe one he dismissed as having no heartis being released this month by Disney's own company after 23 years in the studio vaults. It will arrive in New York in late June.

title: Home Repair Clinic
description: Questions from readers about home repair problems should be addressed to: Home Improvement Department, The New York Times, Times Square, New York, N.Y. 10036. Only those questions of general interest will be answered in this column:

title: CONSUMER VOICE SOUGHT ON P.S.C.
description: ALBANY, April 20Legislation to grant a consumer advocate full membership on the state's Public Service Commission has reached the floor of the State Senate but is meeting strong behindthescenes opposition from the commission itself.

title: Prison Is a Perfect Culture for Growing Conspiracies
description: Whether Patricia Hearst has been converted by the revolutionary rhetoric of the Symbionese Liberation Army remains unknown. There is no question, however, that such a group, originating in the harsh conditions of prison life, can have a potent appeal for those confined offenders who see themselves as the scapegoats of an oppressive, racist society.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market made a comeback last week after its recent weakness as prices advanced in continued slow trading.

title: Girl Burned in Nightgown Wins $850,000 Damages
description: DETROIT, April 20 (AP) Federal District Judge Philip Pratt has approved an outofcourt settlement in which five companies will pay a total of $850,000 to a 5yearold girl who was burned over 70 per cent of her body when her nightgown caught fire.

title: Calls Rising to Free Rudolf Hess, Near 80
description: BERLIN, April 20A spateof publicity has been stirred here and in Britain over the fate of Rudolf Hess, the last Allied warcrimes prisoner, who will mark his 80th birthday next Friday in solitary confinement at Spandau Prison.

title: Miss Edna Harris Bride of Clergyman
description: Miss Edna Marie Harris, who teaches Spanish at the Mountain High School in West Orange, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon in the Franklin St. John's United Methodist Church in Newark, to the Rev. Theodore Moses Booth, minister of the church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert Payne, assisted by the Rev. Harry L. Batts.

title: Miss Walter Wed to B. E. Cameron
description: The marriage of Miss Claire Margaret Walter, sales promotion manager for Swissair here, to Bums Elliott Cameron, who is director of marketing services for the American Film Theater, took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Walter, in Norwalk, Conn.

title: Colgate Tourney Is Tour Springboard
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., April 20  For members of the Ladies Professional Golf Association of America, the $200,000 ColgateDinah Shore tournament going on here is a lot more important than merely the biggest pile of prize money the ladies have ever been allowed to play for.

title: Wendy Troutt Plans Nuptials
description: Miss Wendy Lou Troutt and Charles Spencer Rowe. 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rowe Jr. of Old Greenwich, Conn., plan to be married Oct. 12.

title: A Nostalgic View of Brooklyn Given at Seminar
description: The old Brooklyn had character, some say. It had Gregg creams and Ebbets Field, stoop ball, stick ball and bookmakers who read Milton. Brooklynites used to be a special breed of people, maintain nostalgiacs. They spoke like no one on earth and, legend has it, won World War II singlehandedly.

title: Pam Bressler Plans Nuptials
description: Miss Pam Bressler, a junior at Simmons College, and Richard Scott Schaller, who expects to receive a master's degree in May from the Har yard Graduate School of Business Administration, plan, to be married at the Plaza in August.

title: Women at Princeton: Increase Is Slight
description: PRINCETON  Although Princeton University decided earlier this year to eliminate admission quotas based on sex, the proportions of men and women accepted for this fail's freshman class remain nearly unchanged.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: These are progress report On Times inquiries into Some Unfinished news events

title: Mets' Records
description: TeamAB 372. H 8 .263. HR9.

title: Choose A Place In the Sun To Grow Water Lilies
description: HAPPINESS is having the world's tropical water lily expert living at home with you. On making plans for water gardening all you do is ask. According to George H. Pring, (my father) and Superintendent Emeritus of the Missouri Botanical Garden, Water gardening is one of the easiest ways to garden. Once your plants are placed, you enjoy the results with almost no work. He should know after 63 years of growing and hybridizing them.

title: FRIEND OF GEM IN INDIAN DISPUTE
description: NEW DELHI, April 16A friend of Mahatma Gandhi has broken with Prime Minister Indira Gandhi in a bitter and emotional controversy.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: Ashby Bladen has expressed the opinion that the Federal Reserve Board has little control over the rate of debt formation and that, as a result, the American economy has been hooked on credit inflation (Point of View, Too Much Credit, Built Up Too Fast, March 10).

title: Home Improvement
description: ALTHOUGH it is unlikely that any of us will ever be able to completely rid our homes of all insect pests, there are a number of things that every householder can do to cornbat invasions of creeping, crawling and flying insects, and to ward off the damage that some species can cause.

title: DylanBand TV Special In Negotiations for Fall
description: Bob Dylan has agreed to appear on a onehour television special this fall, according to a spokesman for Timex, which will sponsor the program. We are still in negotiations, but the only unsettled issues have to do with the actual format, said James Ellers, who represented Timex in the negotiations.

title: Whose Tax Burden?
description: State legislators, City Council members and ordinary citizens would be wise to take a searching look at the figures Mayor Beame has produced to justify his choice of a onecent sales tax boost as the principal new revenue source for offsetting a projected $1.5billion budget deficit. In our view, the figures don't add up.

title: Fox Terrier Takes Top A ward
FRANCIS J. LANTRY
description: Francis J. Lantry, former president and chairman of the Treadwell Corporation, an engineering, construction and equipment building company here, died Saturday in Brooklyn. He was 87 years old and formerly lived at 945 Fifth Avenue.

title: Arrival of Brandt Is Linked in Cairo To Prospect of Aid
description: CAIRO, April 21 (AP)Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany arrived here today from Algiers, where the official radio proclaimed his visit there as the beginning of a EuropeanArab dialogue.

title: Beame and Guests Commemorate the 450th Anniversary of Verrazano's Arrival
description: Celebrating the 450th anniversary of Giovanni da Verrazano's, discovery of New York harbor, Mayor and Mrs. Beanie took 300 guests on a boatride yesterday that was a floating festival of Italian food, wine and accordion music.

title: TreasuryDebt Refunding Is Awaited
description: Credit markets this week will be looking in two directionsbackward in an effort to decipher the mixed signals given by last week's events and forward in anticipation of the $4.5billion Treasurydebt refunding due to be announced May 1. As they try to sort out the scrambled significance of downbeat economic news, persistent inflation and a peak in banking's prime interest rate, investors and dealers will be casting an eye beyond this week's calendar of new debt issues to the big Treasury offering.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: EVERETT, Wash., April 21 (AP)A damage suit against the American League, its cluhowners and a concessions firm for the transfersale of the Seattle Pilots baseball team to Milwaukee is set to start here tomorrow. The suit was brought by the state of Washington, the city of Seattle and King County. They charge antitrust violations and fraud in the move of the Pilots to Milwaukee in 1970 after a season's residence in Seattle.

title: Hairpieces: They Help Ease The Anxieties of Middle Age
description: Sometimes it's made from yak hair, sometimes from silicone, sometimes from the locks of Sicilian women. It's favored, for different reasons, by fashion experts, undertakers and bank robbers.

title: The Sea Horse Star (and Its Author) Sheds Alias
description: The Sea Horse, the Circle Repertory Theater Company's new Off Broadway hit, is the first play written by James Irwin. It will also be his last play.

title: 25 Addicts Escape Treatment Center On Staten Island
description: More than 25 addicted detainees escaped from a narcotics treatment center in Rossville, S. I., last night by scaling two 14foot chainlink fences that surround the minimum security, staterun facility, the police said.

title: Marsh Wins Trot
description: RECKLINGHAUSEN, West Germany, April 21 (AP)Joe Marsh Jr. of the United States won two of the five final races today and captured the World trotting championship. Marsh finished with 153 points to 132 for Kevin Brook of Australia and clinched the title on the 19th race of the 20race series.

title: BENJAMIN JOSEPHS
description: Benjamin Josephs, executive director of the National Liquors Stores Assocation, died Thursday in Worcester, Mass., where he lived. His age was 69.

title: Georgetown to Review Priest's Ouster
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 The executive committee of Georgetown University's board of directors has approved a review by the full board of directors next month of the dismissal of the Rev. Edmund G. Ryan as the university's executive vice president for academic affairs.

title: STEVENS CONDUCTS PETRARCH THEMES
description: Denis Stevens, musicologist and conductor, brought his Accademia Monteverdiana to Tully Hall on Saturday night to present a program entitled Seven Centuries of Petrarch in Music.

title: ARTICLE ABOUT TOWN IN WYOMING SCORED
description: GILLETTE, Wyo., April 21 (UPI)Mayor Cliff Davis said today that his town had its problems because of an energy boom that has tripled its population, but said a recent New York Times article that described the community was a vicious, outright negative attack on the whole town.

title: 5 WHITES INDICTED IN BLACK'S KILLING
description: ALLENDALE, S.C., April 21Five white men have been indicted for murder in the shotgun slaying of a black youth almost four years ago in this rural South Carolina county.

title: Poverty Threatens The New Peace of Sudan's South
description: JUBA, the SudanIn the two years since the long civil war in the Sudan came to a negotiated end, the process of national reconciliation has been encouraginglyand in some ways astonishinglysuccessful.

title: Two Test Projects to Seek Power From Ocean's Heat
description: Groundwork is being laid for realistic testing of the hypothesis that substantial Amounts of energy could be derived, at low cost and with no pollution, from temperature differences within the oceans.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Senator James L. Buckley, ConservativeRepublican of New York, said he did not fear a possible challenge to his Senate seat from Howard Cosell, the sportscaster. Mr. Cosell, in a speech Friday at the United States Naval Academy at Annapolis, Md., said he was considering running for Mr. Buckley's seat in 1976, asserting, There are not 10 people in the United States better qualified to run for the Senate than Howard Cosell.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The recent Arab terrorist attack on the small Israeli town Qiryat Shemona has shown once again the irrational savagery that exists in the mind of modern man.

title: New Hempshire Post Filled
description: PLYMOUTH, N.H., April 21 (AP)The provost of the University of New Hampshire, Eugene Mills, has been named acting president effective July 1, when Thomas Bonner leaves. Mr. Bonner will become president of Union College and chancellor of Union University in Schenectady, N.Y. Mr. Mills was named by the university's board of trustees, which met here yesterday.

title: Threats to the Press Cited As Publishers Meet Here
description: A growing barrage of challenges to First Amendment guarantees of press freedom along with everlengthening tentacles of government encroachment on business were decried yesterday in an American Newspaper Publishers Association report here.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, APRIL 22, 1974

description: 5HORSE VAN 1966 FORDAdjustable, largest to smallest horse, excellent running condition & repair, $4500. 203 8695791

title: POPE SAID TO SHIFT JERUSALEM STAND
description: ROME, April 21Pope Paul VI has dropped demands for internationalization of Jerusalem and believes that the United Nations should work out a new formula for the status of the city, according to a leading Catholic churchman in the Middle East.

title: Sports Today
description: BOXING

title: A Family's Back Yard200 Acres of Unspoiled Marsh on the HudsonBecomes a Treasure for the Public
description: HUDSON, N. Y.  Henry Livingston relaxed in the gracious, high ceilinged living room his family has called home for 180 years, rather happy with the fact that not only had he been successful in keeping his family's window on the world beautiful, but that he had also enhanced everyone else's, too.

title: Dartmouth Tops Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, April 21 Dartmouth's first baseman, Greg Cronin, had two hits and scored the winning run, and a relief pitcher, Kevin Kelley, stopped a Yale rally today in the ninth inning as Dartmouth won its fifth straight Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League game, 76.

title: 500 Hold Bicycle Rodeo For Charity and Safety
description: Civic groups in Montclair and Basking Ridge took advantage of delightful spring weather yesterday to go bicycling for charity and safety.

title: River Niger and Raisin Win Tonys
description: Two plays about the struggles of black familiesRaisin and The River Nigertook the honors as the best musical and best play of the 197374 theatrical season at the 28th annual Tony Awards last night. The presentation ceremonies were held at the Shubert Theater.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: When you seed tail, thorough Businees Information call Information For Business 1128677030Advt.

title: ASPIN CHARGES NAVY HIDES TRIDENT COSTS
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, accused the Navy today of hiding at least $2.8billion that would increase the cost, for the new Trident submarine and related missile development to at least $15.2billion.

title: THOUSANDS MARK WARSAW UPRISING
description: Hundreds of candies glowed on Temple EmanuEl's altar yesterday in remembrance of those who perished in the Warsaw Ghetto uprising 31 years ago.

title: Citizen Panel Asks Beame To Cut Cost $300Million
description: The Citizens Budget Commission, taking issue with Mayor Beame, urged yesterday that nearly $300million be cut from the city's $12.2billion ex pense budget for the coming fiscal year to alleviate the problem of raising money to bridge an expected deficit of $1.5billion.

title: Theater: An American Millionaire
description: How much do you like clowns and clowning? On the answer to that question will depend how much you like Murray Schisgal's enjoyable play An American Millionaire, which opened Saturday night at the Circle in the SquareJoseph E. Levine Theater. To be honest there is very little play to like or dislike.

title: HENRY SHAAKER
description: Henry Shaaker, founder and president of the HiScale Products Corporation, manufacturer of Bakelite wire connectors, died. Friday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 76 years old and lived at 433 East 56th Street.

title: Schultz Defends Flyers' Tactics in Beating Rangers
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 21We're not animals as some people think, declared softspoken Dave Schultz, after helping, the Philadelphia Flyers maul the New York Rangers, 4.0, last night in the first game of their semifinal Stanley Cup series.

title: MALIK SAYS, JACKSON IS A FOE OF DETENTE
description: The Soviet Union's delegate to the United Nations, Yakov A. alik, criticized Senator Henry M. Jackson yesterday at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel, where the diplomat spoke at a fundraising luncheon for New World Review, a proSoviet magazine that is edited here.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: South Vietnamese Infantry Fails to Free Ranger Base
description: SAIGON, South  Vietnam, April 21 (Reuters)Two Government infantry battalions trying to relieve a surrounded ranger base near the Cambodian border were stopped yesterday by strong Communist resistance, military sources said today.

title: Finn Harps Victors
description: DUBLIN, April 21 (UPI)Finn Harps defeated St. Patrick's Athletic today, 31, at Dalymount Park to win their first Football Association of Ireland soccer cup.

title: New York Grand Opera Presents a Creditable La Traviata
description: The New York Grand Opera Company, organized last spring by Vincent La Selva as a fully professional company to fill the void which exists between small opera groups and the major companies, put on a highly creditable La Traviata Saturday night at the theater of Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, on West 89th Street.

title: Balloonists Go Far On a Lot of Hot Air
description: FARMINGTON, Conn., April 21A convention of balloonists met here this weekend and everybody got a little high.

title: ABDUCTION RAISES TENSIONS IN ITALY
description: ROME, April 21  Three weeks before a referendum on divorce that is expected to be a political watershed, tension in Italy is mounting.

title: Dance: Clytemnestra
description: The Martha Graham Dance Company has adopted a policy of major cast changes this season, and Saturday night at the Mark Hellinger Theater, Yuriko Kimura made her debut in the title role of Clytemnestra. David Chase made his first appearance here as Agamemnon.

title: Suit Demands County Jails End Wide Range of Abuses
description: Difficult prisoners, often only awaiting trial, are stripped nakdd and thrust into pitchblack cells, others are shackled or isolated and given only milk and tea, according to a description of the county jails of New Jersey in a suit filed last week by the state chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union.

title: Another Enclave to Fall To Women This Week
description: A 39year tradition of an allmale audience for an annual luncheonshow for the nation's newspaper executive is being broken this week as the Banshees invite women editors and publishers for the first time.

title: News Summary and Index MONDAY, APRIL 22, 1974
description: International

title: Kennedy's Opinion Polling Baffles Moscow Audience
description: MOSCOW, April 21Senator Edward M. Kennedy tried out Americanstyle public opinion polling on an audience at Moscow State University today and drew some hostility from a generally silent audience when he asked for a show of hands on whether the Soviet Union should be spending more or less on defense.

title: DEMOCRATS SPUR MOVE TO CUT TAX; NIXON IS OPPOSED
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 Economic instability and increasing pressure from Democratic leaders for a tax cut add a new dimension to problems President Nixon will face when Congress returns from the Easter recess on Tuesday.

title: Case Bids Nixon Quit If His Trial Is Delayed
description: Senator Clifford Case, Republican of New Jersey, said that President Nixon should resign if the House decides to vote for impeachment but does not get the matter over to the Senate for trial within a few months, United Press International reported yesterday.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: FOR a copy of WILLCOX & GIBBS' Asnual Report call 5657920 (WGAMEX) Advt

title: Experiments Indicate Chemical Reactions From Thunder or Sea Wayes May Have Led to Origin of Life
description: WASHINGTON, April 21Thunder and ocean waves may have helped set the stage for the emergence of life more than three and onehalf billion years ago.

title: Chick Harley, an AllAmerica At Ohio. State 3 Times, Dies
description: DANVILLE, Ill., April 21 (UPI)  Charles (Chick) Harley, allAmerica halfback for the Ohio State University football team in 1916, 1917 and 1918, died today at the Veterans Administration hospital here. He was thought to be about 80 years old.

title: TRAXLER TO AWAIT EVIDENCE ON NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) Representative  elect J. Bob Traxler, the first Democrat to win Michigan's Eigth Congressional District seat in 42 years, said today that he would take no stand on impeaching President Nixon until the House Judiciary Committee completed its findings.

title: Bonn Parliament. Is Due to Act On Bills to Legalize Abortion
description: BONN, April 20A threeyear debate about whether to legalize abortion in West Germany is expected to come to an end next week, when Parliament will decide on one of four bills that are strongly opposed by the Roman Catholic Church.

title: 3Day Marathon Dance Gets $40,000 for Cancer
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, April 21About $40,000 for cancer research was raised by Rutgers University students during a threeday dance marathon that ended tonight.

title: VOTERS COMPLAIN OF COSTS AND JOBS
description: The economic trioinflation, the already high cost of living, and unemploymentis emerging as the major issue of the gubernatorial campaign, according to the four major contenders for the Democratic nomination.

title: Who Lives and Dies?
description: ALBANYEthical and legal questions faced by health professionals and institutions when parents decide to withhold consent for lifesaving treatment of critically ill children are being debated in many quarters.

title: NEWS INDEX
CopperExporting Group Is to Convene To Emulate the Oil Producers on Prices
description: The oil countries' successful assault on the treasuries of the industrialized world in the last year has already inspired the principal bauxite countries to take concerted action, and now the major copperexporting countries are going to try it, too.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 37

title: Gen. Ayub Khan Is Buried In Village of His Birth
description: REHANA VILLAGE, Pakistan, April 21 (AP)  Former Pakistani President Mohammad Ayub Khan was buried at the foot of his mother's grave today in this windswept hillside village where he was born.

title: Delaware Canoeist Drowns
description: POND EDDY, Pa., April 21 (AP)  A New Jersey man drowned and another was hospitalized today after their canoe capsized in the Delaware River about three miles south of this Pike County community, the state police reported. The police identified the dead man as James H. Cassidy, 25 years old, of Hackensack. His companion; Gilbert J. Ryon, 24, of Lodi, was admitted to St. Francis Hospital in nearby Port Jervis, N. Y.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. to hear Kenya, Poland, Australia, Austria, Pakistan, Finland, Cyprus and Afghanistan in general debate.

title: SUEZ TRADE LOSSES PUT AT $10BILLION
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 21The closing of the Suez Canal has cost the world more than $10billion in higher shipping charges, trade reductions and other losses, and has brought hardship to a string of ports running from Trieste southeast to Aden, it was reported here yesterday.

title: End of Mine Strike Voted
description: EBENSBURG, Pa., April 21 (UP)The presidents of locals in United Mine Workers District 2, where a strike began 12 days ago over the discharge of two miners, voted tonight to return to work and end the walkout that has idled 12,000 miners in Pennsylvania and West Virginia.

title: Soviet Irked by Egypt
description: The Soviet press gave hints yesterday of Moscow's irritation with Egypt by criticizing United States participation in clearing of Suez Canal and by stressing Soviet support of Syria. Page 8.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Commissioner Ann Klein said a proposed $1.2million budget cut from her Department of Institutions and Agenices would severely affect the state's institutions. The cut, proposed by the Joint Appropriations Committee, would prevent essential repairs and services at Greystone Park Psychiatric Hospital; Ancora Psychiatric Hospital and Rahway State Prison.

title: TOCKS ISLAND UNIT DIVIDED OVER DAM
description: NEWTON, April 21A sixcounty advisory council formed a decade ago to weigh the regional impact of the proposed Tocks Island Dam is now deadlockedand in danger of dissolvingover the issue of building the dam.

title: State Units Blame U.S. Agency For Rising Railroad Accidents
description: WASHINGTON, April 21A charge that the increasing number of accidents plaguing American railroads may be related to the failure of the Federal Railroad Administration to implement a safety inspection program will be the subject of hearings by a House subcommittee.

title: Rural Post Office Will Be Standardized
description: The nation's oldfashioned rural post offices, those often rustic reminders of an age of dirt roads, general stores and boarding houses, will soon be replaced by essentially standard structures in every state.

title: Dr. Rose Hall Dies at 84; A Pioneer Woman Dentist
description: Dr. Rose Hall, a retired den tist and the widow of Dr. David Deutschman, who was chief, of obstetrics at Bronx Hospital,1 died yesterday in the,Fieldston Lodge Nursing Home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. She was 84 years old.

title: TV: Yanks Are Coming
description: The Yanks Are Coming, the 8 P.M. offering tonight on the American Broadcasting Company network, is another of those recreated stories from the workshop of David L. Wolper Productions. Using a collage of new dramatizations and old newsreels the program whips through World War I in the cramped space of an houror 50 minutes, excluding commercials, etc.

title: First Chicago Bank Sets Major Shifts in Its Management
description: A major management reorganization was announced over the weekend by the First National Bank of Chicago and its holding company, the First Chicago Corporation. The bank is the country's ninth largest, with assets, as of March 31, of $12.8billion.

title: ONE KILLED, 7 HURT IN ULSTER VIOLENCE
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland April 21 (AP)One person was killed and seven were wounded today in sectarian violence in Ulster.

title: B. B. KING, AT APOLLO, LECTURES AUDIENCE
description: B. B. King, as a result of his major commercial success over the last five years, has taken not merely to singing and playing the blues but talking about them.

title: Sports Today
description: Jorge Ahumada vs. Angel Oquendo 10round lightheavyweight fight, at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street; first bout, 8 P.M.

title: COLOMBIAN VOTE SHOWS LIBERALS WITH A BIG LEAD
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, April 21 Amid tight security and a carnival atmosphere of street bands, clowns and colorful banners, Colombians voted today in the nation's first free presidential elections in more than 20 years.

title: Laver Downs Borg In Houston, 76, 62
description: HOUSTON, April 21 (AP) Rod Laver, the Australian master, gave young Bjorn Berg a lesson in pressure tennis today, defeating the 17yearold from Sweden, 76, 62. It was Laver's fourth consecutive River Oaks Tennis championship, his third tournament victory in a row.

title: Advertising: Royal Crown Shift
description: About a dozen top agencies last week received questionnaires from the Royal Crown Cola Company, which is putting its $9million account up for grabs after almost five years with Wells, Rich, Greene.

title: Kennecott Earnings Advance, Despite Sales and Output Drop
description: The Kennecott Copper Corporation reported yesterday substantially higher earnings for the first quarter despite a sharp fall in production and sales.

title: Albanian Guilty of Slaying Here In Revenge for Death of Brother
description: A Manhattan jury yesterday convicted a 34yearolds Albanian of murder but acquitted his brother and cousin in the revenge slaying of a fourth Albanian immigrant outside Maxwell's Plum, a popular restaurant at 64th Street and First Avenue, one night two years ago.

title: Dartmouth First In Sailing Regatta
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 21 Dartmouth sailed to victory this weekend in the 10th annual John F. Kennedy Memorial regatta, cosponsored by the Intercollegiate Yacht Racing Association and the Naval Academy. With two firsts, Dartmouth outpointed secondplace Michigan State and thirdplace Cornell after three races yesterday and two today on Chesapeake Bay.

title: Trial to Continue For Deprogramer Of 2 Denver Women
description: DENVER, April 21  The felony trial of Ted Patrick, who calls himself a deprogramer of young people, resumes here tomorrow.

title: Out of Prison a Month, Segretti Tries to Pick Up the Pieces of His Old Carefree Life
description: LOS ANGELES, April 21The tall, tanned lawyer suddenly stopped in midstride, peered through the dim light of Perino's Restaurant Bar at a tiny form huddled over a corner table, and slowly walked over to extend his hand to the smaller man.

title: Orioles Win, 6 to 5, Protest 30 Loss
description: BALTIMORE, April 21The New York Yankees seemed to have split a doubleheader with the Baltimore Orioles today.

title: About New York
description: Peter Mauchlin was convicted of bank robbery in February, and one of the people on the jury was Tillie Mia Weitzner. In fact during the trial Miss Weitzner got to thinking of Mr. Mauchlin as my bank robber, and sometimes she referred to him that way.

title: ISRAELI LABORITES WILL TRY TO FORM NEW GOVERNMENT
description: TEL AVIV, April 21After four hours of raucous debate; the Central Committee of Israel's dominant Labor party beat back proposals for immet. diate elections and cleared the way today for selection of candidate to succeed Premier Golda. Meir. The committee voted by a 2to1 margin to authorize the candidate to try to form a new coalition government.

title: Coalition in Arizona Wants 5 Initiatives On November Ballot
description: PHOENIX, Arid., April 21An unusual statewide citizens' convention opened a drive yesterday to put five key initiatives on the November ballot.

title: Jo Prentice Golf Victor In Playoff
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., April 21Jo Ann Prentice, an Alabama country club owner who had won only four tournaments in 18 years, took the richest event in women's golf today by winning the fourth playoff hole from Jane Blalock with a 3foot putt.

title: Two Test Projects to Seek Power From Ocean's Heat
description: Groundwork is being laid for realistic testing of the hypothesis that substantial amounts of energy could be derived, at low cost and with no pollution, from temperature differences within the oceans.

title: Brigee: Case of the Missing Trophy, Or Getting Lost in the Shuffle
description: An important legal case in the thirties concerned the ownership of a bridge trophy that had been pawned by its temporary possessor who was then unable to redeem it. Bridge organizations, subsequently have been less than eager to allow trophies out of their possession.

title: New Offer in Paper Strike
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (UPI)Members of the Wash ington  Baltimore Newspaper Guild who are on strike against The Washington Post planned to meet tomorrow to considen a contract offer made after a long bargaining session that ended yesterday. The guild has recommended rejection of the contract and called for estab lishment of picket lines, which were not set up when the strike began April 8. The offer inchided no new proposal on wages, the main issue in the strike.

title: Newark Clinic Offers Sex Counseling
description: NEWARK, April 21In 1929, E. B. White and James Thurber posed the question, Is sex necessary? Today, through programs like the United Hospital's Medical Center's sexual guidance clinic here, people are answering with a resounding yes.

title: Books of The Times
description: GO EAST, YOUNG MAN. The Early Years. The Autobiography of William O. Douglas. 493 pages. Illustrated Random House, $10.

title: Holbert Team's Carrera Wins in Atlanta
description: FLOWERY BRANCH, Ga., April 21  Any automobile race in a place called Flowery Branch, with women adorning the paddock and pits, and spectators sunning themselves on lush green hills can run for six hours without becoming a bore.

title: Softer French Foreign Policy Is Defined by Jobert
description: PARIS, April 21French Foreign Minister, Michel Jobert, who returned today from a relaxed Common Market ministerial meeting in Bonn, has cedefiped French policy in a dmtinatly new and more moderate kway.

title: Sephardic Chief Rabbi Of Israel Arrives Here
description: More than a hundred Sephardic Jews greeted Rabbi Ovadia Yossef, Israel's Sephardic chief rabbi, as he arrived here yesterday on his first visit to the United States.

title: JERSEY JAILS SUED OVER WIDE ABUSES
description: Difficult prisoners, often only awaiting trial, are stripped naked and thrust into pitchblack cells, others are shackled or isolated and given only milk and tea, according to a description of the county jails of New Jersey in a suit filed last week by the state chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union.

title: Soviet Irked by Egypt
description: The Soviet press gave hints yesterday of Moscow's irritation with Egypt by criticizing United States participation in clearing of Suez Canal and by stressing Soviet support of Syria, Page 8.

title: DEMOCRATS SPUR MOVE TO CUT TAX; NIXON IS OPPOSED
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 Economic instability and increasing pressure from Democratic leaders for a tax cut add a new dimension to problems President Nixon will face when Congress returns from the Easter recess on Tuesday.

title: Impeachment on Radio
description: A convincing case has been made recently in the press for amending the regulation that would prohibit television coverage of impeachment proceedings, should they occur. The case has also been rationally argued that live television coverage would not be desirable because a grave period in history could deteriorate into a diversion or a theatrical extravaganza.

title: FOUR PLEAD GUILTY IS EQUITY FUNDING
description: LOS ANGELES, April 21, (AP)  Four employes of the Equity Funding Life Insurance Company, including its general counsel and its treasurer, have pleaded guilty to conspiracy charges stemming from the parent concerns $1billion insurancepolicy fraud case.

title: ISRAELI LABORITES WILL TRY TO FORM NEW GOVERNMENT
description: TEL AVIV, April 21After four hours of raucous debate, the Central Committee of Israel's dominant Labor party beat back proposals for immediate elections and cleared the way today for selection of a candidate to succeed Premier Golda Meir. The committee voted by a 2to1 margin to authorize the candidate to try to form a new coalition government.

title: Climb Up Golf Ladder is Long One for Elder
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., April 21 (AP)  Lee Elder, once a crosshanded golf hustler, is a softspoken, easygoing man who chooses his friends care fully and doesn't particularly care to be reminded of his remarkable resemblance to the comedian, Flip Wilson.

title: Record Slumpflation
description: The nation's economic performance in the first quarter of this year was almost certainly the most alarming of the entire postwar period. Real output declined at an annual rate of 5.8 per cent, the sharpest drop in gross national product in sixteen years. The overall price level increased at an annual rate of 110.8 per centthe steepest climb in 23 years. Most disturbing of all, slump and inflation worsened in parallel. By an index of economic disordercombining the rate of decline in real G.N.P. with the rate of inflationthis slumpflation provides the poorest record since World War II put an end to the Great Depression.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Sadat Says Soviet Sought Leverage in Arms Supply
Dartmouth Tops Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, April 21 Dartmouth's first baseman, Greg Cronin, had two hits and scored the winning run, and a relief pitcher, Kevin Kelley, stopped a Yale rally today in the ninth inning as Dartmouth won its fifth straight Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League game, 76.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs
description: Rangers vs. Philadelphia

title: April Killings Set Detroit Record and Bring New Focus on Police
description: DETROIT, April, 21This is Bloody April in the Motor City.

title: Jump for Joyce
description: WASHINGTONUlysses in Nighttown is a new Broadway play based on a portion of James Joyce's classic novel Ulysses and in it actress Fionnuala Flanagan, playing the sinkable Molly Bloom, lies stark naked on a bed in the middle of the stage and delivers the famous streamofconsciousness monologue. As Molly was obsessed with sex, so an essayist is obsessed with Watergate in the following Joycean rivulet:

title: Learning a Foreign Language While Dining on the Country's Food
description: Bon soir, bon soir, said Chantal kegnault, the French instructor, to her class as she handed out vocabulary sheets.

title: TAIWAN'S JAPANESE GIVEN PROTECTION
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 21Local authorities and resident Japanese have taken precautions against any violent demonstrations of antiJapanese feeling following the severing of air links between Taiwan and Japan.

title: PARLEY CRITICAL OF LAND POLICIES
description: HARRIMAN, N. Y., April 21 Mounting land use problems call for basic changes in regulatory mechanisms on both the governmental and private levels, a national conference convoked by Columbia University concluded today.

title: SYLVIA R. LEVINSON
description: Sylvia R. Levinson, who retired in 1961 as chairman of the social studies department of Evander Childs High School, died Saturday at her home, 775 Riverside Drive. Her age was 72.

title: Soccer Results
description: GERMANAMERICAN LEAGUE

title: Hunt Calls for Reform Of the Penal System
description: OMAHA, April 21 (AP) E. Howard Hunt Jr., the former agent of the Central Intelligence Agency who was sentenced to two and a halt to eight years for his part in the Watergate breakin, said last night that the year he spent in Federal prison was the mast incredible period of my life.

title: G.A.O. CRITICIZES IMPORT ACCORDS
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 The General Accounting Office has issued a report criticizing various aspects of the voluntary agreements with other countries that limit imports of textiles and steel, though it does not make a clearcut finding that import restraints are mistaken national policy.

title: DR. EVELYNE LIVANT
description: Dr. Evelyne LiVant, a welfare leader and president of the National Business and Professional Council, died Wednesday in St. Clare's Hospital. She was 75 year old and lived at 12 West 44th Street.

title: New Conversation Piece In Pawpaw, Ill.: The P.O.
description: PAWPAW, Ill.One day last summer when Elizabeth Merriman arrived for work at the post office here, she may have slammed the door a littie too hard.

title: PRICE RISES SEEN AS CONTROLS END
description: For millions of Americans, the ending of more than 32 months of wage and price controls next week is expected to bring another spasm of price increases that will further erode their already shrunken paychecks.

title: Louisiana Voters Approve New State Constitution
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 21Louisiana voters approved a new state constitution yesterday despite opposition from the state's largest newspapers, the state Republican Central Committee and leaders of business and industry, who said that it would create tax problems.

title: Pirates Collect 20 Hits, Sink Seaver
description: There was no joy in Metsvilla last night, And the gloom could become much worse unless Tom Seaver returns to the form that earned him the Cy Young Award last season.

title: Nets Get That Feeling: We're Going All Way
description: Although the brash, young Nets now say they were confident of defeating Kentucky in their American Basketball Association Eastern final playoff, nobody expected the fourgame sweep they completed with a 10390 victory in Lexington on Saturday night.

title: PERMANENT LIMIT OF 55 M.P.H. URGED
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (UPI)Despite the easing of the energy crisis, consideration should be given to making the 55mileanhour speed limit permanent, the head of the National Highway Traffic Administration said today.

title: Theater: A Royal Delight
description: Over the years, Britain's Royal Shakespeare Company has made a specialty of anthology programs. It takes a few actors and a singer, develops a theme, and the end result is instant theateroften of a most compelling kind. As a result, the Brooklyn Academy of Music has invited the company to end Brooklyn's special British season with a couple of these programs.

title: Morse Cartwright, 83, Founder Of Adult Education Group, Dies
description: PASADENA, Calif., April 21 (UPI)  Morse A. Cartwright, founder of the American Association for Adult Education and a former professor of education at Teachers College of Columbia University, died today in Pasadena Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in San Marino.

title: SOVIET IRRITATION WITH CAIRO VOICED
description: MOSCOW, April 21  Subtle but unmistakable indications of the Soviet Union's irritation with Egypt appeared today in the Soviet press.

title: Argentine Paper Bombed
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 21 (AP)A powerful bomb damaged the offices of a leftist newspaper, El Mundo, early today, injuring a watchman.

title: PRICE RISES SEEN AS CONTROLS END
description: For millions of Americans, the ending of more than 32 months of wage and price controls next week is expected to bring another spasm of price increases that will further erode their already shrunken paychecks.

title: Florida Banker Recovers After Alleged Kidnapping
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 21 (UP1)Albert L. Dantzler, a banker in Hallandale, Fla., was released from the hospital today after recuperating for a day from an ordeal in which he said he was forced to swim for his life in the Atlantic Ocean after escaping from kidnappers.

title: MRS. EDWARD L. TATUM
description: Mrs. Viola Kantrowitz Tatum, wife of Dr. Edward L. Tatum, professor at Rockefeller University and a winner of the Nobel Prize in medicine and physiology in 1958, died yesterday of cancer in New York Hospital. She was 55 years old and lived at 450 East 63d Street.

title: Mt. Hermon Air Strikes Go On But Israel Reports Ground Quiet
description: MOUNT HERMON, IsraeliOccupied Syria, April 21 (Reuters)Israeli planes attacked Syrian military targets around this strategic mountain today, military sources said. But, apart from some intermittent shelling, the rest of the Golan Heights front was quiet.

title: Manhattan Tea Party
description: When New York City gets off to an early start on the bicentennial today, it may come as a surprise to many Americans (not to mention Bostonians) that Manhattan had its Tea Party, too.

title: Lili Kraus Plays Mozart, Messiaen As National's Soloist
description: Lili Kraus is a recognized Mozart specialist. She has recorded the complete concertos, written cadenzas for those concertos that require them, and interested herself sufficiently in musicological matters to insert ornamental flourishes at the proper points in the slow movements. But it cannot really be said that her performance of the Concerto No. 24 in C minor (K. 491) yesterday afternoon with Antal Dorati and the National Symphony was very successful one.

title: Knicks Find HorneCourt Disadvantage
description: Forget the homecourt advantage. It hasn't worked for the Knicks and Boston Celtics in the last three playoff games. Boston has won twice at Madison Square Garden and the Knicks' only victory in the fourofseven game series has been in the Boston Garden.

title: OutofTown Buyers Offered Free Buses
description: Outoftown fashion buyers are being treated to free Buyers' Bus Loop as a transportation courtesy while they are here to select their summer and fall lines in the garment district.

title: Fox Terrier Takes Top Award
description: TIMONIUM, Md., April 21 In horse race parlance, the form held true today at the Baltimore County Kennel Club show at the Timonium Race Track. Ch. Sunnybrook Spat On, a wire fox terrier owned by Mrs. Robert V. Clark Jr. of Middleburg, Va., and handled by Peter Green, took his 15th top award, when he was chosen best of 2,571 dogs by Mrs. Ramona Van Court.

title: Van Nostrand Wins Eastern Net Final
description: King Van Nostrand, the East's fifthranking player, won the Eastern men's indoor tennis championship yesterday with a 62, 46, 62, 63 victory over Warren Lucas in the final at the Stadium Tennis Center in the Bronx.

title: As Prices Soar, BankCard Use Jumps
description: I'm forever running out of cash, a housewife in an uppermiddleclass New Orleans suburb remarked recently. My husband gives me money for the week and one trip to the grocery store shoots the whole wad, so I'm always running around with 50 cents or a dollar in my purse.

title: The Right College Chief
description: In 1969 the faculty and students of Manhattanville College organized a weekend colloquium to discuss changing the curriculum of the school, which had been founded in 1917 by the Sisters of the Sacred Heart. The school had already experienced many changes. It had shorn itself of its religious affiliation. It was considering the admission of men, a step since taken, and it was intent on altering its reputation as a school for the rich and socially prominent.

title: Draft Reactivation Doubted
description: JACKSON, Miss., April 21 (UPI)Senator John C. Stennis, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee. says he doubts that the tary draft would be reactivated in the near future. Unless national security was threatened, the Mississippi Democrat said, I don't think it will be possible for several years to enact a selective service law.

title: Issues in Papers Dispute
description: PARTICIPANTS: The New York Times, The Daily News and The New York Post, negotiating as the Publishers Association of New York City, and New York Typographical Union No. 6, representing 819 printers, including 170 substitutes, at The Times; 945 printers, including 200 to 220 substitutes, at The News; and 312 printers, including 38 substitutes, at The Post.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: HACKENSACK, April 19The death of Jimmy Kay left a large gap in Bergen County coaching ranks. Kay, who was basketball coach at Hackensack High School for 11 years, died of a heart attack on April 6. Kay's passing shocked the many persons who knew him or knew about him. He was only 44 year old.

title: Military's 1967 TakeOver Commemorated in Greece
description: ATHENS, April 21 (UPI) The Greek military regime observed today the seventh anniversary of the bloodless coup that brought it to power. Special church services were held in major cities.

title: Colleges Spending Growing Amounts for Security as Reported Violent Crimes on Campuses Increase
description: Spurred by increasing numhers of reported rapes, assaults and other violent crimes, colleges are pouring greatly increased amounts of money into security and new equipment.

title: Elder Takes Florida Golf Play off
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., April 21 AP)Lee Elder, one of the few blacks on the pro golf tour, rallied from two strokes back with two holes to play to gain a tie after 72 holes and then beat England's Peter Oosterhuis on the fourth playoff hole to win the Monsanto open today.

title: New Books
description: A History of Russian and Soviet Sea Power, Donald W. Mitchell (Putnam, $15).

title: Ending the Bear Hug
description: President Sadat's steady and unequivocal withdrawal from the Soviet embrace is the most promising signal that Cairo, if not yet other Arab capitals, sees a settlement with Israel as a realistic goal of policy.

title: W.H.A. Playoffs
description: Chicago vs. Toronto

title: Sawhill Sees Higher Price For Gas When Curbs End
description: ORLANDO, Fla., April 21 (UPI)John C. Sawhill, administrator of the Federal Energy office, said today that he expected the price of gasoline to increase three to five cents a gallon when controls are removed.

title: ROWDIES A WORRY IN EAST GERMANY
description: BERLIN, April 21  New kinds of crimmal activity among the young that have swept Western countries for some time such as vandalism and willful destructiveness, are beginning to cause concern in East Germany.

title: COLOMBIAN VOTE SHOWS LIBERALS WITH A BIG LEAD
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, April 21 Amid tight security and a carnival atmosphere of street bands, clowns and colorful barmers, Colombians voted today in the nation's first free presidential elections in more than 20 years.

title: Personal Finance
description: Small investors, uncertain of their chances in the stock market but increasingly concerned over the impact of inflation on their savings, are looking more closely at the highly favorable interest rates available to them today.

title: 48% FAIL TO FINISH INMATE PROGRAM
description: City prison officials reported yesterday that 48 per cent of the inmates participating in its fouryearold workrelease program either had escaped or were returned to prison and did not complete their onthejob training.

title: BlueLaw Challenger Arrested Again on L.I.
description: A longtime challenger of the state's so  called blue laws, Marvin S. Perlowin, was arrested again yesterday at his clothing store in Jericho Turnpike in Jericho, L. I., after failing to close the store within an hour of being served two summonses charging violations of the General Business Law. He was booked in Woodbury and released in his own custody for arraignment this morning.

title: Affluence
description: BOSTON, April 21  In one short sentence recently Professor Jean Mayer of Harvard, the great nutritionist, illuminated the profound moral and political test that awaits this country on the issue of food.

title: Police Copter Helps Save 2 TeenAgers From Ocean Off S.l.
description: A teenaged boy and girl were rescued from the chilly waters of the Atlantic Ocean off Staten Island yesterday when a police helicopter on routine patrol spotted the pair clinging to an overturned motorboat, the police said.

title: SpringClearance Sale Is On in Soviet
description: MOSCOW, April 21The So viet Ministry of Trade, caught with large backlogs of unsold consumer goods for the domestic market, has resorted to a nationwide springclearance sale to overcome customer resistence to goods that have passed out of fashion.

title: Time for Farm Votes
description: Another bitter and perhaps bloody contest is about to begin over union representation for the longexploited field laborers who pick grapes and lettuce in California's fertile valleys. Our sympathies in that contest are all with the United Farm Workers, a tiny, idealistic organization that has had to combat not only the hostility the politically powerful growers but also cynical backstabbing by the biggest of all unions, the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: Duryea Facing a Tough Vieelection Battle
description: Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea, who is second only to Governor Wilson as a Republican power in this state and who was a hot gubernatorial prospect six months ago, is facing the fight of his political life, not in Albany, but in East Hampton, Southold, Shelter Island and other parts of his home First Assembly District, which covers the entire eastern half of Suffolk County.

title: Finn Harps Victors
description: DUBLIN, April 21 (UPI)Finn Harps defeated St. Patrick's Athletic today, 31, at Dalymount Park to win their first Football Association of Ireland soccer cup.

title: French WinePrice Fall Takes Toll of Importers
description: The collapse of French wine prices following the huge 1973 grape crop has begun to take its toll among the importers here who invested heavily in 1971 and 1972 wines at enormously inflated prices.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BUDDHAS Tantric Buddhism came out of India, grew in Tibet and spread to China. Its aims are the same as those of other Buddhist sects, although its practices are different, and so is the art that it has inspired. Tantric Buddhist Art is the show, through May 24, at the China Institute in America, 125 East 65th Street (744818). The small room that serves as gallery is resplendent in a display of 53 items39 beautiful and intricately wrought bronze and gilt images and 14 tankas, the painted hanging scrolls of temples, These pieces are as old as 1,000 years, as new as the eighteenhundreds. They are a rare mlange of slim female figures, placid Buddhas and a grim ritual apron, replete with gods and dancing skeletons, made of carved human bone.

title: Red Sox Pick Off a 65 Victory From Indians on a Wild Throw
description: The luckless Indians, berthed in the American League Eastern Division cellar, saw one Of their relief pitchers, Milt Wilcox, lose a game for them to the Red Sox in Boston yesterday in the 10th inning without even throwing a single pitch to the plate.

title: Woman Runs a Center To Combat Coronaries
description: NEWARKThe Center for Coronary RiskFactor Control; a project to identify and treat people susceptible to heart disease, is demonstrating that a lowcholesterol diet does not Have to be a hardship diet. The center, under the guidance of Patricia Bergen, a nutritionist, prepares biweekly meatless menus that respect the waistline without draining the budget. Recent dishes that drive home the point include a clam dip, a chiliandbeans dish and a dessert that combines orange sherbert and egg whites in cloud.

title: Cowboys Take Battle To Court
description: DALLAS, April 21 (AP)The Dallas Cowboys obtained a temporary restraining order today to block the World Football League from any kind of contract dealings with Cowboy players.

title: Falcon Back Released
description: ATLANTA, April 21 (AP) Ralph Powell, a 23yearold former running back from the University of Nebraska, was released yesterday after being charged with drug violations and indecent exposure. Powell was in Atlanta for an orientation session with the Atlanta Falcons.

title: Livelier and Longer TV News Spurs Hunt for Talent
description: In the last four years, Charles Scarborough has moved from Hattiesburg, Miss., to Atlanta, to Boston, to New York City. Mr. Scarborough is a televisionnews anchorman.

title: Livelier and Longer TV News Spurs Hure for Talent
description: In the last four years, Charles Scarborough has moved from Hattiesburg, Miss., to Atlanta, to Boston, to New York City. Mr. Scarborough is a televisionnews anchorman.

title: Capital Bureau News Editor Named
description: A. M. Rosenthal, managing editor of The New York Times, announced yesterday the appointment of Bill Kovach as news editor of the newspaper's Washington bureau. Clifton Daniel is chief of the bureau.

title: Kentiedy's Opinion Polling Baffles Moscow Audience
description: MOSCOW, April 21Senator Edward M. Kennedy tried out Americanstyle public opinion polling on an audience at Moscow State University today and drew some hostility from a generally silent audience when he asked for a show of hands on whether the Soviet Union should be spending more or less on defense.

title: EUROPEANS SEEK A POLICY ON GOLD
description: PARIS, April 21The Common Market countries are moving toward a joint approach on the thorny question of the official price of gold.

title: Gujarat, the Quiet State That Rioted, Is Called Warning to India
description: AHMADABAD, India, April 21  Shattered glass and overturned bricks still scar Gandhi Road. At the university, policemen in khaki uniforms sit languidly in groups on the parched grass, watching the students and dozing in the shade.

title: Lake Superior Town Dismayed By Ban on Polluting Ore Plant
description: SILVER BAY, Minn. April 21 (AP)Employes of the Reserve Mining Company and residents of Silver Bay expressed consternation today over a Fideral judge's order closing the company's taconite processing plant here on only seven hours' notice.

title: Bucyk. Gets 3 Goals as Bruins Win
description: BOSTON, April 21 (AP)Johnny Bucyk scored three powerplay goals in the first two, periods and the Boston Bruins unloaded their heavy artillery for four more scores in the final session today for an 8.6 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks.

title: Horses & Equipment
description: 5HORSE VAN 1966 FORDAdjustable, largest to smallest horse, excellent running conditon & repair. $4500, 203 8695791

title: Celtics Hold Off Knicks, 9891, Take 31 Series Lead to Boston
description: The Boston Celtics sneaked through the back door to an improbable victory over the Knicks yesterday. Defying the Knick, mystique and a screaming, partisan crowd of 19,694 at Madison Square Garden, the Celtics tore up the. New York script calling for a lastminute victory and instead held on for a 9891 triumph.

title: Balloonists Go Far On a Lot of Hot Air
description: FARMINGTON, Conn., April 21A convention of balloonists met here this weekend and everybody got a little high.

title: London's Pearly Royalty a Dying Breed
description: LONDON  Bert and Emmie Matthews are oldage pensioners who live in a simple Victorian cottage in Hampstead, North London. Mr. Matthews, who is 67 years old, enjoys his daily pint of beer at the local pub and still works parttune as a clerk. Mrs. Matthews, 63, has raised two daughters and now likes to crochet and knit.

title: I.R.S. DENIES BALKING INQUIRY ON DONATION
description: WASHINGTON, April 21The Internal Revenue Service denied today charges by investigators for the Senate Watergate committee that it was obstructing the panel's inquiry into a $100,000 Presidential campaign donation from Howard R. Hughes, the billionaire recluse.

title: A Family's Back Yard 200 Acres of Unspoiled Marsh on the HudsonBecomes a Treasure for the Public
description: HUDSON, N. Y.  Henry Livingston relaxed in the gracious, high ceilinged living room his family has called home for 180 years, rather happy with the fact that not only had he been successful in keeping his family's window on the world beautiful, but that he had also enhanced everyone else's, too.

title: Financing of Elections
description: TRENTON, April 21 (UPI)The State Senate reconvenes tomorrow to consider legislation providing for partial public of both the primary and general gubernatorial elections. In the Assembly, a bill that would allow private citizens to sue polluters appea red in danger of being weak??ed from its oringinal form because of various amemdments.

title: Threats to the Press Cited As Publishers Meet Here
description: A growing barrage of challenges to First Amendment guarantees of press freedom along with everlengthening tentacles of government encroachment on business were decried yesterday in an American Newspaper Publishers Association report here,

title: Egyptians Say Fanatic Sect Attacked Military College
description: CAIRO, April 21Egyptian policemen investigating an armed attack on a military technical academy here before dawn Thursday have uncovered an underground organization of religious fanatics whose aim it was to overthrow the moderate Governments of Egypt and several other Arab countries, the Government  controlled press reported here today.

title: Major Bills in Congress
description: Fuel  Gives the President broad powers to curtail energy consumption and manage fuel supplies. Veto sustained by Senate.

title: Nashville Paper Costs Rise
description: NASHVILLE, April 21 (UPI) Citing higher printing costs, The Tennessean, Nashville's morning newspaper, announced today that the price of the daily editions would rise from 10 cents a 15 cents at the newsstand and to 65 cents from 45 cents a week for home delivery. The price for home delivery of the Sunday iditions will rise to 35 cents from 25 cents, the paper said.

title: Episcopal Bishop Lays Cornerstone Of Village Church
description: The cornerstone of the new St. John's In The Village Church and Community Center at 224 Waverly Place, at Perry Street, was blessed and laid yesterday by the Right Rev. J. Stuart Wetmore, Suffragan Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New York.

title: Red Smith
description: In New York a man said, He's sound again. We'll ship to Kentucky Friday. In San Francisco a man said: He's as good as Tomy Lee. I don't know if he's as good as. Swaps but he might be. In Louisville a man tore his hair and cried: The adage must be verified that beggars mounted run their horses to death!

title: Printers' Tactics Disrupt News for 4th Day in Row
description: Printers again hampered production yesterday with a slowdown at The Daily News as Theodore W. Kheel, the media tore held informal talks by telephone with union and management negotiators.

title: Music: New and Newer
description: Improvisation figures so importantly in so much contemporary music that Dennis Russell Davies and the Ensemble were able to face with relative calm the problems that chance threw their way at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday. Mr. Davies and his remarkable group of instrumentalists planned three premieres for their New and Newer Music concert, a perilously large order under the best of circumstances.

title: Chile Allows Key Allende Aide to Leave
description: MEXICO CITY, April 21A key member of the deposed Allende Government in Chile, Pedro Vuskovic Bravo, flew into exile here today after spending more than seven months in asylum in the Mexican Embassy in Santiago.

title: Weekly List of Mutual Funds
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: Police Copter Helps Save 2 TeenAgers From Ocean Of f S.I.
