description: A teenaged boy and girl were rescued from the chilly waters of the Atlantic Ocean off Staten Island yesterday when a police helicopter on routine patrol spotted the pair clinging to an Overturned motorboat, the police said.

title: ADDITIONAL TAPES REPORTED SOUGHT BY RODINO PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, April 22  The House Judiciary Committee, has reportedly asked President Nixon for additional tape recordings and documents dealing with Watergate and alleged political influence in Government antitrust and milk price support decisions.

title: Cougars Win, 43, Tie W.H.A. Series
description: TORONTO, April 22 (UPI) Frank Rochon, a rookie, slapped home a goal at 9 minutes 28 seconds of the third period tonight to give the. Chicago Cougars a 43 victory over the Toronto Toros. The victory evened the four  of  seven  game World Hockey Association playoff semifinal at one game apiece.

title: HERBERT LASKEY
description: Herbert Laskey, an industrial real estate salesman and former assistant to the president of the BookoftheMonth Club, died Sunday in Arlington (Va.) Hospital after a heart attack. He was 54 years old and lived at 17 Winding Way in West Orange, N. J.

title: Days of Siege in a Province Near Saigon
description: DUC HUE, South Vietnam, April 15A ragged cluster of women and children stood in the settling dust of the embankment as the helicopter blades rotated to a stop. Two women with dazed infants hanging on their arms sucked ices that had been passed out by a soldier.

title: O.A.S. HEAD SEES END OF CRISIS IN U.S. TIES
description: The Secretary General of the Organization of American States said today that an crisis in relations between the United States and Latin America might be near, but the need for a common market was being threatened by private investors.

title: Birth Curb Drug for Dogs
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 22 (UPI)Several thousand female dogs in eight cities will soon find their daily meal laced with a birth control drug. Upjohn Company announced today that it would undertake a sampling to test the birth control drug in an at home environment as well as at kennels. The announcement was made at a meeting of the American Animal Hospital Association.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, APRIL 23, 1974

title: Red Cross Aids 150 Forced to Evacuate Homes
description: More than 150 tenants evacuated yesterday from the explosion area, most of them from the Envoy Towers apartments next door at 300 East 46th Street, made temporary headquarters in a Red Cross shelter set up in Holy Family Church at 315 East 47th Street (Dag Hammarskjold Plaza).

title: Ronan's New Problem
description: Even with the best of intentions, and with considerable drive, can William J. Ronan really get the Port Authority to take on a major role in developing masstransit projects? That is the big question politiciansand stransportation specialists are asking as Dr. Ronan assumes the chairmanship, of the prospering, multibilliondollar Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: A.C.L.U. Sues to Bar Searches Of Blacks in Drive to Find Killer
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 22 The American Civil Liberties. Union filed suit today asking that the San Francisco police be ordered to stop street searches of hundreds of black men whose descriptions match those of suspected mass killers.

title: Big Rise Noted in Total of Black Elected Officials
description: WASHINGTON, April 22Paced by the election of 26 new Mayors, the number of blacks elected to political office increased sharply last year for a 152 per cent gain over the last five years, the Joint Center for Political Studies reported today.

title: Israeli Labor Party Picks Rabin for Mrs. Meir's Post
description: TEL AVIV, April 22Itzhak Rabin, the commander of Israel's armies in the 1967 war, tonight won the Labor party's nomination to succeed Premier Golda Meir.

title: JACKSON IS CAUTIOUS ON QUICK ARMS PACT
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 Senator Henry M. Jackson said today that the United States was so eager for some kind of armslimitation accord in time for President Nixon's expected trip to Moscow in June that it was willing to consider a quick cosmetic agreement that could harm American security.

title: Baseball Trial Recessed
description: EVERETT, Wash., April 22 (AP)  The Superior Court trial of the suit against baseball's American League, for removal of the Seattle Pilots baseball team after only one season recessed today for week after selection of a threeman, ninewoman jury.

title: Fishmeal for Sale
description: Now that the once elusive anchovy is returning to the Peruvian coast, the military rulers of Peru have begun a search for buyers of proteinrich fishmeal made from the tiny fish.

title: Harvester's Board Backs Sedden Stock Purchase
description: Carrying forward a plan to produce heavy trucks in Britain, the International Harvester Company said yesterday that its board had approved the previously announced proposal to buy the remaining 89 per cent of outstanding shares in Sedden Diesel Vehicles, Ltd., of London.

title: City Moves to Avert Racial Clash in Vote In School District 1
description: The City's Human Rights Commissioner, Eleanor Holmes Norton, met privately with, candidates in the coming Community School Board Districe 1 election last night in an effort to head off racial and ethnic polarization in the campaign.

title: Brueckelen Aims to Get 1667 Grant
description: The charter of the Town of Brueckelen from 1667 is reposing in splendid secrecy in a California library, City Council President Paul O'Dwyer said yesterday. With the historical interest stirred by the nation's bicentennial, New York City should try to get the document back, Mr. O'Dwyer said the Council President and Sebastian Leone, Borough President of Brooklyn, which is the modern counterpart of Brueckelen, issued a statement promising to do all that is legally possible o get the document. John Hayes, deputy borough president, said letters were being prepared suggesting an exchange of something owned by Brooklyn that California might wantMr. Hayes did not say what that might be for the charter.

title: Opposition Sinks Ruler's Backers in Sikkim Vote
description: NEW DELHI, April 22The Congress party, representing the dominant Nepali population in the tiny Indian protectorate of Sikkim, in the Himalayas, has won, 29 seats in voting last week for a new 32member Legislative, Assembly. However, the Government remains under New Delhi's control.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Opponents of the proposed Tocks Island Dam filed suit in Federal District Court in Philadelphia yesterday asking for a temporary restraining order against further destruction of property of historic value by the Army Corps of Engineers. Judge D. W. Artsdalen granted the order pending a hearing today.

title: Rescinding of Price Rises Set on West German Oil
description: WEST BERLIN, April 22 (AP)The West German Federal Cartel Office decided today to order an injunction against subsidiaries of the British Petroleum Company and Texaco, Inc., forcing them to rescind their preEaster gasoline price increases.

title: WOMAN IN CONVENT TO RETAIN ALIMONY
description: CHICAGO, April 22 (AP)An insurance salesman was ordered today to keep paying his former wife $250 a month in alimony even though she has loined a Milwaukee convent.

title: People and Business
description: The Earl of Cromer, who was the British Ambassador to the United States from 1971 until the end of last year, will return to the chairmanship of the London Multinational Bank, effective May I. The Londonbased international merchant bank is jointly owned by Baring Bros. & Co., Ltd., of Britain, Credit Suisse of Switzerland, the Chemical Bank of New York and the Northern Trust Company of Chicago.

title: Paul Stephenson, Director Of Little Theaters, Is Dead
description: Paul Stephenson, a director of little theaters from Vermont to Colorado, died yesterday in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 75 years old and also lived in Dorset, Vt.

title: Celtics' Senior Citizen Making Knicks Go Gray
description: John Havlicek has been tormenting the Knicksespecially in playoff gamesfor many years, so it was no surprise that the Boston Celtics' captain was the driving force in his team's 9891 victory at Madison Square Garden Sunday.

title: OvertheCounter Quotations
People in Sports
description: A tennis star who rose in the East has set in the West. Nikki Pilic, the flamboyant Yugoslav, has signed a contract with the New York Sets of World Team Tennis.

title: Many Things Happen To That $4 in Fabric On Way to a $110 Tag
description: Everything costs too much these days, and clothes are no exception. So they say and they, in this case, means just about everyone.

title: MRS. JOHN S. THORP
description: Mrs. Winifred Klipp Thorp, widow of John S. Thorp, Democratip leader of Nassau County from 1933 to 1947, and mother of Assemblyman John S. Thorp Jr., Democrat of Rockville Centre, died yesterday at her home, 33 Burtis Avenue, Rockville Centre, L. I. She was 77 years old.

title: Stage: Stoppard's Murder Play About Philosophy
description: Tom Stoppard is not just witty, he is clever. He plays with ideas like a juggler, and the ideas he is playing with are sharp, clear and dazzling. Well, perhaps not entirely clearjust sharp and dazzling. I suspect he believes that total clarity obscures true thought.

title: Lawyer and Two Policemen Indicted in S.I. Bribery
description: The indictment of a Staten ??stand lawyer and two policemen on charges of perjury, conpiracy and bribing a witness ??ot to testify against a probe??onary police officer was disclosed yesterday by the special state prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjan. The probationary of??ice; Robert Bottiglieri, had ??een accused of harassing two ??armaids.

title: JERSEY FACES TEST ON OBSCENITY LAW
description: WASHINGTON, April 22  The United States Supreme Court agreed today to rule on whether, the obscenity law that the New Jersey Legislature approved in 1971 is an unconstitutional limitation on freedom of expression.

title: P.S.A.L. In Dispute Over Jobs
description: At least 19 of the 37 Public Schools Athletic League football coaches are thinking of leaving their jobs if a controversial circular from the Board of Education continues to be enforced.

title: Archie Bunker, GermanStyle
description: BERLINOn. New Year's Eve, for the first time nationwide on German television, a show like All in the Family in the Dated States was presented. The reaction was almost sensational.

title: Burns Pledges to Curb Money Growth; Terms. Inflation Problem Dangerous
description: Word from Washington that the Federal Reserve Board is determined to continue moneysupply restrictions regardless of the effect in such areas as home building apparently came, as no surprise to the money markets yesterday. The evidence was sufficiently plain in the rise of the basic lending rate of the First National Bank of Chicago (one of the 10 biggest banks in the country) to 10.4 per cent from the 10.1 per cent it had been quoting for, the last week and an increase in the rate for Federal funds to 11 cent.

title: POLICE IN CALIFORNIA WARNED OF REPRISAL
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 22 (AP)  A man purporting to be General Pax of the terrorist Symbionese Liberation Army vowed in messages to a Sacramento newspaper today that five California peace officers would be slain for any S.L.A. member killed.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: WILLCOX A GIBBS 1972 sales were 86% higher than 1972 (WGANSEX)Advt.

title: A.F.L.C.I.O. Boycotts Social Security Advisory Council Over the Rejection of a Meany Nominee
description: WASHINGTON, April 22The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations is boycotting the Advisory Council on Social Security, a statutory body on which it has long served. The federation charges that the Nixon Administration rejected one of its nominees to the council for poiticlal reasons.

title: HUNT IS SEEKING 5TH TERM IN HOUSE
description: CHERRY HILL, April 22  Representative John E. Hunt, often called New Jersey's most conservative Congressman, announced today his candidacy for a fith term in the First Congressional District.

title: SILVER PRICES UP; SOYBEAN OIL RISES
description: Spurred by inflation fears May silver jumped the 20centanounce daily limit yesterday on the Commodity Exchange to close at $5.22 8/10, up from $5.02 8/10 on Friday.

title: Dr. Frederich A. Blossom Dies; Author, Teacher, Activist 96
description: Dr. Frederick A. Blossorn, editor, author, teacher and activist and the third oldest alummut of Amherst College, died Sunday at his home in pleasant Hill, Tenn. He was 96 years old.

title: NEW JOBLESS AID STUDIED BY PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 The Nixon Administration asked Congress today to reject pending legislation creating a special unemployment benefits program for victims of the energy shortage.

title: RENA CRAIG, EXDEAN AT UNION SEMINARY
description: Mrs. Rena Stebbins Craig, dean of women at Union Theological Seminary in New York from 1955 until her retirement in 1962, died today of leukemia at Washington Hospital Center. She was 79 years old, the widow of the Rev. Clarence J. Craig, Dean of Drew Theological Seminary, Madison, N. J., at his death in 1953:

title: A Workshop for the Career Woman
description: When Janice La Rouche's workshop on career planning began seven weeks ago at the Barnard College Women's Center, most of the 20 women present had more excuse for being unable to start careers than ideas on what they wanted to do.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 43

title: N.B.A. Playoffs
description: Knicks vs. Boston

title: Gershwin Bust at Carnegie
description: A bust or George Gershwin was presented to Carnegie Hall yesterday to commemorate the 50th anniversary Sunday of the late composerpianist's debut in that hall. The bust, sculptured by George R. Anthonisen, was presented by Mr. Gershwins sister, Frances Godowsky, and was accepted for Carnegie Hall by Leontyne Price. One of the sopranos early successes had been in Porgy and Bess. The bust will be on permanent display on the first tier of the hall.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, April 22  The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended April 16.

title: Foreign Stock Exchanges
description: MONTREAL

title: Blacks Renew Job Battle As Building Season Opens
description: A dispute over the hiring of more members of minority groups in the building trade: here has engendered a thicket of lawsuit tied up hundreds of million's of dollars in Federal Construction funds, and grown into a major behindthescenes crisis for the Beanie administration.

title: 3 Women: Their Paths Leading to Terrorism
description: BERKELEY, Calif., April 22 Nancy Ling Perry campaigned for Barry Goldwater and not so long ago Camille Hall was an avowed pacifist and Patricia Soltysik said she wanted to work with animals.Somehow, these women apparently were touched by the political shiftings of recent years and were turned into revolutionaries. Suddenly, they are among the militant women who have emerged as the apparent leaders of the Symbionese Liberation Army.

title: LATE CITY EDITION
description: Weather: Cloudy, mild today; cool tonight. Sunny, pleasant tomorrow. Temp. range: today 6068; Monday 5978. Additional details on Page 81.

title: Jury Rules Fieldston May Collect Upkeep From Its Residents
description: A Bronx civil jury ruled yesterday that the treeshaded neighborhood of Fieldston was a private community legally entitled to charge upkeep fees from homeowners.

title: CHILE TRIAL OPENS JUNTA TO SCRUTINY
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 22  The trial of 57 air force officials and 10 civilians accused of sedition and Marxist sympathies has led to the first public debate here over the legality of the military Junta's overthrow of the elected Marxist coalition Government last September and its conduct since.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, APRIL 23, 1974

title: TESTIMONY ENDED IN MITCHELL TRIAL
description: Testimony in the criminal conspiracy trial of John N. Mitchell and Maurice H. Stans ended yesterday, and the case is expected to go to the jury tomorrow night.

title: N. & W. RAILROAD EXPECTS RECORD
description: On the basis of its firstquarter business, the Norfolk Western Railwayis clearly destined for its first billiondollar, vice president for finance said at a meeting ofsecurities analysts at a newsconference here yesterday.Operating revenues in the fristquarter rose to $241.9millionfrom $222.4million in the 1973quarter.

title: Medicaid and Blue Cross Found Owing Hospitals Millions in '73
description: A state Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that Medicaid and Blue Cross of Greater New York underpaid hospitals by millions of dollars in 1973 and he ordered the insurers to make up the difference.

title: Nominee in Israel
description: As a soldier and diplomat, Itzhak Rabin has come to symbolize a generation of younger Israelis, a tough and tactically unorthodox people tempered by war and dedicated to national survival. His reputation has thus far been decidedly apolitical, resting on his accom plishments as a fighter, as chief of staff during the sixday war of 1967 and as ambassador to the United States from 1968 to 1973.

title: ANSWER TO PREVIOUS PUZZLE
BALLET HISPANICO IS ENERGETIC TROUPE
description: Tina Ramirez's Ballet Hispanico of New York is a company of 13 dancers from the city's barrios and Saturday night they made Clark Center for the Performing Arts pulse with their very youthful energy and charm.

title: Giscard Steps Up Drive, And Enthusiasm Grows
description: DIJON, France, April 21Out of the Mystee executive jet and into the black Citroen. Strasbourg, Mulhouse, Colmar, Auxerre, DijonValery Giscard d'Estaing is whooshing across eastern Francedrawing heavy, curious, even enthusiastic crowds.

title: Radar to Hunt Treasure in a Pyramid
description: WASHINGTON, April 22A new effort to locate a treasureladen burial vault within or under the gigantic Khefren pyramid is being undertaken by the Stanford Research Institute, using a rock penetrating radar.

title: INDIANA STANDARD AND GULF LIFT NET
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation and the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), two of the nation's biggest oil producers and refiners yesterday reported substantial firstquarter earnings increases.

title: Can Ronan Redirect Port Authority?
description: Even with the best of intentions, and with considerable drive, can William J. Ronan really get the Port Authority to take on a major role in developing masstransit projects? That is the big question politicians and transportation specialists are asking as Dr. Ronan assumes the chairmanship of the prospering, multibilliondollar Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: Chess: Lo How the Mighty Do Fall! (And That's Not an Upset?)
description: In world championship candidates competition, in which small differences separate the players, it is not strictly correct to speak of upsets, but Viktor Korchnoi's victory over Tigran Petrosian in the first game of their semifinals match in Odessa was a case of the underdog felling the favorite.

title: Claudine, Funny Film With Realities of Harlem Life
PERCENTAGE CHANGES, IN COMMINGLED EQUITY FUNDS FOR EMPLOYE BENEFIT ACCOUNTS
Union Drops Farah Suit
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 22 (UPI)The Amalgamated Clothing Workers Union dropped today its suit against the Farah Manufacturing Company, the nation's largest manufacturer of pants. Farah employes voted last month to accept a contract proposal for 5,300 local workers, ending an 18month strike and boycott of Farah goods across the country.

title: Japan and Soviet Plan Siberian Loan
description: TOKYO, April 22  Japan agreed tentatively today to lend the Soviet Union $1billion at relatively low interest to finance three projects involving the development of coal, gas, and forestry resources in Siberia.

title: White House Link to I.R.S. In Hughes Inquiry Hinted
description: WASHINGTON, April 22Investigators for the Senate Watergate committee now believe that the White House played a major role in coordinating the Internal Revenue Service's investigation of a controversial $100,000 campaign contribution from Howard R. Hughes, sources familiar with the Senate inquiry said today.

title: Protection for Tenants
description: The insecurity of apartment dwellers in the face accelerating efforts by landlords to convert rental buildings into condominiums or cooperatives was reflected in the turnout here the other day at a hearing of the Assembly Committee on Housing. Tenants from a dozen large apartment complexes were on hand to urge passage of a bill that would require at least 51 per cent tenant consent before conversion could take place. The measure would place a threeyear moratorium on the eviction of any tenant who declined to buy after conversion had been approved.

title: Notes on People
description: James Earl Ray, the convicted slayer of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., ended a fourday hunger strike in the Tennessee state prison in Nashville yesterday, after prison officials warned him they had no intention of going overboard to make him eat.

title: Porter Starts 30Day Term For Lying About Watergate
description: LOMPOC, Calif., April 22 (UPI)Herbert L. Porter, who was the scheduling director for President Nixon's reelection campaign, entered the Federal Correctional Institution here today to serve a 30day sentence for lying in the Watergate investigation.

title: Royals Lose To Red Sox; Yaz Clouts 2
description: BOSTON, April 22 (AP)  Carl Yastrzemski hit two home runs while leading the Boston Red Sox to a 41 victory over the Kansas City Royals tonight.

title: Fewer Scientists Immigrate to U.S.; Tighter Rule Cited
description: In the year ending last June 30, 41 per cent fewer scientists and engineers immigrated to the United States as entered the year before, a study by the. National Science Foundation shows. In the same period, immigration by foreign physicians held steady.

title: Donaldson, Lufkin Profit Shrinks in the Quarter
description: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, Inc., reported yesterday that despite soaring revenues, the brokerage firm barely broke even in the first quarter.

title: SIDNEY A. WIEN
description: Sidney A. Wien, a vice president of HelmsleySpear, Inc., and treasurer of the Midtown Realty Owners Association, died Sunday in the South Shore branch of Long Island Jewish Hospital after a heart attack. He was 50 years old and lived at 101 Cedar Avenue, Hewlett Bay Park, L.I.

title: One Down And One To Go
description: DALLASI view this as a rematch, Frances Farenthold said the other day, speaking of her campaign for governor of Texas. One down and that was Barnes, and one to go and that's Briscoe.

title: Soviet Official Reiterates Call For World Communist Session
description: MOSCOW, April 22  The Soviet leadership today give its first public blessing to the idea of a world Communist conference, which it has been promoting privately, among its allies since last summer.

title: ADDITIONAL TAPES REPORTED SOUGHT BY RODINO PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, April 22  The House Judiciary Committee has reportedly asked President Nixon for additional tape. recordings and documents dealing with Watergate and alleged political influence in Government antitrust and milk price support decisions.

title: Bucks Win, 115 to 99, For Sweep
description: CHICAGO, April 22 (AP)Oscar Robertson ignited a rally in the third quarter that enabled the Milwaukee Bucks to smother the Chicago Bulls, 11599, tonight for a fourgame sweep of their National Basketball Association Western Conference final series.

title: JOHN F. GRINER, LED FEDERAL EMPLOYES
description: WASHINGTON, April 22  John F. Griner, president emeritus of the American Federation, of Government Employes, American Federation of LaborCongress of Industrial Organizations, died today at a hospital in Cairo, Ga. He was 66 years) old and had lived in Cairo since he retired 16 months ago.

title: Fire Closes Boston School
description: BOSTON, April 22 (AP)A twoalarm fire yesterday has forced the closing of the Gilbert Stuart Elementary School in Boston's Dorchester section.

title: Sawhill Defends Higher Fuel Prices
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP)John C. Sawhill, the new head of the Federal Energy Office, defended the higher fuel prices that have settled in around the country and indicated today that they would pay off in increased supplies.

title: Blast Brings Chaos And, for Some, Ruin
description: Yesterday's explosion at Second Avenue and 45th Street spread anguish and confusion through the surrounding blocks of the Turtle Bay neighborhood, which is the nearest thing New York has to a diplomatic quarter.

title: Shabazz Case Defendant Testifies in Newark Trial
description: NEWARK, April 22Lamont Calloway, who is charged with the murder of a Black Muslim minister, James McGregor Shabazz, took the witness stand in his own defense today to deny he ever gave the police a statement implicating him in the crime. He also charged that police interrogators had beaten him severely on three occasions.

title: When inspiration Knocked, She Opened the Door
description: TAPPAN, N.Y.  To Jene Nickford, a door is not just something that opens and closes. It's raw material waiting to be turned into sculpture.

title: MEMPHIS A VICTOR ON BLACK SCHOOLS
description: WASHINGTON, April 22For the third time in the last six months, the Supreme Court has refused to reexamine a Southern school desegregation an that had been attacked for preserving a number of allblack schools in the face of integration orders.

title: Contract Awards
description: CE Lummus a subsidiary of Combustion Engineering, Inc., has been awarded a contract covering engineering, procurement, construction and startup assistance for the Ainerican Natural Gas Company's coal gasification plant to be built in North Dakota. The plant, scheduled for completion in, the late 1970's, will convert lignite supplied by the North American Coal Company to gas. It will have a capacity of 250million cubic feet a day and is estimated within the industry to cost $450million.

title: Ruler of Sikkim, Alone in Palace, Broods and Waits
description: GANGTOK, Sikkim, April 18 The Ruler of Sikkim, stripped of his powers, with his Americanborn wife and children far away, is living unhappily alone in his cliffside palace here, brooding over the events of the last year.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: MACKELL DRAWS 6 MONTHS IN JAIL
description: Thomas J. Mackell, the former Queens District Attorney, was sentenced to six months in prison yesterday for blocking the prosecution of a confidence racket in which members of his office had invested money.

title: Summary of Various Actions Taken by Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, April 22The Supreme. Court took the following actions today:

title: L.I. Officials Ask Data On Offshore Oil Drilling
description: MINEOLA, L. I., April 22  The Executives of Nassau and Suffolk Counties requested today that the Secretary of the Interior make immediately available to the counties research results of Federal Government studies on potential Atlantic Outer Shelf Offshore oil drilling.

title: EMBATTLED HEAD OF V.A. TO RESIGN
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 Flours after wellinformed sources reported that he had been dismissed as head of the Veterans Administration, Donald E. Johnson announced tonight that he would resign in the near future.

title: Dance: Tribute to the Y
description: Agnes de Mille, Jerome Robbins and dancers of various styles and generations joined forces Sunday night to pay tribute to the role of the 92d Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association in the development of American dance. With Walter Terry, the dance critic, as host, the Gala Evening of Dance drew a soldout house as part of the centennial celebrations of the Y.M.Y.W.H.A.

title: Colombia Awaits Changes by New Chief
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, April 22 Alfonso Lpez Michelsen of the Liberal party, one of the two parties that together have long dominated Colombia's politics, was declared the winner of yesterdays presidential election today by a sweeping majority.

title: ANALYSTS UNSURE ON WESTINGHOUSE
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, which previously reported a 55.97 per cent drop in earnings for the fourth quarter of 1973 followed by a 28,1 per cent drop in the first quarter of this year, tried yesterday morning to convince securities analysts that the company now sees clearer skies ahead.

title: Pacers Beat Stars And Trail by 32
description: SALT LAKE CITY, April 22 (AP)The Indiana Pacers, led by the scoring of Mel Daniels and George McGinnis, gained a 110101 victory over the Utah Stars tonight and prolonged the American Basketball Association's Western Division final playoff.

title: Sons of the Fathers
description: A shabby theater in Tel Aviv was the unlikely setting yesterday for what could become a major turning point in the political life of modern Israel. In a deceptively straightforwtard secret ballot, the ruling Labor party elevated a new generation to political maturity.

title: Rangers Shrug at Loss And Brace for Rematch
description: The New York Rangers have it all figured out. So they lost, 40, and rather unceremoniously at that, to the Philadelphia Flyers in the unfriendly confines of the Spectrum. So it was only the first game of a four  of  seven game semifinal playoff for the championship of the National Hockey League.

title: Percentage Gains
description: Stocks with the largest percentage gains on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

title: White House Link to I.R.S. In Hughes Inquiry Hinted
description: WASHINGTON, April 22Investigators for the Senate Watergate committee now believe that the White House played a major role in coordinating the Internal Revenue Service's, investigation of a controversial $100,000 campaign contribution from How* and R. Hughes, sources familiar with the Senate inquiry said today.

title: 8 A.B.C. AFFILIATES BAR PAPP TV PLAY
description: Eight stations in the American Broadcasting Company television network have declined to carry the presentation tomorrow night of The Wedding Band, a play by Alice Childress, which concerns the marriage of a white man to a black woman just after World War I. It will be broadcast from 9 to 11 o'clock.

title: Safe in Court Burglarized
description: A safe in the Criminal Court Building in Staten Island was broken into during the weekend and petty cash amounting to about $10 was stolen. The theft was discovered at 7 A.M. yesterday on the first floor of the courthouse at 67 Targee Street in the Stapleton section.

title: Arabs Said to Back I.M.F. Oil Facility
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 The managing director of the International Monetary Fund reported to the board of the fund today that five major Arab oilexporting countries had expressed their willingness to give financial support to proposed new oil facility in the fund.

title: Jacques Weber Dies at 81; Headed Bloomsburg Mills
description: Jacques Weber, who retired in 1966 as president and chairman of the board of Bloomsburg Mills, Inc., textile manufacturer, of 525 Seventh Avenue, died yesterday in Greenwich (Conn) Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in Greenwich.

title: Issues in Papers Dispute
description: PARTICIPANTS: The New York Times, The Daily News and The New York Post, negotiating as the Publishers Association of New York, City, and New York Typographical Union No. 6, representing 819 printers, including 170 substitutes, at The Times; 945 printers, including 200 to 220 substitutes, at The News; and 312 printers, including 38 substitutes, at The Post.

title: LEGISLATORS VOTE TO DISBAND FRIDAY
description: ALBANY, April 22The Senate and Assembly voted today to adjourn for the year this coming Friday afternoon, in a move that proponents called a psybhological prod, opponents called a charade, and everyone seemed to agree unrealistic in the extreme.

title: Going Out Guide
description: SOUTH PACIFIC What with the current stampede for the art of Africa, you may have overlooked the art that is available from the South Pacific. Oceanic Primitive Arts, 88 East 10th. Street (9828060), deals only in works from that enormous islanddotted area of the world. The gallery opened its doors last October and has a stock of 6,000 pieces. They're not all on show, of course, but much is to be seen that comes from New Guinea, the Fiji Islands, the Solomon, New Caledonia, the Trobriand Islands.

title: U.S. Mail to Canadians Halts Because of Strike
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (UPI)  The Postal Service announced today that It was Malting service to Canada at the request of the Ottawa Government because of the Canadian postal strike.

title: Celtics' Senior Citizen Making Knicks Go Gray
description: John Havlicek has been tormenting the Knicksespecially in playoff gamesfor many years, so it was no surprise that the Boston Celtics' captain was the driving force in his team's 9891 victory at Madison Square Garden Sunday.

title: Textron to Buy Its Shares
description: Textron, Inc., of Providence, R. I., said yesterday it would repurchase up to 500,000 of its common shares and 250,000 of its preferred shares through periodic openmarket purchases. The company said the repurchased common shares would be reserved for warrants and options. The repurchased preferred shares are to be retired.

title: PAN AM JETLINER WITH 107 ABOARD CRASHES ON BALI
description: A Pan American 707 with 107 persons aboard crashed in a remote, mountainous region of Bali in Indonesia yesterday.

title: Washington Wins Regatta CORVALLIS, Ore., April 22
description: Washington Wins Regatta

title: Scientists Opposed to Nuclear Power Accuse A.E.C. of Misleading the Public About Solar Energy
description: WASHINGTON, April 22A group of scientists who have criticized nuclear power has accused the Atomic Energy Commission of a coverup of information about the feasiWay of converting sunshine into commercially useful energy.

title: IVOR BROW DIES; AUTHOR, CRITIC, 82
description: LONDON, April 22  Ivor, Brown, author, critic and former editor of The Obseiver, died today at his home here. He was 82 years old.

title: Office Tower Blast Near U. N. Injures 70
description: A powerful explosion ripped through a 24story office building near the United Nations early yesterday, injuring 70 people; three critically, and leaving hundreds of residents of a neighboring apartment building temporarily homeless.

title: Bridge: U.S. Women to Play Italians In Exhibition Match in Venice
description: The competitors In the Bermuda Bowl contest for the world team championship in Venice next month are all men, but the women will have a chance to show their skills during the first few days. The Italian women's team, which holds the European and world titles, will play an exhibition match against an American sextet.

title: TESTIMONY ENDED IN MITCHELL TRIAL
description: Testimony in the criminal conspiracy trial of John N. Mitchell and Maurice H. Stans ended yesterday, and the case is expected to go to the jury tomorrow night.

title: Peterson Bothered by Status As Forgotten Man of Yanks
description: Weary from Earl Weaver's pestiferous protests, the Yankees enjoyed a welldeserved day off yesterday. One of the players who rested could have chosen the occasion to launch his own protest, but somewhat surprisingly, he declined.

title: AUTOMATION UNIT URGED FOR PRESS
description: A proposal for a labormanagement council for the nation's newspapers to help an orderly transition into the era of automated publishing that is already upon us was offered here yesterday by W. J. Usery Jr., director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.

title: PUERTO RICANS FIND BIAS AT PRINCETON
description: PRINCETON, April 22 The Puerto Rican and Chicano student organizations at Princeton have charged the university with discrimination against those minority groups.

title: Stage: Voodoo Parlour
description: In the Voodoo Parlour of Marie Leveau, two long oneact, tenuously related plays by Frank Gagliano, was presented last weekend at the Playhouse Theater as part of the continuing series of New Phoenix Repertory Company Sideshows. The Sideshows offer a preliminary sketch for a production, drawing upon the Phoenix's talented actors, directors and designers. The sketching is fine, but this time the material is faulty.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 43

title: Music: Janacek's Vixen
description: Janacek's The Cunning Little Vixen is one of the Czech composer's finest operas, but like Ravel's L'Enfant et les Sortilges it calls on human singers to portray animals, which encourages most sensible persons to dismiss it out of hand as they would a movie about talking seagulls or dolphins.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE BOOK, THE RING AND THE POET. By William Irvine and Park Honan. 607 pages. McGrawHill. $15.

title: Iran's Aide at U.N. Doubts Huge Rises In the Price of Oil
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 22Iran's Finance Minister said today that he did not foresee vast Increases in oil prices, but he cautioned that there would be some increases unless the industrialized countries controlled galloping inflation.

title: Broker in Britain Charged In Wilson Forgery Case
description: LONDON, April 22An insurance broker and property dealer was charged today with attempting to sell to a London newspaper a letter bearing the forged signature of Prime Min ister Wilson.

title: Medicaid and Blue Cross Ruled to Owe Hospitals
description: A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that Medicaid and Blue Cross of Greater New York underpaid hospitals by millions of dollars in 1973 and he ordered the insurers to make up the difference.

title: RABBI N. J. NOVOSELLER
description: Rabbi Norman J. Novoseller, executive board member of the Yeshiva College Alumni Association and chairman of the Is; rael Tours Program, died of a heart attack Sunday at the home of his father, Rabbi Sherman Novoseller, in Philadelphia. His age was 28 and he lived at 666 West 188th St.

title: PAN AM JETLINER WITH 107 ABOARD CRASHES ON BALI
description: A Pan American 707 with 107 persons aboard crashed in a remote, mountainous region of Bali in Indonesia yesterday.

title: P.S.A.L. In Dispute Over Jobs
description: At least 19 of the 37 Public Schools Athletic League football coaches are thinking of leaving their jobs if a controversial circular from the Board of Education continues to be enforced.

title: Business Briefs
description: Group Loses Bid to Sue on Bank Loss

title: TV: In Larry, a Struggle to Be Normal
description: By JOHN J. O'CONNOR The fourth presentation in the G.E. Theater series, which has quietly brought a, pronounced element of distinction to the current television season, is called Larry. It was written by David Seltzer, directed by William A. Graham and produced, by Mitchell. Brower and Robert Lovenhelm. The 90minute program can be seen on the Columbia Broadcasting System network tonight at 9:30 o'clock.

title: Weather Reports and Fotecast
AUDITING SCORED BY SCHOOLS AIDE
description: A member of the Board of Education charged yesterday that many school operations, involving the expenditure of millions of dollars, were not being audited because of inadequacies in the city system's financial controls.

title: EMBATTLED HEAD OF V.A. TO RESIGN
description: WASHINGTON, April. 22 Hours after wellinformed sources reported that he had been dismissed as head of the Veterans Administration, Donald E. Johnson announced tonight that he would resign in the near future.

title: Dividend Is Omitted
description: The American Century Mortgage Investors has omitted the dividend normally payable in May. Shareholders received 25 cents in February which had been reduced from the 45cent distribution last November. The trust, based in Jacksonville, Fla., said yesterday a fourthquarter dividend would be considered at the regular meeting in July.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: TRENTON, April 22Jeff Pfeiffer is not the best gymnast in the world. As a freshman, he was not even the best on the Trenton State University team. In fact, in his specialty events, the sidehorse and stillrings, he usually ranked as the team's second or third best. But Pfeiffer's achievements stand second to none.

title: Soviet Juniors Start Basketball Tour
description: They finished their ice cream and filed out of the hotel into the tour bus. They were a group of 11 Soviet Junior basketball players from Moscow, 16and17yearolds, who were in New York for two games against local allstar teams.

title: Mine Shutdown Ends
description: INDIANA, Pa., April 22 (UPI) A 12day work stoppage that made idle 12,000 miners in western Pennsylvania and West Virginia appeared ended today when most of them returned to work in compliance with ap peals by United Mine Workers leaders. The shutdown was started by the dismissal of two miners att he Florence Mining Company. The union said the company had agreed to reopen discussions over the dismissals, which had been upheld by an arbitrator.

title: U.N. TRANSLATORS TO STAY OFF JOB
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 22The United Nations corps of interpreters, dissatisfieird by their long hours of work, decided tonight to stage the nearest thing to a strike that they have undertaken in 29 years of translating speeches.

title: No Time for Delay
description: Congress returns to work today after its Easter recess under the pressure of a unique deadline. If the House Judiciary Committee keeps to its present timetable, a vote in the House of Representatives on the impeachment question is probable in midJuly.

title: New School Board
description: The life of the present fivemember Board of Education the interim body appointed to oversee the transition to a decentralized systemends on June 30th. The law requires that the new board of seven members, who are to serve for a fouryear period, be appointed before June 1. One member is to be named by each of the five Borough Presidents; the two remaining membersatlarge are to be designated by the Mayor.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 3 P.M., on Lebanese complaint against Israel.

title: Trenton Votes to Repeal Port Authority Bond Curb
description: TRENTON, April 22  A measure repealing a 12yearold bond covenant that prevents the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey from undertaking any masstransportation projects that could lose money cleared the New Jersey Legislature easily today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Few assumptions are as central to the American world view as that which maintains that others, particularly nonWesterners, do not value human life as much as we do. The brutality of this assumption lies, in its selffulfilling nature: If Vietnamese lives are not particularly valuable, to the Vietnamese themselves, why should they be to those who execute American policies and decisions? The doctrine cheapens the lives of others, renders them marginal and unimportant, and slights the importance of their misery and suffering. In a presumably secular age, we play gods and value our own lives while devaluing those of others.

title: Hartford Knights End play
description: BLOOMFIELT), Conn., April 22 (AP)  The Hartford Knights have played their last game, Peter Savin, president of the Atlantic Coast Football League team, announced today.

title: Wilson Urges More State Care for Mental Patients
description: ALBANY, April 22Governor Wilson asked the Legislature today to enact a major reform to provide complete state takeover of the care and treatment of patients discharged from the state's mental institutions.

title: Giants Sign Mendenhall and Dvorak
description: Not all New York Giant players are rushing to join the World Football League.

title: Market Place: Pension Funds: How Banks Did
description: The major New York City hanks are never eager to release figures on the performance of their pooled pension funds. One reason may be that, over the last 12 years, the banks for which figures have become available have not done so well as the Standard & Poor index of 500 stocks.

title: HEALTH UNIT BUSY ON MEDICAL RIGHTS
description: PITTSBURGH, April 21An organization created 10 years ago as the health care arm of the civil rights Movement still survivesthe Medical Commit030 for Human Rights. The group is holding its annual convention here at Carlow College, a predominantly female Roman Catholic institution for Women of spirit.

title: PFIZER TO INCREASE ITS OUTLAYS BY 70%
description: Pfizer, Inc., told its shareholders at the annual meeting here yesterday that the company would raise its capital spending this year by almost 70 per cent and also step up its research and development expenditures.

title: Mound Woes Pull Down Mets As They Enter Western Lairs
description: Even for a team that has seen much trouble, the New York Mets were surrounded by woe last night as they flew to San Diego with eight defeats in their last nine games and their pitching in disarray.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Royals Lose To Red Sox; Yaz Clouts 2
description: BOSTON, April 22 (AP)  Carl Yastrzemski hit two home runs while leading the Boston Red Sox to a 41 victory over the Kansas City Royals tonight.

title: Nixons Potential Witnesses For Hearing on Tax Lawyer
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 22 (UPI)Secretary of State Edmund G. Brown Jr. has is sued a list of potential witnesses, headed by President Nixon and his wife, for a June 17 hearing into charges against a Nixon tax attorney.

title: LEGAL
description: NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN by Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., that on April 15, 1974 it issued and filed with the Public Service Commission amendments to its electric rate schedule, PSC No. 8  Electricity, gas rate schedule, PSC No, 8  Gas and steam rate schedule, PSC No. 3 Steam applicable to its customers within the City of New York and the County of Westchester to become effective on and as of May 16, 1974.

title: Advertising: Selling Enquirer
description: The introduction of the garish new National Star has not impeded the circulation growth of The National Enquirer, according to The Enquirer.

title: 2 ParochialAid Bills Offered
description: TRENTON, April 22 (AP) Two Byrne administration bills that would provide $4.5million in textbook and busing aid to private and parochial schools were introduced in the Assembly today. The measures are intended to fulfill Governor Byrne's pledge to provide help for parochial schools within constitutional limits that require separation of church and state. The bills would chiefly aid Roman Catholic schools.

title: LIQUIFIN BID UPHELD FOR RONSON SHARES
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit unanimously affirmed yesterday a District Court order in January permitting Liquifin, A.G., to proceed with its restated offer to purchase up to 2,288,000 shares of common stock of the Ronson Corporation at $8.18 a share.

title: How the Teams Stand Today
description: Tuesday, April 23, 1974

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LARAMIE, Wyo., April 22 (UPI)About 10 white track athletes from the University of Wyoming threatened quit the team today because they were expelled from meeting with the athletic director and track coach where charges of false recruiting promises were discussed. The gathering began with most of the 20man team in attendance, but after about 25 minutes, the spokesman for the blacks, Lester Johnson, asked the whites to leave, sources said.

title: Most Active Stocks
description: Monday, April 22, 1974

title: N.B.A. Playoffs
description: Knicks vs. Boston

title: Gagliardi Keeps Firm Control of His Court
description: When the defense in the conspiracy trial of John N. Mitchell and Maurice H. Stans objected to a fleeting remark by a prosecutor a few weeks ago, Federal. Judge Lee P. Gagliardi intervened quickly.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Anna Doerschuk, 94, Dies; Sarah Lawrence Director
description: Anna Beatrice Doerschuk, director of education at Sarah Lawrence College from its opening in 1928 to her retirement in 1946, died Thursday at a nursing home in New Wilmington, Pa. She was 94 years old.

title: Japan and Soviet Plan Siberian Loan
description: TOKYO, April 22  Japan agreed tentatively today to lend the Soviet Union $1billion at relatively low interest to finance three projects involving the development of coal, gas and forestry resources in Siberia.

title: TeaParty Observances Mako a Splash Here
description: New York City, which spent most of the American. Revolution in the hands of the Rising side and had a large Tory minority to boot, recalled yesterday an early moment of patriotic glory.

title: LIMITS ON TENURE LIFTED AT CITY U.
description: The Board of Higher Education yesterday rescinded the City University's controversial policy of restraining the granting of tenure, a policy that was put in effect last fall by the previous board.

title: Newspaper Talks and Slowdown at News Continue
description: Toplevel negotiators grappled with the critical automation issue in the city's news paper dispute yesterday, but the president of Typographical Union No. 6, Bertram A. Powers, said that the union would continue to put pressure on The Daily News through a slowdown.

title: Women Add Net Prize Of $32,000
description: Mrs. Billie Jean King, the driving force behind women's professional tennis, said yesterday she planned to continue competing until she was no longer at the top.

title: Federal, State and City Investigations Seek to Pinpoint Cause of Explosion
description: Just after 7 A.M. yesterday, a maintenance man named Richard Swanson headed for his job with a printingplate company inthe brown brick building at 305 East 45th Street.

title: 2 Lifers Caught Digging Tunnel In Attempt to Escape at Trenton
description: TRENTON, April 22  Two convicted murderers attempted to tunnel their way out of Trenton State Prison early today, but were discovered by prison guards in a hole they had dug underneath the prison hospital

title: TOWNSHIP TO EVICT DISEASED HORSES
description: SOMERVILLE, April 22 (UPI) A Superior Court judge ordered today a herd of diseased horses, previously housed on the estate of Doris Duke, the tobacco heiress, removed from la Hillsborough Township farm by May 1. The ruling, issued by Judge Wilfred P. Diana, is an offshoot of a $10million suit filed on behalf of Somerset County horse owners against the Animal Medical Center, which previously was on the Duke estate here.

title: PANEL OVERTURNS TACONITE CLOSING
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mo., April 22 (UPI)A threejudge panel of the United States Court of Appals for the Eighth Circuit issued a temporary order tonight allowing the reopening of a Silver Bay, Minn., taconite facility that was ordered closed to half its alleged polluting of Lake Superior.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Most of the 56 residents who escaped from a stateoperated drugrehabilitation center on Staten Island Sunday night were back in the lightsecurity institution yesterday, many having been seized by the police and some having drifted back on their own. Last night, authorities said only 14 remained at large from the institution, the Arthur Kill Community Rehabilitation Center at 2911 Arthur Kill Road in Rossville.

title: Newspaper Recycling Boroughwide on S.I.
description: The Sanitation Department's only boroughwide newspaper recycling program came into being yesterday when the collection of newspapers, begun in 1971, was expanded to cover all of Staten Island.

title: CAMBODIAN TROOPS MISSING IN A CLASH
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, April 22 (AP)Military sources said today that more than 700 Government soldiers were missing after withdrawing from river beachhead 23 miles north of Phnom Penh under a withering rebel assault.

title: Libby, McNeill in Pact
description: Libby, McNeill & Libby of Chicago, has reached an initial agreement with Orchard Hill Farms, Inc., of Red Hook, N.Y., to manufacture and market the former's Libbyland line of frozen children's dinners. The final agreement is being negotiated. No Libby plant facilities are involved.

title: Ore Plant Wins Stay
description: The Reserve Mining Company won a ruling last night from a threejudge panel of the Eighth United States Circuit Court allowing it to reopen the Silver Bay, Minn ore plant that had been ordered closed to halt the polluting of Lake Superior. Pending arguments May 15, the judges granted a stay of the lower court order to shut the plant, Details on Page 55.

title: Penn Relays Spotlight on Mile Field
description: Thirteen subfourminute miles have been run at Franklin Field in Philadelphia. If a 14th is not achieved Saturday, it may be the biggest surprise of the 80th annual Penn Relays.

title: 3M Quarter Net at Peak
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company continued to show recordbreaking quarterly results with the net income of $71.9million, or 64 cents a share, up 10.3 per cent from the strong first quarter of 1973, the company reported yesterday. The gain was somewhat less than the 15 per cent increase realized in the final quarter last year.

title: Wood, Field & Stream New Breed Fisherman
description: There were times in the past 12 months when this writer was bewildered by the proliferation of regional and national organizations devoted to the betterment of either marine or inland fish, One had the feeling that anglers would ber hard put to decide which group to support.

title: Mound Woes Pull Down Mets As They Enter Western Lairs
description: Even for a team that has seen much trouble, the New York Mets were surrounded by woe last night as they flew to San Diego with eight defeats in their last nine games and their pitching in disarray.

title: Avon Earnings Slide 13%; Minnesota Mining Gains
description: Avon Products, Inc., which has compiled a strong growth record over the years through its dominant position in the doortodoor selling of cosmetics and toiletries, reported a 13 per cent decline in March quarter earningsits first decline in more than a decade.

title: Merger Is Completed
description: The merger of Le Gran Corporation into a whollyowned subsidiary of Lucky Stores, Inc., has been completed, it was announced yesterday. Under the plan, the shareholders of Le Gran are entitled to receive eighttenths of a Lucky common share for each Le Gran share and will shortly receive instructions on exchange procedures. The announcement was made by William H. Dyer Jr., chairman of, the board of Lucky Stores, Inc., and David Grand, president of Le Gran.

title: Booty From Bank Is Net Loss
description: MARIETTA, Ga., April 22 (UPI)Three burglars who tunneled 127 feet under Marietta's main street and blasted a hole in the safety deposit room of a bank over the weekend got away with less than $1,000not enough to cover their expenses, the police said today. The burglars had rented office space across the street for $1,000, and the police estimated that it took six to eight weeks to dig the tunnel. The theft occurred at the Cobb Exchange Bank.

title: MRS. GRAHAM GETS A.P. BOARD POSITION
description: Katharine Graham, publisher of The Washington Post, yesterday became the first woman to he elected to the 18member board of The Associated Press.

title: Washington Wins Regatta
description: CORVAILIS, Ore., April 22 (UPI)Washington won the 11th threeday annual Corvallis invitation regatta yesterday despite a surprise loss to Oregon State by its varsity heavyweight crew in 6 minutes fivetenths of a second on the 2,000meter course on the Williamette River. Washington finished with 299 points.

title: Dave Anderson
description: During the recent Masters tournament, Lee Elder was in the Bahamas for a golf exhibition.

title: MACKELL DRAWS 6 MONTHS IN JAIL
description: Thomas J. Mackell, the former Queens District Attorney, was sentenced to six months hi prison yesterday for blocking the prosecution of a confidence racket in which members of his office had invested money.

title: The Theater: Bloomers
description: Brilliant is the only word for Bloomers, a flawless revival of Carl Sternheim's 1911 comedy reflecting the vacuum of middleclass German mentality with lethal precision and hilarity. In Roger Hendricks Simon's staging of his adaptation, British success in 1970, and in the response of his sixmember cast, the Equity Library Theater, at Riverside Drive and 103d Street (6632028), has itself a piece of theater art.

title: Strauss Warns Meeting of Democratic Governors to Stop Calling for Nixon's Resignation
description: CHICAGO, April 22Robert S. Strauss, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, urged Democratic Governors today to stop calling for President Nixon's resignation.

title: Clear Copy, 2d Choice, Wins by Nose at Big A
description: Leon Hekirnian's Clear Copy, the capable filly who only got to the races last November, beat lots of more experienced campaigners at Aqueduct yesterday in Capturing the $29,575 Prioress Stakes in a squeaker.

title: Nationalized Rails Possible, Head of Illinois Line Says
description: MEMPHIS, April 22 (AP) The president of the Illinois Central Gulf Railroad said today that he expected railway nationalization unless the country's publictransport policies were changed.

title: Layer Defies Pressure, Kerry Melville Folds
description: Pressure, that constraining element, showed up in tennis over the weekend, spelling the difference between victory and defeat. Rod Laver fought it off, Bjorn Borg could not and the result was that the 35yearold Australian captured his third straight tournament on the World Championship Tennis tour at Houston. This assured him of a berth in the $100,000 W.C.T. finals next month.

title: ALLOUT ASSAULT BY SYRIA DOUBTED
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, April 21 While Sovietmade armor and missiles have continued to arrive to bolster the defenses of Damascus, Western military observers say they see no evidence that Syria is concentrat ing forces for a fullscale attack against Israeli positions on the Golan Heights front.

title: TimeLoan Tardiness Up
description: Delinquencies on installment loans, reflecting high inflation and unemployment, hit a new high during January and February, the American Bankers Association reported yesterday.

title: CLOSER LINKS SET BY BONN AND CAIRO
description: CAIRO, April 22Egypt and West Germany agreed today to set up a joint cabinetlevel commission to deal with political, economic and cultural matters.

title: Antipollution Bill Stalls In Assembly on Changes
description: TRENTON, April 22A controversial bill that would give individuals the right to sue environmental polluters stalled in the State Legislature today when threatened with changes that the measure's sponsor said would do grave violence to its purpose.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: No Way Out
description: WASHINGTON, April 22If impeachment were solely a matter of politics, President Nixon might well be able to work his way out of the many difficulties now closing in on him. But the question of his impeachment is inextricably entangled with the neutral and inexorable processes of the legal system.

title: Peterson Bothered by Status As Forgotten Man of Yanks
description: Weary from Earl Weaver's pestiferous protests, the Yankees enjoyed a welldeserved day off yesterday. One of the players who rested could have chosen the occasion to launch his own protest, but somewhat surprisingly, he declined.

title: The Mood on Campus
description: During the fall of 1972 an article appeared on this page, written by a high school senior, discussing the trials and tribulations of the collegeadmissions process from the applicant's perspective.

title: AirTight Buildings Deplored
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) Legislation to require that all Federally financed buildings be constructed with windows that can be opened was introduced today by Senator Clai borne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island. Increasingly, we in the United States have been shutting ourselves into these airtight, airconditioned, tomblike buildings that use up and waste immense amounts of energy, Mr. Pell said.

title: PRICES OFF AGAIN ON AMEX AND OTC
Jumpers Author Is Verbal Gymnast
description: A conversation with Tom Stoppard, in common with his play Jumpers (which opened last night at the Billy Rose Theater), is headyfull of verbal acrobatics and intellectual cartwheels.

title: Office Tower Blast Near U. N. Injures 70
description: A powerful explosion rippec through a 24story office building near the United Nations early yesterday, injuring 70 people, three critically, and leaving hundreds of residents of a neighboring apartment build. ing temporarily homeless.

title: Israeli Labor Patty Picks Rabin for Mrs. Meir's Post
description: TEL. AVIV, April 22Itzhak Rabin, the commander of Israel's armies in the 1967 war, tonight won the Labor party's nomination to succeed Premier Golda Meir.

title: PETER CARY
description: Peter Cary, a former assodate editor of. Reader's Digest magazine who later taught at the Famous Writers School in Westport, Conn., died of cancer yesterday in Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital.. He was 62 years old and lived at 209 Whipstick Road, Wilton, Conn.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Ford, in Speech to A.P. Meeting, Opposes Tax Cut and Asks Selected WagePrice Curbs
description: Vice President Ford opposed yesterday a quickie, quickfix tax cut, and said the proposal, urged by leading Democrats in Congress, would add to the fuel of inflation.

title: Penn Central Fills Post
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 22 (UPI)Norman J. Hull, Jr., has been named a vice president and controller of the Penn Central Railroad. The railroad said Mr. Hull would continue to act as controller of railroad operations, but his duties will be expanded to include accounting and financial assistance and advice to the line's trustees on matters pertaining to reorganization.

title: Cohn Considering Running for, D.A. On 2 Party Tickets
description: Roy M. Cohn, the lawyer, said yesterday that he was considering becoming a candidate for Manhattan District Attorney.

title: RETAILERS DISCUSS REVISED SALE TERNS
description: The McCrory Corporation and Interstate Stores, Inc., are discussing revised terms involving the previouslyannounced sale of certain McCrory store groups to an Interstate subsidiary, which have ruled out the inclusion of the S. Klein Department Stores.

title: Trenton Votes to Repeal Port Authority Bond Curb
description: TRENTON, April 22  A measure repealing a 12yearold bond covenant that prevents the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey from undertaking any masstransportation projects that could lose money cleared the New Jersey Legislature easily today.

title: Reform Regression
description: In a time of increasing cynicism about government, it is vital that steps be taken to restore the people's confidence in government. That brave statement by Governor Wilson accompanied release last week of his longawaited recommendations for election reforms.

title: ROCKWELL C. TENNEY OF INVESTMENT FIRM
description: Rockwell C. Tenney, a member of the New York Stock Exchange since 1932 and founder of a publicutilities investment concern, died Sunday in Boston. He was 79 years old and lived also in Hyannis. Port, Mass. and on Grand Cayman Island, West Indies.

title: City Opera Guild Holds 30th Anniversary Party
description: Martha Lipton and Cantor Gauld sent their regrets, she from Indiana University, he from a village in France Arlene Saunders, rehearsing in Boston, telephoned to say that she would drink a silent toast. Irra Petina and Claramae Turner greeted each other with a hearty kiss, and so did Brenda Lewis and Sidor Beiersky and many others who were able to attend the reunion. At the end Julius Rudel said, One or the other of you may have given me a bit of heartburn, but collectively you're the greatest.

title: Treasury Bills Off At the Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 Rates on Treasury bills declined to the lowest levels in a little more than a month at today's auction of these shortterm Government securities.

title: New Niger Junta to Investigate Former Leaders
description: NIAMEY, Niger, April 22Lieut. Col. Seyni Kountche, chief of state of Niger's weekold military government, announced today the formation of a commission to investigate what he described as the illegal activities of former government leaders.

title: Production of Steel Showed 0.3% Drop During Last Week
description: Steel production for the week ended April 20 dipped 0.3 per cent to 2,895,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This compared with the 2,904,000 tons poured in the preceding week. The steel production index slipped to 118.7 from 119 in the week ended April 13.

title: Dooley Reappointed
description: Edwin B. Dooley has been reappointed chairman of the State Athletic Commission for a term ending Jan. 1, 1977. Governor Wilson announced tonight.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: WILLCOX & GIBBS Net Income was 82,111.000 in 19073up 34% (WGAMEX) Advt.

title: SILBERT DEFENDS ACTION IN INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 Earl J. Silbert, the original prosecutor in the Watergate case, defended his investigation today and said that he was very proud of his accomplishments.

title: CARUSE TAX NEID LIKELY THIS YEAR
description: The autouse taxthe focal point for such ferocious protest when the city imposed it a generation ago that it eventually was dropped  was depicted yesterday as a serious likelihood this year.

title: HUNT IS SAID TO OWN $100,000 IN STOCKS
description: LOS ANGELES, April 23 (UPI)While E. Howard Hunt Jr., a Watergate conspirator, was allegedly demanding hush money from the White House and portraying himself to the Senate Watergate committee as destitute, he had more than $100,000 in a stock fund of unclear origins, The Los Angeles Times said today.

title: Old Refrain Paces Filion To 700 Goal
description: Using a helicopter to meet his schedule, Herve Filion has made Cole Porter's Night and Day his harnessracing theme song.

title: President Franz Jonas of Austria Dies
description: VIENNA, April 23 (UPI)President Franz Jonas died early today in a hospital, the presidential office said. His age was 74.

title: Con Ed, Hit by Fuel Costs, Omits Quarterly Dividend
description: The Consolidated Edison Company, plagued by soaring fuel costs and the effects of energy conservation by consumers, yesterday suspended payment of its quarterly dividend, something the company had never previously done since it started paying them in 1885.

title: ARCHDIOCESE URGES A FOCUS ON PRISONS
description: NEWARK, April 24 (UPI) The Archdiocese of Newark urged today that citizens visit prisons, courts and police stations and see how unsatisfactory the criminal justice system in New Jersey is.

title: Durante Is Honored At Banshee Luncheon
description: Jimmy Durante, 81 years old, ailing and in a wheel chair stirred 1,600 newspaper executives and guests into repeated standing ovations yesterday at the annual luncheonshow of the Banshees at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

title: Cranston Says V.A. Employes Were Solicited for Nixon Gifts
description: WASHINGTON, April 23Senator Alan Cranston charged today that employes of the Veterans Administration were encouraged two years ago by their superiors to contribute money to President Nixon's reelection campaign.

title: COMMON MARKET OFFERS GOLD PLAN
description: ZEIST, the Netherlands, April 23  The European Economic Community has a new plan for the use of gold again in the settlement of international accounts and is sending a delegation to Washington to try to win the approval of the United States.

title: Newspapers Too Monolithic As Industry, Editor Asserts
description: A Detroit editor declares here yesterday that the country's newspapers are in trouble, do have a credibility probtern, are being attacked, and asserted that one reason is that we are becoming too monolithic as an industry.

title: U.S. Ambassador in Saigon Returning for Consultation
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP)  The State Department reversed itself today by ordering Graham A. Martin, the outspoken Ambassador to South Vietnam to return this spring for consultations and likely appearances before Congressional committees on United States aid commitments.

title: Wilson Urges Shifts in Levies on Insurers and Ending City's Tax on Premiums
description: ALBANY, April 23Governor Wilson and the legislative leadership proposed today to remove New York City's right to tax insurance premiums, a tax that has yielded the city up to $15million a year, and to double by 1977 the state income tax on insurance companies.

title: Homer Wise, G.I. Who Won Medal of How, Dies at 57
description: Homer L. Wise, a retired Army first sergeant who won the Medal of Honor in World War II, died yesterday in YaleNew Haven Hospital. He was 57 years old and lived at 23 Tree Lane in Stamford, Conn.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Judge Upholds Curb on Teacher

title: ERVIN UNIT TO GET REBOZO TAX DATA
description: WASHINGTON, April 23They Internal Revenue Service, in an abrupt reversal, has agreed to provide the Senate Watergate committee with politically sensitive tax returns and other materials from the personal files of F. Donald Nixon, and Charles G. Rebozo, wellplaced sources said today.

title: HOUSE PANEL VOTES OIL PRICE ROLLBACK
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP)  The House Commerce Committee voted today to roll back the price of roughly 80 per cent of the crude oil produced in the United States. At the same time, the committee adopted an amendment that would impose a system of stiffer price controls on imported oil.

title: Ambassader to Sweden Backed by Senate Unit
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (UPI) The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today approved six diplomatic appointments, inScludivg that of the first ambasador to Sweden in a year and a half.

title: Impeaching At Turtle Bay
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 23There is a kind of impeachment trial going on here at the United Nations zoonot of a man but of a civilization. The poor nations are drawing up the articles of impeachment every day against the rich nations. Please listen, they say:

title: FRANCIS C. LOAN
description: Francis C. Loan, a retired tax specialist for the Standard Oil Company (Nevi Jersey), died of a heart attack Monday at his home at Bournedale, Cape Cod, Mass. He was 71 years old and had lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Decisive Phase Starts
description: GENEVA, April 23The conference on European security entered a decisive phase today with the resumption of negotiations following the Easter recess.

title: Plan to Speed Construction Of Tocks I. Dam Is Debated
description: TRENTON, April 23Scores of opponents of the controversial Tocks Island Dam expreised indignation today at a proposal to move construction of the $360million dam a step closer.

title: Old Refrain Paces Filion To 700 Goal
description: Using a helicopter to meet his schedule, Herve Filion has made Cole Porter's Night and Day his harnessracing theme song.

title: Japanese Long in Jungle in Fine Health
description: TOKYO, April 23  Thirty years of primitive living in a mountainous Philippine jungle may have made former Lieut. Hiroo Onoda one of the healthiest 52yearold men in Japan today.

title: Oil Concerns' Profits Up
description: Exxon and Texaco reported earnings increases of 39 and 123 per cent, respectively, for the first quarter of this year. Details on Page 53.

title: BETTY COMPSON, 77, FILM STAR, IS DEAD
description: Betty Compson, the blond star of more than 100 silent films and early talkies, died Thursday in Glendale, Calif. The actress, who attained fame as Rose in The Miracle Man, the film that also catapulted Lon Chaney into stardom, was 77 years old.

title: A New U.S. Policy on Cuba Is Asked by Senate Group
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (Reuters)The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today called for a new United StatesCuba policy that could lead toward recognition of Premier Fidel Castro's Government.

title: AFTERCARE URGED FOR MENTALLY ILL
description: Dr. June J. Christmas, the city's Commissioner of Mental Health and Retardation, called on the gate yesterday to convert the large empty areas of Its mental hospitals into halfway houses for the chronically mentally ill as an immediate crisis measure.

title: Governor Wilson, Negotiating Quietly in the Wings, Determines Tempo for Legislature
description: ALBANY, April 23Governor Wilson is orchestrating the Legislature's finale, and thus far there has been the sound of silence. Accordingly, the legislators seem to be tapping their feet more out of nervousness than rhythm. I've been here 27 years and by far this is the dullest session yet, said Senator Joseph Zaretzki, leader of the Democratic minority.

title: Market Is Buffeted By Rise in Interest
description: The stock market, buffeted by continued increases in interest rates, tumbled across broad front yesterday as prices fell on increased trading.

title: ERVIN UNIT TO GET REBOZO TAX DATA
description: WASHINGTON, April 23The Internal Revenue Service, in an abrupt reversal, has agreed to provide the Senate Watergate committee with politically sensitive tax returns and other materials from the personal files of F. Donald Nixon, and Charles G. Rebozo, wellplaced sources said today.

title: SIAM IS TERMED HONORABLE MAN
description: With sarcasm and solemnity, evangelistic fervor and laughter, the lawyer for Maurice H. Stans summed up his defense yesterday in an oration to the jury that lasted nearly five hours.

title: SovietMade Tractors Introduced Upstate
description: CANANDAIGUA, N. Y. Abstract talk about EastWest trade and detente is taking on substance and reality here in Ontario County, an upstate dairyfarming community, southeast of Rochester where the first Sovietmade tractors in the United States are trying their nettle on the stillwet fields.

title: The Other News
description: International

title: MRS. NANCY STERN
description: Mrs. Nancy Pribourg Stern, widow of Louis Stern, who was a member of The New York Times delivery staff, died yesterday at her home, 20 Dock Lane, Wantagh, L.I. She was 74 years old.

title: Potential for Disaster
description: The explosion that ripped through an East Side office building offers a terrifying demonstration of the potential for disaster that lurks in the city's network of natural gas pipes that reaches into innumerable business structures and apartment houses.

title: Dollar Declines Sharply
description: LONDON, April 23 (UPI)A flood of dollar selling in New York and Europe sent the American currency sliding to a new low for the year in Frankfurt today and into sharp decline in London and Paris.

title: ANSWER TO PREVIOUS PUZZLE
TV Review
description: Joseph Papp, New York's most active theater producer, returns to television at 9 o'clock tonight, with Wedding Band, the. Mice Childress play that was produced at Mr. Papp's Public Theater. This time, after a furor over Sticks and Bones at the Columbia Broadcasting System, Mr. Papp is allied with the American Broadcasting Company. Not surprisingly, the production offers some refreshingly provocative theater.

title: Friends Say Ford Denies He Undercuts President
description: WASHINGTON, April 23Vice President Ford has contided to acquaintances in recent weeks that he is perplexed by what he senses to be the feeling of some White House aides that he is attempting to undercut President Nixon.

title: High Court Avoids Ruling On Quota for Law School
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 The Supreme Court, dividing 5 to 4, refused today to decide whether professional schools can constitutionally give preference in admissions to members of racial minorities at the expense of white applicants.

title: On Christian Unity Under the Pope
description: READING, Pa.  A casual drive through any United States city or town shows an impressive number of church buildings. Each church stands proudly as it displays its name and its denominational ties for all to see. It is a source of wonder that churchgoers see such a wide difference in theology that each congregation Is willing to make sacrifices to support the church of its choice.

title: RHINO EXPECTS TO EASE DEADLINE ON NIXON'S TAPES
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 President Nixon apparently won today five more days to respond to a House Judiciary Committee subpoena for tape recordings of 42 Watergaterelated conversations.

title: FertilizerOr Famine
description: When a practical solution appears possible for any aspect of the critical energy and food shortages now threatening the world, it should be executed as a matter of urgency. It happens rarely enough.

title: Political Funds in Spotlight at Gulf Meeting
description: PITTSBURGH, April 23Political contributions, women's rights and corporate profits held the attention of a record 1,400 shareholders who attended the annual meeting of the Gulf Oil Corporation today in the ornate Carnegie Music Hall.

title: ASSEMBLY BACKS SOME EXECUTIONS
description: ALBANY, April 23After more than six hours of debate, the Assembly voted early this evening to reimpose a mandated death penalty in the state for the willful murder of a peace officer during the performance of his duties or of an employe of a local or state correctional institution.

title: Restaurant Campaign Puts Accent on Service
description: The National Restaurant Association, with the help of a public relations firm, has created a program to rekindle enthusiasm for an oldfashioned conceptpride in service. Lotsa luck!

title: Woman OddsOn Favorite For Connecticut Governor
description: STORRS, Conn.  Politics is played quietly in the Land of Steady Habits. Without the trombones, as it were.

title: Con Ed, Hit by Fuel Costs, Omits Quarterly Dividend
description: The Consolidated Edison Company, plagued by soaring fuel costs and the effects of energy conservation by consumers, yesterday suspended payment of its quarterly dividend, something the company had never previously done since it started paying them in 1885.

title: S.A. MITCHELL, 77, PARTY CHAIRMAN
description: TAOS, N. M., April 23 (UPI)Stephen A. Mitchell, who was the Democratic National Chairman in the early nineteenfifties, died today in Holy Cross Hospital. He was 71 years old.

title: Love Affair in Egypt
description: CAIROAmerican Secretaries of State have always had astonishing repercussions in Egyptian politics since the Nasserist revolution took power in 1952. A strong Secretary, John Foster Dulles, frustrated the proAmerican sympathies of Nasser himself, refusing to procure him even modest amounts of arms, reneging on a promise to help build his high Nile dam and finally shoving himwith some bewildermentinto Russia's arms.

title: POTATO FUTURES FALL LIMIT AGAIN
