description: Potato futures for May delivery dropped the daily limit on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday for the fifth consecutive session. The close was 15.50 cents a pound, down the 50point limit from 16 cents a pound Monday.

title: Alexandre Dumaine, a Master Chef for 30 Years, Is Dead at 78
description: SAULIEU, France, April 23 (Reuters)Alexandre Dumaine, one of France's most renowned chefs, has died, it was announced today. He was 78 years old.

title: Mets Lose, 102
description: SAN DIEGO, April 23The reeling New York Mets brought their troubles to California tonight looking for a change of venue, but all they got was a 102 pasting from the San Diego Padres for their ninth loss in the last 10 games.

title: DeFunis NonDecision
description: In declining to rule whether the University of Washington was in violation of the Constitution when it turned down a white applicant while admitting black candidates with lower test scores, the Supreme Court appears at first glance to have merely run away from an emotionladen issue. Indeed, the four dissenting justices stated that the Court's failure to meet the controversy headon clearly disserves the public interest.

title: Business Briefs
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., Inc., announced yesterday that its French subsidiary and Societe des Usines Chemiques RhonePoulenc would jointly build and operate a plant for the manufacture in France of adiponitrile, a raw material for the manufacture of nylon.

title: STATE DEPARTMENT CRITICIZES JACKSON
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (Reuters) The State Department today criticized Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, for suggesting that the Nixon Administration was seeking a quick strategic arms agreement with the Soviet Union to improve President Nixon's political fortunes.

title: POLICE FIND BODY OF MISSING GIRL, 4
description: A 4yearold girl whose disappearance in South Jersey set off a widespread hunt two weeks ago was found dead last night in a tidal backwater about 15 miles from her home.

title: An Imported Suit Becomes A Labor Issue for Samuels
description: A $29 imported suit was disclosed yesterday to be a bone of contention between labor leaders and Howard J. Samuels, the Democratic aspirant for Governor who, during four gubernatorial campaigns, has been dogged by suspicions and charges that fie is antilabor.

title: Kunitz Gets Library of Congress Post
description: WASHINGTON, April 23Stanley Kunitz, Pulitzer Prizewinning poet, teacher, translator, critic and editor, has been named the new consultant in poetry to the Library of Congress, L. Quincy Mumford, the Librarian of Congress, announced today.

title: British Football
description: By Reuters

title: Eastern Air Sets Profit; Burlington Industries Up
description: Eastern Airlines, one of the most financially troubled of the nation's domestic airlines, reported yesterday it had a $5.4million net profit last month, its first profitable month since last August. In March of last year, Eastern had a profit of $1.1million. It was the first month of yearoveryear profit improvement reported since September, 1972.

title: Advertising: N.A.B. Facelifting
description: The Newspaper Advertising Bureau, already the largest and most sophisticated media advertising organization, is dramatically increasing its annual budget to support a reorganization needed to meet today's changing marketplace and to take advantage of the growth potential in these troubled times.

title: MAURICE REYMOND OF HILTON HOTELS
description: Maurice Reymond, a vice president of Hilton International, was among the victims of Monday's crash of a Pan American airliner on the Indonesian island of Bali. He was 47 years old and lived at 1 Grade Terrace.

title: Sawhill Forecasts A Wider U.S. Role In Securing of Oil
description: John C. Sawhill, the newt head of the Federal Energy Office, said here yesterday that he expected the Government to play a more active role in securing oil supplies.

title: Issues in Papers Dispute
description: PARTICIPANTS: The New York Times, The Daily News and The New York Post, negotiating as the Publishers Association of New York City, and New York Typographical Union No. 6, representing 819 printers, including 170 substitutes, at The Times; 945 printers, including 200 to 220 substitutes, at The News; and 312 printers, including 38 substitutes, at The Post.

title: COURT LIMITS F.B.I. ON CRIMINAL PILES
description: WASHINGTON, April 23The Federal Bureau of Investigation must expunge a person's arrest record from its criminal files if the arrested person was exonerated and released without charges, a Federal court of appeals ruled here today.

title: Books of The Times
description: FISHING WIDOWS. By Nick Lyons. 154 pages. Crown. $5.95.

title: Fashions Were Part Of a Colorful Show People Were the Rest
description: It was certainly not one of your runofthemill fashion shows. The models posed in tableaux, like living statues, or drifted dreamily around the stage in clouds of smoke. But that's not what set the evening apart. It was the audience.

title: State Plans to Delay Tougher Standards For Auto Emissions
description: TRENTON, April 23 (AP)The state announced today that it planned to delay for seven months, until Feb. 1, the institution of tougher standards for the mandatory state test of auto emissions.

title: Bird Bill Totals $2,000
description: FREDERICK, Md., April 23 (UPI)  County commissioners agreed yesterday to pay a 2,000 billthe cost of scaring off millions of birds from their roosting place near the tiny vilage on Graceham. After the birds finally left, the commissioners were upset because the state Health Department had run up the $2,000 bill without their prior authorization. But they agreed yesterday that the restoration of serenity in Graceham was worth the cost.

title: People in Sports
description: Ben Bluitt, a University of Detroit assistant coach, was named head basketball coach at Cornell University yesterday. Bluitt, 49 years old, becomes the first black head mentor in the Big Red's 110yearold athletic history and the second in the Ivy League. Tom Sanders was named head basketball coach at Harvard last season.

title: Troubled Brittany Expects Little Help From Paris
description: LORIENT, France, April 20  The rocky coastline of the Brittany peninsula, jutting into the Atlantic to the westernmost point of France, encloses some of the most serious problems of France.But even with a presidential election only two weeks away, little seems to ruffle Brittany's pastoral surface. Except for posters bearing the portrait of Jacques ChabanDelmas, the Gaullist candidate, a clash of contenders and issues is not a visible reality.

title: Callaway Found Guilty In Slaying of Shabazz
description: NEWARK, April 23A jury of eight men and four women tonight returned a verdict of guilty of murder in the first degree against Lamont Callaway, who was accused of assassinating James McGregor Shabazz, a Black Muslim minister.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: POETRY The 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A., at 1395 Lexington Avenue (4276000, ext. 720), is a place where poets have always been king. Tonight at 7:30 and next Wednesday, special tribute will be paid to poets who have passed through the Y in years past and were close to its Poetry Center. These particular poets are wellknown and wellremembered.

title: Earnings of Exxon and Texaco Climb Sharply
DeathPenalty RollCall
Sports News Briefs
description: W.F.L. Looks for a Jet or Giant

title: The PresidentElect of Colombia
description: With his thinning gray hair, hornrimmed spectacles and subdued dress, Alfonso Lopez Michelsen, the Presidentelect of Colombia, gives the impression of a British clubman. The im pression is enhanced by an air of ironly and detachment that was in evidence yes terday when the 60yearold law professor and former foreign minister held his first news conference since his overwhelming victory in the elections on Sunday.

title: Gregg Travels a Cautious Road, Bypassing the Monster Circuit
description: ATLANTA, April 23Jennifer Gregg is preparing an essay on Dracula and Frankenstein as a projection of man's fears. She could have used the monsters of auto racing more easily for her NorthFlorida University course. She certainly wouldn't have had to do any research. The 30yearold mother of two children is married to Peter Gregg, whose own fears, and those of his wife, have limited his racing career. I like sunsets too much and walking down the ChampsElyses to want to kill myself, said Gregg last weekend at Road Atlanta, where he competed in the Six Hours of Atlanta.

title: Mrs. King Tops Young Australian
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 23 Mrs. Billie Jean King defeated 17yearold Diane Fromholtz of Australia, 64, 63, tonight to advance to the second round of the $50,000 Virginia Slims tennis tournament at the Palestra.

title: Scientists Criticize A.E.C. Assessment Of Reactor Hazard
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  The scientists' Institute for Public Information condemned today as frivolous and shallow the Atomic Energy Commission's draft assessment of the environmental hazards of the breederreactor development program.

title: TIMES PROFIT UP 20% FOR QUARTER
description: The New York Times Company reported yesterday consolidated net income for the quarter ended March 31 of $4.8million, or 43 cents a share, up 20 per cent from the same quarter last year.

title: Bid by Italians
description: A group of Italian industrial, banking and insurance interestsknown as Capitalfin International, Ltd.has agreed to purchase not less than 8.2 per cent of the capital stock of Signal Companies. Details on Page 59.

title: Patterson Wins Penn Marathon
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 23  Dave Patterson, a gradnate student at West Chester (Pa.) State College who had never run more than nine miles won the 26mile marathon race today to open the 80th annual Penn Relays.

title: MARUBENI TO SELL U.S. FURS IN JAPAN
description: The Marubeni Corporation, a major Japanese trading concern, has concluded an agreement to warehouse and act as a wholesale distributor for American furs in Japan.

title: Market Places Con Ed Move's Repercussions
description: The individual investor who has always believed that even in a bear market utility stocks provided a relatively safe haven got a rude jolt yesterday in the wake of Con Edison's omission of its 45cent quarterly dividend.

title: Blast Caused by Gas
description: Gas rushing from a main torn open by a highpressure water jet was pinpointed by the Fire Department yesterday as the cause of Monday's officetower explosion near the United Nations. An insuranceindustry source put the damage at $10million or more. Details on Page 46.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Music: A Quiet Requiem
description: It was only a few weeks ago that Leon Barzin arid the National Orchestral Association presented the Dvorak Requiem in Carnegie Hall. Monday night it turned up again, this time in Avery Fisher Hall, as conducted by Eugene Ormandy. He was, of course, in charge of the philadelphia Orchestra. So now the seldom played Requiem by the Bohemian master has had two concertWall hearings in New York this season.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 45

title: Machinists Reject Contract
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 23 (UPI) (UPI)A union spokesman said yesterday that employes represented by the International Association of Machinists voted 86 per cent last week against a contract offered by United Airlines. The company has offered raises of $1 an hour over a 28month period.

title: Gas From a Main Split by Water Jet Blamed for OfficeTower Explosion
description: Gas rushing from a main torn open by a highpressure water jet was pinpointed yesterday as the cause of Monday's officetower explosion near the United Nations.

title: Graham Rebellion Still Lures Young
description: In the latte?? ??alt of the nineteensixties, there were murmurings among the young in the dance world that Martha Graham was no longer relevant to their concerns.

title: Wide Farm Protests In Italy Ask Reforms And Pay Increases
description: ROME, April 23Farmhands throughout Italy stayed away from work and participated in demonstrations today in a 24hour strike for higher pay.

title: High Court Avoids Riding On Quota for Law School
description: WASHINGTON, April 23The Supreme Court, dividing 5 to 4, refused today to decide whether professional schools can constitutionally give preference in admissions to members of racial minorities at the expense of white applicants.

title: The Americans In Jet Crash
description: Following, as made public by Pan American World Airways, are the names of the Americans among the crew and passengers of the airliner that crashed on Bali:

title: AN ATTEMPT TO KILL SADAT IS REPORTED
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 13 An article today in Al Anwar, a Lebanese newspaper known for close ties with Egypt, said that President Anwar el Sadat es caped an assassination attempt last week in Cairo.

title: Bridge: Politics Makes Strange ...., But What About Tablemates?
description: Political leaders are often bridge players when time permits. President Dwight D. Eisenhower was competent and enthusiastic, while Sophocles Venizelos, a former Greek Premier, and Iain Macleod, former Chancillor of the Exchequer in Britain, were experts.

title: Rodino Indicates He Seeks Data On Nixon's Role in I.T.T. Case
description: WASHINGTON, April 23The House Judiciary Committee is apparently seeking White House evidence to determine if President Nixon encouraged or knew of false testimony by former high Administration officials about the settlement of a Government antitrust action against the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

title: Dance
description: She is a great poet, a man in the aisle said Monday night at the Mark Hellinger theater as the curtain fell on the revival of Martha Graham's Letter to the World. Presumably, he was referring to the ballet's heroine, Emily Dickinson. Or did he mean Miss Graham?

title: Patterson Wins Penn Marathon
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 23  Dave Patterson, a graduate student at West Chester (Pa.) State College who had never run more than nine miles, won the 26mile marathon race today to open the 80th annual Penn Relays.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 24, 1974

title: No Progress on Cuba?
description: At the General Assembly of the Organization American States in Atlanta, the Foreign Minister Argentina spoke the truth in calling the twelveyearold sanctions against Cuba unrealistic and anachronistic.

title: HONEYWELL REPORTS NEW COMPUTER UNITS
description: Honeywell, Inc., said yesterday that it was introducing its new 60 series of computers consisting of large and small systems that are fully compatable with all earlier Honeywell systems. With special bridges of hardware and software, the new series is also compatible with competitive systems.

title: 2 BELGIAN PARTIES TRY FOR COALITION
description: BRUSSELS, April 23Two of the three parties in the coalition Cabinet that collapsed Jan. 26 agreed today to try to form a new government.

title: Prices Decline Sharply In Corporate Bond Arena
description: Credit Markets

title: The Right of Reply
description: WASHINGTONPat L. Tornillo Jr. has the nation's press lords in a tizzy.

title: PRICES DEPRESSED ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Doubts of a secondhalf recovery in the economy this year plus record prime interest rates, again depressed prices on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market yesterday.

title: SAM IS URGED TO LIST LOBBYISTS
description: WASHINGTON, April 23A regulation under which most persons seeking to influence decisions of the Federal Energy Office would be required to regster as lobbyists has been proposed by John W. Gardner, chairman of Common Cause.

title: A's Strategy Goes Afoul: Indians Win
description: The flamboyant owner of the Oakland A's, Charlie Finley, who is noted for secondguessing his managers, may be placing a telephone call right now to Alvin Dark in Cleveland. The reason: Dark yesterday ordered an intentional walk that helped the Cleveland Indians defeat the A's, 21.

title: LATE CITY EDITION
description: All the News That's Fit to Print

title: Capitalf in, of Italy, Agrees to Purchase 8.2% Signal Shares
description: Capitalfin International, Ltd., a group of major Italian industrial, banking and insurance interests, announced yesterday that it had agreed to purchase not less than 1.8 million shares, or 8.2 per cent of the capital stock of Signal Companies, Inc., Beverly Hills, Calif., a diversified industrial organization.

title: U.S. WEIGHS TRIM IN EUROPE FORCES
description: WASHINGTON, April 23Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger is considering a relatively small reduction in United States forces in Europe, through elimination of some Army and Air Force support personnel.

title: RETURN IS STRESSED FOR PACIFIC GAS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 23 While a citizens' group marched outside in protest against utility rates, stockholders of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company were told at their annual meeting today that the company needed an increased rate of return.

title: PORT UNIT WEIGHS END OF DISCOUNTS
description: TRENTON, April 23  A spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey disclosed tonight that the agency was seriously considering abolishing cutrate commuter tickets and lowering its, tolls for car pools in an effort to cut the consumption of gasoline, reduce vehicular air pollution and get motorists into trains and buses.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: WILLCON & GIBBS Net Income was $2,111,000 in 1973up 34% (WGAMEX) Advt.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Other Obituaries, Page 44.

title: Boston Busing Vote May 21
description: BOSTON, April 23 (AP)The Boston City Council has established May 21 as the date for a nonbinding referendum on busing in the city's school system.

title: Flyers Spurred by Fans in Helmets
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 23 From the top row of the trolleyshaped Spectrum down to the lower seats where Schultz's Army, wearing pointed World War I German helmets, laughs hysterically at blood, the newest breed of hockey fanatics has taken over.

title: Rates of Interest Continue to Rise For Fannie Mae
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  The steep upward trend of mortgage interest rates as reflected in the biweekly auctions of the Federal National Mortgage Association continued today.

title: TV MAKERS CONCEDE POSSIBILITY OF FIRE
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP)  Television manufacturers conceded today that their products cause hundreds of fires annually. But they took issue with Government estimates that up to 10,000 fires each year are TVrelated.

title: Interpreters' Job Action Halts 8 Meetings at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 23About half the staff members who interpret at United Nations sessions stayed out on sick leave today to protest against overwork and understaffing. The oneday action forced the cancellation of eight of the 11 scheduled meetings, including two General Assembly sessions.

title: Beth Barry, '73 Winner, Sets Pace at Pinehurst
description: PINEHURST, N. C., April 23 (AP)Beth Barry, who won the event last year, hit a No. 5 shot to the green on the 20th hole today and ran in an eightfoot birdie putt to beat Mrs. Anne Dana in the first round of the North and South women's amateur golf tournament.

title: ASSOCIATED PRESS REELECTS MILLER
description: Paul Miller, chairman of the board of the Gannett Company, was reelected yesterday as chairman of The Associated Press at the cooperative's turnual business meeting at 50 Rockefeller Plaza.

title: Court Affirms Teacher Used Abusive Rhetoric
description: TRENTON, April 23The threemember Appellate Division of State Superior Court in Trenton today upheld unanimously the dismissal of a Brick Township school teacher on the basis of her improper conduct and use of abusive rhetoric in a speech she made as president of the local teachers association in 1971.

title: Knicks Get Sendoff to Boston by Their Special Fans
description: They compared and traded Knick autographs yesterday at the Lexington School for the Deaf. One youngster gave up two Dave DeBusscheres for one Walt Frazier.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Phillipsburg to Get Rail Service

title: 2 LABOR MEN NAMED TO BENEFITS COUNCIL
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 Caspar W. Weinberger, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, announced today the names of 12 appointeesincluding two officials of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizationsto the advisory council on Social Security.

title: Edward L. Katzenbach Jr., 55, ExDefense Official, Is Suicide
description: Edward L. Katzenbach Jr., a former. Defense Department official and older brother of Nicholas de B. Katzenbach, the former United States Attorney General, shot himself to death yesterday afternoon at his home in Cranbury, N.J., his family reported. He was 55 years old.

title: U.S. SAID TO PLAN $250MILLION AID TO EGYPT IN YEAR
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 The Nixon Administration is planning to ask Congress to authorize about $250million in economic aid to Egypt in the year beginning July 1, a high United States official said today.

title: Music: Durable Moderns
description: All four works chosen by Arthur Weisberg for the second of his Contemporary Chamber Ensemble's three programs this season have demonstrated staying power. The most elderly, Milton Babbitt's essay in 12tone jazz, All Set, dates back 17 years. The youngest, George Crumb's Night of the Four Moons, is five years old, which is getting along as these things are measured in modern music.

title: U.S. Position on Gold
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 The Treasury said today that the United States position on gold remains unchangedwe are not in favor of anything that tends to put gold back in the middle of the monetary system.

title: U.S. Carrier Off Egypt Marks Trend
description: CAIRO, April 23The American helicopter carrier Iwo Jima play anchored six miles, off Port Said, at the northern end of the Suez Canal  a sign of the growing association between Egypt and the Western world.

title: Blast Caused by Gas
description: Gas rushing from a main torn open by a highpressure water jet was pinpointed by the Fire Department yesterday as the cause of Monday's officetower explosion near the United Nations. An insuranceindustry source put the damage at $10million or more. Details on Page 46.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: SOUTHERN RAILWAY COOL ON RATE RISE
description: The president of the Southern Railway, W. Graham Claytor Jr., said yesterday that, if the Interstate Commerce Commission approves a 10 per cent freight rate increase, there will be a substantial number of areas in which his system won't raise its rates the full 10 per cent and some in which we can't concur in any increase at all.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Back to the Slag Heap?
description: Just as the energy shortage is being twisted into an excuse to scuttle standards of environmental protection, it is also being used to undermine Federal rules for occupational health and safety. To document that trend, the new reform leadership of the United Mine Workers offers a copy of Administration proposals for potentially crippling amendments to the Coal Health and Safety Act of 1969.

title: An Effective Show Of Inexorable Rock From Grand Funk
description: Rock critics have tended to be rather patronizing about Grand Funk Railroad. It's a loud band, and a crude one, they've complained. It doesn't really deserve the adulatory success it has enjoyed. But tell that to Carol and Jackie, who are both 15 years old and who come from Rockaway, N.J.

title: City is Given $4.5Million To Aid in Feeding Elderly
description: Supplied with $4.5million from the Federal Government's new nutritional program for Colder persons, the city yesterday augmented its program of serving meals to elderly residents.

title: Theater: Yale in Chelm
description: NEW HAVENThe legendary town of Chelm is a haven for fools, and the greatest fool is Shlemiel. He is sent on a mission to spread wisdom to other lands but, tricked by a rogue, he unwittingly returns directly to his home. Despite the fact that everything is familiar, he decides that this must be a different Chelm, and that some other Shlemiel has taken his place in his Chelm.

title: Troops Reaching Site of Plane Crash on Bali Report All 107 Dead
description: DENPASAR, Indonesia, April 23An Indonesian army unit, after struggling for nearly a day to hack its way through dense jungle and up a steep mountain, tonight reached the site of a Boeing 707 crash and reported that none of the 107 persons on board had survived.

title: RODINO EXPECTS TO EASE DEADLINE ON NIXON'S TAPES
description: WASHINGTON, April 23President Nixon apparently won today five more days to respond to a House Judiciary Committee subpoena for tape recordings of 42 Watergaterelated conversations.

title: New York Schoolboys Beat Moscow's
description: New York met Moscow in basketball last night, and the coach of the Soviet team, Yuri Burakov, summed up the game accurately. He said of the New Yorkers, They are very intimate with the ball.

title: Sudden Comet Changes Laid to Onionlike Layers
description: WASHINGTON, April 23Observations of the comet Kohoutek and of sudden changes in the brightness of a more recent comet called Bradfield have led to the suggestion that comets are layered like onions.

title: Malcolm Urges Razing Of Tombs for a New Jail
description: The city's Commissioner of Correction, Benjamin J. Malcolm, recommended yesterday that the Manhattan House of Detention for Men be demolished and that a new detention facility be built on its site at White and Centre Streets.

title: White House Expert Said Not to Dispute Tape Gap Verdict
description: N.B.C. News reported yesterday that a tape expert hired by the White House would not dispute the verdict of a courtappointed team of experts on an 18minute gap in a crucial Watergate tape, according to The Associated Press.

title: Fire Officer Union Plans Fight on Homosexual Bill
description: The executive board of the Uniformed Fire Officers Association said yesterday that it had adopted a crash program to defeat a bill before the City Council that would ban discrimination against homosexuals in employment, housing and public accommodations.

title: Chrysler Raises Charge For Shipping Vehicles
description: DETROIT, April 23 (AP)The Chrysler Corporation said today it had raised shipping charges an average of $15 on its 1974model cars and $19 on its new trucks.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Police Oust 219 SitIns From Connecticut U. Library
description: STORRS, Conn., April 23After in allnight sitin, 219 demonstrators, most of them black and most students, were removed by the state police today from the Wilbur Cross Library at the University of Connecticut, where they had encamped to press for a black cultural center on campus, more financial aid for black students and other demands.

title: Rain Where It's Moist
description: LONDON (Canadian Press)A newspaper in Essex was taking no chances with its weekend weather outlook. Becoming colder with moderate winds, it said. Rain in moist areas on Sunday.

title: Interpreters' Job Action Halts 8 Meetings at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 23About half the staff members who interpret at United Nations sessions stayed out on sick leave today to protest against, overwork and understaffing. The oneday action forced the cancellation of eight of the 11 scheduled meetings, including two General Assembly sessions.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: It's really mysterious, isn't it? Two months and five days. I don't believe there could have been any misunderstanding about the request. But I believe avoiding irreconcilable conflict if it can be done in reasonable way, if good intentions are indicatedwhich must be assumed for the time being.Representative James R. Mann, commenting on President Nixon's request for a fiveday extension of the House Judiciary Committee's subpoena for tapes. [25:3.]

title: MAYOR OF MILLTOWN TO SEEK HOUSE SEAT
description: TRENTON, April 23 (AP)Mayor David B. Crabiel of Milltown, the younger brother of J. Edward Crabiel, the New Jersey Secretary of State, today announced he would challenge Representative Frank Thompson Jr. for the Democratic nomination in the Fourth Congressional District.

title: Britain's 3Day Week Economy Stood Up Well, but Output Must Increase in Absence of Curbs
description: LONDON, April 23There are growing indications that the threeday work week did not wreak havoc in the British economy. Each new Government report covering economic activity in the first quarter seems to confirm that British industry and the British worker demonactivity in the first quarter seems to confirm that British industry and the British worker demonstrated surprising resilience, despite the imposition of the most drastic restrictions on the economy since World War II.

title: 9 Who Stand and Wait Are Waited Upon at Sardi's
description: The tables were turned on nine waiters yesterday. They showed up at Sardi's for the lunch hour and sat down and ate lunch.

title: U.S. SAID TO PLAN $250MILLION AID TO EGYPT IN YEAR
description: WASHINGTON, April 23The Nixon Administration is planning to ask Congress to authorize about $250million in economic aid to Egypt in the year beginning July 1, a high United States official said today.

title: Connecticut Police Seize 1,000 Pounds of Marijuana
description: CANAAN, Conn., April 231 (AP)The state police and a regional narcotics squad said today that they confiscated 1,000 pounds of marijuana in a rental trailer on Route 7 Monday night.

title: Eastern Air Sets Profit; Burlington Industries Up
description: Burlington Industries, Inc., the nation's largest textile producer, reported yesterday that its profit in the quarter ended March 31 was up 37 per cent from last year. As a result, directors raised the quarterly dividend to 40 cents a share from 35 cents, payable June 1 the first increase in five years.

title: About New York
description: The explosion struck East 46th Street at 7 A.M. on Monday, ripping out the insides of a big office building, injuring people who lived next door, and creating a small holocaust. For a long while afterward, the street belonged to sightseers, reporters and city inspectors, but when darkness came most of them left. By midnight, the street belonged to other people.

title: PORT UNIT WEIGHS END OF DISCOUNTS
description: TRENTON, April 23  A spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey disclosed tonight that the agency was seriously considerthe abolition of commuter muter, tickets and lowering its tolls for car pools in an effort to cut the consumption of gasoline, reduce vehicular air pollution and get motorists into trains and buses.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 43

title: BELL TELEPHONE TIES ORDERED RESTORED
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP)  The Government ordered the Bell System's 22 telephone companies today to provide interconnections for specialized common carriers. They were given 10 days in which to comply.

title: Flyers' 3 Goals in 3d Period Defeat Rangers, 52, for 20 Playoff Lead
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 23 War I, Battle II was waged tonight at the Spectrum. With Bob Kelly and Dave Schultz sounding the call to arms, the Philadelphia Flyers charged from their trenches and stormed the New York Rangers into submission, 52, beating them for the second time in their Stanley Cup semifinal struggle.

title: Callaway Is Found Guilty In Shabazz Murder Case
description: NEWARK, April 23A jury of eight men and four women tonight returned a verdict of guilty of murder in the first degree against Lamont Callaway, who was accused of assassinating James McGregor Shabazz, a Black Muslim minister.

title: Times Sees Talks at a Critical Stage
description: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher of The New York Times, told stockholders yesterday that contract negotiations with Typographical Union No. 6 were at a critical stage and that The Times and The Daily News were going to stand together.

title: National Symphony Orders 12 Works For the Bicentenary
description: National Symphony Orders 12 Works For the Bicentenary

title: Interstate Highway For, the West Side Decried at Meeting
description: More than 30 speakers, representing more than a score of West Side community groups and backed by an overflow crowd of several hundred residents from the area, gathered last night to denounce, ridicule and vow eternal opposition to plans for transforming the West Side Highway and the Henry Hudson Parkway into a multilane interstate highway.

title: New Jersey Sports Wonder Team Tribute
description: PASSAIC, April 23The Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame in Springfield, Mass., will be the scene today of considerable activity when tribute is paid to the Passaic High School Wonder Team of 19191925.

title: SOVIET SEES GAIN ON EUROPE ACCORD
description: MOSCOW, April 23The Soviet Union today hailed the acceptance of one of its cardina?? principles, the recognition o?? existing frontiers, by Westen participants at the Europea?? security talks in Geneva.

title: Japanese, Long in Jungle, in Fine Health
description: TOKYO, April 23  Thirty years of primitive living in a mountainous Philippine jungle may have made former Lieut. Hiroo Onoda one of the healthiest 52yearold men in Japan today.

title: Ore Company Employes Back on Job, but Uncertain
description: SILVER BAY, Minn., April 23The 3,100 employes of the Reserve Mining Company returned to their jobs today with a sigh of relief tempered by a continuing uncertainty over the future of the huge ore processing plant and mine that provides them and their families with a living.

title: MRS. WALTER T. PORT
description: Mrs. Kathleen Nagle Port, the wife of Walter T. Port, a reI tired deputy police inspector, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital. She was 66 years old and lived at 55 Evelyn Place, the Bronx.

title: Governor Nominates 7 New Narcotics Judges
description: ALBANY, April 23Governor Wilson, exercising his power to create new judgeships under the state's special narcotics enforcement program, nominated seven new judges today.

title: Soviet Made Tractors Introduced Upstate
description: CANANDAIGUA, N. Y.Abstract talk about EastWest trade and detente is taking on substance and reality here in Ontario County, an upstate dairyfarming community southeast of Rochester where the first Sovietmade tractors in the United States are trying their mettle on the stillwet fields.

title: Woman OddsOn Favorite For Connecticut Governor
description: STORRS, Conn.  Politics is played quietly in the Land of Steady Habits. Without the trombones, as it were.

title: Ballet: Canadian Guests
description: Rudolf Nureyev and the National Ballet of CanadaI nearly said his National Ballet of Canadaare back in New York, opening for a second season at, the Metropolitan Opera House. The company, which opened last night with his staging of Tchaikovsky's The Sleeping Beauty, will be in residence for two weeks. Following this, Mr. Nureyev stays on for three weeks of performances with his home troupe, Britain's Royal Ballet.

title: Black Clubbed in Selma Assails Blacks Aiding Wallace
description: SELMA, Ala., April 23John Lewis the softspoken Negro leader who was beaten to the ground here nine years ago during the voting rights struggle, came back last night to denounce some nowenfranchised blacks who are talking about reelecting Gov. George C. Wallace to an unprecedented third term.

title: Foes Contest Mt. Hermon in Bitter Cold
description: MOUNT HERMON, IsraeliOccupied Syria, April 23Israeli Air Force planes strafed Syrian positions near Mount Hermon today as dense clouds settled over the peak, concealing from Israeli eyes whether the Syrians were attempting once more to push construction of a road, higher up the bitterly contested mountain.

title: Hawks Win, In Overtime To Lead, 21
description: CHICAGO, April 23 (AP)Jim Pappin's goal at 3:48 of a suddendeath overtime gave the Chicago Black Hawks a 43 victory over the Boston Bruins tonight and a 21 edge in their fourofsevengame semifinal Stanley Cup playoff series.

title: West Point Happy Visit For Yanks
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., April 23A strange epidemic suddenly hit the children of the West Point Elementary School this afternoon, and many of them called in sick just before the New York Yankees began their exhibition game with the West Point Cadets.

title: N.F.L. Owners Mull Over Expansion Plans
description: The team owners of theNational Football League heard an expansion report yesterday at the opening of their meeting here in favor of adding more teams to the league roster, which now stands at 26. But after eight hours of discussion the meeting was adjourned with no action taken.

title: Kennedy in Soviet
description: MOSCOW, April 23Senator Edward M. Kennedy has been handling his visit to Moscow like a potential Presidential candidate testing the waters for 1976, and his Soviet hosts have received him in the same spirit.

title: ANDERSON RESIGNS POST IN MARYLAND
description: TOWSON, Md., April 23 (UPI)N. Dale Anderson, convicted last month of 32 counts of political corruption stemming from the same investigation that drove former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew from office, announced today his resignation as Baltimore County Executive.

title: People and Business
description: A new Federal Reserve Board member, Henry C. Wallich, warned yesterday that, unless both business and labor exercise restraint in the months ahead, their actions could make inflation more difficult to control.

title: Seton Hall Nine Wins, Takes Lead
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., April 23  Bob Hemsworth singled home two huns with two out in the ninth to lift Seton Hall to a 32 victory over Fairleigh Dickinson today and put the Pirates in first place in the Metropolitan Baseball Conference.

title: VIOLATIONS CHARGED TO 18 FOOD PLACES
description: The Health Department has released the names of 18 more restaurants and food stores in the city accused of having violated the Health Code after their owners failed to correct infractions that persisted through two inspections.

title: OvertheCounter Quotations
F.B.I. Doubts Authenticity Of Message From Radicals
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 23 (UPI)The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that the latest message purportedly sent by the selfstyled Symbionese Liberation Army appeared to be a hoax.

title: Court Upholds Dismissal of Teacher For Abusive Speech About Official
description: TRENTON, April 23A state appeals court upheld today the dismissal of a Brick Township school teacher on the basis Of her improper conduct and use of abusive rhetoric in a speech she made as president of the local teachers association in 1971.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Women vs. Jaycees: It's Up to the Courts
description: To the uninitiated, the name Jaycees sounds like, the secondstring ball team at school. Women are having as much trouble getting on the team as girls have had with the Little League.

title: Louvre Unfazed by Doubt on Picasso Gift
description: PARIS, April 23  Some curators of the Louvre concede that art critics may be correct in questioning the authenticity as well as the quality of some paintings from Pablo Picasso's private collection that were donated to the museum by the late painter's heirs.

title: Red Smith
description: Sports of The Times

title: Rabin Is Officially Designated To Form a New Israeli Cabinet
description: DEL AVIV, April 23Yitzhak Rabin, Israel's former Ambassador to the United States and commander of Israeli forces in the 1967 war, was officially designated by President Ephraim Katzir today to try to form a new coalition Cabinet.

title: 5 Steel Makers Indicted On Antitrust Violations
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) A Federal grand jury today indicted five steel companies on antitrust violations in connection with the sale of millions of dollars worth of reinforcing steel bars in Louisiana.

title: Assembly Votes for a DeathPenalty Bill
description: ALBANY, April 23  After more than six hours of debate, the Assembly voted early this evening to reimpose a mandated death penalty in the state for the willful murder of a peace officer during the performance of his duties or of an employe of a local or state correctional institution.

title: Among the Week's Activities, OpenAir Fairs for Children
Inquiry Clearing Rep. Chisholm Of Election Campaign Charges
description: WASHINGTON, April 23The Justice Department has virtually absolved Representative Shirley Chisholm, Democrat of Brooklyn, and her Presidential campaign committee of charges of having mishandled campaign funds.

title: STANS IS TERMED HONORABLE MAN
description: With sarcasm and solemnity, evangelistic fervor and laughter, the lawyer for Maurice H. Stans summed up his defense yesterday in an oration to the jury that lasted nearly five hours.

title: Dr. Dora Hartmann Dead; Training Analyst Was 71
description: Dr. Dora Karplus Hartmann, a psychoanalyst long associated with the New York Psychoanalytic Institute, died Sunday at her home, 1150. Fifth Avenue. She was 71 years, old.

title: Senate Seniority Wins Chicken Battle
description: Washington, April 23One of the Senate's most junior Members waged a floor fight today against a pet, bill of one of the Senate's most powerful members. Seniority won easily.

title: Show on Kissinger Listed
description: A.B.C. News has scheduled a documentary on Secretary of State Henry Kissinger for the evening of June 5. Titled Kis singerAn Action Biography, the onehour program will contain a biography of Mr. Kissinger and film footage of his working day in Washington and his travels, concluding with an interview of the Secretary by A.B.C. News correspondent Howard K. Smith and State Department correspondent Ted Koppel. Aetna Life & Casualty Company will sponsor the show.

title: Output and Profits At Bethlehem Steel Up for the Quarter
description: WILMINGTON, Del., April 23The Bethlehem steel corporation produced and shipped, more steel in the first three months of this year than in, any previous first quarter, Stewart S. Cort, chairman, told about 110 stockholders at the annual meeting here today.

title: News Summary and Index WEDNESDAY, APRIL 24, 1974
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Oil Concerns' Profits Up
description: Exxon and Texaco reported earnings increases of 39 and 123 per cent, respectively, for the first quarter of this year. Details on Page 53.

title: Inquiry Clearing Rep. Chisholm Of Election Campaign Charges
description: WASHINGTON, April 23The Justice Department has virtually absolved Representative Shirley Chisholm, Democrat of Brooklyn, and her Presidential campaign committee of charges of having mishandled campaign funds.

title: A.T&T. to Request fee For Directory Assistance
description: ATLANTA, April 23 (UPI)In an effort to curb misuse of directory assistance calls, the board chairman of the American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation says that his company plans to ask that customers be charged for the service.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Home Hours Given In Daylight Saving Times

title: Kissinger to Leave Sunday On Fifth Mideast Mission
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (Reuters)Secretary of State Kissinger will leave on Sunday or his fifth Middle East peace mission since the October war, the State Department announced today.

title: Notes on People
description: The California Court of Appeals has ruled against Walter H. Annenberg, Ambassador to Britain, holding that his servants with labor grievances have the right to picket his home in Palm Springs.

title: Ford Perplexed by View He Undercuts President
description: WASHINGTON, April 23Vice President Ford has confided to acquaintances in recent weeks that he is perplexed by what he senses to be the feeling of some White House aides that he is attempting to undercut President Nixon.

title: Dr. Herman M. Sternberg, Orthopedic Surgeon, Dead
description: Dr. Herman Max Sternberg, orthopedic surgeon, died of a cardiac ailment yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 147 West 79th Street.

title: Charles B. Vose, ExHead Of Cotton Exchange Here
description: WESTPORT, Conn., April 24Charles B. Vose, former president of the New York Cotton Exchange, and president of the Commodity Clearing Corporation of New York, died Monday at his home at 60 Beachside Avenue. He was 66 years old.

title: Dave Anderson
description: In the medieval wars known as the Stanley Cup playoffs, saints and dragons are interchangeable, depending on the locale. Perhaps the most popular example of this thesis is Dave Schultz of the Philadelphia Flyers, a team of saints or dragons. During the recent National Hockey League season, Dave Schultz served a record total of 348 minutes in penalties. In the current playoffs he has been sentenced for 48 minutes. Dave Schultz thrives on spontaneous combustion. In the City of Brotherly Love, he had been canonized for it. But when the Flyers muscle into Madison Square Garden tonight for the resumption of their semifinal series with the New York Rangers, the perspective of the spectators will be somewhat different. Dave Schultz suddenly will be a dragon to be slain for his recent remark that the Rangers have reputation for choking in the playoffs.

title: Brezhnev Said to Give Sadat Assurances Despite Criticism
description: CAIRO, April 24The Soviet Union has advised Egypt that it is eager to see a stable peace in the Middle East and is also eager to play an active and positive role, informed sources said today.

title: Work at Blast Site Lacked City Permit
description: The ruptured water tank blamed in Monday's officetower explosion was installedand renovated last Saturdayby unlicensed plumbers working without required permits, the city asserted yesterday.

title: Chess:
description: When a player departs from his customary openings repertoire to strike out in territory new to him, the results are often strikingly successful.

title: ... Short Circuit
description: Despite all its financial woes, Consolidated Edison is planning to go ahead with its highly questionable pumpedstorage generating plant at Storm King Mountain. As evidence continues to pile up that the controversial project may not be worth the company's investment and still less worth the environmental damage it may do, Con Edison may yet recognize this elevenyearold albatross for what it isand give it up once and for all.

title: High Court Backs Tenant Jury Trials In Eviction Cases
description: The Supreme Court, overturning an appeals court decision, said today that tenants had constitutional right to jury trials in eviction cases.

title: Jaworski Reported Investigating Possible Favors to Campaign Donors Under White House Pressure
description: WASHINGTON, April 24The Watergate special prosecutor's inquiry into illegal campaign donations has broadened into an investigation of Federal officials who might have done favors for the big donors, according to sources close to the investigation.

title: Percentage Gains
description: Stocks with the largest percentage gains on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.

title: Beirut Police Raid Campus; Arrest 61 Demonstrators
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 24 (AP)Lebanese policemen occupied the campus of the American University of Beirut today and arrested 61 Arab students who had seized buildings in a fiveweek demonstration.

title: ConstructionHiring Battle Intensifies
description: A rally at City Hall Park urging more minoritygroup workers in the building trades added new controversy to an already controversial issue yesterday, as charges were raised that inflammatory leaflets passed out at the demonstration were forgeries.

title: Youth, 16, Accused of Murder In Stabbing in St. Mary's Park
description: A 16yearold youth was arrested yesterday and held without bail on murder charges in the stabbing death of a 24yearold woman in St. Mary's Park in the Bronx two weeks ago.

title: Police Receive Tape Quoting Miss Hearst On Role in Robbery
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 24 In a taperecorded message that the authorities said appeared authentic, Patricia Hearst described herself today as a willing participant in last week's bank robbery.

title: Munich Handles the Press's Curves
description: How does running a department store qualify a man to operate a 237mile subway system, nine bridges and tunnels and assorted rail and bus lines?

title: Affluence & Survival: 3
description: BOSTON, April 24  When Americans ponder the future in terms of energy and resources, we allow thought to be distorted too often by two tenacious fallacies:

title: Yunich, ExMacy Official, Named M.T.A. Chairman
description: ALBANY, April 24Governor Wilson today nominated David L. Yunich, a former vice chairman of Macy's department stores, to be chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the giant agency that runs mass transit in New York City and its suburbs.

title: News Summary and Index THURSDAY, APRIL 25, 1974
description: President Nixon asked Congress for $5.18billion in foreign aid, including a $900million peace package for the Middle East. The request is more than twice the $2.5billion appropriated for the current fiscal year, not counting $2.2billion in emergency aid to Israel, and $960million more than the President's original request. [1:1.]

title: Accounting Unit Seeks Answers
description: The sevenman board that makes rules for the accounting industry wound up two days of public hearings yesterday in search of an answer to the vexing problem of what numbers should be used by corporations in their financial statements in an era of raging inflation.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: U.S. REBUFFS STATE ON PUREAIR DELAY
description: The Federal Government told Governor Wilson yesterday that it was unlikely that he would get the timelimit extension he had requested for putting into effect new Federal airquality standards for transportation in New York City.

title: Neighbor's Dog Kills Boy In Front of East Islip Home
description: A 6yearold boy was attacked and killed by a neighbor's dog yesterday as he played on the lawn of his house in East Islip, L. I.

title: San Francisco Police to Restrict Searches in Inquiry on Murders
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 24The San Francisco Police Department has restricted its controversial practice of stopping lack men on the street and qestioning them about the random murders of 12 persons. The change came in the face of a move to enjoin legally the topandsearch procedure.

title: MRS. HAROLD P. MANSON
description: Mrs. Natanya Neumann Manson, a former member of the Martha Graham dance company, died Tuesday in Mount Sinai Hospital at the age of 50. She was the wife of Harold P. Manson, director of the office of academic affairs of the American Friends of the Hebrew University, and lived at 320 Central Park West.

title: Bank Merger Approved
description: The Federal Reserve Board yesterday approved unanimously the proposed merger of the First Westchester National Bank of New Rochelle into, Barclays Bank of New York. The merger, which was approved by the New York State Banking Department in January, will become ?? it 30 days.

title: Helstoski Cited in Inquiry On SpecialBill Kickbacks
description: NEWARK, April 24  Representative Henry Helstoski, Democrat of the Ninth District, is the target of a Federal inquiry into reports that he accepted payoffs in return for sponsoring special immigration bills designed to enable individuals to avoid deportation, according to a source close to the investigation.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: 31 Pupils Arrested in Toms River

title: SCOPE OF INQUIRY ON IMPEACHMENT MAYBE NARROWED
description: Lawyers for the House Judiciary Committee will propose tomorrow that the scope of the impeachment inquiry be narrowed sharply to include only the most serious potential charges of wrongdoing by President Nixon.

title: Tennessee Rescinds Equal Rights Support
description: NASHVILLE, April 24 (AP) The Tennessee Legislature. has become the second to rescind its ratification of the equal rights amendment.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Nicklaus Favored on Coast Today

title: Board Says Local School Units Aren't Wasteful or Mismanaged
description: Contending that not one of the 32 community school boards was running a deficit, Board of Education officials defended the school boards yesterday against allgations of waste and mismanagement.

title: The News Moves In Automation Gear As Printer Slowdown Enters 7th Day
description: The Daily News, which said it lost 48 pages of advertising in today's paper as a result of the printers' slowdown, reported yesterday that it had moved its automated typesetting equipment from West Orange, N. J., to the newspaper's main plant, at 220 East 42d Street.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: CITY OPERA LISTS 6 NEW STAGINGS
description: The New York City Opera will introduce six new productions during its 197475 seasons at the New York State Theater. Puccini's Manon Lescaut and Johann Strauss's Die Fledermaus will be presented in the fall and Richard Strauss's Salome, Mozart's Idotheneo, Puccini's Turandot and Korngold's Die Tote Stadt in the spring.

title: Perseverance Pays Off For Virginia Trainer
description: A newspaper ad sent Mrs. Elizabeth Davids into the dogshow world. It was for a Bedlington terrier, recalled the Leesburg, Va., resident, but that meant nothing to me. I drove to the address and when I left, I had a 4monthold pup and his papers. He was so high spirited that after a week, we called the breeder, said we couldn't manage him and would she take him back.

title: Sammy Stars a Powerhouse (Davis)
description: Sammy Davis Jr. has always been a powerhouse of a performer. He can tapdance with thunder, mimic his peers and sing Frank Sinatra songs as well as Frank Sinatra. He is a natural choice for a oneman showeven to fill the cavernous Uris Theater, where Tuesday he began a limited engagement (through May 4), his first Broadway appearance since Golden Boy in 1965. His absence from Broadway musicals is a distinct loss for the theater.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: PRINCETON, April 24What does a graduate do when he has left the days of college sports behind, has settled down and begins to feel the need for more activity than an occasional weekend tennis game?

title: Belmonte On Victory Trail Again
description: Eddie Belmonte was in a happy mood at Aqueduct yesterday. He had just scored with Leo Fink's Dr. Eyego in the opening race at $19.80 for $2 and the Puerto Rican jockey was conAt the vinced  for the second time this Race year  that he Tracks was on the way to an outstanding season.

title: MRS. IDA FINKELSTEIN, LAWYER, CIVIC AIDE
description: Mrs. Ida Astrachan Finkelstein, a founder and former president of the Queens County Women's Bar Association and wife of Benjamin Finkelstein, former reporter for The New York Herald Tribune, died Tuesday at the Jackson Memorial Hospital In Miami. She was 74 years old, and her, home was in Miami.

title: Chilean Bishops Accuse Junta of Climate of Fear
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 24The Roman Catholic church of Chile today issued a declaration accusing the military junta of the use of torture, arbitrary and lengthy detentions, of causing largescale, unemployment, of making job dismissals for political reasons, and of establishing an economic policy that church leaders said had shifted the burden to the poor.

title: MASTER CHARGE SUED BY SHOE REPAIRMAN
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 24A local shoe repairman filed class action suit in United States District Court here today alleging that Master Charge is violating Federal antitrust laws by preventing merchants that utilize its services from offering discounts to cash customers.

title: MRS. H. B. BATTERSBY SR.
description: Mrs, Mary Dunn Battersby, widow of Harry B. Battersby Sr., who had been vice president of the Traylor Engineering and Manufacturing Company, Allentown, Pa., died of a heart attack Tuesday evening in Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. She was 85 years old and lived on Cat Rock Road in Cos Cob, Conn.

title: Ground Targets Strafed In Golan Heights Battle
description: TEL AVIV, April 24Syrian and Israeli aircraft took to the air again today to strafe and bomb ground targets on the Golan Heights.

title: The Screen: 'The Outfit':30-Year-Late B Movie From M-G-M Opens
description: "The Outfit," one of the last films to be produced during James Aubrey's administration at M-G-M, stands as an explanation of what happened to drive that once-great company from the ranks of the major studios."The Outfit" is not really a bad movie. It doesn't fail in an attempt to do something beyond its means. It doesn't attempt to do anything except pass the time, which simply isn't good enough when most of us have access to television. It's a B movie, made approximately 30 years too late for the market, about a nice, honorable, revenge-driven bank robber (Robert Duvall) who sets out to destroy the syndicate that murdered his brother.Because the movie is about the ways and means by which that revenge is carried out, it contains a good deal of action in terms of gunfights and holdups, that sort of thing, and hardly anything to think about except, possibly, the members of the cast.John Flynn, a director who has yet to distinguish himself, has reinforced the film's B-picture image by casting it with lots of players one associates with a more innocent time, if not directly with B pictures. Richard Jaeckel, Marie Windsor, Anita O'Day, Jane Greer and Elisha Cook, among others, turn up in roles so small you might miss them without a scorecard.They're all good performers, as are the stars, Mr. Duvall, Joe Don Baker and the late Robert Ryan (in one of his last roles), but the film doesn't appreciate them by giving them anything to do."The Outfit" opened yesterday at the Trans-Lux West and other theaters. With its profanity bleeped out, it could be television fare tonight.

title: Dudleigh Verner, Composed Sweetheart of Sigma Chi
description: DETROIT, April 24 (UPI) F. Dudleigh Vernor who, as an Albion College sophomore in 1911, wrote the music for The Sweetheart of Sigma Chi, died yesterday at the age of 81.

title: $500Million Aid to Con Ed Is Agreed Upon in Albany
description: ALBANY, April 24The leaders of the Legislature have reached agreement on a plan to have the Power Authority of the State of New York buy two Consolidated Edison generating plants at a total cost of nearly $500million.

title: Troopers Contend State Sets Summonses Quotas
description: TRENTON, April 24Nearly half of New Jersey's 1,100 stat troopers have charged that the state police division, in an of fort to harass and intimidate them, imposes a trafficticke quota each trooper mus meet on a monthly, weekly and hourly basis.

title: BroadwayHale Stock Plan
description: BioadwayHale Stores, Inc., Los Angeles, plans to purchase nearly 30 per cent of the common stock of House of Fraser, Ltd. Britain's largest departmerrtstorecompany. Last month, BroldwayHale had announced agreement to purchase 20 per cent, or, about 24million shares of Fraser's stock, so that it is no planning to increase that amount. Edward W. Carter, chatrman, said that his company has already bought about 850,000 common shares of Fraser.

title: Yunich, ExMacy Official, Named M.T.A. Chairman
description: ALBANY, April 24Governor Wilson today nominated David L. Yunich, a former vice chairman of Macy's department stores, to be chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the giant agency that runs mass transit in New York City and its suburbs.

title: Amex Index at Lowest Point Since '73
description: The American Stock Exchange's market value index fell to its lowest point since Dec. 31, 1973 yesterday as prices continued to fall both on the Amex and the overthecounter market.

title: POTATO FUTURES DECLINE FURTHER
description: May potato futures prices dropped the 50pointsaday limit yesterday from 15.50 to 15 cents a pound at the opening under the pressure of leftover sell orders. Prices remained at this level all day on the New York Mercantile Exchange, with only 245 contracts changing hands. It was the sixth day of limit declines. At the close there remained 851 unfilled sell orders.

title: Police Receive Tape Quoting Miss Hearst On Role in Robbery
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 24 In a taperecorded message that the authorities said appeared authentic, Patricia Hearst described herself today as a willing participant in last week's bank robbery.

title: Guild Votes to End 17Day Strike Over Pay at Washington Post
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (UPI)Rejecting the recommendations of their union negotiators for the second time, editorial and commercial employes of The Washington Post voted today to end their 17dayold strike.

title: Faltering Current...
description: The failure of Consolidated Edison to pay its quarterly dividend for the first time in its history provides alarming confirmation of the depressed state of its finances.

title: H. Dean Wellington Dead; Forest Products Executive
description: H. Dean Wellington, an executive in the forestproducts industry for many years, died Tuesday at New York Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived at 9 Brooklands, Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE UNEASY CHAIR. By Wallace Stegner. 464 pages. Doubleday. $12.50. For a few months after his graduation in 1914 from high school in Ogden, Utah, Bernard DeVoto worked as a reporter on the newspaper there. Later on, writes Wallace Stegner in this discreet, sympathetic and consistently interesting biography, warring with the effete and literary in New York, he would belligerently assert his pride in being a mere journalist.

title: Supreme Court Refuses Widower Tax Break Given to Widows
description: WASHINGTON, April 24The Supreme Court refused by 6 to 3 today to grant a Florida widower a property tax exemption that the state gives to all widows.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: NIXON PROPOSES $900MILLION AID TO MIDDLE EAST
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 President Nixon asked Congress today to authorize a total of $5.18billion in foreign economic and military aid for the fiscal year beginning July 1.

title: SMITHSONIAN GETS ART OF W.P.A. ERA
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 More than 200 works of art produced for the Works Progress Administration and the United States Treasury during the Depression were presented today by the General Services Administration to the National Collection of Fine Arts of the Smithsonian Institution.

title: Toronto Revises Hours
description: The Toronto Stock Exchange announced yesterday that effective next Monday, April 29, its trading hours would be 10 A.M. to 3:30 P.M., Eastern Daylight Saving Time. At present the exchange opens at 9 A.M. Eastern Standard Time, to coincide with openings in the United States, and closes at 3:30 P.M., Eastern Standard Time, one hour later than the United States markets.

title: West German Mark Gains On World Money Markets
description: LONDON, April 24 (UPI)  The West German mark ruled the roost on world money markets today. The American dollar and the British pound declined and the price of gold also dropped.

title: Woman, 86, Found Dead After Robbers Start Fire in Home
description: Firemen extinguished a small fire in a Tompkinsville, S. I., residence yesterday and found in an upstairs bedroom the body of an 86yearold woman who had been beaten and bound in bedsheets by robbers 1who had ransacked the home.

title: Taiwan Is Firm on Japanese Flight Curb
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 24A senior Chinese Nationalist official said today that Taiwan would not resume airplane flights with Japan despite a series of apparent hints by Japanese officials that they would like to restore them.

title: Agitate Derby Bound
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 24 (UPI)Agitate, the California Derby winner, will be shipped from Hollywood Park Monday to Louisville for the 100th running of the Kentucky Derby May 4, his trainer, Timmy Jiminez, said yesterday. He's a dead fit horse so he doesn't need much work between now and the. Derby, said Jiminez. Agitate will be ridden in the Derby by Willie Shoemaker.

title: Rabin's Job: Factions a Big Obstacle to Israeli Cabinet
description: JERUSALEM, April 24Moments after Yitzhak Rabin was nominated by the Labor party to succeed Premier Golda Meir, one of the former general's close aides stood in the rear of the party hall shaking his head in sympathy. Now his troubles really begin, the aide said as he joined in the jubilant applause for the Premierdesignate. I don't envy him the next few weeks.

title: People and Business
description: Joseph B. Collinson has been named president of Textron, Inc. He succeeds G. William Miller, who was elected to the vacant position of chairman, while continuing as chief executive officer.

title: A Doctor in Inquiry Being Considered For Hospitals Post
description: A Harlem doctor who has been accused by the state's Welfare Inspector General of inflating Medicaid claims is under consideration for appointment by Mayor Beame to the 16member board of directors of the Health and Hospitals Corporation.

title: Dismissal Weighed In RaceFixing Trial
description: Judge Orrin G. Judd agreed last night to consider the possibility of dismissing Federal indictments against 13 harness drivers accused of fixing superfecta races.

title: Detective Tells of Sharing $420,000 in 9 Drug Raids
description: A detective who was a member of the Police Department's special investigation unit for narcotics has said under oath that he and other detectives kept and shared $420,000 during the course of nine narcotics investigations and that he perjured himself in 20 trials against drug pushers, some of whom were later convicted.

title: W. H. A Playoffs
description: Chicago vs. Toronto

title: SHELL AIDE HITS NORTH SEA PLANS
description: LONDON, April 24  A top oilIndustry executive said today that any efforts by the British Government to nationalize North Sea oil would cause an indefinite delay in production.

title: She Cooks Amidst the Scents of Pomegranate and Lemon
description: You should meet Cleopatra Birrenbach, our friendly feinshmecker told us recently. Her dining room is furnished with Persian antiques and you sit on floor pillows when you dine. She was born in Iran, he added, and she's a fantastic cook.

title: Crude Oil Imports Show an Increase In the Latest Week
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (UPI)United States crude oil imports exceeded 3 million barrels a day last week for the first time in four months, reflecting increased deliveries since the suspension of the Arab oil embargo against the United States.

title: CHILDREN'S KILLER IS ORDERED FREED
description: TRENTON, April 24 (AP)  A oncesocially prominent Iwoman who bludgeoned her two young children to death in 1969 was ordered released on a conditional basis from a state mental institution today.

title: Boost for Democracy
description: At a time when military regimes rule most South American countries, Colombia has joined its northern tier neighbor, Venezuela, in providing an impressive example of democracy at work. In a free election, with competing forces ranging from falangists on the right to Communists on the left, Colombian voters have delivered a landslide victory to Alfonso L6pez Michelsen of, the Liberal party.

title: Lee Myles Sued by Forbes Agency
description: Forbes Advertising, a very small publicly held agency, filed a suit in State Supreme Court on Monday that alledges the chief executive of a client company demanded the sum of $35,000 as a rebate, kickback and gratuity for the continuation of the contractual relationship and the defendants Lee Myles Corporation and Lee Myles Associates Corporation. The agency paid the money, according to the suit.

title: PRESIDENT'S TOUR TO STRESS IMAGE
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 President Nixon will begin tomorrow another series of speaking tripspart of his continuing effort to demonstrate that neither Watergate nor his other problems has robbed him of his leadership ability.

title: SCIENCE STUDY SET ON WORLD ISSUES
description: WASHINGTON, April 24The two main scientific organizations that advise the Federal Government are starting an intensive study of world problems in population, food and energy to determine what must be done to avert a global crisis.

title: JOSEPH. H. QUINN
description: Joseph H. Quinn, former tax manager here for United States Steel International (New York) Inc., and a longtime resident of Westbury, L. I., died in Pittsburgh on Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 56 years old and lived in a Pittsburgh suburb.

title: Byrne Again Backs Bill to Let Citizens Sue to Halt Pollution
description: TRENTON, April 24 (AP) Governor Byrne gave new support today to controversial legislation that would give citizens the right to sue alleged polluters. The bill is opposed by a powerful alliance of business and labor.

title: 2OC PAPERS CALLED INCREASING TREND
description: The annual meeting of the American Newspapers Publishers Association was told here yesterday that a move toward 20cent daily newspapers had been touched off by rising costs that had pushed the cost of paper and delivery to 25 cents for papers of 64 pages or more.

title: Issues in Papers Dispute
description: PARTICIPANTS: The New York Times, The Daily News and The New York Post, negotiating as the Publishers Association of New York City, and New York Typographical Union No. 6, representing 819 printers, including 170 substitutes, at The Times; 945 printers, including 200 to 220 substitutes, at The News; and 312 printers, including 38 substitutes, at The Post.

title: Excerpts From Chilean Church Text
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 24 Following, as translated by The New York Times, are excerpts from the text of a statement issued today by Ral Cardinal Silva Henriquez under the title Reconciliation in Chile:

title: Mets Sink Deeper With 43 Loss in 9th
description: SAN DIEGO, April 24The New York Mets, masters of the lost cause, lost another one tonight when they dropped a 43 decision to the San Diego Padres for their 10th defeat in the last 11 games.

title: Design by Kahn Picked for Roosevelt Memorial Here
description: One of the late architect Louis Kahn's last designs has been approved as the final one for the Franklin Delano Roosevelt memorial at the southern tip of Roosevelt Island, and the Urban Development Corporation, which is building a new town on the island, says it expects to begin construction before the end of 1974.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: TONIGHT AT 7:30 P.M. ON WBAI 99.5 FM THE WILKESBARRE FLOOD A documentary of A natural disaster: Victims and ??. Listenerspons'd WBAI 90.5 FM

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: Action on Oil Companies Urged by Shah of Iran
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, April 24 (AP)The Shah of Iran urged Western governments today to take action against oil companies using the energy crisis to make excessive profits.

title: About the Rangers ...
description: Vic Hadfield, out for 11 days with a sprained ankle, will put on a Ranger uniform, He may see only powerplay action, if at all. Moose Dupont, out with the flu, returns for the Flyers.... Sunday's game will start at 2:05 P.M. at the Garden and will be televised nationally.... The Rangers won the battle of the faceoffs by 4238 on Tuesday, but Bobby Clarke won 20 of his 27 against an assortment of New Yorkers. ... Coach Emile Francis claimed the Rangers outhit the Flyers in the last game (a statement that made some Flyers laugh) and Francis added, There may be 90 hits in the next gameincluding the referee if he gets in the way. ... the latest daily saying on Coach Fred Shero's bulletin board reads: For a nation or a team to become great, they must welcome criticism!

title: Goolagong Is Beaten In 3 Sets
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 24 Helen Gourlay upset secondseeded Evonne Goolagong, 63, 36, 76, and reached the quarter final of the $50,000 Virginia Slims tennis tournament tonight at the Palestra.

title: Arabs Starting to Invest New Oil Money in West
description: A large amount of Arab oil revenues has begun to flow West, including about $1billion to the United Statesa small but significant part of the vastly increased revenues the Persian Gulf states are obtaining for their oil.

title: N.F.L. Accepts Tampa
description: The National Football League voted for expansion yesterday. One new franchise was granted, to Tampa, with at least one more and possibly two or three to be designated later this year. The new team, the 27th in the N.F.L. galaxy, is to be ready to play in the 1976 season.

title: Dismissal Weighed In RaceFixing Trial
description: Judge Orrin G. Jud?? agreed last night to consider the possibility of dismissing Federal indictments against 13 harness drivers accused of fixing superfecta races.

title: Acupuncture Relief of Nerve Deafness Is Questioned
description: The effectiveness of acupuncture in treating nerve deafness in children has been seriously questioned by Dr. Samuel Rosen, an otologist from New York who learned acupuncture methods three years ago when he was one of the first American physicians to visit China.

title: LEGISLATURE AIMS FOR WIDER POWER
description: ALBANY, April 24  With virtually no debate, the assembly today unanimously approved a proposed amendment to the State Constitution that would permit the Legislature to call itself into special session and to set the agenda of items to be discussed.

title: CHINA ALLOWING 300 TO MOVE TO CANADA
description: OTTAWA, April 24  Peking has issued the first 300 exit permits for Chinese who wish to emigrate to Canada under a new family reunification program, according to immigration officials here. The first immigrants are expected soon.

title: Sports Today
JAMES REINHARDT, CRIMINOLOGIST, DIES
description: LINCOLN, Neb., April 24 (UPI)Dr. James Reinhardt, nationally known criminologist, died yesterday at the Lincoln Veterans Hospital. He was 79 years old.

title: Ethiopia Warns Strikers; More Walkouts Expected
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, April 24 (Reuters)  Striking workers apparently ignored today a Government warning of stern action against them. More strikes seemed imminent.

title: Mink Pelts Purchased
description: Ben Kahn, Inc., New York manufacturer, and NeimanMarcus, Dallas specialty store chain, announced yesterday that they have purchased the entire 1974 crop of Black Willow mink, the costliest mink grown. Kahn will manufacture the garments, which will be sold by NeimanMarcus. The 5,000 pelts were, purchased for more than $250,000 from the John Adkins Mink Farm, Coalville, Utah.

title: Inland Raises Dividend
description: The Inland Steel Company announced yesterday that its firstquarter dividend would be increased to 60 cents from 50 cents per share. It is payable June 1, 1974, to stockholders of record May 6.

title: Steel Plan Called Inadequate
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 24 (UPI)The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said yesterday that a recent agreement spelling out plans of major steel companies to combat discrimination was inadequate and asked a Federal court to set aside the settlement. Nine major steel companies signed the agreement to expand job opportunities for members of minority races and women and to give backpay totaling $31million to more than 39,000 persons.

title: Cornell Room Dedicated Without Star
description: Martha Graham went searching about Bergdorf Goodman's last week to buy a dress for Katharine Cornell, who wanted very much to attend last night's dedication of a room to her and her late husband, Guthrie McClintic, at the New York Public Library's theater collection in Lincoln Center.

title: CAROL ROSENBERGER IN ELEGANT PIANISM
description: The precisely poised, patrician elegance of Carol Rosenberger's pianism at Alice Tully Hall on Monday night could not have been applied more aptly to the four composers on her program. Miss Rosenberger, a scrupulous technician and fastidious musician, knows exactly what she wants to extract from a piece of music, and she has all the equipment to realize her intentions on the highest level of accomplishment.

title: A STRIKE DEADLINE AT UNITED AIR LINES
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 The International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers announced that it would strike United Air Lines on May 3 unless a contract settlement was reached before then.

title: NATIONALISTS AHEAD IN SOUTH AFRICA VOTE
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Thursday, April 25 (AP)Prime Minister John Vorster's National party swept toward an expected victory today in South Africa's general election yesterday.

title: A. T. & T. Seeks a Review Of F.C.C. Service Order
description: The American Telephone & Telegraph Company filed a petition yesterday in the Third Circuit Court of Appeals at Philadelphia for a review of the Federal Communications Commission order of Tuesday directing telephone companies to connect with specialized common carriers to enable them to provide privateline longdistance services.

title: Redgrave Frowns on Method Excesses
description: Sir Michael Redgrave, currently gracing the stage of the Brooklyn Academy of Music in the Royal Shakespeare Company productions of The Hollow Crown and Pleasure & Repentence, appeared momentarily at a loss yesterday to explain the British theater's willingness to present such anthology series of dramatic readings.

title: PRICES OF STOCKS DECLINE SHARPLY
description: Stock prices fell sharply for the second consecutive session yesterday as investors' concern over rising interest rates and the inflationary spiral battered the market. Trading volume accelerated.

title: Normal Noise Level At Tombs Is Called TraumaProducing
description: A din resounded yesterday afternoon in the auditorium of the New York County Lawyers Association like the roar of a subway train rushing into the station.

title: Gerken Upsets Borg
description: Arthur Ashe and Rod Laver, battling for the thirdseeded spotin next month's $100,000 World Championship. Tensingles finals at. Dallas, advanced last night to the second round of the United. Bank tennis tournament. It is the final event on the W.C.T. Green tour before the finals.

title: End of the Free Ride?
description: Although many New York City politicians still behave ?? if the environmental and energy crises never happened, there are encouraging signs that the long free ride of the private motorist in this city limy be coming to an end.

title: Fulbright Group Has Lost Power to House Unit
description: WASHINGTON, April 24For more than half a century, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee was the dominant voice in Congress in the international field.

title: Aid for. Police Widows Voted
