description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) The House passed legislation today to provide $50,000 in Federal payments to the survivors of policemen, other local law enforcement officers and firemen killed in the line of duty, The measure now goes to the Senate.

title: BOTH SIDES SUM UP IN MITCHELL TRIAL
description: John N. Mitchell and Maurice H. Stans sat at the very pinnacle of government in this country and thought they were above the law, the. Government charged yesterday in its summation to the jury, in the Mitchell  Stans criminal conspiracy trial.

title: Notes on People
description: Edward M. Korry, the former diplomat and journalist who was made president of the United Nations Association of the United States of America last May, will resign effective Tuesday at the request of the association's board of governors. Mr. Korry, who is 52 years old, worked for The United Press and for Cowles magazines and served as Ambassador to Chile and Ethiopia before succeeding Porter McKeever as president of the United Nations Association, a private research and educational organization with a membership of 80,000.

title: Bando Has Hot Bat on Chilly Day
description: Sal Bando and Ken Holtzman are two outspoken players (which of the Oakland A's is not?) who have publicly expressed interest in the newly announced World Baseball Association. Neither could leave too soon to suit the Cleveland Indians.

title: Beams Names City Job Aide
description: Mrs. Nightingale Fong, executive director of the Chinatown manpower project of the Human Resources Administration, was named yesterday by Mayor Beame as deputy commissioner of the Department of Employment, a $24,889ayear post. Mrs. Fong formerly was vice president of the citywide bilingual commission of the Board of Education.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: G. E. Bomber Role Protested by Marchers
description: CHICAGO, April 24While demonstrators marched in proItest against the General Electric Company's role in the BI bomber program, stockholders voted on issues of minority employment and politics at their annual meeting here today.

title: ENTEREX SUSPENDED BY CHICAGO BOARD
description: The Enterex Commodities Corporation, a New Yorkbased commodity concern, was suspended from membership on the Chicago Board of Trade, effective at the opening of trading yesterday.

title: About the Yankees . .
description: Sparky Lyle, who retired all five Royals he faced yesterday, said he had asked the Yankee management stop having Toby Wright, the organist, play Pomp and Circumstance when he enters a game. The fans might like it, the relief pitcher said, but it doesn't look good when they play it and I come in and get my butt kicked. How about a funeral march? someone asked. It's O.K., he replied, if they want to play Pomp and Circumstance after I do well and the funeral march after I do bad. ... George Medich pitched yesterday despite the flu. However, Ron Blomberg is out temporarily with a pulled muscle his upper right leg.. .. Before Munson hit hip third homer in the fourth, he hadn't driven in a run in seven games and had only five hits in 30 times at bat in that period. . . Bobby Murcer left the game in the seventh with a strained back lie suffered when he slipped fielding Vada Pinson's run scoring double in the second.

title: End Comes Uneasily for DeBusschere
description: BOSTON, April 24The grind of training camps and the travel Dave DeBusschere hated so much ended tonight. It ended with a pained look on his face as he sat at the end of the Knick bench and with a pain in his stomach that had hampered his play.

title: ITS A PULL TRACK IN FRANCE'S RACE
description: PARIS, April 24Twelve candidates are in the running for the presidency of France, a field so large that it is being looked upon here as a sign that the Gaullist system has broken down.

title: DR. WILLIAM HALLER OF BARNARD IS DEAD
description: Dr. William Haller, emeritus professor of English at Barnard College and a member of the Columbia University philosophy faculty from 1909 to his retirement in 1950, died Monday at Worcester (Mass.) Memorial Hospital. He was 88 Years old.

title: Waldheim Asks Aid Now to Poor Lands
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 24 Secretary General Waldheim called today for immediate assistance for countries threatened by economic disaster.

title: Thoughts on Serving in a Seat of Judgment
description: WASHINGTONThe Juror's Manual of the United States District Court says that jury service is perhaps the most vital duty next to fighting in defense of one's country. Yet it seemed hilarious to almost everyone who heard about it when Judge John J. Shies, whose Watergate trial and other manoftheyearmaking activities I had covered, summoned me by form letter for two months of jury duty.

title: Georgia Pacific's Board Approves Expansion Plan

description: BATTING

title: Bank Rate Raised To 8% by Reserve
description: WASHINGTON, April 24The Federal Reserve Boards, in a strong signal of its antiinflation policy, raised its discount rate today to a record level of 8 per cent.

title: Design by Kahn Picked for Roosevelt Memorial Here
description: One of the late architect Louis Kahn's last designs has been approved as the final one for the Franklin Delano Roosevelt memorial at the southern tip of Roosevelt Island, and the Urban Development Corporation, which is building a new town on the island, says it expects to begin construction before the end of 1974.

title: HOUSE VOTES FUND FOR ARE AGENCY
description: WASHINGTON, April 24  The House of Representatives authorized funds today to continue the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency for another year after killing a controversial provision that would have required it to file reports to Congress on the impact of major strategicweapons systems on armscontrol policies.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
Swindle of 2 Concerns Is Laid to Businessman
description: A Long Island businessman has been indicted on a charge of having defrauded two concerns of more than $190,000, the Manhattan District Attorney's office disclosed yesterday.

title: LATE CITY EDITION
description: Weather: Partly sunny today; cool tonight. Sunny and mild tomorrow. Temp range: today 4158; Wed. 4457. Additional details on Page 78.

title: How the Teams Stand Today
description: Thursday, April 25, 1974

title: Acquisition Is Set
description: C H B Foods, Inc., of Pico Rivera, Calif., said yesterday that it had agreed in principle with W. R. Grace & Co. to acquire Grace's Nally's Fine Foods Division headquartered in Tacoma, Wash. The transaction, which was indicated to be a purchase of certain assets costing more than $20million, is expected to be completed in three months. Nally's 1974 sales have been projected at about $65million.

title: Cy Williams, Ball Player Who Hit 251 Homers, Dies
description: EAGLE RIVER, Wis., April 24 Frederick (Cy) Williams, an outstanding majorleague slugger who compiled a record of 251 home runs from the World War I era through the nineteentwenties, died here yesterday. His age was 86. Frederick (Cy) Williams, an outstanding majorleague slugger who compiled a record of 251 home runs from the World War I era through the nineteentwenties, died here yesterday. His age was 86.

title: TV: The Paper Prison
description: Tonight at 10 o'clock the American Broadcasting Company's CloseUp news series examines the slightly incredible and distinctly frightening subject of The Paper. Prison: Your Government Records, with the focus on the sometimes massive files or ominous codes assigned to ordinary citizens, often without their knowledge. The producer is Paul Altmeyer, who in the past has tackled aspects of the same subject for Westinghouse's Group W documentaries.

title: 60 More Are Arrested in SitIn At the U. of Connecticut Library
description: STORRS, Conn., April 24 The state police today arrested 56 students, most of them white and four faculty members on charges of criminal trespass for staging a sitin at the University of Connecticut's Wilbur Cross Library.

title: PLAN TO CUT TAXES OPPOSED BY SIMON
description: WASHINGTON, April 24William E. Simon firmly opposed today the plan backed by many Democrats for a tax cut to stimulate the economy.

title: O.O.P. to Hoar Simon
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP)William E. Simon, who has been nominated as Secretary of the Treasury, and Dean Burch, a counselor to President Nixon, will address the Republican National Committee at an allday meeting Friday. Others who will speak are Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, Senator Bill Brock of Tennessee and Gov, Winfield Dunn of Tennessee.

title: Being One's Own Worst Enemy
description: EAST BRUNSWICK, N. J.I have recurring dream that someday all the successful women in the world will rise up and denounce the women's movement.

title: Anna E. Meltzer is Dead; Painter and Teacher, 77
description: Anna Elkan Meltzer, a painter and teacher whose impressionistic oils in diffused lights, angles and colors were widely known, died Monday in a hospital in Great Barrington, Mass. The widow of Samuel Meltzer, a photographer, she was 77 years old and had been living in Copake, N. Y.

title: Saxbe May Abandon Weekly Talks With the Press
description: WASHINGTON, April 24Attorney General William B. Saxbe, faced with mounting criticism of the blunt and offhand remarks he has made to the press, may be changing or perhaps even abandoning his routine of regular weekly meetings with reporters.

title: Garden Ice Is Inviting To Rangers
The Catastrophists
description: WASHINGTONImmanuel Velikovsky is a catastrophist.

title: Personal Finance
description: Car rental companies, either because of normal replacement programs or efforts to sell off larger models, have used cars for sale in dozens of major cities  many with newcar warranties and attractive price tags.

title: Arabs Starting to Invest New Oil Money in West
description: A large amount of Arab oil revenues has begun to flow West, including about $1billion to the United Statesa small but significant part of the vastly increased revenues the Persian Gulf states are obtaining for their oil.

description: The Federal Reserve Board, in a signal of its antiinflation policy, raised its discount rate to a record 8 per cent. Details on Page 57.

title: Music: Handel's Samson
description: Experts on Handel's oratorios have never been able to decd on an authoritative performing edition of his Samson, simply because Handel himself never did. Some numbers in the sprawling threeact score exist in three possible versions, for instance, and Handel tinkered with the work more than was usual even for this inspired tinkerer.

description: News Summary and Index, Page 41

title: Gas Prices Stirring Fears for Dealers
description: One month after the end of the Arabs' oil embargo, gasoline prices still rising at pumps in the metropolitan area, and the widening difference in prices for the same gallon of fuel is stirring fears that more dealers will be forced out of business.

title: Nettles Hits 10th Homer; Yanks Win
Outlook for Economy
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 The unusually dreary statistics on the performance of the economy in the first quarter of 1974 that have just been published do not mean that the. United States is heading for some kind of disaster, in the view of most of the men and women who earn their pay by looking ahead in this field.

title: $1.4Million to Fight Crime
description: TRENTON, April 24 (AP)  The State Law Enforcement Planning Agency announced today $1.4million in grants to New Jersey counties and municipalities. Among the grants was $13,687 for Bergen County to establish a rehabilitation program for first offenders in lieu of prison sentences.

title: Dr. William R. B. Acker, 64, Professor of Chinese, Dies
description: Dr. William R. B. Acker, in recent years a professor of Chinese language and culture at the University of Ghent, died Saturday in Antwerp, Belgium. He was 64 years old.

title: Skylab Photographs Hint Copper Vein in Nevada
description: Photographs by United States space flights have inAicitted What it is hoped may be a potentially rich copper area in Nevada Ground studies 40 verify the mineral deposits and their extent are still under way.

title: Work at Blast Site Lacked City Permit
description: The ruptured water tank blamed in Monday's officetower explosion was installedand renovated last Saturdayby unlicensed plumbers working without required permits, the city asserted yesterday.

title: CAIRO SAYS SADAT WAS RAID TARGET
description: CAIRO, April 24The Egyptian Government declared today that a group of extremists who attacked a military academy here a week ago had intended to arrest President Anwar elSadat and to overthrow his Government.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: MIXED BAG Mayor Teddy Kollek of Jerusalem says hi?? 310,000 constituents live together not in a melting pot but in a mosaic, a conglomeration of the separate and the differentEuropean Jews and Oriental Jews, Greek Orthodox and Armenians, Arabs and Moslems.

title: Bud Abbott, Straight Man To Lou Costello, Is Dead
description: Bud Abbott, the tall, thin, Iamnotamused straight man who fed Lou Costello the lines and the Situations that got the pair into trouble and laid, their audiences into the aisles with Iaughter, died, of cancer yesterday in his home in Woodland Hills, a Los Angeles suburb. He was 78 Years old.

title: Advertising: Baby Food Spots
description: Permit me to express my dogma and state categorically, writes Mrs. Benjamin I. Weinfeld, a punloving Far Rockaway, L. I., resident, that it's a catastrophe that the TV commercials are littered with dog and cat food ads and not a single babyfood commercialand that's a doggone shame!

title: T.W.A. Sees No '74 Profit
description: OVERLAND PARK, Kan., April 24 (UPI)The high cost of jet fuel will make it impossible for Trans World Airlines to make a profit this year, its chairman, Charles C. Tillinghast Jr., told the annual meeting here today.

title: Discount Rate at 8%

title: 2d McDonald's Outlet In Village Postponed
description: Responding to protests from the community against fastfood chains in the area, McDonald's has decided not to open a second restaurant in a historic section of Greenwich Village.

title: NIXON PROPOSES $900MILLION AID TO MIDDLE EAST
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 President Nixon asked Congress today to authorize a total of $5.18billion in foreign economic and military aid for the fiscal year beginning July 1.

title: Sex Bias Still Marks Science, Engineering
description: CAMBRIDGE, April 24Despite a greater amount opportunities for women in the professions in recent years, women continue to find it difficult to pursue careers as scientists and engineers, according to a report issued today from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: Field of 14 Entered for Blue Grass
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., April 24 A betterthanfair barometer for the Kentucky Derby will be on view tomorrow with the running of the Blue Grass Stakes at Keeneland. A field of 14 has been namd for the 1mile test that will have a gross value of $65,550, the winner earning $42,607.

description: April 25, 1974

description: LINCOLN, Neb., April 24Tough. Very willing to accept responsibility and make hard decisions. A good politician. Exceedingly aggressive. A thoroughly nice woman.

description: LEXINGTON, Ky., April 24 A betterthanfair barometer for the Kentucky Derby will be on view tomorrow with the running of the Blue Grass Stakes at Keeneland. A field of 14 has been namd for the 1%mile test that will have a gross value of $65,550, the winner earning $42,607.

description: When a professional, athlete asks to have his salary increased 10fold in these days of huge, inflated contracts, observers of the sporting scene might gasp.

title: Gary Player in Japan
description: NAGOYA, Japan, April 20 (UPI)Gary Player, the Masters champion from South Africa, and Arnold Palmer will be among 129 competitors in the $100,000 Chunichi international invitation golf tournament starting Friday. Peter Thompson of Australia, fivetime winner of the British open, is expected to be strong contender for the $17,850 first prize, Thomson won the tournament here in 1969 and 1972.

title: Briefs On The Arts
description: Ballet Theater Appoints Tudor

title: SOVIET GIVES VISA TO ROSTROPOVICH
description: MOSCOW, April 24Mstislav Rostropovich, the cellist, has been granted a Soviet exit visa to live abroad for two years, informed sources reported today.

title: BOY, 5, DISCOVERS HIS SLAIN MOTHER
description: A 24yearold woman was found strangled in the cellar of her home in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn by her 5yearold son yesterday morning after the murderer escaped with jewelry and cash.

title: F.C.C. Allows TV Transmitters on Trade Center
description: Six of the stations are now transmitting from the Empire State Building. They are WCBSTV, WNBCTV, WNETTV, WNYCTV, WNEWTV and WORTV. The seventh station, WXTVTV broadcasts from lower Manhattan.

title: DEFICIT OF S. KLEIN IN 1973 IS WIDENED
description: The S. Klein Department Stores, a New Yorkbased department store chain, realized a loss of about $9.6million before corporate financing and expenses and income taxes in the fiscal year ended Jan. 31, compared with a corresponding loss of $3.4million in the previous year.

title: Guards Criticized But Not Indicted in Inmate's Death
description: TRENTON, April 24  The grand jury that investigated the scalding death of a 21yearold inmate at the Trenton State Prison said in a report made public today that two guards had failed to use good judgment in the incident but had not been indicted partly because of a lack of clearcut operating procedures at the prison.

title: SMALLCAR SNARE HAS LEVELED OFF
description: DETROIT, April 24  The massive shift toward small cars that began last fall because of the energy crisis has leveled off in the last several months and there had been a slight recovery of the sale of big cars.

title: DEMOCRATS FAVOR PRJCECUR ACTION
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 Senate Democrats, in a change that reflected mounting anxiety about inflation and its effect on the November elections, endorsed today a limited extension of authority for wageprice controls.

title: INDIANS SCORE ES, ON PEATHERS CASE
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M. April 24  Several American dian groups have expressed fears that the Federal Govern nient may be seeking to sup press their religious culture by arresting Indian curio dealers on charges of selling or possessing for sale the feathers of migratory birds.

title: Net Up for P. & G., Colgate and Squibb
Autopsy Shows Probasco Girl Drowned
description: WEST DEPTFORD, April 24 An autopsy performed by the state's Chief Medical Examiner, Dr. Edwin Albano, showed today that 4yearold Brenda Probasco died of asphyxiation by drowning, and that the body had been in the water possibly since the child disappeared from her home here 14 days ago.

title: Business Briefs
description: Venezuela Studying Oil Companies

title: Plight of Jews in Syria Cited
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 24The chief rabbi of Israel, Ovadia Yossef, met with Secretary General Waldheim today and expressed deep concern over the plight of the Jewish community in Syria.

title: Douglas to Speak Here
description: United States Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas will help open the fourth annual Bronx Week, Borough President Robert Abrams said yesterday.

title: Brifge:
description: The Metropolitan Commercial League Team championship for 197374 has ended, not unexpectedly, in a victory for the strong Metropolitan Life team. The diagramed deal from one of their matches brings out some delicate points in play.

title: EISliafel Advances
description: ST. LOUIS. April 24 (AP) Ismail ElShafei of Egypt overcame a flare of temper in the opening set and went on to upset sixthseeded Raul Ramirez of Mexico, 63, 64 in the $50,000 W.C.T. Holton tennis tournament today.

title: Knicks Eliminated
description: The New York Knicks lost to the Boston Celtics last night, 10594, and were eliminated from the National Basketball Association playoffs, 4 games to 1. The Celtics will meet the Milwaukee Bucks for the league championship. Details on Page 51.

title: Postal Nominee Gains
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) The Senate Post Office and Civil Service Committee approved today the nomination of Robert E. Holding of Cheyenne, Wyo., for a new term on the board of governors of the United States Postal Service, Mr. Holder was nominated by President Nixon for a term that expires in December, 1982.

title: Compensation Urged for Landowners Injured by Environmental Limitations
description: HARRIMAN, N. Y., April 22 A new voice of lamentation in the land is the downzoned property owner, the person whose land value has diminished because of environmental or other constraints.

title: ISRAEL CENSURED IN U. N. COUNCIL
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 24The Security Council adopted tonight a resolution that condemned Israel for what it called violation of Lebanon's territorial integrity and also decried all acts of violence but did not mention the recent guerrilla attack on the Israeli village of Qiryat Shemona.

title: Consumer Notes
description: If you have a credit or charge card of any kind, you have noticed that the envelope that contains your bill usually contains a lot of special offers as well. Even between bills, you undoubtedly receive special offers.

title: Mrs. Streit Advances to Semifinals
description: PINEHURST, N. C., April 24 (AP)Mrs. Marlene Stewart Streit, Mrs. Nancy Roth Syms and two youthful challengers, Lancy Smith and Pat O'Brien, won two matches apiece today to reach the North and South amateur golf tournament semifinals. The defending champion, Beth Barry, was beaten in the second round.

title: Fu Tsoyi, Who Surrendered Peking in '49, Dies
description: HONG KONG, April 24Fu Tsoyi, a popular Nationalist general who surrendered Peking to the Communists in January, 1949, died there last week at the age of 79.

title: Metzenbaum Lists Income Of $3Million in 19601973
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 24 (AP)Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, disclosed today that he had paid $725,004 in Federal income tax on an adjusted gross income of $3,067,753 for the years 19601973.

title: 5 Police Employes Held On Marijuana Charges
description: Five civilian employes of the Police Department were arrested last night in the vicinity of Police Headquarters during a meal break and charged with possession of marijuana. Two were also charged with possession of deadly weapons: 5inch gravity knives.

title: Mrs. Meir Sees Peace With Arabs, But Not in Her Life
description: TEL AVIV, April 24I really and truly believe the time will come when our neighbors will live with us in peace, Premier Golda Meir said tonight on Israeli television.

title: PRICES STEADY ON BOND MARKETS
description: Prices steadied yesterday in quiet trading in the corporate, tax  exempt and Government bond markets in what specialists described as something of a technical upturn. In the shortterm money markets, however, the current upward, movement to a 10 per cent prime rate level broadened to inelude New York and California banking giants.

title: KayserRoth to Buy Stock
description: The KayserRoth Corporation, the diversified apparel maker, said yesterday that it would purchase from time to time an additional 150,000 shares of its common stock. The company's board earlier this year authorized two purchases of 300,000 common shares and these have already been bought.

title: 1,000 More Win Merit Scholarships
SPATE SCHOOL AID REPORTED RAISED
description: ALBANY, April 24  Governor Wilson was reported today to have accepted the demands of suburban Republican legislators for $27million to $34million more in state aid to local school districts. The increase would be in addition to a $42million rise agreed upon last Friday and would lift the supplemental aid package $290million to $297million.

title: Record Net Seen In Second Quarter By Union Carbide
description: The Union Carbide Corporation told its shareholders yesterday that earnings in the second quarter would remain near the record high levels of the first quarter, but he indicated strongly that there would be every sharp price increases for its products.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The body of Rabbi Elliot D. Waldman, 46yearold spiritual leader of Temple EmanuEl in Utica, was discovered Tuesday in Kayuta Lake in northern Oneida County by a state trooper.

title: Celtics Beat Knicks and Take East Title
description: BOSTON, April 24  The Knicks, who have been an erratic team throughout the National Basketball Association season, saved their worst for last tonight. They suffered a virtually complete offensive breakdown in the first six minutes of the final quarter and were trampled by the Boston Celtics, 10594.

title: CAIRO SAYS SADAT WAS RAID TARGET
description: CAIRO, April 24The Egyptian Government declared today that a group of extremists who attacked a military academy here a week ago had intended to arrest President Anwar elSadat and to overthrow his Government.

title: U.N. Condemns Israel
description: The United Nations Security Council, by a vote of 13 to 0, adopted last night a resolution condemning Israel for violation of Lebanon's territorial integrity and also deploring all acts of violence, Details on Page 6.

title: SCHLESINGER SET TO CUT ATOM ARMS
description: WASHINGTON, April 24

title: Belmonte On Victory Trail Again
description: Eddie Belmonte was in a happy mood at Aqueduct yesterday. He had just scored with Leo Fink's Dr. Eyego in the opening race at $19.80 for $2 and the Puerto Rican jockey was convinced  for the second time this year  that he was on the way to an outstanding season.

title: Recital
description: It took only the opening chords of Bach's Fantasia and Fugue in A minor played and pedaled to give a special sense of shifting harmonic colorto remind one on Tuesday night how fine a pianist Grant Johannesen is. The occasion was his recital as another distinguished performer in the series now celebrating the centennial of the 92d Street Y.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Tomorrow, April 26

title: Knicks Eliminated
description: The New York Knicks lost to the Boston Celtics last night, 10594, and were eliminated from the National Basketball Association playoffs, 4, games to 1. The Celtics will meet the Milwaukee Bucks for the league championship. Details on Page 51.

title: TEACHING IS FIRST AS CAREER CHOICE
description: The Gallup Poll has found that teaching is the top choice of college students, with nearly one in fouror 23 per centindicating that that is the field they plan to enter.

description: BASEBALL

title: SCOPE OP INQUIRY ON IMPEACHMENT MAY BE NARROWED
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 Lawyers for the House Judiciary Committee will propose tomorrow that the scope of the impeachment inquiry be narrowed sharply to include only the most serious potential charges of wrongdoing by Preslident Nixon.

title: Oil: Fat City
description: The firstquarter profit returns of the oil companies are coming in, and the results are staggeringa mirror image of the prices that consumers are paying. Exxon was, in a sense, low with a gain of only 39 per cent and firstquarter earnings of $705 million. Texaco was up 123 per cent to $589 million, Gulf up 76 per cent to $290 million, and Indiana Standard up 81 per cent to $121 million. Occidental Petroleum, a relative pygmy, increased its firstquarter earnings by 718 per cent.

title: The Opera
description: Should opera for the young try to be relevant? The question has for some time bothered the board of directors of the Metropolitan Opera Guild, which has in the past presented traditional repertory in the schools in its educationalrogram. Capsule versions of Rossini's The Barber of Seville, Mozart's Cosl fan tutte and Puccini's Gianni Schicchi have met with varying success.

title: $500Million Aid to Coned Is Agreed Upon in Albany
description: ALBANY, April 24The leaders of the Legislature have reached agreement on a plan to have the Power Authority of the State of New York buy two Consolidated Edison generating plants at a total cost of nearly $500million.

title: Harlem Dance Theater Gives Haiku
description: The many sides of the Dance Theater of Harlem were on view Tuesday night at the ANTA Theater as the company presented the third program of its season.

title: Weather Reports and Forecast
DEMOCRATS FAVOR PRICECURB ACTION
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 Senate Democrats, in a change that reflected mounting anxiety about inflation and its effect on the November elections, endorsed today a limited extension of authority for wageprice controls.

title: European Football
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE First Division

title: Market Place: Review Urged Of Stocks Held
description: Several recently announced changes in the status of some corporation securities have emphasized the growing complexity of investing for the individual.

title: U.S. AGENCY HALTS SALES OF 28 SPRAYS
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (UPI)The Environmental Protection Agency issued today a rare emergency order to halt the sale of 28 pesticide sprays containing vinyl chloride, a chemical linked to a rare form of liver cancer.

title: Critics of Veterans Administration Say Ouster of Johnson as Chief Won't End Public Uproar Over Policies
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 Some members of Congress and leaders of veterans' groups con tend that the dismissal of Don aid E. Johnson as head of the Veterans Administration is no likely to stem the public up roar over programs and policies on veterans.

title: STIVELL FASCINATES IN HIS CELTICROCK
description: Fascinating are the folk trails contained in the Celtic music of a young Breton musician, Alan Stivell, who made his American debut at Hunter College on Tuesday, a performance as noteworthy for high musical interest as for his ability to get his audience on its feet, snaking around the auditorium in long, handholding lines.

title: Congress Is Asked to Bar rocks Dam
description: WASHINGTON, April 24Representative Joseph J. Maraziti, Republican of New Jersey, said today the longdelayed Tocks Island Dam should never be built because NeNy York State would never be able to keep from polluting the reservoir the dam would create.

title: Alumni to Hail Performing Arts School at 25
description: In a secondfloor studio of the High School of Performing Arts, Maria O'Neill was wearing what she indicated with gestures of her hunched shoulders was a shawl or a blanket. She took it off and handed it to the girl to her left, who took it apart and braided its strands. The girl next to her made the braid into a necklace and the next girl in the circle fashioned a ponytail out of the necklace. It then became in the hands of two successive girls, a bow and a ball. The next girl bounced the ball, the next hollowed it into a clay vessel and passed it to Ed Shellman, who created a flower vase of it, then gave it to the girl on his left who made it into a widemouthed bowl. It became a pizza in the hands of the next young student and finally, the last girl made it into a shoe.

title: Agitate Derby Bound
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 24 (UPI)Agitate, the California Derby winner, will be shipped from Hollywood Park Monday to Louisville for the 100th running of the Kentucky Derby May 4, his trainer, Timmy Jiminez, said yesterday. He's a dead fit horse so he doesn't need much work between now and the Derby, said Jiminez. Agitate will be ridden in the Derby by Willie Shoemaker.

title: 150 Keep Vigil for Lathers' Union Permits
description: Alongside a sort of shantytown that has been forming on East 76th Street since Easter weekend, some 150 unskilled youths and older men lined up yesterday to answer to their own selfimposed daily 6 A.M. and 6 P.M. rollcalls.

title: A.B.C. Cuts 10 Night Shows And Favors Fare for Families
description: The American Broadcasting Company has canceled 10 primetime programs for next fall and will introduce a dozen new series, many concerned with ethnic minorities, family relationships, or both.

title: BODIES RECOVERED IN BALI JET CRASH
description: TINGA TINGA, Indonesia, April 24  Indonesian Army Rangers today began trying to firing out the bodies of the 107 persons who died Monday night when a Pan American World Airways jet crashed into a mountain in this heavily jungled area.

title: BOTH SIDES SUM UP IN MITCHELL TRIAL
description: John N. Mitchell and Maurice H. Stens sat at the very pinnacle of government in this country and thought they were above the law, the Government charged yesterday in its summation to the jury in the Mitchell Stans criminal conspiracy trial.

title: CONTINENTAL OIL RAISES NET 130%
description: The Continental Oil Company, eighth largest of the nation's oil companies, reported yesterday a 130 per cent increase in profits for the first quarter as the industry continued to show huge gains over its 1973 performance.

title: Panel Questions Weinberger on Nixon's Health Plan
description: WASHINGTON, April 24The House Ways and Means Committee set off a new round of Congressional hearings into national health insurance today by questioning Caspar W. Weinberger, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, for five hours about details of the Administration's proposal.

title: BISHOPS IN CHILE DENOUNCE JUNTA
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 24The Roman Catholic church of Chile today issued a declaration accusing the military junta of the use of torture, arbitrary and lengthy detentions, of causing large scale unemployment, of making job dismissals for political reasons, and of establishing an economic policy that church leaders said had shifted the burden to the poor.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Income Tax: A Fair Levy Perverted

title: Hospital Volunteers Who Pay for the Privilege
description: Hospitals have always been a magnet for volunteers, and Bellevue, that sprawling municipal complex of wards, has drawn its full share of them. One man has been helping out there for 36 years; high school pupils have been known to devote their Christmas holidays to the place.

title: Air Security Zone Is Set Up To Protect White House
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) The head of the Federal Aviation Administration says a new security buffer zone has been designated around the White House to guard against intrusion by unauthorized aircraft.

title: Rep. Burke's Home Looted
description: LOS ANGELES, April 24, (UPI)Burglars pried open the front door of the home here of Representative Yvonne Bratty waite Burke, Democrat of California, and stole $16,000 worth of property, the Sheriff's Department reported yesterday.

title: Bruins Beat Hawks, 52 Series Even
description: CHICAGO, April 25 (UPI) Phil Esposito beat his brother, Tony, for a powerplay goal in the second period tonight, providing the decisive score in the Boston Bruins' 52 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks. The triumph by Boston tied the fourofsevengame Stanley Cup playoff series at two victories apiece.

title: War in Africa Eroded Stability
description: LISBON, April 25Portugal's effort to preserve her overseas territories produced a steady demoralization that eroded the country's political and social stability and led to today's coup against the government of Premier Marcello Caetano.

title: Monsanto Dividend Up 2d Time in 9 Months.
description: Reflecting an unusually strong performance in 1973 and the first quarter of 1974, the Monsanto Company yesterday raised its quarterly dividend for the second time in nine months.

title: CARRIER RAISING APPLIANCE PRICES
description: The Carrier Corporation, the nation's largest manufacturer of airconditioning systems, announced a 7 per cent increasesi in the price of its 1974 room airconditioning units, effective Monday. The announcement nouncement was accompanied by an industry projection that airconditioner sales would increase this year despite the energy shortage and a hint that other manufacturers would raise prices.

title: Out From Behind the Desk and Into the Spotlight Temporarily
description: She comes in all shapes and sizes. She's a 20yearold in a miniskirt who finds that a fringe benefit of her job is the chance to meet a young executive. Or she's past 40, prone to print dresses and a bit hippy from years of sitting behind a Smith Corona.

title: New York Stock Exchange Transactions
Turco Is Given One Year For IncomeTax Evasion
description: NEWARK, April 25 (UPI)A Federal judge sentenced the former Newark City Council President, Louis M. Turco, to one year in prison today on tax charges stemming from Mr. Turco's gambling debts.

title: 2 Units of A.T.&T. Register Increases In Revenue and Net
description: The New York Telephone Company and the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company, two major subsidiaries of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, reported yesterday increased revenues and net income for their first quarter.

title: Birthday News Is Bitter for Options Board
description: CHICAGO, April 25  The Chicago Board Options Exchange, the world's first securities market devoted exclusively to trading stock options, is a year old today.

title: Hollander Plays Gershwin in an Unusual Recital
description: It was a rather unusual program that Lorin Hollander played in Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night, and he played it in a rather unusual manner. Not many years ago the inclusion of Gershwin pieces in a piano recital would have been received with little yips of horror in the serious set. But things have loosened, and such previously scorned composers as Gottschalk and Joplin are assuming a place in the repertory. Even Moszkowski is coming back. Gershwin belongs just as well.

title: Australian, Miss Casals Gain at Net
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 25 Kerry Melville of Australia and Rosemary Casals of San Francisco scored straightset victories tonight and gained the quarterfinal round of a $50,000 Virginia Slims of Philadelphia tennis tournament at the Palestra. They will meet tomorrow.

title: Simon Supported Refinery Proposal Aided by Uncle
description: An uncle of William E. Simon, the former Federal energy administrator who is President Nixon's nominee for Secretary of the Treasury, is a consultant to the company backing a disputed oil refinery near Eastport, Me. Mr. Simon has strongly supported the construction despite opposition from environmentalists.

title: An Aide to Brandt Is Arrested as a Spy
description: BONN, April 25An aide of Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany was arrested last night on suspicion of being a spy for East Germany.

title: U.S.BONN ACCORD ON TROOPS SIGNED
description: WASHINGTON, April 25the United States and West Germany signed an agreement today under which Bonn will provide $2.218billion to offset the cost of maintaining 197,000 American troops in Germany.

title: KISSINGER TO MEET GROMYKO ON SUNDAY
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 Secretary of State Kissinger will confer in Geneva on Sunday and Monday with Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko, before beginning a Middle East trip that may last more than two weeks, the State Department said.

title: Newspapers and Printers Focus Talks on Automation
description: Negotiators for the printers and the city's three major daily newspapers concentrated yesterday on problems related to the proposed introduction of automated typesetting processes as the typographical union's slowdown at The Daily News continued for, the eighth day.

title: Philbin, Giants' Campbell to Join Stars
description: Carter Campbell signed with another New York team, Gerry Philbin ended a retirement without missing a game, George Allen held a practice that almost every top player skipped, and a football team made Charlie Harraway and Paul Robinson two of the richest people in Birmingham.

title: PORTUGAL'S ARMY SEIZES CONTROL AND PROCLAIMS DEMOCRATIC GOAL; CAETANO'S SURRENDER ANNOUNCED
description: LISBON, April 25Portugal's effort to preserve her overseas territories produced a steady demoralization that eroded the country's political and social stability and led to today's coup against the government of Premier Marcello Caetano.

title: Rangers Defeat Flyers, 53, Trail, 21, in Brawling Series
People in Sports
description: The Atlanta Hawks have been discussing a possible trade with New Orleans, the latest expansion club in the National Basketball Association. But there may be a major hitch in the deal. Pete Maravich, the player to be traded, may not go along with the transaction and Pistol Pete has a notradewithoutapproval clause in his Hawks' contract. Maravich, who just finished the fourth season of a fiveseason contract with the Hawks at $300,000 a year, is very distressed, according to his attorney, Lester Zittrain. Pat Williams, general manager of the Hawks, indicated the trade would take place if Pistol Pete eventually agreed to it.

title: Beame Strolls Streets To Show They're Safe
description: Mayor Beame strolled the Lower East Side last night to persuade New Yorkers that streets crowded with people are streets safe from crime.

title: NIXON STILL USING TAXDISPUTE AIDES
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 Two of the men to whom the White House has assigned responsibility for any errors in President Nixon's income tax returns are continuing to assist him in his personal financial dealings.

title: Tides Around New York
description: For high tide at Asbury Park and Belmar, deduct 34 min. from Sandy Hook time. For high tide at Atlantic City (Steel Pier), deduct 26 min. from Sandy Hook time.

title: Yankees Fuss and Lose, 61
description: The kind of defensive collapse that can be expected by the Yankees more than occasionally this season led to a 61 loss to Kansas City and an exchange of words between the manager and his starting pitcher yesterday.

title: Marijuana Vote Urged
description: BOSTON, April 25 (UPI)The Massachusetts Senate has tentatively approved legislation calling for a public referendum before the year ends on whether to legalize marijuana.

title: Recently Published Books
description: FICTION

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS
description: New York731832

title: Arthur Browning Dies at 65; Life Insurance Executive
description: Arthur Malcolm Browning, a retired vice president of group insurance for the New York Life Insurance Company, died yesterday of a heart attack at the Manhasset (L.I.) Medical Center. He was 65 years old and lived in Manhasset.

title: Vote Case Dropped
description: Manhattan District Attorney Richard H. Kuh yesterday dropped an electionfraud case against Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea but asked the state for reform laws that would bar the sort of dirty tricks that had been alleged against Mr. Duryea and five Republican colleagues. Page 10.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: HACKENSACK, April 25The Hackensack High School Sports Hall of Fame will induct nine former graduates tomorrow night, bringing its total to 323 men, and women. Those to be inducted are George Gereghty, Class of 1918; his brother Edward, Class of 1920; Monroe Ward, 1921; Cornelius Breen, 1921; the late John Schoonmaker, 1921; Pat DiZenzo, 1932; Darryl Harris, 1969; Douglas Tremp, 1969; and Armando Insignares, 1969.

title: Samara Captures Decathlon
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 25 Fred Samara of the New York Athletic Club dominated the second day and set a meet record today as he captured the Penn Relays decathlon. Samara's total of 7,864 points eclipsed the record set last year by Ron Evans of Connecticut at 7,819.

title: 13 SEIZED IN RAIDS ON NARCOTICS TRADE
description: Thirteen persons were arrested and four pounds of heroin was seized last night in separate police actions in Queens and Manhattan, each the culmination of sixmonth investigations into drug trafficking.

title: ExAstronaut on High Flight as Evangelistic Leader
description: COLORADO SPRINGSJames B. Irwin, who walked on the moon nearly three years ago, stood holding a microphone, his other hand in the pocket of his navy, goldbuttoned jacket.

title: Dining: Off to India By the Short Route
description: Gaylord, a new Indian restaurant at 50 East 58th Street, is one of a chain with links in New Delhi, Bombay and London, and you might be in any of those places the minute you step through the door. New York vanishes behind you. Whether or not some decorator of genius set out to create this AngloIndian atmosphere or whether it just happened, I can't say, but there it isstrictly pukka, at once exotic and sturdy.

title: An Exhausted Fonda Collapses After Show
description: Henry Fonda collapsed in his dressing room at the Helen Hayes Theater on Tuesday night after a performance of his oneman show, Clarence Darrow.

title: Guild at Washington Post Returns After 16 Days
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP)  Editorial and commercial employes of The Washington Post returned to work today, ending a 16day strike.

title: Nixon Is Greeted Warmly By 10,000 in Mississippi
description: JACKSON, Miss., April 25President Nixon received rousing applause from 10,000 people and words of comfort from the Democratic Governor of Mississippi today when he delivered a speech promising peace and prosperity for a generation.

title: South Korean C.I.A. Queries 240 In Alleged Plot to Remove Park
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 25  The South Korean Central Intelligence Agency announced today that about 240 people were under investigation in connection with an underground student organization that allegedly attempted to overthrow the Government.

title: OFFSHORE STUDY HELD INADEQUATE
description: WASHINGTON, April 25  A committee of the National Academy of Sciences has called a study on environmental risks of offshore oil development in the Gulf of Alaska and along the Atlantic coast a useful first step but inadequate and incomplete.

title: Howerton Named Coach
description: FORT WORTH, April 25 (AP)  Johnny Howerton, a former basketball player at Hardin  Simmons University, was named head coach at Texas Wesleyan College today. Howerton, 40 years old, succeeds Al Peters, who resigned on March 6.

title: FINANCINGARRANGED IN CUBAN PURCHASE
description: OTTAWA, April 25The Export Development Corporation, an autonomous arm of official Canadian trade policy, concluded a loan of 17.9million to the National Bank of Cubali today to finance most of a Cuban purchase of railway locomotives and other equipment from an Americanowned company in Montreal, MLWWorthington, Ltd.

title: MARKET WEAKENS AS INTEREST RISES
description: Rising interest rates and their implications for the economy continued to weaken stock prices yesterday as the trading pace slowed slightly.

title: Output of U.S. Workers Worst Drop Since '47
description: Earnings of United States corporations in the first quarter of 1974 were 24 per cent higher than a year earlier but 4 per cent lower than in the fourth quarter of 1973, the First National City Bank reported yesterday. The biggest dollar gain in profits compared with last year was reported by the petroleum industry, which had a 72 per cent increase in aftertax earnings.

title: Wednesday's Fight
description: Las Vegas, Nev.Beto Gonzalez, 147 pounds, Las Vegas, knocked out Frankie Kolovart, 152, Phoenix, 6 rounds.

title: Howerton Named Coach
description: FORT WORTH, April 25 (AP)  Johnny Howerton, former basketball player at Hardin  Simmons University, was named head coach at Texas Wesleyan College today. Howerton, 40 years old, succeeds Al Peters, who resigned on March 6.

title: British Stop 2 Armed
description: LONDON, April 25 (R?? Two Arabs going to ?? were detained at Lo?? Heathrow Airport tonight being found with a rifle, a tomatic pistol, and ammur on a flight from Boston, British Home Office said.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Dempsey Restaurant Battle Settled

title: About New York
description: You're a Colonial historian? a man who ought to have known better asked. No, mostly I write books about the twenties, the other man answered. He was Matthew Josephson, and among other things he had written The Robber Barons. Chastened, the first man turned to talk to someone else.

title: Nixon Is Greeted Warmly By 10,000 in Mississippi
description: JACKSON, Miss., April 25President Nixon received rousing applause from 10,000 people and words of comfort from the Democratic Governor of Mississippi today when he delivered a speech promising peace and prosperity for a generation.

title: Rep. Conyers Asks Inquiry On Law Enforcement Aid
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI)  Representative John Conyers, Jr. Democrat of Michigan, says that no one knows how the state's are spending $1billion in Federal law enforcement aid, and he wants to investigate.

title: Aaron's 2Run Homer Gives Braves Victory
description: Henry Aaron's homerun record was broken again last nightby Henry Aaron, who else? He hit his 718th career homer, and it lifted the Atlanta Braves to a 32 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: PORTUGAL'S ARMY SEIZES CONTROL AND PROCLAIMS DEMOCRATIC GOAL; CAETANO'S SURRENDER ANNOUNCED
description: LISBON, Friday, April 26A group of army officers, proclaiming a desire to bring democracy to Portugal and peace to her African territories, seized control of the country, yesterday and announced the end of more than 40 years of authoritarian rule.

title: Campaign Controls Voted In Jersey and Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, April 25Both houses of the Connecticut General Assembly have voted overwhelmingly to regulate campaign contributions and spending and, by narrower margins, to prohibit campaign contributions by labor organizations, business and civic associations and all other standing institutions except party political committees.

title: Notes on People
description: A 51yearold San Francisco shipping executive, Norman Scott, is said to be President Nixon's leading choice to succeed John W. Warner as Secretary of the Navy. Administration sources said that Mr. Scott, who is president of American President Lines, was being cleared with key members of the Congress, a sure sign he has the inside track for the nomination.

title: Vorster Widens Margin in South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 25 (Reuters)Prime Minister John Vorster's Nationalist party, as expected, has won its 26th year of uninterrupted power in South Africa with a slightly increased majority but a possibly more dynamic though still divided Opposition.

title: N.B.A. Championship
description: Boston vs. Milwaukee

title: MitchellStans Case Is Given to the Jury
Theater: Ionescopade
description: People will say that my plays are music hall turns or circus acts, says Eugene Ionesco. So much the betterlet's include the circus in the theater!

title: 95 Judger Is First in Blue Grass
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., April 25 The 50th running of the Blue Grass Stakes today served to reestablish Judger's status as a strong contender for the Kentucky Derby a week from Saturday.

title: Events Today
description: NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC, Avery Fisher Hall, 2.

title: The Tightening Coils
description: If anything, the House Judiciary Committee has seemed overcautious in its inquiry into the possible impeachment of Richard Nixon; but the undeniable result has been that the committee has remained reasonably unified across party lines, and mostly immune to the criticisms and counteroffensives of the White House. Now the committee staff has made another good move in recommending to the members that the scope of the inquiry be greatly scaled down from the 56 original allegations.

title: HEARSTS DOUBTFUL DESPITE NEVI TAPE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 25 It was Patricia Hearst's strongest language yet, but her tape recorded message yesterday again failed to convince her family and law enforcement officials that she had joined the underground group purportedly responsible for kidnapping her.

title: Output of U.S. Workers In Worst Drop Since '47
description: WASHINGTON, April 25Productivity in the American economythat is, output per workerhourrecorded its largest decline in the first quarter since productivity statistics were first compiled in 1947.

title: New Motorman
description: The designation as chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority of David L. Yunich, a businessman with a highly developed sense of civic responsibility, is welcome for reasons that go beyond the attendant assurance that the New York City transit system will be kept free of partisan politics.

title: Black Paper Backs Wallace Saying He Has Softened
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 25 (UPI)Gov. George Wallace was endorsed for reelection today by The Birmingham Times, a black newspaper.

title: Allin Cards 66 to Take Stroke Lead
description: CARLSBAD, Calif., April 25Some of golf's most glamorous and currently successful names teed off today in the 22d annual Tournament of Champions, and one of the least glamorous and most selfeffacing members of the pro tour came in with the best firstround score: Brian (Bud) Allin, with a 66.

title: 17 Saigon Army Trainees Are Killed in Mortar Attack
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 26 (AP)  Communist forces fired five mortar rounds into the auditorium of a Government military training center nine miles north of Saigon last night, killing 17 trainees and wounding 118, the South Vietnamese command reported.

title: $13Million Space Fund Rise Voted by House, 341 to 37
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI)  The House passed and sent to the Senate today authorization for a $3.26billion new space budget, $13million more than the Administration requested.

title: Penn Relays Open Today With Field of Fast Stars
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 25  Steve Williams of San Diego State says he has been saving himself this spring for the races that really count.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CINCINNATI, April 25 (AP)  A court hearing on the Cincinnati Bengals' request for a preliminary injunction against the World. Football League will be held Monday as scheduled, a Federal judge ruled today. United States District Judge David Porter refused to rule on a Bengals' request that the hearing be postponed and a temporary restraining order be extended indefinitely past its Monday expiration date.

title: Corporate Demand Drops For Bank Loans in Week
description: Corporate demand for bank loans dropped sharply in the week ended Wednesday, as the Federal Reserve stepped up the pressure and made credit conditions tighter than they had been since late September.

title: PAPERS WARNED OF RADIOTV CURB
description: The nation's newspaper publishersi were warned yesterday of newly revived Administration efforts to bar them from owning radio and television stations. Their counsel urged them to seek protective legislation coming up in the House of Representatives next week.

title: City Planning Aide to Head Midtown Development Office
description: Richard G. Lam Jr., head of the regional planning and transportation division of the Department of City Planning, was appointed by Mayor Beame yesterday as director of the Office of Midtown Planning and Development.

title: FUTURES UP LIMIIT ON CHICAGO BOARD
description: In an unusual price surge, ?? wheat, corn and soybean futures contracts on the Chicago Board of Trade jumped the daily permissible limits yesterday. The reason was lowerthanexpected estimates of carryovers issued by the Department of Agriculture late on Wednesday after the close of trading.

title: U.S. Mideast Policy Shift Seen at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 25Diplomats here view the United States vote last night for a Security Council resolution condemning an Israeli reprisal attack on Lebanon as a new development in Washington policy.

title: Cabinet Is Shuffled by Sadat To Put Stress on Development
description: CAIRO, Friday, April 26President Anwar elSadat named a new Cabinet last night, retaining for himself the Premiership but appointing the Finance and Economy Minister, AbdelAziz Hegazi as First Deputy Premier, a post that did not exist before.

title: Senate Approves Provision For NoFault Plans in Effect
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI)The Senate voted today to allow states that have nofault automobile insuranceor those who have it by 1975up to four years to comply with a proposed national law.

title: Doar Says Inquiry Is Concentrating on 7 Areas of Allegations Against Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, April 25John M. Doar, chief counsel of the House Judiciary Committeeapos;s impeachment inquiry, said publicly today that his staff was concentrating its investigation on seven broad areas of allegations against President Nixon.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 26, 1974 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Jersey City Police Official Among 4 Indicted in Bribes
description: TRENTON, April 25  Two state grand jury indictments accusing a Jersey City deputy police chief, a West New York lawyer and two other men with bribery and obstruction of justice were announced today following separate investigations of police corruption in Hudson County.

title: How the Teams Stand Today Friday, April 26, 1974
description: American League WEDNESDAY NIGHT

title: Lisbon's GeneralCritic Antonio Sebastiao Ribeiro de Spinola
description: Since he returned from beleaguered Portuguese Guinea to a hero's welcome in Lisbon 18 months ago, Gen. Antnio Sebastio. Ribeiro de Spinola has figured prominently in speculation about Portugal's future. Though hardly a liberal by international standards, the 64  year  old cavalryman has been the prime mover in a month of debate and unrest that culminated in yesterday's coup against a firmly entrenched dictatorship. It would surprise few observers if he became Portugal's new strongman.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Mrs. Manley Poses A Problem in Names
description: Because she is highly respected in her fielddirect marketingMrs. Joan Manley, publisher of TimeLife Books and the first woman vice president of Time Inc., has given her industry a special problem. And it's one that hasn't been adequately resolved.

title: The Pop Life
description: New York state officials who witnessed the 600,000plus crowd at the Watkins Glen festival last summer are expressing great skepticism that the state would allow any more mass gatherings unless a promoter could satisfy their worries over health facilities, crowd control and emergency vehicle access.

title: EDITORIAL UNIT ASKS AN INQUIRY OF LASKY
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI)A group of newspaper editorial writers has asked the National News Council to investigate the possibility of conflict of interest by the syndicated columnist Victor Lasky.

title: Vote Case Dropped
description: Manhattan District Attorney Richard H. Kuh yesterday dropped an electionfraud case against Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea but asked the state for reform laws that would bar the sort of dirty tricks that had been alleged against Mr. Duryea and five Republican colleagues. Page 10.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Public Service Electric and Gas Company has issued a letter of intent to award a contract for construction of the breakwater for its proposed offshore, floating nuclear power plant to the Drava Corporation of Pittsburgh. The American Dredging Company and the Gates Construction Corporation of Little Ferry, N. J., will be associated in the project whose cost will be more than $200million. The breakwater will be the largest manmade structure ever placed in the ocean and will be located 2.8 miles in the Atlantic Ocean about 12 miles northeast of Atlantic City.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Today, April 26

title: Celtics Happy to Win but Wary of Bucks
description: I'm very happy, but winning this series is just overcoming another obstacle on the way to our goal, said John Havlicek of the Boston Celtics Wednesday night after Boston eliminated the Knicks from the National Basketball Association playoffs, 10594, at Boston Garden.

title: BURMAH OR SETS GREAT PLAINS BID
description: The Burmah Oil Company announced yesterday in Toronto that it planned to make an offer for the 1.1 million shares of the Great Plains Development Company of Canada, Ltd., that it does not already own. Burmah also plans to redeem outstanding convertible debt of Great Plains. The two transactions would be valued at more than $77million. Burmah has owned some 2.1 million shares, or about 65 per cent, of Great Plains's 3.2 million shares outstanding since 1963. It plans to merge the Canadian company into its Burmah Oil Canada, Ltd., subsidiary. Burmah would pay minority holders of Great Plains $40 a share for their stock.

title: Soviet Junior Five Wins
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., April 25 (UPI)The Soviet Union's Naional Junior basketball team opened a 15point lead in the second hal fand hung on for a 9490 victory over the Long Island junior allwas led by Mike Palmer's 24 points. However, he connected on only 11 of 38 shots from the floor as Long Island hit on only 35 of 97 attempts.

title: Support for Kennedy Drops Among Democratic Leaders
description: BOSTON, April 25 (AP)Senator Edward M. Kennedy has suffered a dramatic dip in support for the 1976 Presidential nomination among Democratic party leaders, according to a survey by The Christian Science Monitor.

title: POLICE DISPUTED ON GUN PENALTIES
description: The Administrative Judge of New York City yesterday questioned the validity of a Police Department report issued last September that said violators of guncontrol laws stood an increased chance of escaping Conviction and imprisonment.

title: Issues in Papers Dispute
description: PARTICIPANTS: The New York Times, The Daily News and The New York Post, negotiating as the Publishers Association of New York City, and New York Typographical Union No. 6, representing 819 printers, including 170 substitutes, at The Times; 945 printers, including 200 to 220 substitutes, at The News; and 312 printers, including 38 substitutes, at The Post.

title: Merrill Meeting: Very Little Thunder
description: There was very little thunder at the annual meeting of Merrill Lynch & Co. yesterday as Donald T. Regan, the chairman, rode herd on the wounded bears.

title: Off Off Broadway
description: It is advisable to telephone theaters for schedules and prices. Most, if not all, theaters accept Theater Development Fund vouchers.

title: ROBERT E. DEMPSEY, STATE JUSTICE, DIES
description: Justice Robert E. Dempsey of the State Supreme Court died yesterday of cancer in Roswell Park Memorial Institute, Buffalo. He was 70 years old and lived in Peekskill, N.Y.

title: MitchellStans Case Is Given to the Jury
description: A jury of nine men and three women began deliberations yesterday in the case against John N. Mitchell, the former Attorney General, and Maurice H. Stans, the former Commerce Secretary, accused of attempting to impede a Federal inquiry in return for a secret $200,000 cash contribution to President Nixon's reelection campaign.

title: Pierpont Morgan's Taste In Art Illuminates a Show
description: When very clever people get angry, they are just as silly as everyone else. This infer from what Roger Fry had to say about Pierpont Morgan. Fry was the most influential English art critic of his day, and in 1905 he could have gone to the National Gallery in London as director. He chose to come and work at the Metropolitan Museum of Art instead, and there was just no way he could get along with Morgan, who was then the museum's redoubtable president. Fry wrote home of Morgan that a crude historical imagination is the only flaw in his otherwise perfect insensibility.

title: Books of The Times
description: CRUEL AND UNUSUAL JUSTICE. By Jack Newfield. 205 pages. Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $7.95.

title: Chilly Spring in Soviet Causing Concern Over Crop Prospects
description: MOSCOW, April 25A cold damp spring has delayed plantling and prompted some official concerns about the weather's ultimate impact on the harvest.

title: Fielstoski Denies Getting ImmigrationBill Payoffs
description: HACKENSACK, April 25Representative Henry Helstoski, Democrat of the Ninth District, said tonight that he would meet tomorrow with Jonathan L. Goldstein, the United States Attorney for New Jersey, and deny he had received payoffs in return for sponsoring special immigration bills for aliens.

description: ACROSS

title: Greenwich Hotel in the Village Is Closed Down for Conversion
description: The seedy Greenwich Hotel, long denounced by its neighbors as a refuse for muggers, panhandlers and drug addicts in the heart of Greenwich Village, has been closed by its new owners, who hope to renovate it into luxury apartments.

title: Truck Tonnage Off in Week
description: WASHINGTON, April 25The American Trucking Association, Inc., reported today that intercity truck tonnage last week fell 1.5 per cent from the yearearlier week. Truck tonnage last week was down 1.2 per cent from the preceding week. The American Trucking Association, Inc., reported today that intercity truck tonnage last week fell 1.5 per cent from the yearearlier week. Truck tonnage last week was down 1.2 per cent from the preceding week.

title: Nine Football Rules Amended by Pros To Enliven Games
description: Sweeping rules changes were made yesterday in an effort to enliven the National Football League games. Not since 1933 has the sport been so drastically altered.

title: Wood, Field & Stream Brown Trout Gets Belated Plaudits
description: Many years ago when I was an undergraduate at Dartmouth College, I journeyed south for a few miles to fish for brown trout in the Mascoma River between Mascoma Lake and Lebanon, N.H.

title: News Summary and Index FRIDAY, APRIL 26, 1974
description: International

title: Times Sq, Arts Fair Set for Students
description: A sprawling arts exposition will turn the Times Square area into a vast stage next week as leaders and students in the performing and visual arts display their creations to thousands of careerminded high school and junior high school students.

title: Dacca Orders Crackdown
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, April 25 (AP)The Prime Minister, Sheik Mujibur Rahman, ordered a crackdown today on subversive elements. The Government announced that the purpose was to round up arms and ammunition and stop smuggling and hoarding of grain.

title: Wednesday's Fight
description: Las Vegas, Nev.Beto Gonzalez, 147 pounds, Las Vegas, knocked out Frankie Kolovart, 152, Phoenix, 6 rounds.

title: S. E. C. GIVES AMEX OPTION CONDITIONS
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 The American Stock Exchange was advised by the staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission today that it was prepared to recommend approval of the Amex pilot program of trading in stock options if certain major conditions could be met.

title: PRICES OF BONDS SHOW A DECLINE
2 DELTA FLIGHTS EXPOSED TO RAYS
description: WASHINGTON, April 25  Passengers on two Delta Airline flights that were carrying improperly packed radioisotopes in their cargo holds earlier this month received radiation doses up to 25 times the level considered generally acceptable for an entire year, officials of the Atomic Energy Commission said today.

title: Progress of Military Hailed by Proxmire
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP)Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, a frequent critic of military waste and cost overruns, gave the military top rating today for accomplishments in the last two decades.

title: Business Records
description: INVOLUNTARY PETITION FILED AGAINST: MISS GLAMOUR COAT COMPANY, INC., 265 W. 37th St, N.Y. Petitioners are Caesar & Co.; Deering Milliken, Inc., and Collins and the Aikman Corporation.

title: Bridge: Who Lead? If It's East's, This Must Be Grossinger's
description: Enthusiasts who attend regional championships are entitled to be confused by the 1974 scheduling.

title: U.S. Aides Expect Lisbon's Tie To NATO to Remain Unchanged
description: WASHINGTON, April 25Administration officials said today that they thought the overthrow of the Portuguese Government would probably have an important impact on Africa but would not lead to any changes in Portugal's adherence to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

description: Byrne Offers Teaching Hospital Plan

description: News Summary and Index, Page 39

title: Why Did a Harmless Dog Kill Boy? Officials in Suffolk Seek the Answer
description: EAST ISLIP, L. I., April 25Suffolk County officials sought todayby postmortem examination and questioning of witnessesto determine what had caused a Saint Bernard dog to attack and kill a 6yearold boy yesterday.

title: Codd Praises Cab Driver Who Returned Lost Items
description: Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd yesterday hailed an honest act by a taxi driver as typical of what cabbies do that goes totally unnoticed.

title: LEVITZ TO SOLICIT ELECTION PROXIES
description: Sidney A. Levitz, the former president of the Levitz Furniture Corporation, has indicated to the Securities and Exchange Commission his intent to solicit proxies in favor of his election to the Levitz board.
