description: BASEBALL

title: Art Valued at $19Million Stolen From Irish Mansion
description: BLESSINGTON, Ireland, Saturday, April 27A gang of armed art thieves directed by a young woman raided the mansion of a goldmining millionaire here late last night, tied up everyone in the house and got away with master1 pieces valued by the police at $19.2million.

title: Madeira, Exiles' Home, Resort Isle
description: Madeira, to which deposed Portuguese leaders have been exiled, is the largest island in the Madeira archipelago, about 400 miles off Africa and 600 miles southwest of Lisbon.

title: In Shift, Assembly Votes Simply to Suspend Surtax
description: ALBANY, April 26In a shift, the Assembly today voted to have the state retain the power to impose a 2.5 per cent surtax on personal income. It did so by simply suspending the tax for another year.

title: Concert: Da Capo Group
description: If composing were purely a matter of devising intellectually gratifying formal schemes, the new scores by Milton Babbitt and Harvey Sollberger that were played by the Da Capo Chamber Players at Alice, Tully Hall on Thursday night could be greeted with unfeigned admiration. But the better composers have always gone beyond the drawing of beautiful blueprints.

title: American League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Belger Runs 4:12.2 Mile, But Power Wins Relay
E.P.A. Is Fighting to Bar Shift of Gasoline Mileage Testing to Another Agency
description: WASHINGTON, April 26A struggle is under way to determine whether the Environmental Protection Agency will continue to test the gasoline mileage of new carsor whether, as a top official of the agency fears, the testing may be transferred to another agency that will be more amenable to being influenced by the, automobile industry than E.P.A. has the reputation for being.

title: Music: Reimann Zyklus for Baritone
description: Aribert Heimann: a name that will be new to most American concertgoers. He is a German composer, born in 1936, and on Thursday night Pierre Boulez hand the New York Philharmonic presented the American premiere of his Zyklus, or cycle, for baritone and orchestra. Dietrich FischerDieskau, to whom the work is dedicated, was the singer.

title: Fonda Still in Hospital
description: Henry Fonda, who collapsed Tuesday with what physicians called total exhaustion, was not released from Lenox Hill Hospital as expected yesterday because of a worsening of his condition. Mr. Fonda collapsed after a performance of his oneman show, Clarence Darrow, at the Helen Hayes Theater. A hospital administrator said late yesterday that the 68yearold actor Would remain several more days until control of his heart rhythm was gained.

title: Trenton Prison to Shift 83 In First Step of PhaseOut
description: TRENTON, April 26Governor Byrne and Mrs, Ann Klein, the Commissioner of Institutions and Agencies, today took what they said was a first step in closing the Trenton State Prison only hours after an eruption of violence in which five guards and three inmates were injured.

title: Ford Advocates Tax Incentives For Industries With Shortages
description: WASHINGTON, April 26Vice President Ford, in his first major speech on economic policy, endorsed today the use of tax incentives to expand industrial capacity in industries where there are shortages.

title: MitchellStan Jury Seeks Don Nixon Memorandum
description: What has been called the Don Nixon memorandum throughout the 45day MitchellStans trial was the first official document the jury asked to review yesterdayits first full day of deliberations.

title: Test Today Will Whittle Derby Field
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 26 The 100th running of the Kentucky Derby next Saturday promises to attract more than a score of entrants, a matter of concern to Lynn Stone, Churchill Downs president. The Churchill Downs meeting will start tomorrow, with the Stepping Stone purse as one of the main attractions. This race, too, will have a comparatively big field, with 13 named on the overnight list.

title: Kissinger Says Diplomacy Is Not Used for Politics
description: WASHINGTON, April 26Secretary of State Kissinger strongly defended the Administration's foreign policy today against any suggestion that President Nixon was trying to manipulate it for domestic political advantage.

title: Judge Ginsberg of Nassau Indicted on Bribe Charges
description: MINEOLA, L. I., April 26Judge Martin Ginsberg of Nassau Family Court was indicted today on charges of soliciting and receiving $8,000 in bribes for promises of political favors in 1970 and 1971, while he was a State Assemblyman.

title: LATE JERSEY EDITION
description: General news, P. 35; sports, P. 22.

title: ETHIOPIAN UNITS MUTINY IN CAPITAL
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, April 26Units of Ethiopia's Army in Addis Ababa and police commandos staged mutinies here today, military sources said tonight.

title: Holty Art Shown in Memorial Exhibition
description: The American painter Carl Holty, who died last year at the age of 72, was a more unusual figure than was generally appreciated in his lifetime. Living abroad in the years 1926 to 1935, he came to know most of the major European artists of his time, and he sometimes wrote about their work with real distinction. He was perhaps the first of the many American painters to study with Hans Hofmannin Munich, in 1926, before Hofmann came to Americaand he was a member of the abstractioncreation group in Paris in the early nineteenthirties.

title: The Dance: Nadia Potts
description: No ballerina would wish to be caught napping as The Sleeping Beauty in Rudolf Nureyev's version of the ballet for the National Ballet of Canada. Not only does Mr. Nureyev overshadow his partners in the company, but the diffusiveness of the production tends to take attention away from the heroine herself.

title: Notes on People
description: In news conferences in St. Louis, Kansas City, and Jefferson City, Senator Thomas F. Eagleton, Democrat of Missouri, announced yesterday he was a candidate for reelection. Mr. Eagleton, briefly a candidate for the VicePresidency in 1972until it was disclosed that he had once undergone shock treatments for depressionproposed that he and his Republican opponent, Thomas B. Curtis, limit their campaign expenditures to $300,000. He cited a Common Cause study in which the citizens group concluded that incumbents received twice as much money for campaign expenses as challengers.

title: Rockefeller University Chief Named to Head Foundation
description: The Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation yesterday named Frederick Seitz, president of Rockefeller University, as its chairman of the board. Dr. Seitz has been on the foundation's board for two years.

title: Fire in DrugTreatment Unit
description: A fire yesterday in the Exodus House, a drugrehabilitation center at 309 East 103d Stereeet, caused considerable damage to the fivestory building. There were no reports of injuries. The fire started at 3:45 P.M. and was brought under conteral at 5 P.M.

title: Council Kills a Bill To Deprive O'Hagan Of Second Fire Post
description: A City Council committee yesterday killed a proposal for legislation that would have forced John T. O'Hagan to give up either his appointment as Fire Commissioner or his role as Chief of the Fire Department.

title: Surgery for Briles
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 26 (UPI)The Kansas City Royals announced today that, pitcher Nelson Briles will undergo surgery on his right knee for cartilage damage. The pitcher, acquired in the offseason from Pittsburgh, is expected to be out for about two months.

title: GOING OUT
description: NOW YOU SEE IT Evidence that the hand, with some help from the imagination, is quicker than the eye will be demonstrated tonight at the annual Society of Magic's salute to magic show.

title: Ingram Being Suggested To Head the Rock Island
description: Several directors of the Chicago, Rock Island & Pacific Railroad have been urged by a consultant to the Federal Railroad Administrator, John W. Ingram, to appoint Mr. Ingram, 45 years old, to the post of president of their railroad.

title: People in Sports
description: Refusing to hang up his sneakers after the recent season of limited action, Jerry West signed a longterm contract yesterday with the Los Angeles Lakers that will assure him of playing at least one more (his 15th) season with the National Basketball Association team. There are not set years in volved in the contract, said Allan Rothenberg, the Lakers' attorney. It's openended and for as long as Jerry wants to play, with some provisions for beign with the Lakers after his playing days over.

title: Votes in Congress
Defining Detente in Terms of the United Nations Charter
description: NEW HAVENThe Administration has contended, as Prof. Marshall D. Shulman, director of the Russian Institute of Columbia University, sums up its position, that Senator Henry M. Jackson's amendment to the Trade Reform Act requires the United States to choose between morality with continued high tension and dtente with trade. The United States faces no such choice.

title: Horses & Equipment
description: REG. APPALOOSA STUD

title: Rozelle Fines Eight Chargers And Svare for Drug Violations
description: The San Diego Chargers' general manager, Harland Svare, and eight players have been fined a total of $40,000 and placed on probation for violation of National Football League drug policies, Commissioner Pete Rozelle announced yesterday.

title: ANSWER TO PREVIOUS PUZZLE
Policeman Is Accused Of Issuing False Ticket
description: MINEOLA, L. I., April 26 A Nassau County patrolman was charged today with having given a spurious summons for speeding to a woman motorist who was actually out of the state on a visit to Florida.

title: New U.S. Attorney David Gershon Trager
description: I'm not the type who counts my chickens before they hatch, David Gershon Trager said yesterday. Yesterday was hatching day for the 36yearold heavyset associate professor of law. Ever since last January he had been aware that he was under consideration to succeed the late Robert A. Morse as United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York.

title: Roslyn Young Dies at 77; Had Been R.F.C. Official
description: Roslyn Diehl Young, a former executive of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, died Monday in the Powhatan Nursing Home, Falls Church, Va., at the age of 77.

title: MRS. CHARLES WEST JR.
description: Mrs. Ellen Shealy West, assistant personnel director of Time Inc., died Wednesday at the Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital after a series of strokes. She was 51 years old and lived in Wilton, Conn.

title: GAF TO INCREASE ITS PRICES ON FILM
description: The GAF Corporation said yesterday that it would increase its photographic film prices by an average of 5 per cent to 7 per cent, beginning June 1.

title: Promotion Campaign Is Set For Atlantic City Gambling
description: ATLANTIC CITY, April 26 (UPI)  Joseph A. Hoffman, State Commissioner of Labor and Industry, today announced a $200,000 tourist promotion campaign to bolster proposed legalized gambling as an attraction here.

title: Golf Results
description: AT LEEWOOD G. C. MET. P.G A. PROAM EVENT Par 35, 3671. 5,897 Yards The Leading Pro Scocas

title: EDWARD W. WARREN
description: Edward Willard Warren, senior partner in the law firm of Warren, Henkelman, Mcmenamin & Kreder in Scranton, Pa., died April 18 at his winter home in Key Largo, Fla. He was 78 years old and lived also in Waverly, Pa.

title: Music: Reimann Zyklus for Baritone
description: Aribert Reimann: a name that will be new to most American concertgoers. He is a German composer, born in 1936, and on Thursday night Pierre Boulez and the New York Philharmonic presented the American premiere of his Zyklus, or cycle, for baritone and orchestra. Dietrich FischerDieskau, to whom the work is dedicated, was the singer.

title: Energy Shortage Buffets Trading Stamps
description: The trading stamp industry took another severe setback last year, primarily because of the gasoline shortage, and industry officials and observers say it may be 1975 before stamp savers and companies find substantial improvement.

title: Watch on the Bench
description: After long neglect, the State Legislature, the Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals and the State Commission of Investigation are addressing themselves to the urgent matter of censuring or even removing judges who discredit the bench and diminish respect for the law.

title: Era of Change Looms for Knicks
description: The retirement of Dave DeBusschere, the physical limitations of Willis Reed, the selfannounced (but still unofficial) retirement of Jerry Lucas, wilt alter the character of New York Knick teams from now on. No matter what degree of success or failure they may have starting next year, the club will not be the same as that which has just concluded a stage of development.

title: Burch Bids Republicans Identify Party With Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, April 26Republican leaders from around the country turned the silent treatment today on the latest White House effort to identify an embattled President Nixon with party candidates for office this year.

title: Town's Little League Reluctantly Signs 3 Girls
description: UNION, N.J., April 26 They've been playing Little League baseball in this modest, suburban town for 21 years.

title: Chronology of the Events, Leading to the Portuguese Military Uprising
description: LISBON, April 26Following is a chronology of events that led up to military overthrow of the Portuguese Government yesterday:

title: Dave Anderson
description: For the first time, the Nets have an opportunity to upstage the Knicks in the New York basketball realm. It could be the beginning of a reign.

title: Brandt Says He Knew Aide Was a Spy
description: BONN, April 26 (Reuters) West German Chancellor Willy Brandt said in Parliament today that he had kept a suspected Communist spy on his personal staff to help security forces crack an espionage ring at the heart of the West German Government.

title: Franklin Lifts Its Prime to 11%; Coast Banks Move Up to 10%
description: The prime rate for commercial bank loansone of the basic interest rates in the nation's economymoved to new high ground yesterday as the Franklin National Bank went to 11 per cent from 10 per cent, and several California banks went to 10.

title: U.S. Court Upholds ExMental Patient In Treatment Suit
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 26 (AP)The Constitution requires mental hospitals to give treatment to patients committed against their wills, a Federal appeals Court ruled today.

title: PENNSY REPORTS $9.8MILLION LOSS
description: The Penn Central Railroad reported yesterday that it had an additional $9.8million net loss last month operating 3,000 trains a day over its 19,000mile system. This raised the net loss for the first quarter to $68.3million  $13.1million greater than in the comparable period last year, when the system's net loss reached $55.2million, The March, 1973, net loss was $9.5million.

title: ChabanDelmas Given Endorsement by Jobert
description: PARIS, April 26 (UPI) Foreign Minister Michel Jobert, who personified France's policy of independence of the United States under the late President Georges Pompidou, today threw his support behind the official Gaullist candidate, Jacques ChabanDelmas, for the presidency of France.

title: Royal Ascot Surprises At Yonkers
Aid to Phoning on Light Beams Devised
description: WASHINGTON, April 26The Bell System has taken a new step toward the transmission of telephone calls over beams of light. It is expected that eventually 3,000 or 4,000 messages can be transmitted simultane ously through a glass fiber the thickness of a human hair. P. K. Tien, a scientist at the Bell Telephone Laboratories facility in Holmdel, N. J., was granted Patent 3,806,226 this week for a method of linking together lightguiding electronic components that are to form part of the circuitry.

title: EXSHERIFF GUILTY ON 2 INMATES' WORK
description: BRIDGETON, April 26 (UPI) David Valentino, former sheriff of Cumberland County, says he will appeal a conviction by the County Court that he had allowed two inmates out of jail to work without supervision.

title: N.B.A. Championship
description: Boston vs. Milwaukee

title: A .E. C. Report Warns of Peril Of Terrorists Stealing Uranium
description: WASHINGTON, April 26An internal Atomic Energy Commission study released today contains a warning on what it called entirely inadequate safeguards to prevent the theft by terrorist groups of uranium and plutonium for the manufacture of homemade atomic bombs.

title: DAMASCUS REPORTS BATTLES ON GOLA N
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, April 26 (Reuters)Syria reported tonight that several Israeli tanks and tracked vehicles were deIstroyed and a number of IsIraelis were killed in renewed clashes on the Golan Heights today.

title: BALI CRASH SPURS INQUIRY ON PAN AM
description: The Federal Aviation Administration ordered an emergency, indepth inspection of the worldwide flight operations of Pan American World Airways yesterday, following the crash of a Pan American Boeing 707 on Bali, in Indonesia, on Monday. It was the fourth crash of a Pan Am 707 within nine months.

title: State Bids Shubert Board Step Down During Inquiry
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz has called on all six directors of the Shubert Foundationincluding Irving Goldman, the city's Commissioner of Cultural Affairsto disqualify themselves from any significant decisionmaking during his office's investigation of alleged financial irregularities or face legal action for their removal.

title: 3 AMERICANS LOSE APPEALS IN TURKEY
description: ANKARA, Turkey, April 26 (AP)A fivejudge criminal appeals court today upheld a lower court decision sentencing three Americans to life imprisonment for conspiring to smuggle drugs into Turkey. The session lasted five minutes.

title: Rangers, Flyers Catch Breath Between Rounds
description: The Rangers and Philadelphia Flyers walked around with swollen faces yesterday, but the New Yorkers were smiling just a bit more through their expensive bridgework,

title: Byrne Decision to Approve Rutgers Hospital Praised
description: TRENTON, April 26  Dr. Stanley S. Bergen Jr., president of the College of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, said today that he was very pleased by Governor Byrne's decision to approve plans for a $30million teaching and specialtycare hospital on the Piscataway campus of Rutgers Medical School.

title: Allegheny Ludlum to Begin 10Year Expansion Program
description: PITTSBURGH, April 26 (UPI)  Allegheny Ludlum Industries will proceed with plans for 10year expansion program in flat rolled steel, Roger S. Ahlbrandt, chairman, told the annual meeting of shareholders today.

title: 83 BEING SHIFTED IN TRENTON PRISON
description: TRENTON, April 26Governor Byrne and. Mrs. Ann Klein, the Commissioner of Institution and Agencies, today took what they said was a first step in closing the Trenton State Prison only hours after an eruption of violence in which five guards and three inmates were injured.

title: OvertheCounter Quotations
Renewed New Delhi Aid Stirs Debates In American and Indian Establishments
description: NEW DELHI, April 26A debate over the resumption of American aid has erupted within the American and Indian establishments here.

title: G.O.P. Is Silent on Nixon Leadership Bid As Burch Makes Appeal at Luncheon
description: WASHINGTON, April 26Republican leaders from around the country turned the silent treatment on the latest White House effort to identify an embattled President Nixon with party candidates for office this year.

title: 24 Sentenced in Greece by Special Military Court
description: ATHENS, April 26A special military court imposed terms of imprisonment on 24 persons here yesterday fer a variety of alleged martiallaw offenses including subversion and operating unlicensed radio transmitters.

title: Pierre's, Helas, Serves Up Last Souffles
description: The last liver pt, the last lobster bisque and the last cheese souffl were served at Pierre's yesterday afternoon, and another modest New York landmark disappeared.

title: Portugal's African Territories Contain Vast Potential Wealth
description: In contrast with the small size and sparse resources of Portugal, her African possessionsparticularly Angolaare vast storehouses of actual and potential wealth in the form of oil, iron ore, diamonds, coal, coffee and tropical produce.

title: U.S. GRAND JURY HEARS RESTOSKI
description: NEWARK, April 26Representative Henry Helstoski, Democrat of the Ninth District, testified briefly today before a Federal grand jury investigating allegations that he accepted payoffs for sponsoring special immigration bills to protect aliens from deportation.

title: Royal Ascot Surprises At Yonkers
description: YONKERS, April 26Royal Ascot N, a New Zealand import who had raced only twice before in the United States, tore the cloak of invincibility from Ambro Nesbit in the Meadow Skipper pace tonight at Yonkers Raceway

title: Mitterrand's Sallies Stir Election Crowd in Lyons
description: LYONS, France, April 24Franois Mitterrand, single candidate of the leftist alliance for the presidency of France, was nearing the end of his hourlong speech before a rapt aulience of 17,000 that filled the Lyons sports palace from the rostrum to the highest, row of he third balcony,

title: Fali TV Schedule: Old Formulas, New Time Slots
description: Although the three networks will bring in 31 new program series next fall in the most extensive renovation of primetime schedules in many years, the viewer will not likely be impressed next. September with either the originality or variety of the new offerings. From what has already been seen of the series pilots that have played in recent weeks as television movies, and from the networks' own written descriptions of the shows not yet exposed on the air, it is clear that virtually all will simply be further variations of the timetested formulas that have long constituted basic television entertainmentfare.

title: Antiques: Westport Show
description: WESTPORT, Conn.When the SouthportWestport Antiques Show opened here for the first time a decade ago, few dealers or collectors knew how rich and varied was the legacy of American 19thcentury craftsmen.

title: They Adopted Vietnamese Children, Now Help Others Do Same
description: DENVER  It might have been a kaffee klatsch: eight mothers in a living room, passing homemade cookies; baby squeals from the next room, a pink balloon in repose on the lime green rug.

title: Hayes Stroke Up In Madrid Golf
description: MADRID, April 26 (UPI)Dale Hayes of South Africa took the lead in the $40,000 Madrid open golf tournament today with a fourunderpar 88 and a tworound score of 210.

title: SUNDAY NEWS ADS CUT BY 200 PAGES
description: The Daily News estimated yesterday that it would lose about 200 pages of advertising from tomorrow's newspaper as result of increasing pressure through a slowdown by printers represented by Typographical Union No. 6.

title: Canned Plums
description: When the first city marshals were appointed by the Dutch to collect civil judgments here three centuries ago, there may have been some justification for the job. But the marshalssome of whom now make more than $100,000 a yearlong ago became a useless luxury.

title: Perelman Shaken Up By Florida's Charms
description: Shaken and sobered, a mere shard of his former self, S. J. Perelman has just returned from prolonged expoSure to the undiscovered country from which no caviler returns. Mutable and trepid, mournfully intoning tithe Largo al Factotum from Respighi's Cantata for Whispering Parms, he has shaken the mold of Florida from his plimsolls and is now exorcisring the peninsular memory.

title: PHILHARMONIC POST TO GO TO FLORIDIAN
description: The New York Philharmonic will get a new concertmaster this summer, and yesterday afternoon he was introduced locally as soloist with the orchestra. He is Eliot Chapo, 28 years old, from Miami Beach and a graduate of the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia, where he studied with Efrem. Zimbalist and Oscar Shumsky. He is now associate concertmaster of the Pittsburgh Symphony.

title: Understating of Oil Profits Alleged by Some Analysts
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 John C. Sawhill, the new head of the Federal Energy Office, said today that the agency was reviewing its standard for determining how much an international oil company can charge itself for imports of its own crude oil.

title: PIUS KNEW IN 1941 OF DRIVE ON JEWS
description: ROME, Arpil 26The Vatican made public today wartime documents showing that Pope Pius XII learned no later than the beginning of 1941 that the Nazis, were deporting large numbers of Jews from areas in their grip.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Four new buildings on the Brooklyn College campus in Flatbush were dedicated formally yesterday in ceremonies at which Mayor Beame reaffirmed his support for free tuition and open admissions throughout the City University. The new buildings, which cost $65million, contain nearly a million square feet of floor space, nearly doubling the college's classroom space at its main campus. Classes have been meeting in the new buildings since September.

title: Chemical Plant in Clifton Clears Explosion Debris
description: CLIFTON, April 26  Employes of the Atlantic Chemical Corporation began to pick up the debris today from the thunderous explosion last night that extensively damaged part of the industrial dye plant here and shook the surrounding neighborhood.

title: Goatskin Products Confiscated Here; Anthrax Is Feared
description: City Health Department inspectors yesterday confiscated several dozen products that were made in Haiti from untanned goatskin with the hair still attached. They said the products might be contaminated with anthrax, an acute bacteriat disease.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Pro Transactions BASEBALL
description: CALIFORNIA (AL)Recalled Morris Nettles, outfielder, from Salt Lake City farm club; placed Lee Stanton, outfielder, on disabled Iist.

title: MILITARY LEADER IN LISBON PLEDGES ELECTIONS IN YEAR
description: LISBON, April 26The general who assumed the leadership of Portugal yesterday after the swift military coup said today that a provisional government of civilians headed by a military man would be formed in three weeks. He promised general elections in one year.

title: Morrison's Widow Dead
description: LOS ANGELES, April 26 (Reuters)  Pamela Morrison, 27 years old, widow of the Rock music star Jim Morrison, was found dead in her apartment, last night apparently of a drug overdose, police reported today. Her husband, who was the leader of the rock group The Doors, died of a heart attack in Paris in 1971.

title: Foster Title Bout Set
description: LONDON, April 26 (Reuters)Bob Foster, the world light heavyweight boxing champion, has agreed to meet either John Conteh or Chris Finnegan in a title fight here on July 2.

title: Camden Sheriff Confirmed
description: TRENTON, April 26 (AP) The Senate yesterday confirmed the nomination of Joseph W. Coyle to succeed Arnold Cream as sheriff of Camden County. Mr. Cream is Jersey Joe Wolcott, the former heavyweight boxing champion who has taken a post in the State Department of Community Affairs.

title: HARRY GUTMANN, HEBREW LEADER
description: Harry K. Gutmann, chairman of the board of trustees of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations and an insurance executive, died yesterday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. His age was 64.

title: Television
description: An hourlong television documentary titled Wild Science was briskly absorbing and entertaining last night as it covered new areas of scientific endeavor and demonstrated achievements. The program, made by Lee Mendelson Productions in association with the Encyclopaedia Britannica, was shown over the National Broadcasting Company network.

title: Liquidation for Winston
description: Shareholders of the N. K. Winston Corporation, shoppingcenter developers, yesterday at a special meeting approved a previouslyannounced plan for liquidation of the corporation and for the subsequent distribution of the concern's net assets to the shareholders. The board approved the action last October in the belief that the assets will have a greater value than the trading value of the concern's common stock.

title: Duryea Asks More for Arts As Senate Doubles Budget
description: ALBANY, April 26  The State Senate has voted to double the current budget for the State. Council on the Arts, and Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea said today that he, favored an even larger increase.

title: Voters in Survey Prefer Democrats by Wide Margins
description: The Louis Harris Survey gives the Democrats a 23point advantage over Republicans in November Congressional elections, the largest margin it has lever reported.

title: G. M. ANNOUNCES 85% PROFIT DROP
description: DETROIT, April 20The General Motors Corporation announced today that its earnings for the first quarter of 1974 declined by 85 per cent from the 1973 first quarter.

title: PLEA FOR NEW TRIAL FOR CHAPIN DENIED
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (UPI)  United States District Judge Gerhard A. Gesell rejected today motions for aquittal and a new trial made by Dwight L. Chapin, former Presidential appointments secretary convicted of lying to the Watergate grand jury.

title: Abortion Law Eased By a Narrow Vote In West Germany
description: BERLIN, April 26 After long debate the lower house of the West German Parliament voted today in Bonn to legalize abortions in the first three months of a pregnancy.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Mindful of the fact that June will soon be busting out all over, and mindful of the fact that people are still getting married, and mindful of the fact that most brides think they need plates and glasses (also known as china and crystal), Georg Jensen held a little wingding the other night.

title: Princeton Chorus, Marking 100 Years, Sings in Airy Tone
description: The centuryold Princeton University Glee Club came to Carnegie Hall on Thursday night for a celebratory concert. The ensemble now has as many women as men students, adding up to an appropriate total of 100 singers. With them came an instrumental group, made up of students and area musicians, with that fine professional violinist Nadia Koutzen as concertmaster.

title: MOBIL OIL RAISES NET 66% IN QUARTER
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation, second largest in the nation, after Exxon, yesterday announced a 66 per cent increase in firstquarter net income to $258.6million compared with $155.8million in the same period last year.

title: BERNIE OCKENE
description: BAYONNE, N. J., April 26 (AP)Bernie Ockene, coach of the St. Peter's College basketball team, died at Bayonne hospital today, apparently of heart attack. He was 55 years old.

title: LEADING INDEXES UP 1.7% IN MARCH;Dent Says Gain Indicates Economy Will ImproveSome Are Doubtful
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) The Government reported today its composite index of leading economic indicators rose a substantial 1.7 per cent in March. Secretary of Commerce Frederick B. Dent said this pointed to a gradual improvement in the economy in the months ahead.

title: SENATE AIDES ASK WHITE HOUSE CURB
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (DPI) Senate investigators have concluded that excessive secrecy and concentration of power in the Presidency gave rise to the Watergate scandal, and they have drafted recommendations to drastically diffuse that power as a safeguard against any recurrence.

title: SHUBERT BOARD GETS ULTIMATUM
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz has called on all six directors of the Schubert Foundationincluding Irving Goldman, the city's Commissioner of Cultural Affairsto disqualify themselves from any significant decisionmaking during his offices investigation of alleged financial irregularities or fate legal action for their removal.

title: Franklin Bank Lifts Prime Rate to 11%
description: The prime rate for commercial bank loansone of the basic interest rates in the nation's economymoved to new high ground yesterday as the Franklin National Bank went to 11 per cent from 10 per cent, and several California banks went to 10.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 55 YEARS GIVEN TO BANK BOMBER
description: Peter Phillip Mauchlin, who, bombed a bank near Union Square last October injuring 10 persons, was sentenced to 30 years yesterday in Federal Court for that crime and for having robbed three other Manhattan banks.

title: U.S. Gives a Report On Its Pursuit Here Of Nazi Criminals
description: An audience composed largely of hunters of Nazi war criminals, including several persons who were survivors of massacres of Jewish populations, yesterday heard Gen. Leonard F. Chapman Jr., the Immigration Commissioner, give an accounting of his agency's pursuit of the fugitives.

title: 2 Accused of Slaying a Woman And Slashing Stepson in Bronx
description: Two Bronx men were arrested yesterday and charged with fatally stabbing a 35yearold woman in her apartment and leaving her wounded stepson hanging upside down in a closet.

title: News of the Screen
description: Greece Is Subject Of a New Dassin

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE Clash on Taxes and Controls
description: A NOTHER classic confrontation may be erupting between the Congress and an incumbent Administration over national economic policies in this era of high inflation and increasing employmentor it may all turn out to be no more than political maneuvering keyed to next November's elections. The potential clash, which has been simmering for some months with the growth of public furore over the intolerable level of prices, burst into the open last week When a large number of Senate Democrats indicated they favored a lastminute reprieve for some form of lift economiccontrols program, scheduled to expire cornpletely two days hence. At the same time, more vocal support for a tax reduction was forthcoming from some legislators.

title: Baha'i Movement Growing
description: TEANECKOver the last five years, Benjamin Kaufman, a professor of history and English at Fairleigh Dickinson University and a member of the Baha'i faith for 34 years, has received an unusually large number of invitations from New Jersey colleges and high schools to give lectures about the teachings of his religion.

title: CONNECTICUT JURY OF SIX CRITICIZED
description: HARTFORD, April 27After nearly a year in use in criminal cases in Connecticut, sixmember juries were given poor marks this week at a meeting of the Connecticut Bar Association.

title: EDUCATION CHIEF IN FLORIDA QUITS

Tomorrow night it will be Alfred Hitchcock who will be honored at the Film Society of Lincoln Center's annual fundraising gala at Avery Fisher Hall. Unlike Chaplin, who had become inactive by the time the Film Society honored him, and Astaire, who had more or less abandoned dancing, at least professionally, to beCome a character actor, Hitchcock is still doing what he's always done most brilliantly.

He was describing the final days of this year's legislative session, offering the comment as his total disclosure of what was going on at his meetings with the two legislative leaders. title: JAPAN PURSUING EASIER OIL POLICY

title: The Oriental quest of an orphan from the Bronx
description: Quin's Shanghai Circus is a war novel without the usual furniture of war: no suicide pilots, no fancy kill machines, no homages to the foot soldier, no initiations into the rites of combat, no bittersweet recollections of the home front. Instead, Edward Whittemore's booka thick, feisty account of Japan's tortured dance with the West before, after, and during World War IIis peopled with circus masters, prostitutes, priests, gangsters, voyeurs, retarded manboys, pornography collectors, pederasts, dwarfs, fat American giants and sadfaced secretservice agents, who change identities from time to time and drift through landscapes that resemble Tokyo, Shanghai and the Bronx.

title: SCIENTISTS ARGUE MARINER 10 GOAL
description: Scientists and engineers at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in California intend to resolve this week an, intriguing space exploration problem  how precisely to aim the Mariner 10 spacecraft, now circling the sun, for its icheduled second encounter with the planet Mercury in September.

Why, wonders his protagonist Davey Cable, should we have to choose between a Clune and a Rice, between two desperate kings, between political and economic manipulation so complex it absorbs government, and a mindless liberation that might destroy it?

title: Food
description: This unusual version of a Hungarian chocolatenut torte rises high in the pan as it bakes and sinks as it cools to a rich, fudgetextured cake. Frosting? Yes, and it couldn't be simpleror better. Some of the original cake batter is set aside to thicken to a spreading consistency.

description: For the third year in a row, Democrats are facing a party primary battle for nominations for seats on the New York Court of Appeals, the state's highest tribunal.

title: What's Doing in SALZBURG
description: GOING FOR BAROQUE  The whole of this Austrian city, at least the whole of the Old City, is a showpiece. If you don't know where to start, try the Baroque Museum in the Mirabell Gardens. It's so new that loins local people may not have heard about it, but they'll know where the gardens are. The museum is an audiovisual thing, nicely done even if you don't understand German. After the Baroque Museum, no matter how many threestar and fourstar at tractions you hit, don't fail to see the Collegiate Church (Kollegienkirche), which was designed at the end of the 17th century by Fischer von Erlach, whose name you will hear a hundred times on tours of Vienna and Salzburg. The church was built as the university church and is entered from Universittsplatz. Some guidebooks don't even mention it, possibly because their authors were so captivated by the flower stands in the square in front of the church entrance that they neglected to notice the church itself. That's a mistake. After looking at the flowers, gaze heavenward at the figures of the Evangelists on the church tower, then walk inside. If you think baroque is all clusters of knickknacks, be proved happily wrong. The church displays great line and simplicity; proportions and symmetry are perfectwith baroque decorations. The great delight is in discovering that baroque can permit such a clean and simple creation as this.

General Spinola says his Government will not negotiate now with the liberation movements in Angola, Mozambique and GuineaBissau; and these organizations have rejected in advance his idea for a federation of the three territories with Portugal.

title: Two novels
description: Anne Tyler is especially gifted in the art of freeing her characters and then keeping track of them as they move in their unique and often solitary orbits. Her fiction is filled with displaced persons who persist stubbornly in their own destinies. They are oddballs, visionaries, lonely souls, but she has a way of transcribing their peculiarities with such loving wholeness that when we examine them we keep finding more and more pieces of ourselves.

title: Terra infirma Mortgage On Amerida By Leonard Downie Jr. 288 pp. New York: Praeger. $7.95. Unreal Estate The Lowdown on Land Hustling. By Anthony Wolff. 290 pp. San Francisco: The Sierra Club. $7.95.
description: Real estate, as most of us aredimly aware, is the last remaining frontier of tycoon capitalism, where a fortune can still be made by pyramiding borrowed money and taking tax deductions as you grow. Surprisingly, this is the part most of the protest literature on urban planning leaves out. But the decline of the cities and the rape of the countryside probably can be best understood as the hidden social cost of unearned speculative gain for a shrewd few. Or as Leonard Downie Jr. writes in Mortgage on America, the housing, communities and environmental conditions produced are no more, than neglected byproducts of a system that invites wind; fall profit.

title: Potter Is Inspired by Loneliness of a Swamp

Mr. Firriolo's fruit and vegetable store here is one of dozens that have sprung up throughout Long Island in the last year. title: What's New in Art
Some Liberation Music, Please
description: WHEN the lumbering structure of television begins to respond to the vibrations of women's liberation, the, movement can claim progress that is particularly significant and farreaching. It's happening. In the beginning, just a couple of years ago, the subject, was limited to scattered news items and titillating talk shows. Generally the more radical messages were being manipulated by the medium, frequently wrapped in protective condescension.

title: Kerr on Shlemiel the First
description: NEW HAVEN, CONN. ONE of the pleasant things about Isaac Bashevis Singer's short stories is that he doesn't bother to explain himself. He throws an aside at you and lets you make of it what you will. Thus, in A Quotation From Klopstock, a libertine Is describing his harrowing experiences at the hands of an exceedingly jealous, possibly suicidal, woman. To get rid of Nina was impossible, he says. She carried poison with her. I fell into, such despair that I began to write a playthe one they ruined later ill the Central Theater.

description: In the past, it was bridge, canasta, MahJongg. Today, it's backgammon. Since 1969, the number of Americans who play, backgammon regularly has increased tenfold, from 200,000 to 2 million. Cardinal Industries, Inc., of Brooklyn, one of the largest manufacturers of backgammon sets in the United States, sold as many sets in 1973 as it had in the previous 20 years combined. Backgammon sets are turning up with increasing frequency in class magazine advertisements. Publishers are rushing new backgammon books into print.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The military junta now ruling Portugal made it clear that it was not prepared to end the war in the African territories by granting independence. Gen. Antdnio de Spinola, the junta's leader, told a meeting of newspaper editors in Lisbon that selfdetermination should not be confused with independence. The statement appeared to indicate the possibility of future conflict between the junta and leftist forces in Portugal, but an open break may not come for some time. General Spinola indicated signs of alarm at some of the activity of the left, as it gave vent to feelings that had been suppressed for almost half a century. [1:8.1]

description: I'M not sure I'd want to be a playa playwright means wanting to wright if Off Off Broadway didn't exist because to me wanting to be work in the theater and I'm too damn impatient to sit around for months or years trying to raise funds and find stars for a Broadway production.

In defeating the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Princeton, Harvard rowed the 2,000meter course in 5 minutes 43.7 seconds.

title: Peddlers and hellhorses
description: Timothy Todd is a fasttalking peddler intent on unloading a gollywhopper egg on Farmer Foote. What's a gollywhopper egg? Well, T.T. can quickly handle that question. Oh, a gollywhopper is a very good egg to have. Think of all the benefits of owning the incredible bird that will soon spring from ita bird that can literally do everything, even eat words. We all have come across such salespersons hustling gollywhoppers, or used cars, or encyclopedias. But then old Farmer Foote down the farm has never seen a coconut (a.k.a. gollywhopper egg) in his life, so why shouldn't he fall for the sales pitch?

title: Rock Fans Erupt at Richmond Festival
description: RICHMOND, April 27 (AP)Policemen wielding clubs moved into a rock music festival here today when some of the 22,000 young rock fans began throwing bottles and burning police cars because of drug arrests.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONWilliam Saxbe's way of speaking is now being compared in the press with Martha Mitchell's; his colleagues in the Justice Department are known to be disturbed by his blunt and offhand remarks; his public image, of a man who says quickly and sometimes too quickly what is in his mind, is rather improbable when compared with the image that a nation's chief legal officer might logically be thought to want.

title: A Joyful Lisbon Celebrates With Flowers
description: LISBON, April 27The Portuguese were saying it with flowers today. Just what they were saying was not quite clear, even to themselves, except that they were very happy.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Recently, a New York woman, an avid bargainhunter, rushed to a store which had advertised a coat at 30 per cent off  only to learn that it was no longer in stock.

title: Bridge
description: Heroes and Villains shooting at each other in Western movies often find themselves in a tricky situation where action seems called for, but any move will create a target and lead to disaster.

title: A little Flatbush goes a long way
description: Sam Berman is a smalltime gambler living with his father Ben in the Erasmus High section of Brooklyn. As his father says interminably, it's a neighborhood in transition. Even the physical Brooklyn of Ben's childhood has all but disappearedonly a synagogue remains  and Sam's highschool classmates have almost all fled to the comparative safety of Long Island and New Jersey. Brooklyn is being taken over by blacks and Puerto Ricans; petty crime and violence are common; traditional values and beliefs are fading fast.

title: A gallery of concerns Sketchbook 19661971
description: American culture has never offered much encouragement to the man of letters, the person who writes in a broad range of forms and with an easy movement among them, and who is less a literary conqueror than a kind of witness. The distinction is scarcely absolute, but the littrateur in the European tradition is less likely than an American author to think of writing as the perfecting of a circumscribed craft such as fiction or poetry or, from a different perspective, to suppose that writing has chiefly to do with the expression of self and so to attach romantic or apocalyptic significances to it. To write, in that older tradition, is to test consciousness and maintain it, to try to fulfill, as the acceptance of a responsibility, the human need for articulation, for voices. In everything Max Frisch has published novels, stories, plays, essays, political and social commentary, and now this Sketchbook made up of some of those things and a number of unclassifiable forms  he has wrestled with the angel or demon of the literary vocation. It has been a struggle whose intensity and painfulness have been masked by his charm and urbanity, his wryness and wit.

title: Ballet: A New Don Juan
description: In a way Don Juan is the silliest and the most glorious of Romantic figures. This seems to be the approach that John Neumeier takes in his absorbing new ballet, Don Juan, which was danced here for the first time at the Metropolitan Opera House Friday night by the National Ballet of Canada.

title: T. J. Brady Jr. Weds Lauren Timberlake
description: Miss Lauren Sinclair Timberlake, daughter of Mr. and Mrs Shelby V. Timberlake Jr. of Pelham Manor, N.Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Thomas Joseph Brady Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Brady of Elmsford, N.Y.

title: Clinic Sees Drop in Drug Use
description: RIDGEWOODThree years ago, the odds would have been good that the youth casually sprawled on a waiting room couch at the Raymond E. Banta Valley Center was a heroin addict undergoing detoxification, and was at the clinic for his daily dose of methadone.

title: Rent Issue Is Nearing Denouement In Albany
description: ALBANYAs the state Legislature barrels pellmell into its adjournment frency, 91 pieces of rentcontrol, vacancydecontrol or maximumbaserent legislationrepeal, restructuring or fabricationhave found their way into the legislative hopper. That is two more than the number of legislators representing New York City.

title: L.I. Fencing Master Stresses Drama
description: CENTERPORTTo the uninitiated, the padded red heart hung on one wall of the tiny studio might have been a symbol of love. But to the students of Oscar Kolombatovich, the faded red fabric heart typified death.

title: Tremors From Lisbon . . .
description: The political earthquake that finally struck Portugal last week sent tremors right across southern Europe and deep into black Africa.

title: Dartmouth Appoints Aide
description: HANOVER, N. H., April 27 (AP)Harland W. Hoisington Jr. has been named director of financial aid at Dartmouth Col, lege, effective July I. Mr. Hoisington, coordinator of the Dartmouth Plan for yearround operation and a former director of financial aid at Columbia University, will succeed Robert K. Hager.

title: 2Handed Backhand: Debits Outweigh Credits
description: Tennis players are just as bewitched as any other sportsmen by a successful novelty in their sport. So when they see a stroke catch on and work for some of the top players the world, they wonder whether they ought to try it, too.

title: Lhasa Apso, In Upset, Is Best In Show
description: STANTON, Del., April 27 The outsider came through in a stunning upset today at the 33d show of the Wilmington Kennel Club, which drew 1,873 dogs.

title: Boating Completes Best Year Despite Energy Crisis
description: Despite a loss of popularity in the fourth quarter of 1973 due to the fuel crisis, recreational boating in the United States just completed the most successful year in its history.

title: Tina Brodsky Affianced to David Bellet
description: Miss Tina Brodsky, a teacher of English and social studies at the Fleming School here, will be married in August to Dayid F. Bellet, an investment officer in the research department of the First National City Bank.

title: Population Growth Termed Greatest Peril to Humanity
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI)  Russell W. Peterson, chairman of the Council on Environmental Quality, has warned that the United States must help reduce worldwide population growth if the quality of life is to improve.

description: LOS ANGELES, April 27 (AP)Ron Cey and Bill Russell homered and Al Downing and Mike Marshall combined on a fourhitter today, leading the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 52 victory over the Montreal Expos.

description: AT GREENVALE, L.I.

description: Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Straus 3d of New York and Rye, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Andrea Straus, to Amir Shaviv, son of Mr. and Mrs. Yakov Shababo of Haifa, Israel. The future bridegroom changed his surname.

title: A 3Tiered Law Education Is Proposed by U.S. Judge
description: DALLAS, April 27 (UPI)A Federal Appeals Court judge has proposed a threelevel law education that he said would teach prospective attorneys how to act effectively in the courtroom.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Kinnelon Zoning Protects Privacy
description: KINNELONRolling hills and wooded sections abound in this 19.7squaremile borough in the northern part of Morris County, a community where privacy and lots of space are the both the business executives and retired people who make their homes here. Industry, multifamily houses and commercial development are effectively blocked through zoning regulations that require at least an acre of land for onefamily residences.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:
A promising experiment in bringing exjunkies back into society with supported work
description: Drug addicts have long known what government planners are just beginning to find outthat one of the worst parts of coming off heroin what to do with themselves after they're drugfree. John Lyons, for instance, is a 37yearold exjunkie who had kicked his habit three times in the past nine yearsbut then could never find a job. You couldn't just tell them you were an addict, so you'd have to lie, he said. But you could never lie up a record. Somewhere, there would be that question: Where have you been for the past few years?

title: QUAKER SENTENCED IN DRAFT REFUSAL
description: WILKESBORO, N.C., April 27A 19yearold Quaker was sentenced this week to 26 months in jail after being convicted in Federal Court of refusing to register for the draft.

title: Ehizuelen Does 552 Triple Jump
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, April 27 (UPI)A University of Illinois freshman, Charlton Ehizuelen of Nigeria, made the best triple jump of the outdoor season today at the 65th annual Drake Relays.

title: The Stability In Nigeria
description: LAGOSA little more than four years ago, Nigeria emerged from the fratricidal Biatran war to begin a remarkable recovery that seems likely to establish it as the leader of Black Africa.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Robert Pelgrift Jr. to Marry Susan Curtis on June 8
description: Miss Susan Grace Curtis, a thirdyear student at Columbia Law School, and Robert Youngs Pelgrift Jr., who is in his third year at the Harvard Law School, plan to be married June 8 in the Dwight Chapel of Yale University.

title: Holden Caulfield from the East Bay
description: Jack the Bear is a vigorous, engaging and effective novel, one which may, in a few years, call many of its readers back for a second look. It is a novel of adolescence, told in the first person, which means that, first of all, it has to triumph over the notinconsiderable weight of its own tradition  meaning, obviously, those twin fountainheads and AllAmerican literary siblings, Huckleberry Finn and The Catcher in the Rye

title: Nicholson Has Turned 80, and Is Better Than Ever
description: OF English modem artists, surely the best known in America is Henry Moore, whose sculptures appear in most of our museums and many of our public places. Second rank probably belongs to the painter Francis Bacon and his unnerving evocations of human torment. Tested on these two names, anyone reasonably versed in modern art could, I'm sure, quickly summon mental images of their work and give adequate descriptions of them.

title: The Game Plan After Controls: A. Lot of the OldTime Religion
description: The old axiom that you can't beat something with nothing will be sorely tested as the demise of wage and price controls approaches April 30. Although director controls now have fewer public supporters than streaking, they, did serve to demonstrate at least a resolve to beat inflation. With, the apparent junking of the stabilization program, the statistics are displayed without protective filters, and they do not make pretty viewing.

title: Khrushchev Hoped For a. Freer Society, '71 Memoir Reveals
description: Nikita S. Khrushchev, in reminiscences published this weekend, expressed hope for a more enlightened Communist society in the Soviet Union in which people would enjoy their inalienable rights.

title: Daddy, what was Winston Churchill?
description: On Jan. 24, 1965, there died Winston Spencer Churchill, Knight of the Garter and, if he had not refused the title, Duke of London, Six days later he was given a state funeral in St. Paul's Cathedral, an honor previously reserved for two great men of war  Admiral Lord Nelson, victor at Trafalgar, and the Duke of Wellington, victor at Waterloo. What brought Churchill into this select company? The men of the time had no doubt as to the answer. He was the savior of his country, the first Englishman to be so hailed since King Alfred the Great.

title: CAIRO SAID TO FACE TOUCH ARMS ISSUE
description: Egypt will face appalling problems if she either seeks complete independence from Soviet military supplies or buys her arms from Western as well as Communist sources, according to United States and European logistics experts.

title: The 53 points
description: The following are the 53 allegations originally placed before the House Judiciary Committee for investigation and study in its inquiry on whether to recommend the impeachment of Richard M. Nixon. They were compiled by the committee staff from Government, press and private sources.

Y., have announced the engagement of Dr. Kendall's daughter, Miss Virginia Ann Kendall, to Jeffrey, David Guerrant of Ellicott City, Md., son of Mr. and Mrs. David E. Guerrant of New Canaan, Conn. description: Many at the anniversary dinner greeted Mayor Beame as Abe, without affectation. They were also on a firstname basis with Prof. Meyer Schapiro of Columbia University. the renowned art historian, and with Nat Holman, coach of many of City College's greatest basketball teams.

title: With Capitalist Aid, Siberia Is Opening Up
description: The vast natural riches of Siberia have become a fulcrum of growing economic relations between East and West. The region, extending across the northern third of Asia, from the Urals to the Pacific, already accounts for 75 to 80 per cent of the Soviet Union's energy resources, as coal, oil, natural gas and hydroelectric power, and of some highvalue metals like gold and tin as well as diamonds. Now, following the signing of a $1billion agreement last week, some of those resources will be delivered to Japan and possibly later to the United States.

title: Concert: Bach to Twinkle, Twinkle
description: RUTHERFORD  What promises to be a loud, but joyful, event will take place here on the afternoon of May 11. Taking over the gymnasium at Fairleigh Dickinson University, 300 young string musicians will begin a concert with some of the moredifficult works of Bach and Vivaldi and then play their way down to Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star.

title: New York Schoolboys Lose Big Races
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 27It was a bright, sunny day at Franklin Field for the Penn Relays today but New York area schoolboys had a gloomy time of it in the victory column of the big races.

title: Thoughts on Kentucky Derby: Keep the Bad Horses Out of It
description: People ask me how it feels to ride two Kentucky Derby winners in a row. They want to know if I was nervous, if I got goosebumps when the band played My Old Kentucky Home, if I worried about criticism.

description: MANHATTAN and Jerusalem are the subjects of two current photographic exhibitons. At the NewYork Historical Society, through the summer, is Manhattan Now 14 Photographers Look at the Form of the Old City. At the Jewish Museum, through Sept. 3, is Jerusalem: City of Mankind, the work of 21 photographers.

title: Rewards of Peace
description: The challenge to wouldbe peacemakers for the Middle East has long been one of making all sides see that they have more to gain through reaching a settlement than through military means. The moment is ripe for the United States to make a new case for this fundamental point; that is precisely the goal of President Nixon's 1975 foreign aid message.

title: PORTUGUESEJUNTA OPPOSES FREEING OF AFRICAN LANDS
description: LISBON, April 27The military junta now ruling Portugal after a coup two days ago made it clear today that it was not prepared to end the wars in the African territories by granting independence.

description: Mrs. Betsy Perkins Washburn of Worcester, Mass., was married yesterday afternoon to Duane Thomas Sargisson of Petersam, Mass. The Rev. Donald Whitcomb performed the ceremony in St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Worcester.

description: Robert. L. Hamill, chairman of Sanderson & Porter, engineers, who had specialized in building electrical power plants here and abroad, died Friday at his home, 700 Park Avenue. He was 75 years old and also lived in Lawrence, L. I.

title: Appeal on Ouster Allowed
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex. April 27 (UPI)A judicial council of the United Methodist Church has determined that a minister who was suspended after he announced that he was a homosexual may reapply for his ministerial credentials but that the Southwest Texas Conference of the church is under no obligation to accept the application of F. Gene Leggett, who was suspended after he led a protest at a meeting of the conference here in June, 1971.

title: Despite Expanded League, TV's Not in Picture Yet
description: From 5 to 8 to 9 to 15 teams. This has been the story of the North American Soccer League, which opened its season in Dallas last night. The magnitude of the league's growth across the nation and Canada, however, can perhaps best be underlined by the fact that the league's new offices are in more spacious quarters on Sixth Avenue here.

description: For two consecutive quarters, the oil companies have shown how good things can be, with double and even tripledigit percentage gains in profits.

title: Bei Him They're Still Schn

Tight and The Beer Barrel Polka, to the stage door of the Shubert Theater on the north side of the same block where they are now packing the house eight times a week in the new musical memento of World War II, Over Here.

title: The Readers Have Their Say on Shylock
description: TO THE EDITOR: FRED M. HECHINGER defends the recent ABCTV presentation of The Merchant of Venice (Why Shylock Should Not Be Censored, March 31). He claims that, unlike the Jewish agencies which protested the broadcast, he decided the issue on the grounds of rational analysis rather than the reflex reaction of programed emotions. To the contrary, on the very grounds of rational analysis, and holding momentarily in abeyance the question of whose programed emotions are turned on, Shakespeare's Shylock should be censored.

description: The Yankees desperately wanted a second baseman and they traded for Walt Williams, an outfielder.

description: JERSEY CITY  The removal of about 140 abandoned vessels from the shoreline of Liberty Park, the focal point of New Jersey's bicentennial celebrations, is a toppriority item in the $14million New York Harbor cleanup project that Congress authorized last month.

description: In an unusual political happening, Stanley Harwood, the Nassau Democratic chairman, is recommending William J. Deeley. Jr., the unsuccessful Democratic candidate for county executive last year, for a Republican patronage plum, a $48,173 state Court of Claims judgeship.

description: WASHINGTON, April 27Some say they did not. Some say they did, but it was not illegal. One says he did, but his arm was twisted.

title: An economic analysis of that peculiarly economic institution
description: If a more important book about American history has been published in the last decade, I don't know about it. Time on the Cross is at once a jarring attack on the methods and conclusions of traditional scholarship and a lucid, highly readable analysis of the special American problemblack slavery. It isn't going to make anyone with an established interest in the subject very happy, but then, that's the point.

title: Striped Bass and Bluefish Are Expected to Be in Good Supply
description: Fuel shortages may curtail the activities of the offshore Atlantic Coast sport fishing fleets this Summer and fall, but striped bass and bluefish, the prime targets of inshore anglers and surf fishermen, should be in good supply.

title: Virginia 500 Is Problem For Rookie
description: MARTINSVILLE, Va., April 27It's a good thing for George Follmer that he's starting on the front row tomorrow for the $64,825 Virginia 500. The former CanAm champion has been unable to figure out where to pass anyone on the .525mile Martinsville Speedway.

title: The World

title: Joseph B. Shane, Professor At Swarthmore, Alumni Aide
description: Joseph B. Shane, who retired in 1972 as vice president for alumni affairs and public relations and professor of education at Swarthmore College, died of a heart ailment yesterday at Taylor Hospital in Ridley Park, a Philadelphia suburb. He was 70 years old and lived in Swarthmore.

description: PROVIDENCE, R.I. April 27 Northeastern's heavyweight crew pulled away from Brown and Columbia over the last 1,400 meters to win the varsity eightoared race and complete a sweep of five races today on the Seekonk River.

title: Island Fighting Offshore Drilling
description: MINEOLA  The Count Executives of Nassau an Suffolk took a joint actio last week in what is expected to be a protracte and bitter battle betwee those who regard offshor oil drilling as necessary an those who say that the pos sible benefits of such activit are more than outweighes by the danger of damage to Long Island's beaches.

title: Foster and Laurie
description: The underlife of New York City is not its only reality, but despite the extraordinary amounts of time and money spent studying it, and despite the peculiar glamorization (the other side of piety and of disdain) it is sometimes subjected to its human immediacy is far too rarely apprehended by those who do not share in it. There are large numbers of people who do not live this life, but who, by living so closely with it every working day, do share it and unquestionably understand it in a way that they themselves may not ordinarily perceive and may not about.

title: Smalley Keeps Frostbite Title
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., April 27David V. Smalley, champion of the Larchmont Yacht Club winter fleet, successfully defended his Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound Frostbite chempionship in the 21st annual Y.R.A. regatta sailed at Larchmont Y. C. today.

title: Miss Calve Fiancee of S. B. Pierce
description: Miss Catherine Calve, assistant prosecutor of the High Court of Avesnes, France, and Stephen B. Pierce, who is with the international departmennt of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company here, plan to be married July 13 in St. Jean de Luz, France.

description: WASHINGTON, April 27The United States' first experiment with peacetime regulation of prices and wages will end at midnight Tuesday with the country in the grip of the worst inflation in two decades.
