description: Seven crew members of a Liberian tanker were injured, one fatally, in an engineroom fire yesterday morning that left the 556foot vessel floundering in heavy seas about 400 miles northeast of Bermuda.

title: Verdict Dims a Key Impeachment Issue; Value of Tapes Stressed
description: WASHINGTON, April 28The acquittal verdict today in the MitchellStans trial heartened the White House, virtually, eliminated a key issue in the House imqeachment inquiry and underscored the importance of the Watergate tape recordings in other criminal and impeachment proceedings.

title: News Summary and Index MONDAY, APRIL 29, 1974
description: John N. Mitchell and Maurice H. Stans were acquitted in New York of all charges in their criminal conspiracy case, ending the first trial of former Cabinet officials since the aftermath of the Teapot Dome scandal in the nineteentwenties. A jury of nine men and three women deliberated 26 hours over a period of four days. [1:8.]

title: Jurors Couldn't Believe Federal Witnesses
description: The jurors in the MitchellStang trial said yesterday that they had voted to acquit the two former Cabinet officers of all criminal charges because they could not believe the testimony of crucial Government witnesses.

title: LOUIS ROITMAN
description: Louis Roitman, a voice and piano teacher who sang as a tenor soloist with choral groups, died Saturday in Queens General Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 4147 56th Street, Woodside, Queens.

title: An American Wife in Islam
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia Claudia Crawford, who grew up in Westport, Conn., was both excited and worried when her banker husband was transferred to this citadel of Moslem conservatism.

title: Amnesty Objectors, but Not Deserters
description: POWAY, Calif.The issue of amnesty for Vietnamwar conscientious objectors, draftevaders and armedforces deserters who fled the country has polarized much of the public. Indeed, the issue is manyfaceted, and I have wrestled mightily with but a few of its aspects in Order to clarify my own thinking.

title: Jerseymen's Convention Ends With History Tour
description: MOUNT HOLLY, April 28A group of 80 teenagers, including some who hope to write, teach and preserve New Jersey's history, toured historic sites in three South and Central Jersey communities today.

title: Ornaments Of City Past Are Shown
description: For some years the Brooklyn Museum has been rescuing pieces of architectural sculpture from New York's demolished buildings and giving them a home in its sculpture garden. Now the fruits of the museum's laborswhich have been substantially aided by the Anonymous Arts Recovery Society, founded by the art dealer Ivan Karpcan be seen at Rockefeller Center in a temporary exhibition entitled New York Ornaments.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Complaints from New York apartment dwellers charging tenantrelocation companies with harassment tactics have dropped sharply in the last year and are well below a peak reached several years ago, city and state officials report.

title: Support of Mrs. Gandhi Urged by Party
description: NEW DELHI, April 28Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Congress party caucus warned today that a grave economic situation was being turned into a grave political one and appealed to party workers to close their ranks and stand behind their leader.

title: Advertising: FullService Shops
description: The speculation last week that the Royal CrownWells Rich Greene rift might have been caused by unhappiness at the bottler level shines the light on an unglamourous, yet frequently vital, function of a fullservice agency.

title: Italian Church Suspends Priest Who Supports the Divorce Law
description: ROME, April 28  Roman Catholics in a workers' district here protested today against the church's punishment of former abbot who is in favor of the law permitting divorce.

title: Steven Turkowitz Weds Erica Kleine
description: Miss Erica Kleine, the assistant editor with House Beautiful's Special Publications in New York, was married at noon yesterday to Steven Michael Turkowitz, who is with the New York law firm of Schwartz, Burns, Lesser & Jacoby.

title: Yankees Win, 112, Lose, 85;. Mets Sweep Giants
description: A long afternoon of batters outshining pitchers and Graig Nettles tying the major league home run record for April with his 11th ended with a stalemate between the New York Yankees and Texas Rangers. A Lap Day crowd of 28,609 at Shea Stadium looked on.

title: Saigon Reports Tank Attack In the Delta Near Cambodia
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, April 29 (Reuters) The South Vietnamese command reported today that Communist forces had attacked a Government outpost in the Plain of Reeds close to the Cambodian border with five amphibious tanks.

title: DoubleBarreled Death
description: A House subcommittee on national security policy plans hearings this week on a chemical warfare resolution that should have been made unnecessary four years ago. Its purpose is to force a review of the Army's chemical warfare policies and, more specifically, to jog the Senate into ratifying at long last the Geneva Protocol of 1925. This would forbid a signatory from making first use of chemical weapons in a war.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Washington's Futile Policy Toward Havant
description: WASHINGTONThe Nixon Admin. istration's recalcitrant reaction to the planned sale to Cuba of motor vehicles manufactured by United Statesowned companies in Argentina has more cast a pall on the new spirit in hemispheric relations recently proclaimed by Secretary of State Kissinger.

title: TV: 6Hour, 2Part QB VII on ABC
description: With enough huffing and puffing to justify the equivalent of War and Peace, the makers of QB VII have brought forth a curiously smudged version of a bestselling novel by Leon Uris. Without commercials, it runs for five and a half hours. With commercials, it's about an hour longer. And the latter, of course, is the version that will be carried on ABCTV in two marathon installments tonight and tomorrow.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Texas School Put on Probation

title: DuryeaWilson VoteReform Debate Is Unlikely
description: ALBANY  Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea has been telling associates that there is no way that he can accept a compromise on campaign reform that includes Governor Wilson's proposal to give the enforcement powers to the Secretary of State. The State Constitution requires election machinery to be, bipartisan, Mr. Duryea has been saying, and therefore he insists that his own proposal for a bipartisan state election commission independent of the Governor is more acceptable.

title: Bridgeport's New Courthouse Draws Objections From Judges and Lawyers
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.  If judges could rule on matters of taste and design as well as law, state officials, Contractors and architects involved in the construction of the newly completed Fairfield County Courthouse here would be put in the stocks and have their noses tweaked by every passing lawyer.

title: Rangers Top Flyers in Overtime, 21
description: Pushing pressure to the breaking pointeven for hockey fansthe Rangers scored suddenly in a dramatic overtime period yesterday, won 21 and evened their Stanley Cup series against the young, battling Flyers at two games each.

title: Fear of Runaway Prices Spurs Pay Demands
description: WASHINGTON, April 28Sam Mayer is Worried. Earning $1.80 an hour work. ing for a private security agency Pittsburgh, Mr. Mayer is barely able to makeends Meet now and has no idea how he will get by after the price controis program ends on Tuesday:

title: Sadat Is Confident Kissinger Will Get IsraeliSyrian Pact
description: President Anwar elSadat of Egypt, in an interview televised yesterday, said he thought Secretary of State Kissinger would succeed in getting a ceasefire between Syrian and Israeli forces.

title: Verdict Dims a Key Impeachment Issue; Value of Tapes Stressed
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 The acquittal verdict today in the MitchellStans trial heartened the White House, virtually leliminated a key issue in the House impeachment inquiry and underscored the importance of the. Watergate tape recordlags in other criminal and impeschment proceedings.

title: Penn Eight, Eli Women Win Races
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 28 The Yale varsity women's crew accomplished something today its male counterparts have been unable to do the last ten years. The Yale girls beat a varsity eight from the University of Pennsylvania. They did it by two lengths over a 1,000meter course on the choppy Schuylkill River this morning as part of a sixevent regatta.

title: Germany's Political Crisis
description: The arrest of a suspected spy for Communist East Germany on Willy Brandt's personal staff further weakens the political position of West Germany's Chancellor just as he has begun to fight back against setbacks in state and local elections.

title: Allen Miller Triumphs in Golf by One
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 28 (AP)Allen Miller had three bogeys today then had to sink a birdie putt on the 17th hole to capture the $18,000 first prize in the Tallahassee open golf tournament.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 29, 1974

title: Red Smith
description: Ever so long ago Fielding H. Yost, the patron saint of Michigan football, was consulted about a proposal award a team one point for each first down in addition the scores for touchdowns, conversions, field goals and safeties. Coach Yost was a reasonable man, and he responded in a reasonable tone. Yes, he said, you could do that and you'd still have a game." He paused reflectively. Of course, he said, it wouldn't be football, but you'd still have a game.

title: NEWSPAPER TALKS OFF TILL TOMORROW
description: A negotiation session between Typographical Union No. 6 and the city's three major daily newspapers scheduled for today was postponed yesterday until 2:30 P.M. tomorrow by Theodore W. Kheel, the mediator in the dispute.

title: Mrs. King Is Upset by Miss Morozova
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 28 Just when it seemed that a predictable pattern had softened much of the drama from the women's professional tennis tour, Olga Morozova surprised Mrs. Billie Jean King, by defeating her 76, 61, today in the final round of the $50,000 Virginia Slims tournament.

title: GIFT SCHEME LAID TO INSURANCE MAN
100,000 IN MARCH FOR SOVIET JEWS
description: With priests, ministers and rabbis in the vanguard, a crowd estimated by the police at more than 100,000 paraded down Fifth Avenue yesterday to demonstrate solidarity with Soviet Jews denied the right to emigrate to Israel.

title: 12 MUSICIANS KEEN IN MODERN WORKS
description: The Speculum Musicae gave another brilliant and totally absorbing concert of 20thcentury works Saturday night in Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: Bottle Stops Champion
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, April 28 (UPI)  Chartchai Chionoi of Thailand, the World Boxing Association flyweight champion, retained his title last night with ay split decision over Fritz Chervet of Switzerland in 15 rounds. There were no knockdowns but the enraged Swiss fans stormed the ring when the decision was announced and Chartchai was knocked down by a bottle, as he was being hustled to the dressing room after his unpopular victory.

title: Gaganvihari Mehta, 74, Is Dead; Indian Economist, Envoy to U.S.
description: NEW DELHI, April 28 (UPI) Gaganvihari Mehta, former Ambassador to the United States, died of a heart attack today at the age of 74, the Press Trust of India reported.

title: TOOLS SHIPMENTS AT PEAK IN MARCH
description: Shipments of new machine tools in March equalled the record level of just under $176,9million, while sales of used machine tools in both March and the first quarter set new highs.

title: Who Do You Believe?
description: WASHINGTON  When Whitney North Seymour Jr., then United. States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, called a news conference to announce the indictments of John Mitchell and Maurice Stans, he heaved a sigh for the cameras and bemoaned a sad day for justice.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming Passenger and Mail Ships

title: YOO CHIN SAN
description: SEOUL. Korea. April 28  Yoo Chin San, head of South Korea's opposition New Democratic party, died of intestinal cancer at Hanyang University Hospital here today. He was 68 years old.

title: HUNT SUES MOBIL FOR $13BILLION;Oil Producer and, 12 Others Are Accused of Going Back on Libyan Agreement
description: ALEXANDRIA. Va., April 28 (UPI)Nelson Bunker Hunt, the Texas oil man, has filed $13billion antitrust suit in United States District Court here against the Mobil Oil Corporation.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs
description: Rangers vs. Philadelphia

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Crucible of O'Neill's Genius Is Sold
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., Agril 27Eugene O'Neill's boyhood summer homethe setting for both the tragic Long Day's Journey Into Night and the comic Ah Wilderness!was sold today to the Eugene O'Neill Memorial Theater Center in Waterford. The deed was formally transferred in a ceremony held on the front lawn of the eightroom, twostory wooden building, known as the Monte Carlo cottagea national landmark since August, 1971.

title: Corrections Director Named
description: CONCORD, N. H., April 28 (AP)Joseph C. Vitek, warden of the New Hampshire State Prison, has been named Nebraska's corrections director, effective June 1.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: DISCOVERER What Christopher Columbus actually discovered when he came upon Hispaniola in 1492 were Indians who represented a Central and LatinAmerican population that had been working gold and making gold artifacts for 1,000 to 1,500 years.

title: Yarborough Takes Wild Virginia 500
description: MARTINSVILLE, Va:, April 28  It began with all the grace of hippopotami thrashing in a giant bathtub. When it ended, with Cale, Yarborough a 2.1second winner over Richard Petty, the rest of the field for the Virginia 500 looked almost as if it had been run over by a herd of elephants.

title: Leftists Plan Lisbon Roles; Socialist Leader Returns
description: LISBON, April 28 Mario Soares, the leader of the Socialist party, returned here in triumph today from five years of exile in Paris as Portuguese leftists began organizing themselves for the possibility of role in a provisional government.

title: Bloomfield College Faces Trial For Ending Tenure for Faculty
description: Bloomfield College, a small, private coeducational institution in Bloomfield, N. J., goes on trial today, accused of having broken a contract with its faculty union when it dismissed 11 tenured faculty members last year and abolished tenure for the remainder of the teaching staff.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Max Richtman Weds Lucy Freedman
description: Miss Lucy Diane Freedman, an educational consultant in Washington, was married yesterday afternoon to Max Richtman, legislative assistant to Representative Sidney R. Yates, Democrat of Illinois.

title: Weather Reports and Forecast
Bruins Rout Hawks, 62, For 32 Lead
description: BOSTON, April 28 (UPI) The Boston Bruins trounced the Chicago Black Hawks, 62, tonight on two goals each by John Bucyk and Phil Esposito to take a 32 lead in their Stanley Cup semifinal series.

title: KISSINGER MEETS GROMYKO TO SEEK MIDEAST BACKING
description: GENEVA, April 28  Secretary of State Kissinger arrived here tonight and met with Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko to discuss SovietAmerican issues and to try to get Soviet help in his efforts for an IsraeliSyrian accord.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Princeton Borough and Princeton Township will start a joint publictransportation program this morning, when the Princeton community bus service goes into operation. The shuttle service involves two buses. The 48minute route links Princeton University, the central business district and the residential sections of the suburban community. The service, which will cost 25 cents a ride, will operate on weekdays between 9 A.M. and 4:30 P.M. for a 90day experimental period.

title: EAST BLOC LOOKS TO FIRM DETENTE
description: GDANSK, PolandThe leaders of the Soviet bloc, although they are perhaps not quite so confident as they profess to be, seem to be counting on what they call an irreversible improvement in relations between the Soviet Union and the United States and an effective end to the cold war.

title: State Troopers' Complaints Allege Promotions Are Linked to Politics
description: NEWARK, April 28The disputtt between New Jersey's 1, 600 state troopers and their commander goes beyond alleged trafficticket quota system, according to troopers in terviewed here last week.

title: JOHN LEVINSON DIES; LAWYER, GOLFER, 59
description: KENNEBUNK BEACH, Me., April 28John O. Levinson, a Chicago corporation lawyer and a nationally known amateur golfer, died yesterday in the Maine Medical tenter, Portland. He was 59 years old.

title: Teachers Approve Pact Ending Strike In Kansas City, Mo.
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 28 (AP)The Kansas City Board of Education and teachers gave Overwhelming approval to contract agreement today, ending the teachers' strike in its 42d day.

title: Nixon Talk on Tapes
description: President Nixon will go on television tonight with a repoct on his planned response to the House Judiciary Committee's subpoena of 42 taped conversations, White House sources reported. Details on Page 19.

title: Concert
description: Gustav Leonhardt, the Dutch harpsichordist who is well known here through concerts and recordings, was back in town Saturday night and at Tully Hall, but the event this time was more than a harpsichord recital.

title: TOMS RIVER LIFTS STUDENT PENALTY
description: TOMS RIVER, April 28The first of 196 students who were suspended last week for protesting a shortened spring vacation will be readmitted to school tomorrow, the Superintendent of Schools said today, but they must bring a parent to meet with school administrators before they can return to classes.

title: Lauda's Ferrari Wins in Spain
description: MADRID, April 28  The Ferrari cars, which have slowly been going around in circles the last two years, made a few quick adjustments today and won the Grand Prix of Spain. It was the team's 50th Grand Prix victory, and the first for Niki Lauda of Austria.

title: Illegally Parked Cars Hog City Hall Spaces
description: In the crowded streets around City Hall on any weekday, illegal parking preempts a majority of metered parking spaces and frequently many of the spaces reserved for municipal agencies as well.

title: Jurors Couldn't Believe Federal Witnesses
description: The jurors in the MitchellStans trial said yesterday that they had voted to acquit the two former Cabinet officers of all criminal charges because they could not believe the testimony of crucial Government witnesses.

title: Nixon Seeks Senate Conservative Aid
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 President Nixon, who was preparing today to step up his campaign against impeachment, is directing his appeal increasingly to the minority conservative bloc in the Senate.

title: RON CARTER QUARTET PLAYS BUOYANT JAZZ
description: The Roland Hanna Quartet, which has just completed six concerts in the series Jazz: The Personal Dimension, turned up. this weekend at the Cellar, Columbus Avenue and 95th Street where it was known as the Ron Carter Quartet.

title: U.S. Panel to Study Steps to Heal Herbicide Damage in Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, April 28The Defense Department next month will, convene a committee from eight Government agencies to study, what steps the United States can take to help South Vietnam cope with the ecological damage caused by the American use of herbicides during the war.

title: Jack Holland Weds Ellen A. Thalhimer
description: Miss Ellen Ann Thalhimer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Goldsmith Thalhimer of Richmond, was married last evening to. Jack K. Hol land, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Kurt Holland of Atlanta.

title: Kodak Profit Rise Trails Sales Gain
description: The Eastman Kodak Company reported yesterday a slight rise in profit for the first quarter ended March 24, despite a strong increase in total sales for the period.

title: Promise of the Sun
description: One hopes that it is cool technological calculationand nothing more nefariousthat keeps damping enthusiasm among official energy planners for the option of solar energy. The suspicion cannot always be avoided that solar energy research is being downgraded for fear of threatening the private sector's financial commitment and the Administration's not unrelated political commitmentto nuclear power as the future prime source of electricity.

title: Mozambique: Raids Go On
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, April 28  About 70,000 Portuguese soldiers are reported involved in the fighting against African nationalist guerrillas in the East African territory Mozambique.

title: MITCHELL AND STANS ARE ACQUITTED ON ALL COUNTS AFTER 48DAY TRIAL
description: John N. Mitchell and Maurice H. Stans were acquitted yesterday of all charges in their criminal conspiracy case, thus ending the first trial of former Cabinet officials since the Teapot Dome scandal.

title: Pet Hospital Group Elects
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 28 (AP)Dr. R. L. Ticehurst of Atlantic Highlands, N.J., has been elected president of the American Animal Hospital Association. The 5,500member pet hospital organization concluded its annual convention here today.

title: Personal Finance HomeSales Taxes
description: One who sells his home and buys another has long been able to defer payment of the Federal income tax on any gain he makes on the first home provided the costof the new house is at least as much as the adjusted price of the old one.

title: Ashe Drops First Match To Tanner
description: DENVER, April 28 (AP) Roscoe. Tanner won a battle of power serves today, whipping Arthur Ashe, 62, 64, for his first $10,000 victory on the World Championship of Tennis tour in the final Green Group event.

title: About the Mets ...
description: Sentimental choice among the Mets for the Kentucky Derby  except for Rube Walker, the pitching coach  is Rube the Great. ... Between games of the doubleheader, several Giants received awards from Charles (Chub) Feeney, president of the National League and a resident of San Francisco. To Bobby Bonds: a Golden Glove Award for outfield defense in 1973. From The Sporting News: to Bonds, as player of the year; to Ron Bryant, as pitcher of the year; to Gary Matthews, as rookie of the year, and to Steve Ontiveros, as minorleague player of the year ... Doctors advised Giants not to expect Tito Fuentes back this week. The second baseman injured his back in season's opener. ... Next for the Mets, three in Los Angeles against the redhot Dodgers. George Stone, Jerry Koosman and Tom Seaver will pitch against Don Sutton, Tommy John and Andy Messersmith, whose combined record is 11 victories, one defeat.

title: NIXON TO REPORT ON TAPES TONIGHT
description: WASHINGTON, April 28  President Nixon will go on television tomorrow night with report to the nation on his planned response to the House Judiciary Committee's subpoena of some 42 taped conversations, White House sources said today.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 35

title: RUSSIAN CAUTIONS WEST ON TACTICS
description: MOSCOW, April 28  The dissident Soviet historian Roy Medvedev has reiterated his warning to the West that too much outside pressure will prevent rather than promote greater liberalization in the Soviet Union.

title: 2 Paintings Stolen in Poland
description: WARSAW, April 28 (UPI) Two paintings valued at a total of $390,000 have been stolen from a museum in Gdansk, in northern Poland, the newspaper Zycie Warszawy said today. The paintings were The Woman Carrying Glowing Embers by Brueghel the Younger and The Sketch of an Altar by Van Dyck.

title: Egyptian Mayor Offers Nixon Money for Taxes
description: CAIRO, Monday, April 29 (Reuters)The mayor of a small Egyptian village has offered President Nixon $2,500 toward helping the Presdent settle his tax debts, but Mr. Nixon declined, the semiofficial newspaper Al Ahram reported today.

title: Trials of French Election: Ridicule and Rotten Fruit
description: PARIS, April 28The campaign for the Presidency of France, with only one week to go before the first round of voting next Sunday, is rapidly getting hoarser and hotter.

title: W.H.A. Playoffs
description: Chicago vs. Toronto

title: Rutgers Sweeps 3 Races
description: DERBY, Conn., April 28 Rutgers' lightweight crews swept to victory in all three races over Yale and Dartmouth today at the Derby race course on the Housatonic River.

title: Issue and Debate
description: Early in February, at the height of the nation's gasoline crisis, Peggy Galgano, an 18yearold nursing student from Westchester County, rolled down her car window, craned her neck toward the service station and gazed disconsolately at the 50 cars ahead of her, all waiting for a turn at the gas pump.

title: ELMER O. FREMONT SR.
description: Elmer G. Fremont Sr., honorary chairman of Emerson Consultants, Inc., 30 Rockefeller Plaza, management consultants, died Friday in Birmingham, Mich., where he lived. His age was 85.

title: Bridge: Might Have Been Is Found More Truth Than
description: The famous lines of Whittier about the saddest words of tongue or pen have a constant application in tournament bridge. Players lie awake at night thinking of might  have  beens, as the South player might have done after the diagramed deal from the Vanderbilt Cup in Vancouver, British Columbia, last month.

title: Miss Reppert Is Bride Here
description: Miss Margro Farrar Reppert and Perrin Hamilton Long Jr., son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Long of Chappaquiddick Island, Edgartown, Mass., were married here yesterday afternoon in Trinity Episcopal Church by the Rev. Birney W. Smith Jr.

title: CALENDAR HEAVY IN DEBT MARKETS
description: Traders in the credit markets this week face among other things an announcement of plans for a $5:6billion Treasury refunding, an estimated $457million in new corporatedebt offerings and an estimated $418million in new taxexempt, as well as a regular weekly auction of Treasury bills today and a oneyear bill auction on Wednesday.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: TEANECK, April 28When John Hill, the New York Giants' offensive tackle, was named an assistant track coach at Fairleigh Dickinson University, he replaced a man who has the 1976 Olympics on his mind.

title: A.B.A. Championship
description: Nets vs. Utah

title: Suspect in Attempted Murder And Rape Freed Without Bail
description: Criminal Court Judge Bruce McM, Wright, who has often been criticized for his lenient bail policies, last night paroled without bail a 41yearold defendant accused of kidnapping, attempted murder of a police officer and rape.

title: INSTITUTE APPOINTS HARVARD ECONOMIST
description: The board of trustees of the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N. J., has announced the appointment of Prof. Albert O. Hirschman, a Harvard economist, as the second professor in the institute's, School of Social Sciences.

title: Experimental Findings Challenge Accepted Theories on Atomic Physics and Cause Confusion in Science
description: Experiments with new and more powerful research tools, some of them described for the first time last week at a meeting of the American Physical Society in Washington, have thrown into turmoil science's efforts to comprehend nature on its most basic level.

title: About New York
description: The question is whether New York is getting better or worse, and the answer is that it all depends on how you look at it. This is no answer, of course, but then the question isn't very good either. New Yorkers have always complained about their city; it is their way, and there is something deep in a New Yorker's soul that cries out against saying things are fine. If someone from Indianapolis, say, tells a New Yorker that his city stinks, the New Yorker probably will agree with him. It will not occur to the New Yorker, though, to move to Indianapolis.

title: Brandt's Party Fears Effect of Spy Case
description: BONN, April 28The arrest last week of an East German Communist spy on Chancellor Willy Brandt's staff began this weekend to take on grave domestic and international political implications.

title: Books of The Times
description: LOST CHANCE IN CHINA: The World War Dispatches of John S. Service. Edited by Joseph W. Esherick. 409 pages. Random House. $12.95.

title: Group in Ridgefield Is Formed to Block I.B.M. Copter Pad
description: Ridgefield is set in a remarkably diversified terrain of hills, streams and woods, wrote the historian Allan Nevins, where no factory smoke stains the sky, and the distant train whistle seldom Interrupts the cawing crows.

title: John Miller Coast Victor By a Stroke
Japanese Retains Title
description: TOKYO, April 28 (AP)  Zensuke Utagawa of Japan retained his Orient featherweight boxing title today knocking out Romeo Tomagan, a Filipino fighting out of Guam, in the sixth round of a scheduled 12round bout. Each weighed 125 pounds.

title: A FACULTY UNION IS SUING COLLEGE
description: Bloomfield College, a small private coeducational institution in Bloomfield, N. J., goes on trial today, accused of having broken a contract with its faculty union when it dismissed 11 tenured faculty members last year and abolished tenure for the remainder of the teaching staff.

title: Du Quoin Will Remain Host to Hambletonian
description: The Hambletonian harness racing's premier event will remain at the Du Quoin (Ill.) State Fair, its site since 1957. A contract for the stake for 3yearold trotters was extended yesterday for three years, beginning in 1975, at a meeting of the 21member Hambletonian Society at the Sheraton LaGuardia Hotel.

title: Richardson on Tapes
description: Former Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson Said the White House tapes being sought by the House Judiciary Committee could very well tip the impeachment case against President Nixon one way or the other. Details are on Page 19.

title: Bill on Secrecy Is Planned
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) Legislation intended to give Congress a role in determining what Government information can be kept secret for national security reasons will he introduced tomorrow by Senator Edward S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, and Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York. The bill would set up a Congressional monitor over security classification and create a national registrar of classified documents.

title: Miss Blalock Wins by 3 in Birmingham
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 28 (UPI)Jane Blalock shot a twounderpar 70 today to win the $5,000 first prize in th Birmingham Classic by three strokes over Sandra Palmer.

title: J. Walter Thompson Has $2Million Loss
description: The J. Walter Thompson Company reported a net loss of more than $2million in the first quarter, which is attributed to a number of factors, but primarily the worldwide energy crisis.

title: Tenant Complaints Drop In Relocation Areas Here
description: Complaints from apartment dwellers charging tenantrelocation companies with harassment tactics have dropped sharply in the last year and are dell below a peak reached several years ago, city and state officials report.

title: Egyptians Accuse Qaddafi Of Starting Plot for Coup
description: CAIRO, April 28An official Egyptian document today for the first time explicitly accused Muathmar elQaddafi of Libya of having instigated a plot to arrest President Anwar elSadat and to overthrow the moderate Egyptian Government.

title: Glassmaker's Studio Burns in Valley Cottage
description: VALLEY COTTAGE, N.Y., April 28A 100yearold red barn on Old Mill Road here where Maurice Heaton, the 73yearold glassmaker, maintained his studio burned to the ground early today with a loss of valuable tools and a collection of irreplaceable church windows.

title: ISRAEL ANDSYRIA CONTINUE TO SPAR
description: TEL AVIV, April 28Israeli and Syrian forces continued to spar today with smallscale air strikes and sporadic shelling along their troubled front lines.

title: In the Gubernatorial Race, Some Verities of Campaign Spending
description: While competing with each other to bare their financial souls and reassure an electorate shocked by the Watergate scandals, four Democratic gubernatorial candidates are also providing a rare glimpse into the making of a gubernatorial campaign and, in some cases, their political weaknesses.

title: Ballet: Martha Graham's Fantasia
description: At a time when so many of our choreographers, lost like uncouth Adams in the forest of nomenclature, are reduced to calling works New Ballet One, or perhaps even New Ballet Two, or, to be adventurous, Concerto, or Symphony in Seven and a Half Movements for Brass Band and Harmonium, Martha Graham continues to enrich literature with the titles of works. Indeed, I would prefer merely to read a list of her repertory to seeing the repertory of many a lesser choreographer. Her genius for her art spills over into related fields. She knows language. It helps.

title: About the Yankees...
description: Until yesterday's twin bill at Shea, Ron Blomberg, who had been out with a leg injury, had batted in only three runs this season. By the end of the second inning of the second game. Blomberg had topped that figure by one with his second home run of the day.... A homer by the Rangers' Mike Hargrove in the sixth inning of the opener was the first of his major league career. The 24yearold rookie spent last season with Gastonia (N.C.) of the Western Carolinas League.... The official scorer announced he had removed an error from Mel Stottlemyre's record and credited Jim Spencer with a hit in the second inning of Friday night's game.... The Yankees conclude their homestand with two games against Oakland tomorrow night and Wednesday afternoon. The As pitchers are expected to be Vida Blue and Jim (Catfish) Hunter.

title: Davis Designates Another Hit in 43 Oriole Victory
Celtics Go 1Up On Bucks
Maurice Hubert Stans
description: The defense calls Maurice Stans. The former Commerce Secretary stood up and walked to the witnesses who preceded him. Mr. Stans turned to face the jury. He seemed relieved at last to tell his story. He spoke in a rambling folksy way. It was the 39th day of Maurice Hubert Stant's conspiracyperjury trial.

title: A.B.A. Championship
description: April 30At Nassau Coliseum, 3:05 P.M.

title: Promotions Linked to Politics, Jersey State Troopers Allege
description: NEWARK, April 28The dispute between New Jersey's 1,600 state troopers and their commander, goes beyond an alleged trafficticket quota system, according to troopers interviewed here last week.

title: 100,000 IN MARCH FOR SOVIET JEWS
description: With priests, ministers and rabbis in the vanguard, a crowd, estimated by the police at more, than 100,000 paraded down Fifth Avenue yesterday to demonstrate solidarity with Soviet Jews denied the right to emigrate to Israel.

title: Exile Is Met With Songs In Portugal
description: LISBON, April 28  Mr. Soares, called out a Danish reporter standing on a table in the crowded stationmaster's office, would you compare yourself to Lenin at the Finland Station?

title: 3 Top Generals in Ethiopia Reported Arrested by Army
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, April 28 (Reuters)The former commander of Emperor Haile Selassie's bodyguard and two other top generals have been arrested by the army, military sources said today.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 35

title: Twelve Months On
description: BOSTON, April 28How much longer it seems. It is just a year since the speech that President Nixon hoped would still the tremors of Watergate but that in fact marked the beginning of the earthquake: his broadcast address of April 30, 1973.

title: HIGHRISK POLICIES INCREASE IN COST
description: The highrisk pool that the State Legislature, ordered fire insurance companies to set up in 1968, largely for shun areas, has proved successful enough to lose business.

title: AIRLINE PLANNING ATLANTIC SHUTTLE
description: WASHINGTON, April 26A British airline says it plans to start a nofrills, noreservations shuttle service between New York and London in June, despite official uncertainty about its future that will eventually have to be resolved in the White House.

title: Asian Development Bank Seeks Iran as Member
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, April 28 (Reuters)Shiro Inoue president of the Asian Development Bank, said the bank should consider the possibility of tapping surplus funds from oilproducing countries, and added that he would shortly go to Teheran to ask Iran to become a member.

title: Kurosawa's '43 Sanshiro Sugata Opens
description: Glimpses of his subsequent greatness are plain to see in Akira Kurosawa's 1943 movie, Sanshiro Sugata, his first directorial stint.

title: National League YESTERDAY'S GAMES
description: New York 6, San Francisco 0 (1st). New York 6, San Francisco 4 (2d). Chicago 4, Atlanta 3. Los Angeles 4, Montreal 0. Pittsburgh 7, Houston 3, St. Louis 9, Cincinnati 2. San Diego 3, Philadelphia 4. Standings on Page 44

title: SEGRETTI CITES LINK TO NIXON'S ATTORNEY
description: Donald H. Segretti, who was released from prison last month after being convicted for political dirty tricks, said yesterday that Earl J. Silbert, the original Watergate prosecutor, knew that Mr. Segretti was paid by Herbert W. Kalmbach, then President Nixon's personal attorney, and did not pursue the connection.

title: Yankees Win, 112, Lose, 85 Mets Sweep Giarits
2 DOCTORS OFFER DYSLEXIA THEORY
description: Two New York psychiatrist believe they have discovered that a faulty connection some where between the brain, and the inner ear is the cause o?? primary dyslexia, a commo?? learning disorder that inter feres with a child's ability to read.

title: A Historic Trial: Few in Such High Posts Have Faced Such Serious Charges
description: John N. Mitchell and Maurice H. Stans had, as the prosecutor said at the start of his summation on Wednesday, sat at the very pinnacle of government in this country, and because of that what their 48 actual trial days lacked in drama was more than made up for in historic importance.

title: Soviet Jew Is Seized On Way to Address Americans by Phone
description: MOSCOW, April 28A Leningrad Jew who has been refused permission to emigrate to Israel was arrested yesterday as he was on his way to respond to an invitation to address an American group by longdistance telephone, friends of the family reported today.

title: All the Children Sewed, All Did Woodwork  Regardless of Sex
description: The scene: The Educational Alliance Child Care Center on the Lower East Side.

title: DAVID E. GOLIEB
description: David E. Golieb, who retired in 1959 as executive vice president of Deknatel, Inc., of Queens Village, Queens, hospital supplies manufacturer, died Saturday at his home, 239 Central Park West. He was 88 years old.

title: Troubled Fiat, Once Liberal, Builds Ties to Italy's Establishment
description: ROME, April 28The Fiat Motor Company, the fifth biggest auto maker in the world and Italy's largest private company, is hardpressed at present and says its immediate prospects are not good, but it voices confidence that it will be able to regain a smooth ride.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Two Children Die in Brooklyn Fire

title: Penn Bight, Eli Women Win Races
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 28  The Yale varsity women's crew accomplished something today its male counterparts have been unable to do the last ten years. The Yale girls beat a varsity eight from the University of Pennsylvania. They did it by two lengths over a 1,000meter course on the choppy Schuylkill River this morning as part of a sixevent regatta.

title: BackDoor School Laws
description: By approving a bill to restore tenure to supervisory positions in the city schools, the State Senate has embarked on a direct threat to decentralization and to the concept of managerial accountability.

title: Verdict for the Defense
description: The acquittal of John N. Mitchell and Maurice H. Stans of charges stemming from a secret cash contribution to President Nixon's reelection campaign represents a notable victory for the defense in an historic case. It substantially vindicates the two former Cabinet officers and the American system of justice which gave them their day in court before a jury of peers.

title: KISSINGER MEETS GROMYKO TO SEEK MIDEAST BACKING
description: GENEVA, April 28  Secretary of State Kissinger arrived here tonight and met with Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko to discuss SovietAmerican issues and to try to get Soviet help in his efforts for an IsraeliSyrian accord.

title: Bank Robber Eludes Office Search
description: Despite a chase by four bank employes and a twohour search of an office building into which he had run, a robber escaped with $2,900 yesterday after he held up the Chemical Bank branch on Madison Avenue near 46th Street.

title: DeFunis Decision May Bring Pressure to End Race as College Admission Criterion
description: Colleges and graduate schools remain free to use race as special consideration in admissions decisions following the Supreme Court's refusal to rule on the merits of the DeFunis reverse discrimination case last week, but some campus officials see pressure in the decision to substitute in the future colorblind criteria such as an applicant's social and economic background.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE GYPSY'S CURSE. By Harry Crews. 207 pages. Knopf. $5.95.

title: Bar Chief for Impeaching
description: MEMPHIS, April 29 (UPI)The president of the American Bar Association said today if he were in the House of Repressentatives, he would vote to impeach President Nixon. I think it's desirable for the Watergate issue to be resolved, said Chesterfield Smith. It can't be resolved in the court because President Nixon cannot be convicted or acquitted of any charges while he is still President.

title: ANSWER TO PREVIOUS PUZZLE
Leading Candidates for Governor of California Lose Ground in Polls but Maintain Edges
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 29Both the leading Democratic and Republican candidates for the nominations for Governor of California have maintained their edges in the latest public opinion polls, but both have also lost ground.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Superior Court Judge David D. Furman of Middlesex County invalidated the amendments to Madison Township's zoning ordinances on the ground that they did, little to open up what be called an essentially exclusionary housing code. The changes, he ruled, constituted only a token step in the direction of making more middleincome housing available in the community, and did nothing whatever to make lower income housing available.

title: Senate Votes to Lift Port Agency Curb
description: ALBANY, April 29A bill to end bond designed covenants that bar the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey from investing more heavily in mass transportation was approved unanimously by the Senate tonight without debate.

title: GORDON D. SHAUB
description: Gordon Dietrich Shaub, environmental engineer and project manager for Roy F. Weston Company of Roslyn; L. I., died Saturday of a heart attack at the Plandome Country Club, Manhasset, L. I. His age was 36 and he lived in Port Washington, L. I.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: Hy Kahaner is President of the House of Kahaner Div. of WILLCOX & GIBBS (WGAMEX)Advt.

title: Drive by Foes Imperils Homosexual Bill
description: The public campaign by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, fire fighters and police officers has made uncertain the future of the homosexual civilrights bill, which seemed assured 10 days ago of passage by the City Council.

title: 2 Held Hostage in $200,000 Bank Holdup
description: RANDOLPH TOWNSHIP, April 29The wife of a bank executive and her housekeeper were held hostage this morning while the executive was forced to go to the National Community Bank's main office in Dover, fill a briefcase with $200,000 in cash and give it to two holdup men.

title: 19 RESTAURANTS LISTED AS DIRTY
description: A delicatessen where Mayor Beanie stopped for a cornedbeef sandwich on a walking tour of the Lower East Side last week showed up yesterday on the city's list of dirty restaurants.

title: A WEIDMAN REVIVAL FOR HOUSE DIVIDED
description: The bulk of Charles Weidman's repertory has been absent from our stages for so long that we seize eagerly any revival he chooses to make. In his current Sunday evening series at the Expression of Two Arts Theater, he is offering A House Divided, not seen here for more than 20 years, and Commedia, a section from Opus 51.

title: FIAT STOCKHOLDERS MEETING
description: The Ordinary Meeting of Fiat Stockholders took place on April 26, 1974, in Turin. Mr. Giovanni Agnelli, the Chairman of Fiat, in his report emphasized the fundamental rile played by the automobile as the principal instrument of mobility. He said that it was with this confidence that Fiat had stepped up its investments In the South of Italy and completed the agreement with the Brazilian Government for, the establishment of a car factory at Minas Gerais, thus giving the go ahead to the execution of the most important initiative of the Group. Fiat was equally committedthe Chairman saidto ex Rand those production sectors such as buses, trains and every other collective mode of transport in town and out of town that could successfully integrate the services offered by the automobile.

title: Toll in Peruvian Landslides Is Officially Put at 250 Dead
description: LIMA, Peru, April 29 (Reuters)  The first official toll in the landslides last Thursday that wiped out two Andean villages put the number of dead today at 250 and the missing at 500.

title: PORTUGAL PARTIES SPLIT WITH JUNTA ON AFRICA POLICY
description: LISBON, April 29The major Portuguese parties of the left and center differed today with the nation's new leader, Gen. Antonio de Spnola, over his longrange program of keeping the African territories tied to Portugal.

title: RENTRISE REPEAL IS DEBATED AGAIN
description: A bill to repeal rent increases of up to 4 per cent a year in many of the one million rentcontrolled apartments here was defended by tenant spokesman and denounced by landlords at a City Council hearing yesterday.

title: Harvard Study Finds Some Benefits in Temporarily Dropping Out of College
description: A researcher at Harvard University maintains that dropping out of college for a semester or longer, a practice that has traditionally been frowned upon by a society oriented toward completing an undergraduate degree in four years, may be more beneficial than people have thought.

title: Key Allende Aides To Face Trial Soon In Chilean Capital
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 29 The military junta said today that the most important of the imprisoned members of the overthrown Marxist coalition Government would be transferred this week to Santiago in preparation for courtmartial proceedings.

title: School Coaches Defer Move on Job Action
description: Coaches of the Public Schools Athletic League lastnight deferred their threatened job action.

title: Colson Asserts Kissinger Wanted Ellsberg Stopped
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 A former Presidential counsel, Charles W. Colson, in the first public account of his involvement with the White House plumbers group, declared today that Henry A. Kissinger had played a major role in the initial highlevel concern aver Dr. Daniel Ellsberg.

title: No Clues on Lost Balloonist
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP)  A $10,000 reward offered for information about the missing balloonist Thomas Gatch Jr., has produced no clues, a spokesman for Mr. Gatch said today. Mr. Gatch disappeared two months ago while trying to become the first man to cross the Atlantic in a balloon.

title: ExGovernor of Mozambique Is Flown to Portugal
description: The following dispatch was provided to The New York Times by The Argus Africa News Service of Johannesburg, South Africa.

title: Senate Backs Tourism
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP)The Senate adopted a resolution today calling on Government agencies to allocate sufficient energy supplies to maintain a robust tourist industry. The resolution said tourism was the second largest retail expenditure in the United States and provided 4 million jobs.

title: DR. CHARLES POSNER OF HARLEM HOSPITAL
description: Dr. A. Charles Posner, former director of obstetrics and president of the medical board of Harlem Hospital, died Sunday at his apartment in the Croydon Hotel. He was 76 years old.

title: Saigo Army Veteran Burns Himself to Death
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 30 (Reuters)A 35yearold South Vietnamese Veterlin burned himself to death in The An Quang Pagoda in Saigon last night, leaving letters saying that he did it for a peaceful Vietnam, a spokesman at the major Buddhist Pagoda said today.

title: Strauss Protests Time Networks Gave Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP)The Democratic National Chairman, Robert S. Strauss, asked the three major television networks today to reconsider their grant of air time for President Nixon's 9 P.M. address.

title: Pan Am Airways' Loss Grew in First Quarter
description: Pan American World Airways, Inc., reported yesterday a $24.4million net loss for this year's first quarter. It was the second worst showing of any calendar quarter in the company's history. (In the first quarter of 1972 Pan Am had net loss of $37.9million.)

title: Quotation of the Day
description: In giving you these, blemishes and all, I am placing my trust in the basic fairness of the American people.President Nixon, announcing that he would turn over edited transcripts of Watergate conversations to the House Judiciary Committee. [1:8.]

title: Front Page 3  No Title
165 in a Motorcycle Gang Cited for Following Closely
description: READING, Pa., April 29 (UPI)State policemen stopped about 165 members of the Pagans motorcycle gang near here yesterday and charged them with following each other too closely.

title: Mrs. Carrie Rukeyser Dead; Headed Temple Sisterhoods
description: Mrs. Carrie Ballin Rukeyser, a past president and director of the National Federation of Temple Sisterhoods, died yesterday at her home, 20 Old Mamaroneck Road, White Plains. Her age was 65. She was the wife of Merryle S. Rukeyser, economist and financial columnist.

title: Chess:
description: Paul Keres, the Estonian grandmaster, once remarked that he preferred to play in a style opposite to that of his opponent. Against positional maneuverers, he would draw on his remarkable talent as a tactician; against tacticians, he would show off the positional side of his play and his skill in end games.

title: LISBON'S EXCHIEFS LIVING IN A PALACE
description: FUNCHAL, Madeira, April 29 Cool breezes, forested mountains and vineyards producing the famous Madeira wines com??ine to make this Portuguese island a major resort. Since last week, it his also been the home of the exiled leaders of the ousted Portuguese Government, who are living in palatial luxury, reading, watching television and, according to one aide, hoping for the best.

title: F.B.I. TO SEEK TAPS ON TERRORIST UNITS
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) The Federal Bureau of Inestigation told a House panel today that it was barred by present laws and court decisions from wiretapping terrorist groups like the socalled Symbionese Liberation Army.

title: ABC Debut for QB VII Upset By Timing of Nixon's Speech
description: President Nixon's televised address last night collided with the carefully laid plans of ABCTV for one of its major events of the season, the showing of the first part of QB VII, a six hour adaptation of the Leon Uris novel, which reportedly had cost $2.5million to produce. The network is presenting it in two parts on successive evenings.

title: Newspaper Endorsements Held Influential in Voting
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., April 29 (UPI)Though the American public ranks television as its major source of campaign news, newspaper endorsements appear to carry more weight in the outcome of a Presidential election, according to a researcher at the University of Michigan.

title: Stock Prices Mixed in Slow Trading
description: The stock market played a waiting game yesterday and closed without a definite trend in very dull trading.

title: Alioto Says Police Have an Information Source in Zebra Case
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 29Mayor Joseph L. Alioto said today that with his help the police were in contact with an Important source of information in the investigation of the Zebra murders. The Mayor would not identify the source nor would he describe the information.

title: House Supports Measure To Create a Fire Academy
description: WASHINGTON. April 29 (UPI)The House voted 352 to 12 today to create a United States Fire Academy to train professional and volunteer firefighters in the latest methods of flame control and arson investigation.

title: Senate Approves Easing Of Voters' Registration
description: TRENTON, April 29  A Byrne administration bill designed to ease voterregistration restrictions by allowing eligible voters to register by postcard was approved tonight by the State Senate.

title: Receivership Is Set for DebtRidden Miami Hospital
description: MIAMI, April 29A United States bankruptcy judge here decided today to appoint a receiver to administer the financial affairs of the debtridden Cedars of Lebanon Hospital.

title: White House Yacht Secured
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 (UPI)  The Navy has hilt a new cinder block security wall near the dock where the Presidential yacht Sequoia is tied up. White House military aides said the wall was built at a cost of $400 after a chainlink fence was blown down Sept. 29, 1973, by the downdraft of a sky crane helicopter near the dock at the Navy yard.

title: Business Briefs
description: Ford Argentine Unit to Sign Cuba Pact

title: Nixon Said to Have Paid Most of His Back Taxes
description: BALTIMORE, April 29 (AP)  President Nixon has paid most of the $467,000 that the Internal Revenue Service said he owed in back taxes and interest, according to an authoritative source quoted tonight by The Baltimore Sun.

title: Kuh Won't Appeal In 1967 Slaying Of Marine Sergeant
description: Ditrict Attorney Richard H. Kuh decided yesterday not to appeal a decision that set aside a manslaughter conviction of William A. Maynard for a 1967 shotgun slaying of a Marine sergeant in Greenwich Village.

title: UNION DISAPPOINTS 150 SEEKING WORK
description: Work permits from the Metallic Lathers Union, Local 46, will not be issued on a firstcome, firstserved basis, it was announced yesterday, though 150 men have camped outside the union's office on East 76th Street, in some cases for more than two weeks.

title: COLLEGE DEGREES SEEN CHEAPENED
description: Dr. William J. McGill, the president of Columbia University, declared last night that an overexpansion of American higher education in recent years had led to a rapid deterioration in the quality of the fouryear degree at many public colleges and universities.

title: Dr. Harry S. Levine Dies; An Internist in Brooklyn
description: Dr. Harry S. Levine, former senior internist for the Kings Highway Medical Group of the Health Insurance Plan and attending physician at Greenpoint (Brooklyn) Hospital, died here yesterday. He lived at 441 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: CHARLES D. HILLES, EXI.T.T. OFFICER
description: Charles Dewey Hilles Jr., a former executive vice president and director of the International Telegraph and Telephone Company, died Sunday in Doctors Hospital. He was 71 years old, and lived at 350 East 57th Street and in Millbrook, N.Y.

title: Advertising: New Retail Venture
description: Last week the Television Bureau of Advertising urged more national ad agencies to get into the retail business and yesterday DancerFitzgeraldSample announced it is in. Beautiful timing, but pure coincidence.

title: PUBLISHERS CONFER TO REVIEW POSITION
description: The publishers of the city's three major daily newspapers met yesterday to review their position in the contract dispute with the printers In preparation for the resumption of bargaining talks at 2:30 P.M. today at Automation House, 49 East 68th Street.

title: The City's Colleges
description: The Legislature has approved a measure that would place the city's eight community colleges fully under the authority of New York City's Board of Higher Education. Although the board, and thus the City University, is in fact now largely responsible for the operation these institutions, the existing organizational structure still involves the State University and its trustees routine management decisions and paper work.

title: 2 Held Hostage as Banker Gives $200,000 in Holdup
description: RANDOLPH TOWNSHIP, April 29The wife of a bank executive and her housekeeper were held hostage this morning while the executive wah forced to go to the National Community Bank's main office in Dover, fill a briefcase with $200,000 in cash and give it to two holdup men.

title: Marine Police Preparing for a Busy Boating Season
description: MONMOUTH BEACHFair winds and enough gasoline would turn the summer of 1974 into a pleasurable season for New Jersey's thousands of inland and saltwater pleasureboat enthusiasts, say the experienced sailors in this area.

title: Mrs. Mitchell Is Suing Husband For Separation and Maintenance
description: Lawyers for Martha Mitchell, the wife of former Attorney General John N. Mitchell, said last night that steps for a legal separation of the couple were started yesterday in State Supreme Court.

title: 20 Are Seized in Madrid On Charges of Terrorism
description: MADRID, April 29 (Reuters) The Spanish police today announced the arrest of 20 Communists who were alleged to have planned terrorist attacks on May Day.

title: Bridge: Young Swiss Team Victor In L.I. Regional Tournament
Syrian Planes Strike at Mt. Hermon
description: IN ISRAELIOCCUPIED SYRIA, April 29After several days of relative quiet, Syrian forces fired hundreds of artillery shells on Israeli positions today and Syrian jets bombed a high, snowcovered saddle on Mount Hermon. Israel reported that four Syrian MIG21's had been shot down by interceptor aircraft.

title: More Unity In Unionism
description: Six years have gone by since the late Walter P. Reuther led his United Auto Workers out of the A.F.L.C.I.O., complaining that it had become a complacent, contented pillar of the status quo, devoid of either initiative or idealism. Institutionally, not much has changed inside the federation since that walkout. George Meany, now only four months removed from his 80th birthday, sits granitelike in command mind and tongue sharp, rule total.

title: 2 Networks Call U.S. Suit Retaliatory
description: LOS ANGELES, April 28 (AP) The CBS and ABC television networks accused the Nixon Administration today of bringing an antitrust suit against them in retaliation for their refusal to play ball with the Administration.

title: Transcript of Nixon's Address to the Nation Regarding Controversy Over Tapes
description: Following is a transcript of President Nixon's address last night, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: CHRYSLER PAISES AUTO PRICES 2.9%
description: DETROIT, April 29  The Chrysler Corporation increased the price of its 1974 model cars an average of $99 today, predicted that another price rise would be needed before next September and issued report that showed its earnlings for the first quarter of the year were down 98.2 per cent.

title: Foreign Aides Get Tips on Techniques To Prevent Crime
description: Putting on their beat diplomatic manner, police officials and civic leaders entertained United Nations and consular personnel at a buffet luncheon with white wine yesterday and then showed them techniques to use against crime  which one poke lecturer described as the negative behavior of some of citizens.

title: 13 Inmates Cut Themselves
description: ST LOUIS, April 29 (UPI)Thirteen white prisoners slashed their arms and wrists with razor blades last night in an apparent protest over integration in a cellblock with blacks.

title: Orthodox Prelate Resigns
description: LONDON, April 29 (Reuters) Metropolitan Anthony Bloom, the Russian Orthodox prelate in Western Europe, has resigned in a row over human rights in the Soviet Union, The Times of London reported tonight.

title: Text of Proposal for Olympic Eligibility
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland, April 29 (Reuters)Following is the text of the International Olympic Committee draft proposal for its new code of eligibility (Rule 26) for Olympic Games, and the relevant bylaws:

title: Bar Chief for Impeaching
description: MEMPHIS, April 29 (UPI) The president of the American Bar Association said today if he were in the House of Representatives, he would vote to impeach President Nixon. I think its desirable for the Watergate issue to he solved, said Chesterfield Smith. The president of the American Bar Association said today if he were in the House of Representatives, he would vote to impeach President Nixon. I think its desirable for the Watergate issue to he solved, said Chesterfield Smith.

title: Funeral in Parliament For Jonas of Austria
description: VIENNA, April 29 (AP)President Franz Jonas was buried today in a state funeral. Mr. Jonas died Wednesday of cancer at the age of 74.

title: Geon Trading to Resume
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced yesterday it would allow exchange and overthecounter trading in securities of Geon Industries, Inc., to resume today.

title: Derby Spree Under Way in Louisville
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 29 At high noon today, a mintjulep sundae containing nearly a ton of vanilla ice cream was devoured here at a public birthday party in honor of next Saturday's 100th Kentucky Derby. Naturally, the 10 foothigh concoction oozed with mint sauce, 72 pounds of it.

title: Witness in TrotFix Trial Attempts to Change Plea
description: Seymour Rothstein, a Queens cab driver, became the second key government witness to change his stance yesterday as the trial of 13 harness drivers accused of fixing superfecta races moved into its seventh week at the Federal Court Building in Brooklyn.

title: U.N. Will Examine Torture Charges in Mozambique
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 29  Charges of Portuguese atrocities against black Africans in the Portuguese East African territory of Mozambique will be investigated by a United Nations commission next month, a United Nations spokesman announced here today.

title: LATE CITY EDITION
description: Weather: Chance of showers later today, tonight. Cooler tomorrow. Temp. range: today 7085; Monday 6189. Additional details on Page 81.

title: Thinking About the Unthinkable
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Our military leaders spend untold hours directing contingency planning for almost every conceivable threat to the nation's security both from within and without. Some of the threats are real. Most, though possible, are highly unlikely.

title: BRITAIN PLANNING CORRUPTION STUDY
description: LONDON, April 29Prime Minister Wilson moved today to set tip a royal commission to lookinto reports of corruption and other irregularities involving public officials.

title: C.A.B. AIDE SCORES AIR TICKET RULES
description: WASHINGTON, April 26A senior official of the Civil Aeronautics Board has accused the nation's airlines of writing selfserving ticketing regulations filled with jargon, doubletalk, strange phraseology and catch phrases as a defense weapon to thwart the grievances and desires of the public.

title: Security Wall Erected In Prison Trouble Area
description: TRENTON, April 29 (UPI)  An eightfoothigh cinderblock wall has been erected to divide a wing of Trenton State Prison that wag the scene of a disturbance last week, state officials said today.

title: U.S. SEES NO CHANGE IN PORTUGUESE TIES
description: WASHINGTON, April 29  The State Department said today that an exchange of notes between the United States and Portugal's new military government marks the continuation of relations without interruption between the two countries.

title: PORTUGAL PARTIES SPLIT WITH JUNTA ON AFRICA POLICY
description: LISBON, April 29The major Portuguese parties of the left and center differed today with the nation's new leader, Gen. Antnio'de Spinola, over his longrange program of keeping the African territories tied to Portugal.

title: CANADA PROPOSES FREEZE ON PRICES
description: OTTAWA, April 29In a move against windfall profits, the Government asked Parliament today for power to freeze prices, or order them rolled back, where there is evidence of profiteering by suppliers.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Legislation creating powerful energy panels and giving the Governor authority to declare an energy emergency was given final legislative approval yesterday Connecticut. The State Senate sent the Housepassed measure to Gov. Thomas J. Meskill, who was expected to sign it. The Senate vote on the bill was 342. An amendment designed to prohibit preferential treatment or discrimination in the sale of petroleum products heating oil, was rejected by the upper house 15 to 2.

title: EXOFFICIAL IS FOUND NOT GUILTY OF BRIBE
description: TOMS RIVER, April 29 (UPI)  James Callaham, former Jackson Township Attorney, was found, not guilty today of all counts of conspiracy and accepting a $5,000 bribe in 1970 in an alleged scheme to obtain a permit for a trailer park.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 30, 1974

title: Circle in Square Takes Its Closing Notice Down
description: Circle in the Square, which announced last month that it would cease operation after 23 years, has taken down its own closing noticeat least for the present.

title: $250,000 Reward Offered In Dublin for Return of Art
description: DUBLIN, April 29 (UPI)  A London insurance company offered a reward of $250,000 today for recovery of the 19 masterpieces stolen Friday in what has been called the world's biggest art robbery.

title: L.I. POLICE SUICIDE NOT INQUIRY TARGET
description: A Government prosecutor said yesterday that a policeman who was found with a subpoena from the Federal Strike Force on Organized Crime in his pocket after he committed suicide last Saturday night at his home on Long Island was not the target of an investigation.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: MANDEL'S FRIENDS LINKED TO PAYOFFS
description: The office of United States Attorney George Beall in Baltimore is investigating information that close associates of, Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland received payoffs for selling jobs and judgeships, according to sources close to the case.

title: Ailing Folk Art Museum Is Under inquiry by State
description: The Museum of American Folk Art, which began 13 years ago as the first institution in the city devoted to this booming field, is being investigated by Attorney Getieral Louis J. Lefkowitz's office as to its financial condition and the disposition of certain art objects from its collection.

title: Market Place: Con Ed Upsets Shareholders
description: Shareholders of Consolidated Edisona company owned largely by individuals rather than giant corporationsstill haven't gotten over last week's dramatic omission of the quarterly dividend. It was the first time the company has failed to pay a dividend in almost 90 years.

title: Article 1  No Title
Wood, Field & Stream
description: I have a tiny notebook bearing the legend Loose Ends, and its chaotic contents remind me of every tackle box I own.

title: SECURITY ANALYSTS SEEK STRICT RULES
description: LOS ANGELES, April 29 Security analysts are taking steps to make it tougher to work in their trade.

title: 12 Indicted on L. I. Over Making of Film Called Pornography
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., April 29  Twelve men and women, including a national porno film star, were indicted here today on obscenity charges stemming from their alleged participatim in a film that was made in Suffolk County.

title: Fire Destroys Court Tapes
description: CAMDEN, April 29 (AP)A fire swept through a storage room of the Camden County Courthouse today, destroying several thousand court reporter, stenotype tapes of trial testimony. The cause of the fire is under investigation by state police and the. Camden Fire Marshal's office. It was reported that the loss might affect several hundred criminal and civilcourt appeals.

title: Hitchcock Skills for Mood and Imagery Are Recalled at Gala Benefit Tribute
description: A twitching eye. A man with one missing finger. A reverse striptease in which a woman is forced to put on makeup. A shadow behind a shower curtain.

title: Kissinger and Gromyko Vow Mideast Cooperation
description: ALGIERS, April 29  The United States and the Soviet Union agreed today to use their influence and to coordinate their efforts to achieve a positive outcome of the Middle East negotiations now under way to achieve a troop separation on the SyrianIsraeli front.

title: Kissinger and Gromyko Vow Mideast Cooperation
description: ALGIERS, April 29  The United States and the Soviet Union agreed today to use their influence and to coordinate their efforts to achieve a positive outcome of the Middle East negotiations now under way to achieve a troop separation on the SyrianIsraeli front.

title: JUSTICES TO WEIGH NIXON FUNDS CURB
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether President Nixon acted illegally in refusing to spend $6billion worth of water pollution funds that Congress had appropriated.

title: Nixon's Counterattack Buoyed by MitchellStans Acquittal, He Acts to Turn the Watergate Tide
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 President Nixon tonight sought to launch the strongest counterattack so far in his long struggle to survive Watergate. The documents he has decided to release, he conceded, were ambiguous and in some cases damaging. But he asserted they would demonstrate that the President has nothing to hide, and it seemed clear from the atmosphere at the White House that he and his senior aides believed the latest effort would bring him victory.

title: ATTEMPTED SUICIDE DEFERS TAX HEARING
description: A pretrial hearing for a methadonetreatment doctor and his wife, accused of tax fraud, was adjourned here yesterday, after their lawyer reported that the doctor had attempted suicide.

title: Maplewood Pacts Expiring
description: Labor contracts between two unions and Maplewood Equipment, New Jersey's secondlargest bus line, are scheduled to expire at midnight tonight, a company spokesman said yesterday. The spokesman for the line, which serves 45,000 to 50,000 daily commuters from northern New Jersey to New York, said the unions and the company had been actively negotiating. Representatives of the United Transportation Union and the Transportation Workers Union could not be reached for comment.

title: Ballet: Petit's Le Loup
description: Roland Petit's Le Loup has not been seen locally for 20 years, when it was danced by Mr. Petit's own Ballets de Paris. However, it has Maintained itself in a few repertories, including those of the Royal Danish Ballet and the National Ballet of Canada. It was the Canadians who brought it back to New York for one solitary performance at the Metropolitan Opera Houe osn Sunday.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: PAUL. WE LOVE YOU. WERE WORRIED PLEASE LET US KNOW YOU'RE O.K. MOM. DAD. BINGO.Advt.

title: Juror Says Dean Played Minor Role
description: A vice president of the First National Bank who served as a juror in the MitchellStans trial said yesterday the panel that acquitted the two former Cabinet officers Sunday considered that John W. Dean 3d had had a relatively minor part in this case.

title: Oilman Reported Freed
description: Victor E. Samuelson, the American oil executive for whom a $14.2million ransom was paid to Argentine guerrillas more than a month ago, was reported released near Buenos Aires yesterday. He was said to have boarded a plane for the United States. Page 14.

title: News Summary and Index TUESDAY APRIL 30, 1974
description: International

title: Gurney Indicted in Florida On State Election Charges
description: WASHINGTON, April 29Senator Edward J. Gurney, Republican of Florida, has been indicted by a county grand jury in Tallahassee, Fla., on charges of violating state election laws, an aide in the Senator's office here annouced today.

title: Silurians Elect Hagedorn
description: Charles G. Hagedorn, editor and publisher of Town & Village, has been elected president of the Society of the Silurians, an organization of newsmen and newswomen. Others elected at a weekend meeting included Paul Buiar of Paul Buiar Associates as first vice president; Marvin Sleeper, public relations director for the Hearst Corporation, as second vice president; Barnett Bildersee of Bildersee Public Relations as secretary; Ben Weberman, editor of American Banker, as treasurer, and Victor House as counsel.

title: News Summary and Index TUESDAY, APRIL, 30, 1974
description: The United States and the Soviet Union agreed, in a joint statement, to use their influence and coordinate their efforts to achieve a positive outcome of the Middle East negotiations. The statement, issued after a meeting in Geneva between Secretary of State Kissinger and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, was interpreted by Americans as a boost to Mr. Kissinger's efforts to bring about a troop separation between Syria and Israel. It also seemed to meet Moscoves insistence that the Soviet Union be permitted to share more fully in the negotiations, which have been dominated by the United States. [1:12.]

title: JOSEPHTHAL SETS CANTELLA MERGER
description: Cantella & Co., a Bostonbased brokerage firm, will be merged into Josephthal & Co., a member of the New York and American Stock exchanges, the firms announced jointly yesterday. Vincent Cantella, who is chairman of the board of governors of the Boston Stock Exchange and holds a seat on the New York Stock Exchange, will join. Josephthal as a general partner. At least for the present, Josephthal will continue to operate both its own office in Boston and the Cantella office.

title: Venezuela Plans to Nationalize IronOre Industry Led by U.S.
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, April 29 (AP)  Venezuela's new Government pledged today to forge an austerity economy despite unprecedented riches from oil, and unveiled plans to nationalize the United Statesdominated iron  ore industry along with a broad range of foreignowned companies.

title: Oilman Reported Freed
description: Victor E. Samuelson, the American oil executive for whom a $14.2million ransom was paid to Argentine guerrillas more than a month ago, was reported released near Buenos Aires yesterday. He was said to have boarded a plane for the United States, Page 14.

title: The Other News
description: International

title: Earthquake Rocks Egypt
description: CAIRO, April 29 (Reuters) An earthquake rocked a large area of Egypt, including Cairo, tonight but there were no repoets of casualties, the Middle East New Ageney said.

title: Wilson Names Kahn, a Cornell Dean, To Succeed Swidler as P.S.C. Chief
description: ALBANY, April 29Governor Wilson today appointed Dr. Alfred E. Kahn, dean of Cornell's College of Arts and Sciences, as the new chairman of the State Public Service Commission.

title: Walter Pate, Whose U.S. Teams Won Davis Cup 3 Times, Is Dead
description: Walter Lacey Pate, nonplaying captain of the United States Davis Cup tennis team before and after World War II, died Saturday in a nursing home in Louisville, Ky. He was 94 years old.

title: DISMISSAL OF CHARGE IS ASKED BY REINECKE
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 (UPI)Lieut. Gov. Ed Reinecke of California asked the Federal District Court today to dismiss an indictment against him, saying that the special Watergate prosecutor, Leon Jaworski, had promised not to prosecute him.

title: Notes on People
description: The White House announced yesterday that President Nixon would nominate. Stephen A. Nye, a San Francisco lawyer, to be a member of the Federal Trade Commission. The 37yearold Mr. Nye would fill the unexpired term of David S. Dennison Jr., which ends. Sept. 26, 1977: Mr. Dennison resigned last December . . . Also announced was Mr. Nixon's intention to nominate two directors of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting. They are Durward Belmont Varner, president of the University of Nebraska, to succeed Jack Valenti, whose term has expired, and Virginia Duncan, a producer and director at television station KQED in San Francisco, to succeed Thomas B. Curtis, who resigned a year ago.

title: Cargo Theft Is Target Of Forces in 15 Cities
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP)  Transportation and law enforcement officials in 15 metropolitan areas have formed task forces to try to reduce cargo theft, Attorney General William B. Saxbe announced today.

title: Herbert Hosking, 68, Editor And Consultant, Is Dead
description: Herbert Hosking, a management consultant and formed, editor, died Sunday in Mount Sinai Hospital Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 262 Central Park West.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Sadat Stresses Friendship For Both U.S. and Soviet
description: CAIRO, April 29 (UPI) Egypt's new Cabinet, announced last Thursday, was sworn in here today before President Anwar elSadat.

title: Bernadette Devlin Here
description: Bernadette Devlin McAliskey, a former member of the British Parliament from Ulster, said yesterday in a speech at Fordham University's Lincoln Center campus that the struggle for freedom in Northern Ireland could only be won by forcing unity among workingclass people regardless of religion. The only thing worse than a British lord and master is an Irish lord and master in his own country, Mrs. McAliskey said.

title: REPORT TO NATION
description: WASHINGTON, April 29President Nixon announced tonight that he would turn over to the House Judiciary Committee and make public tomorrow 1,200 pages of edited transcripts of Watergate conversations.

title: Wood, Field & Stream Notes on Aluminum, Tuna, Etc.
description: I have a tiny notebook bearing the legend Loose Ends, and its chaotic contents remind me of every tackle box I own.

title: 113 Inmates Cut Themselves
description: ST. LOUIS, April 29 (UPI)Thirteen white prisoners slasbed their arms and wrists with razor blades last night in, en apparent protest over integration in a cellblock with blacks.

title: COLLEGE DEGREES SEAN CHEAPENED
description: Dr. William J. McGill, the president of Columbia University, declared list night that an overexpansion of American higher education in recent years had led to a rapid deterioration in the quality of the fouryear degree at many public colleges and universities.

title: OvertheCounter Quotations
Rangers, Flyers Play Tonight; Cliches May Fly at Spectrum
description: The words have been spoken a hundred times, the same thought for the same situation. Last Sunday night Bill White of the Chicago Black Hawks repeated them after his team had dropped the fifth game of the series with the Boston Bruins to trail, 3 to 2.
